<h2 id='tocuniq3'>Book One</h2>

Book One

With the completion of the eighteen volumes of Explanations on Isaiah, I desired to move on to Ezekiel, which I had often promised to you, Eustochium, virgin of Christ, and to your holy mother, Paula, and to place the final hand, so to speak, on the work of prophecy. And behold, suddenly I received news of the deaths of Pammachius and Marcella, and of the siege of the city of Rome, and of the sleeping of many brothers and sisters. And so I was struck with consternation and amazement, so that for days and nights I could think of nothing else but the salvation of all. And I considered myself to be a captive in the captivity of the saints, and I could not open my mouth until I learned something more certain. While I am suspended between hope and despair, I torture myself with the misfortunes of others. But when the most shining light of all the earth was extinguished, or rather, when the head of the Roman empire was cut off: and, to speak more truly, the whole world perished in one city, I was speechless and humiliated, and I kept silent among the good, and my sorrow was renewed: my heart burned within me, and a fire blazed up in my meditation (Psalm 38:4); and I did not consider that saying to be neglected: Music is an inconvenient narration in mourning (Sirach 22:6). But because you insist on this incessantly and the wound gradually forms a scar: and the Scorpion is pressed between Enceladus and Porphyrion on the Trinacriae ground, and the Hydra with many heads has stopped hissing against us: and a time has been given, when we ought to not respond to the snares of heretics, but to devote ourselves to the interpretation of the Scriptures, I will tackle the prophet Ezekiel, whose difficulty is proven by the tradition of the Hebrews. Nam nisi quis apud eos aetatem sacerdotalis ministerii, id est, tricesimum annum impleverit, nec principia Geneseos, nec Canticum Canticorum, nec hujus voluminis exordium et finem legere permittitur, ut ad perfectam scientiam, et mysticos intellectus, plenum humanae naturae tempus accedat. Quod opus si per Domini misericordiam ad calcem usque perduxero, transibo ad Jeremiam, qui in Lamentationibus suis, sub typo Jerusalem quatuor plagas mundi, quadruplici plangit alphabeto.


<h2 id='tocuniq4'>(Cap. I.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 1—Verse 1) And it came to pass in the thirtieth year, in the fourth, in the fifth month. The thirtieth year is not, as most suppose, the age of the prophet, nor the year of Jubilee, which is the year of remission; but from the twelfth year of the reign of Josiah, king of Judah, when the Book of Deuteronomy was found in the temple of God, until the fifth year of the captivity of Joachin, surnamed Jechoniah, who was led captive to Babylon with his mother, and with Daniel and the three young men, and Ezekiel (which is the first captivity of the tribe of Judah) when the wrath of God was poured out upon Jerusalem (2 Kings 22; 2 Chronicles 34; 2 Kings 24). But according to the mystical interpretation, it is prefigured that the Lord and Savior, who came to be baptized at the age of thirty (Luke 3), which is the perfect age in man. Hence, in the book of Numbers according to the Hebrews, the priests begin to minister in the tabernacle not at the age of twenty-five, as in the Septuagint, but at the age of thirty (Numbers 4). As a sign of this, Joseph also preceded, when he distributed grain to the starving people in Egypt (Genesis 41), and John the Baptist came to the banks of the Jordan and preached the baptism of repentance (Luke 3). And what is written in the fifth, with the sentence pending, is understood to be in the fourth month. For immediately following is the fifth month. And to make this more clear, they added Seventy above.

<h2 id='tocuniq5'>(Vers. 2.)</h2>

(Verse 2) When I was among the captives by the river Chebar, the heavens were opened, and I saw visions of God in the fifth month. It was the fifth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin. I saw the people sitting by the rivers of Babylon, and David prophesied in the spirit: By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept (Psalm 137). Chebar, either the name of a river or, according to its interpretation, which means 'heavy', it signifies the Tigris and the Euphrates, and all the great and weighty rivers that are said to be in the land of the Chaldeans. And understand that the heavens are open not by the division of the firmament, but by the faith of the believer, because the celestial things are mysteries revealed to him. Therefore, even in the baptism of the Savior, when the Holy Spirit descended upon him in the form of a dove, we read of the heavens being opened (Matthew 3), and with them opened, the visions of God are revealed. Not just one vision, but many, as the Lord spoke through the prophet: 'I will multiply visions, and in the hands of the prophets I am likened.' (Hosea 12:10). These are the visions that the entire prophecy of Ezekiel weaves together. According to the Hebrews and other interpreters, the exile of Joachin is called more significantly, and not captivity, which the Septuagint translated. For he was not taken captive by the conquered city; but by his own will, he was led to Babylon. Therefore, let the first exile be called Joachin, that is, Jechoniah; but let the second or ultimate captivity be called Zedekiah.

<h2 id='tocuniq6'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3) The word of the Lord came to Ezekiel, the son of Buzi, the priest, in the land of the Chaldeans, by the river Chebar. And to Daniel and Ezekiel, who were in Babylon next to the rivers, the mysteries of the future are revealed over the waters, indeed in the purest waters, so that the power of baptism may be shown. Otherwise, even the Apostle Paul, when cleansed by Ananias in the Lord, his eyes being covered with scales beforehand, was freed from blindness (Acts 9). And in Genesis, those who were the first to live came forth from the waters. Also, it should be understood that in the thirtieth year of his age the Lord came to baptism: in the fourth month, which is called January among us, and is at the beginning of the year, except for the month of Nisan, in which the Passover is celebrated. For among the Eastern peoples, after the harvest and the pressing of grapes, when the tithes were brought to the temple, October was the first month, and January the fourth. On the fifth day of the month, the sign of baptism is added, in which the heavens were opened to Christ, and the day of Epiphany is held in high reverence until now, not as some think, the nativity in the flesh, for then he was hidden and did not appear. This is fitting for this period, when it was said: This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased (Matthew 3:17). Moreover, 'Buzi' is translated into our language as 'Ezekiel', strengthened by God, despised and contemptible. That which is so fitting to the Lord, that we may say the Creator of the world, who is the Father of the Savior, is rejected and despised by all heretics, who do not accept the old Testament. It is not surprising that the Lord is the strength of God: since He is the power and wisdom of God Himself.

And the hand of the Lord became upon him there. LXX: And the hand of the Lord became upon me. In order to see the visions of God and understand, we need the hand and strength of God upon us (I Cor. I). In whose hand and arm the people of Israel were brought forth from Egypt; a part of whose strength even the Magi understood, saying: It is the finger of God (Exod. VIII). And the Savior in the Gospel: But if I cast out devils by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God is come upon you (Matth. XII, 28)." } For in another Gospel it is written: But if I by the finger of God cast out devils (Luke 11:20).

<h2 id='tocuniq7'>(Vers. 4.)</h2>

(Verse 4.) And I saw, and behold, a whirlwind wind was coming from the North, and a great cloud, and fire enveloping, and brightness around it. And from its midst there was a kind of lightning, that is, from the midst of the fire. LXX: And I saw, and behold, a spirit pulling up (or lifting up) was coming from the North, and a great cloud in it, and shining fire, and brightness around it. And in its midst, there was a vision like lightning in the midst of fire, and brightness in it. In the consolation of the migrating people, and the revelation of God's will, the prophet sees the greatest vision. All the synagogues of the Jews are silent regarding its interpretation, claiming it to be beyond human understanding. And concerning this, and the construction of the temple, which is written about in the final prophecy, they attempt to undertake something. However, what we have received from our ancestors, and comparing spiritual things with spiritual in accordance with our limited understanding, we are able to speculate more than explain. We believe that kind-hearted and faithful readers will grant us forgiveness, as we beg for pardon for our audacity, or rather, our ignorance of faith, and that they will show favor rather than anger. Firstly, it must be known that the spirit that takes away or raises, which we have interpreted as the eagle, is understood by some as the wind of a whirlwind, and according to Symmachus and Theodotion as a blast and the spirit of a storm, received by some in a favorable direction, and by others in the opposite direction. The Hebrew word Rua is understood according to the quality of the places, either as spirit, or soul, or wind. Spirit, as in: Send forth your spirit, and they shall be created (Psalm 104:30). Soul: His spirit shall go forth, and he shall return into his earth (Psalm 145:4). Wind: Thou breaketh the ships of Tharsis with a violent wind (Psalm 47:8). And elsewhere: Fire and brimstone, and the spirit of storms, is the portion of their cup (Psalm 10:7). Those who understand the wind and the breath of the storm, feel this: the wrath and fury of God coming from the North, that is, from Nebuchadnezzar, and Jerusalem after six years from this vision shall be captured. In the fifth year of the reign of King Joachin, who was the fifth ruler in Jerusalem during the reign of Zedekiah, we read that after six years he was taken captive and brought to Babylon. Therefore, to those who dwelled near the river Chebar and willingly surrendered themselves to the king, it is revealed that they did well to obey the decree of God. In a short time, both the province of Judah and the city of Jerusalem were to be captured. And when a great cloud is described, let us understand it to portend the showers of inversions upon Judah, and the rains of collisions. And when fire appears wrapped around, it foreshows impending punishments and the evils of captivity. And the splendor surrounding it signifies the open judgments of God. But those who interpret it in the opposite way, namely, the good way, understand it to be the spirit that takes away or lifts up, the Holy Spirit, who takes away vices and sins from men, or lifts up those who are lying low to high things, and causes them to retreat from the very cold north wind, from which evils blaze up over all the earth (Sirach 43); and in Jeremiah, that terrible pot is kindled from the face of the north wind (Jeremiah 1). They also refer to the great cloud with respect to the person of Christ, who came into Egypt of this age upon a light cloud: and great is properly said in comparison to the lesser ones, namely, the prophets and all the apostles and saints, of whom it is written: And thy truth unto the clouds (Ps. 35:6); and: I will command the clouds that they rain no rain upon Israel (Isaiah 5:6); and elsewhere: The clouds are the dust of his feet (Nahum 1:3); and again: Clouds and darkness are round about him (Ps. 96:2). He also desires that the shining fire and its brightness be received in the same way as it is written: God is a consuming fire (Deuteronomy 4:24). He says that the Savior came to send fire upon the earth, and he desires to burn in us and in all who believe (Luke 12:49). Despite bringing terror and punishment to sinners, he still shines with splendor and is full of light and radiance. Therefore, he purifies us so that he may grant us greater joy in our purified state.


<h2 id='tocuniq8'>(Vers. 5.)</h2>

(Verse 5) And in the midst of it is the likeness of four living creatures, and this is their appearance: the likeness of a man is among them. And what follows, 'And there was a brightness in it,' should be noted. Unless the Scripture had added, saying: 'That is, from the midst of the fire,' we could have erred due to the ambiguity of the word, thinking that the appearance or vision was of lightning in the midst of the wind, or of a spirit. Therefore, it must be understood that in the midst of the fire and the torments of God, there is the likeness of lightning, which is more precious than gold and silver; so that after judgment and the torments, which seem sorrowful and harsh to those who endure them, the more precious brilliance of lightning appears, while God's providence governs all things, and what is thought to be punishment is actually a remedy.


<h2 id='tocuniq9'>(Vers. 6.)</h2>

(Verse 6.) And in the midst of it was the likeness of four living creatures, and this was their appearance: the likeness of a man in them. In the midst of it, though not explicitly stated, is understood to be electrum; but it is better understood as fire, which is light to believers and punishment to unbelievers. Therefore, in the midst of this fire was the likeness of four living creatures, a likeness but not in nature; and the four living creatures that are subsequently described as having a quadriform shape have one likeness of a man, so that all rational things in the world may be displayed. For God said, 'Let us make man in our image, after our likeness.' (Genesis 1)." } But the image and likeness of God is not a bodily form, but of the mind: described in the likeness of the true image of Christ, who is the image of the invisible God. These rational creatures revolve in four places, either because of the four cardinal points of the world, by which the globe is enclosed, or because of the four places, celestial, terrestrial, and infernal, and supercelestial, of which Paul the Apostle also speaks: That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those in heaven, on earth, and under the earth (Philippians 2:10). Of the three, there is Paul's testimony. Let us also consider the fourth. Praise the Lord, O heavens and you waters above the heavens, let them praise the name of the Lord (Psalm 148:5), and furthermore, other heavenly things are mentioned by the Apostle, and other things above the heavens (1 Corinthians 15).

<h2 id='tocuniq10'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7.) Four faces to one, and four wings to one, and their feet are straight feet, and the sole of their feet is like the sole of a calf's foot, and they sparkle like the appearance of burning bronze. And the hands of a man are under their wings on their four sides. LXX: And four faces to one, and four wings to one, and their legs are straight, and their feet are like the feet of a calf, and they sparkle like gleaming bronze, and their wings are light, and the hands of a man are under their wings on their four sides. We will endeavor to explain what the prophetic speech means to us, after briefly summarizing the opinions of each person, regarding the four animals, whose appearance resembled that of a human (only to the extent that they each had four faces, and four wings, and straight feet, and the sole of their foot was like the track of a calf's foot, or, as the Eagle interpreted it, round, which the Septuagint completely omitted), as well as the gleaming sparks of bronze, and their light feathers, which are not mentioned in Hebrew, and also the hand of a man under their wings divided into four parts, and the rest that the prophetic speech describes. Some believe that the four Gospels, which we also followed in the prologue of Matthew's commentary, are represented by the names of these animals: Matthew, because he described Jesus as a man: The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. They attribute the lion to Mark: The beginning of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God, as it is written in the prophet Isaiah: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare the way of the Lord: make his paths straight (Isaiah 40:3). Calves. In the Gospel according to Luke, which begins with the priesthood of Zacharias. Eagles, at the beginning of John, who, soaring to the heights, began: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. As for what seemed to us in the aforementioned work, we spoke in more detail in the Apocalypse of John (Chapter IV), where the species and names of these creatures are related to the four Gospels (also known as the Evangelists). We will attempt to explain how the description of all animals can be adapted to them, in its appropriate place. But others, who foolishly follow the wisdom of philosophers, believe that there are two hemispheres in the temple of the Cherubim, us and the Antipodes, as if humans were lying down and falling. Many, according to Plato, attribute rational soul, irascible soul, and concupiscible soul, which he calls λογικὸν, θυμικὸν, and ἐπιθυμητικὸν, to humans, lion, and calf: placing reason, cognition, mind, and understanding, as well as virtue and wisdom, in the citadel of the brain; and attributing ferocity, anger, and violence to the lion, which lies in the gall. Moreover, they locate desire, luxury, and the longing for all pleasures in the liver, that is, in the calf that clings to the earthly works. And they place forth, besides these three, a fourth, which is called by the Greeks συντήρησιν, which is the spark of conscience in the heart of Cain also, after he was expelled from paradise, which is not extinguished, and by which we, conquered by pleasures or by madness, and sometimes deceived by the appearance of reason itself, perceive that we sin. As the eagles are properly assigned, not mixing with three, but correcting the three that wander, which we sometimes read in the Scriptures called the spirit, who intercedes for us with unutterable groanings (Rom. VIII, 26). For no one knows the things of a man, except the spirit that is within him (I Cor. II, 11). And Paul also, writing to the Thessalonians, prays that they may be preserved whole in soul and body (I Thess. V). And yet this very conscience, according to what is written in the Proverbs: The wicked when he is come into the depth of sins, contemneth (Prov. XVIII, 13): we see to precipitate with some and to lose their place, who do not even have shame and modesty in their offenses, and deserve to hear: The face of a harlot is become to thee, thou hast (Alex. knowest) not been ashamed (Jerem. III, 3). Therefore God rules this team of horses like a charioteer, and restrains it in its unregulated steps, and makes it obedient, and compels it to obey his command. We will also discuss the nature of the soul, that is, of man, which the same philosophers call the microcosm. There are those who simply believe, according to the opinion of Hippocrates, that the four elements of the world are represented by four animals, from which all things are composed: fire, air, water, and earth. How these elements mix with each other, and how they appear to be joined together while remaining distinct, and how they touch each other, and how in one person they have four species and forms of animals, is not the purpose of this work. They also consider the four wheels that rise from earthly things to the heights, joined together with singular and four-formed animals, either as a mixture of the same elements or as the cycle of the four seasons, which is completed by twelve months, and the turning year, which has received its name from the fact that it always turns and returns to itself. Of these things, it has been elegantly said in one verse:

Spring, summer, autumn, winter, and months, and years. And it is said: There was a wheel in a wheel, they think it means year after year. About which another poet (Virgil, Georgics II):

And each year rolls on in its own footsteps. They also compare the likeness of the firmament to crystal, and they wish to understand this sky that we observe: under which four living creatures roll and pass. And they assume that the throne of sapphire-like color, and the man sitting above it in human likeness, describe the rule of everything and of all things under his feet, of the omnipotence of God; and to be said at the end: This is the vision of the likeness of the glory of God: through which, as through a certain picture and image, Providence is shown. And that the feet of animals are said to be straight, and the hoof of a calf, or round, to soar from earthly things to celestial ones, and with all angles removed, to follow roundness, which is the most beautiful of all figures. To indicate sparkling sparks, everything is full of light, and the hands of man under the feathers of both man himself, and the lion, and the calf, and the eagle: so that reason sustains everything, and lifts from earthly humility to celestial things. We can refer both to the Gospels and to all the things we have mentioned above. I remember hearing about four disturbances, which Cicero discusses at length in his Tusculan Disputations: joy, sorrow, desire, and fear. Of these, two are present and two are future, symbolized by four animals, about which Virgil briefly writes in Book VI of the Aeneid.

From these things they fear, desire, grieve, and rejoice: those things which owe their reason and power to God; and which are opposed, or rather imposed, by the four virtues, Prudence, Justice, Fortitude, and Temperance, so that they may be governed by their judgement. They completely ignored how these virtues are suited to the faces of a man, a lion, a calf, and an eagle. On these matters, the same philosopher and orator engages in a discussion in three books on duties addressed to his son. I have read a short discussion of a certain Catinus, whom the Syrians call 'subtle', that is, clever and ingenious. He believes that the order of the twelve tribes of the camp is described in the wilderness, toward the East and West, North and South, which are linked together by both charity and kinship, and that this is the wheel within a wheel that is led by the spirit and protected by a cloud in the desert, and illuminated by a pillar of fire at night; and they do not return to Egypt, but always hasten to go to the promised land. But in the middle, electricity is interpreted as the Holy of Holies, and the face of a man represents the whole of Israel; the lion represents the royal scepter of Judah; the calf represents the priestly and Levitical tribe. In addition to these, there is the face of an eagle, symbolizing God's vengeance and judgment, looking down from heaven on everything, and ready to tear apart the sinner, as mentioned in Hosea: 'Like an eagle over the house of God' (Hosea VIII, 12), that is, the temple. And in this same chapter (17), the great eagle with great wings and claws, which has the ability to enter into Lebanon, is understood to be Nebuchadnezzar, who even now signifies that he is about to come, and to sit as a charioteer on such a chariot of God, and to give commands, whether to do or not to do. But this, he says, is said to the people who are in Babylon, that if they submit their necks to God and obey His commands, they will once again deserve His help and regain the land they had lost.


<h2 id='tocuniq11'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Vers. 8, 9.) And they had wings, and the wings were joined one to another: they returned not when they went, but every one went straight forward. The Gospels are joined to one another and stick together, and they fly to and fro throughout the whole world; they have no end of their flight, nor are they ever overcome and retreat, but always they go forward to further places. And Paul says: Forgetting what lies behind and straining forward to what lies ahead (Philippians III, 13). We can say the same about the virtues of the soul, and about the flight of time, and the mixture of elements, that by leaving the past behind, they always hasten towards the former things. And that time slips away and flees is demonstrated in a short verse (Virgil, Georgics III).

But time flies meanwhile, it flies irreparably. And in a lyric poem (Horace. Carm. od. 14):

Alas, alas, swift years slip away, O Posthumus, Posthumus!

<h2 id='tocuniq12'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) The likeness of their faces was that of a man, and the face of a lion on the right side of the four, and the face of an ox on the left side of the four, and the face of an eagle above the four. The faces represent the beginnings of the Gospels, in which the face of a man and a lion, that is, the birth of Christ, and the voice of prophets thundering in the wilderness, hold the right side. But the face of an ox, that is, of sacrifices and the priests of the Jews, is on the left side, which has been abolished and passed on to the spiritual priesthood, of which it was said: You are a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek (Psalm 110:4); so that all things may be united in it and considered as one body. But the eagle, which is both a symbol of birth and a symbol of prophecy, which is fulfilled by the coming of the Lord, and a symbol of the priesthood that has passed, 14 and beyond all these things, refers to the spiritual birth, how the Father is in the Son, and the Son in the Father. Concerning which it is rightly said: Who shall declare his generation? (Isaiah 53:8) These are, according to the Apocalypse (Chapter 4), as we have already said, the four living creatures full of eyes before and behind, one of which is like a lion, and the second like a calf, and the third has a face like a human, and the fourth is like a flying eagle. There they are said to have six wings: two covering their faces, two covering their feet, and two for flying. And they never cease saying day and night: Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty, who was, and is, and is to come (Rev. 4:8).

<h2 id='tocuniq13'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11) And their faces and their wings were extended above, two wings of each were joined together, and two covered their bodies. And above we said that the Gospels and the times, and all rational creatures, and the four virtues are joined to each other, so that whoever lacks one lacks them all. And that the two wings are extended and elevate themselves upward, signifies heavenly preaching, and all things tending towards the majesty of God. But of the two things by which bodies are covered, human knowledge is excluded, and perfect intuition is not provided, as the Apostle says: In part we know, and in part we prophesy. But when what is perfect comes, those things that are in part will be destroyed (I Cor. XIII, 9)." }

<h2 id='tocuniq14'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(Verse 12.) And each one walked in front of his own face. Where the impulse of the spirit was, there they walked, and they did not turn back when they walked. He who holds the handle of the plow should not look back (Luke 9:62), nor imitate Lot's wife (Genesis 19), lest he fall into the punishment of Deuteronomy (Chapter 19) and perish in the incurable disease, like Eli, who had offended God with the vice of his sons (2 Kings 4). How much more do the four animals, which were full of light and feathers, which follow the preceding Holy Spirit, fly through the world like this, and raise themselves to the heights to protect their bodies with the wings of history, and not give us a fuller view? But what is said secondly: They did not turn back when they advanced, indicates the sacrament of both instruments, which quickly advance in these four creatures, both Law and Gospel for the future; and they never receive a backward movement.

<h2 id='tocuniq15'>(Vers. 13, 14.)</h2>

(Verse 13, 14.) And the likeness of the living creatures was like burning coals of fire, and like the appearance of torches. This was the vision that was running among the living creatures, the brightness of the fire, and lightning coming out of the fire. And the living creatures were going and returning in the likeness of a flashing lightning. LXX: And in the midst of the living creatures was the vision, like burning coals of fire, like the appearance of torches running among the living creatures; and the brightness of the fire, and lightning was coming out of the fire like a flash. And what follows: And the animals were running and returning like a species of gazelle, which is added from Theodotion's edition to the Septuagint: so as not to seem to say something contrary to the two previous statements of the prophet, they thought that what they believed to be contradictory, that is, both the animals were running and returning, should be omitted, so as not to cause scandal to the reader. But it is better to translate in divine books what has been said, even if you do not understand why it has been said, than to remove what you do not know. Otherwise, many other things which are ineffable and the human mind cannot comprehend will be erased by this license. However, we say this, just as it is written in the same place in Proverbs: 'Do not answer a fool according to his folly, lest you be like him' (Prov. 26:4); and then it is stated what seems to be contradictory to us: 'Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he seem wise in his own eyes' (Prov. 26:5); and both statements agree in accordance with the difference in times and persons, as the fool is despised because he does not accept wisdom; and foolish pride is shaken off by other folly, just as the Apostle says: 'I have become a fool; you compelled me' (2 Cor. 12:11); so in this place we should seek why it was said above for the second time: 'Animals did not turn back when they walked, but now, they ran and turned back.' And if a question did not ensue, it would be like a flashing lightning, which in Hebrew is called Bezec, and interpreted by Symmachus as the appearance of a lightning beam. Therefore, just as the ether flashes with frequent fires and lightning bolts dart and return in the blink of an eye, without losing their source and, so to speak, the origin of fire and material: so too these animals, proceeding with undisturbed pace, hasten to their former places. But if, however, those who have undertaken it find anything hindered, they do not so much retreat as they contract themselves, to be extended again and to provide the light that they had momentarily hidden, in order to give food to the slaves at their proper time, neither to give holy things to the dogs, nor to throw pearls before swine (Matthew 7). Hence Paul also says: I have given you milk to drink, not solid food, for you were not yet able to receive it (1 Corinthians 3:2). And the election of Judas and the anointing of Saul do not argue that God is ignorant of the future, but they show that He is the judge of present things (Matthew 10). And it is commanded to the Apostles, that if they perceive an unworthy house by greeting, they should first shake off the dust from their feet; and let the peace which they gave to the house return to them. But the coals of a burning fire and the lamps running amidst the animals, are interpreted from that place of Isaiah: And fire shall devour the substance as hay, and I will sanctify them in a burning fire (Isaiah 5:24). And of them it is also written elsewhere: Coals shall fall upon them (Psalm 139:11). And against deceitful lips, in another psalm it is said: What can be given to you, or what can be added to you, to a deceitful tongue? The sharp arrows of the mighty, with coals of desolation (Psalm 119:3-4). And in another place: You have coals of fire, you will sit on them; they will be a help to you (Isaiah 47:14). Whenever we look at any creature, the knowledge of God shines forth, as the Creator is recognized from the creatures. And from the midst of animals, the splendor of fire and lightning goes forth. For if you apply yourself to the Gospels, in the midst of simple words and humble history, you will find the sacraments of the Holy Spirit.

<h2 id='tocuniq16'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 and following) And as I looked at the animals, there appeared a wheel on the earth beside the animals, having four faces. And the appearance of the wheels and their work was like the vision of the sea. And there was one likeness for the four of them, and the appearance and work of each was like a wheel within a wheel. As they went, they went in the four directions and did not turn when they walked. The wheels also had stature and height and a fearsome appearance, and the whole body was full of eyes all around the four of them. LXX: And I saw, and behold, one wheel upon the earth following four animals. And the appearance of the wheels and their workmanship was like the color of beryl. And the likeness of the four was their appearance: and their work was as a wheel in the middle of a wheel. They went every one straight forward: whither the impulse of the spirit was to go, thither they went: and they turned not when they went. And their backs, and their height, and the appearance of them was terrible. And I saw, and I saw, and their backs were full of eyes, round about the four wheels. A single wheel appeared on the earth, which, divided into four, had as many faces as animals followed. And the resemblance of the four wheels to the four animals was so great that the single wheel was truly believed. And their work and structure were like a vision of beryl, which we turn into the sea. The eagle placed the jacinth; which stone resembles the sky. And their appearance was like a wheel within a wheel, so that you would believe not one wheel, but another joined to it. They were going in four directions and were not being dragged or turned back. For how could they turn back when they were following animals that always tend towards what is in front of them? Moreover, the size of the wheels and their height was such that it was a marvel to those who saw it. And the whole body and backs were filled with light all around, so that you could not see any limbs that did not have the light of eyes: like the stories of the poets describe Argus to have been with a hundred or many eyes, which Juno turned into a peacock because of his careless guarding, so that what is a marvel of the Creator God would be a condemnation of adultery without punishment. All the celestial and terrestrial things, and whatever falls under human understanding, are turned by the wheels of the Sun. The Moon runs the annual circle of the Sun through each month. Lucifer himself, who is the evening star, while he shines red towards the East and the West, tempers the darkness of the night with a small light and completes the same course every two years. And the four stars called wandering also move, and all that shines in the sky, as well as the varieties of crops, trees, and herbs, run their course in four seasons on their own wheels, and we see nothing that has not been before. The spirit moves in a gyrating motion, and it returns to its own circles. All the streams flow into the sea, yet the sea is not filled (Eccles. I, 6, 7). Why? Because they return to their sources from the abyssal depths. And as for the Gospels, that is, the four living creatures that breathe and live, if anyone considers their course and rotation, in a short time they will see that the world is completed by the apostolic teaching. The wheel within a wheel, or the joining of the two Testaments, signifies the ladder of Jacob (Gen. XXVIII), the tongs of Isaiah (Isai. VI), and the double-edged sword. It also represents the harmonious Gospels, whose course and structure tend towards heaven, touch slightly on earth, and always hasten towards the heights." } Concerning which, it is said elsewhere: 'Holy stones roll on the earth' (Zach. IX, 16); from which the celestial Jerusalem is built. I think this signifies the same thing as that which is sung in the psalm: 'The voice of your thunder in a wheel' (Psal. LXXVI, 19). And elsewhere: 'Which inflames the wheel of birth' (Jac. III, 6). The meaning of these testimonies in their respective places is not of this time. However, the whole body and backs full of eyes will approve, who will see that there is nothing in the Gospels that does not shine with light and illuminate the world with its brightness, so that even those things that are considered small and insignificant may shine with the majesty of the Holy Spirit.


<h2 id='tocuniq17'>(Vers. 19 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 19 and following) And as the animals walked, the wheels beside them also moved. And when the animals were lifted up from the ground, the wheels were lifted up at the same time. Wherever the spirit went, the wheels went there too, for the spirit of life was in the wheels. As the animals moved, the wheels moved; when the animals stood still, the wheels stood still; and when the animals were lifted up from the ground, the wheels followed them. For the spirit of life was in the wheels. Four animals followed the spirit, and a cloud that was in the spirit. And again, the wheels were lifted up from the earth, not the animals, but the spirit followed, to show their own will: because the spirit of life was in the wheels. Three things are indicated both in the animals and in the wheels together, when they stood, when they walked, when they were lifted up, which both the animals and the wheels did in common. For, animals standing still were not able to walk on wheels, nor were animals walking on the ground able to elevate themselves on wheels, but there was one action, one rest, one journey, and one elevation. And it is said secondly, because the spirit of life was in the wheels: so that we may not at all think of the wheels as vessels, which we see in the wagons of carts and chariots, but as living beings, indeed above living beings. For the animal-like man does not perceive those things that are spirits. Therefore, these wheels, in which the spirit of life was, make all things in order and measure, and they have harmony with animals, following them, and through them, the Holy Spirit; indeed, having skipped the middle, they enjoy the companionship of the Holy Spirit. All these things, according to the earlier understanding, a wise reader will be able to fit together with various interpretations.

<h2 id='tocuniq18'>(Vers. 22 seqq.)</h2>

(Verses 22 and following) And the likeness above the heads of the living creatures was like the appearance of a crystal terrible to behold, and they spread out their wings above, each creature having two wings that covered their bodies, and the other wings were similarly covered. And I heard the sound of their wings, like the sound of many waters, like the sound of the Almighty God. When they walked, it was like the sound of a multitude, like the sound of an army camp; and when they stood still, their wings were lowered. For when a voice came above the firmament that was over their heads, they stood and let down their wings. And above the firmament that was over their heads, there appeared the likeness of a sapphire stone, as the likeness of a throne. And upon the likeness of the throne, there was the likeness as the appearance of a man above it. Wherever the spirit went, the creatures went in the direction that the spirit was moving. The creatures' wings were straight and they made a loud noise, like the sound of a voice from the Highest. The creatures moved in their formations and seemed powerful, which in Hebrew is called 'Saddai'. Many things have been omitted in this and other chapters by them, which they have postponed to include due to their length. However, what we have interpreted more clearly, one to another: each covered their body with two wings, and the other also covered their body similarly, for which it is written in Hebrew, a woman to her sister, a man covered his body with two wings, and a man also covered his body similarly: therefore, after the woman, the man is placed in the same person, so that we do not think of gender in heavenly beings: since in one and the same according to Hebrew custom, both the man and the woman are called the same. However, it seems that above there are 24 animals and an equal number of wheels, a likeness of the firmament, which we call the sky, having the appearance of crystal, which is very pure, and is said to congeal from clean and shining waters with excessive cold: just as water is also congealed by frost and is called κρύσταλλος in the Greek language. It was fitting, however, that in the higher things there should be surpassing purity, which protects all things, that is, the rational and wise virtues, and the course of the four seasons, and the regions of the world, and the order of all things, and the preaching of the Gospel, which is understood in part and veiled in part. And the voice of the wings of flying creatures is heard, like the sound of many waters, which, according to the Apocalypse of John (Chap. XVII), signifies peoples, and gradually progressing, is said to be like the voice of armies, and like the voice of the Most High God, which is called in Hebrew Saddai, and according to the Septuagint, the voice of the Word; so that we may believe that the voice of the Son of God is in all that is proclaimed in the world. And while the animals stood, their wings were lowered. For they could not bear the resounding voice of Almighty God in the heavens, but they stood and marveled; and in their silence, they demonstrated the power of God, who sat upon the firmament. The firmament below had the appearance of crystal, while the firmament above appeared like a sapphire stone. The sapphire stone resembled a throne, and the one sitting on the throne resembled a human. From this, we understand that the firmament, crystal, sapphire, and human are shown in similarity, not in truth. However, many testimonies teach us to understand the human as God the Father. Among these is the one in the Gospel: a certain man planted a vineyard and leased it to farmers (Matthew XXI, 33). And a little later: He sent servants and above all his son (Ibid., 37). Again: A certain man made a marriage for his son (Matth. XXII, 2). Not that the son is excluded from the kingdom, about which Isaiah wrote: I saw the Lord sitting on a high and exalted throne (Isai. VI, 1). And John said: This, he said, Isaiah said, when he saw the glory of the Son of God (Joan. XII, 41); but that he reigns in the Father and the Son. For all things are the Son's of the Father, who is the image of the invisible Father (Coloss. I, 15). For also in Daniel, God the Father is shown sitting (Dan. VII), and the Son of Man is offered to Him, that He may receive the kingdom. And in the Apocalypse of John, the same things are written about the Son (Apoc. III, VII). And in the battle of the first martyr Stephen, He is seen standing at the right hand of the Father. Concerning whom it is sung in the psalm: The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right hand. I will make your enemies a footstool for your feet (Psalm 110:1). Just as the purest and brightest things are shown in the heavenly realms, which illuminate our bodily eyes, so in the sapphire, that is, in the throne of God, and above the firmament that we understand as the sky, the hidden and mysterious and incomprehensible mysteries of God are revealed: He made darkness his hiding place (Psalm 18:11), appearing in a cloud and in darkness. And it is written in Exodus: And under the feet of God was like the work of sapphire stone, and as the appearance of the clearest sky (Exod. XXIV, 10). And thus the bride describes the beauty of the bridegroom in the Song of Songs: His belly is like a ivory tablet on a sapphire stone (Cant. V, 14). And in the Book of Revelation, the first foundation is written as jasper, the second as sapphire (Apoc. XXI). And in the breastplate of the high priest, in the order and arrangement of each stone, the second order has carbuncle, sapphire, and jasper (Exod. XXVIII). We have spoken about these things to some extent in the Explanations of Isaiah, concerning the stones.

<h2 id='tocuniq19'>(Vers. 27, 28.)</h2>

(Verse 27, 28.) And I saw a resemblance of amber, like the appearance of fire within it all around, from its loins and upward; and from its loins downward, I saw a resemblance of shining fire all around, like the appearance of a rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day. This was the appearance of the splendor all around. This was the vision of the likeness of the glory of the Lord. The likeness of a man sat upon the likeness of a throne, which had the likeness of a sapphire stone, and it was likened to amber from its loins and upward. The electrum, both inside and outside, had the appearance of fire. But a shining fire was present around the loins and below, to show that the things above the loins, where sensation and reason are located, do not need fire or flames, but rather the most precious and pure metal. But the things below the loins, where copulation, generation, and the incitement of vices occur, need the purifying flames, so that once they have been cleansed, they can have a resemblance to a rainbow, commonly called Iris, which is in the cloud during a rainy day. For indeed Iris, which is called rainbow in the Holy Scripture, and in the Apocalypse of John is also called by the same name Iris (Apoc. IV), can only appear in rain and a watery cloud, of various and most beautiful colors, gradually transitioning into others. Hence also the poet (Virgil, Aeneid IV).

A thousand lights snatch various colors. But following the custom of the common people, the same poet says: 'When he drinks, he says, there is a rainbow.' From this he signifies that the rainbow never appears unless in the cloud and in the waters. This rainbow is a sign of God's mercy and covenant that he made with humans: that when it appears in the cloud, we know, according to the example of antiquity, that we will never again be destroyed by a flood (Genesis IX). From this it is shown that after punishments and penances, and the purging of sins, there will be future mercy, only for those who deserve to see God reigning. Where it is said: Here was the appearance of splendor in a circle. In the circle of God, or of the throne, or of all that was seen. And this is the vision of the glory of the likeness of God: not that he saw the glory of the Lord, but the likeness of his glory. And all this vision is: a spirit lifting up, and a great cloud, and four living creatures, and as many wheels following the creatures, and a spirit, which deserved to be under the firmament of God. After they were lifted up, they heard a voice like many waters, and like the sublime word of God, and the voice of camps and armies, they spread their wings and showed their astonishment in silence. And there appeared one sitting on the likeness of sapphire, like the likeness of a man, who had the appearance of electrum from his loins upward, and the appearance of fire from his loins downward in a circuit. After this, a sign of mercy is given, like the appearance of a rainbow when it is in the cloud on a rainy day. We have already spoken at length about this vision because it is both obscure and variously explained by many. In what follows, as much as possible without harming the senses, we will strive for brevity due to the magnitude of the volume.

<h2 id='tocuniq20'>(Cap. II.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 2, Verse 1) 23 And I saw, and fell upon my face, and heard the voice of him that spake. He was not lifted up by the greatness of the visions, but by the consciousness of human frailty he fell on his face. Hence, the apostle Paul, after the ascension into heaven and paradise, and the hearing of unspeakable words, says that a messenger of Satan was given to him, to buffet him, lest he be exalted. And Abraham fell upon his face after hearing the words of God. And yet, because he had fallen not due to sin but due to humility, he is lifted up by the Lord and commanded to hear his words (Genesis 17). It should also be known that to fall on one's face is different from falling backward. Abraham, after hearing about the birth of Isaac, fell on his face and laughed (1 Samuel 4). However, Eli, who had sinned, fell backward. And it is written about Dan in Genesis: Let Dan be a serpent on the path, biting the horse's heel, and let the rider fall backward, awaiting the salvation of God (Genesis 49:17-18). For because he had fallen off the horse to be bitten by a snake, he awaits the coming of the Savior. And in the Gospel according to John, those who had come to apprehend the Lord, after he answered: I am, they fell backward to the ground (John 18:6); not enduring his statement, who had said to Moses: Go, say to the children of Israel: He who is, has sent me to you (Exodus 3:14).

And he said to me: Son of man, stand on your feet, and I will speak to you ((Vulg. with you)). He could not hear the word of God while lying down, but he hears it with Moses: But you stand here with me (Exodus XXXIV, 2). Daniel also mentions that this happened to him (Daniel X).

<h2 id='tocuniq21'>(Vers. 2.)</h2>

(Version 2.) And the spirit entered into me, after he had spoken to me, and set me upon my feet. And I heard him speaking to me, and saying: Son of man. LXX: And the spirit came to me, and took me, and lifted me up, and set me upon my feet: and I heard him speaking to me, and he said to me: Son of man. The divine word had commanded the prophet and had ordered: Stand on your feet (Psalm XXXIX, 3); but he could not stand without the help of God and the coming of the Holy Spirit: therefore, he enters into him, or takes and raises him up, so that he may stand firmly and be able to say: He has set my feet upon a rock (Ephesians VI, 14). And we read of no sinner standing, but it is said to the saints: Stand therefore with your loins girt. However, that sinner deserves to hear what is written in Deuteronomy 24: There shall be no firmness in the tread of your foot. It is frequently said to Ezekiel: Son of man, and rarely to Daniel: both of whom in his person said: But the Son of man has nowhere to lay his head, he consoles the captive people and brings them back to repentance.


<h2 id='tocuniq22'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) I send you to the sons of Israel, to the apostate nations who have turned away from me. They and their fathers have transgressed my covenant up to this day. They are called not the people of God Israel, but the apostate nations, those who have departed from the Lord, not only the fathers, but also the sons. And it is not that the sons should be held accountable for the sins of the fathers; but rather, that the impiety should be equal among both fathers and sons. Furthermore, what the LXX translated, provoking and turning me to bitterness, signifies that our sins cause the kind and gentle nature of God to change into bitterness." } For as it is said to the saints, 'Taste and see that the Lord is sweet' (Psalm 33:9); so sinners feel him as bitter. Therefore, the Apostle relates the goodness and severity of God towards the saints and sinners (Romans 21). And of the sinners who were lying down, it is written: 'The Lord raises up those who are cast down, the Lord loves the just, the Lord loosens the bound' (Psalm 145:8). Indeed, rewards are promised to the standing saints.


<h2 id='tocuniq23'>(Vers. 4.)</h2>

(Verse 4.) And they are children with a hardened face and an unyielding heart, to whom I am sending you. This is not found in the Septuagint. It is of great mercy to send God to such people and not to despair of their salvation, and it is a prophetic confidence that he does not fear to go to such people. But we must understand the phrase 'hardened heart' and 'hardened face' according to what is said to sinners: 'Your neck is an iron sinew, and your brow is bronze.' (Isaiah 48:6) And those who are accused of having a heart of stone in their subsequent actions, because God says He will tear it out and replace it with a fleshy one, so that through its softness it may embrace God's commandments.

<h2 id='tocuniq24'>(Vers. 5.)</h2>

(Verse 5.) And you shall say to them: Thus says the Lord God: If perhaps they will hear, and if perhaps they will be silent: for the house is provoking, and they shall know that there has been a prophet among them. Something similar is written in Jeremiah: If perhaps they will hear and repent (Jer. XXVI, 3). And in the Gospel: Perhaps they will fear my son (Matth. XXI, 37). God speaks these things with a doubting affection, in order to show the free will of man, so that the foreknowledge of future evil or good does not make immutable what God knows will happen in the future." } For it is not because he knows what is going to happen, that it is necessary for us to do what he has foreseen: but rather, because we are going to do it by our own will, he knows the future as if he were God.

<h2 id='tocuniq25'>(Vers. 6.)</h2>

(Verse 6) So you, son of man, do not fear them, nor be afraid of their words, for they are unbelievers and subverters with you. LXX: And you, son of man, do not fear them, nor be dismayed by their presence, for they are insane and will gather against you all around. Though they may have stiff necks and rebellious hearts, my commands are stronger. And do not think that you will be deceived if you are sent to those who will not listen to you. Behold, I forewarn you that they will be mad and gather against you and surround you, leaving you no escape. But they will do this because they are unbelievers and despise the commands of God.

And you dwell with scorpions. Do not fear their words, and do not dread their faces, for their home is vexing. They are able to strike, to pierce with a curved wound, and with a barbed sting, so that the same blow opens both skin and disperses poison. Each one is given a name according to their character. You write and are called Pharisees: Brood of vipers (Matthew 23:33). And of Herod, who was a deceiver: Go and tell that fox (Luke 13:32). And false prophets are compared to foxes in this same Prophet. And now they are said to be scorpions with an untamed heart. Hence we read in the Gospel: All who came before me were thieves and robbers, and the sheep did not listen to them (John 10:8). And how did the lost sheep of the house of Israel listen to their adversaries? From this it is shown that those who listened lost the name of sheep and took on other names, so that they did not perish like sheep, but like vipers, foxes, and scorpions.


<h2 id='tocuniq26'>(Vers. 7, 8.)</h2>

(Vers. 7, 8.) And you shall speak my words to them: perhaps they may hear and fear, or be silent, because they are rebellious. But you, son of man, listen to what I speak to you. Therefore, there should be no ceasing, even though those we speak to are wicked; on the contrary, according to the Apostle (II Tim. IV), let us preach the word of God opportune, importune, for it is possible that both the hardened may be corrected to gentleness, and the obedient, with a changed will, may not listen.


Do not be exasperating, just as a house is exasperating. Once we said to put on the bitterness of Septuagint, whether irritation or exasperation. Therefore, what he says is this: You should not imitate those whom you are sent to correct, lest you deserve a similar sin and punishment.

Open your mouth, and eat what I give you. Make yourself worthy, he says, for my speeches, and receive spiritual food, so that as it is said in the Gospel: He who has ears to hear, let him hear (Luke 8:8); and here let it be said: He who has an open mouth for eating, let him eat. Hence the Lord speaks to the Psalmist: Open your mouth, and I will fill it (Psalm 80:11). And he responded: I have opened my mouth, and I have drawn in the spirit (Psalm 118:131). And the apostle Paul, who had in himself the treasures of wisdom and knowledge, and in whom Christ the Lord spoke, writes to the Corinthians: My mouth is open to you, oh Corinthians (II Cor. VI, 11). And Matthew reports about the Savior: Opening his mouth, he taught the disciples (Matt. V, 2).

And I saw, and behold a hand sent to me. For the hand that is sent, the Seventy translated it as extended. That which is sent and extended is for those who receive benefits. But it is contracted by those to whom it speaks through the Prophet: 'Has the hand of the Lord been shortened and contracted?' (Isaiah 50:2) And in the Psalm: 'Why do you withdraw your hand and your right hand from the midst of your bosom until the end?' (Psalm 73:11) Finally, He extends His wings in His passion, receives His disciples, and carries them on His shoulders, and He says: 'All day long I have stretched out My hands to a disobedient and gainsaying people' (Isaiah 65:2), that He may gather the children of Israel, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings; and by the extension of Moses's hands, Israel overcomes Amalek (Exodus 17).


<h2 id='tocuniq27'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9) In which was wrapped a book, and He spread it out before me, and it was written on the inside and on the outside: there were written in it lamentations, and a song, and woe. And He said to me: Son of man, whatever you find, eat it. Concerning the wrapped book, the seventy chapters of the book were translated. In the hand of the Lord, who was sitting on the throne, what was sent and extended. Of whom it is also said in the Psalms: It is written about me in the chapter of the book (Psalm 39:8). Chapter 27, let us understand the beginning. This book, wrapped and sealed, written inside and outside, or before and after, was of such difficulty that no one could open it and read it, neither in heaven, nor on earth, nor under the earth, except the lion of the tribe of Judah, the root of David and Jesse, whom John in the Apocalypse said had devoured himself (Rev. 5), not all of it, but in a chapter, that is, in the beginning. For it is impossible that human nature should devour the whole treasure of this book. And the prophet spread it out before them and presented it to be read and known, for it is said in Isaiah that it is signed to a people not redeeming (Isa. XXIX). Even to this day, the veil is placed over the Jews in the old Testament. And it was written before and behind; about the future and the past. Or certainly on the surface, in the letter of history, inside, in spiritual understanding, of which the Psalmist also says: All the glory of the king's daughter is within (Psal. XLIV, 14). And in it there were both inward and outward lamentations, and song, and woe. Lamentations, concerning those who are called to repentance, just as Samuel, Apostle Paul, mourned and lamented for Saul and the Corinthians, whom they desired to save (2 Chronicles 16; 2 Corinthians 12). Song about those who are worthy of God's testimony, and to whom the Psalmist commands: Sing to the Lord a new song (Psalm 95 and 97, 1). But woe to those who are deeply despairing and when they come into the depths of sin, they despise (Prov. XVIII).

<h2 id='tocuniq28'>(Cap. III.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 3, Verse 1) Eat this scroll, and go ((Vulg. going)), speak to the children ((Vulg. to the children)) of Israel. Unless we eat the open scroll beforehand, we cannot teach the children of Israel. Finally, even David, after he himself received mercy, said: I will teach, he said, the wicked your ways, and the ungodly will turn to you (Psalm 50, 15).

<h2 id='tocuniq29'>(Vers. 2.)</h2>

(Ver. 2.) And I opened my mouth, and he fed me with that scroll. And he said to me: Son of man. I, he said, opened my mouth, because I was told: Open your mouth, and eat. And, with my mouth open, the Lord provided food; so that the beginnings of desire may be in us, and we may attain the perfection of blessedness from the Lord. For it is not of the one willing or of the one running, but of the merciful God (Rom. IX, 16). Yet both the willing and the running are of our own will. For it is opened, they translated the Septuagint, he opened, so that 28 God is understood: for he opened the mouth of the prophet, and fed him.

<h2 id='tocuniq30'>(Vers 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) Your stomach will eat; and your bowels will be filled with that volume which I give to you. LXX: Your mouth will eat, and your stomach will be filled with that chapter given to you. The beginning of the lesson, and the simple history, is the essence of this volume. But when we have stored the book of the Lord in the treasure of our memory through constant meditation, our spiritual stomach is filled, and our bowels are satisfied, so that we may have, with the Apostle Paul, the bowels of mercy (Colossians 3), and that stomach may be filled of which Jeremiah speaks: My bowels, my bowels, I am pained at my very heart (Jeremiah 4:19).


And I ate it, and it was in my mouth like sweet honey. David also says: How sweet are your words to my throat, sweeter than honey to my mouth (Psalms 118:103). And elsewhere: The judgments of the Lord are true, desired more than gold and precious stones; and sweeter than honey and the honeycomb (Psalms 19:10, 11). And Samson found honeycomb in the mouth of a lion (Judges 14); and after the resurrection, the Lord ate a piece of broiled fish and honeycomb (Luke 24). And in Proverbs it is said about the bee, even though there are no Hebrew examples of this: Go to the bee, and learn how industrious it is, and how it makes its work pure: by which the labor of kings and the foolish is misused for their own health (Prov. VI, 8, sec. LXX): this is what Moses and the prophets, and the evangelists, and the apostles have done; so that whoever becomes a king, whose heart is in the hand of God, may enjoy sweet foods. But whoever is simple and without the cunning of the serpent has the innocence of doves, let them believe with simple faith and be saved: because everywhere there are traps, and often the devil transforms himself into an angel of light (II Cor. II): and honey drips from the lips of a harlot woman, promising sweetness so that she may spread poison (Prov. V).


<h2 id='tocuniq31'>(Vers. 5.)</h2>

(Verse 5.) And he said to me: Son of man, go and enter (in the Vulgate it is not 'and enter') into the house of Israel, and speak my words to them. It is said to him: Go and enter into the house of Israel, it is shown that he was not with the sinful people; although he seemed to dwell in the same place on the banks of the river Chebar. For it is written: And I was in the midst of the migration next to the river Chebar. Indeed, the conversation of the prophet was separate, and he was offended by the sight of the wicked. Moses did the same thing (Exodus 33) when he pitched the tabernacle far away from the camp, and when he had entered it, the pillar of cloud would descend and stand at the entrance of the tabernacle.

<h2 id='tocuniq32'>(Vers. 5, 6.)</h2>

(Verses 5, 6) For you are not being sent to the people of profound speech and difficult (Vulgate: unknown) language, to the house of Israel, nor to many peoples who speak an unknown language, whose speech you cannot understand. And if I were to send you to them, they would listen to you. But because they do not want to come to you, you go to them. For they do not have need of a doctor who is well, but of one who is sick (Luke 5:31). And you cannot say: I cannot speak to them, because their language is different, and we are barbarians to each other, and we cannot understand each other's speech. What shall I speak about the united people? If I were to send you to different nations, nonetheless my authority and power would conquer all difficulty. And I wish that the time were at hand, when I am about to send my apostles to all nations, so that I may give thanks for languages, and that they may preach and subdue the whole world under my yoke of one faith, from the diversity of languages; it would be easier for those who are deep and profound in speech to hear, and who have nothing of Jewish frivolity, but enter with a heavy and solid foot, and although the languages are unknown, the faith is known. And it follows: And if I were to send you to them, they would listen to you. Finally, he sent, and they all believed together. Hence, Paul and Barnabas speak to the Jews (or rather, to them): It was necessary for the word of God to be preached to you, but since you do not want to receive the message, behold, we turn to the Gentiles (Acts 13:46). And about the centurion, it is said: I have not found such great faith in Israel (Matthew 8:10).

<h2 id='tocuniq33'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7) But the house of Israel does not want to listen to you, because they do not want to listen to me. For the whole house of Israel is weary-faced and hard-hearted. Do not be saddened, he says, if they do not want to listen to you. Therefore, they will not listen to you: because they will despise listening to me: just as the Savior also said: 'Whoever does not receive you, does not receive me' (Ibid., X, 40). In which it is clearly shown that free will is granted. And two reasons are given as to why they do not listen: because they are perverse of will, he says, and weary-faced, or, as the Seventy have translated, contentious: and it is understood that, being often invited to salvation, they did not want to listen.


<h2 id='tocuniq34'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Version 8, 9) Behold, I have made your face stronger than their faces, and your forehead harder than their foreheads. Like adamant and like flint I have made your face. Do not fear them or be afraid of their presence, for they are a rebellious house. And he said to me, 'The house of Israel has a stubborn and audacious forehead, and a heart as hard as scorpions. Therefore, I have given you a very hard face and a forehead that will not be ashamed.'" } From this we learn that sometimes it is necessary to resist the audacity of God's favor, and when the situation demands it, to stand firm and face adversity head on. However, this is attributed so that our true modesty and human decency does not fear the plots of enemies.

<h2 id='tocuniq35'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) Son of man, take all my words that I speak to you, and receive them into your heart, and listen with your ears. This is the nourishment of the book, and these are the words by which, according to the diversity of those who hear, either lamentation, or song, or woe is spoken ((or spoken to)). And yet it should be noted that before the words of God are to be composed, heard, and understood more diligently in our hearts, and thus proclaimed to the people.

<h2 id='tocuniq36'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11.) Go, enter into exile (or captivity), to the children of your people, and speak to them, and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: if perhaps they may hear and be quiet: And our Lord came to the people of Judah, sent by the Father, to proclaim remission to the captives, and to fulfill in him what is written: Ascending on high, he led captivity captive: he gave gifts to men (Psalm 67:19).


<h2 id='tocuniq37'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(Vers. 12.) And the Spirit took me, and I heard behind me a great sound of shaking: Blessed be the glory of the Lord from His place. God of whom it is written: The Lord lifts up the meek (Psalm 146:6), He Himself also took up the prophet, who was not in the flesh, but in the spirit, and walking in the spirit, he did not fulfill the works of the flesh: for the spirit of God was in him. Therefore, despising earthly things, he is carried away by the spirit, and he hears behind him a great sound of shaking, forgetting the past and reaching out to the future, so as to leave the snares of his enemies behind him. We read of a similar incident in the book of Exodus (Exod. XXIV), when Pharaoh and his entire army pursued the Israelites, and the angel in the pillar of cloud left the front of the camp and came behind them, standing between Israel and the Egyptians all night. This caused great fear among the Egyptians and allowed the Israelites to hear the words: 'Blessed be the glory of the Lord from His place.' The place of the Lord is wherever He finds lodging. Alternatively, the Son is the place of the Father, just as the Father is the place of the Son, as the Lord Himself, our Savior, said: 'I am in the Father, and the Father in Me' (John XIV, 11). This same thing also signifies Michael: Behold, the Lord will come forth from his place, and will come down upon the high places of the earth. And the mountains shall be melted under him, and the valleys shall be as wax melting before the fire, and as waters that are poured down a steep place. (Mich. I, 3, 4) For when the Lord and Savior descended, and proceeded from the Father, the high places of the earth and the mountains were moved, and the lower parts of the valleys were liquefied. This place can be the glory of the Lord, and the inaccessible light, of which the Apostle speaks: Who only hath immortality, and inhabiteth light inaccessible. (I Tim. VI, 16). When we turn over in our minds the past judgments of the Lord, we hear the voice from behind of a great commotion. When we reflect on the future in our hearts, a voice is heard about the things that came before, and from those that are before.

<h2 id='tocuniq38'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13.) And the voice of the wings of the animals striking one against another, and the voice of the following wheels of the animals, and the sound of a great commotion. Because it is understood, ἀπὸ κοινοῦ according to the Hebrew: I heard behind me the sound of a great commotion, and I heard the voice of the wings of the animals, and the sound of the wheels, added by the Septuagint: And I saw the voice of the wings of the animals striking one against another, and the rest according to what is read in Exodus: And all the people saw the voice of God (Exod. XX, 18): that is, the voice that came from behind, the prophet heard; but what was in front of him, he saw. But it is better and truer to have understood a heard voice than a seen one, as well as the beating of wings against each other and the sound of wheels, which we mentioned above, and the great commotion that showed the coming wrath of God upon the people of Israel.

Verse 14. The Spirit also lifted me up and took me away, and I went bitterly in the indignation of my spirit. Septuagint: And the Spirit lifted me up, and received me, and I went high in the impetuosity of my spirit. After being lifted up by the Spirit and taken by him, then in the indignation and bitterness of his spirit he went where he was carried, understanding the indignation of God and what the vision signified, pondering in his mind. 32 Whether he was carried high by the impetuosity of his own spirit, desiring to go where the Lord commanded." } But let us understand his spirit, not the Holy Spirit, but the spirit of man, about which it is said in many places, as in Isaiah: My spirit rises up to you, O God, during the night (Isaiah 26:9). And the prophet is carried (not as some think) in spirit, but in the very body, which we also read about in Habakkuk according to Theodotion (Daniel 14).

<h2 id='tocuniq39'>(Vers. 15.)</h2>

(Verse 15.) For the hand of the Lord was with me, strengthening me. And I came to the exile at the mound of new fruits, to those who lived near the river Chebar. And I sat where they were sitting, and I stayed there for seven days mourning among them. LXX: And the hand of the Lord became strong upon me, and I entered into the lofty captivity. And I went around the inhabitants along the river Chebar, who were there. And I sat there for seven days, dwelling among them. For the reason that we have translated, Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion have placed the Hebrew words Thel Abib (): which the Seventy translated, lofty and roundabout; believing it better to say something than to impose something that would make the reader question. But we have learned from the Hebrews that Thel abib means, when new grains or barley are gathered, and after hunger and scarcity, before they are ground in the threshing floor, they promise some hope of food. Thus Israel, small and weak, who dwelt on the banks of the river Chobar, like one revived and sprung from the earth, promised the sowing of the Jewish people. But the hand of the Lord came upon the prophet, strengthening him, so that he may receive the name of a watchman, and teach what he has learned. And for seven days he dwells among them, seeing all that they are doing, so that he may know what he should reprove. And he mourns, or converses in their midst, seeing their crimes and the just punishment of God for the iniquity of their sins. For the reason that we have mentioned, he translated it grieving, and it is written in Hebrew as Masmim (), Theodotion translated it, admiring, in order to express the astonishment of the Prophets who perceive their iniquities. But the second edition of Aquila, which the Hebrews call 'according to accuracy', translated it: 'being calm', that is, being at rest, and being separated from them in mind although he was indeed among the 33 captives, to show.

<h2 id='tocuniq40'>(Vers. 16, 17.)</h2>

(Verse 16, 17.) But after seven days had passed, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel, and you shall hear a word from my mouth and declare it to them from me. The one who is to be a watchman and declare God's words to the people must rest for a long time and grieve over what he sees. He must have no guilt concerning the things he will correct in others.

<h2 id='tocuniq41'>(Vers. 18, 19.)</h2>

(Verse 18, 19.) If you say to the wicked, 'You shall surely die,' and you do not warn him or speak to warn the wicked to turn from his wicked way, that person shall die in his iniquity; but his blood I will require at your hand. But if you warn the wicked, and he does not turn from his wickedness or from his wicked way, he shall die in his iniquity; but you will have delivered your soul. The two are wicked, or unjust, as the Septuagint has translated. One who does not listen to the observer and dies in his impiety, whose blood is sought from the hands of the observer. Another, to whom the observer announces, and he, despising to listen, dies in his own fault: only so that the observer is free from blame. From this we understand that the Lord threatens the impious and says, 'You shall die by death,' in order to turn him away from his impious way and live. For the threat is not against men, but against sins; nor against those who turn away from vices, but those who remain in sin. And a great danger it is, to remain silent about God's teachings, for three reasons: either out of fear, or out of laziness, or out of flattery. Hence, Isaiah says: Woe is me, for I have kept silent (Isaiah 6:5). And what follows: But you have saved your own life, means what the Apostle says: If someone's work is burned up, they will suffer loss, but they themselves will be saved, yet as through fire (1 Corinthians 3:14); in order to prove whether an outsider is to blame for the death of the one who perished, or if they themselves are guilty. For the work of the teacher, the salvation of the student is.

<h2 id='tocuniq42'>(Vers. 20, 21.)</h2>

(Verse 20, 21.) But if the righteous turns away from his righteousness and commits iniquity, I will put a stumbling block before him. He will die because you did not warn him; he will die in his sin, and the righteous deeds he had done will not be remembered. But I will hold you accountable for his blood. However, if you warn the righteous man not to sin, and he does not sin, he will surely live because you have warned him, and you have saved your own soul. Just as we read about two wicked or unjust individuals: One, who did not listen, and perished; the other, who listened and persisted in wickedness: so there are two just individuals, one who did not listen and perished; the other, who listened and turned to repentance, saved his soul. It should be noted that the just individual can fall; and if he has a teacher, he can be converted to better things. And therefore, good deeds require a constant teacher, so that a misstep does not hold back the foot from the best course. And indeed, the wicked or unjust, if they do not repent, will die in their wickedness and iniquity. But the righteous, if they commit wickedness and sin, do not die immediately; rather, they are placed in stumbling or torment before them, as Theodotius said, in weakness: so that they may be tormented and not find a smooth path, and understand themselves to be weak, of whom the Apostle also says: Therefore, many are weak among you, and many sleep (I Corinthians XI, 30). For it is beneficial for the righteous to understand their sin and the torment of their conscience, and to say with the Psalmist: I am turned in my pain, while the thorn is fastened in me (Psalm XXXI, 4). And just as the wicked are not encountered by injustices if they turn away from their wicked way and live, so the ancient just deeds do not benefit the righteous if they are overwhelmed by new crimes. But what he introduces is: he will surely die, because you did not announce to him, it is understood, that he could have lived if the watcher and master had taught him.

<h2 id='tocuniq43'>(Vers. 22.)</h2>

(Verse 22.) And there the hand of the Lord was upon me, and he said to me: Rise up, go out into the field, and there I will speak with you. What we have translated from Hebrew as 'there' is significantly placed, and there is no doubt that it signifies a place. For earlier we read: 'And I came to the captivity to the heap of new corn, to them that dwelt by the river Chebar' (Ezekiel 3:15). And rightly to the one to whom he had spoken, he sat down and is commanded to rise. And he who had entered to pass through, heard: go out, not into rugged valleys, not into steep cliffs, but into a wide field that can hold the glory of the Lord. Therefore, it is said to the Corinthians: Be enlarged (I Cor. VI, 13). When he enters to capture the captives, about whom it is said that they are mad and pursue him, perhaps he needs a strong hand in order to resist and endure the fury of those who pursue him. But when he goes out into the field, indeed the hand of the Lord is upon him: for he could not go out without his help, but strength is not added. For he goes out not to fight, but to see the glory of God. And it should be noted that while sitting among the captive, the Prophet himself did not see the glory of the Lord.

<h2 id='tocuniq44'>(Vers. 23.)</h2>

(Verse 23) And I arose and went out into the field, and behold, there the glory of the Lord stood, like the glory that I saw by the river Chebar. At the command of the Lord, he enters and at the command he exits, and he sits with those who are sitting; for the number of captives cannot hear him standing. And he went out into the width of the field, and saw the glory of the Lord standing, which he had previously seen walking and lifting itself up, and sometimes standing. Because near the river of this age, called Chobar, which can be interpreted (or, is interpreted) as most serious, glory was seen: which means that all the glory of this world overflows and does not have a stable degree. But the standing and persevering glory of the Lord, when seen with the standing Prophet in the field, could neither stand nor be seen among the captives.

<h2 id='tocuniq45'>(Vers. 24.)</h2>
