(Verse 24) And I fell on my face, and the spirit entered into me, and set me upon my feet: and he spoke to me, and said to me: Enter, and shut thyself in the midst of thy house. Unable to withstand the glory of the Lord standing, he fell on his face, so that he might be lifted up by the spirit entering into him. The spirit set him upon his feet and spoke to him, saying: Enter and shut yourself in the midst of your house. And here is the meaning: Because you have been strengthened by the vision of the Lord's majesty, do not fear or be afraid of anyone; but return to your own home, either for bodily needs, as some think, or as a sign of a future siege. Just as Isaiah, barefoot and naked, prophesied the captivity of the people for three years and the nakedness of the people (Isaiah 20), so you are also confined to your house, the very work of a prophet announcing the impending siege of the city of Jerusalem.


<h2 id='tocuniq46'>(Vers. 25, 26.)</h2>

(Verse 25, 26.) And you, son of man, behold, chains have been placed upon you, and they will bind you with them, and you will not go out from among them, and I will make your tongue cling to the roof (or throat) of your mouth, and you will be mute, not as a man reproving them (They are absent from the Vulgate): because the house is provoking. What is closed in the house, what is bound with chains, what does not go out to them, among whom it dwells, but among the multitude of captives, it suffers the loneliness of prison (as I have said above), an indication of siege, because Jerusalem is shut up and surrounded by the army of the Chaldeans, it will not allow anyone living there to go out. This is the pot about which Jeremiah speaks (Jerem. I), and he himself is this Prophet in the following; in which the flesh of the people is consumed. But the fact that the language of the Prophet clings to the palate or throat and becomes mute does not have the authority of a reproachful one, the reason is clear: because he says, 'the house is provoking.' And the sense is: They are of such bitterness, and of such contention against God, that they do not deserve to hear the one reproaching. From this it is clear that where there is a multitude of sinners, those who deserve correction are unworthy sinners, who are to be corrected by the Lord.

<h2 id='tocuniq47'>(Vers. 27.)</h2>

(Verse 27) But when I speak to you, I will open your mouth, and you shall say to them, 'Thus says the Lord God: He who has ears to hear, let him hear; and he who is at rest, let him rest; for the house is rebellious.' What we read in Ecclesiastes, 'A time to keep silence, and a time to speak' (Eccles. III), is also affirmed in prophetic discourse: that it is the same wisdom to be silent and to speak in due time, and to give food to one's servants at the proper time. Therefore, Isaiah also said to the unbelieving people: I have kept silent, will I always be silent? says the Lord (Isa. 65). Therefore, he who, for a long time, kept his mouth shut because of the multitude of sins, because he saw that some could be converted, of whom it was said: He who hears, let him hear, and he who rests from evil, let him rest, and let him cease: therefore, speaking with an open mouth, not by his own will, but by the command of the Lord, he speaks to the people. But what we have set forth: He who hears, let him hear: and he who rests, let him rest: for which the Septuagint translated: He who hears, let him hear: and he who is unbelieving, let him remain unbelieving: the second edition of Aquila translated it thus: He who hears, will be heard: and he who leaves, will be left. And he said: To anyone who has, more will be given, and from anyone who does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him (Mark 4:25).

<h2 id='tocuniq48'>(Cap. IV.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter IV - Verses 1, 2) And you, son of man, take for yourself a brick, and you shall put it before you, and you shall draw on it the city of Jerusalem. And you shall set up a siege against it, and build a siege wall against it, and pile up a mound against it, and you shall encamp against it, and set up battering rams against it all around. As we have said before: Go inside and enclose in the midst of your house, and behold, chains have been put on you, and they shall bind you, and you shall not go out. This is a symbol of the prophet of the future siege of the city of Jerusalem: now he is commanded to draw geometric art on a brick, and to place that brick before the prophet, so that after he has drawn Jerusalem in the dust, he may depict the entire siege against it, representing the fortifications, the piled mounds, the encircling army, and the battering rams, all of which are common in capturing cities. They are called fortifications, with which a city is enclosed, so that no one can escape from the besieged: embankments are brought in, with which the rampart and moat are filled; camps, the guards of the soldiers around; rams, with which the foundations of walls are shaken, and the joints of stones are dissolved. But this is said to signify the captivity of the nearby city of Jerusalem under Zedekiah: in the eleventh year both the king and the city were captured. On the side, which in Greek is called the feminine kind, Symmachus more clearly interpreted it as 'brick', which we can call a 'small brick' or 'tile'." } In whose dust the geometers are accustomed to describe lines, that is, lines and radii. From which some people want, it is not absurd to also have knowledge of this doctrine (repeating those examples, that Joshua son of Nun sent out explorers who would describe the land (Joshua 2) which is properly called Geometry: and the angel in Zechariah had a Geometric cord for measuring Jerusalem (Zechariah 2). And what the Prophet is now commanded to describe in the dust of Jerusalem (which is properly called Scene painting) we can take as a brick and a representation of Israel in mourning, which served Pharaoh in clay and brick (Exodus 1). Or let it be compared to a city which they thought was strong and impregnable, but which crumbles at the touch of water, as has been said before: Is not the hardest rock, or the mountain of the desert, turned into clay, which is corrupted by the flooding of Babylon; according to what is written: Therefore the Lord will bring upon you abundant and mighty waters, the king of Assyria (Isa. VIII, 7).


<h2 id='tocuniq49'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) And you shall take for yourself an iron griddle and place it as an iron wall between you and the city, and you shall set your face against it, and it shall be for a siege, and you shall surround it. This is a sign to the house of Israel. What we said above, both the prophet himself and the description of the side, the fortifications, the rampart, and the battering rams, surrounding Jerusalem as a sign preceding its siege, is now stated more clearly, after many things that are in the middle: The iron griddle is a sign to the house of Israel, and it represents a great wrath of God that will not be weakened by any prayers and will not be moved to mercy. For just as iron tames all metals, and nothing is harder than it, so the incredible crimes of Jerusalem, through their own vice, made God, who is naturally gentle, the most severe. It is also said that the frying pan is the barrier between the people and God, opposite to the wall, to show that the entire multitude can be quickly broken and reduced to nothingness. The hardening of the face against the city is a sign of severity, according to what we read elsewhere: The face of the Lord is against those who do evil; to destroy their memory from the earth (Ps. XXXIII, 17).


<h2 id='tocuniq50'>(Vers. 4 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 4 and following) And you shall lie on your left side, and you shall bear the iniquities of the house of Israel upon it, according to the number of the days that you lie on it, you shall bear their iniquity. For I have assigned to you a number of days, three hundred and ninety days, to bear the iniquity of the house of Israel. And when you have completed these, you shall lie down on your right side for a second time, and you shall bear the iniquity of the house of Judah for forty days. I have given you a day for a year, I say, a day for a year. Let us consider the three hundred and ninety years that are equal to the same number of days in which the prophet lay bound and confined on his left side, so that he did not turn to the other side, demonstrating the captivity and miseries of the ten tribes, that is, the Israelites. And the forty years in which he lay on his right side, as the holy Scripture tells us, representing the sins of Judah, concerning this it must be said that under King Pekah, the son of Remaliah, who reigned in Israel for twenty years, Tiglath-Pileser, the king of Assyria, came and took, Aijon, Abel, the house of Maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, and all the land of Naphtali, and took them away to Assyria. After whom, Hoshea the son of Elah reigned in Israel for nine years, and he was captured with all of Samaria by Salmanassar, the king of the Assyrians, and he was transported to Elam and to the cities of the Medes in the rivers Abor and Gozan. But in the sixth year of the reign of King Hezekiah, as the holy book of Kings narrates, Hoshea was captured. If we calculate in order, we can find out how many years Israel was in distress and oppressed under the yoke of captivity. From the sixth year to the twenty-ninth year (for Hezekiah reigned for twenty-four years) twenty-four years are reckoned: after him came Manasseh, and he reigned for fifty-five years. After him Amon reigned for two years. After him Josiah reigned for thirty-two years. After him Jehoiakim, also called Eliakim, reigned for eleven years. After him Jehoiachin, also called Jeconiah, who was immediately taken into captivity, reigned for eleven years, and Zedekiah reigned in his place for eleven years, during which time Jerusalem was captured and the temple destroyed. Therefore, from the first captivity of Israel, which occurred under King Phacee until the eleventh year of Sedecias, when the Temple was desolated, there were 164 years (Al. 70). From the second captivity, when Osee was captured and all of Samaria was destroyed, there were 135 years (Al. 80). And there were 70 years of desolation of the Temple, which added to the first captivity, makes a total of 234 years. For in the second year of the reign of Darius, king of the Persians, the temple was built by Zerubbabel, the son of Salathiel, and Jesus, the son of Josedec, with the prophesying of Haggai and Zechariah. Darius reigned for thirty-six years, and when one year is subtracted, his reign was thirty-five years. After him, Xerxes, the son of Darius, reigned for twenty years. After him, Artabanus reigned for seven months. And Xerxes, also known as Μακρόχειρ, reigned for forty years. After him, Xerxes reigned for two months, and Sogdianus reigned for seven (or four) months. Darius, known as Νόθος, succeeded him, who reigned for nineteen years. After him, Artaxerxes, known as Μνήμων (or Memnon), the son of Darius and Parisatis, reigned for forty years, and he is called Assuerus by the Hebrews. It is under his reign that the story of Mordecai and Esther, found in the book of Esther (chapter 8), takes place. This is when the entire Jewish people were saved from the danger of death and regained their former freedom. From the second year of Darius to the final year of Assuerus, there are 155 years and four months. In addition to the previous 234 years, they make a total of 389 years and four months. The death on the right side, that is, 40 years, can be easily calculated. After Eliacim, who was called Joacim, his son Joachin, also known as Jechonias, reigned for three months. During his reign, the servants of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon ascended to Jerusalem and surrounded it with fortifications. Then King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came to the city while his servants were besieging it. And Joachin, the king of Judah, went out to the king of Babylon, he and his mother, and his servants, and his princes, and his eunuchs, and the king of Babylon took him in the eighth year of his reign and brought forth all the treasures of the house of the Lord, and the treasures of the king's house. And after a little while: 'He carried away all Jerusalem, and all the princes, and all the mighty men of the army, ten thousand into captivity, and every craftsman, and smith, and nothing was left, except for the poor people of the land.' (Ibid.). After capturing Jerusalem with an infinite multitude of people and all the resources, Zedekiah reigned for eleven years. Under his rule, the city was captured and the temple was destroyed. Its desolation lasted until the second year of Darius, a period of seventy years. In the thirty-first year of the temple's desolation, Cyrus reigned in Persia after overthrowing King Astyages of the Medes. According to the prophecy of Isaiah, Cyrus sent back to Jerusalem nearly fifty thousand people from the tribe of Judah, along with the temple vessels that Nebuchadnezzar had taken, and other things that are narrated by Ezra in his history. Therefore, just as in Israel, that is, the ten tribes under the rule of King Pekah of Israel, under whom the Israelite people suffered much devastation by Salmanasar, until the fortieth year of King Assuerus, we calculate three hundred and ninety years, when the persecution of all the Jewish people was alleviated, so from the first year of Jechoniah, when a great part of Jerusalem was transported to Babylon, until the first year of Cyrus, king of the Persians, which was the thirtieth year of the desolation of the temple, forty years are reckoned, under which the captivity of the Jews was loosened, and freedom was restored to the people. Some, combining three hundred and ninety years for the Israelites and forty years for the Jews, make four hundred and thirty years, and they want them to be fulfilled from the baptism of the Savior to the end of the world. However, others, especially the Jews, want to be counted in tribulation, distress, and the yoke of captivity, four hundred and thirty years from the second year of Vespasian, when Jerusalem was captured by the Romans and the temple was destroyed, and thus the people to return to their former state. Just as the children of Israel were in Egypt for four hundred and thirty years, so may the final captivity end in the same number. And it is written in Exodus: Now the sojourning of the children of Israel, who dwelt in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years. And again: After four hundred and thirty years, the entire army of the Lord went out at night. And I am quite amazed why the Vulgate editions have ninety years, and in some it is written one hundred and fifty years: when clearly, the Hebrew text, as well as Aquila, Symmachus and Theodotion, hold three hundred and ninety years; and among the Seventy, who are not corrupted by the fault of the writers, the same number is found. The most difficult question, and I dare say proudly, not explained by anyone  42 , we believe has been expounded not so much by our knowledge, as by the grace of the Lord, fulfilling what He Himself promised: Seek, and you will find: ask, and you will receive: knock, and it will be opened to you (Matthew VII, 7). But whoever wants to calculate from the first captivity, which happened under Manahen, son of Gaddi, king of Israel, who reigned in Samaria for ten years (2 Kings XV): when Phul, king of the Assyrians, came into the land of Israel and received one thousand talents of silver; and after him, two more years Phacce, who reigned in Israel, will find that in the twenty-eighth year of king Assuerus, three hundred and ninety years were completed, when the story of Esther is said to have occurred: which is also more credible. For not with the end of the reign of Assuerus, but while he was still reigning, Israel cast off the yoke of the most burdensome servitude.

<h2 id='tocuniq51'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7.) And you shall turn your face to the siege of Jerusalem, and your arm shall be extended, and you shall prophesy against it. LXX: And you shall set your face against the siege of Jerusalem, and you shall strengthen your arm, and you shall prophesy against it. Preparation of the face is necessary, as well as strength, and confirmation of the extended and bared arm, so that not only through voice, but also through gesture and appearance of the prophet, the siege of the city may be demonstrated.


<h2 id='tocuniq52'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Vs. 8) Behold, I have surrounded you with chains, and you will not turn from one side to the other, until the days of your siege (or conclusion) are fulfilled. The left side, because it was without a temple and knowledge of God, is assigned to the Israelites; the right side, to the Jews, in which the worship and religion of God (or gods) resides. And it should be noted that in one side is the punishment of sinners, and in the other is the exercise of virtue. And one does not turn from one side to the other, so that no respite from torment is indicated, until the perfect conclusion of the aforementioned days is fulfilled. What the day is to prophets, that the year is to the patient (Gen. XXIX). And the years that Laban thought were few days for Jacob. But not only in punishments is there variety according to the diversity of merits; but also in the retribution of good things, lambs stand on the right, and kids stand on the left. Hence it is written in another place: The heart of the wise is in his right hand, but the heart of a fool is in his left hand (Ecclus. X, 1). There are different bonds of the Lord, by which we are bound for salvation; other bonds of the devil, by which he had bound a woman for eighteen years in the Gospel (Luke XIII). And so each and every one of the sinners is bound by the cords (Prov. V, 22). This the Lord loosens through the resurrection of Lazarus, who had been lying bound with graveclothes and burial bands (John XI).

<h2 id='tocuniq53'>(Vers. 9 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 9 onwards) And you shall take wheat, and barley, and beans, and lentils, and millet, and spelt, and put them in one vessel, and make yourself bread for the number of days that you shall lie on your side; three hundred and ninety days you shall eat it. And your food which you shall eat shall be by weight, twenty shekels a day: from time to time you shall eat it. And you shall drink water by measure, the sixth part of a hin: from time to time you shall drink it. And you shall eat it like barley bread, and cover it with human excrement in their sight. This is how we interpret the vice, for which it is called Chasamim in Hebrew. The Septuagint and Theodotion rendered it as ὄλυραν, which some believe to be oats, others believe to be rye. But the first edition of Aquila and Symmachus translated it as ζέας or ζείας, which we call either spelt or emmer in the spoken language of Italy and Pannonia. Moreover, they also added figurines to the vase. And the prophet is commanded to foretell a future famine, and to demonstrate through action the poverty of the people of Israel. Just as in times of scarcity, one does not seek diverse and luxurious foods, but rather how to fill the stomach, so now the prophet mingles wheat, barley, beans, lentils, and millet, along with oats, in one vessel and makes three hundred and ninety loaves, which he will eat each day. Each loaf weighs twenty shekels, that is, stateres. The shekel, that is, the stater, has four drachmas. Eight drachmas, however, make a Latin ounce, so that one loaf is said to have ten ounces, by which the soul is drawn more than it is sustained. The sterility of food increases the sterility of water. For it is commanded to drink one sixth of the Hebrew measurement, which is called a hin, each day. Furthermore, a hin makes two Attic choas: 44 which we can call two Roman sextarii, so that the hin measurement is the Hebrew sextarius and our military one, of which one sixth makes one third of a Roman sextarius. Food and drink do not give strength, but prevent death, according to the famous Orator. And when he says, 'From time to time you shall eat or drink', he means from evening to evening, although some may misunderstand it as meaning from year to year. And the bread itself is made like barley bread mixed with ashes. It is said that it should be covered with human excrement, not for those who are going to eat it without knowledge (for ignorance usually tempers misery), but for those who see it, so that the sight causes horror before the taste causes nausea. Also, it should be noted that according to the number of days on the left side, three hundred and ninety subcinericii breads should be ordered to be made and eaten each day, and no mention should be made of the forty breads on the right side. This is a secret hint that the punishment of the sinful people is not the same if they have knowledge of God and of the one who has completely departed from the religion of the true God. We can also say this according to spiritual understanding, that the Jewish people, after offending God, still eat subcinericii bread mixed with wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and oats; one type of food for humans, the other for animals. For in that they seem to believe in one God, they have something of wheat. But in denying the Son, they feed on barley and beans, with which the belly of those who eat is inflated, and the mind is said to be oppressed: to such an extent that even to the Pythagoreans, the food is detestable. Because of a lentil, Esau lost his birthright (Genesis XXV). Millet is the food of peasants, rustic people, and birds. Oats, or weeds and wild herbs, are eaten by dumb animals. But what is written according to the Septuagint, that Elijah, fleeing from Jezebel, found barley bread, gritty and covered with ashes (3 Kings 19), is a sign of persecution and scarcity. Therefore, he is fed by ravens, so that because he did not find food in Israel, he would be nourished by unclean Gentile foods. Also, the very law they read, but do not understand, is bread covered with ashes and covered with human excrement. Therefore, Paul the Apostle says that he considered the gains of the Law and the observance of the former ceremonies as dung, in order to gain Christ (Philippians 3).


<h2 id='tocuniq54'>(Vers. 13 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 13 onwards) And the Lord said: So shall the children of Israel eat their bread, defiled among the nations to which I will cast them out. And I said, ah, ah, ah, Lord God: Behold, my soul is not defiled, and I have not eaten carrion or torn flesh from beasts from my infancy until now, and no unclean meat has entered my mouth. And He said to me: Behold, I have given you cow dung instead of human excrement, and you shall make your bread with it. According to the book of Zechariah (Zech. III), prophets are extraordinary men who predict the future through their works and speak on behalf of God. We frequently read in many places that God compares Himself to being in the hands of the prophets (Hosea XII, 10). Just as Ezekiel ate bread in excrement, so too will the Israelites, or all the people of Judah, or as some believe, the ten tribes, eat polluted bread among the nations. Although this is not a threat to those who have already been expelled, it is directed towards those who will be expelled from the promised land. When he learned this from the Prophet, he vehemently denounced it according to Aquila, ah, ah, ah. But according to Symmachus and the Seventy, he responded μηδαμῶς, which in Latin means 'by no means'. Therefore, Theodotion translated it as 'O Lord God'. We should not think that he is contradicting the command of the Lord, but rather giving reasons, or rather begging, why he cannot do this. Finally, he obtained what he asked for, and the severity of the sentence was tempered by a milder command. It is questioned why Ezekiel refused more easily, and why Hosea was immediately joined to a prostitute without contradicting or even responding, claiming to have a chaste body and not be defiled by the company of a harlot, as the Apostle says: 'He who is joined to a harlot becomes one body with her' (1 Cor. VI, 16). From this it is shown that the figure of the Synagogue, or the Church, was not truly accomplished according to the letter: which we have explained more fully by expounding the prophet. Morticinium is said to be a killing that loses life without shedding blood, and in which the soul dies, torn apart by wild beasts, which is called θηριάλωτον in Greek. But as for the human excrement, which is granted to be cattle manure, lighter evils are signified: while they are indeed commanded to eat bread cooked in cow manure; but it is far from being the uncleanness of human excrement: and even to this day this sentiment is observed among the Jewish people, that they do not eat their bread in human excrement. For they do not serve idols, nor do they worship the various wonders of demons; but they work with the flesh and belly and the goods of this earth, as it is said: Those who do these things shall live in them (Lev. XVIII, 5; Deut. IV). But we despise earthly things, and not only do we trample the foods of human waste, and consider earthly delights to be worthless, but we eat the bread that descends from heaven (John. VI), and we enjoy that food, of which the Psalmist sings: Man eats the bread of angels (Psalm LXXVII, 25); living not by the flesh of the Egyptians, but by the thinness of the manna.


<h2 id='tocuniq55'>(Vers. 16, 17.)</h2>

(Verse 16, 17.) And he said to me: Son of man, behold, I will break the staff of bread in Jerusalem, and they shall eat bread by weight and with anxiety, and drink water by measure and with dismay. So that when bread and water are lacking, everyone will collapse to his brother, and they shall waste away in their iniquities. The Hebrew word מתא (Mate) is translated as staff in the first edition of Aquila, and as firmament in the second edition and by Symmachus and Theodotion. But that which he had shown in his work and explained in his speech, and the sleep of the left and right sides, and the ash bread mixed with six varieties of spices, representing the evils of the world, he strives to demonstrate the famine of food in Jerusalem and the incredible shortage of water, so that everyone may turn to their brother, hoping for assistance from another, which he does not perceive in himself. For it is the nature of humans, that in times of pressing evils and the weight of distress, they have more trust in those close to them rather than in themselves: and they waste away in their own injustices, while enduring everything for the sake of injustice. And I fear that even in our own Jerusalem, where the vision of peace is seen, this breaking of bread is found, which the Lord crushes when he is angry and judges us unworthy of his bread. And I hope that at least in weight and anxiety we may deserve to receive him, and may our dry tongue, with excessive dryness, be moistened by the finger of Lazarus at the end (Luke XVI). But with the deficiency of bread and water in the Church, a man will fall against his brother, and everywhere there is discord, with us tearing apart the tunic of Christ, which not even the soldiers dared to tear in the passion of the Savior (John XIX); and with our sins festering, as we do not possess the justice of God. It is written in Jeremiah that the little ones, that is, the common people of the Church, would seek bread and there would be no one to break it for them (Lamentations IV, 4). But Paul, a man of 48 churches, knew that Christ broke the legal bread and gave it to the disciples to be distributed. He confidently says: Is not the bread that we break a participation in the body of Christ? (I Cor. X, 16.) And those who are weak and need the milk of infancy cannot eat the staff or strength of bread, nor can they receive solid food. And nothing nourishes the mind of a person eating as much as the bread of life, of which it is written: And bread strengthens the heart of man (Psal. CLXXXIII, 15).


<h2 id='tocuniq56'>Book Two</h2>

Book Two

47. In the volume of the Explanation of Second Ezechiel, O virgin of Christ Eustochium, this is the beginning.

<h2 id='tocuniq57'>(Cap. V.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter V — Verses 1 onwards) And you, son of man, take for yourself a sharp sword, like a barber's razor, and pass it over your head and your beard, and you will take for yourself a balance of weight and divide them. One-third you shall burn with fire in the midst of the city, when the days of the siege are complete, and one-third you shall strike with the sword around it; and one-third you shall scatter to the wind, and I will unsheathe the sword after them. And you shall take from there a small number, and you shall bind them at the top of the cloak, and from them you shall take them out again, and you shall throw them into the middle of the fire, and you shall burn them. From there fire will come out into all the house of Israel. For three parts of hair and wool, one of which is burned in the middle of the city, another is cut with a sword around it, the third is scattered to and fro by the wind, from which a small amount is taken, and it is bound at the edge of the cloak, and again a small portion of the third part is thrown into the fire, from which flame comes out into all the house of Israel, LXX four parts were interpreted. And when they had said: Burn a fourth part with fire in the midst of the city, and cut a fourth part with the sword in its circuit, and scatter a fourth part to the wind, for there will be a remaining fourth part, they added from their own: And take a fourth part, and burn it in the midst of the city: as if it were not the same as the first, and as if something else was said in this part that was added. Finally, the Lord Himself will explain the riddle of the divided hairs into three parts through the Prophet, saying: A third part of you shall die by pestilence, and be consumed by famine in your midst, signifying that famine and pestilence are fire; and a third part of you shall fall by the sword in your circuit, describing external slaughters and wars. He says, 'But I will scatter a third part of you to every wind, showing that they are the ones who are to be taken captive. After them, he says he will strip or pour out his sword, so that captivity will not be the last of their troubles. And he will take from those scattered and captive ones, and bind on the top of his garment those who are to return from captivity to Jerusalem, and from them also he will take a portion and consume it with fire and flame, signifying the Macedonians under whom the inhabitants of Judea, and especially Jerusalem, suffered greatly.' But what he says, from that, that is, to the people of the Jews; or, according to the Seventy, from her; so that it is understood, from the city of Jerusalem, fire will come out into every house of Israel: The history of the Maccabees tells that a certain part of the Jews handed themselves over to Antiochus Epiphanes, and incited him to persecute the people, and many other things that are written in the same history, and in the volumes of Josephus, especially the dispute between Hyrcanus and Alexander, on account of which Cneus Pompey took Jerusalem and subjected it to Roman rule; and afterwards, under Titus and Vespasian, the city was captured and the temple was destroyed. And after fifty years, under Aelius Hadrian, the city was completely burned and destroyed, to the extent that it lost even its former name. However, just as in the case of the emperor and his beard, it is an indication of beauty and manliness, and if they are shaved, an ugly nakedness is revealed, so too Jerusalem and its people, separated from the living body of God, are handed over to famine, pestilence, slaughter, and the sword, captivity and dispersion. From this dispersion, under the form of hairs, a certain part is tied at the top of the cloak, so that a small amount is again given to the fire, from which an infinite flame and nearly the whole of it, devastating, comes out into every house of Israel.

<h2 id='tocuniq58'>(Vers. 5 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 5 and following) Thus says the Lord God: This is Jerusalem; I have set it in the midst of the nations and surrounded it with lands. But she has despised my judgments, acting more wickedly than the nations, and has gone beyond the laws of the surrounding lands. They have rejected my judgments and have not walked in my commandments. The Prophet also testifies that Jerusalem is situated in the center of the world, demonstrating that it is the navel of the earth. And the Psalmist, expressing the birth of the Lord, says: Truth, he says, has risen from the earth (Ps. XLVIII, 12). And afterwards, commenting on his passion: He has worked salvation in the midst of the earth (Ps. LXXIII, 12). For on the eastern side, there is the region called Asia. On the western side, there is the region called Europe. In the south and the south wind, there is Libya and Africa. In the north, there are the Scythians, Armenia, Persia, and all the nations of the Pontus. In the midst, therefore, of nations, placed in such a manner that the God who was known in Judea (Ps. LXXV), and his great name in Israel, all the nations around followed its examples, which, having followed the impiety of the nations around it, it even conquered them in its own wickedness. This was well interpreted by Symmachus: These, he says, are the judgments which I have changed, O Jerusalem, which I have placed in the midst of the nations, and the regions around it; I have changed my judgments on account of the impieties which it has learned from the nations, and my righteousness from the regions that are around it, because they have rejected my statutes and have not walked in my judgments. But what the Seventy have said, that my justifications are unjust from the Gentiles, and my laws from the regions that are within it, without me speaking, is clear.

<h2 id='tocuniq59'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Verse 8, 9.) Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because you have surpassed the nations that are around you, you have not walked in my statutes, nor have you carried out my judgments, nor have you acted according to the judgments of the nations that are around you. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, and I myself will execute judgments in your midst in the sight of the nations. And I will do to you what I have not done, and the like of which I will never do again, because of all your abominations. Regarding what we have interpreted: Because you have surpassed the nations that are around you, Symmachus translated: Because your multitude was from the nations that are around you. Aquila's second edition: Because you have been numbered among the nations that are around you. And the Septuagint: Because your opportunity is from the nations that are around you. And the meaning is, either that Jerusalem, by its own crimes, surpassed all the nations around it, or that its multitude, not the people of Israel, but the crowd of other nations, is to be called. Certainly, among the number of other nations which surround them, they have been converted, or have had every opportunity to teach the nations which they ought to have taught more favorably. 'Why,' He says, 'have you not walked in My commandments and not done My judgments, when you have even conquered all the nations around you with your wickedness, and have not done what those nations frequently did, which were written in their hearts by the natural law?' Therefore, not through Angels, nor through any ministers, but I myself will perform my judgments in you, to the sight of all that I have not done before, and I will not do furthermore. By saying 'judgments', he shows the truth of the sentence, so that it doesn't seem that anger exceeds the measure of punishments. He did not do such things in any nation as he did in Jerusalem: 'For the servant who knows the will of his master and does not do it, shall be beaten with many stripes' (Luke XII, 48). Powerful storms endure powerfully (Wisdom 6:7). And similar things, he says, I will not do anymore. It was well said, I will not do similar things. For after the killing of Christ, he will make things much harsher. For it is one thing to have occasionally worshiped idols for which they were punished before, and another to have killed the Son of God.

<h2 id='tocuniq60'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) Therefore fathers shall eat their sons in the midst of you, and sons shall eat their fathers: and I will execute judgments in you, and scatter all your remnant into every wind. First in this way: Therefore, thus says the Lord God: behold, I am coming to you, and I myself will bring about judgments in your midst. Second: Therefore, fathers will eat their sons in your midst. Third: Therefore, as I live, says the Lord God; surely because you have violated my sanctuary in all your offenses, and the rest. However, it should be noted that where there are beauty and honorable things, and according to the merit of those who sustain them, God himself declares that he will do it. But where there are sad and unworthy things for God, he indeed says it will happen, but not by him, as at present: Therefore, fathers will eat their sons in your midst, and sons will eat their fathers. For he did not say, 'I will make the fathers eat their sons in your midst, and the sons eat their fathers.' But what was appropriate and did not seem unworthy of the majesty of God, he says that he will do. For it follows: 'And I will execute judgments in you, and I will scatter all your remnants to every wind.' We can see something similar in the curses of Deuteronomy, and especially in that place: 'Those who glorify me, I will glorify, but those who despise me will be brought to nothing.' (Deut. 28). For He who glorifies Himself, glorifies Himself. But those who despise Him, will not be despised by the Lord, or reduced to nothingness (for it follows that he says), but absolutely, reduced to nothingness: not by God, but according to their merits and sins. We read in the book of Kings, in a time of famine, a mother devouring her own son (2 Kings 6). Josephus also recounts many similar acts during the siege of Jerusalem. But when fathers eat their sons, or sons their fathers, history tells nothing, unless perhaps in many desperate evils, it must be believed that even these things have happened. This can also be referred to our Jerusalem: when masters are pitted against their disciples, that is, fathers against sons, and disciples against masters, that is, sons against fathers, they are stirred up by mutual rebellion, and that which is said by the Apostle is fulfilled: But if you bite and devour one another, take heed that you be not consumed by one another (Gal. V, 15). And the Prophet sang in mystical language: 'When my enemies approached me to devour my flesh' (Ps. XXVI, 2). And Job similarly speaks: 'If my maidservants have said: Who will give us some of his flesh to eat?' (Job XXXI). And concerning the masters who seek profit from their disciples and have no concern for their well-being, it is said: 'Who devour my people like bread' (Ps. LII, 5). Of these [widows] also the Apostle says: They eat the houses of widows (Luke 20; Matthew 23). We can understand, fathers, that those who eat their sons and those who eat their fathers, not only in Babylonia, but also in the Roman siege. Moreover, what is said: And I will scatter all your remnants to every wind, pertains more to the Roman captivity, when they were scattered throughout the entire world. And this is the dispersion of hair and beard to every wind.


<h2 id='tocuniq61'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11.) Therefore, I live, says the Lord God: unless for the reason that you violated my sanctuary in all your offenses, and in all your abominations, I will also break (or, according to the Septuagint, cast away) you, and my eye will not spare, and I will not have mercy. This is specifically said to Jerusalem, because you violated my sanctuary by forsaking me, and you worshiped idols in my temple. I will also break all your idols, and crush and overthrow them, or cast you away, because you have cast me away first. And my eye will not spare when I see you in hunger, sword, and submission to servitude; nor will I have mercy, because you do not deserve my mercy. For it is written: Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy (Matthew 5:7). The same applies in the Church, where God may daily say to teachers and priests who have acted negligently: Because you have violated my holy things in all your offenses, and in all the abominations you have committed, I will also crush and break you, and I will repay for what you have done to my people. About which the same Prophet speaks more fully against the shepherds here (below, XXXIV), that they cover the wool of the sheep and feed on milk and cheese, and do not seek the broken and sick flock.

<h2 id='tocuniq62'>(Vers. 12, 13.)</h2>

(Verse 12, 13.) A third part of you shall die of pestilence, and shall be consumed by famine in your midst; and a third part shall fall by the sword all around you; and I will scatter a third part to all the winds, and I will unsheathe the sword after them. Thus shall my anger be fulfilled, and I will cause my fury to rest upon them, and I will be comforted. And they shall know that I, the Lord, have spoken it in my zeal, when I have accomplished my fury upon them. Because the seventy translators had previously placed it in four parts, which in the description of fire, sword, and dispersion had approved to be only a prophetic discourse, so that the superfluous one part of fire would be divided into two parts, in this place also they divided the same first part into two, so that they would say: One fourth part of you will be worn out by death, and one fourth part of you will be consumed by hunger in your midst, and one fourth part of you will fall around you, and I will scatter one fourth part of you to every wind: although what we have placed, 'And one fourth part of you will fall by the sword,' has been added from the edition of Theodotion under asterisks. However, it is clear that the Hebrew truth contains three parts. Of the first of which it is said: 'And a third part of you shall die of pestilence, and be consumed with famine in your midst.' And it would have been much better to translate what is written, rather than seek support for a badly translated matter. And we do not say that this was done by those to whom antiquity gave authority, but it was corrupted by the fault of many centuries of scribes and readers. Although even Aristeus, Josephus, and the entire school of the Jews assert that only five books of Moses were translated by the Seventy-two. The chapter that we mentioned above seems to be omitted now. I will only add this, which is necessary in what he says: 'And I will pour out my wrath upon them and make my anger rest upon them, and I will comfort myself, and they shall know that I am the Lord, when I have poured out my indignation upon them.' We have often explained how the wrath, anger, and zeal of God should be understood, that God speaks in human emotions: not that he is angry, but that we may perceive through punishment and torment that God is angry. However, zeal is to be understood under the metaphor of a husband and wife, who as long as he loves his wife, is jealous; if he neglects her, he says that which we are going to say in the following: My zeal shall depart from you, and I will no longer be angry with you. And that which is joined: And they shall know that I the Lord have spoken in my zeal, not to those who have been consumed by famine and pestilence, nor to those who have fallen by the sword in the midst of the city, but to those who shall be scattered into every wind, they shall feel the anger of God for the deaths of others and their own miseries, which they have not wanted to perceive as God's mercy.


<h2 id='tocuniq63'>(Vers. 14.)</h2>

(Verse 14) And I will make you a desert; and what follows: and a reproach to the nations that are around you, it is not found in the Septuagint: for which they added from their own, and your daughters around you. And again, according to both editions, in the sight of everyone passing by. But it is profitable for Jerusalem to be desolated in all its vices, and to be reduced to a desert, and to recognize its own sins, so that what should have been an example of virtues to other nations may be an example of miseries. But we can understand his daughters, small cities, or Churches scattered throughout the world, as whoever is a stranger of this world, and says with the Psalmist: I am a stranger and a sojourner like all my fathers (Ps. 39:12); and of whom it is said: Those who pass by do not say: The blessing of the Lord be upon you (Ps. 129:8), let him see his reproach and be grieved.

<h2 id='tocuniq64'>(Vers. 15.)</h2>

(Verse 15.) And you will be a reproach and blasphemy, a example and wonder among the nations that surround you. For this, in the Septuagint, it is written: And it will be στενακτὴ, which means mournful. And in Theodotion it is added, καὶ δηλαἳστὴ; the meaning of this word is unknown. For this, three other interpreters have translated it as blasphemy, which in Hebrew is called Geddupha (). It follows:

When I bring judgments upon you in my wrath and indignation, and in the rebukes of my anger, which I, the Lord, have spoken, Jerusalem laments, when she offends God, that he may bring judgments upon her in his wrath and indignation. This is testified by Paul, who says: We were by nature children of wrath, like the rest (Ephesians 2:3). And again: For while we are still in this tent, we groan, being burdened (2 Corinthians 5). And we say with Jerusalem: I will bear the wrath of the Lord, because I have sinned against him. Some interpret Δηλαἳστὴν as unhappy and miserable; others understand it as clear and exposed to miseries.

<h2 id='tocuniq65'>(Vers. 16.)</h2>

(Verse 16) When I release the arrows of the worst famine (as is added in the Vulgate), which will be deadly: and when I send them to destroy you, and I will gather famine upon you, and I will break the staff (or rod) of bread. It is evident that we suffer famine and pestilence, and the worst beasts, and whatever other evils in the world, because of our sins. Therefore, that famine, of which mention is made in Ruth (Ruth 1), and in the book of Kings under Elijah (3 Kings 17), when the sky was closed for three years and six months, and under Elisha (4 Kings 6), whose incredible poverty was compensated by sudden abundance, was sent by the judgment of God. Not only was this done then in Jerusalem, but our Jerusalem also experiences it, in which, because of the magnitude of sins, hunger for hearing the word of God is sent first. Then hunger is followed by death; so that those who have not heard may taste and see that the Lord is sweet. (Psalm 33:9), afterwards let us feel: The death of sinners is the worst. (Psalm 22). We have already spoken about the firmament and the staff of bread. (Above, Chapter 4).

<h2 id='tocuniq66'>(Vers. 17.)</h2>

(Verse 17) And I will send famine upon you, and the most evil beasts to destroy you; and pestilence and blood will pass through you, and I will bring the sword upon you. I, the Lord, have spoken. The most evil beasts will be brought upon the deserted land which has been devastated by famine, sword, and disease. These present times also reveal when familiar animals, such as dogs, are driven into a frenzy to attack their masters, and the land is filled with bears, wolves, and all other kinds of beasts. The passing of pestilence and blood signifies disease and the sword. But even in our Jerusalem the worst beasts are sent, when we are handed over to ignominious sufferings, and to a perverse sense and consciousness of sins, which torture and tear apart our souls (Rom. I). Dissensions, heresies, schisms, rivalries, envies, sorrows, detractions, evil desires, and greed, which is the root of all evils (II Cor. XII), are the worst beasts. When they are in us, we deserve to hear: Your transgression shall reprove you (Jeremiah). And we pray and say: Do not deliver the soul of the one confessing to you to the beasts (Ps. LXXIII, 19).


<h2 id='tocuniq67'>(Cap. VI.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter VI—Verse 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face towards the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them. And you shall say: Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God. Thus says the Lord God to the mountains and hills, to the cliffs and valleys. The frequent use of 'Adonai Dominus' in this Prophet seems to be explained briefly for the Greeks and Latins, who do not have knowledge of the Hebrew language. Adonai is one name out of the ten names of God, and it signifies Lord, which we often use to refer to God. Finally, when Sarah called Abraham her lord, she used this name (Gen. XVIII). And where it is said 'O my lord the king', Adonai is written (Exod. XXVIII). Therefore, when the two names, Lord and Lord, are joined together, the first name is common, the second is properly of God, which is called ἄῤῥητον (silent), that is, ineffable, and it was also written on the golden plate that was on the high priest's forehead. But the mountains of Israel, which were occupied by the idols of demons, do not hear and understand their Creator with their ears, but with the command and power of their creator. Just as the sea saw and fled, the Jordan turned back (Ps. CXIII): not with physical eyes which it lacked. And it is said to the sea: Be still, be silent (Mark IV, 39). And the winds are commanded by a word; and it is commanded to a worm, who struck Jonah's shade (Jon. IV). And from the same land it is written: He looks at the earth, and makes it tremble (Ps. CIII, 32). The Prophet speaks to those who indicate that idols are to be destroyed, as well as altars and all the ceremonies they previously served. We can understand that the mountains of Israel and the princes represent those who excelled in power, wisdom, knowledge, and wealth. And it should be noted that while the face is hardened, it is not only directed towards mountains, but also hills, rocks, and valleys, where inferior status and levels of knowledge and wisdom are known. To me, the mountains seem to represent those who have attained perfect knowledge; the hills, who are slightly lower; the rocks, who have no knowledge and rely only on conversation, presuming to interpret Scriptures for themselves, having zeal for God but not according to knowledge (Rom. X; James III); but the valleys are called the least in the Church, who are both inferior in life and knowledge, yet do not depart from the assembly of the Lord's family. Those who are commanded to hear the word of God, so that each person may understand according to their own measure and understanding what the Lord commands.

<h2 id='tocuniq68'>(Vers. 4, 5.)</h2>

(Verses 4, 5.) Look, I will bring a sword upon you and destroy your high places. I will demolish your altars, and your idols will be shattered. I will cast the slain in front of your idols, and I will scatter the corpses of the children of Israel before your idols. I will also scatter your bones around your altars in all your dwellings. It is said on the mountains of Israel that God will destroy their high places, where people worship false gods, and break down their altars and idols. The worshippers will be killed in front of their temples. The dead bodies will lie where they used to offer sacrifices. Their bones will be scattered not on mountains, but on the hills where they lie, around their altars, and in all the cities and villages of Israel. This, according to the letter. Otherwise, even against those who are exalted in pride, and of whom the Apostle speaks: Knowledge puffeth up, but charity edifieth. (1 Cor. VIII, 1), the sword is drawn, so that all their idols, which they have formed in their minds, may be destroyed and lie dead, and they may feel themselves to be dead, realizing that their idols and fictions are of no use to them. And he says that the bones of mountains are scattered around the altars, indicating that the most courageous among them should be separated from themselves. For it is beneficial for wicked people to be divided from wicked people by perverse knowledge. And just as those who were building a tower with the worst consent were scattered for their own benefit, and their language was divided (Genesis 11), so will the bones of the mountains be scattered, so that they may understand their futile efforts. This is what we have established: 'And I will give the corpses of the children of Israel before the face of your idols,' which is not found in the Septuagint.


<h2 id='tocuniq69'>(Vers. 6, 7.)</h2>

(Verses 6, 7) The cities will be deserted, and the high places will be demolished; your altars will be scattered and your idols will cease to exist; your temples will be broken down and your works will be destroyed. And the slain will fall among you, and you will know that I am the Lord. The clear reason why the cities of the mountains are to be deserted is this: so that the high places, altars, and idols may be destroyed, and the temples may perish, and all worship of idols may cease; and let the slain fall in the midst of the mountains; and let them know that He alone is the Lord. Through which occasion is given to us, to follow more closely spiritual understanding, so that the cities of heretics, which are interpreted as Churches, and the lofty pride of them, and the altars of perverse doctrines be shattered, and the idols perish, which they had feigned to themselves in their own hearts, and the shrines be crushed, not temples, which have risen up against the temple of the Lord, and are called in Greek language τεμένη, that is, shrines and temples, and all the works of the mountains be crushed, which are not the works of God, but of the teachers of false knowledge. And when the slain shall fall among the mountains, either those whom the mountains themselves have slain, or the religious men who have killed them in their wickedness for their own salvation: then shall be the end of the proud mountains, that they may know that He is the Lord. And it may happen that from one people of the mountains of Israel, when others are slain, the others may come to know. For when the pestilence has struck, the fool will be wiser." }

<h2 id='tocuniq70'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Verse 8) And I will leave among you those who have escaped the sword among the nations, when I scatter you among the lands, and they will remember me among the freed captives to whom they were led captive. That which the Lord speaks to Elijah: I have left for myself seven thousand men who have not bent the knee to Baal (3 Kings 19:18); and the Apostle Paul writes: And now in this present time there is a remnant according to the election of grace, 59 who have been saved (Romans 11:5), which can be applicable to this chapter. And indeed the Apostles, who were of the seed of Israel and had fled the sword, were reserved for this reason, that they might be dispersed into the lands and preach the Gospel among the Gentiles, and be remembered among the Gentiles as God's people, among whom they were living in the time of captivity. And this can also be said, that some of those reserved from the captivity of Judah were reserved for the purpose of proclaiming his name among the Gentiles and proclaiming his power. The peoples of heretics who were able to escape the sword of their destruction and the worst faction that had been stirred up against God, dispersed here and there, will remember the name of God, by repenting and they will rejoice by considering themselves captured by ecclesiastical men.

<h2 id='tocuniq71'>(Vers. 9, 10.)</h2>

(Verses 9, 10.) Because I have broken their hearts by committing adultery and departing from me, and their eyes commit adultery after their idols. And they will be displeased with themselves for the evil they have done in all their abominations. And they will know that I, the Lord, have not spoken in vain, to bring this evil upon them. Many things from this chapter in the Septuagint are omitted, and it is changed. I swore to the heart of the one committing adultery: therefore we have put forth: I have broken their hearts by committing adultery. He swore and decreed to do what he demonstrated by his actions; whether he has corrupted his heart by fornication and turned away from God, of whom the Lord speaks through Hosea: They are seduced by the spirit of fornication (Hosea IV, 12). And they fornicate with their eyes after idols, through whose windows it is said that death has entered. For this reason, in the book of Daniel, two elders ordered Susanna to be revealed, so that they could enjoy the beauty of her naked body (Dan. XIII). And it was not in vain that the Lord spoke, in order to bring about evil or evils, when those who were subject to his sentence turned to repentance. But if the heart is hard and untamable, not even feeling the penalties of correcting kindness, it is said to them: I struck your children without cause: you did not receive discipline. (Jeremiah 2:30). And it is also profitable for heretics that their hearts be broken, the worst treasure of perverse teachings, because they have turned away from the Lord, and their eyes commit adultery, pursuing their own inventions. Those who, when they have been reminded of the Lord, will be displeased with themselves in all their abominations, and understanding the truth of true faith, will know that He is the Lord. Therefore, he often brings tribulation, which seems destructive and harmful to the patient, in order that they may repent.

<h2 id='tocuniq72'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11.) Thus says the Lord God: Strike your hand, and stamp your foot, and say: Alas! for all the abominations of the evil house of Israel. The Prophet is commanded to show the magnitude of sins with his hands, feet, and words, so that by the gesture of his body and the indignation of his voice, he may display the appearance of one astounded, amazed, and weeping. For just as when we perceive something new and remarkable, we tremble both in body and soul, so much so that we applaud with our hands, and stamp our feet on the ground, and bend our voice to weeping, in the same way, now, the prophet seeing with the eyes of his soul the coming punishments, speaks of all the abominations of the evil house of Israel that follow. We strike spiritually with the hand, when we separate ourselves from evil deeds. We tread with the foot, when we do not walk the path of sinners. We lament and weep, when we are displeased with what is happening. What is shown by the word, alas. For which Aquila interpreted as ἂ ἂ, Symmachus σχετλίασον, which means lament or wail. LXX and Theodotion εὖγε, which is more of an insult than a lament.

Those who will perish by sword, famine, and plague. This is the cause of mourning, because the inhabitants of the mountains, and the worshippers of altars and idols will perish by sword, famine, and plague. Those who are led astray by various errors, and change their faith daily, are carried along by every wind of doctrine: they are struck down by the sword, and divided into factions, abandoning the unity of the Church's faith. But whoever does not have spiritual food, dies of hunger, not knowing Him who said: I am the life (John XIV, 6). Furthermore, one who is devoted to either individual or multiple vices cannot be separated from them, as it once fell due to a certain ancient pestilence (alternatively called uterine pestilence).

<h2 id='tocuniq73'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(V. 12) He who is far away will die from the plague; but he who is near will fall by the sword, and he who remains and is surrounded by famine will die, and I will pour out my anger upon them. He who escapes the siege of the city and migrates to the desert will die from the plague; but he who is near will fall by the sword of the enemy. And he whom the enemy army surrounds will die from hunger and lack, and in all these things the anger of God will be fulfilled, so that those who remain may know that He is the Lord. Whoever departs from the Church will immediately die by the plague. Whoever seems free and diligent will be struck by the sword of their enemies if they do not take caution. Whoever is satisfied with simple faith behaves like a beast and does not make progress in any good work. They are not imitators of the ant, which prepares and gathers food in the harvest. This person will die of hunger and will be filled with the wrath of the Lord in all these things.

<h2 id='tocuniq74'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13.) And you shall know that I am the Lord, when your slain ones shall be among your idols, around your altars on every high hill, on all the mountaintops, under every green tree, and under every leafy oak, the place where they offered pleasing aroma to all their idols. It is clear from the text itself, and it does not require interpretation, that the army of Israel was cut down in the mountains of Israel and on the high hills, among the very altars and groves of the idols, which are called green trees. They were punished where they had sinned. According to the anagoge, let us follow the proposed order. When the masters of the heretics have been crushed and overcome by the ecclesiastical men who are instructed in the knowledge of the Scriptures, we see them lying dead among the idols they had invented, as well as those who exalted themselves against the knowledge of God, lying low in the mountains and hills beneath every leafy tree; those who had grandiose words and the shadow of leaves, but not the fruit of good works; those who were under every leafy oak tree that does not bear the fruit of men, but of pigs: where they burned fragrant incense not to God, but to their idols. And they could not say what is written about Noah: 'The Lord smelled the pleasing aroma' (Gen. VIII, 21): and what Paul says: 'We are the pleasing aroma of Christ to God in every place' (II Cor. II, 15). But just as a holy odor delights God, so sin is committed by the person from whom that psalm is chanted: 'My wounds stink and fester because of my foolishness' (Ps. XXXVII, 6), he kindles foul incense for his idols. That which we interpreted, in all 62 mountain peaks: and after a little while: And below the entire leafy oak, they left 70.

<h2 id='tocuniq75'>(Vers. 14.)</h2>

(Verse 14) And I will stretch out my hand against them, and I will make the land desolate and waste, from the wilderness of Deblatha, in all their habitations; and they shall know that I am the Lord. O mountains of Israel, when your slain men are among your idols, around every high hill, on all the mountaintops, and under every green tree, and under every thick oak, the place where they offered sweet aroma to all their idols. Then I will stretch out my hand upon them, and make the land a desolation and a waste, from the wilderness of Deblatha, throughout all their habitations; so they shall know that I am the Lord." } Many believe that it is the same place, about which it is written in Jeremiah: 'And they took Zedekiah in the desert that is near Jericho, and all his army fled from him. And when they had taken the king, they brought him to the king of Babylon in Riblah, which is in the land of Hamath' (Jer. XXXIX, 5). It can also be called Deblatha or Reblatha, due to the close similarity between the Hebrew letters Daleth and Res, which are distinguished by a small apex. But according to mystical understanding, the Lord extended His hand over all those who had been deceived by heretical error, in order to make their land, which is interpreted as the Church, desolate from the desolation of Deblatha, which in our language means 'mass of figs' and 'bunch of figs' compacted together, so that after experiencing a simulated sweetness, which was not the cultivated land, but the wilderness, they may discover bitterness and then realize that He is the Lord. Honey indeed drips from the lips of a harlot, who for a time fattens the throats of those who eat, and afterwards is found to be bitter with gall (Proverbs 5:3-4). This also signifies the two baskets of figs, which were placed in Jeremiah in front of the temple (Jeremiah 24): one of good figs, and one of bad figs: of which one is referred to the Church of Christ, the other to the congregation of the wicked.

<h2 id='tocuniq76'>(Cap. VII.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter VII, Verses 1, 2.) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: And you, son of man, thus says the Lord God of the land of Israel: The end, the end has come upon the four corners of the earth. These corners of the world we have interpreted as the East and the West, the South and the North. Concerning these corners, Isaiah also speaks: Lord, from the corners or ends of the earth we have heard wonders (Isaiah 24:16), which were carried out throughout the whole world by the apostles. And it is written about the saints: 'If you sleep among the middle ranks of the silver-winged clergy, and the back of the dove is pale with gold' (Ps. 67:14). Therefore, when the Lord approached and saw Jerusalem, he wept and said: 'How many times have I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were not willing!' (Matthew 23:37). This is he who, in the song of Deuteronomy, spread his wings and received them, and carried them on his shoulders' (Deut. 32). There are certain spiritual wings of the earth, by which we fly up to heavenly things. There are four types of believers: the house of Aaron, the house of Levi, the house of Israel, and those who fear the Lord. Concerning them the Psalmist sings: House of Israel, bless the Lord; house of Aaron, bless the Lord; house of Levi, bless the Lord; you who fear the Lord, bless the Lord (Psalm 134:19-21). In Aaron, there is the priesthood; in Levi, there are the priests and ministers; in Israel, there is the entire people; in those who fear the Lord, there are the converted proselytes. However, we believe that after the threat of the mountains of Israel, the prophetic message is directed to all the land of Israel, whether it be the ten or twelve tribes: and the prophet does not predict future events, but rather sees the impending captivity. For in the fifth year of the reign of Zedekiah, Ezekiel began to prophesy to the captives in Babylon; and in the ninth year, Nebuchadnezzar came and besieged Jerusalem, and he took it in the eleventh year of Zedekiah. From which it is clear that the end has come and is approaching, not over mountains and hills and rocks and valleys, but over the four corners of the earth from every part of Israel: not all of the earth: for if he had said that, it could be believed of the whole world; but simply of the earth, which signifies the Israelites. For thus he had begun: Thus says the Lord God of the land of Israel: The end has come, the end has come upon the four corners of the earth.

<h2 id='tocuniq77'>(Vers. 3, 4.)</h2>

(V. 3, 4.) Now my anger is upon you, and I will unleash my fury upon you, and I will judge you according to your ways, and I will bring all your abominations against you. 64 And my eye will not spare you, and I will have no mercy: but I will place your ways upon you, and your abominations will be in your midst: and you will know that I am the Lord. In this chapter the order has been changed and confused according to the LXX Interpreters, so that the first are now the last, and the last, or the first or middle, are transferred to the extremes. From this, following the order of truth, we have set forth the Hebrew text itself and other interpreters. So the speech is directed towards the land of Israel, that the end and consummation may come upon it, and the Lord may send forth his anger upon it, not an unjust anger, but one that comes solely from indignation; but it is full of equity and reason, so that he may judge it according to its ways and show it all its abominations: so that he may remember his works and understand what evil he has done. But when he says, 'My eye will not spare you, and I will have no compassion,' like a most merciful physician who cuts away putrid flesh and cauterizes diseased wounds, he does not spare in order to spare; he does not show mercy in order to show greater mercy; lest any rottenness and corrupting flesh remaining in the body should corrupt it. The Lord strikes those whom he loves, and he chastises every son whom he receives (Hebrews XII, 6). To understand this is: 'I will strike, and I will heal' (Deuteronomy XXXII, 39). For every medicine has bitterness at the time, but afterward the fruits of pain are shown in health. Such a thing is also spoken by God through Amos: For I have known you from all the tribes of the earth, therefore I will avenge all your sins. For the Lord knows those who are his. And concerning his ways (or goings out), it is said (2 Timothy 2), I will place abominations and blemishes in the midst of it: so that the former sins may be placed before the eyes of the sinner, who is punished for his health. And when the Lord does this, those who have been oppressed will know that He is the Lord. This is what is meant by the following testimony: 'I will avenge Jacob according to his ways and repay him according to his deeds' (Hosea 12:2).

<h2 id='tocuniq78'>(Vers. 5, 6.)</h2>

(Ver. 5, 6.) Thus says the Lord God: One affliction, behold, comes: the end comes, the end comes. It has awakened against you, behold, it comes. Constriction comes upon you, who dwell in the land. These are not found in the Septuagint, but in their edition of the translation of Theodotion, they have been added under asterisks. But let us follow the Hebrew. Instead of affliction, which according to Symmachus, who interpreted it as κάκωσιν for the sake of clarity, we have put: and in Hebrew and in Greek it is written κακία, or πονηρία: that is, malice. It is said (Al. Dicit) that the final time of the sins of the land of Israel has come: so that it may no longer escape the sentence of God, which it has deserved for a long time. And because it had not yet fully committed its sins, therefore the punishment was delayed; according to that which is written: For the sins of the Amorites are not yet complete (Gen. XV, 16) . Hence the Lord also said to the Jews: And you, he says, fill up the measure of your fathers (Matt. XXIII, 32) . Therefore, misery comes to you; affliction comes, and captivity comes. And lest you think I am threatening future things, I show with my finger and demonstrate. Behold, it comes, the end comes, the end comes. He who until now seemed to be sleeping and resting to you, suddenly woke up against you and arose. Constriction comes, which in Hebrew is called Sephphira, and which Aquila interpreted as προσκόπησιν, that is, contemplation and foresight, which you always fear will come to you in a timid manner; and which Theodotion interpreted as πλοκὴν, that is, the order and connection of all evils. Furthermore, what is said about you who dwell on earth, we must take according to the Book of Revelation by John: Woe to all who dwell on earth (Rev. 8:13). For the holy one is not an inhabitant of the earth, but a stranger and a pilgrim; and he says: I am a stranger and a pilgrim, like all my fathers (Ps. 38:13). Therefore even Abraham the Hebrew, that is, the crosser and the sojourner, is mentioned; hastening to pass from the present age to the future. We can interpret this place spiritually against the Jews, upon whom comes the end and consummation from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah, son of Barachiah, whom they killed between the temple and the altar (Matt. 23). For as long as they did not lay hands on the Son of God, the sentence of the Lord slumbered and was delayed. But when they killed the heir, so that the inheritance might perish, then all the order of miseries and perplexity awoke against them; for they did not seek heavenly things, but desired to cling to earthly things.


<h2 id='tocuniq79'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7) The time has come, the day of slaughter is near, and not the day of glory of the mountains. The word 'Adarim' in Hebrew, which we divided into two words, 'Ad' and 'Arim', is interpreted by Theodotion as 'the glory of the mountains'. Symmachus translates it as 'the time of restoration' and says: 'And the time is near: the day of haste, not of restoration.' The Septuagint, on the other hand, translates it as: 'The time has come, the day is approaching, not with disturbance or pains.' Theodotio: The time has come, the day of hunger is near and not the glory of the mountains. It is a time of slaughter, and even now famine is evident among the Jewish people who have neither prophets nor the word of God by which the souls of believers are nourished. But understand, O mountains, those who have knowledge of the Scriptures. Concerning them, it is also said in another place: 'You shine wondrously from the eternal mountains' (Psalm 75:5). Moreover, the Seventy who said: 'Not with disturbance, and not with pains,' signify that they have only such ignorance of God and blindness of mind, so that they are neither disturbed by their sins nor tormented by the pains of repentance.


<h2 id='tocuniq80'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Verse 8) Now I will pour out my anger on you and unleash my fury against you; I will judge you according to your ways and punish you for all your detestable practices. If we calculate from the fifth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin to the ninth year of the reign of King Zedekiah, when Nebuchadnezzar came and besieged Jerusalem, it will be three and a half years. Therefore, it is rightly said: Now I will pour out my anger on you. I will never predict what is coming to you, nor will I threaten things that are far in the future: now I will unleash my rage upon you. This rage and anger are not without judgment: but to bring your ways upon your own head, and to make you feel all your abominations. However, we can also speak about the ultimate captivity, that after the killing of Christ, when the end came to them and sin awoke against them, that was fulfilled which is written: Now the wrath of God has come upon them to the end (I Thess. I, 16). When Jerusalem was surrounded by Titus and Vespasian and its desolation came, and it was fulfilled: 'Behold, your house will be left to you desolate' (Matthew XXIII, 38). Then they were judged according to their ways and blasphemies, by which they denied the Lord; and they felt the wrath of God: and all His indignation was poured out upon them, and they received the punishment for their crimes, so that the destruction of the temple may remain until the end.


<h2 id='tocuniq81'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9.) And my eye will not spare, nor will I have mercy: but I will impose (or give) your ways to you, and your abominations will be in your midst, and you will know that I am the Lord who strikes. He adds that the causes of severity and harshness, or as heretics suppose, the cruelty of God, in not sparing His eye nor showing mercy, saying: I will give you your ways, and your abominations will be in your midst; that you may feel what you have done, and seeing your abominations either before you or placed in the midst of all, you may correct your error with repentance, and by departing from your former works, when you hate what you have done, then you will realize that He Himself is the Lord. (Heb. XII). He strikes in order to correct and discipline every son whom he receives.

<h2 id='tocuniq82'>(Vers. 10, 11.)</h2>

(Verse 10, 11.) Behold the day, behold it comes, the contraction has gone forth: the rod has blossomed, pride has sprouted. Iniquity has risen in the rod of impiety, not from them, and not from the people, nor from their noise: and there will be no rest for them. LXX: Behold the day gives birth, behold the end comes, the complex has gone forth, and the rod has blossomed, pride has sprouted, injustice has been aroused, and it will crush the strength of the wicked, and not with disturbance nor with haste, and they are not from them, nor is beauty in them. The day has been shortened, he says, and the impending captivity is near. The rod that threatened you for a long time has flourished, and it has given birth to the fruit of wounds. Your pride has sprouted what you deserved, so that the injustice, which is not from a pitiful people, nor from those who are led like dumb animals by their masters, nor from their clamor and noise, in which they cried out in vain, deceived by the priests and Pharisees, may rise up against your wicked rod with a united voice and say: 68 Crucify, crucify such a one (John 19:6). Where they will not have rest, but eternal captivity. Moreover, the Seventy interpreted it in the sense in which it is written: for you do not know what the coming day may bring forth (Prov. XXVII, 1). They said: Behold, the day brings forth what it had conceived long before: and the end has come, and the bond that embraces all your evil deeds shall be broken and shall no longer imprison, or as Symmachus interpreted it, inspection, so that God may see all that you have done and consider your works, and render to each one according to what they deserve. But in that which they themselves have also translated similarly, the rod has flourished, as we can use that testimony: Do not take the rod away from your son (Prov. XIII, 13). And the Apostle: What do you want? Shall I come to you with a rod, or in love and a spirit of gentleness (I Cor. IV, 21)? But even God resounds in the mouth of the Psalmist: I will visit their iniquities with a rod and their sins with scourges: but I will not take away my mercy from them (Psal. LXXXVIII, 33, 34). Therefore the Lord visits and strikes, so that all pride, which has long been hidden and enclosed, may arise and be revealed; and injury may be aroused against the arising and burgeoning pride, and the strength of the wicked may be crushed, not with disturbance or haste. For the end of a flourishing rod is healing and correction, which does not come by merit to those who are corrected, nor by the beauty that they do not possess in themselves, but by the mercy of the Lord. This passage is difficult and differs greatly between the Hebrew and the Septuagint, with many additions from Theodotion's edition, in order to make it appear more coherent.

<h2 id='tocuniq83'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(Verse 12.) The time has come, the day is near. It is not only said to Jerusalem that the time of captivity has come and the day has approached when it will be besieged by the Babylonian army; but also to the one who rejoiced in his built and expanded barns, the Lord speaks: Foolish one, tonight your soul will be taken away from you. And the things that you have prepared, whose will they be? (Luke 11:20) This is also what the Apostle says: The time, he says, has been shortened (1 Corinthians 7:29). And in another place: For the figure of this world passeth away (Ibid., 31). It should be noted that He did not postpone this for the future, but spoke of the present, saying, 'passeth away,' and daily the figure of the world slips by. For it never remains in the same state; but the figure of things that grow and decay always flies by and changes. Hence also the Lord says: Heaven and earth shall pass away (Matth. XXIV, 35).
