But if these things, in which all that is in the world is contained, pass away and pass by, what can be perpetual in human affairs?


<h2 id='tocuniq84'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13) The one who buys should not rejoice, and the one who sells should not mourn. It is natural to rejoice in the acquisition of possessions, but to mourn in their sale. However, in the face of slavery and captivity, both joy and sorrow are in vain. Hence the Apostle says: 'Time is shortened.' Moreover, those who have wives should live as though they do not have them, and those who weep should live as though they do not weep, and those who rejoice should live as though they do not rejoice, and those who buy should live as though they do not possess, and those who use this world should live as though they do not make use of it (1 Corinthians 7:29-31).' For they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark, and the flood came, and destroyed them all, as the Lord said in the Gospel (Matthew 24).

Because his anger was against all his people. This is found in the Septuagint. For 'populus' can denote both a multitude and a crowd according to the Hebrew interpretation; for it signifies 'Amona'. And the reason is clear, because therefore the one who buys should not rejoice, and the one who sells should cease to mourn, because the anger of God will soon come upon the whole multitude of the land of Judaea, or Jerusalem. For it is understood from the preceding statements, in which it is written: Thus says the Lord God of the land of Israel, etc.


<h2 id='tocuniq85'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13) Because the one who sells will not return to what he has sold. This is spoken according to the Hebrew custom. For every sale returned to the seller in the fiftieth year of remission, which among them is called the Jubilee. Therefore, before the year of remission arrives, when possessions return to their previous owners, captivity will arise, which will take away the whole custom of the city. Moreover, what the Seventy translated, 'Because the one who buys will not return to the seller,' since it does not agree with the history at all, according to the allegory, can have this meaning: that we say that the one who was deceived by the error of a heretic, when he understands the deception of the teacher, will not at all return to the seller, that is, to the teacher, but despises and disregards him.


And even in their lifetime, their life will not return to them because the vision will not return to the whole multitude. Just as possession does not revert to the previous owner when the city is destroyed, so too the prophetic vision and warning that is directed to the whole multitude of the city will in no way return and will be in vain. Rather, it will be fulfilled in the remaining few to whom the prophecy is directed. He says this in order to indicate the impending captivity, so that they would not say according to their usual manner: This vision will be for many days and will be fulfilled after a long time. We can say this, that after the prophetic vision has departed from the Jews: For the law and the prophets were until John the Baptist (Matt. 11:13), after the killing of the Savior, it will never return to them, nor will they deserve to have prophets anymore. And significantly, he says, the vision will not return to the whole multitude. Therefore, it will return to those who believed in the Lord from the Jews, namely the apostles, and the remnants of the Jewish people who were saved from Israel. But these two verses are not found in the Septuagint edition.

And a man will not be strengthened in the wickedness of his life. LXX: And a man will not obtain in the eyes of his life. And the sense according to the Hebrew is: His wickedness will not profit a man, nor will it provide any strength to him. According to the Septuagint: And a man, who desired what he thought was precious in the world, will not obtain it; but with freedom perishing, all that is beautiful will be lost. However, the ambiguity of the Hebrew letters Yod and Vav, which are distinguished only by their size, caused some to interpret wickedness and others to interpret eyes.


<h2 id='tocuniq86'>(Vers. 14.)</h2>

(Verse 14) Sound the trumpet, let everyone prepare. LXX: Sound the trumpet, and judge all things. We read in many places about the sound and noise of trumpets, such as there: 'Raise your voice like a trumpet' (Isaiah 58:1); and elsewhere: 'Blow the trumpet at the new moon, at the appointed time on our festive day' (Psalm 81:3); and in the Apostle: 'For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of an archangel, and with the trumpet of God' (1 Thessalonians 4:16). And in the Gospel: Do not sound the trumpet before you (Matt. 6:2). And the history of Numbers tells of trumpets made of gold and silver (Num. 10 and 31), which are compared to prophetic speech and the teaching of the Apostles. It is now commanded that everyone be prepared for battle at the sound of the trumpet and the horn. Moreover, what the Seventy have said, 'Judge all things,' there is no doubt that it applies to the authority of the apostles. After the trumpet of the angels has sounded, they will judge in twelve thrones, over the twelve tribes of Israel. Of whom Paul was speaking: We will judge angels (I Cor. VI, 3); and elsewhere: The world will be judged in you (Ibid., 2). However, according to the current sense, those who are entrusted with this office are commanded sarcastically to blow the trumpet, so that everyone may prepare against the army of Babylon.

And there is no one who goes to battle. For my anger is over all his multitude. And these are not found in the Septuagint. God had commanded (Num. X) that the trumpet sound to prepare the army, which could resist the strength of the Babylonians; but it was of no avail to command, since there is no one in the people who dares to go forth to war. Therefore, the people is weakened and lacks the strength to fight, because all the anger of God is over all his multitude, understood to be the city of Jerusalem, or the land of Judah. But both in our land and in Jerusalem, when either public persecution or the various incentives of vices try to overcome us, the teachers sing in vain and hurry to prepare us for war, when there is no strength in the people, which has been taken away on account of the sins deserving the anger of God.

<h2 id='tocuniq87'>(Vers. 15, 16.)</h2>

(Vers. 15, 16.) The sword is outside, pestilence and famine are inside. Those who are in the field will die by the sword; and those in the city will be devoured by pestilence and famine. And those who flee from them will be safe, and they will be like doves of the valleys trembling on the mountains. Each one in their own wickedness. Seventy, the doves of the valleys, or as Theodotion translated, those contemplating, were completely silent. And what we have interpreted, everyone is trembling: each one in their own wickedness, as Theodotion translated it, everyone murmuring, each one in their own wickedness; so that under the metaphor of meditating doves, it signifies that each person from the people mourns their own sin, and understands and feels why they suffer these things. But we have discussed above the three parts of others who die in the city, namely, those who perish from pestilence and famine, those whom the sword kills outside, and those who escape captivity by flight: of whom he who is saved will pass over to the mountains, and, like murmuring doves, he will tremble while bewailing his sins. And tropologically (to take it in a moral sense), we must interpret that he who is in the field and the countryside, outside the borders of the Lord's city, which is interpreted as the Church, will be struck by the enemy's sword. But he who lives negligently in the city and does not prepare food for himself, of which it is written in Proverbs: 'He who works his land will be filled with breads.' (Prov. XII, 11.) This one will die from famine and pestilence. However, only a few who have avoided the sword of heretics or the hunger of their own laziness will be saved, unless they are in the mountains and take on the wings of a dove, and fly away and find rest. These doves, as long as they are in the valleys, tremble and fear everything: we are commanded to imitate their innocence, of which it is written in the Psalm: 'If you sleep among the ranks, the wings of a silver dove, and its hindparts in the whiteness of gold.' (Ps. 67:14) In whose likeness the Holy Spirit descended and remained upon the Lord and Savior. And rightly according to Theodotion we shall call the meditating dove (Matth. III), he who meditates day and night in the law of the Lord, and of whom it is written: The mouth of the just will meditate wisdom (Ps. XXXVI, 30).

<h2 id='tocuniq88'>(Vers. 17.)</h2>

(Verse 17.) All hands shall be dissolved, and all knees shall flow with water. And they shall gird themselves with sackcloth, and terror shall cover them. Before the knees flowing with water, Seventy shall be carried away, their thighs shall be defiled with moisture. But when all shall tremble and flee to the mountains, all hands shall be dissolved, and no one will be able to resist the enemies, and with the magnitude of fear, urine shall pollute the knees, and the bladder will not be able to hold back the flowing waters. They will gird themselves with sackcloth, and trembling will possess everything. This happened among that people, not only among the Babylonians, but also among the Romans, when the wrath of God came upon them to the very end. Moreover, it happened in our own Judea, in which is the confession of the Lord, when transgressions have multiplied, and the love of many has grown cold, all the hands of good works will be dissolved, and all knees, or rather thighs, will flow with the waters of those who sought unlawful unions, and whom Scripture names 'eunuchs', that is, those enduring a seminal discharge and are unclean. Therefore, those who are such should gird themselves with the sackcloth of repentance and fear the impending judgment. And he who does so will deserve to hear Isaiah saying: Strengthen the weak hands and make firm the feeble knees (Isaiah 35:3).

<h2 id='tocuniq89'>(Vers. 18.)</h2>

(Verse 18) In every face there is confusion, and in every head there is baldness. The redness of the face is a sign of shame, and the consciousness of sins shines on the face: and the hope of salvation is when shame follows the sin. Therefore, it was said to her who boasted in her sins with a hard heart: Your face has become like that of a prostitute, you do not know how to blush (Jer. III, 3). Baldness of the head is also a sign of sorrow, when the hair loses its beauty, and we lose the beauty of our hair. And it is also said about Jerusalem: You will have baldness for the ornament of your head, because of your deeds (Isaiah III, 17). And another prophet says: All heads will be shaved in every place, and every beard will be cut (Jeremiah XLVIII, 37). Micah also says about the same Jerusalem: Shave and cut the hair of the sons of your pleasures, enlarge your baldness like an eagle (Micah I, 16). And it is ordered to have baldness over the dead. But only the holy ones, that is, the Nazirites, and those who have deserved to reach the priesthood of the Lord, do not shave their heads (Num. 6). For they do not have the works of death, nor are they unclean, because they are Nazirites, that is, the holy ones of the Lord. But if anyone has died in their presence, all the previous days will not be counted as their sanctification. Samuel, the holy one of God, possessed the eternal ornaments of the head: and he heard this from the Song of Songs: Your locks are black as a raven's (Cant. 5:11)."    } Furthermore, Samson, because he lost his hair, lost his strength (Judges 16): and gradually, as his hair grew back, his former strength returned so that he killed more in his death than in his life. But Elisha, though he was bald in body, still enjoyed the curls of the head because he was a Nazirite of the Lord. Hence, little boys, because they were little and had not yet reached the age of manhood, mocked his baldness and said, 'Go up, bald head! Go up, bald head!' (2 Kings 2:23). 74 of them were torn apart by the bites of wild beasts; their leaps and the woods were their dwelling place.


<h2 id='tocuniq90'>(Vers. 19.)</h2>

(Verse 19) Their silver will be thrown outside, and their gold will be as dung. LXX: Their silver will be thrown on the streets, and their gold will be despised. When forced to flee and be captured, they will throw away their riches and the weight of gold and silver on the streets, desiring only to save their own lives, lest they be burdened with what was once luxury. Otherwise, according to the anagoge, all the silver of the captives and those fleeing from Jerusalem will be thrown on the streets, on the wide and spacious road that leads to death, because they have forsaken the narrow path of salvation. But every gold will be despised, or considered as dung and filthiness. For he cannot have purity, who is outside the Church of the Lord.

Their silver and their gold will not be able to save them on the day of the Lord's wrath. And this is not found in the Septuagint. But there is no doubt that during the time of siege and famine, it does not deliver those hungry for gold and silver: and their teeth are crushed like the hardest stones with this most precious metal. Finally, it follows:

They will not satisfy their souls, and their bellies will not be filled. In the presence of evil, we have learned that many rich people, exhausted by poverty, have had the outcome of beggars, between silk, gems, and the weights of gold and silver. But their silver and gold, those who are outside the Church, are not able to free the souls of the possessors on the day of the Lord's anger, but it shows that they will have eternal hunger and suffer with empty stomachs, as that testimony says: The redemption of a man's soul is his own riches (Prov. XIII, 8). Our true riches are those that the truth of Christ has taught us (Luke 16), who commanded us to make friends for ourselves with unrighteous mammon, so that they may receive us into eternal dwellings.

Because a scandal of their wickedness has occurred. Therefore, he says, neither the soul will be satisfied, nor the stomach filled, because this very gold and silver has become a stumbling block of their crimes. But it signifies idols, which are made of gold and silver, condemn their own craftsmen. For which reason the Seventy translated it: because the tortures of their wickedness were, so that they should be tormented in their own wickedness, and understand that they have turned God's gifts into blasphemy.


<h2 id='tocuniq91'>(Vers. 20.)</h2>

(Verse 20) And they have placed the ornament of their necklaces in pride, and they have made images of their abominations and idols from it. LXX: They have placed the chosen ones of the world in pride, and they have placed images of their abominations and stumbling blocks from them. And those things which I had given as adornment to those who possess them and riches, they have turned them into pride, so that from those things they could liberate their own soul through acts of charity and good works, they had material for arrogance. Finally, they made idols out of gold and silver, and turned my gifts into the images of demons. Furthermore, as the Seventy say, they put the chosen ones of the world into pride, referring to gold and silver, which is considered the most valuable thing in the world. And that which follows: Let us know that the addition by Theodotion is easy to understand according to the allegory, that the heretics placed gold and silver, the senses and the teachings of the Scriptures that have been chosen by the world, and which have been given to us as adornment, as fuel and material for pride, and made images of various teachings and abominations and their offenses from them, so that through what they could worship and adore God, they would offend God by means of these.


<h2 id='tocuniq92'>(Vers. 21.)</h2>

(Verse 21.) Because of this, I gave them over to uncleanness, and I will give them into the hands of strangers to plunder, and to the wicked of the earth for a spoil, and they shall defile it. LXX: Because of this, I gave them over to uncleanness, and I will deliver them into the hands of strangers, to plunder them, and to the pestilential of the earth for a spoil, and they shall pollute it. For they made for themselves images of their abominations and of their idols from the gold and silver and ornaments that I had given them; therefore, I gave them over to uncleanness and to excrement. For which Symmachus translated, unwilling to express the filth of idols. And he said, I will deliver these into the hands of the enemy, so that they may plunder everything,and not so much defile, as demonstrate that which seemed to be most holy before to be contaminated. We too are handed over into the hands of enemies and strangers to God, when we make our ornaments images of demons, and all our glory is possessed by the impious or pestilent of the earth, so that they may subject us to their power.


<h2 id='tocuniq93'>(Vers. 22.)</h2>

(Verse 22.) And I will turn my face away from them, and they will violate my sanctuary, and emissaries will enter into it (either as the Septuagint has translated rashly, or as Symmachus and Theodotio have translated, by breaking in and being pestilential) and defile it. For when, he says, because of the previous abominations of the people, I turn my face away from them, and I will not judge them worthy in my eyes, then they will violate my sanctuary, which signifies the Holy of Holies, for which the Septuagint has translated 'visitation' (so that they might demonstrate the presence of God in the holy things) and the wicked and pestilential ones will break in: except for the priests and the high priest, no one else dared to enter. What we know from the Babylonians, and from King Antiochus and Gnaeus Pompeius, and finally was done under Vespasian and Titus, when the temple was captured and destroyed, and all the things that the following prophecy encompasses. God also turns His face away from our evil deeds: and because His face is turned away, therefore the secret of God is violated, so that the pestilence may enter for the priests and saints of God, and contaminate everything: so that the place that should have been holy becomes a place of impurity, according to the Gospel: My Father's house shall be called a house of prayer: but you have made it a den of thieves (Matthew 21:13).


<h2 id='tocuniq94'>(Vers. 23.)</h2>

(Verse 23.) Make a conclusion, for the land is full of bloodshed, and the city is full of injustice. LXX: And I will bring disturbance, for the land is full of bloodshed, and the city is full of iniquities. The Hebrew word 'Arethic' (), Aquila interpreted it as 'conclusion', Symmachus and Theodotion as 'crucifixion'. For this reason, the Seventy put 'φυρμὸν', which we translate as 'disturbance'. Therefore, O prophet, conclude my anger against the land of Judah and against the city of Jerusalem in a short discourse, so that just as the land is full of bloodshed, for all are judged in blood, pouring out innocent blood: which the Scripture also records that the Jews did to Naboth's person. Thus their own blood is founded, and the city is shown to be full of iniquity. For the city of Jerusalem is also filled with the blood of the prophets from one gate to another, even under Manasseh's reign (1 Kings 21). And a conclusion, disturbance, and affliction will come upon them, so that no one can escape the imminent miseries.

<h2 id='tocuniq95'>(Vers. 24.)</h2>

(Verse 24.) And I will bring the worst of the nations, and they will possess their houses. And these are not found in the Septuagint. For priests and prophets, I will bring the worst of all nations, the Babylonians, to possess your houses and to subject you to servitude. But the worst demons will also possess our houses, that is, our souls (for we are the temple of God and the Holy Spirit dwells in us - I Cor. VI), if our land is full of bloodshed and our dwelling is full of wickedness.


And I will make the arrogance of the powerful rest: and their sanctuaries shall be possessed. LXX: And I will turn away the noise of their strength: and their sancta shall be defiled. All arrogance offends God. Therefore, the worst of the nations shall possess the houses of the powerful and the proud, and they shall obtain their sanctuaries, because a defiled place of holiness enters, and its impurity contaminates it. However, it is significant that the sanctuaries of God were polluted and his secret violated, he did not say, they shall possess my sanctuaries, but their sanctuaries: because after the contamination they withdrew from me.


Distress is near. Seventy: Atonement will come. According to the previous order, Aquila and Theodotio are rightly interpreted as distress, and Symmachus as grief. However, the Seventy placed the word of joy in the midst of all the sorrows: so that the mind of the mourner may be sustained, and he may hope for better things amidst adversity, and the Lord may be propitious; of whom it is written: The Lord raises up the downtrodden (Ps. 145:8). But we, following the previous opinion of Symmachus, have joined it with the latter, so as to say:

<h2 id='tocuniq96'>(Vers. 25.)</h2>

(Verse 25.) With the approaching distress, they will seek peace, but it will not be found. This cannot possibly be reconciled with the Septuagint. For if reconciliation comes, how will they seek peace and not find it? Indeed, those who have heard from the apostles will seek peace and not find it, for they did not keep the peace in their house (Matthew 10:12), nor did they let it rest in their minds, but by their evil deeds, they cannot find it. But the peace itself is that which surpasses all understanding (Philippians 4:7), and which the victorious Savior, ascending to the Father, left to the apostles (John 14).


<h2 id='tocuniq97'>(Vers. 26.)</h2>

(Verse 26) Disturbance upon disturbance will come, and hearing upon hearing. LXX: Woe upon woe will be, and message upon message. Just as it is said to the saints: Rejoice, I say again rejoice (Philippians 4:2); and it is written about them: They will go from strength to strength (Psalm 84:7), so that present blessings may abound to future blessings. Similarly, for those upon whom distress comes, and those who have sought peace and have not found it, disturbance will come upon disturbance, or woe upon woe, as it is also written in the Apocalypse: one woe has passed, and behold, another woe is coming quickly (Revelation 9:12). And the one who heard about it will come upon the one who heard about it, and the messenger upon the messenger; according to the blessed Job: While this one was still speaking, another messenger came (Job 1:16), increasing evils with evils, and describing the noise and turmoil of the approaching Babylonians.

And they sought a vision from the Prophet: and the law shall perish from the Priest, and counsel from the elders. Specifically, each individual seeks out specific things. The Prophet seeks prophecies of the future. Interpreting the law is the duty of the Priest. Mature age seeks wise counsel; according to what is written: 'In the council of the saints (or the just) and the congregation, great are the works of the Lord' (Ps. 110:1-2). But these things were not only sought by the prophets, priests, and elders at the time when the Babylonian army was coming against Jerusalem; but they are sought daily in the Churches. If they have lost vision, law and counsel, in vain do they boast of having prophets, priests, and elders.

<h2 id='tocuniq98'>(Vers. 27.)</h2>

(Verse 27.) The king will mourn, and the prince will be clothed in sorrow, or, according to the Septuagint, in death: those who desired something, namely what we have expressed from the Hebrew text, completely remained silent about the king mourning. However, the Holy Scripture commemorates that Zedekiah and all the princes of the people of Judah were consumed with sorrow. And we can, although this may seem blasphemous at first glance, say that the king mourning for our sins and transgressions is Christ, who speaks in the Psalms: 'What profit is there in my blood, when I go down to the pit?' (Psalm 30:10). And when he came near Jerusalem, he wept over it, and said, 'Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to you! How often I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing. (Matthew 23:37)! In addition, the princes will either be apostles in a good way, mourning for sinners, or they will be the opposite, those to whom it is said: 'Hear the word of the Lord, you princes of Sodom!' (Isaiah 1:11). And he shall be clothed, according to the Septuagint, with destruction, he who does not have the armor of God, nor is clothed in Christ. For as many as have been baptized in Christ, have put on Christ (Galatians 3:27).

And the hands of the people of the earth will be troubled, or, according to the Septuagint, dissolved. When there is no vision in the prophet, and knowledge of the Law in the priest, and counsel in the elders; and the king mourns, and the prince is in sorrow, or in destruction, subsequently the hands of the people will be troubled, losing their order, or dissolved, not having ancient strength. And it is rightly said that the people of God, whose hands are troubled, and who do not have a citizenship in heaven, but are people of the earth, of whom it is written: 'Those who depart from you shall be written upon the earth' (Jeremiah 17:13).


I will deal with them according to their ways, and judge them according to their judgments, or as the Septuagint has translated, I will avenge them. God renders to sinners according to their ways, in order to hold to the truth of judgment. However, in the saints, the measure of mercy exceeds. For the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shall be revealed in us (Rom. VIII, 18). For the wages of sin is death (Ibid. VI, 23), which the sinner receives according to their ways and deeds. Moreover, the virtue of the just enjoys the largesse of the Lord, of which Paul speaks: The gift of God is eternal life. And he added: And I will judge them according to their judgments, that Gospel saying sounds: with the judgment you pronounce you will be judged (Matthew 7:1). And the Apostle: For in passing judgment on another you condemn yourself, because you, the judge, practice the very same things (Romans 2:1).

And they shall know that I am the Lord. This verse is often used in this prophet, that the knowledge of God may be followed by punishments and torments, so that those who did not understand through blessings may come to know through sufferings.

<h2 id='tocuniq99'>Book Three</h2>

Book Three

79-80  Nothing long lasts that has faith, and all the past series of times do not profit: unless perhaps it has prepared the support of good works, which always look to the future, indeed to the eternal, and are not limited by any boundaries. The true saying is: All that rises falls, and all that grows old ages. And elsewhere: For there is nothing made by work and hand, which old age does not accomplish and consume. Who would believe that Rome, built with victories from the whole world, would fall, that it would become both mother and tomb to its own people, that the coasts of the whole East, Egypt, and Africa, would be filled with the number of slaves and servants of the once dominant city, that daily Bethlehem, once noble for both sexes and overflowing with all wealth, would receive beggars? Since we are unable to provide assistance to those, we sympathize and join tears to tears: burdened with the task of the holy work, while we do not allow ourselves to see the converging streams without groaning, we have dedicated almost all our effort to explanations in Ezekiel, and we desire to translate the words of the Scriptures into action, and not just speak of holy things, but do them. Therefore, once again reminded by you, O virgin of Christ Eustochium, we resume the interrupted work, and undertaking the third volume, we desire to satisfy your desire: praying for you and all who will read, that they may consider not our abilities, but our intention, one of which is human frailty, the other is a holy will in the Lord.


<h2 id='tocuniq100'>81 (Cap. VIII.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

Chapter 8, Verse 1: And it came to pass in the sixth year, in the sixth month, on the fifth day of the month, I was sitting in my house, and the elders of Judah were sitting before me. In the fifth year of the exile of Jehoiachin, in the fourth month, on the fifth day of the month, a superior vision was given to the prophet. But the vision which we now want to explain occurred in the sixth year of the same king, in the sixth month, on the fifth day of the month. From which it is clear that after a year and two months, these events that are written occurred, and either the prophecy was interrupted for a year and two months, or it was carried out for the entire fourteen months that the previous discourse includes. But in the sixth year and in the sixth month, and on the fifth day of the month, which are numbers referring to the creation of the world, and to the carnal senses, which perceive earthly things and have not yet contemplated heavenly things, the one who understands that the prophecy is directed to the elders of Judah will not be amazed. Among them seventy held censers, and twenty-five worshipped the sun in the temple, and the prophet sat in his house fleeing from the crowd; and the elders of Judah sat before him, either desiring to hear the prophet's words or plotting against him. And by 'elders of Judah' we should understand not those who belonged to the ten tribes of Israel that were previously captured, but rather those who, from the tribe of Judah, were led into captivity with Jechoniah.

<h2 id='tocuniq101'>(Vers. 2.)</h2>

(Verse 2) And the hand of the Lord God fell upon me there. And I saw, and behold, a likeness resembling the appearance of fire, from the appearance of His loins and downward, fire; and from His loins and upward, a splendor resembling the appearance of lightning. The Hebrew language does not contain the word 'man'. However, we have added a vision of the aura, which is not found in the Septuagint, from Theodotion. And because of what we have said, the hand of the Lord fell upon me, as translated by Symmachus. The hand of the Lord came upon me 82 times, which in Hebrew is called Tephphol (). But the hand signifies action, that is, works, so that one may understand the mysteries of the vision. And it should be noted that he does not see the truths themselves, but the likeness of fire, because fire appeared from the loins downward; and from the loins upward, it appeared like the splendor of a vision. For the brightness, which is called Zor in Hebrew, translated the aura to Theodotus, to show the refreshments of God in the heavens. Finally, in the book of Kings, the blessed Elias contemplates the coming of the Lord not in a storm and whirlwind, not in the burning of fire, but in the appearance of a thin and gentle breeze, to prove the gentleness of Almighty God. However, the works of sexual intercourse, which are symbolized in the loins, are purged downward by fire. And the works of virtues, which rise from the loins to the uppermost parts, have splendor and brightness, and yet it is not said that fire reaches all the way to the feet, nor does the brilliance of lightning reach all the way to the head, but it goes downward and upward, so that, depending on their merits, there is one part that extends to this and that member, and another that reaches to those and these. And just as those who attain to the perfection of holiness reach all the way to the summit, so those who are in the depths of sin are to be believed to hold the fiery feet of the wicked.


<h2 id='tocuniq102'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) And a likeness of a hand was sent forth and it took hold of me by the hair of my head. LXX: And the likeness of a hand extended and took me by the fringe of my head. And this likeness of a hand, the hand itself is not extended, for there is nothing corporeal in God. And it appears like a hand, as a member of the human body and familiar, not at all terrifying the one who is assumed and seized. For if it had touched the prophet in the likeness of a snake or any other beast, the very dissimilarity of the limbs would have terrified the one who was assumed." } And the part of the hair is called a κράσπεδον, which means a fringe: one of which is usually taken on the hair, the other on the clothes.

And the spirit lifted me up between the earth and the sky. First, by the likeness of a hand, I am grasped; afterwards, I am lifted up by the spirit, which does not immediately raise me up to heaven, but between the earth and the sky, so that, leaving behind earthly things for a while, I may hasten towards heaven. Moreover, we can also say this, that by virtue of good works, the prophet is grasped by the likeness of God's hand, and by knowledge of spiritual things, he is lifted up by the spirit.


<h2 id='tocuniq103'>(Vers. 4)</h2>

(Verse 4). And he brought me to Jerusalem in the vision of God, near the inner gate that faces north, where the idol of jealousy was located to provoke rivalry. And behold, there the glory of the God of Israel was, according to the vision that I had seen in the plain. LXX: And he brought me to Jerusalem in the vision of God to the entrance of the gateway that faces north, where the statue of the ruler was. And behold, the glory of the Lord God of Israel was there according to the vision that I saw in the plain. But this, which is found in some codices. And in the statue the image of Zel ** is added from Theodotion. The rest similarly. When he says: 'He brought me to Jerusalem in a vision of God,' he shows that he was not transferred in body, but in spirit. According to this vision, we can see both the heavens and the depths of the sea and the underworld, while we embrace the rationalities of each thought. But first he comes to the entrance, which faces the North, so that he may see there the statue of the idol of Zel to provoke emulation; so that he may be able to penetrate to the inner chambers from that place, and behold the rest, which are described afterwards. The history tells that a statue of the idol Baal was placed in the temple of God. This idol is beautifully called the idol of Zel, because it provokes emulation and zeal for the Lord, as it is said in Deuteronomy: 'They have provoked me to jealousy with that which is not God: they have provoked me to anger with their vanities: and I will provoke them to jealousy with those which are not a people' (Deut. XXXII). And because zeal and possession, which is called Cena in Hebrew, are called by the same name, the Seventy have interpreted the statue of Zel as the statue of the possessor. Finally, when Cain was born, his parent said, by God's power, I have obtained a man (Gen. IV, 1), alluding to the possession of a man, and gave the name Cain. And there was the glory of the God of Israel, not because He delighted in such proximity, but to destroy their idol of Zeal and their temple. Therefore, the city and the temple were soon destroyed. And it is written in Isaiah, that a narrow bed cannot hold two, and a short cloak cannot cover both (Isa. XXVIII); the Scripture signifies what the Apostle said: What agreement is there between Christ and Belial? Temple of God and idol (2 Corinthians 7:25).

<h2 id='tocuniq104'>(Vers. 5.)</h2>

(Verse 5) And he said to me, "Son of man, lift up your eyes toward the north." So I lifted up my eyes toward the north, and behold, north of the altar gate, in the entrance, was this idol of jealousy. Because we have set up the idol of jealousy north of the altar gate, seventy elders of Israel, with Jaazaniah the son of Shaphan standing among them, have entered into it. He said, he said to me, either the glory of God, which I had seen in the field, or the spirit that lifted me up between heaven and earth. And he spoke to me, after he had transported me to Jerusalem, and made me see either the city or the temple, and commanded me to lift up my eyes towards the way of the North. For there, a statue of Baal was placed, which he called the idol of Zeli, at the very entrance of the gate. But those who attribute the idol of Zeli, whether to the glory of God or to the spirit, unjustly change the person of the idol, altering the majesty of God.


<h2 id='tocuniq105'>(Vers. 6.)</h2>

(Verse 6.) And he said to me: Son of man, do you see what they are doing? The great abominations that the house of Israel is committing here, to cause me to withdraw from my sanctuary? And yet, when you turn back, you will see even greater abominations. Do not think that I am unjustly leaving the temple and abandoning the city, look at what they are doing in the temple. And when you see that, do not think that the end of their wickedness has come, you will see even greater things. Indeed, what can be understood about our Jerusalem and our temple can also be understood as an example of Ophni and Phinees (2 Kings 2), when we carry out the crimes of idols in the tabernacle of God; and we engage in sexual immorality with those who have dedicated themselves to the service and ministry of God; and we take the first fruits of his sacrifices, giving them to the use of clients and slaves, and we do everything for the sake of profit. But if these things that we see are so great, how much greater should those things be that escape human consciousness?


<h2 id='tocuniq106'>(Vers. 7 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 7 and following) And he brought me to the door of the court, and I saw, and behold, there was a hole in the wall. And he said to me, 'Son of man, dig in the wall.' And when I dug in the wall, there appeared a door. And he said to me, 'Go in and see the evil abominations that they are doing here.' This is what I have translated: 'And I saw, and behold, there was a hole in the wall,' which is not found in the Septuagint. And because everything is shown as if in an image or picture, he says that he saw a hole in the wall and was commanded to dig it and make it larger, so that with the hole opened wider, he could enter and see what he could not see from outside. By which it is shown, both in the Church and in each one of us, that greater sins are indicated by small vices, and as if through certain openings, one reaches great abominations. For by the fruits the tree is known (Matt. 12:33, 34), and out of the abundance of the heart, the mouth speaks. As a sign of the inner person, words burst forth: as how a lewd speech, for it cleverly conceals its vices, sometimes reveals an obscene conversation; and the hidden greed inside is indicated by the desire for a small thing. For greater things are shown by lesser ones, and the conscience cannot be hidden by expression and eyes, while a luxurious and lascivious mind shines forth in the face; and the secrets of the heart are revealed by the movement of the body and gestures.

<h2 id='tocuniq107'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) And when I entered, I saw that the entire likeness of reptiles and abominable animals and all the idols of the house of Israel were depicted on the wall all around. Not only was the idol of Zeli standing at the entrance of the North Gate, but also all the walls of the Temple were painted with various images of idols, so that there was no beast that the wall painting did not show. So far, we see this in the shrines of idols and the temples of the pagans, that foolish religion worships all kinds of beasts. And so Virgil says:

All kinds of gods and monsters, and the barking Anubis, As if those monsters that it praises are not monsters.

Against Neptune and Venus, and against Minerva. We can also show in the walls of our temples idols depicted, when we are subject to all vices, and we paint in our hearts the consciousness of sins, and various images. Of which it is also said in the Psalm: Lord, in your city you will scatter their image (Psalm 72:20). And in another place: Nevertheless,  man walks in image (Psalm 38:7). For it is certain that there is no man who does not have some kind of image, whether of holiness or sin. Therefore, it is said of the furious and the wrathful: Their fury is like that of a serpent; like the deaf adder that stops its ears, which will not hear the voice of the charmers (Psalm 58:5). And concerning wicked men: O generation of vipers, who has warned you to flee from the wrath to come? (Matthew 3:7). And concerning the deceitful and cunning: Go, tell that fox (Luke 13:32). And concerning the lovers of women: They have become mad like horses towards women: each one neighs after his neighbor's wife (Jeremiah 5:8). Concerning animals and foolish people: Do not be like a horse or a mule, which have no understanding. And again: Put a bridle and a bit in their mouths, those who do not come near to you (Psalm 32:9). And many similar things. But this that we have mentioned: And behold, no representation of reptiles and animals is found in the Septuagint.


<h2 id='tocuniq108'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11) And seventy men from the elders of the house of Israel, and Jezonias the son of Saphan stood in their midst, standing before the paintings, and each had a censer in his hand, and the vapor of incense rose up. When it says that seventy men were from the elders of the house of Israel, who held censers in their hands, it indicates that there were many other priests who did not do this, but perhaps they were held captive by other sins. And it is said that Jezonias the son of Saphan stood among them, as if the leader of their wickedness and sacrilege, who, having abandoned the religion of God, worshiped idols, and in the temple, did not adore God, whose temple it was, but the paintings on the walls. And it is beautifully said: Jezonias, the son of Saphan, stood in the midst of the standing elders, the judges and condemners, because he was both a prince and one of those whose prince he was, and they stood firmly in their crimes and did not waver in evil; but they persisted most strongly. And the smoke of incense, which rose from those offering sacrileges, showed the vapor of confusion and turmoil. This event happened at that time according to the letter. Furthermore, it is necessary for us to pray that the elders of the house of Israel, multiplying the sacred number seven by seven tens, do not remain in their errors and worship the images of idols, and that the sacrilege does not rise up against God. When we see the most wicked people gathered, of whom it is written: 'I hate the congregation of evildoers' (Psalm 26:5), and worse leaders, and a ruler who is both in charge of the people and the elders, let us say that Jezonias is standing before the images, and that each of them has a censer in their hands, worshiping not the majesty of God, but their own opinions, and not offering a pleasing fragrance to God, but a foul stench to the idols.


<h2 id='tocuniq109'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(Verse 12.) And he said to me: Surely you see, son of man, what the elders of the house of Israel do in the darkness, each one in the hiding place of his chamber. For they say: The Lord does not see us; the Lord has forsaken the land. From this, he says, it is shown what each one does in his own chamber when they gather together in the temple. But according to the anagoge, it can be better understood that some leaders of the Churches do in the darkness things that are even shameful to speak of. This is the hidden man of the heart, of whom it is said: Enter into thy chamber (Mich. VI, 4). And again: He who sees in secret shall repay thee. Let each one recall his own conscience, and let him remember the works of darkness in the darkness, and let him know the scripture: Everyone who does evil hates the light, and does not come to the light, lest he be reproved by the light (John III, 20; I Thess. V). And in himself he shall understand this to be fulfilled: He who is intoxicated is intoxicated at night (Prov. II, 25). Because standing according to the letter cannot. For how many are intoxicated with days of feasting and banquets? But because the drunkenness of the heart offends God, it is of darkness, not of light, therefore whoever is intoxicated, is intoxicated at night. However, when the elders of the house of Israel have done evil in darkness and in the hidden places of their chambers, and have thought that they could hide from God, then they will consequently say: The Lord does not see us, the Lord has forsaken the land. There are many sinners who walk according to their own thoughts, who do not consider that God cares about mortal things, nor that our vices pertain to Him. Certainly, if we were to think that God sees and is present when we sin, we would never do what displeases Him. Furthermore, what follows is, 'The Lord has forsaken the earth', which is also the opinion of some philosophers who, from the movement and constancy of the stars, suspect that there is providence in the heavens, and that earthly things are despised, since nothing virtuous or in accordance with order is done on earth.


<h2 id='tocuniq110'>(Vers. 13, 14.)</h2>

(Verse 13, 14.) And he said to me: Yet you shall see even greater abominations which they ((or these)) do. And he brought me to the entrance of the gate of the house of the Lord, which faced north; and behold, there were women sitting there ((or they were sitting)) mourning for Adonis. We interpreted him as Adonis, and in the Hebrew and Syrian language he is called Thamuz (). Because according to a Gentile fable, in the month of June, the lover of Venus and the most beautiful young man was killed, and it is narrated that he revived afterwards, they call the same month June by the same name, and they celebrate an annual commemoration for him, in which he is mourned by women as if dead, and afterwards he is sung and praised when he revives. And after that, 89, when the leaders and elders of the house of Israel were shown what they had done in the temple and in the darkness of the chambers: even the vices of women are described, who mourn in private the society of lovers, and rejoice if they can obtain them. And because the same paganism interprets subtly such fables of poets that have obscenity, it thinks that the killing and resurrection of Adonis, with mourning and joy, are shown: the former of which it thinks is demonstrated in the seeds that die in the earth, the latter in the crops, by which the dead seeds are reborn; let us also call those women who are either saddened or rejoice at the evils and goods of the world, with a soft and effeminate mind: and let us say that they mourn for Thammuz, those things namely that are considered the most beautiful in the things of the world.


<h2 id='tocuniq111'>(Vers. 15, 16.)</h2>

(Verse 15, 16.) And he said to me: You have certainly seen, son of man: yet you shall see even greater abominations than these. And he brought me into the inner court of the house of the Lord, and behold, at the entrance of the temple of the Lord, between the vestibule and the altar, were about twenty-five men with their backs to the temple of the Lord and their faces toward the east, worshiping the sun. We interpreted this vestibule as referring to Symmachus, who placed a πρόπυλον (gate) there, because the Septuagint and Theodotion translated the Hebraic word as Aelam. The first edition of Aquila translated it as προστάδα (forecourt), and it was interpreted as the temple of Aelam, which we can express as the portico of the temple or the covered court that was between the temple and the altar. And as we read above, after the idol of Zeli, which appeared at the gate of the North: Still turned, you will see greater abominations; and with the pictures of all the beasts that the seventy elders and Jezonias the son of Saphan worshipped, holding censers in their hands, it is said a second time: Still turned, you will see greater abominations that they do, because the weeping women sat for Adoniden; and after the third sin, it is said: Still turned, you will see greater abominations than these. But what is the greater abomination of the three previous crimes? Namely, the fourth which follows: Behold, at the entrance of the Lord's temple, between the vestibule and the altar, there were about twenty-five men with their backs towards the temple of the Lord, and their faces towards the east, and they were worshiping the rising sun, because, despising the Lord, that is, the Creator, they were worshiping the sun, that is, a creature of the Lord, as commanded by the Lord Himself through Moses (Deut. XII), that they should not worship God against the East, as the manner of the Gentiles, but wherever they were in the world, whether to the East, or to the West, or to the South, or to the North, they should worship against the temple, where the Lord was believed to dwell in the Holy of Holies. Indeed, we read that Daniel also did this in Babylon (Dan. 6), who, with the windows of his upper chamber open towards Jerusalem, worshipped the Lord contrary to the temple. Concerning the literal meaning, no one doubts that this was sacrilege. As for the allegorical meaning, he will be able to know that all heretics are worse than their predecessors, that is, than the idol of Zeal and the painted figures of animals on the wall, and the weeping of Adonis, through which idolatry and pleasures are shown, who understands the prophet saying: But you have hated discipline, and have cast my words behind you (Ps. 49:17). And in another place: They have turned their back to me and not their face; though I taught them, rising up early and teaching them, yet they did not listen to receive instruction."  } But we worship the sun of justice in such a way that we worship God in the temple of the Old Testament, where the Law and the Prophets are, where the Cherubim and the mercy seat are. Twenty-five men translated it, seventy placed it, twenty; and in some copies, five from Theodotion were added.

<h2 id='tocuniq112'>91 (Vers. 17.)</h2>

91 (Verse 17.) And he said to me: Surely you have seen, son of man: Is it a light thing to the house of Judah that they should commit these abominations which they have committed here? For they have filled the land with wickedness and have turned to provoke me. And behold, they put the branch to their nose. Because we have said: And behold, they put the branch to their nose, the LXX translated: and behold, they stretch the branch, to be all in agreement: And behold, they stretch the branch as if mocking. Symmachus interpreted it as though they were emitting a sound resembling a song through their nostrils. However, it signifies twenty-five men who are firmly established in a square formation, and through the five senses multiplied by five, they form the shape of a square, not only having a temple behind them, but also applying a branch to their nostrils, similar to idols. Without a doubt, it signifies that they are worshiping idols, namely the palm branches, which are called βαΐα in the Greek language. Finally, Job also says that he had this virtue among others, that he never looked at the sky, the sun, the moon, and the shining stars, and kissed his hand (Job 31), that is, he worshiped creatures. However, Symmachus' interpretation signifies a foul and hoarse sound coming from his nostrils in contempt of God. And all heretics, who have filled the earth with iniquity, and turned to false knowledge in order to provoke the Lord to anger, are to be considered: when they want to praise God, they rather blaspheme with an ugly sound, or consider the God of the Old Testament of little importance, mock, and scorn Him.


<h2 id='tocuniq113'>(Vers. 18.)</h2>

(Verse 18.) So I will also do in my wrath; my eye will not spare, nor will I have pity. And when they cry to my ears with a loud voice, I will not hear them. And what follows, And when they cry to my ears with a loud voice, I will not hear them, is not found in the Septuagint. For all these things, says the Lord, that they have done, I will do in my wrath; my eye will not spare, nor will I have pity. When the ancient heretics hear this, they accuse the Creator of being cruel and bloodthirsty; and they do not consider the Apostle Paul, who certainly, according to their own words, is an apostle of the good God, writing to the Corinthians, If I come again, I will not spare (2 Corinthians 12:2); so that the rod may discipline the wrongdoers and the wanderers may be brought back to salvation. For those who do not understand what is beneficial for themselves, and frequently ask for things contrary to that, it is expedient for them to not be heard by the Lord. Hence, in the Lord's Prayer, we say: Thy will be done (Matthew 6:10). Not our will, which is accustomed to err, but Thy will, which knows the future. And it is sometimes a great happiness to not deserve mercy in the present. And therefore, the Lord will not spare those who are from the house of Judah and have departed from the confession of the Church. And when they cry out with a loud voice, of which the Lord said: Their cry has come to me (Gen. 18): yet the Lord will not hear them, so that, compelled by their evil deeds, they may understand what they have done.

<h2 id='tocuniq114'>(Cap. IX.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 9, Verse 1) And he cried out in my ears with a loud voice, saying: The visitations of the city have drawn near. The Seventy have transferred vengeance for visitations. For I will take vengeance and repay, says the Lord (Deuteronomy 32:35). And every vengeance is like that of a sick person, like one who has wounds, like one waiting for healing hands, according to what is written elsewhere: I will visit their iniquities with a rod, and their sins with scourges, but I will not take away my mercy from them (Psalm 88:33-34)." } And rightly (as we have said above), the visitation or punishment is said to be approaching in close proximity to captivity.

And everyone has a vessel of destruction in his hand. He did not say, 'he had', as the Septuagint translated. For he does not narrate things past, but shows things present and future. Therefore, the one who strikes evildoers because they are evil, and has vessels of destruction in order to kill the worst, is a minister of the Lord.

<h2 id='tocuniq115'>(Vers. 2, 3.)</h2>

(Verses 2, 3.) And behold, six men came from the way of the upper gate, which faces toward the north, and each one had an instrument of destruction in his hand. There was also one man among them clothed in linen, with a writer’s inkhorn at his side. And they went in and stood beside the bronze altar. Now the glory of the God of Israel had gone up from the cherub, where it had been, to the threshold of the temple. And He called to the man clothed with linen, who had the writer’s inkhorn at his side. Regarding the lines that we have interpreted next to Symmachus 93, LXX, ποδήρη; Theodotion itself is the Hebrew word Baddim (); Aquila, the principal translators. Again, when we said, and the writer's inkwell at his kidneys, LXX put: And a sapphire belt on his kidneys; Theodotion, κάστυ in his hand; Aquila, μελανοδοχεῖον, that is, the scribe's inkwell at his loins; Symmachus had writing tablets on his kidneys. And when we had transferred ourselves, the threshold of the house, Seventy and Theodotion, the courtyard, that is, under the open sky, we set as the entrance. As for the destruction of the vessels that each man held in his hands, only Seventy interpreted the axe. Therefore, in order to atone for the sins of humanity, who were created on the sixth day of the creation of the world, six men come and descend from the upper gate, or as the Seventy translated, from the high place to the North. And each person had a hatchet in their hands, about which John speaks: For now the axe is laid to the root of the trees. Every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire (Matt. III, Luke III, 9). And in the middle there was one of the six men, that is, the seventh, dressed in the garments of a priest, and he had a scribe's inkwell at his waist, with which he would write down the sins of all and separate the number of the saints from the sinners, or a sapphire belt of sapphire-colored stone, which is among the ornaments of the high priest. Six men went out and stood next to the bronze altar. For there were two altars: one of incense, made of gold on the inside, and the other in front of the temple, made of bronze for burnt offerings. It is said that those who stand next to the altar are prepared to carry out the command of the one who gives orders, so that if they see anyone there who has not had their sins forgiven, they know that they are subject to the judgment and execution of the Lord. The glory of the God of Israel also ascended, whether it was taken up by one of the cherubim, and went to the threshold, or to the inner part of the courtyard of the house and vestibule, which is not covered, but enjoys the freedom of the air. The glory of the Lord itself, who was in the form of a pontiff, and had an inkwell in his loins, called out, and said what the Scripture testifies. Some interpret the six men, who are called Angels, as those who obey the will of God; and they understand the one who had the vestment of the pontiff as the Savior; according to that, he is the Priest and Angel of great counsel, and that which is said: You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek (Psalm 109:4). But the talaris, which the Septuagint translated, is one of the eight vestments of the high priest, which is called talaris in Latin; and it gets its name from descending to the feet. I know that I published a book about the vestment of the high priest many years ago, and I am sending the reader for an explanation of it. For I cannot say everything in all places, and what Aquila's first edition and Theodotion said κάστυ, for which in Hebrew it is read Cesath (), when I asked in Hebrew what it meant, he responded to me in the Greek language that it is called καλαμάριον, because reeds are stored in it. We call ink, from the fact that it has ink. Many people call them inkwells, from the fact that they are containers for writing quills. Of the four Cherubim, one Cherub is sent from the glory of the Divine Majesty to speak to the one who was clothed in the garments of the high priest. And although many people think that Cherubim is a neuter gender and plural in number, we must know that Cherub is singular in number and masculine in gender, and its plural is Cherubim of the same gender: not because there is gender among the ministers of God, but because each thing is called by different genders according to the properties of its language. The angels are called in the plural number Malachim, and Cherubim, and Seraphim of the same kind and number. Furthermore, sabaoth, which is interpreted as hosts or armies and powers, are called in the feminine gender, plural number, and end in the final syllable Oth. Those, however, who wish the Savior to be understood under the figure of a high priest, use the example from the Apocalypse of John, in which it is written: 'And I turned to see the voice that spoke with me.' And when I turned, I saw seven golden candlesticks: and in the midst of the candlesticks one like unto the Son of man, (Apoc. II, 12, 13), etc.

<h2 id='tocuniq116'>(Vers. 4 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse. 4 and following) And the Lord said to him: Pass through the middle of the city, through the midst of Jerusalem, and put a mark on the foreheads of the men who groan and lament over all the abominations that are committed in the midst of it. And to the others he said in my hearing: Pass through the city after him, and strike. Your eye shall not spare, and you shall show no pity. Kill old men outright, young men and maidens, little children and women, but touch no one on whom is the mark. But do not kill anyone on whom you see the mark. Begin at my sanctuary.\" So they began with the elders who were before the temple. Then He said to them, \"Defile the temple and fill the courts with the slain. Go!\" So they went out and killed in the city. Or, as the Hebrews believe, because the Law is called Thora among them (), which is written with the letter at the beginning of its name; they received this sign who fulfilled the precepts of the Law. And to come to our own, the ancient Hebrews used 96 letters, which the Samaritans still use today, the final letter being Thau, resembling a cross, which is painted on the foreheads of Christians and is frequently marked in hand inscriptions. There are some who think, because according to the Hebrew alphabet this is the last letter, it is shown that there would be a multitude of sinners, remains of saints. Therefore, those who groan and sorrow are saved; who not only did not consent to evil works, but also mourned the sins of others, according to how Samuel mourned for Saul (3 Kings 16), and the apostle Paul mourned for those who did not repent after sin. And he himself said: 'For in this tabernacle we groan' (2 Corinthians 5:2). And elsewhere: 'Great is my sorrow, and unending is the pain in my heart' (or 'in my heart') (Psalms 4:7). And it is commanded that the six men should kill everyone except those who are able to say: 'The light of your countenance is signed upon us, O Lord' (Psalms 4:7), sparing not the old man, nor the young man, nor the virgin, nor the child, nor the woman. According to mystical interpretation, the old men are those who are in the Church, of whom it is said: 'The grey hair of a man is his wisdom' (Wisdom 4:8); the young men are those who are most ready for battles of faith; the virgins are those who keep their chastity with their whole mind; the children are those who drink milk of infancy and do not yet understand solid food; the women are those who testify to the weakness of their souls by the frailty of their sex. To all of whom no mercy is shown if they believe themselves to be something without the seal of Christ. And what follows: 'And begin from my sanctuary,' that is, as the Seventy translators have rendered it, 'begin from my saints,' or it signifies the priests, who were engaged in the temple and worshipped idols; or those who, by the merit of their priesthood, were called holy in the people, and who, for the sake of sin, were the first to deserve punishment in the sight of the people. For the time has come (I Cor. VII), for judgment to begin at the house of God.

<h2 id='tocuniq117'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7.) So they began with the elder men who were in front of the house. And he said to them: Defile the house and fill the courts with the slain. Fill the courts with the slain. For the courts, which are called 'Aseroth' in Hebrew (LXX), they laid out roads. But the elder men, about whom we read earlier that they had censers and offered incense to idols, were killed. There is no longer any religious worship in the temple, for, having offended God's religion, everything has been defiled so that judgment comes from where sin comes. The atria are filled with corpses in the temple, and not the streets, which were certainly outside, unless perhaps we can understand the streets ((or perhaps we can understand the streets)). And the angels could not dare to defile the temple with the blood of the dead, in which the glory of God previously dwelt, unless the Lord had commanded this for the departing ((or believing)) glory. Everyone who is dead in sin defiles the atria of the temple, and the streets of the city of the Lord, in which he lives: but when rising with Christ, he ceases to be dead.


And they went out and struck those who were in the city. Or, as others have reported, they struck the city; calling the city itself the city.

<h2 id='tocuniq118'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Verse 8.) And when the slaughter was complete, I remained: and I fell upon my face, and crying out, I said: Alas (Vulg. Alas, alas, alas), Lord God, therefore do not destroy all the remnants of Israel, pouring out your wrath upon Jerusalem? With all those who did not have the seal, fallen by slaughter, the prophet fell upon his face, thinking that no one had survived except himself from the multitude of those killed. And because this seemed to be contrary to the sentence by which the Lord had ordered that the men with sealed foreheads should not be killed, therefore it was subtracted in the Vulgate edition. But we, following the Hebrew truth, have put, I remained. And it should be noted that he did not say alone: what he had said seemed to be the opposite, but I remained, so that it may be understood with the others who had marked foreheads. But in order to know clearly what was said, I remained, in the book of Kings, when Elijah speaks to God: Your altars have been destroyed, and I am left alone, and they seek to take my life (3 Kings 19:14); he used the word alone because he did not know that others had remained. Some think that this can be understood about the people of Judah, in whose likeness Ezekiel came before; namely, when all had turned aside, they had become altogether useless. And the Prophet testifies: Save me, O Lord; for the Holy One has failed. For only the Lord has been found who has not committed sin, and no deceit has been found in His mouth. But what is said: pouring out Your fury upon Jerusalem, signifies the magnitude of the outpouring of punishment, as we read elsewhere: Contempt has been poured out upon princes. And again: My steps have nearly slipped (Psalm 73:2). And in a good way. The love of God has been poured out into our hearts (Romans 5:5). And: Grace has been poured out on your lips (Psalm 45:3). And on the contrary: Pour out your fury on the nations that do not know you, and on the kingdoms that have not called upon your name (Jeremiah 10; Psalm 79:6). And: Draw out the spear and close up against those who pursue me (Psalm 35:3).


<h2 id='tocuniq119'>(Vers. 9, 10.)</h2>

(Vers. 9, 10.) And he said to me: The wickedness of the house of Israel and Judah is exceedingly great. And the land is filled with blood, and the city is filled with perversion. For they have said: The Lord has forsaken the land, and the Lord does not see. Therefore, my eye will not spare, nor will I have mercy: I will repay their ways upon their heads. Seeing his prophet weep for the people, and marveling at the magnitude of his anger, the Lord gives reasons: not as he thought, unjust or excessive punishment, but deserved and just sentencing. Iniquity, he says, of the ten tribes of Israel and the two tribes of Judah is great, and not only great, but excessively great. And he does not suffice to say this, but he repeats it, strongly, so that the magnitude of the punishment is in proportion to the magnitude of the iniquity. From this we learn, contrary to what most people think, and especially the Stoics, that sins are not equal; but rather, they are either great or small, and punishing judgment varies according to the quality and measure of the sinners. The land, he says, is filled with blood, or as the Septuagint translates, with peoples; and the city is filled with aversion, or as the Vulgate edition has it, with iniquity and uncleanness: much blood has been shed, not just a little, but from one gate to the other; and the whole city has turned away from the worship of God, and instead it is filled with impurity, namely the filth of idolatry. But the cause of such crimes is that they believed there is no providence over the earth, and that God does not care for mortal things, according to what we read elsewhere (Virgil. book IV, Aeneid).

Undoubtedly it is the task of the gods, that concern disturbs their tranquility. Therefore, because they either thought that there was no providence, or that which had been before in the peoples at this time had abandoned their own people, for this reason the eye of God will not spare, nor will he have pity, so that, raging against vices, he may be appeased by virtues, and may bring down upon their heads the ways and sins of those, either upon the principal (ἡγεμονικὸν) of their heart, or upon the rulers of the people, as the book of Numbers says, in which the rulers of the people are said to be the heads of the peoples.


<h2 id='tocuniq120'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11) And behold, a man clothed in linen, who had a writing case at his waist, answered, saying: I have done as you commanded me. LXX: And behold, a man clothed in a white garment (that is, a tunic) and girded with a belt around his waist, answered, saying: I have done as you commanded me. He is the man to whom it was commanded to pass through the midst of Jerusalem, and to set a mark on the foreheads of the men sighing and crying for all the abominations that are done within it. He says that he has fulfilled the Lord's commandments and has marked the foreheads of mourners with the seal of the letter Tau (or armed them, as others interpret). But the six men whom the Lord had commanded, saying, 'Go through the city following him, and strike; show no mercy to anyone, and do not announce such things.' For they have filled the sentence of sorrow, not with words, but with deeds. And in this place, for ποδήρη, that is, a long robe, which the Septuagint has interpreted, Theodotion put the Hebrew word Baddim (); Symmachus, a line; Aquila, a distinctive garment, or robe. Symmachus placed 100 tables; Aquila, an inkwell; Theodotius, a helmet.

<h2 id='tocuniq121'>(Cap. X.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter 10, Verses 1-2) And I looked, and behold, in the firmament that was above the head of the cherubim, there appeared something like a sapphire stone. And there was a likeness of a throne above it, like the appearance of a sapphire stone. And he said to the man clothed in linen, 'Go in between the wheels, beneath the cherubim, and fill your hands with coals of fire from among the cherubim, and scatter them over the city.' Concerning the firmament that was above the cherubim, the sapphire stone that had the likeness of a throne, and the wheels that the living creatures followed, it is enough to have mentioned them, and let the reader be satisfied with their explanation. But now, what is commanded to the man clothed in linen, for whom the Septuagint in this place have interpreted as 'the stole,' that he should take coals of fire from the midst of the cherubim, and scatter or spread them over the city, seems to me to signify this: that after the killing and slaughter of many, and the dead bodies in the streets, the coals of fire are taken in order to punish or cleanse Jerusalem, according to what is written in Isaiah: 'He has made him holy in the burning fire, and it shall devour as straw' (Isaiah 10:17). These are the coals which, as a remedy for the inflaming and corrupting of the tongue, the Prophet desires, saying: 'What shall be given to you, and what shall be added unto you, deceitful tongue? Sharp arrows of the mighty, with coals of desolation' (Psalm 119:3-4). And many other things of this kind may be found in the holy Scriptures, of which we have frequently spoken. It is only to be noted here that in Isaiah, who had sinned so much in his speech, and had declared that he had unclean lips, a coal is taken to purify him. But here, because the city was full of wickedness and after the punishment, dead bodies, many coals of fire are taken, not with one hand, but with both, in order to purify all of Jerusalem. However, it should also be understood that these coals of fire are taken not for purging, but for punishment and torment, which are scattered over Jerusalem.

<h2 id='tocuniq122'>(Vers. 3 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 3 onwards) And he entered into my sight. And the cherubim stood at the right side of the house when the man entered, and the cloud filled the inner courtyard. And the glory of the Lord rose above the cherub at the threshold of the house, and the house was filled with a cloud, and the courtyard was filled with the splendor of the glory of the Lord. And the sound of the wings of the cherubim was heard as far as the outer courtyard, like the voice of the almighty God speaking. And when he commanded the man, who was clothed in linen, saying: Take fire from among the wheels that are between the cherubim; that man entered and stood beside the wheel. And the Cherub stretched out his hand from the midst of the Cherubim to the fire that was between the Cherubim, and took it and put it into the hands of him who was clothed in linen. And he took it and went out. And the likeness of a hand of a man appeared under their wings. Seeing this, the prophet entered, and the man who was clothed in a long robe or linen, and as the Septuagint now changes its interpretation, holy stole, as among the Hebrews one word is held to be Baddim (), and the other interpreters persist in their initial translation. However, as it is said, he entered into the midst of the wheels, which are underneath the Cherubim, to fill his hands with fiery coals. When he had entered, he stood only beside the wheel, and either because of the sadness of punishing Jerusalem, or because of the greatness of glory, he did not send his own hand into the fire, but one of the Cherubim, that is, the Cherub sent his hand, and took the fire, which was in the midst of the Cherubim, and put it into the hand of the one who was clothed in linen garments. The one who entered was accepted; and yet Scripture does not say what the one who entered did, so that he would leave the sad narrative to our understanding rather than subject it to our eyes. But as the man entered, who was wearing linen garments, the Cherubim stood on the right side of the house, so that the holy and heavenly virtues seemed to hold the right side of the house of God, and those that are sent for punishment, of whom it is written: 'He sent against them the wrath of bad angels' (Ps. 77:49), are believed to possess the left side. And when the glory of the Lord was lifted up from the Cherub, who was about to deliver the firebrands to the man, and had passed over to the threshold of the house, immediately the cloud, darkness, and thick smoke filled the inner courtyard. For in the presence of the majesty of the Lord, no punishments are carried out, and the glory of the Lord is seen in the courtyard, about which it is written: The sound of the wings of the Cherubim could be heard all the way to the outer courtyard. For the sound, in Hebrew, is written as voice: a voice that had a resemblance to the voice of the Almighty God speaking. For what reason they translated it as 'Saddai', the voice of God; and Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotio translated it as 'capable', which signifies strong and powerful. Note, reader, in which they agree or disagree, so that from the comparison of both without our prompting, you may understand the divine mysteries, and that which I previously mentioned, namely, that the 'nonveritas' (falsehood) is not said, but the 'similitudo' (similarity) in the firmament, and on the throne, and in the hand of man. For now we see in a mirror dimly, but then face to face. Now I know in part; then I shall understand fully, even as I have been fully understood.

<h2 id='tocuniq123'>(Vers. 8 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 8 and following) And I saw, and behold, four wheels beside the Cherubim. One wheel beside one Cherub, and another wheel beside one Cherub. And the appearance of the wheels was like the vision of a chrysolite stone, and their appearance was the same, four of them as if one wheel in the midst of another wheel. And as they went, they went in the four directions, and did not turn back as they went, but followed the direction to which the first went, and the others followed, and they did not turn. And the whole body of them, and their necks, and hands, and feathers, and circles, were full of eyes round about the four wheels. And he called these wheels voluble, as I heard. And it had four faces: one face was the face of a cherub, and the second face was the face of a man, and in the third was the face of a lion, and in the fourth was the face of an eagle; and the cherubim were elevated. Consider what was before, or how many species of wheels, according to the Septuagint, like a vision of tharsis: but now according to the same, like a vision of a carbuncle; so that the likeness of wings through fire, which is transmitted by the cherub, may be shown: although in Hebrew, both above and here, it is written 'tharsis,' but the eagle translated it as 'chrysolite,' Symmachus as 'hyacinth.' And again, wherever we turn: And every body of theirs, which is implied by the wheels, is written in Hebrew: And all their flesh, and necks, and hands, and wings, and circles. Note that flesh is called in the heavenly powers, so that when we read: Flesh and blood cannot possess the kingdom of God, nor does corruption possess incorruption (1 Cor. XV), we know that it is not the substance of flesh, but works that are being condemned: For Basar (), which is written in this place, signifies not a body, but flesh. But those 103 circles of wheels, he called them "cast iron", by which the roundness of wood is confined and compressed. But these wheels have not only flesh, or a body, or limbs: but also necks, and hands, and feathers, so that we may perceive the efficiency of things in each, not just the images of limbs. These wheels themselves are also called in the Hebrew language 'Gelgel' (גֶּלְגֶּל), which Symmachus interpreted as 'rolling', and Aquila as 'wheel'. Furthermore, what follows: Hearing me, until that place where it is written: Cherubim were lifted up, in the Septuagint it is not found; but it is added from the Hebrew. In which it is to be observed, that by no means, as it is said above: The face of a man, and the face of a lion on the right side of the four, and the face of a calf on the left side of the four: and the face of an eagle four; so that they are believed to be different on the left and right: but an equal order of all is described, with the Scripture saying: The four faces had one: One face, the face of a Cherub, and the second face, the face of a man: and in the third face, the face of a lion: and in the fourth face, the face of an eagle; so that the first and second, and third, and fourth face, are described not by the diversity of places on the right and left, but by one order through degrees. But he called one face, namely the first, Cherub, for which he said above, the face of a calf. From this it is understood that the face of a Cherub is the face of a calf. The explanation of all these, except for the vision that has passed, contains their meaning.

<h2 id='tocuniq124'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(v. 15 onwards) It is the living creature that I saw by the river Chobar. And when the Cherubim walked, the wheels went beside them. And when the Cherubim lifted up their wings to be lifted up from the earth, the wheels did not resist, but they were also beside them. As they stood, they stood, and when they were lifted up, they were lifted up. For the spirit of life was in them. All things live for God, and feel their Creator. For God is not the God of the dead, but of the living (Matthew 22:32). And all the bodies of the celestial orbs are full of eyes (Supra I).
