And in the psalm it is said: The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament proclaims the work of his hands. Day unto day utters speech, and night unto night reveals knowledge (Ps. XIX, 1, 2). The sun and the moon, the sea and the rivers, the mountains and the hills praise God, and the elements revolve in their own cycle year after year, and on earth we understand the order of the heavens, so that they may revolve and run according to the order of the ancient law; and we perceive nothing new upon the earth. But what is said: It is an animal, which I saw next to the river Chobar (Eccles. I), Scripture shows that we should understand the same thing in the exposition of the animal, which we understood above.

<h2 id='tocuniq125'>(Vers. 18 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 18 and following) And the glory of the Lord went out from the threshold of the temple and stood over the cherubim. And the cherubim lifted up their wings and were exalted from the earth in my sight. And as they went out, the wheels also followed them. And they stood at the entrance of the east gate of the house of the Lord, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them. It is the creature that I saw beneath the God of Israel by the river Chebar, and I understood that they were cherubim. Four, by four faces to one: and four wings to one, and the likeness of hands of a man under their wings: and the likeness of their faces, the same faces which I had seen by the river Chobar, and their looks and the impulse of every one of them to go straight forward. The glory of the Lord, or majesty, which had stood by the threshold of the temple, stood over the cherubims. They lifted up their wings, and the wheels also with them: and the glory of the God of Israel was over them. And the glory of the Lord went up from the midst of the city, and stood upon the mount that is on the east side of the city. First, he was in the temple, then he stood in the atrium of the temple or on the threshold. As he left the temple, clouds and darkness filled the inner sanctuary of the temple. And once again, the glory itself sat above the cherubim, and as they immediately flew away and went out, the wheels followed. And the glory stood at the eastern gate of the house of the Lord, not at the temple entrance, but behind the atrium and threshold at the entrance of the eastern gate of the house of the Lord. When the prophet saw this, he said, 'It is the creature that I saw under the God of Israel, next to the river Chebar, and I understood that they were cherubim.' For what new thing had he seen that he understood to be Cherubim, which he had not understood before? Cherubim in our language is a multitude of knowledge: the knowledge of the sacraments of God, and his throne and rest. Hence it is also said in the psalm: You who sit above the Cherubim, make it manifest (Ps. LXXIX, 2). For the glory of the Lord always dwells in the multitude of knowledge, and it is made manifest when all things are demonstrated by royal providence; nothing happens by chance, nor does anyone speak without reason: The Lord has forsaken the earth, and the Lord does not see (Supra IX, 9). And their gaze and desire, is to forget the past, and extend themselves into the future (Philippians 3).

<h2 id='tocuniq126'>(Cap. XI.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 11, Verse 1) And the spirit lifted me up and brought me to the gate of the house of the Lord, which faces east and looks towards the rising sun. For the glory of the Lord had departed from the threshold of the temple and stood above the cherubim. And as the cherubim were flying, the glory itself stood at the entrance of the gate of the east side of the house of the Lord. And the prophet, who could not go near it, was lifted up by the spirit and brought to the same gate of the east side of the house of the Lord, which faces the sun of righteousness, as it is written: Behold, a man whose name is the East (Zechariah 6:12), so that it would no longer remain in the temple, which was clouded by the fog of ignorance; but standing at the gate of the east side of the house of the Lord, it would understand the following sacraments.


<h2 id='tocuniq127'>(Vers. 2 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 2 seqq.) And behold, at the entrance of the gate were twenty-five men, and I saw among them Jezoniah the son of Azur, and Phaltiah the son of Benaiah, leaders of the people. And he said to me: Son of man, these men who devise wickedness and give evil counsel in this city, saying, 'The houses have recently been built. This city is a cooking pot, and we are the meat.' Therefore, prophesy against them, prophesy, son of man. And the Spirit of the Lord rushed upon me, and he said to me, speak: Thus says the Lord: So you have spoken, O house of Israel, and I know the thoughts of your heart. You have killed many in this city, and you have filled its streets with the slain. Therefore thus says the Lord God: Your slain whom you have laid in the midst of it are the meat, and this city is the pot, but I will bring you out of the midst of it. You have feared the sword, and I will bring the sword upon you, declares the Lord God. And I will bring you out of the midst of it, and give you into the hands of foreigners, and execute judgments upon you. I will judge you with the sword: in the border of Israel I will judge you, and you shall know that I am the Lord. This shall not be for you a pot, neither shall you be in the midst of it as flesh. In the border of Israel I will judge you, and you shall know that I am the Lord. What follows is not found in the Septuagint, but is added from the Hebrew: Because you have not walked in my commandments, and have not kept my judgments, but have done according to the judgments of the nations that are around you. The prophet is taken according to what is written: 'The Lord takes pleasure in those who fear him' (Ps. 146:6); or he is lifted up from the earth and brought into the gate of the eastern house of the Lord, so that he may know the oaths of the twenty-five men who were at the entrance of the gate, and the sons of Jezaniah son of Azzur, and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, the princes of the people. Therefore, those who were at the entrance of the gate of the eastern house of the Lord, despairing of salvation and ready for destruction with a guilty conscience, and unwilling to correct their sins through repentance, say: 'Although houses have been rebuilt after the first captivity which had fallen, we know that this city is like a cooking pot, and we are the meat to be consumed and burned in it,' according to what is written in Isaiah: 'If a storm passes through, it will not come upon us' (Isa. 28:15). While they were saying these things, the spirit of the Lord rushed upon the prophet, and a second time commanded him to prophesy, saying: 'Because you have said these things, and the secrets of your hearts are not hidden from me, I will interpret to you how the city is like a cauldron, and you are like meat: not in the sense that you spoke, but in another sense that you do not fear. Indeed, the city is like a cauldron in appearance, but it will not be filled with your flesh, but with the flesh of those whom you have killed.' But as for you who think that you will die in this city, I will bring you out from the midst of the city and deliver you into the hands of the enemy, and I will execute judgments on you. You shall fall by the sword. I will judge you at the border of Israel, and you shall know that I am the Lord. And it is also said: I will judge you at the border of Israel, and you shall know that I am the Lord. But you shall endure all these things, because you have not walked in my commandments and have not done my judgments, but have acted according to the wickedness of the nations around you. And when it is clearly stated according to the letter, omitting for a moment the names of Jezoniah, Azur, Phaltiah, and Benaiah, which we reserve for another time, it must be said that even today in the Church, which is the house of the Lord, and before the gate, and at the entrance, or on the way of the gate, which signifies the Savior, through whom we enter to the Father, there are twenty-five men, representing all senses. And as far as my memory does not fail me, I could never find this number in a positive light; although in the Book of Leviticus, twenty-five years are chosen for the priestly ministry; for in Hebrew, it does not have this number, which is stated in the Septuagint, but thirty, which is contained in the beginning of this prophet's and the Lord's age, when he came to the banks of the Jordan, and was baptized by John (Luke 3). But if in the Gospel there are found five wise virgins and five foolish ones (Matt. 25), let us know that this number is placed in the middle, and depending on the quality of the users, it can be attributed to the good or the bad. Therefore, these men, who refer everything to the senses and have two principles, as we have said above, are contained in the dual number, which divides unity, and in the number of the second day they do not seem to be from the Lord, according to the Hebrew truth. And in Noah's Ark, two by two, unclean animals are brought in (Genesis 6). But the Lord, by bringing together what was divided, made both one and broke down the middle wall, condemning enmity in his flesh (Ephesians 2). Therefore, he speaks in a more noble and lofty way: I and the Father are one (John 10:30), to call us from the Jewish duality into the unity of the Christian faith. Finally, with the destruction of the Jewish priesthood, the Lord suffers not under one ruler but under two, Annas and Caiaphas: to show the division of their religion and the error of it. There are many at the entrance of this gate before the house of the Lord in the East, who are compared to their nations by their own vices, and they despair of salvation because of the consciousness of their sins, and they say: The city in which we live is a sieve, and we are all flesh, and we will be consumed by the burning of Babylon, whose fiery arrows are: unwilling to repent and despairing of salvation. Therefore, they hear that they themselves are not the lost and destroyed flesh of the city, but those whom they have scandalized and killed. And thus a sword is imposed upon them so that, after they have been judged not among the nations but among Christians within the borders of Israel, they may then recognize that he himself is the Lord according to what is read in the Psalms: When he killed them, they sought him (Psalm 77:34), so that they may recognize through torments the one whom they have not recognized through benefits.

<h2 id='tocuniq128'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13.) And it came to pass when I prophesied, Phaltias the son of Banajae died. And I fell on my face, crying out with a loud voice, and said: Woe, woe, woe, Lord God! Are you bringing an end to the remnant of Israel? As the prophet prophesied, one of the two princes, Phaltias the son of Banajae, dies, whose name means falling ruin, and he is the son of a builder or mason. For οἰκοδόμος cannot be translated into our language as anything else." } The son of Azur, called Jezonias, is being saved from the changing of princes. Jezonias's ears are ringing, because the soul is understood. But Azur, on the other hand, is the support or assistance. Therefore, if someone falls away from the Lord and was of very poor building, they rightly fall, and God's prophecy confirms this. However, the one who obeys God's commands and is sustained and supported by His help, rightly remains in power among the people. We read in Exodus (Chapter II) that after Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, died, the children of Israel groaned because of the works of mud, straw, and bricks, and cried out to the Lord, whom they could not cry out to while he was alive. Isaiah also (Chapter VI), after the death of King Uzziah, who had leprosy, saw the Lord sitting on a high and lofty throne, and the seraphim standing around him; and understanding that he had unclean lips, and dwelling among a people with unclean lips, he deserves to have a burning coal from the altar put on his lips, and his unclean lips be purged. Here, through the strength of God prophesying, the prince who had turned away from the service of the Lord falls in order to be lifted up by Christ. For if the resurrection is from the Lord, the devil is in ruin. In this, it is sought how the Savior is spoken of. Behold, here He is placed in ruin, and the resurrection of many in Israel (Luke 2:34). In the ruin of those who stood wickedly, and the resurrection of those who have fallen. When the prophet saw this, he fell on his face, not from the merit of sinning, but from the affection of mourning; and with a loud voice, which came from great fervor of faith, he cried out three times, and said, Alas, alas, alas, Lord God, are you bringing about the end of the remnant of Israel? And there is this feeling: Even the very remnants that seemed to exist in the people, with you being indignant, will be obliterated.

<h2 id='tocuniq129'>(Vers. 14 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 14 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, your brethren, your brethren, the men who are near to you, and all the house of Israel, to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem have said: Get far away from the Lord, to us this land has been given as possessions. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: because I have cast them far away among the nations, and because I have scattered them among the lands, I will be a little sanctuary for them in the lands where they have come. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, your brothers and the men of your captivity, and all the house of Israel are finished; to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem have said: You are far away from the Lord: to us is given the land for an inheritance. Therefore he says: Thus says the Lord Adonai, because I will scatter them among the nations, and disperse them in all the land, and I will be a little sanctification to them in the regions where they have entered there. First, we must speak about the variety of interpretation. Because it is found in Hebrew, the men closest to you (for this is what Goliath means) translated it as the men of your captivity. Then it follows: all to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem said; for all, they put those, it is accomplished, because of the ambiguity of the letters and words: Chullo, for which Aquila and Symmachus and Theodotion translated as all; they translated it as it is accomplished, which does not at all resonate according to the meaning. Therefore, the word of the Lord came to Ezekiel, who had said: Alas, alas, alas, Lord God, are you bringing the end to the remnant of Israel? Specifically through the death of Phaltiah and those who were killed with him, because they are not the remnant that the prophet believed to be in Jerusalem, but rather those who appeared to be captives in Babylon. And the meaning is this: O son of man, your brothers, born of the same lineage as you, your brothers, I say, whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem said had turned away from the Lord because you are captives, and you had handed yourselves over to Jechoniah, but the land of Israel has been given to us as an eternal possession. So I say to them, that although I have sent them far from the land of Israel and scattered them among nations and made them live in foreign lands, I will still be with them even in foreign and hostile places for a small sanctification, as long as there are some among them who do not submit to idolatry and remember God's commandments, just as Daniel and the three youths did, and it is believed that there were others like them, in the likeness of the great princes mentioned in the Scriptures (Dan. III). From all these things we learn that we should not insult those who have been condemned by God's judgment to punishments; nor should we reproach a man who has turned away from his sins; nor should we ever say to those who repent and leave the Church: 'You have gone far away from the Lord; the land has been given to us.' For thus says the Lord: Although I may separate them for a short time from my Church, and disperse them among the nations, yet I will be for them a small sanctification, as long as they remember their sins and hasten to return to their former seats because of repentance." }


<h2 id='tocuniq130'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 17 and following) Therefore say: Thus says the Lord God: I will gather you from the peoples and assemble you from the countries where you have been scattered, and I will give you the land of Israel. And they shall go there, and they shall remove all the offenses and all the abominations from it. And I will give them one (or another) heart and put a new spirit within them; I will remove the heart of stone from their flesh and give them a heart of flesh, so that they may walk in my statutes and keep my ordinances and obey them. Then they shall be my people, and I will be their God." } But as for those whose heart follows their offensive and abominable ways, I will place their path upon their own head, says the Lord God. This divine message speaks to those who were captives in the land of Babylon, to the 111 brothers of the prophet Ezekiel, and to the nearby ones whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem ((or Israel)) said: You have strayed far from the Lord, the land has been given to us as our possession. But these following words speak: I will gather you from the peoples and restore to you the land of Israel. And when you have entered, you shall remove all idols, on account of which you have offended God, and I will give you a heart that fears, and the service of God, so that you may by no means serve different idols, or any other than what you have had before. And I will give a new spirit in your inner being, according to what is written: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me (Ps. 50:12). And I will remove from you a heart of stone, that is, a hard heart, according to what Stephen, the first martyr in Christ, speaks: You stiff-necked people, uncircumcised in heart (Acts 7:51). And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened, so that he would not let the people of Israel go (Exod. VII). And I will give them a heart of flesh, soft and tender, and able to receive the commandments of God, so that they may be written on the tablets of their carnal hearts. Therefore, a soft heart is given, and a hard heart is taken away, so that they may walk in my precepts, keep my judgments, and be a people of God; and the Lord, who was once their adversary, may be their God. But those who do not repent of their previous sins and continue to walk after their abominations, I will repay them, says the Lord, according to what they deserve, so that their ways may be upon their heads. These things are thought to have happened under Zerubbabel, the son of Salathiel, and under Jesus, the son of Josedec, the high priest, and under Ezra and Nehemiah, to the tribe of Judah, and to those who returned with them. It is also believed that the inhabitants of Jerusalem, who were taken captive under King Zedekiah of Judah, or who fled with Jeremiah to Egypt, were dispersed to all lands and did not return to the city of Jerusalem. However, the full conversion of those who were captive and the remnant of Israel is understood in Christ, when the remnants were saved and on one day three thousand believed, and again five thousand (Acts 2). And others, about whom James speaks to the apostle Paul: Do you see, brother, how many thousands of believing Jews there are? hi omnes aemulatores Legis sunt (Act. XXI, 20) . Sed et quotidie superbi 112 habitatores urbis Jerusalem, quorum cor post offendicula et abominationes suas ambulat, Dei merentur offensam, ethi qui foris erant, ablato corde lapideo, et accepto corde mollissimo, per poenitentiam revertuntur ad Ecclesiam; et ambulant in praeceptis Domini, judiciaque ejus custodiunt, fiuntque Domini populus, et Dominus, quem prius offenderant, fit eis Deus.


<h2 id='tocuniq131'>(Vers. 22, 23.)</h2>

(Verse 22, 23.) And the cherubim lifted up their wings, and the wheels were with them, and the glory of the God of Israel was over them. And the glory of the Lord went up from the midst of the city and stood upon the mountain, which is east of the city. Gradually, the glory of the Lord departed from Jerusalem. First leaving the temple, it stood in the courtyard or at the threshold of the house, and then at the entrance of the eastern gate. Finally, with its wings and accompanying wheels lifted up, it stood upon the mountain, which is east of the city, undoubtedly signifying the Mount of Olives, from which the Savior ascended to the Father. And the glory of the Lord stood still, which had departed from the city of Jerusalem and had come upon the Mount of Olives, as a sign of resurrection and light, so that from there it would see Jerusalem being destroyed and burned. And what is said: 'The glory ascended from the midst of the city' (John 14:31), the Lord speaks to the disciples in other words: 'Rise, let us go hence' (Luke 13:35). And to the Jews: 'Your house shall be left desolate' (Matthew 23). Josephus also reports that a voice was heard in the temple of the angels and heavenly powers, which were previously in the defense of the city: 'Let us depart from these dwellings' (Josephus, Antiquities of the Jews). And in a marvelous way, even to the present day, the glory of the Lord, which departed from the temple, stands shining on the Mount of Olives and gazes upon the formerly Jewish temple, dissolved into ashes and ruins, with the sign of the cross.

<h2 id='tocuniq132'>(Vers. 24, 25.)</h2>

(Verse 24, 25.) And the spirit lifted me up and brought me to Chaldea for the transmigration in a vision in the spirit of God, and the vision that I had seen was taken away from me. And I spoke to the transmigration all the words of the Lord that He had shown me. Because we have translated from the Hebrew truth: 'And the vision that I had seen was taken away from me,' the LXX translated: 'And I ascended from the vision that I had seen.' Both of which mean that the prophet was not physically transported from Babylon to Jerusalem, but in spirit, the vision that had led him in spirit to Jerusalem was taken away, and he returned to himself and spoke to the transmigration all that had been shown to him, specifically to those of whom it is written above: 'I was sitting in my house, and the elders of Judah were sitting beside me, and the hand of the Lord God fell there upon me, and I saw.' (Above, Chapter 8, Verse 1). And in a wondrous way, while these people who had come to visit were sitting, the prophet saw mystical visions and was absent from those who were sitting in front of him, but present in body without spirit. And everything is happening so that those who were captive may receive consolation, that they may be brought back to the land of Israel and walk in the commandments of the Lord, and he will be their people and they will be his people. But those who do not turn to repentance, but continue to walk in their abominations, will receive what they have done. However, we often remind that words are often spoken in the Holy Scriptures for things.

<h2 id='tocuniq133'>(Cap. XII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter XII - Verses 1 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, you dwell in the midst of a rebellious house, who have eyes to see and do not see, who have ears to hear and do not hear, for they are a rebellious house. Because we translate: You dwell in the midst of a rebellious house, the Septuagint put: You dwell in the midst of their iniquities. But from what follows, Because they are a rebellious house, we understand that the previous sentence also applies to this verse. Furthermore, we frequently learn from experience, concerning anger also, that it is a sensation which, when it is excited in the middle of the house, you experience, which, owing to the bitterness of its vices, makes God, who is naturally sweet and merciful, bitter and cruel. Otherwise, we read of God: 'O taste and see that the Lord is sweet' (Psalm 33:9). However, the prophet dwells in the midst of a people who provoke God to bitterness, who has eyes and does not see, ears and does not hear, not from a defect of the senses, but from the obstinacy of wickedness. And so the Lord said to the Jews: If you were blind, you would have no sin (John 9:41), accusing and condemning their voluntary blindness. Therefore, because they have eyes to see, and do not see: ears to hear, and do not hear, and they despise your words, teach them through images and pictures; and show them with physical figures, so that they may recognize the coming captivity not only by hearing, but also by seeing.


<h2 id='tocuniq134'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Version 3.) Therefore, son of man, prepare for yourself vessels of migration: and you shall migrate daily before them. You shall migrate from your place to another place in their sight, if perhaps they may look upon it: for the house is rebellious. LXX: And you, son of man, prepare for yourself vessels of captivity; and you shall capture daily before them: and you shall capture from your place to another place in their sight, so that they may see that the house is rebellious. There is no doubt that the whole content of this place indicates the future captivity of King Zedekiah of the tribe of Judah, who was captured with Jerusalem. But since some want the captivity of Zedekiah, which is interpreted as the righteous Lord, to precede the type of the Savior, who descending from heaven to earth, assumed a human body, and these are the vessels of captivity, I therefore think it necessary to warn the prudent and cautious reader, and indeed to present these things, so that we may not seem to omit anything, but not to approve. For an impious king cannot surpass in form the one who is the perfect example of all piety. But it is narrated in the history of Jeremiah the prophet and the Kings that Sedeciah was captured by the Babylonians and Chaldeans and was led from place to place (Jeremiah 39 and 2 Kings 25), that is, from Jerusalem to Babylon, and other things that Ezekiel speaks of in the following. However, those who refer to the Lord Jesus Christ believe that his captivity and migration from place to place signify his descent from heavenly to earthly realms.


<h2 id='tocuniq135'>(Vers. 4 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 4 and following) And you shall bring out your vessels like the vessels of one who moves by day in their sight. But you shall go out in the evening before them, like one who migrates before their eyes. Dig a hole in the wall for yourself, and you shall go out through it in their sight. You shall bear it on your shoulders (Vulgate: you shall be carried), you shall escape in the darkness (Vulgate: you shall be brought out). You shall cover your face, and you shall not see the ground, for I have appointed you as a sign to the house of Israel." } LXX: And you shall bring forth your vessels of captivity by day in their sight. And you shall go out in the evening in their sight, as one goes out into captivity. You shall dig through the wall for yourself, and you shall go through it in their sight. You shall be carried on your shoulders, and you shall go out in hiding. You shall cover your face, and you shall not see the ground: for I have set you as a sign to the house of Israel. The prophet is commanded to do this as a symbol of what Zedekiah will do in reality. Collect, he says, your belongings (for these are the vessels of a traveler) while they watch. And after they have seen what you will do, you will go out in the evening in the likeness of a traveler. We read that Zedekiah fled by night with the wall secretly bored through, to the deserts of the Jordan, and there he was apprehended by the Babylonians, and this signifies the pierced wall. But what he says: On your shoulders you will carry, implies your belongings, and whatever those fleeing on a journey are accustomed to carry for comfort on the way. In the darkness you will escape (or carry off); you will not be seen by anyone. You will cover your face, or by the blindness that happened to it, your eyes will be plucked out by Nebuchadnezzar; or so that it is not known that he himself is the king, and the care of those serving will become greater. And what follows: And you will not see the land, that signifies that the blind one will be led to Babylon and will not see it. For I have given you as a portent to the house of Israel: for indeed the things said and done by the prophets have been both words and deeds. And in Zechariah, men of wonders are called, because they portend the future (Zech. III). And in Hosea, God speaks: 'I am like a prophet's hand' (Hosea XII, 10). But those who wish to understand Christ in the person of Ezekiel, take the vessels of captivity to mean the human body, and the pierced wall, by which He broke the gates of hell, and rising, appeared to the believing suns; and He was carried on the shoulders when He ascended as a victorious conqueror to heaven with angelic powers; and He goes forth concealed, and veils His face, so that the divine majesty is not seen in mortal flesh, and He does not see the earth, so that His eyes may not be dazzled by that which does not deserve His gaze. For the eyes of the Lord are upon the just (Psalm 33:16), and his face is against the wicked. They say that all these things were done so that, by way of a likeness to man, he might soften the hard hearts of the Jewish people towards the faith. And this is given as a sign to the house of Israel; according to that which is written: Behold, this child is set for the fall, and for the resurrection of many, and for a sign which shall be contradicted (Luke 2:34).

<h2 id='tocuniq136'>(Vers. 7, 8.)</h2>

(Verses 7, 8.) Therefore, I did as he had commanded me: during the day, I brought out my vessels like the vessels of a migrant, and in the evening, I dug a hole in the wall with my own hand. In the darkness, I went out and carried on my shoulders 116 (or was carried on their shoulders) before their eyes. LXX: And so I did according to all that he had commanded me: during the day, I brought out the vessels like the vessels of captivity; and in the evening, I dug a hole in the wall with my hand and went out and went into hiding: I was taken upon their shoulders in their sight. He testifies that he has completed the things he was ordered to do, and he does not need interpretation according to both opinions, as was explained above. However, it should be noted that at the same time Jeremiah prophesied in Jerusalem, and Ezekiel in Babylon, and his prophecy was sent to the captives; and his to those who lived in Jerusalem; so that by God's providence the unity of the two would be proven in different regions, and those who heard would understand that whatever happened to the people was not by the power of idols, but by the command of the Lord.


<h2 id='tocuniq137'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9) And the word of the Lord came to me in the morning, saying: Son of man, did not the house of Israel, the rebellious house, say to you, What are you doing? Say to them: Thus says the Lord God. If the rebellious house asks you, Why are you doing this? Or according to the Septuagint, even if they do not ask, you shall go in, so that they may know why you did these things. Say to them: Thus says the Lord God.

<h2 id='tocuniq138'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 and following) This burden is against the prince who is in Jerusalem, and against all the house of Israel who are in their midst. Say: I am your portent: as I have done, so it will be done to them. They will go into exile and captivity. But the prince who is in their midst will be carried on shoulders, he will go out in darkness; they will dig through the wall to bring him out; his face will be covered, so that he may not see the land with his eyes. And I will spread my net over him, and he shall be taken in my snare, and I will bring him to Babylon in the land of the Chaldeans, and he shall not see it; there he shall die. And all who are around him, his helpers and his troops, I will scatter to every wind, and I will unsheathe the sword after them, and they shall know that I am the Lord, when I scatter them among the nations and disperse them in the lands. And I will leave a few of them remaining from the sword, from famine, and from pestilence, that they may declare all their abominations among the nations where they go, and shall know that I am the Lord. First, let us explain the history. Say, he said, to those, o son of man, whether they ask or not. What are you doing with this? that burden and vision are about the leader, who is in Jerusalem, signifying the leader Sedeciah. And say: I am your omen, or as the Septuagint translated, I am the one who performs wonders; so that from the present things, the future can be known. As I have done, so it shall be for them, to the leader and all those who are with the leader. In the transmigration to Babylon, the captives will be led, and the leader who is in their midst will be carried on shoulders, either by animals or by those who fled with him. In darkness and in the shadows of night he will go out; his companions will dig a wall so that they may bring him out. His face will be covered, either out of fear of the pursuer or due to the injury of blindness, so that the blind man may not see the land of Babylon. And I will spread my net over him, and he will be captured in my snare. For indeed, by the consent of the Lord, he was captured by the Babylonians; and he testifies that these things that he suffered were done by the enemy. And being led into Babylon, he will not see the land of the Chaldeans, and there he will die as a captive. However, all his companions and helpers and associates in his escape, when he is captured, I will scatter them here and there, and I will not allow them to depart in safety. But I will unsheathe my sword in the hands of the enemy, so that when they are dispersed among the nations, they will understand that I am the Lord, and that all things have been done according to my will. And I will leave, he says, some of his companions who have fled with him, and who have been able to escape, a few who have escaped the sword, and famine, and pestilence, so that when they have come to various regions through flight or captivity, they may recount all their crimes either by word or by example; because of which they have deserved such great evils, and understand that I myself am the Lord. But the one who attempts to explain the allegory and the beginning of the explanation concerning the Savior, the leader who is in the midst of Jerusalem, interprets himself, who has preceded as a portent and a sign, that both he and his companions are captives of this world, and who, emerging from the underworld as a victorious conqueror, is carried on the shoulders of angels: he has come forth in darkness, unrecognized by unbelievers, having destroyed the middle wall, he has made both one: his face is covered, so as not to regard the land of the Jews (Ephesians 2). It is no wonder if the Lord has hidden his face; since even until this day the veil is placed before the unbelieving people. And the Lord has spread his net over him, as the bride speaks of him in the Song of Songs: Behold, he is standing behind our wall, looking through the windows, appearing through the lattice (Song of Songs 2:9). Also, Jeremiah says: The spirit of our face, Christ the Lord, has been captured in our sins (Lamentations 4:20). And: Though he had not committed sin, he was made sin for us (II Cor. V, 21). And he shall be brought into Babylon, the confusion of this world, into the land of the Chaldeans, who are interpreted as demons, so that he may draw back to salvation those who had been enslaved by demons, and lead captive the ancient captivity. And he says that he will not see the land of the Chaldeans, and he will die there, so that he may give us all life through his death. But he dispersed all his helpers and companions, the apostles and the apostolic men, throughout the whole world. And he drew the sword after them, so that they might be crowned with various martyrdoms, and then they themselves, or those who had believed in them, might understand that he is the Lord, and therefore he dispersed them among the nations, and scattered them in the lands, so that they might bear much fruit. And he left from them a few men, like the Apostle John, and others, freed from the sword, and from hunger, and from pestilence, and avoiding the assault of persecutions, so that they might recount the crimes of the Jews and the injustices of all the nations into which they had entered, so that, having performed acts of penance, they might know that he himself is the Lord. We have spoken these things, leaving judgment to the reader's discretion. However, there is no doubt that it is dangerous to compare the captivity and death of the impious king to the sacrament of the Lord.

<h2 id='tocuniq139'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 17 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, eat your bread with trembling (Vulgate adds 'but'); and drink your water with haste and sorrow. And say (Vulgate says 'you shall say') to the people of the land: Thus says the Lord God to those who dwell in Jerusalem, in the land of Israel: They shall eat their bread with anxiety and drink their water with desolation, so that the land may be desolate because of the wickedness of those who dwell in it. And the cities that are now inhabited will be deserted and the land will be deserted, and you will know that I am the Lord. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, you will eat your bread with sorrow, and drink your water with torment and anguish. And you will say to the people of the land: Thus says Adonai the Lord to the inhabitants of Jerusalem on the land of Israel: They will eat their bread with poverty, and drink their water with dispersion, so that the land and its fullness may be dispersed. For all who live in that impiety and their cities will be desolated, and the land will be scattered, and you will know that I am the Lord. After the prophecy of the prince and his allies, which was shown in a physical image, came to the people: and whatever is said by the prophets is referred to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, who, in the evil of siege, will eat their bread in distress and poverty, and drink their water with torment and tribulation. But these things, he said, O prophet, are said to you, that you may speak to the people of your land, and say: Thus says the Lord to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, who are in the land of Israel: You will endure the evil of being besieged by Nebuchadnezzar and the Chaldeans, famine and thirst, so that the whole land with its abundance may be destroyed, signifying the inhabitants through what is inhabited. And lest they think that this happens to them without cause: Say to them, he says, that because of their crimes and impieties, all the cities of Judah will be reduced to desolation, and the entire cultivation of the land will perish, so that they may know the raging God, whom they refused to recognize as merciful. Can the inhabitants of Jerusalem, who believe in Christ, say this in accordance with the anagoge, dwelling in the Church? And if they have incurred offense through their sins, let them eat bread with poverty, and drink water with sadness and distress: not the food of bread, nor the drink of water, but sustaining the hunger for the word and doctrine of God (Amos VIII). For when, either through the fault of princes who are to be captured and handed over to the Babylonians, or through our hardness, we have lost the word of God, and have not deserved to have useful waters: then in sorrow and want, we shall take our food, and the earth will lose the multitude of believers, and the cities, which are understood in the entire world as the Church, will be desolate, and the earth will be a wilderness, so that all may know that there has been offense to the Lord. Indeed, we can understand this even in a time of persecution.

<h2 id='tocuniq140'>(Vers. 21 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 21 onward) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel, saying: The days are prolonged, and every vision shall fail? Therefore say to them: Thus saith the Lord God: I will make this proverb to cease, and it shall be no more proverbs in Israel.  And speak to them, that the days are at hand, and the word of every vision. For there shall be no more any vain vision, nor doubtful divination in the midst of the children of Israel. Because I, the Lord, will speak, and whatever word I speak will be done. It will no longer be delayed, but in your days, rebellious house, I will speak a word and make it happen, declares the Lord God. And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, behold the house of Israel, who say, 'The vision that this man sees is for many days from now, and he prophesies of times far off.' Therefore say to them, Thus says the Lord God: None of my words will be delayed any longer: the word that I speak will be fulfilled, declares the Lord God. What we have said, according to Symmachus, all other interpreters have rendered as a proverb, which is called Masal in Hebrew. Again, where we have said: 'There will be no ambiguous divination,' the Seventy translate it as: 'And the soothsayer according to grace:' for which reason all have interpreted it as slippery, whereas we have said ambiguous, so that, listening to the deceiving words of their prophets, we may know them. Now the meaning of this whole chapter is: He had prophesied against the prince who was in Jerusalem, and then announced to the people that there would be famine and the burning heat of drought. Because the unbelieving multitude accepted the old and worn-out proverb: The threat of the prophets is delayed for a long time, and every vision will perish, since it is seen in vain: or according to Symmachus, it will vanish into thin air and wind. Therefore, say to them, he says, that my threat will by no means be delayed, nor will false and ambiguous divination be brought forth among the people that has an uncertain end, so that it is said at one time and fulfilled at another: but now, as long as you who speak and those who listen are alive, let the word that I have spoken be fulfilled. But it signifies the imminent captivity of the city of Jerusalem, and the imminent capture of Zedekiah with the people of Judah. Not only at that time, but even today, the unbelieving crowd and the stubborn hearts of mortals do not accept the prophecy of God: but they consider all that the prophets threaten, all that the Gospel proclaims, to be postponed to another time. And let us understand here the parable that is mentioned by the Seventy, to be taken as a proverb, according to what we read in the psalm: and I became a byword to them (Psalm 68:12). And in this same prophet: What is this parable to you in the people of Israel, saying: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the teeth of the children are set on edge?

<h2 id='tocuniq141'>Book Four</h2>

Book Four

I wish, if it were possible, Eustochium, to weave explanations in Ezekiel through each of the books with their own prophecies, and not to divide what is connected with prophecy by exposition: so that the course of the one dictating and the one reading would be easier; and to separate the long and immense journey of interpretation at certain intervals, as if by titles and indexes, and, to speak more properly, by arguments, to show what each book contains. But what should I do, when some prophecies are short and others long: so that often by necessity we are compelled to compress many into one book, and divide one into many? Hence now also against the prophets and prophecies, against the elders of the people of Israel and against the land upon which they are being led, we want to include in the fourth book a catalogue of the worst plagues, and also about the vine wood, which when it has been cut off, is useless among all the woods of the forest. Because it does not fit into one volume, we reserve the other part of it for the fifth volume: warning the most prudent reader's concern, so that he knows what we explain in this and what he should read.

<h2 id='tocuniq142'>(Cap. XIII.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter 13, Verse 1, 2.) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy against the prophets of Israel who prophesy, and say to those who prophesy out of their own heart: Hear the word of the Lord: Thus says the Lord God. This is what we have added: Those who prophesy, and say to those who prophesy out of their own heart, the LXX omitted, and because it is not in Hebrew, they added, and you will prophesy, and say to them. This is a message against false prophets who deceived the people and prophesied something other than what God commanded." } And let it not move anyone that they are called prophets, for holy Scripture has this custom, to designate each one of their prophecies and speeches as a prophet: just as the prophets are called Baal, and the prophets of idols, and the prophets of confusion. Hence even the apostle Paul calls a Greek poet a prophet: A certain one of their own prophets has said: Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, lazy gluttons (Titus 1). And in Hosea we read: 'Like a prophet, a madman carrying the spirit' (Hosea 9:7). But whatever was said to the Israelite people at that time is now applied to the Church: that the holy prophets are the apostles and apostolic men. However, false and insane prophets are all heretics, whose leaders fabricate lies from their own hearts, and those who are led astray by them believe in the lies of others.

<h2 id='tocuniq143'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) Woe to the foolish prophets, who follow their own spirit and see nothing. LXX: Woe to those who prophesy from their own heart and see nothing at all, abandoning what is proposed by us, who follow their own spirit. While the name of prophets is common to both the good and the bad according to the rule of the Scriptures, they differ in that the good prophets are said to be wise, but the bad ones are foolish and ignorant. The former refers to ecclesiastical men, the latter to all heretics, who abandoning the spirit of God, follow their own spirit, for they prophesy not by divine inspiration, but from their own heart, therefore they see nothing. But the one who is wise follows not the thoughts of his own heart, but the spirit of God, as it is written in the book of Wisdom (Wisdom 9:17) 'And your counsel who has known, except you give wisdom and send your Holy Spirit from above?' And the prophet also says in another place: 'You shall walk after the Lord your God' (Psalm 27:11). And in another place: 'Lead me in a straight path' (Psalm 143:10). And again: 'Let your good spirit lead me into the land' (Psalm 143:10). And to the people of God, the pillar of fire and the cloud were guides in the wilderness (Exodus 13:21). And Jeremiah speaks: I have not labored following you (Jeremiah XVII, 16). But will not the heretic who follows his own spirit, stumble in darkness, and the blind lead the blind into the pit? Although they may seem to see more in their mysteries, or rather their orgies, than the ecclesiastical teachers, they see absolutely nothing: because they have lost the sun of justice, and in vain imitate those who were once called seers, and to whom it is said: 'Go, you who see: return into the land of Judah; and in Bethel you shall not prophesy' (Amos VII, 12, 13). Therefore, the visions of Isaiah and Obadiah are placed in the titles. And the Lord commanded the apostles: Lift up your eyes and see (John IV, 35). And the prophet humbly prays: Open my eyes, and I will contemplate the wonders of your law (Psalm CXVIII, 18).

<h2 id='tocuniq144'>(Vers. 4 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 4 and following) Your prophets, Israel, will be like foxes in the desert. You did not stand up against them or build a wall for the house of Israel to stand strong in battle on the day of the Lord. They see false visions and speak lies, saying, 'The Lord says,' when the Lord has not sent them; yet they expect their word to be confirmed. Have you not seen false visions and spoken deceptive divinations? But you say, 'The Lord declares,' when I have not spoken. LXX: Like the foxes in the deserts are your prophets, Israel ((Al. they were or will be)). They did not stand firm, but gathered flocks against the house of Israel. Those who say in the day of the Lord: seeing lies, divining vanity, who say, says the Lord, and the Lord did not send them: and they began to stir up discourse. Have you not seen a false vision, and spoken vain divinations? And you would say, says the Lord, and 124 I have not spoken. Let us first speak according to the Hebrew. The prophets of Israel are like foxes, committing daily the thefts of domestic birds: those who dwell, according to Aquila and the Septuagint, in the deserts; according to Symmachus and Theodotion, in the walls and ruins: who cannot ascend against, nor oppose a wall for the house of Israel. We read that Aaron stood in the midst against the fire devouring the people of Israel and opposed a wall for the safety of the people (Num. XVI). In the book of Jeremiah it is also written: 'Do not come before the Lord, nor stand against His anger with persistent prayer' (Jeremiah 7). Just as a wall is set up against an enemy and one usually opposes the one coming from the front: so the will of God is broken by the prayers of the saints. Hence, it is also said to Moses: 'Leave me, and I will destroy this people'. For to whom is it said: 'Leave me' (Exodus 32:10), it is shown that he has the power to hold back. These cannot stand in battle on the Lord's day, to fight for the people with prayers and resist the decrees of God with supplications. Therefore, since they see vanity and divine falsehood, and claim to be sent by the Lord when they are not sent by Him, and persist in errors, and desire to establish their own word, they are accused of preaching all things in vain, saying that their falsehood is the word of the Lord. Furthermore, according to the Septuagint, the sense here is: all heretics are like foxes because of their deceit and wickedness, about whom the Savior speaks: Foxes have holes, and birds of the air have nests (Matth. VIII, 20). And it is written about Herod: 'Tell that fox' (Luke 13:32). And about those same foxes that deceive the innocent and plunder the vineyard of Christ, Solomon speaks: 'Catch the foxes for us, the little foxes that ruin the vineyards' (Song of Solomon 2:15). And in the psalm about those who are deceived by their treachery, it is sung: 'They shall go down into the depths of the earth, they shall be delivered into the hand of the sword, they shall become the portion of foxes' (Psalm 63:10, 11). Prophets who are like foxes did not stand in the firmament; nor did they deserve to hear with Peter: You are Peter, and upon this rock I will build my church (Matthew XVI, 18). Neither are they like Moses, to whom it was said: But you stand here with me (Deuteronomy V, 31). Nor like him who says: He has set my feet upon a rock; but they were tossed about by every wind of doctrine. They did not stand in the firmament, of which we read in the eighteenth psalm (125): The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament declares the works of his hands. These people gathered together the irrational ones, and because of the excessive innocence of the animals, they are like them, against the house of God. Hence now it is said: And the flocks gathered over the house of Israel: neither did they rise, nor were they able to raise others; but whatever they did and do, they are full of lies. And what follows: And they began to stir up talk, it signifies that they indeed want to rise up and lift themselves up to lofty things; but what they desire, they cannot fulfill: and it is said to them: Did you not see false vision and speak of vain divinations? And that which follows, and you were saying, 'Thus says the Lord, and I have not spoken', is not found in the Septuagint.

<h2 id='tocuniq145'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Vers. 8, 9.) Therefore thus says the Lord God: Because you have spoken in vain and have seen lies, behold, I am against you, declares the Lord God. And my hand will be against the prophets who see vanity and who divine lies. They shall not be in the council of my people, nor be enrolled in the register of the house of Israel, nor shall they enter the land of Israel. And you shall know that I am the Lord God. LXX: Therefore say: Thus says the Lord God. Because your words are lies and your divinations are empty, therefore behold, I am against you, says the Lord God, and I will stretch out my hand against the prophets who see lies and speak empty words. They shall not be in the discipline of my people, nor shall they be written in the writings of the house of Israel, nor shall they enter the land of Israel. And they will know that I am the Lord. Under the guise of prophets, this speech is against heretics, who speak empty words and see lies, and persist in establishing their own doctrine. May the Lord himself come against them and rise up, and stretch out his hand against them to strike them, and not hold back to spare them. He threatens that they will not be among the council of the Lord's people, nor in his Church, but in the synagogue of the devil, and not be written in the house of Israel. Of which it is said in another place: Let them be written upon the earth (Jeremiah 17:13): not upon the land of Israel, which is the land of the living, of which it is now said, nor shall they enter into the land of Israel; but upon the land of the dead and the shadow of death, so that after they have suffered these things, separated from the assembly of the people of God, they may understand that he himself is the Lord. For what we translate as 'they shall not be in the council of my people,' the Septuagint translated as 'they shall not be in the discipline or correction of my people.' For there is one kind of correction for adversaries and another for sons. Hence, Jeremiah also says, 'Chastise us, O Lord, but with judgment, not in your anger, lest you make us few in number. Pour out your anger on the nations that do not know you, and on the kingdoms that do not invoke your name.' (Jeremiah X, 24, 25).

<h2 id='tocuniq146'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 onwards) They have deceived my people, saying: peace, and there is no peace. And he himself was building a wall: but they were plastering it with mud without straw. Say to those who plaster without mortar, that it will fall. There will be a flooding rain, and I will give large stones falling from above, and a stormy wind shall scatter them. Indeed, behold, the wall has fallen. Will it not be said to you, where is the plaster that you plastered? Therefore, thus says the Lord God: I will cause a stormy wind to break forth in my fury, and there shall be a flooding rain in my anger, and great hailstones in fury to consume. And I will break down the  wall that you have plastered with whitewash, and bring it down to the ground, so that its foundation will be laid bare. And it shall fall, and you shall be consumed in the midst of it. And you shall know that I am the Lord. Thus will I satisfy my wrath upon the wall, and upon those who have plastered it with whitewash. And I will say to you: The wall is no more, nor those who plastered it. The prophets of Israel who prophesy to Jerusalem and see a vision of peace, but there is no peace, says the Lord God. LXX: For they have deceived my people, saying, 'Peace, peace,' when there is no peace. And one builds a wall, and they plaster it with whitewash. Say to those who plaster it with whitewash, it will fall. There will be overflowing rain, and I will bring great stones upon their joints, and they will fall. And a destructive wind will come and it will be torn down. And behold, the wall has fallen, and they will not ask you, 'Where is the whitewash that you plastered?' Therefore thus says the Lord God: 127 And I will break the spirit that carries away in my fury, and there will be a flood of rain in my anger, and I will bring in great stones in my fury to complete the destruction, and I will dig down the wall that you have plastered, and it will fall. And I will lay it bare on the ground, and its foundations will be exposed, and it will fall. And you will be consumed in my fury, and you will know that I am the Lord. And I will vent my anger against the wall, and against those who plaster it, it will fall. And I said to you: There is no wall, nor those who plaster it, the prophets of Israel who prophesy concerning Jerusalem and see visions of peace for her: there will be no peace for them, says the Lord God. The prophets of Israel, who will not be in the council of the people of God, nor will be written in the scripture of the house of Israel, nor will enter the land of promise, they will suffer these things, because they deceived my people, proclaiming peace and prosperity without true repentance and conversion, according to what is said elsewhere: Peace, peace, where is the peace? (Jeremiah 8:11) Therefore, God metaphorically built for them a wall through the commandments of the law and the words and threats of the holy prophets. For this Hebrew word signifies these things: that it would ward off every incursion of wild beasts and hostile attack from them, while they turned to God, and were encompassed as it were by a wall and most firm barrier. But the false prophets promised them peace, not once only, but frequently: for this repeated word peace signifies. And these false prophets would build this wall, which is called 'Cir' in what follows, with untempered mortar, as Symmachus has interpreted, that is, with pure mud, and which would not have straw, so as neither to afford any strength. But indeed, LXX and Theodotion leave it in folly: but Aquila, interpreting the Hebrew word Thaphel as ἀνάλῳ, which means without salt, passing from one translation to another, just as food without salt has no flavor, so too clay without straw, which gives it strength and binds it, cannot provide any strength to the wall. Say, he says, to those who promise them vain things and offer empty help, that this wall and this barrier will fall, and I will send a very heavy rain, namely the most fierce enemies. But it signifies the Babylonians and the Chaldeans; and it metaphorically refers to the same hailstones rushing down from above, in order to depict a sudden whirlwind that overturns and demolishes an unstable wall; and afterwards it is said to them, that is, to the false prophets, Where is the plaster which you smoothed over, and where is the help which you promised? Moreover, whatever we have said about false prophets can also be applied to heretics, because all their fabrications are dissolved by the anger of God; and the edifice of false doctrines, which the Holy Spirit does not support, crumbles, and collapses down to its foundations and is reduced to dust, and it is leveled to the very earth, and it falls, and the prophets who made the promises are consumed, and the people to whom the promises were made are consumed along with them: so that after God has fully vented His anger and said to them: this wall is not, that is, it is not your defense; and there are none who plaster it, but everything is empty and will achieve nothing: then you will know by these actions that I am the Lord. But so that we may know who those are who plaster the wall, it follows, the prophets of Israel, that is, the false prophets, who prophesy to Jerusalem and see a vision of peace for her. These are the cause of sin and destruction and foolish security. For there will be no peace, says the Lord, because the Lord did not send them, nor did He speak to them. This, which the LXX translated as 'and over their joints,' is not found in the Hebrew. It signifies, however, the joints of stones in the wall or the supports of wood by which the walls are strengthened. And also that which we read above: he himself was building a wall; many report to the people of Israel, who promised themselves vainly, either the help of the Egyptians, or peace.

<h2 id='tocuniq147'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 17 and following) And you, son of man, set your face against the daughters of your people who prophesy from their own hearts. Prophesy against them and say, 'Thus says the Lord God: Woe to those who sew magic charms on all wrists and make veils for the heads of people of every height, in order to ensnare souls. They even ensnare the souls of my people while they seek their own gain. They have violated me among my people for a handful of barley and a piece of bread, killing souls that should not die and keeping alive souls that should not live, by lying to my people who listen to lies.' Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against your cushions, with which you hunt the souls of the flying ones, and I will tear them off your arms, and I will release the souls that you hunt, souls for flying. And I will tear off your necklaces, and I will set my people free from your hand, and they shall no longer be in your hands for plunder. And you shall know that I am the Lord. Because you have made the heart of the righteous sad, whom I have not made sad, and have strengthened the hands of the wicked, so that he does not turn from his evil way and live, therefore you shall no longer see false visions or practice divination. I will deliver my people out of your hand. And you shall know that I am the Lord. LXX: And you, son of man, set your face against the daughters of your people, who prophesy out of their own heart; and prophesy against them, and say, 'Thus says the Lord God: Woe to the women who sew magic charms on their sleeves and make veils for the heads of people of every height, in order to hunt souls! Will you hunt the souls of My people, and keep yourselves alive? And will you profane Me among My people for handfuls of barley and for pieces of bread, killing people who should not die, and keeping people alive who should not live, by your lying to My people who listen to lies?'" } Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against your pillows, with which you hunt down souls, and I will tear them from your arms, and I will let the souls go, even the souls that you hunt to scatter. I will also tear your veils and deliver My people out of your hand, and they shall no longer be in your hand to be hunted; then you shall know that I am the Lord. Because you have perverted the righteous with your lies, and I have not caused him grief, and you have strengthened the hands of the wicked, so that he does not turn from his wicked way to save his life." } Therefore, you will no longer see your lies, and you will not divine any more divinations yet. And I will deliver my people from your hand, and you will know that I am the Lord. Above, the divine word was directed to the prophets, who lined the wall with mud, as it did not have straw, nor could it give any strength to the wall or the wall. Now, it is commanded to the prophetesses of the people to put, or direct, their faces, and, as the Septuagint translated, to strengthen. On the other hand, just as false prophets were inspired by a diabolical spirit to subvert the commands of God, so against prophetesses, such as Deborah (Judges 5) and Huldah (2 Kings 22), and in the Acts of the Apostles, the four daughters of Philip the evangelist who prophesied were inspired by a demonic spirit (Acts 21), as were others of the same sex, among whom were Prisca and Maximilla, who undermined faith in the truth with their false prophecies. But the Hebrews, however, say that they have been instructed in the arts of magic through necromancy and the spirit of Python, such as the one that was seen raising the soul of Samuel (1 Kings 28); and in the Acts of the Apostles, there was a diviner who gained much profit for her masters, from whom the unclean spirit was cast out by the command of the apostle Paul (Acts 16). But we will say this, that other heretics preach the power of their false teachings. Of whom there were Pythagoras and Zeno, from whom the Stoics; also the Brahmins of the Indians, and the Gymnosophists of the Ethiopians, who, because of their abstinence from food, are considered a wonder by their nations. They are rightly said to whitewash the wall and promise some kind of strength; but because they do not have the seasoning of Christ, their labor is in vain and their building will perish. For unless the Lord builds the house, those who build it labor in vain (Psalm 127:1). Other doctors of pleasures and desires, are said to use pillows and to place their hands under every elbow, like the Epicureans and the Pyrrhonists, and among us Jovinianus and Eunomius, who say: Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die. Therefore, the prophet is commanded to set or harden his face against the daughters of his people. And first it must be said, what the set or hardened face signifies. Namely, that which is written about the Lord: The face of the Lord is against those who do evil, to cut off their memory from the earth (Psalm 33:17). For just as wax melts before the face of fire, so the sinners perish before the face of God. According to this meaning, the prophet also says in the same context: Son of man, set your face against Teman and Dara and Negeb. And again: The word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against the sons of Jerusalem. And a little later: The word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against the sons of Ammon. And again: Firm your face upon Pharaoh the king of Egypt (below, XXIX, 2). And again: Son of man, firm your face upon Gog and Magog. And in another place: I will firm my face upon that man, and I will place him in the desert, and in destruction, and I will take him away from the midst of the people: and you will know that I am the Lord (below, XIV, 8). Therefore, woe to these heresies, and to these teachings, which deceive all ages and sexes, promising rest, in order to capture the souls of the wretched and to defile me to my people, while I am believed to love pleasure: and this not because of their, and their half-heartedness, as we read in Hosea (Hosea V), but because of a handful of barley, by which animals are made foolish, and a fragment of bread. Not whole bread, nor solid testimonies of the Scriptures, but those which have been broken, and diminished and cut off by heretical depravity; in order to deceive and lead astray even the holy ones, and to drag them to death; and they contend that they can give life to sinners with empty promises. Therefore, the merciful and compassionate God does not kill the prophetesses themselves, but breaks their snares, which like nets, capture flying souls, so that after they have been broken, they have the free ability to fly. And they would tear the veils or necklaces in which the principal part of the soul reclined and by which the heads of the deceivers were covered. For the Apostle teaches that the heads of men should not be veiled, but rather that they should gaze upon the revealed face of the glory of the Lord (2 Corinthians 3). For you, he says, were breaking the spirits of those who served God with false terrors, and you were keeping the wicked enclosed with deceitful promises, so that while they were not repenting, they would not receive the life which they had lost. Therefore, you will by no means see empty visions, nor will I call your lies prophecies; but divinations, of which it is written: There is no sorcery in Jacob, nor divination in Israel (Num. XXIII, 23): so that I may deliver my people from your hands, and you may come to know that I am the Lord who has saved the lost.

<h2 id='tocuniq148'>(Cap. XIV.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 14, Verse 1 and following) And the elders of Israel came to me and sat before me. And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, these men have set their abominations in their hearts and have set the stumbling block of their iniquity before their faces. Will I be inquired of by them? Therefore speak to them and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: Every man of the house of Israel who sets his abominations in his heart and puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face, and comes to the prophet, I the Lord will answer him according to the multitude of his abominations, that I may lay hold of the house of Israel in their own hearts, because they have all turned away from me to their idols. Therefore say to the house of Israel, ‘This is what the Lord God says: Repent and turn away from your idols, and turn your faces away from all your abominations. For everyone, whether he is of the house of Israel or of the foreigners residing in Israel, who has alienated himself from Me and has set idols in his heart and placed the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face, and who comes to the prophet to inquire of Me through him: I, the Lord, will answer him Myself.' And I will set my face against that man, and will make him a sign and a proverb, and I will cut him off from the midst of my people: and ye shall know that I am the LORD. And if the prophet be deceived when he hath spoken a thing, I the LORD have deceived that prophet, and I will stretch out my hand upon him, and will destroy him from the midst of my people Israel. And they shall bear the punishment of their iniquity: the punishment of the prophet shall be even as the punishment of him that seeketh unto him; that the house of Israel may go no more astray from me, neither be polluted any more with all their transgressions; but that they may be my people, and I may be their God, saith the Lord GOD. LXX: And men from the elders of Israel came to me and sat before me. And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: 133 Son of man, these men have set their thoughts in their hearts, and have set the torment of their iniquities before their face: shall I answer them when they inquire? Therefore speak to them, and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: Every man of the house of Israel who sets his thoughts in his heart, and sets the torment of his iniquity before his face, and comes to the prophet to inquire of him concerning me, I the Lord will answer him according to the multitude of his thoughts: that the house of Israel may be prevented from straying in their hearts, which have gone away from me with their thoughts. Therefore say to the house of Israel, Thus says the Lord God: Repent, and turn from your idols, and turn away your faces from all your abominations. For any man of the house of Israel, or of the strangers that sojourn in Israel, who separates himself from me and sets up idols in his heart and puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face, and comes to the prophet to inquire of him concerning me, I the Lord will answer him myself. And I will set my face against that man; I will make him a sign and a byword and cut him off from the midst of my people, and you shall know that I am the Lord." } And if a prophet should err and speak a word, I the Lord have caused that prophet to err. And I will stretch out my hand against him and destroy him from the midst of my people Israel. And they will bear their iniquity according to the iniquity of the inquirer, and the iniquity of the prophet will be likewise, so that the house of Israel may not stray from me, and they may not still be polluted with all their transgressions. And they will be to me a people, and I will be to them a God, says the Lord God. After he had spoken to the prophets who prophesied in their hearts and lined the wall without restraint; and to the prophetesses who used to wear veils and put their hands under every elbow, and made coverings and covered the heads of the whole age (through which the teaching of perverse doctrines is shown), they came to the prophet, not all of the elders, lest they all seem to err; but some of the elders of Israel, and they sat before the prophet: for what reason they had come, differing in silence; and immediately the word of God came to the prophet, indicating why they were present. For it is not the nature of man, however holy, to know the secrets of the heart. Hence it is said of the Savior alone: And Jesus seeing their thoughts, said: Why do you think evil in your hearts? (Matthew IX). And the meaning is: Son of man, these men who sit before you have placed their uncleanness in their hearts, or their thoughts; and, according to Symmachus and Theodotion, idols and scandal, that is, the ruin and torment of their wickedness, they have placed against their own face, and thus they came to inquire the word of the Lord. Should I respond to such people who come to me with their previous thoughts, not even leaving behind their impious deeds during this time, but believing in idols and fraudulent divinations, harboring the destruction of wickedness against their own face and torment, while despairing of better things and being prepared for punishment, and thus desiring to know my words through you? Therefore, because they have come to you with a perverse heart, you shall not respond to them in your own person, lest the authority of the respondent be seen as trivial; but you shall respond to them by my command, and you shall say to them: Thus says the Lord God. But the overall meaning of the passage, to summarize in a brief explanation, is this: A person is not from any other nations, whose errors may be forgiven, but from the house of Israel. This person, with their previous vices that we have mentioned earlier, comes to inquire of the prophet. I will respond to them according to their heart, and according to their impurities, so that they may hear in accordance with what they desire and believe. For someone who asks not with the intention to learn, but with the intention to test, does not deserve correction. For they have departed from me and have followed idols. And this is a short warning, that they should depart from idolatrous thoughts and perverse intentions, and turn to me, leaving behind their previous (or rather, their own) sins. For he who deceitfully asks questions does not deserve to hear the truth, but should be captivated by his own heart, just as the Scribes and Pharisees, who questioned (or rather, tested) the Lord, heard: Why do you test me? And again: Nor will I tell you by what authority I do these things (Matthew 21:27). But whoever is such a person, and asks in this way, God places his face upon him, or affirms; so that by the severity of his countenance, the hardness of his forehead may be softened, and he may serve as an example, and as a proverb, or for solitude, and for destruction, so that with him being lost from the people of God, others may know that he himself is the Lord who knows the secrets of the heart and understands the wickedness of the mind; he does not consider the words of those who speak, but their hearts. And that which follows seems to raise the question: When a prophet errs and speaks a word, 'I, the Lord, have deceived that prophet,' we cannot call him a true prophet, but a false prophet, who is called a prophet in a secondary sense. And this can be explained by that passage of Scripture, when King Ahab of Israel went to battle, he did not want to listen to the prophet Micaiah, but he followed the advice of the false prophets (3 Kings 22). And Michael said that he saw the Lord sitting on a throne, and the spirit of error offered itself to deceive the king. The devil is also said to go around the earth in the book of Job, and is said to stand in the sight of God and to have power over Job's substance and then over his body (Job 1 and 2). And Balaam the diviner is also sent by the Lord to deceive Balak the son of Beor (Numbers 22). But all of this is said so that the strength of false prophets is not esteemed, that the people may be deceived, and they would rather hear lies than accommodate their ear to truth. But it is because of God's wrath that the wicked and unbelieving people listen more to false prophets than to true prophets. Finally, he extends his hand over him, understood as the prophet, and removes him from the midst of his people, so that he may bear his iniquity, for similar error and similar punishment. In this way, both the one who asks and the one who is asked may bear their iniquity, and the house of Israel, those who have desired to hear the words of God, may not be deceived by false prophecies. Instead, may they be the people of God and deserve to have the Lord. In that which he said: I, the Lord, have deceived him, the words of Solomon agree, who, when speaking about God, says: He will mock the mockers (Prov. III, 34): and this is also a testimony: If the wicked have walked before me; and I will walk against them in perverse fury (Lev. XXVI, 27, 28). And that which is said secondly, man of the children of Israel, and strangers who are joined to them, shows in us, according to the Apostle, the double man, external and internal (I Cor. XV). For many, indeed, having the physical form of a man, they assume the images of various beasts, which the prophet, desiring to scatter, begs: Lord, in your city you will scatter their image (Psalm 72:20). Concerning those of whom it is written: Man, though in honor, does not understand, he is compared with foolish animals and has become like them (Psalm 49:21), they are not men, but men are beasts. Again, those who hear in the Gospel, 'You brood of vipers, how can you escape the coming wrath?' (Matthew 23:33) They are not men but serpents. And about whom it is written, ‘Foxes have dens and birds have nests’ (Matthew 8:20). And about Herod, 'Go tell that fox' (Luke 13:32), they are not men but foxes. But those who possess both the name of man, if they wander, are corrected by punishments so that they understand that He Himself is the Lord. Moreover, what we have also placed according to the LXX: "A man who has been alienated from me and has placed his thoughts in his heart, and torment, or punishment for his wrongdoing before his face, it is testified to him that which is written in Isaiah: 'Walk in the light of your fire, and in the flame that you have kindled' (Isaiah 50:11). For each person kindles the fires of his own desires, and prepares punishments, while he does not want to correct the error with repentance, but remains in errors, deserving the fire of flames.


<h2 id='tocuniq149'>(Vers. 12, 13 seqq.)</h2>

(v. 12, 13 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, when the land sins against me by acting faithlessly, I will stretch out my hand over it, and break the staff of its bread, and send famine upon it, and cut off from it man and beast. Even if these three men, Noah, Daniel, and Job, were in it, they would deliver only themselves by their righteousness, says the Lord God. But if I bring upon that land the worst beasts to lay waste to it and it becomes impassable because of the beasts, and these three men are in it, as I live, says the Lord (add: God), they will not deliver sons or daughters, but they alone will be delivered; but the land will be desolate.
