Or if I bring a sword upon that land and say, ‘Let the sword pass through the land, and I kill men and animals from it,’ and these three men are in the midst of it, as I live, says the Lord God, they will not deliver sons or daughters, but they alone will be delivered. But if I bring a pestilence upon that land, and pour out my indignation upon it in blood, to cut off from it man and beast, even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it, as I live, declares the Lord God, they would deliver neither son nor daughter. They would deliver but their own lives by their righteousness. For thus says the Lord God: Even if I cause harmful judgments of sword, famine, wild beasts, and pestilence to come to Jerusalem, to cut off from it man and beast, yet behold, some survivors will be left in it, sons and daughters who will be brought out; behold, when they come out to you, and you see their ways and their deeds, you will be consoled for the disaster that I have brought upon Jerusalem, for all that I have brought upon it. Behold, they themselves will go out to you, and you will see their way and their inventions, and you will be consoled for the evil that I have brought upon Jerusalem in all that I have imposed upon it. And you will be comforted when you see their way and their inventions, and you will know that I have not done all that I have done in vain, says the Lord God. Four plagues will be brought upon the sinful land, or as the Septuagint has translated, the land of sinners: famine, beast, sword, pestilence. If each of these plagues is brought in parts to each region, and these three men, Noah, Daniel, and Job, whose righteousness is proclaimed in the words of Scripture, will pray for the sinful land, they will not only be unable to save it, but not even their sons and daughters, if they commit the works of the sinful land; they will only be able to save themselves. It is asked why only Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, and other righteous patriarchs and prophets are mentioned, since there were surely others of the same virtue. This is easily explained: Noah, because a great flood was imminent and the whole earth had defiled the ways of the Lord, could not prevent it, but he had his sons, who perhaps were of the same virtue, preserved for the propagation of the human race. Daniel also mitigated the imminent captivity of the Jewish people with no tears (Dan. 1). But Job, not because of sins, but because of testing, did not free his house or his children (Job. 1). Others, however, say that these three men alone witnessed both prosperity and adversity, and then prosperity again: and for this reason they are mentioned together; and this is subtly signified, so that just as those men saw both good and evil, and then joy again: so the people of Israel, who had previously enjoyed good things, and later endured the yoke of captivity, if they repent, may return to their former happiness. But if Noah and Daniel and Job were gathered together and placed in one place, they could not shield the sinful earth, that is, those who dwell on the earth, from the wrath of God. What then can be said of those who believe that through the merits of their parents and virtues, sinful children can be freed from the fires of hell? Hence, neither a sinful son (or rather, a transgressor) can be freed by a righteous father, nor can a chaste mother of good conduct bestow rewards of chastity upon her unchaste daughter. And on the contrary, the vices of parents will not harm their children; but the soul that sins, it shall die (Ezekiel 18:20). Lot, while living in Sodom, saved not only his wife but also his daughters, who perhaps had not sinned (Genesis 19). And the holy man Josiah, not only did he not save the sinful people with his virtues, but he himself died in their sins (2 Kings 23:30). But if at any time the Lord promises his mercy to their descendants because of Abraham and David, it should be noted that he does not spare those who persist in their wickedness, but rather those who repent, so that the conduct of the children might benefit from the merit of their fathers. When, he says, these things are so, and the sinful land is not saved from the punishments of such great men by prayers for mercy, thus says the Lord God: because Jerusalem has committed abominable sins, I will bring upon it four plagues at once: the sword, by which it is slain by enemies; and famine, which it endures during the siege; and beasts, which devour those who flee into the deserts and woods; and pestilence, which always follows hunger and scarcity. But the Vulgate edition translated death for her. He says, "I will bring these things upon her, so that neither men nor animals remain in her." Yet, out of my mercy, I will leave some in her who will raise their sons and daughters, and let the captives come here, that is, to Babylon and Chaldea, so that when you see them and perceive their works, you may understand that they were justly captured and that my judgment was just, and let your captivity bring you consolation. For it is through understanding that I have freed them from sword, famine, beasts, and pestilence, so that you may learn from their wickedness the reason why Jerusalem was destroyed, the temple burned down, and the people led captive, except for those whom the sword, famine, beasts, and pestilence have consumed." 139} These things were said about that Jerusalem, of which Ezekiel prophesied among the Chaldeans, captivity was drawing near. Furthermore, also upon our land, to which it is said: You are dust, and to dust you shall return (Gen. III, 19); and upon our Jerusalem, and upon each of the believers, if they have despised God's commandments and have become transgressors, famine will be brought upon them; not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but a famine of hearing the word of God. The sword shall be brought forth, of which we read: They shall be delivered into the hands of the sword: the parts of foxes were (or will be). (Psalm 63:11). And to Mary: A sword shall also pierce through your own soul. (Luke 2:35). The beasts shall be brought forth, for whom it is asked that the righteous man not be delivered: Do not deliver the soul of the one who confesses to you to the beasts. (Psalm 73:19). The plague shall be brought forth (which seventy interpreters have translated as death), of which it is written: The worst death is the death of sinners. (Psalm 34:22). And: The soul that sins, it shall die. And if bitter death separates in this way? Concerning all these things, neither the teaching of spiritual parents, whom we understand as teachers, nor the rulers will be able to deliver, unless there is agreement from the sons, and their pleas have helped their efforts. For the righteousness of the righteous will be upon him, and the wickedness of the wicked will dwell within him: Each one will die for their own sin, and their righteousness will save them. And the Jews say in vain: Abraham is our father (John VIII), when they do not have the works of Abraham. But if there is any confidence, let us only trust in the Lord. For cursed is every man who has hope in man (Jeremiah XVII, 5), even if they are holy, even if they are prophets. We read: Do not trust in men (Psalm CXLV, 2). And again: It is good to trust in the Lord, rather than to trust in princes (Psalm CXVII, 6). Not only in secular rulers, but also in the rulers of the Churches, those who are just will only save their own souls. However, they will not be able to save the sons and daughters whom they have begotten in the Church if they are negligent. And yet the Apostle says: If anyone's work is burned up, he himself will be saved, but only as through fire (1 Corinthians 3:15). But the hand is stretched out over the earth, which is given over to transgression, so that the rod or strength of bread may be crushed. She threatens with outstretched plagues, unwillingly extended by those who extend her, and she raises (them) to strike sinners, but (she does it) to frighten with extension, and to preserve the frightened.

<h2 id='tocuniq150'>(Cap. XV.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 15, Verses 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, what will be made of the vine tree among all the trees of the woods that are among the trees of the forest? Will wood be taken from it to make something, or will a peg be made from it to hang any vessel on? Behold, it is given to the fire as food; the fire has consumed both ends of it, and the middle of it has been turned into ashes. Will it be useful for any work? Even though it was intact, it was not suitable for work: how much more so when the fire has consumed and burned it, will nothing come of its work? Therefore, thus says the Lord God: As the vine tree among the trees of the forest, which I have given to the fire for consumption, so I will give the inhabitants of Jerusalem; and I will set my face against them. They will come out from the fire, and the fire will consume them. And you shall know that I am the Lord, when I set my face against them and make the land desolate and deserted, because they have been rebellious, says the Lord God. Regarding the interpretation that we have provided: both parts of it were consumed by fire, and half of it was reduced to ashes. The Seventy translated: The annual purification consumes it by fire, and it is released at the end. Again, where we said: When I turn my face towards them, they turned it, when I become stiff-necked. They also interpreted transgression as a betrayal. Moreover, through various similitudes, which the Greeks call parables, the destruction of the city of Jerusalem is foretold. And just as above (in chapter IV), the siege and famine of the same city are described, in which a pan was used to cool the meat of the people, and on the side where the fortifications and the mounds of battering rams and siege engines were painted, and afterwards we read about it here: it is also written in Jeremiah (Jeremiah I, 13), 'The pot that is boiling in the face of the north wind signifies the city of Jerusalem'; and the cuts of the Negev, and Teman, and Darom, signify the same thing: thus in the present passage, the same Jerusalem is compared to fruitful vineyards and vines. Of which it is written elsewhere: I have planted you a fertile vine, all true: how have you turned into the bitterness of a strange vine? (Jerem. II, 21.) And in Isaiah: I have planted, he says, a choice vine (Isai. V, 2), which signifies both choice and beautiful. And in the Psalms we read: You have brought a vine out of Egypt: you have cast out the nations, and have planted it: you were the leader of its journey (Psal. LXXIX, 9). And we learn more clearly, Scripture saying: But the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel (Isai. V, 7). As long as this vineyard produces fruit, there is nothing more valuable than it among all the trees of the forest; but if it ceases to bear grapes, it will be useless in every way, except to be handed over to the fire along with its roots and branches. The other trees of the forests (not to mention the fruit-bearing trees, of which Scripture makes no mention at this time) may not have fruit, but when cut down, they offer great utility for all of agriculture and the use of weapons: they are made into shields, shaved into spears, used for doors, contained in chests, barrels, and provide all the household furnishings. But if the vine once ceases to produce grapes, it is so useless that not even a peg can be made from it to hang something on. And when you remove the small hammers, the fire first seizes both parts of them, then the flame consumes them: and it is of so little advantage when it has been reduced to ashes, that even when it is intact, it provides no usefulness without fruits. However, there is ambiguity in the Hebrew word Sene (), which is written with three letters, Sin and Nun and Yod; if it is read as Sene, it means two; if it is read as Sane, it means years. And it came to pass that for its two extremities, which we have interpreted as both parts of it, the Seventy interpreted as its annual purgation: when Aquila said, its two last things; Symmachus to Theodotion, its two extremities. And the order is this: Just as a fruitless vine is handed over to fire for no usefulness: so too Jerusalem, indeed its inhabitants will be handed over to burnings, so that they may go out from the fire, and fire may consume them, that is, even if they escape from the city, they will be consumed outside by the enemy's sword; and those who remain, pressed down by the weight of miseries, will recognize that I am the Lord: when I set or harden my face against them, and deliver them into eternal desolation. For sinners are not like other peoples, but they have become transgressors. For it is one thing to neglect what you do not know: it is another to despise what you have worshipped. We can understand the vineyard and Jerusalem in a spiritual sense, to mean the multitude of believers. And if it is neglected and loses the cultivation of its ancient religion, and does not bring forth the fruits of virtue, nor produce the wine that gladdens the heart of man, it will be handed over to eternal burnings and considered as nothing. For the servant who knows his master's will and does not do it, he will be beaten with many blows (Luke 12:47). Something similar the Lord speaks in the Gospel according to John: I am the true vine, and my Father is the vinedresser. Every branch in me that does not bear fruit he takes away, and every branch that does bear fruit he prunes, that it may bear more fruit (John 15:2). Indeed, the Savior is the vine, and we are the branches, and God (also called the Father) is the vinedresser. As long as we keep God's commandments, we are always being cultivated and our cultivation is a purification: For it is not of him who wills, nor of him who runs, but of God who shows mercy (Romans 9:16). But if we bring forth fruit, we are pruned by the Father, so that we may bring forth more abundant fruit. It is shown that all our effort, with the help of God, reaches its end and bears the fruit of fullness. But whoever does not bear fruit, will be taken away by the Father. And when he is taken away, Scripture does not say what the Father does with him, unless perhaps separation from Christ's body is an everlasting punishment and destruction. What we have understood in the vineyard and the vine, the Savior teaches under a different figure in the Gospel: Salt is good, but if the salt has lost its taste, it is useless, except to be thrown out and trampled by men. (Mark 9:49). And if the eye that illuminates the whole body is blind, it can hear from the Lord: If the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness (Matthew 6:23, 13)? For in comparison to the transgressor and the one who denies God at first, the punishment is lighter for those who have never known God. And the trees of the woods or forests, according to the variety of believers, have some usefulness in a great house; in which there are not only golden and silver vessels, but also wooden and earthenware ones; some for honor and others for dishonor (2 Timothy 2).


<h2 id='tocuniq151'>(Cap. XVI.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter XVI - Verses 1, 2) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, make known Jerusalem its abominations, and you shall say: Thus says the Lord God to Jerusalem. Septuagint: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, testify against Jerusalem its iniquities, and you shall say to her: Thus says the Lord Adonai. In these verses, the summary of each prophecy was brief, so we have included the entire chapters, immediately following. But because the discourse is directed towards Jerusalem, testifying and teaching about the sins that she has committed; and it extends almost to the number of two hundred verses, until that place where it is written: When I have been appeased to you in all that you have done, says the Lord God, we must put every prophecy in parts; and we must join fitting explanations to those things which we have proposed. Under the person of a harlot woman who was first joined in the company of men, Jerusalem and her origin, and upbringing, and puberty, and marriage, and adultery, and divorce, and again restoration are intertwined; so that both the kindness and judgment of the man, and the crimes of the adulteress and harlot may be known, while after all the punishments he raises up to her an everlasting covenant: so that she may remember her iniquity, and may be confounded, and may no longer have the mouth open because of her own confusion, when he has been appeased to her in all that she has done. For it is very profitable for sinners to know what they have done. Hence the penitent speaks: For I know my iniquity, and my sin is always before me (Psalm 50:4). However, Jerusalem can be understood in four ways: Either as that which was burnt by the fire of the Babylonians and Romans; or as the heavenly Jerusalem; or as the Church, which is interpreted as the vision of peace; or as the souls of individuals who, by faith, behold God. And what many think should be interpreted as the heavenly Jerusalem, the Church does not accept, lest we be compelled to interpret all the things contained in the present prophecy as referring to the ruins and torments of heavenly powers, and their restoration to their original state.


<h2 id='tocuniq152'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) Your lineage and generation are from the land of Canaan (Vulgate: Chanaea). Your father is Amorite, and your mother is Hittite. Great is the faith and grand the audacity of the prophets, accusing one man, the whole city of ignobility. Marvelous is Daniel, who dared to speak to a aged sinner, joining adultery with murder, saying: 'The seed of Canaan, not Judah, has deceived you' (Dan. 13:56). Magnificent is Isaiah, who cries out to the princes and people of Judah: 'Hear the word of the Lord, O princes of Sodom, give ear to the law of our God, O people of Gomorrah' (Isa. 1:10)." } But not lesser is Ezekiel, who speaks confidently to the whole city: Your root and your lineage are from the land of Canaan: your father is Amorite and your mother is Hittite. Although Stephen, the first martyr of the Gospel, spoke to the insane people (Acts 7:51): You resist always the Holy Spirit with stiff neck and uncircumcised heart (or you resist always, [as] other versions say). And though we may understand that the root of Jerusalem and its lineage are the land of Canaan, according to what is said that the people was called in Egypt and lived there for a long time (for Ham, the father of Canaan, was the chief of the Egyptian nation), nevertheless, according to the likeness of their crimes, we will say that the root of Jerusalem is the land of Egypt: Whence its father is also called Amorite, which is interpreted as ‘multo sermone celebratus’ (celebrated with much speech). And your mother Chethaea, that is, being out of her mind; either she herself is insane or she sends others into insanity. For everyone who commits sin is born of the devil (John 8:54). Therefore, throughout the whole world, this famous name of the ancient father exists, and it turns many into insanity. And it is commanded to Jerusalem, either according to the literal sense or according to the spiritual sense, to abandon the ancient father, and it is said to her: Listen, daughter, and see, and incline your ear; and forget your people, and your father's house; and the king will desire your beauty (Psalm 44:11). And it is promised to him that if he truly desires to return to the true Father after sin: I will restore you as you were when you were born. Whose nobility is so great, that the city of Jerusalem, which descended from the lineage of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, had God as its Father? And yet because he sinned and abandoned the true parent, he deserves to hear: Your root and your generation are from the land of Canaan: Your father is Amorite, and your mother is Hittite. If she heard this, what will happen to us who are called from the filth of the nations, having washed away every stain in the bath of the Savior, if we defile the garment of Christ and do not have the wedding garment at the banquet? Certainly, let us be handed over to eternal burnings, with our hands and feet bound, in which there is weeping of the eyes and gnashing of teeth (Matthew 22).

<h2 id='tocuniq153'>145 (Vers. 4, 5.)</h2>

145 (Vers. 4, 5.) And when you were born, on the day of your birth your umbilical cord was not cut, and you were not washed in water for cleansing, nor were you rubbed with salt, nor were you wrapped in swaddling cloths. No eye had pity on you, to do any of these things for you out of compassion: but you were thrown out on the open field, for the abjection of your life, on the day you were born. LXX: And on the day you were born, they did not bind your breasts, and your umbilical cord was not cut, and you were not washed in water for cleansing, nor were you rubbed with salt, and you were not wrapped in swaddling cloths. No eye had pity on you, to do any of these things for you, and no one had mercy on you, and you were thrown out on the open field, in the corruption of your soul, on the day you were born. Let us discuss the order of reading about each. When Jerusalem was born from the father of the Amorite and the mother of the Hittite, and was poured out from the womb, her umbilicus was not cut, by which the fetus is nourished in the womb like trees and branches, which are nourished by the hidden moisture of the earth through their roots. And just as the seed of men is signified in the loins, so the female genitals are called umbilicus in honorable speech according to the custom of the Scriptures, as testified by Job, who speaks figuratively of the Devil as a dragon: His power is in his loins, and his strength is in the navel of his belly (Job 40:11). For this ancient serpent, called the devil and Satan, who deceived the world, has power over men in the loins, and over women in the belly. But this signifies about Jerusalem: that it did not immediately receive the law, nor were the beginnings of its shameful birth cut off from it: but it first lived a Gentile life; for which reason the Seventy translated: On the day you were born, your breasts were not bound (Ezek. 7), having this holy Scripture custom, that it may use the word 'heart', 'bosom' or 'breasts' according to each appropriate context. Priests in whom there must be teaching, and they require the law from their mouth, receive a small chest. John lies on the chest of the Lord in order to draw from the most abundant fountain the streams of wisdom. In the Song of Songs, the Virgin has two breasts, like two twin kids of a she-goat, which feed on lilies until the day breathes and the shadows are cast away. The loving mother immediately binds her daughter's breasts as soon as she is born, so that they cease from tender swelling and preserve virgin beauty. But when she reaches the age of puberty, it will be said of her: Will the bride forget her adornment, or the virgin her waistband? (Jeremiah II, 32) It follows: And you have not been washed in water for your salvation. The bodies of newborn infants, as soon as they are expelled from the womb, are usually washed: so too does the spiritual generation need the saving bath. For no one is clean from filth, not even if his life were of only one day. (Job XXVI, 14, 15). And in the Psalms we read: 'In iniquities I was conceived, and in sins my mother conceived me' (Psalm 50:7). The second birth cancels out the first birth. For it is written: 'Unless a man be born again of water and the Holy Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God' (John 3:5). There are many washings which the Gentiles have in their mysteries, and the heretics promise: they all wash, but they do not wash unto salvation. Therefore it is added: 'and in which you were not washed unto salvation.' This can be understood not only about heretics, but also about members of the Church who do not receive baptism with full faith for salvation. It should be said about them that they have received water, but they have not received the Spirit. Just like Simon Magus, who tried to buy God's grace with money, he was indeed baptized in water, but he was not baptized for salvation. Thirdly, it is said: it is not salted with salt. When the tender bodies of infants still retain the warmth of the womb and first declare the beginnings of their laborious life with cries, they are usually rubbed with salt by midwives, so that they become drier and more compact. Furthermore, Jerusalem, which was born of wicked parents, has achieved nothing of taste, nothing of diligence. But those who are reborn in Christ, it is said to them: You are the salt of the earth (Matth. V, 5); and it is commanded to them by the Apostle: Let your speech always be seasoned with grace (Coloss. IV, 6). Hence, both wise people and fools are called tasteless. And in the Book of Leviticus it is decreed by the law: Your every sacrifice shall be seasoned with salt. The salt of the Testament of the Lord will not cease from your sacrifices: in all your offerings you shall offer salt (Leviticus II, 13). Whoever has been seasoned with this salt and has dried up every rotten and harmful moisture by its mixture, will no longer say: My wounds have putrefied and become corrupted from the face of my foolishness (Psalm XXXVII, 6). I know that I have read in a certain volume about the Lord Savior, that he himself is the heavenly salt; and not only does he season earthly and infernal things, but he also shares his flavor with heavenly things: so that what is written may be fulfilled: Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace to people of good will (Luke II, 14). The fourth thing is: to be not wrapped in swaddling clothes. And the Savior was wrapped in swaddling clothes as an infant, and everyone who is born needs God's protection through the wrapping of cloth. It is natural, however, that when parents are not lacking in care, the umbilical cord of newly born infants is first cut off, then they are washed with water to cleanse the blood. Thirdly, the moisture of the little bodies is dried by adding salt. Fourthly, so that the tender bodies of infants are wrapped in swaddling clothes for two reasons: so that the body, which is dried with salt, does not leak through the clothes, is preserved and tightened; and to prevent the most delicate limbs from easily becoming deformed. And even the bodies of the Barbarians are healthier than Roman bodies. Until the second and third year, they are always wrapped in swaddling clothes. But not such is Jerusalem, whose navel is not cut, nor are her breasts bound, nor is she washed with water for her health, nor is she salted with salt, nor is she swaddled and constrained by the garments of infancy. But why has she deserved none of these things? The following Scripture testifies. The eye has not spared you, to make one of them for you, having mercy on you. For which reason the seventy made this translation: Your eye has not spared you, in order that I might make one out of all these. And it is necessary that the double edition have a double understanding. The prior one signifies this: Your eye has not spared you, in order to make one of these out of pity for you. And the sense is: No one has had pity on you, offending God; no one's bowels have been moved on your behalf, that at least one of the four might be made for you; because you did not deserve to receive all at once. In another it is said: Your eye did not spare you, so that I may have mercy on you. And this is its meaning: You have acted in this way, and thus you were born in sin, and your mother conceived you in iniquity, so that she did not even have mercy on you herself. And when you acted in such a way that you became cruel towards yourself through evil deeds: what could I do for you, who did not even deserve to receive one of the good things of the past? Therefore, because none of the things that usually happen to infants happened to you; and this happened not without reason or without judgment, but because of your fault and sin, for which even you yourself did not have mercy: therefore you were cast down on the face of the earth, or the fields; and you were cast down because of the wickedness of your soul on the day you were born. Let us pray that we may not be cast down by the wickedness of the soul into the face of the field, in which there is a wide and spacious road that leads to death; in which the cavalry of the Chaldeans revels. And at the same time, it must be considered that no one can commit any evil on the day he is born, except at the time of the bath, when the wise generation of the faithful believer is taken in faith.

<h2 id='tocuniq154'>(Vers. 6, 7.)</h2>

(Verse 6, 7.) But passing by you: I saw you trampled in your own blood. And I said to you when you were in your blood, live: I said, I say to you, in your blood, live. I multiplied you like the growth of the field, and you came in and reached the female world. Your breasts swelled, and your hair sprouted: and you were naked and full of confusion. LXX: And I passed by you, and saw you mixed in your own blood, and I said to you, from your blood, multiply life, as I gave you the rising of the field, and you multiplied, and became great, and you entered the cities of cities. Your breasts were upright, and your hair was grown: yet you were naked and full of shame. After you were cast face down on the ground, or on the surface of the earth, because of the wickedness of your soul, I no longer deserved to help you. Nevertheless, as I passed by, I saw you trampled upon, or mixed in your own blood, that is, guilty of mortal sins. And I provoked you, granting you repentance, and I said to you: Although you are in blood, live converted; and there was such abundance of all things in you, that you had the likeness of the most fertile fields, and the blessing of Jacob, which his father gave him, saying: Behold, the smell of my son is as the smell of a full field which the Lord has blessed (Gen. XXVII, 27); and you would enter the innermost chambers of the Lord, and you would say with the bride: The king brought me into his chamber (Song of Songs I, 3); and you would reach the land of womanhood, for which the Septuagint translated: and you entered into the cities of cities; so that just as the Song of Songs is called the Saeculum and the world, so the cities may be called the cities of cities. Of which it is said in the Gospel: 'You shall have power over ten, or over five cities' (Luke XIX, 17, 18): so that not only the city, but also the metropolis of the city, may be called faithful Zion, according to what is read in Isaiah: 'Faithful mother of cities' (Isa. I, 26, 27). Furthermore, what Symmachus interpreted, 'and you have come to the adornment of women', or as Theodotio, 'and you have entered into the adornment of adornments', for which we have explained the Hebrew meaning: 'and you have come to the world of women', indicates the time of puberty, when girls are called nubile and can be joined to their husbands' embraces. Finally, it follows: Your breasts swelled, and your hair grew. The honorable maturity of young girls is indicated when their breasts swell or rise, and their hair grows. And when she was prepared for marriage, and had the beauty of her body, she did not have the coverings of clothing, nor was she protected by the help of God. If anyone does not have the clothing of Christ, they are naked. If anyone is not clothed with the bowels of mercy, goodness, humility, chastity, meekness, patience, they lie upon the face of the earth: and their beauty is defiled by confusion and nakedness." }


<h2 id='tocuniq155'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Verse 8) And I passed by you and saw you, and behold, it was your time, the time of lovers. And I spread my cloak over you and covered your shame. Septuagint: And I passed by you and saw you, and behold, it was your time, the time of revelers; and I spread my wings over you and covered your shame. What mercy! It was not enough to see her once trampled in blood and provoke her to repentance, but he visited her again, even though she was sinning, and because she was naked and full of shame, he came and visited her again, and behold, it was her time, the time of lovers; whether according to the Septuagint, the time of revelers, or according to the second interpretation of Aquila, the time of marriage, namely, the time of betrothal and wedding; according to the first edition of the same and Theodotion, the time of breasts, which is interpreted as the time of nursing; for which Symmachus translates it as the time of love, which signifies affection. Therefore, that was the time when women could join with men and endure marital intercourse. However, merciful God spread His wings and received them, and He carried them on His shoulders, numbering 150, according to what is written in the Gospel: 'How often have I desired to gather your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you were not willing' (Luke 12:34)? Or He extended His cloak as wings, which is interpreted as the winged cover under which Ruth slept at the feet of Boaz (Ruth 3). And on the border, that is, the fringe of our garment, we are commanded to attach hyacinth fringes. This, however, was done to cover the shame of Jerusalem: showing the female genitalia under this name. Indeed, according to the Apostle: We surround the dishonorable parts of our body with greater honor (I Cor. XII, 13). Therefore, the Psalmist sings: Blessed are those whose sins are forgiven, and those whose sins are covered (Ps. XXXI, 1). As for Cham, because he did not protect his father, he is marked with eternal curse (Genes. IX). Let us apply what we have said about Jerusalem to our own soul, which, as long as it is in infancy, is free from sin. However, when the time of its maturity comes, there are many lovers of demons and heretics, and of perverse doctrines, who desire to lead it astray. They are repelled by the protection of God, so that it receives not the followers of the devil, but the ministers of the Savior. Concerning those who turn aside, there is in Hebrew the word Dodim (lovers), which, according to the meaning of their language, signifies all that has been mentioned above. The time of love and the love of God, can be understood in Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: when the Lord promised to them the liberation of his people after the servitude in Egypt.

And I swore to you; and I entered into a covenant with you, says the Lord God. LXX: And I swore to you, and I entered into a covenant with you, says the Lord God. For I spread my garment, or my wings, over you: and I covered your shame: therefore I swore to you, and I entered into a covenant, or testament, with you: that you would be joined to me rather than to others who wanted to turn to you, according to that, The Lord has sworn and he will not repent: you are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek (Ps. 109:4; Heb. 6). For the end of every controversy is an oath. And as I live, says the Lord: unless the sinner repents of his evil, he shall suffer death (Ezek. XVIII). Therefore, at the time of marriage, Israel receives the oath of God, for every dowry gift. And because David has spoken thus: Remember, O Lord, David, and all his meekness (Ps. CXXXI, 1): he who has sworn to the Lord, has vowed to God, the God of Jacob; and the Lord himself swears to him, the Scripture says: The Lord has sworn in truth to David, and he will not disappoint him (Ibid., 11).


<h2 id='tocuniq156'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9.) And you became mine, and I washed you with water, and I cleansed your blood from you, and I anointed you with oil. For I spread out my wings, and I covered your disgrace, and I swore to you, and I entered into a covenant with you; therefore you have become my possession: so that what belonged to another, when you appeared unclean, you began to belong to me, when I confirmed my covenant with you by oath. Or according to the custom of the prophets: you have become mine, he says, because you are united to me by the marriage bond: and I washed you, he says, with the water of saving baptism. For unless one is born again of water and the Holy Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God (John 3:5). And elsewhere we read: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire (Mark 1:8). This baptism is also spoken of by the prophet Isaiah, saying: The Lord will wash away the filth of the sons and daughters of Zion; and he shall cleanse the blood from their midst, with the spirit of judgment and the spirit of burning (Isaiah 4:4). But when he has washed and cleansed the blood, like the woman who had been hemorrhaging for twelve years and was healed by touching the hem of his garment (Mark 5), water alone is not enough to wash and blood alone is not enough to cleanse, unless he anoints with oil as well. Just as the Samaritan, who is interpreted as guardian, first soothed the wounds with the infusion of oil and then restrained them with the severity of wine (Luke 10). But our Lord was anointed with another oil, which did not mitigate the pain of wounds, but gave joy, as the Holy Spirit said to him: Therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of gladness above your companions (Ps. 44:8). And there are also counterfeit strengths that pretend to be soothing oils, promising sweet things through heretics; but they turn into bitterness, which the prophet detests when he says: But the oil of the sinner shall not anoint my head (Ps. 140:5). But if one is anointed from an anointing, that is, Christ is called, see how much Jerusalem has advanced: so that she herself, anointed with spiritual oil, has received the name of Christ; according to which we also read in the Psalms concerning Abraham: 'Do not touch my anointed ones, and do no harm to my prophets.'

<h2 id='tocuniq157'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) And I clothed you in multicolored garments. LXX: And I clothed you in various garments: The ceremonies of the Law, in the pursuit of which you abandoned idols. These are the various garments with which Joseph was clothed: and his brothers could not sell him unless they first stripped him of his varied tunic (Gen. XXXVII). And concerning the bride, it is said in the forty-fourth psalm: The queen stood at your right hand in a golden garment, surrounded by variety (Ps. XLIV, 10). This is the clothing about which the Apostle speaks: Put on the new man, who is renewed in knowledge according to the image of the Creator (Ephes. IV, 24). We want to know what are the various clothing? Let the same Apostle teach us, writing to the Believers: Therefore, clothe yourselves with the bowels of mercy, kindness, humility, meekness, patience (Coloss. III, 12). What is more beautiful than this variety? About which even Job spoke: Who gave wisdom to women for weaving, or knowledge of various colors (Job. XXXVIII, sec. LXX)? And the high priest, once a year, when he offered sacrifice for the people, entered into the Holy of Holies, and used various garments (Exodus 39; Hebrews 9). Surely if the richness of different garments and not holiness and the diversity of virtues made distinctions, these garments would be attributed to Pharaoh and Nebuchadnezzar, and not to Joseph, who, under a foreign and pastoral father, could not have colorful and royal clothes.

And I shoed you with jacinth. LXX: And I shoed you with hyacinth. Aquila and Symmachus, jacinth; Septuagint and Theodotion, hyacinth. For which it is written in Hebrew, Thas. And because the speech is beautifully directed to Jerusalem, and under the persona of a woman, all her adornment is expressed, jacinth or hyacinth shoes are narrated, which do not suit the persona of men. Finally, the making of the Passover is commanded, without any variation of color, so that they may be girded with loins and shod with feet. These are the shoes about which the Apostle writes: having your feet shod with the preparation of the Gospel of peace. Philo, a most eloquent man among the Jews, compares hyacinth in the garments of the high priest to bronze, by which he believes heavenly and celestial things are signified. Neither is Jerusalem shod in hyacinth shoes until it is washed with water. Hence, the feet of the Apostles are washed by the Savior, to whom the Lord had previously commanded them to shake off the dust of their feet (Matthew 10). And the bride says in the Song of Songs: I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them? (Song 5:3). And divine scripture witnesses to both Moses and Joshua (Exodus 3) to loosen the strap of their sandals, for the place on which they stand is holy. But once their feet have been washed and cleansed of all filth, they are clad in hyacinth or purple-colored sandals, both of an airy and blue hue, so that they may be caught up into the presence of the Lord in the air and hasten to the heavenly realms.


And I have girded thee with fine linen. Jerusalem is adorned not only with diverse colors and adorned with hyacinth, but it is also girded with fine linen, from which the finest threads are woven into the vestment of the high priest. And the wife in Proverbs, who makes double cloaks for her husband, both for this age and for the future, is said to have made garments for herself from fine linen and purple (Prov. XXXI). With this fine linen, the loins are girded whenever the abundant incentives of desire need to be restrained, and nothing of gross humors ((or, of gross Venus)) is left in them: and we fulfill the commandment of the Apostle who says: Stand therefore, having your loins girded about with truth (Ephes. VI, 14); as if he were saying in other words, with fine linen. And the Lord speaks to the Apostles: Let your loins be girded, and your lamps burning in your hands (Luke 22:35). For unless we bind up the flowing rheum of the loins, we are not able to hold lamps in our hands. Hence God speaks to Job: Gird up your loins like a man (Job 38:3). And those who partake of the Lamb, having their feet shod, holding a staff, standing in the truth of the Gospel, and prepared for Christ's blood, are said to have their loins girded (Exodus 12). In the region where the loins are mortified, Elijah and John the Baptist are girded (4 Kings 1; Mark 1). Concerning them, the repentant one moans lamentably, saying: For my loins are filled with illusions (Psalm 37:8).

And I adorned you with fine clothing. LXX: And I surrounded you with threefold garments. For which Aquila translated as 'florid' or 'palpable'; Symmachus, as 'a garment'; Theodotio put the Hebrew word 'Messe' (). And when I diligently inquired what the word 'trichapto' meant, which the LXX translated, and I could not find its usage or etymology in any Greek word, I finally learned that it is a compound word from the LXX (for new things require new names), which signifies a garment of such great delicacy that it is believed to have the thinness of hair and threads. And so I, wanting to express the thinness of the garment, translated it as 'subtilibus' for 'trichapto', because it was woven with a thin thread and covering. And appropriately for those people, of whom he said in rebuke: 'This people's heart has become fat, and Jacob has eaten and drunk and become satisfied and fat, and his beloved has kicked and abandoned his Maker' (Deut. XXXII, 15), now the thinness of garments is forgiven. For even in the book of Wisdom, which is attributed by some to Solomon, the spirit of wisdom is called the only-begotten and manifold, thin and changeable (Sap. VII). And manna, of which it is written, 'Man ate the bread of angels' (Ps. 77:25), is said to have been as fine as frost and to have resembled coriander seed (Exod. 16). According to the interpretation of the second edition of Aquila, who interpreted it as flourishing, we can understand it as clothing or the fertility of the land of Judah through metaphor, or the beauty of divine worship.

<h2 id='tocuniq158'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11.) And I adorned you with ornaments. Now he lists the ornaments in general, which he enumerates in the following sections, armlets and a necklace, earrings and a crown, and the rest of the ornaments that he gave to Jerusalem, as it is said in Isaiah that she lost them all because of her own fault. For it is written: Because the daughters of Jerusalem are haughty and walk with an outstretched neck (Isa. 3:16-17), and the rest: instead of a belt, they are girded with ropes, instead of a head-dress, they are disfigured with baldness, and instead of beautiful and soft clothing, they are surrounded by the roughness of sackcloth." }


And I gave bracelets into your hands. LXX: And I surrounded your hands with bracelets. When God has given us good works, He encircles our hands with bracelets. Hence it is said to be likened to the hands of prophets (Hosea 13), and frequently in the hand of Haggai or Jeremiah and other similar statements we have read (Haggai 1). In Job also the lip of the dragon is pierced by a bracelet, and all of its venomous hisses, which are understood in perverse doctrines, are pierced by the circle of good works (Job 40).


And he will remove the ornament from their neck, which we have translated as torque according to the second edition of Aquila and Symmachus. The Septuagint and Theodotion translated it as κάθεμα, which is written not only here, but also in Isaiah: The Lord will take away the glory of their garments, the headbands, the crescent ornaments, the pendants, and the κάθεμα (Isa. III, 18). But I think κάθεμα is derived from various gems descending as a necklace on the chest of women, which is also the most beautiful adornment for women.


<h2 id='tocuniq159'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(Verse 12) And I put a ring on your nose, or, your nostrils. The Hebrew word Nezem (), except Symmachus, who interpreted it as ἐπιῤῥίνιον, all translated it as a ring: not that rings are placed in the nostrils, which are called rings because they hang from the ears: but so that the circles made in the shape of earrings may be called by the same name, and even to this day among other women's ornaments, golden circles are accustomed to hang from the front of the face and hover over the nostrils. We receive these [mystical perceptions] when, together with the Apostle, we can say that we are a sweet aroma of Christ in those who are saved and in those who perish. To some, we are a fragrance of death leading to death, but to others, we are a fragrance of life leading to life (2 Corinthians 2:15). When we are alive and it can be said of us, 'The dead do not praise you, O Lord, nor do those in the realm of the dead' (Psalm 115:17), then God smells the sweet fragrance of our sacrifice and we have a golden circle of senses and divine doctrines in our nostrils. When we are truly dead and we are immersed in filth and the filth of disgrace, we have that nose ring, about which Solomon wrote: Like a golden nose ring on a pig’s snout, so is the beauty of a woman who is ill-tempered.

And circles in your ears. LXX: And 156 wheels above your ears. He closes his ears, so as not to hear the judgment of blood, and he covers them with thorns, so that he may not become a partaker with the envious and detractors, of whom it is written: Do not associate with detractors, for their destruction will come suddenly, and who knows the ruin of both (Prov. XXIV, 21, 22)? Specifically, this applies to both the one who detracts and the one who willingly listens: the former has circles and wheels in his ears, not the wheels that the Cherubim follow (for that belongs to angelic strength), but rather small wheels that are in keeping with human frailty. Therefore, it is said to God: The voice of your thunder is in the wheel (Psalm 76:19). Indeed, in those who pass through earthly things and barely touch the ground with their small steps, of which it is written: Holy stones roll upon the earth (Zechariah 9:16), the voice of the thunder of the Lord resounds, and the sound of lofty teachings. But those who are led astray by human errors and do not have solid footsteps, but are carried about by every wind of doctrine (Ephesians 2), and expelled from the paradise of firmness, dwell in the region of Naid, which means fluctuation, they deserve to bear eloquence of falsehood, which inflames the wheel of our birth (Genesis 4).


And a crown of beauty on your head. LXX: And a crown of glory upon your head. We have interpreted 'decor' according to Symmachus for the sake of elegant meaning. Otherwise, in Hebrew, it is called 'Thopherth', and in other translations, it is called 'καύχησις' or 'gloriatio'. The other ornaments belong to individual body parts. The adornment of the head is the dignity of the entire body. But it calls the crown the diadem of women, by which the hair is bound and ambition is adorned. We want to know what is the crown of beauty on the head of Jerusalem, let us turn to Exodus, in which it is written: And he made a plate of pure gold, and wrote on it an inscription of the seal of the sanctification of the Lord, and placed it on the head of Aaron (Exod. XXXIX, 29). The sign of the sanctification of the Lord is the name of the omnipotent God, which is written with four Hebrew letters (), and among them it is called ineffable, since his name cannot be spoken. Whose majesty even the gentiles do not ignore, and the altar of the Athenians testifies to the unknown god. Hence also the Apostle says: Him whom you worship as unknown, I proclaim to you (Acts 17:23). I consider this to be that crown, of which the Psalmist also says: You have put a seal upon us, the light of your countenance, O Lord (Psalm 4:7). And the Apostle spoke: I have finished the race, I have kept the faith, henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness, which the righteous judge will give to me (2 Timothy 4:7-8). And in another place to the Believers: My joy and my crown (Phil. IV, 1). For the glory of the fathers, the sons. And in Solomon it is written: The crown of glory is old age (Prov. XII, 6); namely, those who have destroyed what belongs to children, and after reaching adulthood, have come to old age, and to the names of the fathers, of whom John writes after the children (I John II), and the young men who can say: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I understood like a child, I thought like a child: but when I became a man, I put away childish things (I Cor. XIII, 11).


<h2 id='tocuniq160'>(Vers. 13.)</h2>

(Verse 13.) And you are adorned with gold and silver. We have often said that gold pertains to the mind, silver to eloquence. And may the Lord grant us to deserve to receive divine understanding and wisdom, and to express with the beauty of eloquence that which we conceive in the mind, and by no means make it an idol as the heretics do, of whom it is written: 'I gave them silver and gold; but they made Baal out of silver and gold' (Hosea 2:8). And this, according to spiritual understanding, is more suitable for the decoration of women. Otherwise, silver, a cheaper material, is the adornment of country and poor maidservants, which is not fitting for Jerusalem, which is said to have advanced to queen.

And you are dressed in fine linen and purple and multicolored garments. LXX: And your robe is of fine linen, and your headband, and your cloak are of many colors. The Hebrew word Mesi (), and here Theodotion put it just as above, Aquila ἄνθιμον, Symmachus polymiton. But we, as mentioned above, said polymiton near Symmachus; the LXX translated it as τρίχαπτα, preserving the previous interpretation: to show thin garments similar to hair. But every adornment is described for women, to bathe, to cleanse, to anoint with oil, and to be dressed in colored garments, to be shod in hyacinth, to be girded with linen, to be clothed in fine garments or in thin ones, to wear armlets and a golden necklace, to have circles hanging from the ear and rings in the earlobes, 158 to be adorned with a diadem on the head, with gold and silver. Although silver is a cheaper material and is placed last of all. You are dressed in linen and polytus, and in colored garments; or, as the Seventy have translated, in attire and cloaks, for these signify outer garments, so that she might not only be adorned with the care of her body and have all the ornaments of women, but also be concerned with the arrangement of her bed and couch, so that after she has completed these she might come to the delights of food and not allow anything to be wanting even in these things. All these things we will adapt to spiritual understanding, so that they cover the delicate limbs of the spouse with a light and refined fabric, so as not to burden them with the weight of heavy cloths, but also to provide both utility and beauty.

You have eaten both honey and oil, and you have become very beautiful. After clothing, she takes care of the food, so that she may eat in Jerusalem both honey and oil, either separately, as many think, or by the mixing of the three, a sweeter bread, which is the bread that came down from heaven (John 6); and under three names, as some suppose, she indicates the sacrament of the Trinity: not that there is a difference in substance; but so that by the different names of honey and oil and bread, the sweetness of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit may be shown together. And this should be noted, that in many sacrifices fine flour is offered, the finest marrow of wheat, of which it is written: 'And he fed them with the fat of wheat' (Psalm 80:17): not barley, nor meal, which is only offered when a husband is moved by the spirit of jealousy. In the book of Judges we read about Deborah (Judges 4), who is interpreted as a bee, whose prophecies are as sweet as honey, and is related to the Holy Spirit, which is called Rua in the feminine gender by the Hebrews. In the Gospel of the Hebrews, which the Nazarenes read, the Savior is introduced speaking: 'My mother, the Holy Spirit, has taken me just now.' Furthermore, the similar thing that is done with wheat is referred to the Lord, who says about Himself: 'Unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains alone. But if it dies, it produces much fruit' (John 12:24). But the oil, which sustains and refreshes the limbs of the weary, and is the nourishment of light, and with which the constant light of the lamps is kindled in the tabernacle of God, is said to correspond to the Father. All of these bestow grace on those who believe, as the Apostle says: There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit distributes them. There are different kinds of service, but the same Lord. There are different kinds of working, but in all of them and in everyone it is the same God at work. (1 Corinthians 12:4-6) Whoever partakes of this food, which is so sweet and delightful, and is nourished by the radiance of the most pure bread and oil, will be transformed into beauty and will become most beautiful, not just once, but repeatedly, exceedingly so. For a duplicated adverb adds weight to the speech: to which nothing can be added beyond the greatness of beauty.

And you advanced to the kingdom. This is not found in the Septuagint, which perhaps those in Alexandria translating the Scriptures from the Hebrew truth into the Greek language were afraid to publish, lest they be seen to offend the king of Egypt while mentioning that Jerusalem was the rightful kingdom of God: although the learned approve only the five books of Moses interpreted by them (see above, chapter 5). Therefore, after multiple decorations, after the crown, after the abundance of gold and silver, after the most beautiful garments and cloaks, after incredible beauty, he advances to being the queen, because she is the city of a great king, of whom it is written: Give your judgment to the king, and your justice to the king's son (Psalm 17:1). And in the Apocalypse of John, Jerusalem is described as a bride adorned and prepared for her husband (Apoc. XXI). In the Psalms, it is also said about the same: The queen stands at your right hand in a golden robe, adorned with various colors (Ps. XLIV, 10). However, everything we say about Jerusalem, so as not to dwell on each individual case, and so that the magnitude of the books does not bore the readers, let us refer to the Church. For if Jerusalem is our mother, according to the Apostle (Gal. IV), but our mother is the Church: consequently, Jerusalem is the Church, the mother of the early believers who are described in heaven.


<h2 id='tocuniq161'>(Vers. 14.)</h2>

(Verse 14) And your name went out among the nations because of your beauty, for you were perfect in my splendor which I bestowed upon you, says the Lord God. LXX: And your name went out among the nations in your splendor, for it was complete in the beauty which I placed upon you, says the Lord God. This passage was more clearly interpreted by Symmachus: And your name went out among the nations, which was perfect because of my dignity, which I had bestowed upon you, says the Lord God. And the meaning is: Through my kindness and incredible generosity, you have reached the title of queen, so that the conversation of all nations would speak of you, and you would be praised not for your own merits and virtues, but for my complete generosity. For unless the Lord builds the house, those who build it labor in vain. Unless the Lord guards the city, the watchman stays awake in vain (Psalm 127:1-2). For neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is anything, but only God who gives the growth (1 Corinthians 3). For it is not the one who wills or the one who runs, but God who shows mercy (Romans 9:16): so that after we have done everything, we may say: We are unworthy servants, we have only done what we ought to have done (Luke 17:10). Not so that free will is taken away from man by the goodness of God, but so that freedom itself should have the Lord as its helper.

<h2 id='tocuniq162'>(Vers. 15.)</h2>

(Verse 15.) And having confidence in your beauty, you have fornicated in your name, and you have exposed your fornication to all who pass by, so that you may become theirs. It is a great danger to trust not in the mercy of God, but in your own appearance. And the higher one may be, the more they should fear lest they fall and fornicate in their own name. Indeed, the adversaries rejoice in despising ordinary food and desire exotic nourishment. Hence it is said about the devil: His food is choice (Habakkuk 1:16). He does not want to deceive anyone. Saul, who was chosen by the Lord as king, hastens to supplant Judas the apostle. Therefore, let us not trust in our own beauty, nor think that God's generosity can be our virtue; but rather let us hear: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring (Prov. XXVII, 1). And in another place: Brothers, if a person is caught in any wrongdoing, you who are spiritual should restore that person gently. But watch yourselves, or you also may be tempted (Galatians VI, 1). Let us not expose or pour out our fornication to every passerby, so that we do not become not of God, in whom we believe, but of the one by whom we are defiled. He who receives all vices, and receives in his bosom the spirit of diverse sins passing by, and spreads his legs to every passerby, he pours out his fornication and begins to endure the dominion of the one whose guest he has become.

<h2 id='tocuniq163'>(Vers 16.)</h2>

(Verse 16.) And taking from your garments, you made for yourself lofty sewn things, and you fornicated over them, as it had not been done and will not be done. LXX: And you took from your garments, and made for yourself idols which were sewn, and you fornicated over them, and you shall not enter, nor shall it be. Symmachus interpreted this passage as follows: And when you took from your garments, you made for yourself lofty multicolored things, and you fornicated in them, not made nor to be made. Aquila and Theodotius translated Proconsutis et versicoloribus et excelsis, sive idolis, ἐμβολίσματα, which means various fabrics sewn together, and an idol made like a patch, as if it were a multicolored garment. 'I have clothed you with colors,' he says, 'and you have put on fine linen, and silk, and many different shapes. But the clothes with which you have been lavishly adorned, you took and made idols or high places,' which in Hebrew are called Bamoth, 'which have never been done before, nor will they be done again.' That which you have received for decoration, you have turned into an insult to the donor. What can be understood about Jerusalem according to the letter, is that it has attributed all the commandments of the Law and the abundance of riches and all things to idols, which no other nation has done, nor will do. For all the nations that have served idols from the beginning are not guilty of such a great crime. But our Jerusalem, which means the vision of peace, is divided by heretics, when they take one or another testimony of the Scriptures from their own places and try to apply them to those with which they cannot be connected. To them and to those above, we read in the same prophet: Woe to those who consume pillows under every elbow, and make coverings over the head of all ages (Sup. XIII, 18): which the Lord, prohibiting to be done, speaks in the Gospel: No one puts a patch of unshrunk cloth on an old garment. Otherwise, the patch pulls away from it, and a worse tear is made: nor do they put new wine into old wineskins (Matthew IX, 16, 17). There are those of the Nazarene sect, who try to adapt the observance of the old Law to the grace of the Gospel. And all heretics, who seek to apply testimony in one place to a congruous meaning in another: even though the tunic of the Lord, woven throughout with a single thread, cannot be altogether torn apart, but woven with the Holy Spirit, it does not receive any tearing apart. That which is said according to the Septuagint, “you shall not enter nor it shall not be,” signifies this: when you make idols of perverse teachings, which you think are lofty, and you commit fornication with them, believing in those things which you yourself have fabricated, you will not be able to enter the temple of God. And when your idols will have no substance, nor will they exist forever, as the Apostle says: 'For we know that an idol is nothing in the world' (I Cor. VIII, 4).

<h2 id='tocuniq164'>(Vers. 17.)</h2>

(Verse 17.) And you took vessels of your adornment from my gold and my silver, which I gave you; and you made male images for yourself, and you fornicated with them. According to the letter of the Law, the Lord commanded that censers, vases, candlestick, the Ark of the Covenant, and all things made of gold or gilded, and other things made of silver, were to be made, all of which were crafted in Jerusalem and turned into idols of Bel, or Baal, Chemosh and Ashtoreth, and Milcom. According to spiritual intelligence, we make idols out of gold and silver of the Holy Scriptures when we corrupt the grace of understanding and eloquence with heretical depravity, and we exalt ourselves in heaven and our tongue descends to earth. However, the images in which every heresy commits fornication are called masculine, because each one thinks that they worship the most powerful and possess what they have created, and that it cannot be overthrown by any attack. These are the images that we have created from our hearts, and which are to be destroyed in the heavenly Jerusalem, of which the Prophet declares: 'O Lord, you will scatter their image in your city' (Ps. LXXII, 20). For whoever is a man and has lost the name of God, it is said of him: 'Nevertheless, man walks in his image, yet he is troubled in vain' (Ps. XXXVIII, 7). But we have one man, and we worship one image, which is the image of the invisible and omnipotent God.


<h2 id='tocuniq165'>(Vers. 18.)</h2>

(Verse 18.) And you took your multicolored garments, and covered them: it is understood images of men: so that every form which had been received for use, be turned into blasphemy. But we do this, whenever with prudence, temperance, fortitude, justice, and all virtues we surround heretical wickedness, under the pretext of these virtues, we deceive even the simple; so that, seeing the honey of virtues, they do not avoid the poison of vices.


And you have set before them my oil and my incense. And my bread (or as the Septuagint translates, my loaves) which I gave to you; fine flour, and oil, and honey, with which I nourished you, you have set them before them for a sweet smell. The oil of which we have spoken above, and the incense, or perfume, of which the Psalmist proclaims: Let my prayer be directed as incense in your sight (Ps. 140, 2); and the loaves of the proposition, which we are commanded to offer to God: also fine flour, the purest sense of the Scriptures, and honey, which Jonathan tasted, and his eyes were opened and he was strengthened (1 Sam. 14), miserable Jerusalem placed before the sight of idols, or before male images, so that they might be to them for a sweet smell, which by their nature are sweetest and most pleasing: but while they are offered to idols and false teachings, they are turned into bitterness.


<h2 id='tocuniq166'>Book Five</h2>

Book Five

163-164 In order to avoid confusion in the numbering of books, and to prevent the order of the volumes from being corrupted by the passage of time, I have included prefaces for each book. This way, the reader can easily identify which book they should read and what prophecy needs to be explained. In the previous volume, that is, the fourth one, I discussed a part of the prophecy against Jerusalem, which begins with the words: 'Your root and your generation are from the land of Canaan,' and extends to the place where it is written: 'You have set before them bread, oil, and honey, which I have nourished you with, as a sweet-smelling aroma.' I have explained this briefly in my discourse. Now the remaining part of this prophecy, along with the rest that follows, is dedicated to the fifth volume, and to your name, Eustochium. In it, you will find nothing of rhetorical art, nothing of composition, and the beauty of words: but the care of simple and careful diligence, so that this alone may be my praise, if you understand the words spoken by the prophet through me.

<h2 id='tocuniq167'>(Vers. 20 seqq.)</h2>

(Verses 20 and following) And it came to pass, says the Lord God, that you took your sons and your daughters, whom you bore unto Me, and offered them up to be devoured. Is your whoredom not enough, sacrificing my children? And you gave them to be consecrated. And after all your abominations and whoredoms, you did not remember the days of your youth, when you were naked and covered in shame, trampled in your own blood. LXX: And it came to pass after these things, says the Lord God, that you took your sons and your daughters whom you had borne to me, and you sacrificed them to be consumed, as if you were a little harlot. And you killed your sons and gave them to be offered to them, that is, above all your adultery and abominations, and you did not remember the days of your infancy, when you were naked and dishonored, living in your own blood. That he begot sons and daughters for himself, Jerusalem, about whom it is written: I begot sons and exalted them; but they despised me (Isa. I, 2); and the Holy Scripture mentions that they sacrificed to idols: They sacrificed their sons and daughters to demons (Ps. CV, 37). And again: They shed innocent blood (Ibid., 38), the blood of their sons and daughters, whom they sacrificed to the idols of Canaan (Exod. IV, 22). But he calls his own according to the Hebrew. For he himself had said of them: My firstborn son is Israel. Or according to the Septuagint, your children, whom you have begotten through fornication. But in the place where we have placed them, and where you consecrated them, for whom the Septuagint translated, and you gave them to appease, or to expiate, Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion also translated and led them away: because the pagans either make their children pass through fire, or force young or adult individuals to pass over. When you do these things, he says, you do not remember your infancy, when I took you covered in blood and washed you, and after many things which prophetic speech narrated, I united you to myself. Our Jerusalem also, if it is supplanted by heretical fraud, takes away her sons, who are stronger in faith, and the daughters who do not have such great strength of faith. Or certainly the sons, who know mystical things: the daughters who follow a simple history; and she delivers them to be devoured by demons, and when she kills them, she believes she can give them life and appease the idols, by whose killing they are satiated. And what is said according to the Septuagint, that is, upon all your fornication and abominations, it signifies that the doctrine of demons is worse than all sins and fornications: in fact, it will kill those whom it has either begotten to God with great labor or made its own children, whom it generated in fornication.

<h2 id='tocuniq168'>(Vers 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 and following) And it came to pass after all your wickedness: woe, woe to you, says the Lord God. And you built yourself a brothel, and you made for yourself a brothel in all the streets. At every head of the road, you built a sign of your prostitution, and you made your abominable adornment, and you spread your feet to everyone passing by, and you multiplied your fornications. And you prostituted yourself with the sons of Egypt, your neighbors, who had much flesh, and you multiplied your fornication to provoke me. LXX: And it came to pass after all your wickedness, woe, woe to you, says the Lord God. And you built for yourself a dwelling of prostitution, and you made yourself a prostitute in every street. And at the beginning of every path you built your prostitution: and you corrupted your beauty, and spread your legs to everyone who passed by, and multiplied your prostitution: and you committed adultery with the sons of Egypt your neighbors, who are of great flesh, and you multiplied your prostitution to provoke me to anger. The Vulgate edition does not have this, which is said second, but it was added from the edition of Theodotion. And again, where we said, 'And you built yourself a brothel,' the Seventy translated it as 'And you built yourself a dwelling place of fornication,' Symmachus and Theodotion translated it as 'brothel'; Aquila, wanting to express the etymology of the Hebrew word Gob (), put 'pit,' which we can say means 'pit': to signify a den and a dark pit, in which the lust of prostitutes is involved. And what follows: And you made for yourself a brothel in all the streets, for which the Seventy translated ἔκθεμα, which in Hebrew is Rama: and both Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotio interpreted it as lofty or sublime. Lastly, in the following passages, where it is written: At every head of the road you built a sign of your prostitution, for a sign and fornication, again in Hebrew it has Rama (), which we have interpreted as either brothel or sign, since among the Hebrews it is one word. However, this is put forth, that it may be high; so that for those who wish to fornicate, the place of fornication appears far away and it is not necessary to search. What we have said once and again and again, let it suffice to have said it forever, that under the guise of a woman, after many benefits from her husband, she describes Jerusalem's fornication, how she has departed from God and joined idols, and her hidden fornication has not been satisfied; but she has built for herself a brothel, and has placed a sign on every street for passersby, so that they may come to the harlot and satisfy their lust, not only their own, but also that of the one who spread her legs wide to every passerby, and defiled the greatness of beauty with the greatness of fornication; and among other things, she has also been cast down in love for the great flesh of the Egyptians, her neighbors. And in order to demonstrate every kind of depravity, it is deformed by a manifold kind of filth. However, there is no doubt that Palestine is neighboring Egypt, as the Lord said to Abraham: I will give you all the land from the river of Egypt to the great river Euphrates (Gen. 15:18), so that on one side it has the Egyptians, and on the other side it has the Assyrians, with whom it is said to have committed fornication in later times. But the fornication of Jerusalem with the Egyptians is an imitation of their idolatry. But towards our Jerusalem, whether the Church or the souls of the faithful, if they are negligent and give themselves up to all vices, a twofold curse is directed, that they may hear: Woe, woe to thee, saith the Lord God, according to what is written in the Apocalypse of John: Woe to all the inhabitants of the earth (Apoc. VIII, 13). For if the saint says: I am a stranger and a sojourner, like all my fathers (Psal. XXXVIII, 13): why is not the sinner called an inhabitant of the earth? He builds for himself a brothel, who with complete freedom of forehead commits sins; according to that which is written: When a sinner comes into the depths of wickedness, he despises (Prov. 18:3). And he constructs the highest place in all the streets: For wide and spacious is the way that leads to death. And at every head of the street he builds; so that he does not leave behind any kind of sins; but imitating the harlot of Proverbs, openly in the streets and in the corners of the streets, he invites foolish young men passing by into his embraces, and pollutes the beauty of the soul, which she received as a gift from God the Creator (Prov. 5 and 7). And all his journeys are full of disgrace, and he reveals his heart to all the thoughts that provide incentives for vices, and he spreads his legs apart, and he fornicate with his Egyptian neighbors, whose examples he follows, namely the pagans who glorify themselves in their disgraceful acts, and it is so wicked that it surpasses even them in disgrace. And he does all of this to provoke God to anger. Moreover, the Egyptians are said to have large sexual organs, either because of the magnitude of their disgrace or because of the deformity of their sins. Wherefore, the holy one, of the flesh of little children, which daily decreases in it, and is thinned by virtues, so that it is not called flesh, but spirit: and speaks in the psalm: My soul thirsts for you, O God, how greatly my flesh thirsts for you (Psalm 62:2): or (as some copies have it) how my flesh is consumed: In a desert and trackless land, and without water: thus I have appeared to you in holiness (1 Corinthians 5). Therefore, the Corinthian fornicator is handed over to the destruction of the flesh, so that his spirit may be saved. Concerning this flesh, it is written: All flesh is grass, and all the glory of it is like the flower of grass. The grass withers, and the flower falls away: but the word of the Lord endures forever (Isa. XL, 6, 7). The Apostle also spoke about this: Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God (I Cor. XV, 50). And God speaks in Genesis: My spirit shall not remain in these people, for they are flesh (Gen. VI, 3). And it is said to the believers: Those who are in the flesh cannot please God. But you are not in the flesh, but in the spirit (Rom. VIII, 8, 9). But the flesh of the saints is different, of which it is written: Every flesh shall see the salvation of God (Isaiah XL, 5).

<h2 id='tocuniq169'>(Vers. 27.)</h2>

(Verse 27) Behold, I will stretch out my hand upon you and take away your justification, and I will give you to the souls of those who hate you, the daughters of the Philistines, who are inflamed by your wicked way. LXX: But if I stretch out my hand upon you and take away your lawful rights and give you to the souls of those who hate you, the daughters of foreigners who have caused you to turn aside from your path. And what follows: ἠσέβησας, which means, you acted impiously, is relevant in relation to the following chapter of the Septuagint, and is consistent with the conclusions of the previous section. However, the Lord extended his hand over Jerusalem to correct the wrongdoer and to take away their rightful possessions, which were considered rightful by the Lord as long as they obeyed God's commandments. But when they worshiped idols and turned their religion into impiety, their possessions were no longer considered rightful. Which is to be observed not only in the law and ceremonies, but also in the sabbaths and feast days and new moons. For God says in the law: 'My sabbaths and my feast days'. But when they turned away from God, it is said to them: 'I will not accept your new moons, and sabbaths, and great day: my soul hates your fasting and rest, and your solemnities' (Exodus 31; Deuteronomy 5; Isaiah 1:14). This is also written about the people (Deuteronomy 7). For when the people who were called the people of God turned away from the Lord, it is said to Moses about them: Your people, whom you brought up out of the land of Egypt, have sinned (Exodus 32:7). This stretching out of the hand is called elsewhere lifting up or visitation. For when God does not correct the one who is sinning, he withdraws his hand. But if the person has sinned and has begun to be sick in the law of God, a visitation is sent to him, according to what is sung in the psalm: If his children forsake my law, and do not walk in my judgments, I will visit their transgression with the rod (Psalm 89:31-32). And in this is written: If the earth sin against me, that it may trespass against me, I will stretch forth my hand upon it, and will break the staff of the bread thereof, and the rest. In which we inquire, what is meant by the stretching forth of the hand, and the sending forth thereof. However, the Devil speaks to the Lord: Put forth thy hand, and touch all that he hath: unless he bless thee to thy face (Job 2:5). And it seems to me that the hand is sent for the trial of those to whom it is sent; but it is stretched forth for the punishment of those who deserve chastisement. Not only extension and insertion; but also the spreading of God's hands is called expansion, as Isaiah proclaims from the person of the Lord: All day long I have spread out my hands to a people who do not believe and who contradict (Isa. 65:2). The Holy One is also said to lift up his hands, as Scripture says: The lifting up of my hands is an evening sacrifice (Ps. 140:2). But since the legitimate laws of God have been removed from the Jewish people, let us ask them what observance of the law they have. They can't offer victims when the temple has been taken away and destroyed; nor can the stoning of adulterers and the punishment of other crimes allowed by law be carried out, nor can the sabbatical year and other such things be observed. However, it is given into the hands of the enemies of the daughters of Palestine, when it is handed over to the Palestinians, whom the Seventy indiscriminately call foreigners: which we can understand as cities or towns of Palestine. Our own Jerusalem, too, if we abandon the ceremonies of God, and his hand is stretched out against us and all observance of the law is taken away, will be handed over to the daughters of Palestine and not to the sons. For we are not first delivered to more powerful punishments, but according to the quality of sins, to lesser ones, so that having been corrected in the lesser ones, we may avoid the greater torments.
