The Philistines, that is, the Palestinians, with the first part of the word changed, are interpreted as fallen with a cup, or by the act of breaking. Through which it is signified that we are to be delivered to the opposing powers, who have drunk from the cup of Babylon, and have fallen, and whose works are perverse. So great will be the correction and disgrace of wretched Jerusalem, that even the hostile powers themselves will be ashamed at the magnitude of our sins. This we have interpreted according to Symmachus as 'scelerata': Theodotion put the Hebrew word itself as 'Zemma'. But when the ceremonies of God were removed from the Jewish people, they passed over to us along with the priesthood and legislation, as the Scripture says: 'Appoint, O Lord, a lawgiver over them' (Psalm 9:21). And in another place: Set a law for me, O Lord, in your way (Psalm 26:11).

<h2 id='tocuniq170'>(Vers. 28, 29.)</h2>

(Verse 28, 29.) And you have played the harlot with the sons of Assyria: because you were not satisfied, and after you played the harlot you were still not satisfied. And you multiplied your harlotry in the land of Canaan with the Chaldeans, and still you were not satisfied. LXX: You have acted impiously, and you have played the harlot with the sons of Assyria; and still you were not satisfied: and you played the harlot, and were not filled; and you multiplied your adulteries to the land of Canaan, and the Chaldeans; and you were not satisfied in these things either. Above is written, Jerusalem fornicated with the sons of Egypt, her neighbors, who are of great flesh: here the other neighborhood of the Assyrians is indicated. And therefore both are delivered to the nations, because they worshipped the idols of both, and entering Chaldea, which is the land of Canaan, they imitated the errors of those whose authority they were under. According to the allegory, we often move from one sin to another. And when we do not repent of our previous sins, we increase sins with sins, and we are satisfied with no error, but like a long rope and the continuous strap of a young heifer, we drag sins, and we multiply our covenant, or fornication, in the land of Canaan, which is interpreted as fluctuation, and with the Chaldeans, who also sound the same as us, as if they were demons (Ps. 39:3). And always we have footsteps in the salt, and never can we say: he established my feet above the rock. And we are subjected to the wickedness of heretics, who have the likeness of demons: whether to those very Demons, about whom Paul writes: We do not have a battle against flesh and blood, but against the rulers of these dark realms, against spiritual wickedness in heavenly places (Ephesians VI, 12).

<h2 id='tocuniq171'>(Vers. 30, 31.)</h2>

(Verse 30, 31) In which shall I cleanse your heart, says the Lord God, when you do all these works of a prostitute and shameless woman? For you have built your brothel at the head of every street, and you have made your high place in every square. Yet you have not acted like a prostitute, scorning payment. LXX: What shall I do with your heart, says Adonai the Lord, when you have done all these works of a fornicating and impudent woman? And you have prostituted yourself three times among your daughters, when you built your brothel at the beginning of every street, and made your foundation in every square; yet you were not like a prostitute, gathering wages. And as the Seventy interpreted: And you have fornicated three times with your daughters, which is not found in Hebrew, nor has any of the other interpreters put it. However, God speaks all these things contentiously to Jerusalem, because He cannot find a remedy to cure her sick and ailing condition; according to what Isaiah writes: What more was there to do for my vineyard that I have not done to it? (Isa. V, 4) ? And Hosea said: What shall I do to thee, Ephraim? what shall I do to thee, Juda? Your mercy is as a morning cloud, and as the early dew it goeth away. (Hosea 6:4). For your idolatry is not in secret, but is committed with complete freedom, that you would set up altars and high places in all the beginnings of the ways and at the cross-roads, and you would make a foundation or an elevated place, about which we have spoken above, in every street. Nor has she imitated cunning harlots, who used to increase the price of desire by difficulty, and from this provoke lovers to frenzy. Or according to the Septuagint: You were not like a prostitute collecting wages, but you gave what you should have received, so that neither in the fact that you committed fornication and followed demons, would you be protected by their help, but oppressed by various captivities, you would feel your calamities. Indeed, this can also be applied to every Christian soul, who, abandoning the worship of God, has indulged in vices and luxury, and followed a worldly life, in which he did not even act successfully, but lost the wealth of religion and did not receive the wealth of the world: nor was there any difficulty in defiling it, but she herself introduced herself to her lovers. There is also another spiritual fornication, when we abandon the Church and join the heretics, and build our brothel at the head of every path, as the divine word commands: Stand in the ways and see, and ask for the eternal paths of the Lord, where the good way is, and walk in it (Jeremiah VI, 16), that is, in the books of Moses, Joshua, Judges, and Kings, Isaiah and Jeremiah, and the other prophets. In all the beginnings of the paths, he builds his brothel, who abuses the testimonies of the Scriptures to support his corrupt doctrine, and says: This is what Isaiah says, this is what Hosea says, this is what Moses said, this is what Daniel said." } And he does not put his brothel in the middle of the streets, nor at the ends of the roads, but at the beginning. For if he comes to the knowledge and profound books of divinity, he will not be able to go astray. He also makes his high place, or base, in every square, allowing himself to be defiled by the debauchery and vices of the heathens, even among the heretics when he has been defiled by them, not having grace, but subject to contempt, because he easily lost the chastity of the past faith. However, what we mentioned earlier does not exist in Hebrew: You have committed adultery three times with your daughters, whether it is said literally in Jerusalem, that she has committed adultery of every kind in her towns and villages; and there is no corner or square left where she has not set up idols of idolatry: or deceiving the Church and the believers, who have not heard the words of the Apostle: Now may the God of peace Himself sanctify you completely; and may your whole spirit, soul, and body be preserved blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ (I Thess. 5:23); but they have committed adultery in every way, with their body, soul, and spirit. We read in Proverbs: 'But you, write them down in a threefold manner, so that you may answer the words of truth that are presented to you' (Prov. XXII, 20, 21). And it is commanded to us that we understand the words of truth, that is, the holy Scriptures, in three ways. First, according to the literal sense; second, in the middle, through tropology; third, in a higher sense, so that we may know the mystical things. According to the literal sense, it is this: 'Neither let us commit sexual immorality, as some of them committed, and fell in one day twenty-three thousand' (I Cor. X, 8). And: Do not murmur, as some of them murmured and were destroyed by the destroyer (1 Corinthians 10:10). However, in the middle and according to tropology, when we depart from the letter and ascend a little higher, as the Apostle says: It is written: You shall not muzzle the ox that is treading out the grain. And immediately after: Is it for the sake of oxen that God is concerned? Or does he speak surely for our sake? (1 Corinthians 9:9). And finally, that is, in the third and highest and sacred understanding, according to the saying of the same Apostle: Therefore, a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife. (Matthew 19:5)" } This is a great mystery. But I speak concerning Christ and the Church (Ephesians 5:31-32). The daughters, however, are the Church of the fornicating, first of the believers, and then of the deceived in the heresy of the soul, whose fault is attributed to the mother.

<h2 id='tocuniq172'>(Vers. 32 seqq.)</h2>

(v. 32 onwards) But like an adulterous woman, who brings in strangers over her husband. To all prostitutes payment is given: but you have given payment to all your lovers, and you used to give them gifts so that they would come to you from every direction to have sex with you. And it happened in you contrary to the custom of women in your prostitution, and after you there will not be prostitution. For in that you gave payment and did not receive payment, the opposite has happened to you. LXX: The adulterous woman, similar to you, received wages from her husband. She gave wages to all who fornicated with her, and you gave wages to all your lovers, and burdened them to come to you in your fornication. And it happened that you acted perversely against women in your fornication, and after you, no women fornicated because you gave wages and wages were not given to you. And it happened that you acted perversely. That which is written in the LXX, similar to you, is not found in Hebrew, and disturbs the order of reading, and raises a significant question, which woman, of whom is she similar to: when Jerusalem itself is said to be an adulterous woman. Therefore, Jerusalem took the abundance of all things, which had been given to her by the generosity of her husband, and gave it to strangers, that is, to demons and idols, according to what is written in Hosea: 'And she did not know that I gave her the wheat, and the wine, and the oil, and multiplied her silver: but she made silver and gold for Baalim' (Hosea 2:8). So, being angry, He immediately declares: 'Therefore, I will turn and take away my wheat in its season, and my wine in its season; and I will take away my clothes and my linen, so that I will no longer cover her shame. And now I will reveal her uncleanness in the sight of her lovers, and no one will rescue her from my hand.' And while all women who engage in prostitution usually receive payment from their lovers, Jerusalem did the opposite, giving more than she received. And to display the generosity of her payment, she would burden (or, honor), she said, 174 of them to come to her in rotation; so that there would be no neighbor who would not be mixed in with her disgrace. And indeed, Jerusalem surpassed other prostitutes in this as well, not only giving her own earnings, which she had acquired through the custom of depravity and toil; but also giving marital gifts to her lovers and her rapists. The explanation of adultery has been so great that it is preferred not only to those present, but also to future prostitutes. Hence, we have interpreted according to Symmachus: 'And after you there will be no fornication.' For in comparison to you, every subsequent fornication will be considered lighter. Whatever we have said about Jerusalem refers to the Church and the souls of the believers, who give their lovers the gifts of marriage - namely, gold in the sense of understanding, silver in speech, and clothing that veils our filth and shame. They give these gifts to either opposing powers or teachers of false doctrines, when they assert that lust and passive lust, according to the genital organs of the body, demand sexual intercourse in accordance with natural law, and that all foods made for this purpose should be used indiscriminately, to be consumed." } Prudence is necessary only insofar as it benefits oneself; justice has no place, for if it prevails, one would have to beg and other such things. Taking these things, miserable Jerusalem, in which the vision of peace should be, turned the sharpness of intellect and the elegance of speech into ugliness. And for her lovers, adorned against her husband, she came forth with these ornaments, in which she had been adorned for the abuse of good by her husband. And what follows: And you gave them that they may enter to fornicate with you from all sides, all kinds signify sins, so that she is not satisfied with one offense, but endures a hunger for sinning and, against the laws of nature, is defiled by all the shameful members even to the top of her head.


<h2 id='tocuniq173'>(Vers. 35 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 35 seqq.) Therefore, harlot, hear the word of the Lord. Thus says the Lord God: Because your brass has been poured out and your shame has been revealed in your fornication (Vulg. in your fornications) upon your lovers, and upon the idols of your abominations in the blood of your sons, whom you have given to them. Behold, I will gather all your lovers, with whom you have mixed yourself, and all whom you have loved with all those whom you have hated, and I will gather them against you from all around, and will expose your shame before them, and they will see all your disgrace." } And I will judge you with the judgments of adulterers, and those shedding blood, and I will give you over to the blood (Vulgate: to blood) of fury and zeal, and I will give you into their hands, and they will destroy your brothel, and demolish your prostitution, and they will strip you of your clothes, and they will take away the vessels of your adornment, and they will leave you naked, full of shame. And they will bring a multitude upon you, and they will stone you with stones, and they will kill you with their swords. And they will burn your houses with fire, and they will execute judgments against you in the eyes of many women, and you will cease to fornicate and no longer give wages. And my indignation will rest upon you, and my jealousy will be removed from you, and I will rest and not be angry anymore, because you have not remembered the days of your youth and have provoked me in all these things. Therefore, I have given your ways upon your head, says the Lord God, and I have not done according to your wickedness in all your abominations. LXX: Therefore, harlot, hear the word of the Lord: Thus says the Lord God: Because you have poured out your bronze and your shame will be revealed in your prostitution to your lovers, and in all your wicked thoughts, and in the blood of your sons whom you gave to them. Therefore, behold, I will gather all your lovers with whom you have mingled, and all those whom you have loved with all those whom you have hated, and I will gather them against you from all around, and I will reveal your wickedness to them, and they will see all your shame. And I will avenge on you the vengeance of the adulterous, and those who shed blood, and I will put you in the blood of fury and zeal, and I will deliver you into their hands. And they will burn down your brothel, and destroy your foundation, and they will strip you of your garments, and take away the vessels of your glory, and leave you naked and full of shame, and bring a multitude upon you, and stone you with stones, and cut you with their swords. And they will set fire to your houses, and the women will execute vengeance against you in front of many. And I will turn you away from prostitution, and you will no longer give rewards. And I will unleash my fury upon you, and my zeal will depart from you, and I will rest, and I will not be concerned. Because you have not remembered the days of your youth, and you have grieved me in all these things. And behold, I will bring your ways upon your head, says the Lord God; and you have done wickedness beyond all your evil deeds. We lay the foundations of this and that story. For you have done these things, which the previous discourse encompasses: therefore hear, O harlot, what you have done, and what you will suffer. You have poured out your brass that you received from me, and you have given payment to your lovers, which you should have received, and you have killed your children while offering them to idols, so that you have not only become an adulterer, but also a murderer. Therefore I will gather all your lovers, with whom you have committed adultery, both those you have loved and those you have hated. And I will expose you to the gaze of adulterers, so they may see your disgrace, and the genitals that once aroused their lust. All these things are said in metaphor of an adulterous and murderous woman, who not only committed adultery against her husband, but also killed her children. They are spoken against Jerusalem, and that all the nations, whose idols she worshipped and whom she turned God's gifts into their worship, should be gathered against her, and that the temple of Baal should be destroyed, and the altars of the whole city should be overturned by fire, and nothing should remain in her. And as it is customary, all the stones are thrown against the adulteress, and to kill the prostitute, so that she is killed by the wounds of each of them: in the same way, so that all women see the punishment of the harlot: thus in the sight of others, in the surrounding area of cities and all nations, Jerusalem is to be abandoned. And for this to happen, so that she stops committing adultery, and does not give any more wages to her lovers, and the wrath of God may rest, and He may not be angry with her anymore, since she has ceased to love. From this we perceive that there is a great offense, that God is not taken care of, but rather that he allows man to be subject to his own crimes and sins. 'My zeal,' he says, 'will be taken away from you, and I will rest, and I will no longer be angry, as if I were a stranger, and that which has departed from me, and which I have handed over to eternal nakedness.' But if Jerusalem has suffered this, because she has fornicated with idols, what do we think she will suffer when she has slain the Son of God? And you, he says, have done all these things, forgetting your former blessings, and you have provoked me to anger, or you have grieved me, whom you should have provoked to joy by good works. Therefore, I will also render to you your works into your head. And when I overthrow you, O adulteress, I will exercise less of my anger towards you than you deserve, so that divine mercy might be demonstrated, that sins might be greater than punishments. According to tropology, every soul receives spiritual wealth from God, according to that Gospel (Matthew 25, Luke 19) which is said in the parables of five and two talents, and of the ten servants receiving one mina each, who, when they act negligently, become debtors of fifty (or ten) denarii and five hundred, and because of this, in the presence of the lovers whom we understand to be demons and opposing virtues, the disgrace of Jerusalem is revealed, either on the day of judgement or in the time of repentance when they are admonished. And indeed God alone sees hidden things, as the Gospel says: And your Father who sees in secret (Matthew 6:6). And in another place: God examines the hearts and kidneys (Psalm 7:10). And in the book of Kings: You alone know the hearts of all the sons of men (2 Kings 8). But when it is fulfilled: There is nothing hidden that will not be revealed, and nothing secret that will not be known (Luke 12:2). And in another place: Do not judge before the time, until the Lord comes, who will bring to light the hidden things of darkness and reveal the counsels of the hearts, and then praise will come to each one from God (1 Corinthians 4:5); and when the time of correction comes, then what Hosea said will be fulfilled: Now their thoughts have surrounded them (Hosea 7:2). And in another place: When they accuse or defend themselves in their thoughts, on the day when God will judge the secrets of men (Rom. II, 15). And again: Behold the man and his works before his face. And all those who fornicated with her before will see her wickedness, and God will deliver her into the blood of fury and zeal. For the rage of a man is full against an adulterous wife, and she cannot be redeemed at any price. But the blood of children can be understood as we call the good thoughts, which are inherent in men by God, sons of Jerusalem; whom the adulteress kills when she turns to evil deeds. It is also beneficial for Jerusalem, that its brothel be dug up, and the entire seedbed of its fornication be destroyed. For when this has been done, it will no longer provide rewards, and the indignation of God will rest, and He will not be zealous for its chastity: namely, according to those who interpret these things in a positive way. However, others, as we have said above, interpret it in the opposite way, that it is a great sign of God's anger not to be angry once He has condemned a fornicate, and has given up on their salvation. But if heretics who do not accept the old Testament, according to the Septuagint edition, criticize in this place what has been said: And you grieved me in all these things; because God not only receives anger, but also suffers sorrow and sadness, let us ask them how they accept that, which is certainly a commandment of the good God: Do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, in whom you are sealed for the day of redemption (Ephesians 4:30). Whatever they may say in defense of that testimony, we will apply it to the satisfaction of the present discourse.

<h2 id='tocuniq174'>(Vers. 44.)</h2>

(Verse 44.) Behold, everyone who speaks a proverb will apply it to you, saying: As the mother, so her daughter. You are the daughter of your mother, who cast away her husband and her children, and you are the sister of your sisters, who cast away their husbands and their children. LXX: These are all the things they have said against you in a parable, saying: Like mother, like daughter. You are the daughter of your mother, who rejected her husband and her children, and you are the sisters of your sisters who rejected their husbands and their children. He posts a catalog of vices and corrections (or corrections) in Jerusalem, through which he is drawn back to salvation, and adapts to it the well-known proverb in the common language of the people, or as the Septuagint translated it, the parable: Like mother, like daughter. However, the mother of Jerusalem, as it is written above and in the following, is called Chethaea and is interpreted as raging or turning to madness: through which the incentives of this world are shown, which lead the captive soul to destruction and separate her from her husband (without a doubt, it is said to be the word of God and his teaching). And the sister of their sisters, as we will read shortly, is called Sodom and Samaria: one of which signifies a Gentile way of life and luxury, the other the seductions of the heretics. Furthermore, what is read in the Septuagint: 'the sisters of your sisters, who rejected their husbands and their sons,' does not make sense. For what other sisters did Sodom and Samaria have that are sisters of Jerusalem? And this must be investigated: which husbands did Sodom and Samaria dismiss, and which sons did they reject? But unless we are able to say this, that the feet of those always erring fluctuate, and there are no solid footsteps which are against the truth; rather, they run here and there, and are carried about by every wind of doctrine, while they pass from falsehood to another falsehood (Ephesians IV). And when they realize that they have labored in vain at first, they move on to second and third things.

<h2 id='tocuniq175'>(Vers. 45 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 45 seqq.) Your mother is Hethaea (otherwise Chethaea), and your father is Amorrhaeus, and your older sister is Samaria: she and her daughters who dwell to your left. But your younger sister, who dwells to your right, is Sodom and her daughters. But you did not walk in their ways, nor did you commit crimes like theirs, but rather you did even more wicked things than them in all your ways. LXX: Your mother is Chethaea, and your father is Amorrhaeus, and your older sister is Samaria: she and her daughters who dwell to your left, and your younger sister, who dwells to your right, is Sodom and her daughters: and not even in her ways did you walk, nor did you act according to her iniquities, but you transgressed them in all your ways. He had said before: Your father is Amorrhaeus, and your mother is Chethaea; here the order and number are changed: Your mother is Chethaea, and your father is Amorrhaeus. For when they have committed crimes, they are divided into parts; and when their union is abandoned, they advance to a crowd and multitude, which is unable to ascend the mountains with Jesus. But the sisters of Jerusalem, Samaria and Sodom, one on the left and the other on the right, even according to physical understanding, if you look from the eastern side of the temple of Jerusalem, you will approve. Majorca is called Samaria, because she sinned first and was led into captivity by the Assyrians: and Sodom is smaller and younger, which is related to a multitude of nations. Otherwise, at that time Sodom did not exist, which was previously mentioned in the Scriptures before Jerusalem, along with Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, it was destroyed by divine fire (Genesis 19). However, between the two sisters, Jerusalem, which is also called Judea by another name, was led into Babylon by the Chaldeans: and Jerusalem sinned much more wickedly than Samaria and Sodom, worshiping the idol of Baal in the temple and later killing the Son of God. Furthermore, according to allegory, Samaria and Sodom, that is, heretics and Gentiles, often commit lesser offenses than those who are considered Jerusalem, that is, the clergy. Hence, it is said to the Corinthians, who believed in Christ but were burdened by evil deeds: It is actually reported that there is sexual immorality among you, and such sexual immorality as is not even named among the Gentiles, that a man has his father's wife (1 Corinthians 5:1), and so on. The heretics, however, who nonetheless accept the old Testament, understand three natures from this passage: spiritual, animal, and earthly. And they refer the spiritual to Jerusalem; the animal to Samaria; the earthly to Sodom. Let us ask them briefly how these three natures, spiritual, animal, and earthly, which are certainly different among themselves, are said to have one mother and one father? This does not agree with their false notion. And how can the animal and earthly nature, according to the same prophet, be restored to its ancient state, that is, to the spiritual state? which is contrary to their own nature. And that Samaria is understood to refer to heresies, and in the prophet Hosea, and in many other places, especially in this testimony: Woe to those who despise Zion and who trust in the mountain of Samaria; they have plucked up the firstfruits of the nations. (Amos 6:1). For all heretics despise Zion, which is interpreted as a watchtower, and is referred to the Church; and they trust in themselves on the mountain of Samaria, namely in the pride of perverse doctrines, which they think are sublime, and through these fraudulent preachings, they plunder and devastate the foundations of the nations; so that, by the miracle of their teachings, they might draw even the powerful of the Gentiles into heretical error.

<h2 id='tocuniq176'>(Vers. 48, 49.)</h2>

(Verse 48, 49.) I live, says the Lord: that your sister Sodom herself and her daughters have not done as you and your daughters have done. Behold, this was the iniquity of your sister Sodom: pride, gluttony, and the abundance, and the idleness of herself and her daughters; and they did not stretch out their hand to the poor and needy. And they were haughty, and did abominations before me, and I took them away as you saw. And Samaria has not sinned half as much as your sins; but you have surpassed her in your wickedness and have justified your sisters in all your abominations that you have done. LXX: I live, says Adonai the Lord; your sister Sodom did this, both she and her daughters did as you and your daughters have done. However, the iniquity of your sister Sodom was arrogance and satiety of bread, and in abundance. She and her daughters lived in luxury and had plenty, but they did not strengthen the hand of the poor and needy. They boasted arrogantly and committed iniquities in my presence, so I took them away as you have seen. And Samaria has not half sinned with your sins, and you have multiplied your iniquities above them, and have justified your sisters in all your iniquities which you have done. That which was written by the seventy interpreters, this she and her daughters had in Hebrew, and not in the old Testament of God is an oath: As I live, says the Lord (Num. XIV, 21). But in the new: Amen, amen I say to you (Joan. XIII, 16). But if this is common with other things: the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, is not the God of the dead, but of the living (Marc. XII, 16, 27). And in another place: I will please the Lord in the land of the living (Psalm 116:9); we ask, in what way does God claim the common term for Himself properly. But how is it said that an arbor is good, and a good man, and a good shepherd, and a good servant (Luke 18); no one, however, is absolutely good, except God alone: thus, when angels and all other virtues, even patriarchs and prophets, and also apostles, are called the living in comparison with the Almighty God, they are called dead. For what man is there that liveth, and shall not see death?” (Psalm 88:49). Hence also the apostle Paul, speaking of God, says: “Who only hath immortality, dwelling in light inaccessible” (1 Timothy 6:16). And concerning the wellspring of life, he says: “For you are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God” (Colossians 3:3). Therefore, he who swears and speaks, saying: “As I live, saith the Lord,” describes the sins of Sodom and her daughters, and sets forth their first pride, which is the special sin of the devil and the first sin. Where the same Apostle says: 'Lest being puffed up he fall into judgment of the devil' (I Tim. III, 6), because of which he fell from heaven. For he had said: 'By strength I will do it, and by wisdom I will remove the bounds of the peoples, and I will destroy the strength of them that are mighty, and I will shake the inhabited cities, and I will take away the whole world as with the hand, as a nest, and as the eggs that are left, I will gather' (Isai. X, 13, 14). And: 'God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble' (Jacob IV, 6). We also read in another place: Why do you boast, O earth and ashes? And the Gospel recounts the Pharisee's pride, overcome by the humility of the tax collector (Luke 18): whose garden is filled with the abundance of bread and all things, and with leisure; or as the LXX translated it, with the opulence of delights and luxury. That rich man in the Gospel, clothed in purple (Luke 16), is reported to have had no other fault than that, being rich in wealth and abundance, he had burst forth in such great pride that he did not reach out his hand to the poor and needy Lazarus: and thus he forgot his own condition, to the point that he did not even give to this wretched man what was to be thrown away. For what reason and in another place is it written: Everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted (Luke XIV, 11). Pride, gluttony, abundance of all things, leisure and luxury, are Sodomitic sins, and because of this, there follows forgetfulness of God, which considers present goods to be perpetual and never in need of necessary things. Therefore, it is also commanded by the law: Take heed, lest when you eat and drink and are satisfied, and build good houses and possess flocks and herds, silver, and gold, you forget the Lord your God (Deuteronomy VIII, 11). And in another place it is written about Israel: He ate and drank, and became satisfied, and grew fat, and kicked. (Deut. XXXII, 15) Knowing this, the wisest of all, Solomon, prays in Proverbs: Give me what is necessary and sufficient, so that I may not become satisfied and deny you, saying: Who will see me? Or becoming poor, I may steal and profane the name of my God. (Prov. XXX, 8, 9) And what follows: and you justified your sisters in all your abominations, which you have done, not simply asserting that Sodom and Samaria were just, but by comparing them to worse things, just as the tax collector, whom we mentioned before, is not called completely just, but by comparison to someone worse. And yet even though Sodom and Samaria are such wicked places, they did not sin even half as much as Jerusalem. For the servant who knows his master's will and does not do it will be punished severely (Luke 12:47). And: The mighty will endure torment mightily (Wisdom 6:7). Furthermore, concerning the idea that leisure is included in Hebrew for delights (or riches), it should be understood to refer to this meaning: In idle pursuits, the soul is restless; that is, there is always something to be done, so that the field of our heart does not become overgrown with the thorns of evil thoughts when our hand ceases to act.


<h2 id='tocuniq177'>(Vers. 52.)</h2>

(Verse 52.) Therefore, you also bear your own shame, as you have surpassed your sisters in your sins, acting more wickedly than them (or, done to them): for they are justified from you. LXX: And you will endure your torment in that you have corrupted your sisters in your sins, in which you have unjustly treated them, and you have justified them over yourself. The second tablet after the shipwreck is to be ashamed when you have sinned and not subject to the reproof, which is said against Jerusalem: You have become like a harlot, and you do not know how to be ashamed (Jeremiah 3:3). He carries his own torment, who is tormented by his own conscience, and in this world endures his own torment by his own will, so that he does not endure eternal torment (Genesis 4). And we corrupt our brothers and sisters, or rather, they are provoked to greater sins by our sins. What I say will become clearer: Imagine someone in a position of priesthood not living well, and tarnishing the dignity with their actions. Surely, by imitating his vices, the lay brother is corrupted? For whoever scandalizes one of the least ones, it would be better for him to have a millstone hung around his neck and be thrown into the depths (Matt. XVIII, 6). Likewise, the sisters of Jerusalem are justified by comparing them to Sodom and Samaria, not because they are inherently righteous, but as we said, by comparison to the worse.

So you will also be confused; and your gate will bear your shame, which you justified your sisters. Seventy: And you will be confused, and you will bear your shame, because you justified your sisters. Confusion follows shame: shame correction: correction consolation: consolation salvation: according to the saying of the Apostle: Tribulation worketh patience: and patience trial: and trial hope: but hope confoundeth not (Rom. V, 3-5). There is no doubt that in the future: because at present he destroys his sins through confusion. This and that of the Gospel also speak: There is confusion that leads to death, and there is confusion that leads to life (Eccli. 4:25). The Holy Spirit also encourages sinners in the Psalms: Let all my enemies be confounded and ashamed: let them turn back and be confounded and very quickly (Psalm 39:15). It is written elsewhere: Declare your sins first, that you may be justified (Isa. 43:26, sec. LXX). And again: The righteous is his own accuser at the beginning of his speech (Prov. XVIII, 17). Therefore, it is not surprising if Jerusalem is provoked to confusion and shame; for she has sinned so much as to have justified her sisters. To her it is subsequently said: And you, and your daughters, return to your former state.

<h2 id='tocuniq178'>(Vers 53, 54.)</h2>

(Verse 53, 54) And I will restore their fortunes, the fortunes of Sodom and her daughters, and the fortunes of Samaria and her daughters. And I will restore your own fortunes in their midst, that you may bear your disgrace and may be ashamed of all that you have done, comforting them.\n\nLXX: And I will restore their fortunes, the fortunes of Sodom and her daughters, the fortunes of Samaria and her daughters, and I will restore your own fortunes in their midst, that you may bear your punishment and have disgrace for all that you have done, in provoking me to anger. Great was the progress of Jerusalem, as after the confusion and disgrace, which it willingly accepted and bore inflicted upon it by the judgment of God, saying: I will bear the anger of the Lord, because I have sinned against Him, let restoration to its former state be promised to it. But yet, because in comparison with its sins, Sodom and Samaria were justified, of which one is on the right and the other on the left; first, the conversion or captivity of Sodom is restored, as Aquila has interpreted it; secondly, the captivity of Samaria, as the same Aquila and Symmachus have translated; and finally, Jerusalem, which had been oppressed by greater iniquity, and had shown its sinful sisters to be just by comparison with itself, will be restored. For who doubts that among three sinners, or rather impious, the Gentile, the heretic, the ecclesiastic, the one who is of greater dignity is worthy of much greater punishments? For the powerful, as we have said, endure torments powerfully. But the one who is of lesser dignity is worthy of mercy. And the servant who knows the will of his master and does not do it, will be beaten with many blows. Hence also Peter says: For the time has come for judgment to begin from the house of the Lord. And in this same passage, the prophet commands those who have axes to start from my holy ones (above, IX, 6), so that Jerusalem, having turned and restored to its former state before her sisters, may bear her disgrace, and be confounded, and be ashamed of the things she has sinned, and may comfort her sisters in all things, while she endures more grievous things (Jeremiah VI). Or certainly let her be confounded and ashamed, because she has provoked God to anger. From which it is clear that God does not have natural anger, but rather he is the most merciful and gentle God, provoked to anger by our own vices, as the Apostle says: Do you despise the riches of his goodness, and forbearance, and patience? Do you not realize that God's kindness is meant to lead you to repentance? But because of your stubbornness and unrepentant heart, you are storing up wrath for yourself (Romans 2:4-5), which God does not have naturally. And it is written elsewhere: You have let loose your anger that consumed them like stubble (Exodus XV, 7). For what is joined together and united in one body cannot be thrown, but that which is outside the body. For example, a spear, weapon, arrow, sword. We also read in the Gospel (Matthew X, 15) that it will be more tolerable for the land of Sodom on the day of judgment than for those who do not receive the apostles.

<h2 id='tocuniq179'>(Vers. 55.)</h2>

(Verse 55.) And your sister Sodom and her daughters will return to their former state. And Samaria and her daughters will return to their former state. And you and your daughters will return to your former state. LXX: And your sister Sodom and her daughters will be restored as they were at the beginning, and Samaria and her daughters will be restored as they were at the beginning. And you and your daughters will be restored as you were from the beginning. Among other fables and endless genealogies and delusions that they invent, the Jews also dream this, that in the coming of their Christ, whom we know as the Antichrist, and in his thousand-year reign, Sodom will be restored to its ancient state, so that it will be like the paradise of God, and like the land of Egypt; and Samaria will regain its former prosperity, so that the Assyrians will return to the land of Judah (4 Kings, 17, 18). For we read that the ten tribes were captured by the kings of Assyria, namely Phul, Salmanassar, and Teglathphalassar, and to this day they remain in captivity. Also, at that time Jerusalem must be rebuilt, along with all its daughters, that is, the cities, villages, and castles that will be under its future authority, flourishing as they once did. And Jerusalem itself must be built with gold, silver, and precious stones, as Isaiah prophesies: I will restore your judges as at first, and your counselors as in the beginning, and afterwards you will be called the city of righteousness, the faithful mother of cities of Zion (Isa. 1:26); and our Apocalypse speaks: And David sings: Do well, O Lord, in your good will to Zion, and let the walls of Jerusalem be built (Ps. 50:20). And in another place: Cities of Judah will be built, and they will inhabit and dwell there, and their seed will be directed forever (Ps. LXVIII, 36). But we, leaving the perfect knowledge of these things to the judgment of God, indeed confessing with certainty, after the second coming of the Lord and Savior, that nothing humble, nothing earthly, will be future; but we say that the heavenly kingdoms which are first promised in the Gospel, are completed in the state of the Church and are continually being completed. Sodom returns to its ancient state, when it once again follows its natural inclinations and the wicked soul recognizes its Creator. Samaria regains its ancient blessedness, forsaking the error of heretics and joining the teachings and faith of Christianity. And when these have returned, and Jerusalem, the vision of peace, which is interpreted as the Church, will return to its former state. As it is written: 'His tent is in peace' (Psalm 76:2); and: 'Jerusalem, which is built as a city that is compact together' (Psalm 122:3); and in the Apostle: 'But Jerusalem which is above is free, which is the mother of us all' (Galatians 4:26); and in the same: 'You have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to innumerable angels' (Hebrews 12:22). And he returns with his daughters, who are dispersed throughout the whole world. We have discussed this more fully in the explanations of Isaiah.

<h2 id='tocuniq180'>(Vers. 56 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 56 and following) However, your sister Sodom was not heard in your mouth in the day of your pride before your wickedness was revealed, as it is now with the disgrace of the daughters of Syria and all the daughters of Palestine around you who surround you. You have borne your own wickedness and disgrace, says the Lord God. LXX: If your sister Sodom had not been in your mouth to hear in the days of your pride before your wickedness was revealed, as it is now with the daughters of Syria, and if this had not happened, what would have become of you and all the daughters of foreigners around you who surround you?" } You carry your impieties and your iniquities. Symmachus interpreted this passage as follows: Because your sister Sodom was not heard through your mouth on the day of your pride, before your disgrace was revealed, as in the time of the reproach of the daughters of Syria, and of all the daughters of Palestine who surround you and encircle you. You will carry your wickedness and your vileness. Theodotion translates it as follows: And your sister Sodom was not heard through your mouth on the day of your pride, before your evil was revealed: as the time of the reproach of the daughters of Syria, and of all the foreign daughters around her, who abhor you and surround you. You have borne your fornication and your contaminations, says the Lord Adonai. Our translation corresponds to the Aquila edition; I have set them all down so that, through comparing all of them, we might be able to find some trace of meaning, and in the meantime, without prejudice from others, it seems to us that the order of reading should be restored thus: In the days of your pride, when you sinned, you did not remember the downfall of your sister Sodom before your wickedness was exposed to such an extent, that you became a reproach to all the cities of Syria and Palestine that are around you. Since you have conquered in the crime against your sister and were not terrified by her example so as to endure similar things and restrain your foot, now, however, your ignominy has been revealed, listen to God's judgement. Either carry, according to the Septuagint; or you have carried, according to Aquila and Theodotion; or you will carry, according to Symmachus, your crime and ignominy, so that after you have endured punishment for sacrilege, you may obtain forgiveness not by your own agreement, but by my mercy. In the Hebrew language, Syria is called Aram, which means 'sublimity'. And according to the explanation of that passage of the prophet Isaiah, in which Aram and Ephraim conspire against Judah and Jerusalem, the clever wisdom of the heathen and that which promises itself the sublimity of knowledge, is joined to the malice of heretics and attacks Judah, in which true confession is and cannot be overcome. Likewise, this same arrogance of Syria, that is, of the philosophers with the daughters of foreigners, in whom the manifold errors of diverse teachings among nations are shown, mocks Jerusalem and holds her in contempt, by whom she is overcome in vices.


<h2 id='tocuniq181'>(Vers. 59 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 59 onwards) 188 Because thus says the Lord God: And I will do to you as you have despised the oath, to make the covenant void. And I will remember my covenant with you in the days of your youth, and I will establish an everlasting covenant with you. And you shall remember your ways, and be ashamed when you receive your sisters, both the older and the younger; and I will give them to you as daughters, but not because of your covenant. And I will establish my covenant with you, and you shall know that I am the Lord, so that you may remember and be confounded, and never open your mouth again because of your shame, when I forgive you for all that you have done, says the Lord God. LXX: Thus says the Lord God: And I will do to you as you have done, you who have despised these things, so that you may transgress my covenant. And I will remember my covenant that I made with you in the days of your youth, and I will establish with you an everlasting covenant. And you will remember your ways and be ashamed when you receive your older sisters with your younger sisters, and I will give them to you as a trial, not according to your covenant. And I will establish my covenant with you, and you shall know that I am the Lord, so that you may remember and be confounded and may never open your mouth again because of your shame, when I atone for you for all that you have done, says the Lord God. Therefore, I said to you: your crime and your shame you bear, whether you have borne it or will bear it; so that you may receive what you deserve: because you have despised my oath and nullified my covenant. But when it is fulfilled, I will kill, and I will give life; I will strike, and I will heal (Deut. XXXII, 39): then I will remember my covenant, which I once had with you. And I will raise up for you a covenant, not of the law that has passed, but an eternal covenant of the Gospel: so that when you remember your ways, and receive your greater and lesser sisters, or their companions, I will give them to you as daughters, or as a proof (for there must be heresies, so that those who are approved may become manifest), not according to your merit, but according to my mercy, and then you shall know that I am the Lord; and you shall remember my benefits, and be confounded, and say according to the Apostle: 'I am not worthy to be called an Apostle: because I persecuted the Church of God' (I Cor. XV, 9). And let not your mouth be opened any more because of your shame. For it is the privilege of the saints to open their mouth according to the Apostle who says: My mouth is open to you, O Corinthians (II Cor. VI, 11); and of the Lord and Savior, who, opening His mouth, taught them (Matth. V), and also in the Psalm: I will open my mouth in parables (Ps. LXXVII, 2). But to the sinner it is said: You have sinned: be silent (Gen. IV). And: Why do you take my covenant in your mouth? (Ps. XLIX, 16). And it is not beautiful praise in the mouth of a sinner (Sirach 15:9). And the holy one deserves to hear: Open your mouth, and I will fill it (Psalm 81:11). From which we understand that even when we have received the previous glory through the mercy of God, and indeed have received the eternal covenant of the Gospel, after the Lord has been appeased to us in all that we have done, we should keep the memory of our past sin and always keep our mouth shut, because we are saved not by our own works, but by the grace of God.


<h2 id='tocuniq182'>(Cap. XVII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 17, verses 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, propose an enigma, narrate a parable to the house of Israel, and say: Thus says the Lord God: A great eagle with large wings, long feathers, full of feathers and variety, came to Lebanon and took the top of the cedar. He pulled out the top of its branches and carried it to the land of Canaan, and placed it in a city of merchants. And he took from the seed of the earth, and placed it in the earth for seed in order to establish roots above many waters; he placed it on the surface. And when it sprouted, it grew into a vine of wide breadth with low stature: its branches looked toward it, and its roots were under it. So the vineyard was made, and it bore fruit in branches, and sent out shoots. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, tell a narrative, and speak a parable to the house of Israel, and say: Thus says the Lord God: A great eagle with great wings, long in plumage, full of talons, which has a long path to enter Lebanon, and took the choicest cedar. He uprooted the tops of tenderness and brought them to the land of Canaan. He placed it in a walled city and took it from the seed of the earth and gave it a plantation in a field above many waters. He put it there to be looked at: it sprouted and became a weak and small vine, so that only 190 branches appeared under it, and its roots were beneath it. And it became a great vineyard, and it produced branches and extended its branches. When the prophets are said to say: Propose a riddle, tell a parable, or as the LXX translated: tell a narrative, and speak a parable, it is shown that what is said is obscure. For there is no doubt that to utter a riddle and a parable is one thing in words, and another thing in meaning. And the Savior indeed spoke to the people in parables, which he explained in secret to the apostles. Therefore, we must understand riddles and parables in such a way, as if riddles and parables are Two are presented now in the prophecy of Ezekiel by the Aquila. Now, first of all, we must speak: in the following we shall discuss the second. And in the meantime, let us make a simple story. The great eagle, with its large wings, long body, full of feathers and variety, or as the Septuagint says, full of claws, is King Nebuchadnezzar of the Chaldeans, of whom Hosea also speaks: Like an eagle over the house of God (Hosea 8:1). He, commanding many nations and surrounded by an innumerable army, came over the house of God, undoubtedly the temple, or as Scripture says now, to Lebanon, of which Zechariah speaks: Open your gates, Lebanon, and let fire devour your cedars. Howl, O fir tree, for the cedar is fallen; because the mighty are spoiled: howl, O ye oaks of Bashan; for the forest of the vintage is come down. There is a voice of the howling of the shepherds; for their glory is spoiled: a voice of the roaring of young lions; for the pride of Jordan is spoiled. Thus saith the LORD my God; Feed the flock of the slaughter; Whose possessors slay them, and hold themselves not guilty: and they that sell them say, Blessed be the LORD; for I am rich: and their own shepherds pity them not. For I will no more pity the inhabitants of the land, saith the LORD: but, lo, I will deliver the men every one into his neighbour's hand, and into the hand of his king: and they shall smite the land, and out of their hand I will not deliver them. And I will feed the flock of slaughter, even you, O poor of the flock. And I took unto me two staves; the one I called Beauty, and the other I called Bands; and I fed the flock. Three shepherds also I cut off in one month; and my soul lothed them, and their soul also abhorred me. Then said I, I will not feed you: that that dieth, let it die; and that that is to be cut off, let it be cut off; and let the rest eat every one the flesh of another. And I took my staff, even Beauty, and cut it asunder, that I might break my covenant which I had made with all the people. And it was broken in that day: and so the poor of the flock that waited upon me knew that it was the word of the LORD. And I said unto them, If ye think good, give me my price; and if not, forbear. So they weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver. And the LORD said unto me, Cast it unto the potter: a goodly price that I was prised at of them. And I took the thirty pieces of silver, and cast them to the potter in the house of the LORD. Of whom, as the Scripture of the Evangelist Matthew testifies (Matt. 1), our Lord and Savior was born through Salathiel and Zorobabel. He brought forth from the same land's seed, that is, from the royal lineage, Matthan the uncle of Jechoniah, whose name he changed, and called him Sedecias, and made him king in Jerusalem, and set him over many peoples. And yet he placed him on the surface, and did not establish the power of his empire on a deep root: but he appointed him to be seen, and to be under the authority of Babylon, or of humble stature, with his branches looking towards it: so that he would indeed rule over the people of Judah; but he would look towards the command of the Babylonians." } For this is what Scripture says: A small stature, with branches reaching toward it, the eagle is understood. This is more clearly translated by the Seventy, and it happened to be planted in a weak and small vineyard: so that its branches alone appeared, it seemed to indeed have a kingdom, but its kingdom itself was lowly and feeble, ruled by the authority of the Babylonian prince. This is what is mentioned in the current chapter, to which we shall add the rest.


<h2 id='tocuniq183'>(Vers. 7 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 7 seqq.) And there was another large eagle, with great wings and many feathers. And behold, this vine, as if sending out its roots toward it, extends its branches toward that eagle, to be watered by the irrigation of its shoots. It planted it in good soil, by many waters, so that it would produce leaves and bear fruit, and be a great vineyard. Say: Thus says the Lord God: Will it prosper? Will it not uproot its roots and break its fruit off, causing all the shoots of its sprouting to wither and dry up, so that it will not exert a mighty arm or have many people to uproot it completely? Behold, it is planted, so will it prosper? Will it not wither when the burning wind touches it, and be dried up, and its shoots wither in the dry ground? LXX: And another great eagle came, with large wings and many claws: and behold, this vine was entwined with it, and its roots were attached to it, and its branches spread out to it, to water it with the soil of its planting. In a good field, over much water, it was nourished: to produce shoots and bring forth fruit, and to become a great vineyard. Therefore say: Thus says the Lord God: Will it thrive? Will not its roots wither and its fruit rot, and all the vegetation that springs up from it wither and dry up? It will not thrive, even with a strong arm or a large population, to uproot it from its roots. And behold, it fattens up. Will it thrive? As soon as the scorching wind touches it, it will wither, dry up, and be dried by the heat. Will not its fertile soil dry up? The second eagle, that is, the other one, and it too is large, full of feathers, with many talons, because of its rapacity and the devastation of many nations, is the king of Egypt, Pharaoh. And behold, this vine is understood to be King Zedekiah, who had been established by Nebuchadnezzar in Jerusalem, began, he says, to send his shoots to it, that is, to the king of the Egyptians, to send messengers, and to ask for help from him against the king to whom he was subject. For this is what the Scripture now says, that it may water it from the channels of its growth. This vine, which was planted in good soil by Nebuchadnezzar, to produce leaves and bear fruit and grow into a larger vineyard, is therefore commanded by the prophet to speak to the vine, which was planted by Nebuchadnezzar, and has sent its branches to the Egyptian eagle: will it thrive because it has attempted to do this, and will not all its shoots and branches soon wither? And he said, 'Did he not flee with the powerful arm, and a multitude of people? For fleeing from King Zedekiah and being deserted by the help of the Egyptian king, he was captured by the generals of Nebuchadnezzar in the deserts of Hierichontiis (also known as Hierichuntis). And all his companions were scattered here and there, as is written in the books of Kings and Chronicles, and in the book of Jeremiah (2 Kings 25, Jeremiah 39).'

<h2 id='tocuniq184'>(Vers. 11 seqq.)</h2>

(Ver. 11 seq.) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Say to the rebellious house: Do you not know what these things mean? Say: Behold, the king of Babylon is coming to Jerusalem, and he will take the king and the princes and bring them to himself in Babylon. And he will take some of the royal offspring and make a covenant with him, and he will take an oath from him. But he will also take strong men from the land, so that his kingdom will be lowly and not exalted, but will keep his covenant and observe it. When he departs from him, he sends messengers to Egypt, to give him horses and a great army. Will he succeed? Will he escape who has done these things? Can he break the covenant and yet escape? As I live, declares the Lord God, surely in the place where the king dwells who made him king, whose oath he despised, and whose covenant with him he broke, in Babylon he shall die. Pharaoh with his mighty army and great company will not help him in war, when mounds are cast up and siege walls built to cut off many lives. He had indeed despised the oath, to break the covenant. And behold, he stretched out his hand: and after he has done all these things, he shall not escape. This is a riddle, this is a parable, which the Scripture showed under the two eagles and the vineyard, the two kings of Babylon and Egypt; and King Zedekiah, who, against the oath, abandoned his friendship with Nebuchadnezzar and transferred himself to the king of Egypt. He shall strike a covenant with him, and he shall take an oath to him, to keep his covenant and preserve it. He who breaks a covenant, it is said, will not escape. And from this we learn that faith must be kept even among enemies, and that it doesn't matter to whom, but by whom you have sworn. For he who believed in your name for the sake of God is found to be much more faithful, and he was deceived by you, who, under the pretext of divine majesty, plotted treason against your enemy, or rather, your friend by now. For, as it is said, in the place of the king who appointed him as king, whose oath he made void, and the covenant he had with him was broken, he will die in the midst of Babylon. For we read that Zedekiah was captured, taken to Riblah, and there his sons were killed before his eyes, and then blinded like a wild animal in a cage, and transported to Babylon (2 Kings 25). Therefore, even though Scripture may seem contradictory to itself, it is nevertheless true in both instances. For it had been prophesied to Zedekiah, 'You will enter Babylon, and you will not see it' (Jeremiah 34:4). He did enter Babylon, because he was taken there, but he did not see it, because he was blinded. But that which follows, 'And he shall not engage in battle against him with a great army, nor shall he make war with a multitude of people against him; in the casting up of mounds, and in the building of ramparts, in order to kill many souls,' is understood in two ways: either the Egyptian king coming against King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon will not be able to fight, nor resist such a multitude with a small army; or King Zedekiah himself will be conquered by Pharaoh, from whom he hoped for assistance: not that Pharaoh conquered him, or that the Scripture testifies to this anywhere; but rather the conquest by Nebuchadnezzar was carried out by the intervention of the Egyptian king. And it was not this king who was seen besieging Jerusalem, but the one in whom Zedekiah had vainly hoped. Behold, he said, he reached out his hand to the king of Egypt and surrendered himself; and he committed perjury and sacrilege against God. Will it benefit him, he said? And when he has done all these things, he will not escape.

<h2 id='tocuniq185'>(Vers. 19 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 19 and following) Therefore, thus says the Lord God: As I live, surely I will bring down upon his head the oath that he despised and the covenant that he broke. I will spread my net over him, and he will be caught in my snare; I will bring him to Babylon and there I will judge him for his unfaithfulness in which he despised me. And all his fugitives, along with all the troops with them, will fall by the sword, and the survivors will be scattered to every wind. Then you will know that I am the Lord, who has spoken. The saying is secular.

Trickery or virtue, who seeks in an enemy? Those who say that enemies are to be deceived by deceit are accustomed to oppose us. To whom should we acquiesce? Sedecias did far worse: for he deceived not an enemy, but a friend, with whom he had been joined in a covenant of the Lord. Therefore, as long as you do not swear and enter into an agreement in the name of the Lord, it is a matter of prudence and fortitude, either to deceive or overcome your adversary in any way you can. However, when you bind yourself by an oath, it is not an adversary, but a friend who has trusted you; and under the pretext of an oath, that is, the invocation of God, he has been deceived. Therefore, the Scripture now says: I will put the oath that he despised, and the covenant that he broke, on his head. And so that we do not think that the oath, covenant, and agreement belong to the king of Babylon or to Zedekiah who made it, it follows: In the transgression when he despised me. Therefore, whoever despises the oath, despises the one by whom he swore, and he does wrong to the one whose name he trusted. For this reason, I will spread my net over him, says the LORD, and he will be taken in my snare; I will bring him to Babylon and I will bring him to judgment there. Therefore, whatever Nebuchadnezzar did against Zedekiah, he did not do it by his own strength, but by the anger of God, in whose name Zedekiah had sworn falsely. According to Agogen, although the interpretation may seem violent, it must be understood that just as all other living creatures are commonly referred to in both good and bad terms, so it is with the eagle and the lion. In a good sense, it is said: The Lion's cub of Judah (Genesis 49:9). In a contrary sense: Our adversary the devil prowls around like a roaring lion (1 Peter 5:8). And in Psalm it says: He lies in wait in secret places, like a lion in his den; he lies in wait to catch the poor (Ps. IX, 9). It is said in a positive sense about the eagle, that the righteous, becoming rich, makes wings for himself like eagles, so that he can return to the house of his predecessor. And in Isaiah it is written, that the righteous shall bring forth wings like eagles (Isa. XL): they shall run and not be weary: they shall walk and not faint. And rightly did he who said: With strength will I make, and with the understanding of intelligence will I take away the bounds of the nations, and their strength will I plunder: and I will shake cities which are inhabited, and the whole world I will seize with my hand as a nest, and as broken eggs (Ibid., X, 13, 14), now described under the persona of an eagle: not wanting at all to harm the Lebanon, which is interpreted as whiteness, and is referred to as incense, he lashes out at the tops of the cedars, and at princes, and at the royal lineage, according to that verse in Habakkuk: His food is choice (Abac. I, 16). And he makes a testament, that those whom he has taken captive may submit their necks to the Babylonian king, and fulfill what the Apostle speaks: Whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may not blaspheme (I Tim. I, 20). And in another place: Whom I have delivered, he says, to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved (I Cor. V). Therefore, if perhaps we are cast out from the congregation of brothers and from the house of God because of some sin, we should not resist: but with a calm mind, bear the sentence passed against us, and say with the Prophet (Mich. VII, 9), I will endure the wrath of the Lord, because I have sinned against Him, until He justifies my cause, and so on. And it often happens that we, who are subject to one another, pass from one to another, who promise us their help; and they do not remain in their previous opinion. This must be avoided by all means, lest our shoots wither and our seeds dry up: and we are believed to act against God's covenant.

<h2 id='tocuniq186'>(Vers. 22 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 22 and following) Thus says the Lord (God is added in the Vulgate): And I will take from the top of the cedar's branch, and I will put from the top of its branches; I will break off a tender one, and I will plant it on a high and lofty mountain: on a high mountain of Israel I will plant it. And it will sprout into a shoot, and it will bear fruit, and it will become a great cedar, and all birds will dwell under its shade: every flying creature will nest under its leafy branches. And all the trees of the field will know that I, the Lord, have humbled the tall tree and exalted the low tree, and I have dried up the green tree, and I have made the dry tree flourish. I, the Lord, have spoken and have done. LXX: For thus says the Lord God: I will take from the top of the choice cedars, and from the head of their branches I will tear off a tender shoot, and I will plant it on a high and lofty mountain. On the mountain height of Israel I will plant it, that it may bear branches, produce fruit, and become a majestic cedar. Under it will dwell birds of every sort, and in the shade of its branches they will nest. And all the trees of the field shall know that I am the Lord; I bring low the high tree, and make high the low tree, dry up the green tree, and make the dry tree flourish. I am the Lord who speaks and acts. This is what is read in the Septuagint: 'And I will take from the top of its branches,' which is added in the Theodotion edition. And what follows: 'And its branches will be restored,' is marked with an obelus because it is not found in the Hebrew. The true Nebuchadnezzar therefore takes from the topmost part of the cedar's trunk, from the top of its branches, so that his kingdom may be humble and not exalted. But the Lord God Almighty, who spoke to Ezekiel, takes from the royal lineage and from the lineage of David; and he plants on a high and lofty mountain, as it is written in the psalm: 'But I have been set up as king by Him on His holy mountain of Sion' (Ps. II, 6). For the ruler of Judah has failed, and the leader of Israel, until he comes to whom it belongs. And he shall be the expectation of the nations. This one has come forth as a shoot and has produced fruit, and he has surpassed all cedars by his loftiness, so that all the birds of the sky dwell under him and all the creatures of his shadow are protected. Concerning him, Habakkuk says: His power is hidden in his horns. And he desires to gather his chicks under his wings, like a hen. So that all the trees of the region may know that he is the Lord. Speaking in allegories about believers: This is the one who once humbled the exalted tree of Israel, and exalted the humble people of the nations, who dried up the green tree of the Jews, flourishing and sprouting in the Law and the Prophets; and made the dry tree of the nations bear fruit: so that he might fulfill with his works what he always spoke. The same thing is signified by the words of Simeon in the Gospel, saying: Behold, this one is set for the falling and rising of many (Luke 2:34). And the grain of mustard seed, which is the smallest of all seeds, when it has grown, becomes a dwelling place for birds (Matthew 13:32). Some interpret it differently, the lofty tree humbled, and the humble exalted, referring to the passion of the Lord and Savior. Who, being in the form of God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped, but emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant (Philippians 2:6-7); and after the resurrection, the same tree was exalted, which was first green, dried up by death, and then revived, regaining its original greenness. Others refer both to Israel: that first he will come in humility and be dried up: and second he will be restored to his former state, with the fulfillment of what the Apostle Paul says: When the fullness of the Gentiles comes in, then all Israel will be saved (Deuteronomy 5:9-10).

<h2 id='tocuniq187'>Book Six</h2>

Book Six

I thought that, once the serpent was killed, the new heads of the hydra would not revive, and, according to the fables of the poets, that Scylla, being dead, would not torment me with the Scyllaean dogs that do not cease to bark. And yet, even with the heretics of God struck down by His hand so that they may not be tempted, if possible, even the chosen ones of God (Matthew 24), heresy itself does not die. They have left behind their hateful puppies, who pretend to be ours but do not abandon the poisons of their ancient mother and the deceitful Ulysses. They only smear their lips with honey and, as the words of the Scriptures say (Psalm 54), they make their words softer than oil. But they themselves are arrows and fiery darts that must be repelled and extinguished by the shield of faith. I have said these things, daughter Eustochium, in order to encourage you to assist me in my prophetic work and to resist the heretics with prayers. May the Lord explain, through my mouth and with his understanding, the sixth volume of the Explanations on Ezekiel. And may the same Spirit of grace, by which the things revealed to the prophets were written, also be revealed to us as we discuss them, so that we may be able to say: I opened my mouth and breathed in the spirit (Psalm 118, 131).

<h2 id='tocuniq188'>(Cap. XVIII.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter XVIII, Verses 1, 2) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: What do you mean by turning this proverb into a parable in the land of Israel, saying: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge? LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: ÷ Son of man, what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel, saying: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge? What the Seventy said, son of man, is not found in Hebrew. However, the divine Scripture warns of that which was said in Exodus: I am the Lord your God. A jealous God, who punishes the sins of the fathers upon the children to the third and fourth generation for those who hate me, and shows mercy to thousands for those who love me and keep my commandments (Exod. X, 5; Deut. V, 9, 10). And again: The Lord descended in a cloud and stood with Moses, and Moses called upon the name of the Lord, and the Lord passed before his face, and called out to him, saying: O Lord God, merciful and gracious, patient and full of mercy, and truthful, and one who keeps justice, and shows mercy to thousands, forgiving iniquities, and transgressions, and sins: and he does not cleanse the iniquities of the fathers upon the children and upon the children's children, to the third and fourth generation (Exod. XXXIV, 5 seq.), it should be understood in such a way, as a proverb and a parable, so that it sounds one thing in words and holds another sense; as we have said above concerning the parable of the two eagles. And the Lord also says in the seventy-seventh psalm: I will open my mouth in parables: I will utter propositions from the beginning (Ps. LXXVII, 15). And in the Gospel, He presents the parable of the sower, the tares, and the mustard seed, which, though it is the smallest of all seeds, grows into a great tree (Matt. XIII), in such a way that He presents one thing in words and holds another in meaning. And until this present day, we believed that the two testimonies from Exodus, which we placed above (Isa. XXIX), were not a parable, but a simple explanation of the sentiment. And although we did not dare to say anything, nor did a clay vessel speak against the potter, why did you make me this way, in this way: still, we endured a hidden scandal, that the injustice of God seemed to cause one person to sin and another to pay for sins. For if the sins of the fathers are visited upon the children to the third and fourth generations, it seems unfair for one person to sin and another to be punished. But from what follows: to those who hate me, the scandal of a threat or command is resolved. For they are not punished in the third and fourth generation because their fathers sinned, since it is rather the fathers who were sinners that should have been punished; but because they became imitators of their fathers and hated God with inherited evil and impiety, even as the branches grow from the root. Heretics in this place, who do not accept the Old Testament, often say against the creator: How good and just is the God of the Law and the Prophets, who, while silent and inactive toward the sins of the fathers, repays those who have not sinned; in fact, how much cruelty is there on His part, that He extends His wrath even to the third and fourth generation! We will respond to those who accuse us, and in this the mercy of the Creator God is demonstrated. For it is not of cruelty and severity to maintain anger unto the third and fourth generation, but a sign of mercy to delay the punishment of sin. For when it says: O Lord God, merciful and compassionate, patient and full of mercy; and it adds: punishing the iniquity of the fathers on the children, and on the children's children, it indicates that his mercy is so great that he does not immediately punish, but postpones the sentence of punishment. But if the punishment of sinners is deferred to the third and fourth generation, what more does it do for the just and holy? It follows: And keeping justice and mercy for many thousands who keep His commandments and do His precepts. It is written in Proverbs: As the sour grape is harmful to the teeth, and smoke to the eyes, so is iniquity to those who use it (Prov. X, 26). From this it is clear that it is not the teeth of others that ache and become numb, but those who have eaten the sour grape. But the meaning of this passage is as follows: just as if someone were to say, 'The fathers ate a sour grape, and the teeth of the sons were set on edge,' it is ridiculous and lacks consequence, so it is unjust and perverse for fathers to sin and for sons and grandsons to be tormented. There are those who interpret what is written in Exodus, 'visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation,' in such a way that they apply it to the human soul, saying that the father is a light touch and the source of sensory actions and vices, while the son, if the thought of sin is conceived, and the grandsons, if you conceive and commit any evil act, and the great-grandson, that is, the fourth generation, if you not only do what is evil and criminal but also glory in your crimes, according to what is written (Ibid., XVIII, 3): 'When the wicked has come into the depths of evil, he scorns.' Therefore, God does not punish the first and second impulses of thoughts, which the Greeks call 'propatheia', without which no one can exist. But if someone decides to act on their thoughts, or if they refuse to correct the actions they have taken, then punishment will follow. Hence, it is written: No one is without sin, not even if their life lasts only one day. But the years of their life are countless. (Prov. XX, 9). And in another place: Who can boast of having a pure heart? And again: Even the stars are not clean in his sight: and against his angels he found wickedness (Job 25:5). But if that exalted nature is not free from sin, what can be said of humans, who are surrounded by frail flesh? They should speak with the Apostle: Wretched man that I am, who will deliver me from this body of death (Romans 7:24)? And also, when we have done everything, we should say: We are worthless servants; we have only done what we ought to have done (Luke 17:10). And: Unless the Lord builds the house, those who build it labor in vain; unless the Lord guards the city, the guard keeps watch in vain (Psalm 127:1). But for the proof of this matter, that not the first impulse of thought, indeed, but the small instinct of the mind is punished by God, but if you consume in action what you have conceived in mind, it must be brought up from Genesis: Ham sinned, mocking the nakedness of his father; and it was not he who laughed who received the sentence, but his son Canaan: Cursed be Canaan; he shall be a servant to his brothers (Genesis 9). For what justice is there if a father sins and the sentence is pronounced against the son? Moreover, the statement made by the Apostle (1 Timothy 2) that a woman will be saved if her children remain in faith, sanctity, and chastity, seems to lack justice, as if good children and grandchildren would save their parents. For how many holy parents have wicked children, and conversely, how many sinful parents have righteous and holy children? Therefore, according to this interpretation, everything that we have said above must be understood as meaning that the sins of parents and ancestors should be punished in the branches, not in the root. Let it suffice for now to have said this about the proverb or parable: that the Law and the Prophets, that is, Exodus and Ezekiel, indeed God himself who has spoken here and there, should by no means seem to disagree in their teachings or correct what he said there. But if anyone can find a better or alternative interpretation that reconciles the contradictions in these testimonies, it is better to accept their opinion.


<h2 id='tocuniq189'>(Vers. 3, 4.)</h2>

(Verse 3, 4.) As I live, says the Lord, there shall no longer be to you this proverb in Israel. Behold, all souls are mine: as the soul of the father, so also the soul of the son is mine. The soul that sins, it shall die. LXX: As I live, says the Lord God, there shall be no more mention of this proverb in Israel: for all souls are mine. As the soul of the father, so also the soul of the son is mine. The soul that sins, it shall die. What it signifies, I live, says the Lord, and the parable, or proverb, above we have spoken more fully: which will never be said in Israel, but in those who do not have knowledge of God, nor can discern the truth.
