All, he says, are my souls; according to creature, not according to merit: as Moses was called a man of God, of whom it is written: The prayer of Moses, the man of God (Deuteronomy 33:1). And Elijah, who spoke to the captain of fifty soldiers: And if I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven upon you, and upon the fifty men (2 Kings 1:12). But a person who commits sin and is a son of iniquity is not called a child of God, as servants and slaves of God are called, of whom it cannot be said: Everyone who commits sin is a slave of sin (John 8:34). And again: For by whatever a person is overcome, by that he is enslaved (2 Peter 2:19). Just as the sins of children do not harm their parents, so the sins of parents do not overflow onto their children; but the soul that sins, it shall die: not by the abolition of its substance, but from its association with Him who says: I am the life (John 14:6). And elsewhere he says: Everyone who lives and believes in me shall not die forever (John XI, 26). And: Amen, amen I say to you: If anyone keeps my word, he shall not see death forever (John VIII, 51); for our life is hidden with Christ in God (Colossians III, 3); and that which is written will be fulfilled: Amen, amen I say to you: If anyone hears my word and believes in him who sent me, he has eternal life and does not come into judgment, but has passed from death to life (John V, 24). But what is said by Balaam, 'Let my soul die with the souls of the righteous' (Num. XXIII, 10): this has the meaning that he desires to die to the world and sin, and to live with the souls of the righteous, whose life is Christ, and they are able to sing: 'I will please the Lord in the land of the living' (Ps. CXIV, 9). For God is not the God of the dead, but of the living' (Matth. XXII, 32). And if Balaam, as is likely, is translated into our language, he sounds like a vain people: it is clear that a vain people of the nations desires to have fellowship with the souls of the righteous, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who are called 'straight' and 'just'. And the book of Genesis received its name from their word.

<h2 id='tocuniq190'>(Vers. 5, 6 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 5, 6 and following) And if a man is righteous and does judgment and justice; does not eat on the mountains or lift his eyes to the idols of the house of Israel; does not violate his neighbor's wife or approach a menstruating woman; does not oppress anyone; returns a pledge to the debtor; does not commit robbery; gives bread to the hungry; covers the naked with clothing; does not lend money at interest or take excessive interest; turns his hand away from iniquity; judges truly between man and man; walks in my statutes and keeps my judgments to do truth: this man is righteous, he shall surely live, says the Lord God. LXX; But the man who is righteous, who practices justice and righteousness; he does not eat up on the mountains, and does not lift his eyes to the idols of the house of Israel; he does not defile his neighbor's wife, and does not approach a woman during her menstrual flow; he does not oppress anyone, he returns a debtor's pledge, he does not commit robbery, he gives his bread to the hungry, he covers the naked with clothing, he does not lend money at interest, and he does not take more than he loaned; he turns his hand away from wrongdoing, he judges with righteousness between a man and his neighbor; he walks in my statutes, he keeps my ordinances, in order to practice them; this is the righteous man, he shall surely live, declares the Lord God. He says, 'Do you want to know what has been said: I will repay the sins of the fathers in the third and fourth generation (Deut. 5:9), it does not mean what most people think it means; nor is it similar to this saying: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the teeth of the sons are set on edge (Jerem. 31:29). Listen to what I am going to say: if there is a righteous father who did these things, and the son did not do them, and he had a wicked son who, abandoning the virtues of his father, gave himself over to crimes; will not the righteous father live because he is righteous, and will not the wicked son die because he has committed all the things that the father, by avoiding them, became righteous for?' Let us examine the catalogue of virtues of the father, which seem to me to be divided into seventeen parts. The first of which is to have made judgments; the second, similar to the first, is to have joined justice to judgment; the third is not to have eaten on the mountains; the fourth is not to have lifted one's eyes to idols, or as the LXX translated, to the thoughts of the house of Israel; the fifth is not to have violated one's neighbor's wife. The sixth is to have avoided the embraces of a menstruating wife. The seventh, not having saddened (or oppressed) a person, or as the Septuagint has it, not having oppressed by power; the eighth, having returned a pledge to a debtor; the ninth, not having seized anything by force, or according to the Septuagint, not having seized robbery; the tenth, having given bread to the hungry; the eleventh, having covered the naked with clothing; the twelfth, not having given money at interest; the thirteenth, not having taken anything more than what was given; the fourteenth, having turned away his hand from iniquity; the fifteenth, which seems similar to the first, but is different in part, having made a true judgement between man and man, or his neighbor; the sixteenth, having walked in the commands of the Lord; the seventeenth, having kept his judgments and statutes. We will explain the meanings of each of these things in what follows. If the man is just and performs judgment, it says. It is written in Proverbs: The thoughts of the just are judgments (Prov. XII, 5). Whoever possesses this virtue, to do nothing without reason and judgment, can say that prophetic word: The judgments of the Lord are true, justified in themselves (Ps. XVIII, 10), and when he judges all things rightly, so as not to show partiality to the poor in judgment, he will fulfill the command of the Lord: You shall judge the small and the great alike (Prov. XVIII), boldly saying: My soul has desired to desire your judgments at all times (Ps. CXVIII, 10)." } And again: I have chosen the way of truth; I have not forgotten your judgments (Verse 30). And in the same psalm: I know that your judgments are righteous (Alternate: just) (Verse 75); and so great shall be his blessedness, that he shall understand the judgments of the Lord, which are very deep; and he shall say with the Apostle: O the depths of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out (Romans II, 33). And in prayer let him mention: For thy ordinances are delightful (Psalm 118:39). After judgment comes justice, which whoever possesses will surely possess Christ, who has become for us justice, sanctification, and redemption (1 Corinthians 1); so that he may perform true justice, and not show partiality in judgment; but knowing his own righteousness, judge the righteousness of others. The third is not to eat on the mountains, which the Jews consider to be a sin related to idolatry. For we frequently read in the books of Kings and Chronicles: Nevertheless, he did not depart from the high places. Still, the people sacrificed in the high places and burned incense on the heights (3 Kings 15:22; Chronicles 20), as the Scripture signifies, that they offered sacrifices to idols in the mountains and groves, and burned incense. But we will say that he eats in the mountains, who says with the Pharisee: I thank you, God, that I am not like this tax collector: I fast twice a week: I give tithes of all my possessions (Luke 18:12), etc. And on the contrary, the tax collector, hearing him who had said, 'Learn from me, for I am meek and humble of heart' (Matt. 11:29), struck his chest with his hand, that is, the treasure of wicked thoughts, and did not dare to lift his eyes to heaven. And that which is said elsewhere, 'Do not seek what is beyond your strength, and do not investigate what is beyond your power' (Ecclus. 3:22), accuses all heretics of devouring the mountains of pride and despising the simplicity of the Church, and not knowing what is written about themselves: 'God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble' (James 4:6). In the fourth place, it is set, and it has not lifted its eyes to the idols of the house of Israel, for which the Seventy translators had thoughts. But the idols, that is, the images they have fashioned from their own hearts, all heretics make, to which they lift the eyes of their hearts, those who have considered their falsehood and deceit as truth. However, the house of Israel is called idols, which are found in the Church; and through the occasion of the false name of knowledge, they deceive even the simple ones, so that they may introduce the doctrines of the philosophers into the house of Israel, that is, those who contemplate God with their minds. In the fifth place it is set forth: and he shall not violate the wife of his neighbor, or contaminate her, which openly prohibits adultery; but from that which is added, of his neighbor, unless every man is understood to be a neighbor, it appears to be a precept that we should abstain from the wives of our friends; but freely pollute the spouses of our enemies and strangers. Therefore every man is to be considered the neighbor of man, according to the parable of the Gospel, which is presented by the Savior, of a certain man who, going down from Jerusalem, was wounded by robbers: when the Pharisee asks who was his neighbor, teaching him that he is a neighbor who does good. The mystical understanding of the holy man's wife can be related to wisdom, as Solomon says: Love her, and she will embrace you; cherish her, and she will protect you (Prov. IV, 6). He who desires to defile her, criticizes the blessings of others and, ignited by the torches of envy, violates what is sacred, corrupts what is chaste, and contaminates what is pure. The sixth is: Moreover, one should not approach a menstruating woman or wife. Throughout each month, the heavy and sluggish bodies of women are relieved by the discharge of impure blood. At the time when a man has intercourse with a woman, it is said that the conceived fetus inherits the defect of the seed, so that lepers and elephantiasis sufferers are born from this conception, and both sexes have deformed bodies, with either smallness or enormity of limbs, and corrupted discharge. Therefore, it is prescribed for men to know the specific times of intercourse, not only with other women, but also with their own, whom they seem to be united with by law, as Scripture says: 'Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth' (Genesis I, 28), when they should come together and when they should abstain from their wives. Indeed, both the Apostle and the Ecclesiastes proclaim: There is a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing (Ecclesiastes 3:6). Therefore, let the wife beware, lest she provoke her husband by enticing him with the desire for sexual intercourse, and let the husband not force himself upon his wife, thinking that he is entitled to the pleasure of conjugal relations at all times. Hence, Paul says: Let each one learn to possess his own vessel in sanctity and honor (1 Thessalonians 4:4). Beautifully in the little thoughts of Pythagoras in the Xystus, it is said: He who ardently loves is an adulterer of his own wife. Some person who translated this book into Latin wanted to illustrate it with the name of the martyr Xystus, not considering in the whole volume, which he foolishly divided into two parts, that the name of Christ and the Apostles were altogether omitted. It is not surprising if he transformed the pagan philosopher into a martyr and bishop of the Roman city: just as he also changed the book of Eusebius, first called 'On Origen', by the name of the martyr Pamphilus, so that the most impious book 'On the Principles' could more easily be accepted by Roman ears with such a praiser. It follows in the seventh place: And he shall not grieve a man, or, as the Septuagint translated, he shall not oppress by power. By what fault and sin I do not know whose someone else is. For the Egyptians indeed oppressed the Hebrews by power. Hence even Habakkuk complains, why the wicked oppress the just (Habakkuk 1). And I wish this were said only of those who are outside, and not of those who are inside. For even the leaders of the Churches often oppress the people through pride. Of which it is written: They made you a leader, so that you would not be arrogant: be among them as one of them (Sirach 32:1). And the Savior commanded: Whoever wants to be first among you, let him be the last of all (Matthew 20:27). And what is said in Hebrew, and he will not grieve the man, is in agreement with the testimony of the Apostle: Do not grieve the Holy Spirit, who dwells in you (Ephesians 4:30). And in the Gospel according to the Hebrews, which the Nazarenes are accustomed to read, among the greatest crimes is considered the one who grieves the spirit of his brother. But if the sadness of another kills the one who grieves, what should be said about wickedness and a tyrannical mind, to whom applies the following: 'Why does the earth and ashes boast?' (Sirach 10:9). Like someone who has forgotten his own condition, to be filled with phlegm, bile, feces, and, after a short while, to be consumed by worms, may he place his mouth in heaven and his tongue reach down to earth, and say with the true Nebuchadnezzar: 'I will ascend into heaven, above the stars of heaven I will set up my throne, and I will be like the Most High' (Isaiah 14:12). The eighth is: The pledge shall be returned to the debtor. Not to all debtors, otherwise there will be many opportunities for receiving pledges, which will become an opportunity for accumulating wealth. But to the debtor, about whom it is written in the law that he is poor, and who has put up his own clothing as a pledge, and who should receive it back before sunset (Deut. XXIV), lest due to the cold he cry out to the Lord, who is the avenger of his injury. But if, according to what follows, we must give bread to the hungry and cover the naked with clothing (Exod. II): how much more should we give what is his own, if the poverty of the debtor is unquestionable? We can also give a pledge to the debtor, when we, who are united by love, and who owe mutual charity to each other, give our pledge, holding nothing of his debt against him. It holds the ninth place: He has not seized anything by force, or according to the Septuagint, he has not committed robbery. The Apostle speaks about robbers, stating that among other sinners we must not even eat with such people, and every robbery is mixed with violence (1 Corinthians 6). If violence is inflicted justly, robbery is not profitable. And there is a holy violence, and a desirable robbery, of which the Gospel also writes: From the days of John the Baptist until now, the kingdom of heaven has been forcefully advancing, and the forceful ones lay hold of it (Matthew 11:12). Of this also speaks Judas, the brother of James: But others save with fear, pulling them out of the fire, hating even the garment defiled by the flesh (Jude 1:23). And on the contrary, the opposing powers hasten to seize prey to their own detriment, those whom they are robbing. And Jacob's saying: 'A wild beast has devoured him: a wild beast has taken Joseph away' (Genesis 37:33). Therefore, the sheep of the Lord that follow him are not taken from his hands. And he says: 'What my Father has given me is greater than all, and no one can snatch from the hand of my Father' (John 10:29). From this, it is clear that there is one power, strength, and substance of the Father and the Son. For if no one can snatch from the hand of the Son what the Father has given, and these same things are in the hand of the Father which are not taken from him, it is clearly proven that all things are common to the Father and the Son, and the Son holds the Father in his hand, just as the things that belong to the Son are held in the hand of the Father. The tenth is: He will give his bread to the hungry. By this we are taught that alms should not be given to those who are full, but to those who are hungry; and not to give bread to those who burp from fullness, but to those who are tortured by emptiness. For in bread is contained all nourishment. And it is significantly said, his bread: lest we turn bread acquired through robbery, usury, or ill-gotten gain into mercy. For the redemption of a man's soul (Prov. 13:7) is his own riches. We see that many people, both clients and the poor, and farmers do this; not to mention the violence of the soldiers and judges, who oppress through power or commit theft, so that they may give a little to the poor from the many, and take pride in their own wickedness. And let the deacon publicly recite the names of those who offer in the Churches: as much as this person offers, as much as that person has promised, and they please themselves with the applause of the people, while their conscience torments them. And we give material to the miserable, so that they may rejoice in the things they receive, and not mourn for the things they have taken away. But it is better that we understand the bread of the just man, who says: I am the living bread, which came down from heaven (John 6:51); and whom we beseech to grant us in prayer: Give us this day our substantial bread, or that which will come to us (Matthew 6:11); so that, having always received him afterwards, we may deserve to receive him daily in the present age. He gives this bread to the righteous who are hungry, of whom it is written: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst (Matth. V, 6). For the righteous person makes the common bread of all his own, as the prophet says: I will take from them strength, or the staff of bread. What we are speaking of, if indeed we are of Christ, or rather what the prophet mentions, is the bread of believers and the hungry. This bread is not to be given at all to those who have eaten and drunk and are satisfied, and have grown fat and kicked, of whom it is said: Woe to you who are satisfied now, for you will hunger (Luc. VI, 25), lest they vomit him out, as Solomon says: He will vomit and defile your good words (Prov. XXIII). What the Savior says in other words: Do not give what is holy to the dogs; nor cast your pearls before swine (Matt. VII, 6). It holds the eleventh place: And clothed the naked. This statement, according to the explanation of the previous verse, should be interpreted in two ways: that we give clothing to the naked, as the Savior says: I was naked, and you clothed me (Matt. XXV), and that we give the clothing of Christ to the naked in faith and virtues, of whom it is written: For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ (Gal. III, 27). He was naked in this garment, not having a wedding garment, he was cast out from the feast. Concerning this nakedness, the Lord speaks to Jerusalem: But you were naked and full of confusion. It holds the twelfth number: And has not lent money at interest, or as the LXX translated, has not given his money for interest. In Hebrew, all kinds of usury are prohibited; in the LXX, only money. According to what is written in the fourteenth psalm: 'Who has not given his money at usury' (Psalm 14:5). And how is it said: 'To your brother you will not lend money at interest, but to a stranger you will lend at interest' (Deuteronomy 15:6, 23:10). But see the progression: At the beginning of the Law, interest is only prohibited among brothers; in the prophets, usury is prohibited for everyone, as Ezekiel says: 'He has not given his money at usury'. Furthermore, in the Gospel, there is an increase in virtue, with the Lord commanding: 'Lend to those from whom you do not expect to receive' (Luke 6:35). It follows in the thirteenth place: And moreover he shall not receive more. Some people think that usury exists only in money. But divine Scripture, foreseeing this, takes away the excess of everything, so that you do not receive more than you gave. Usury is usually demanded in the form of wheat, barley, wine, oil, and other goods, as the divine word calls it, as an abundance. For example, let us give ten measures during the winter season, and let us receive fifteen measures during the harvest, that is, more than half. Whoever considers himself most just will receive a fourth portion more, and they are accustomed to argue and say: I gave one bushel, which produced ten bushels. Is it not just that I should receive a half bushel more from my own, when he, by my generosity, has nine and a half bushels of my own? Let us not be deceived, says the Apostle, God is not mocked (Galatians VI, 7). Let the merciful lender respond to us briefly: did he give to the one who has, or to the one who does not have? If he had, he certainly should not have given, but he gave as if he did not have. Therefore, why does he demand more as if from someone who has? Others are accustomed to receiving small gifts of different kinds in exchange for borrowed money, and they do not understand that it is called interest and excess, whatever it may be, if they receive more than what they gave. The fourteenth step: From wickedness, it says, he turned away his hand, so as to flee from all wickedness. For wickedness is not only committed by the hand, but also by other members, as Solomon says: Remove wicked lips far from you (Prov. IV, 24). And in the Psalms: They spoke iniquity on high (Ps. 72:8). The foot also runs to iniquity, and the eye desires another man’s wife; neither should one imitate him of whom it is said: He has done no iniquity, and there is no deceit in his mouth (Isa. 53:9). Therefore, we are commanded to make friends for ourselves with unjust mammon, so that they may receive us into eternal dwellings. The fifteenth is: He shall have made a true judgment between man and man, or between his neighbors. What seems to sound the same as before, where it is written: If he is just, and he does judgment; but with the truth of judgment added: which he does between man and man, or his neighbor, is seen to have the intensification of virtues. Hence, in the beginning of Proverbs, after many precepts, the correction of judgment is brought forth. To know, he says, wisdom and discipline, and to understand the words of prudence, to receive the subtilties of speeches, and to know true justice, and after all to correct judgment (Prov. I, 2, 3). Therefore, the Apostle (I Cor. VI) rebukes those who are established in the Church for having disputes among themselves, and the least esteemed and least respected person is chosen to judge between man and man, he who has destroyed what is small and has reached the mature man; and yet he needs a greater understanding in order to attain to the truth of judgment. It continues in the sixteenth place: Let him walk in my commandments. And in the seventeenth: He shall keep my judgments and my justifications, that he may do them, and keep also my commandments: in which commandments of the Lord are said to be precepts, and in which they are said to be justifications. The one hundred and twelfth psalm is full of precepts and justifications, and in part the eighteenth, in which it is written: The justices of the Lord are right, rejoicing hearts, and the commandment of the Lord is lightsome, enlightening the eyes (Psalm 18:9). In which it is asked, how in the same prophet God said: 'I have given them non-good justifications, in which they will not live in them' (Psalm 119:28). The easy and fuller answer is in the following, that the Jews who follow the letter die, and the Christians who understand the life-giving Spirit live. It is tedious, if we want to prove by testimonies where the precepts of the Lord are said to be and where justifications are said to be, and in what individual, or differences, or obscurities they are involved. And in the present place it is said: Here is the righteous one, he will live, says the Lord God. Whoever does these things, and does not do those, will not be punished for the sins of the father, but will live by their own virtues.

<h2 id='tocuniq191'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 10 seqq.) But if he has begotten a son who is a robber, shedding blood, and he has done one of these things (or as the LXX translated, and he has committed sins: he has not walked in the way of his righteous father), and indeed he does all these things, not doing, but eating in the mountains, and defiling the wife of his neighbor, troubling the poor and needy (or oppressing), robbing plunder, not returning a pledge, and lifting his eyes to idols, committing abomination, giving into usury, and receiving more, will he live? When he has done all these detestable things, he shall surely be put to death; his blood shall be upon him. In Hebrew, the word for thief is 'Pharis' in the second edition of Aquila, 'transgressor' in Symmachus, and 'pestilent' in the Septuagint and Theodotion. Just as a pestilence creates diseases and devastates the regions where it has spread, so does a pestilent man ravage everything. Let us first say, according to history, that you may know that the iniquities of the fathers do not overflow upon the children. If the righteous person does what the previous passage has described in order, they will live. But if they have a son who departs from the service of the Lord and exchanges the virtues of his father for vices, doing what his father did not do and not doing what his father did do, can he live? Certainly not, but he will be guilty of shedding his own blood. Furthermore, according to spiritual understanding, the righteous man, if he preaches the Gospel faith, and his son and disciple are deceived by heretical error, he will be called a plague. About which it is written in the first psalm: And he has not sat in the seat of pestilence (Ps. I, 1). And in the proverbs, the confident and audacious person is called proud and pestilent (Prov. XXXIII). This person has shed the blood of deceivers and constantly multiplies all sins; eating on the mountains of pride and polluting the Church of their neighbor, distressing the needy and poor in the knowledge of the Scriptures, oppressing and supplanting them; seizing the plunder from those whom they have deceived from the Church: not returning the pledge that they received from the master, in order to fulfill what is written: Freely you received, freely give (Matth. X, 8). And to idols and images, which he fashioned from his own heart, lifting up his eyes and committing all abominations, and giving money at interest, to increase the error of the master's disciples through diligence; and demanding more from those to whom he had given, than he had given: surely he will not be able to live, but will die in his own blood.

<h2 id='tocuniq192'>(Vers. 14 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 14 onwards) But if he has a son who sees all the sins his father has committed, fears them, and does not commit similar sins (like them): he does not eat upon the mountains, does not lift up his eyes to the idols of the house of Israel, does not violate his neighbor's wife, does not oppress anyone, does not withhold a pledge, does not commit robbery, gives bread to the hungry, covers the naked with clothing, turns his hand away from injuring the poor, does not take interest or excessive profit, follows my statutes, and keeps my commands: he will not die for his father's iniquity, but will surely live." } His father, who accused falsely, and used violence against his brother, and committed evil in the midst of his own people: he died in his wickedness. And, he says, do not be surprised, if the son of a righteous man, turning to vices and sins, dies by death. On the contrary, if the son of a wicked and impious man, 214 should see the perversity of his father's ways, and turn away, so that he does not do evil and does good, he should not be held responsible for his father's wickedness. And that which can be received in us, about which it says in the Psalms: Listen, daughter, and see, and incline your ear, and forget your people, and your father's house; and the king will desire your beauty (Ps. 44:11). And we, who are created from the stock of the nations, in order to leave behind the sins of our parents, and to practice judgment and justice, and to live in them. Therefore, we repeat what we have discussed above in greater detail. And thus, we quickly traverse all things, desiring to pass over to those things which are more obscure and new.


<h2 id='tocuniq193'>(Vers. 19, 20.)</h2>

(Verse 19, 20.) And you say: Why did the son not bear the iniquity of the father? Clearly, because the son has practiced judgment and justice, he has kept and done all my commandments: he shall surely live. The soul that sins shall die. The son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, and the father shall not bear the iniquity of the son. The righteousness of the righteous shall be upon him, and the wickedness of the wicked shall be upon him. He resolves the question, which the listener could have raised to the contrary. He often used to say: Why did the just son not bear the iniquity of his father? To which he himself responds: Clearly, because the son acted well and did not commit the father's offenses. And it is just that just as the sinner dies in his wickedness, so the just one lives in his virtues: and the soul that has sinned dies, and the one that has kept God's commandments lives.

<h2 id='tocuniq194'>(Vers. 21, 22.)</h2>

(Verses 21, 22.) But if the wicked turns away from all the sins he has committed, and keeps all my commandments, and does judgment and justice: he shall surely live, and not die. All the iniquities which he has committed, I will not remember. To this extent, he says, the sins of the fathers do not pass on to the children, nor does the wickedness of the father burden the righteous son: nor are others punished for the sins of others, so that the same person who was previously wicked and sinful, if he later repents and turns to better things, his past sins shall not be judged by their age, but he shall be received into my flock, with an innovation of virtue. At the same time, it must be considered what kind of repentant sinner the wicked and sinful person accepts. If, as he says, he turns away from all the sins he has committed and keeps all the commandments of the Lord, so as to abandon all crimes and pursue all virtues; if he does all good things and forsakes all evil things; then I will forget all of his iniquities that he has committed.

<h2 id='tocuniq195'>(Vers. 23.)</h2>

(Verse 23) In his righteousness, which he has worked, he shall live. Not so much my righteousness as his shall live: although it is the duty of my righteousness to reward the good with good, and the evil with evil.

Is it my will that the wicked should die, says the Lord God, and not that they should return from their ways, and live? (I Tim. II). Therefore, it is the will of the Lord that all should be saved, and come to the knowledge of the truth. However, wherever there seems to be a severe and harsh judgment of God, it condemns not the people, but the sins.

<h2 id='tocuniq196'>(Vers. 24.)</h2>

(Verse 24.) But if the righteous turns away from his righteousness and commits iniquity, and does according to all the abominations that the wicked man does, shall he live? All the righteousness that he has done shall not be remembered. In the trespass that he has trespassed and in the sin that he has sinned, in them he shall die. As for the righteous, his previous sins do not burden him; so the sinner who was once righteous, his former righteousness does not help him. For each person will be judged according to what is found in them.

<h2 id='tocuniq197'>(Vers. 25.)</h2>

(Verse 25.) And you said: The way of the Lord is not fair. Hear, O house of Israel: Is not my way fair: and are not your ways unjust? Give reasons why the judgment of the Lord is just. Do you think, he says, that it is unjust for me to render the sins of fathers to their children (Deuteronomy 24); and for others to eat sour grapes, and the teeth of others to be set on edge (Jeremiah 31)? Behold, everyone dies in their own sin, and is made alive in their own righteousness: in both cases, judgment is based on the present, not the past. Rather, your unfair opinion is that you think a parable is not a parable, but you interpret it as if it were the truth of history, so that the crimes of others are punished in others.

<h2 id='tocuniq198'>(Vers. 26.)</h2>

(Verse 26) For when the righteous turns away from his righteousness and commits iniquity, he will die for it. In the iniquity (or injustice) that he has committed, he will die. This can also be understood as: The righteous, who is initially the people of Israel, turns away from his righteousness because he has forsaken the author of righteousness, and commits iniquity by denying the Son of God. In the sin and wickedness that he has committed, he will die: not in many, but in one, killing the heir in order to destroy the inheritance.


<h2 id='tocuniq199'>(Vers. 27, 28.)</h2>

(Verse 27, 28.) And when the wicked turns away from his wickedness which he has done and does judgment and righteousness, he will preserve his own life. He will live because he considers and turns away from all the transgressions which he has committed; he will not die. On the other hand, says the prophet, the people of the nations who do not have knowledge of God and the wicked, if he turns away from his wickedness which he has previously practiced in idolatry and does the things commanded by the law of Israel, he will preserve his own life. And seeing that he perished in the injustices that he committed, he will believe in him who says: I am the way, the truth, and the life (John XIV, 6): he will live and not die.

<h2 id='tocuniq200'>(Vers. 29.)</h2>

(Verse 29) And the children of Israel say: The way of the Lord is not fair. Are not my ways equal, O house of Israel? Are not your ways unequal? Even until this day, Israel blasphemes God, questioning why He has forsaken His people and taken in a multitude of nations. The Lord accuses them that their ways are crooked, and with just judgment, He will send other vine-dressers into His vineyard to replace the lost tenants. This understanding is conveyed in the parable of the Gospel, as the Jews said: This will not happen (Luke 20:16).


<h2 id='tocuniq201'>(Vers. 30.)</h2>

(Verse 30.) Therefore, I will judge each one according to their ways, O house of Israel, says the Lord God. Whether they are from the multitude of nations or from the people of Israel who are being judged, there is no partiality with God (Colossians 3:25), but each one will be rewarded according to their faith, and they will be condemned for their impiety and unfaithfulness.

<h2 id='tocuniq202'>(Vers. 31.)</h2>

(Verse 31.) Turn away and repent from all your iniquities, and iniquity will not be for your ruin. Cast away from yourselves all your transgressions, in which you have transgressed. This speech is specifically directed to the Israelites, urging them to repent and abandon their iniquities or transgressions against God. However, it can also be understood to apply to both the Israelites and the multitude of the Gentiles, urging them to forsake their vices and turn to Him who can heal their contritions.


And make for yourselves a new heart and a new spirit. In abandoning the old ways, live in the newness of the spirit. The new heart of the Israelites is to believe in the one they previously denied. The new heart of the Gentiles is to abandon idols and disregard the worship of the dead, and to believe in the God of the living.

And why will you die, O house of Israel? It is better, as we have said above, to takes this exhortation in which it is written: Repent, and do penance, to mean the person of the Jews, whom God does not want to die, and to whom he now speaks: why will you die, O house of Israel, who have the fathers Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, of whom it is written: God of the living, and not of the dead (Mark 12:27). Why will you die because of your fault, who owe your life to the merit of your fathers, and to my mercy?" }


<h2 id='tocuniq203'>(Vers. 32.)</h2>

(Verse 32.) Because I do not desire the death of the one dying (or the sinner), says the Lord God: return, and live. I do not want, he says, you to die, whom I have begotten for salvation. For I have begotten sons, and I have exalted them: but they have despised me (Isa. 1:2). Therefore, return and live. It is not said to return, except to those who were previously with God, and later abandoned his company. And live through repentance, you who are dead through sin. Therefore, Israel, because it does not return to its former state, is to be believed to be dead.

<h2 id='tocuniq204'>(Cap. XIX.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 19, Verses 1 and following) And you shall take up a lamentation for the leaders of Israel, and you shall say: Why has your mother, the lioness, lain down among the lions? Among her cubs, she reared her young. And one of her cubs grew up and became a lion; he learned to capture prey and devour people. And the nations heard about him, and they captured him with their wounds, and they brought him in chains to the land of Egypt. When she saw that she was weakened and that her hope was destroyed, she took one of her cubs and made him a lion." } He who walked among lions, became a lion. He learned to capture prey and devour men. He learned to make widows and lead their cities into desolation, and the land and its abundance were laid waste by the roar of his voice. And peoples from all provinces gathered against him and cast their net over him; he was captured in their wounds. And they put him in a cage, they brought him in chains to the king of Babylon, and they sent him to prison so that his voice would no longer be heard on the mountains of Israel. LXX: And you take up the lamentation over the prince of Israel and say: What was your mother, a lioness, doing among lions? She lay down among young lions. And she brought up one of her cubs; he grew into a young lion and he learned to tear the prey. He devoured men, and the nations heard of him. He was caught in their pit, and they brought him with hooks to the land of Egypt. When she saw that she had waited in vain, that her hope was lost, she took another of her cubs and made him a young lion. He prowled among the lions; he became a young lion and learned to tear the prey. He became a lion and learned to snatch prey. He devoured men and fed on their audacity. He led their cities to the desert and laid waste to the land and its abundance with the sound of his roar. Nations from all around set snares for him and spread their nets over him. He was caught in their corruption and they put him in chains. He was brought to the king of Babylon in a cage and brought into the prison, so that his voice would no longer be heard on the mountains of Israel. I know that in this place I have read many explanations, hindered by such obscurities, that they have not so much revealed as enveloped the reading, when all the writings refer to contrary strengths, and describe lions and wars in the heavenly Jerusalem: how one of them was captured, and another one was appointed in his place, and many testimonies are given: that the devil and his companions are accustomed to be called lions, as it is written about the Apostle Peter: Our adversary the devil is like a roaring lion, going around and seeking how he may enter (1 Peter 5:8); and about the Psalms: Do not deliver the soul of Your turtle dove to wild beasts (Psalm 74:19). Certainly, when it comes to history, it is said that Johanan, the son of Caraeus, was led into Egypt: how he was called lion while fleeing with a few, I do not know: and Sedeciah, another lion, who was also led into Babylon. But leaving such explanations to the judgment of the reader, let us say that, by captivity being near, the prophet narrates the past rather than prophesying the future. For after the sixth year of Sedeciah (indeed, immediately in the following we read: And it came to pass in the seventh year, in the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month) a lamentation is taken up concerning the princes, or the prince of Israel, and it is said: Why did your mother lie down among the lions? Therefore, the lamentation is over the princes, namely all those who are descended from the line of Josiah. The mother of the princes of Jerusalem is called a lioness, who bore and nursed 219 cubs: and she brought up one of her cubs and made him a lion, signifying Joachaz the son of Josiah, whom Pharaoh Necho led into Egypt, and in his place installed Joacim. After his death, his son Jechoniah was made king, and he, along with his mother and the nobles of the city, was led into Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar. From him is born Salathiel, the father of Zerubbabel, who received his name from being born in Babylon (2 Kings 23). And it is clear that under the metaphor of the lioness, lion cubs, and lion, and again, another lion, is described what had already happened at that time when this prophet was speaking. For after he brought out from the royal line Joachaz, son of Josiah, and made him king, he became so cruel in a short time that he is remembered figuratively as having taken prey and devoured men. When an Egyptian came to him, he captured him not without wounds, either in a pit, as is specifically stated in Hebrew: in order to preserve the figurative capturing of lions, which are always captured in pits. And he brought him in chains or in shackles to the land of Egypt, and there he died. When his mother, who had given birth to him, who had nursed him, who had made him king, saw this, her expectation was destroyed. She took Jechoniah, the son of Joachim, from among the other kings and made him king. He also, imitating the cruelty of his predecessor, is described as being fierce like a lion, for he devoured men, made many widows, led cities to desolation; and at the sound of his roar, the entire province was terrified, so that nations came together and spread their nets over him, and captured him in a pit, and placed him in a cage, and in chains. This was not done to Jechoniah, for he had surrendered himself to the king of Babylon and was taken to Chaldea; but it was an allegory of a lion, who is captured in pits, bound with chains, and kept in cages. Furthermore, according to the history: we read about this concerning Zedekiah, who was made king of Jerusalem after Jehoiachin. And this has caused some to understand Zedekiah instead of Jehoiachin, because chains are mentioned, and a cage, and prison are named. Therefore, he was saved in prison, not killed, and only removed from the kingdom. However, the history narrates that Zedekiah, being led blindfolded to Babylon, was immediately killed there.


<h2 id='tocuniq205'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 seqq.) Your mother is like a vine planted in blood, by the water. Its fruits and branches have grown from many waters. And solid rods have become scepters of dominion for her, and her stature has been exalted among the branches. And she saw her height in the multitude of her palm trees: and in anger, she was uprooted and thrown to the ground, and a burning wind will dry up her fruit: they withered, and the strong rods were dried up, fire consumed her. And now she has been transplanted into a desert, in a pathless and thirsty land. And fire has come out from the rod of her branches, which consumed its fruit, and there was no strong branch in it, nor a scepter of rulers. She has mourned, and it will be for mourning. LXX: Your mother is like a vine, like a flower in an evil pomegranate planted in water. Its fruit and its bud have come from much water. And a branch of strength has become for her among the chiefs of the tribes, and she has been exalted by her greatness in the midst of her offspring. And he saw his greatness in the multitude of his palm trees, and it was shattered in anger: it was thrown down to the ground, and a burning wind dried up its chosen ones. They were avenged, and his rod of strength was dried up. Fire consumed it, and now they have planted it in the desert, in a land without water, and fire came out from its chosen ones and consumed it, and there was no rod of strength in it. It is a lamentation in three parts, and it will be a lamentation. In different speeches, one thing is said. And just as in the previous examples we read about Jerusalem being compared to a beautiful woman, and again about a lioness who nourished lions in her den, now the vine or vineyard is compared to the most beautiful thing, which is planted above the water, and because of this the branches nourished by the moisture have grown so much that one branch, which the Scripture calls a very strong or mighty rod, has become a scepter of the rulers. For what reason to translate the Septuagint into three leaders, so that kings may be made from it. But it itself was of such great beauty, that the splendor of its vigor was equal to the flowers of the pomegranate, which is said in Hebrew as if a vine in your blood, compared to the redness of flowers, therefore the vine was lifted up: Because God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble (James 4:6), it was uprooted in the fury of the Lord and thrown to the ground, so that the ruins of Jerusalem, the elegant translation of the vine, would be preserved. Although the vineyard may be beautiful and spread out with long branches, if you remove the poles and supports, the joined land dries up from the heat, especially if the burning wind, which the Greeks call καύσωμα, has dried up its fruit so that it withers and is as if consumed by fire. As for what is added in the Septuagint: They have been avenged, because it is written in Hebrew, they have withered, I cannot understand what significance it may have. Therefore, how is that vineyard of such fertility and abundance of fruits and such beauty, now transplanted into a desert, into an impassable and thirsty land? However, it signifies the land of Babylon to which they were carried away, or Egypt where they sought refuge, or the very land of Judah, in which only a few poor people remained, whom Godolias (also known as Gotholias) was appointed as governor to gather and govern the remnants of the people (4 Kings 25). Against whom he rose up, from the royal stock, from the branch of the vine of Ismael, who killed him in Maspha (also called Masepha), and devoured all the fruit of the vine, and from then on there was no strong branch in the vine, nor a scepter of rulers (Jeremiah XL and XLI). For no king remained to govern the people, but they fled with Johanan son of Carea to Egypt. Therefore, there is mourning and a parable of lamentation, to mourn the royal line that has ceased in Judaea, until the one who is appointed comes: He himself was the expectation of the nations (Genesis XLIX, 10). From this it is clear that the earlier reading, in which it is said: Why did your mother, the lioness, lie among lions? and this one in which it is written: Your mother is like a vine planted over water, with blood as its roots, belonging to Jerusalem, which lost its lions and its branches, and there was no branch left to rise up as a tribe or a ruling scepter. For it begins with lamentation and ends with lamentation. Take up the lamentation for the princes of Israel. This is, in the beginning and now in the end, a lamentation; and with lamentation and the mourning of parables, a royal lineage must be followed. Furthermore, according to the 222nd anagoge, which others refer to as the heavenly Jerusalem, they say that many have fallen in this valley of tears, and that kings have ceased to exist, and the once beautiful vineyard has been dried up by the burning wind, so that no green palms remain in it, which Jeremiah later laments in the form of the city, we understand (Matthew 24) concerning the Church, because in the last times, with multiplied iniquity, the love of many grows cold, so that even the chosen ones of God may be tested, and their leaders may be captured in the snares of the devil, who is not content with capturing only one king, but hastens to capture kings and princes daily, according to what is written: His chosen food (Habakkuk 1:16). The branches of the Church, which were once equal to flowers and the redness of blood, are later dried up by the wind. This exposition is also indicated by the parable of the Gospel, in which, after the rising of the sun, the plants that had sprouted are scorched by the heat and suddenly wither (Mark 4); so that hardly any of the branches remain that can rise up and become worthy leaders of the people. This is spoken in other words by Amos: 'I will send a famine upon the land: not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of God' (Amos 8:11). Where should we mourn and lament over the leaders of Israel, through whose fault and pride Judaea has been deserted and Jerusalem captured.

<h2 id='tocuniq206'>(Cap. XX.—Vers. 1.)</h2>

(Chapter 20, Verse 1) And it happened in the seventh year, in the fifth, in the tenth month, men from the elders of Israel came to inquire of the Lord and sat before me. After eleven months and five days of the previous vision, a word came again to the prophet, after the men from the elders of the house of Israel came to inquire of the Lord and sat before him. However, it was the custom of the people of Israel to seek whatever they desired to know from the Lord through the prophets, as many examples attest. Saul, seeking the lost donkeys, goes to Samuel and receives counsel from a young man to offer a quarter shekel to the prophet. When Jeroboam's son falls ill, his wife is sent to Shiloh to Ahijah (also called Abijah) the prophet, bringing gifts of bread, cakes, grapes, and a small jar of honey, in order to find out about their son's condition. David also consults another prophet, Nathan, to ask whether he should build a temple for the Lord. And Ahab inquires whether he should go up to Ramoth Gilead or not (3 Kings 22). In Isaiah also (Isa. 37) and in the book of Kings (4 Kings 19), it is foretold what will happen with Sennacherib. It is not surprising that in the Old Testament the prophets announce in advance what is going to happen, since we read that Agabus prophesied to Paul what was going to happen (Acts 21). It is written in Deuteronomy: The nations whom the Lord will destroy before you, they listen to dreams and divination, but the Lord your God has not given you that (Deut. 18:14). For it is the custom of the Gentiles to consult the Chaldeans, haruspices, diviners, sorcerers, oracles of demons, by which their error is deceived. Hence even now the elders of Israel go to a prophet to inquire of the Lord through him, and yet they remain silent about the inquiry, while he who was to be questioned knew what they were asking, so that in him there was a miracle of knowing why they had come, and answering those things which silent speech contained in the mind.

<h2 id='tocuniq207'>(Vers. 2, 3.)</h2>

(Vers. 2, 3.) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, speak to the elders of Israel and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: Have you come to inquire of me? As I live, I will not answer you, says the Lord God. To the righteous who ask fitting questions, a promise is given. While you are still speaking, I will say: Here I am. But for the sinners, like the elders of Israel whose crimes the prophet describes, there is no answer given; but rather a rebuke for their sins. And an oath is added: As I live, the sentence of denial is made stronger."  } But if I were to respond to what the Seventy said, I would say to you: Symmachus translated it more clearly, I will not respond to you.

<h2 id='tocuniq208'>(Vers. 4.)</h2>

(Verse 4.) If you judge them, if you judge, son of man. LXX: if I avenge them with vengeance, son of man: They indeed came to interrogate me, desiring to know about those things which they doubt, and future events; but you, son of man, judge them, so that the response may not be of a prophet, but the sentence of a judge for the iniquities they have committed, and for following the crimes of their fathers. Or certainly, if I avenge them with vengeance, it may be understood as follows: They are so covered in wickedness that they are not even worthy of correction and reprimand, according to what is said in the prophet: I will no longer visit your daughters, and your daughters-in-law, when they have played the harlot (Hosea 4). Where even sinners, who have gone deep in sin, are forgiven to fulfill the desires of their hearts (Prov. XVIII).

Show them the abominations of their ancestors, and say to them: 'Seventy times seven: declare to them the iniquities of their ancestors, and say to them: If the sins of the ancestors do not flow down to their children, how are the abominations and iniquities of the ancestors now placed upon the elders? Clearly for this reason, so that they may be shown to act similarly to their parents, and, with hereditary evil, drag the longest rope of sins, so that those who imitate their vices may fear their punishments.'


<h2 id='tocuniq209'>(Vers. 5, 6.)</h2>

(Vers. 5, 6.) Thus says the Lord God: On the day when I chose Israel and raised my hand for the descendants of the house of Jacob, I appeared to them in the land of Egypt and raised my hand for them, saying: I am the Lord your God. On that day I raised my hand for them, in order to bring them out of the land of Egypt into the land that I had provided for them, a land flowing with milk and honey, which is excellent among all lands. LXX: Thus says the Lord God: From the day I chose the house of Israel and became known to the descendants of the house of Jacob, and was made known to them in the land of Egypt, and I took them in saying: I am the Lord your God: on that day I took them by my hand, saying: to bring them out of the land of Egypt into the land that I had prepared for them, a land flowing with milk and honey: a land surpassing all lands. For what the Seventy said, 'honeycomb' is beyond all lands, for which we have interpreted it as 'excellent' among all lands. Aquila's first edition placed 'firmament'; the second, 'illustrious'; Symmachus, 'region'; Theodotion, 'fortitude'; that is, the foundation of all lands, because in it there is the religion of God, and the temple, and the ceremonies, and the knowledge of God. And to such an extent the people of Israel, when they were established in Egypt, were ignorant of God, that when Moses was sent to them, he said, 'If they ask me, who sent you?' What shall I say to them? Say, He who is, sent me (Exod. III, 13, 14). Therefore, he became known to the people in Egypt, and to the descendants of the house of Jacob, 225 when he raised his hand against the Egyptians for their sake, and said: I am the Lord your God, and he chose them to lead them out of the land of Egypt, to a land flowing with milk and honey. For they could not yet eat solid food: but like little children and infants, they needed honey and milk for their infancy. Surely, whoever considers the land of Judea, not only as the most famous but also as the most fertile of all lands, from Rhinocorura to Mount Taurus and to the Euphrates River, cannot have any doubt regarding the power and beauty of its cities and the pleasantness of its regions, namely Palestine and Phoenicia, Arabia, Syria Coele, Cilicia, and other regions that the Lord promised to the Israelites if they had kept God's commandments. Because they did not receive these regions, it was a fault of their disbelief. For many nations remained in the province of Palestine and Judea, who were not expelled. For the one to whom a promise is made is not responsible for the crime, if he himself has become unworthy of the promise, especially when the option of the one making the promise is presented: If you are willing and listen to me, you will eat the good things of the land. But if you are unwilling, the sword will devour you. Therefore, the present is chosen: and the one who is chosen cannot be immediately tempted or perish; for both Saul, chosen as king, and Judas, chosen as an Apostle, later fell due to their own fault. The raising of the hand, or extension, indicates the posture of the striker: to strike the Egyptians for them, and to free the people of Israel from Egypt.

<h2 id='tocuniq210'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7) And I said to them: Each one must cast away the offenses of their eyes, and do not defile yourselves with the idols of Egypt; I am the Lord your God. LXX: And I said to them: Each one must cast away the abominations of their eyes, and must not be defiled with the inventions of Egypt; I am the Lord your God. Concerning the offenses, which are called Secuse in Hebrew, Symmachus interpreted them as nausea, the second edition of Aquila as amputations, to signify that they should be cast away from the eyes like blurriness, and like nausea, which not only obstructs sight but also creates vomiting in those who see. And the Hebrew word for "gelule" is a term coined by the Septuagint; the first edition of Aquila, improperly translated; the second edition of Symmachus and Theodotion, they interpreted as idols: whom we are currently following. However, as they were leaving Egypt, they were commanded to forget the idols to which they had served for a long time, and even to cast them out of their sight so that they would not even consider them worthy of looking at, and to not continue to be polluted by the things with which they had long been defiled. I your Lord God, he says, not the Egyptian wonders, not the inventions of various monsters. But even to us, when we go out from Egypt, it is commanded that we cast off the offenses of our eyes: lest we be delighted with those things with which we were previously delighted in the world, lest we be defiled by the idols of Egypt, namely the inventions of the philosophers and heretics, which are rightly called idols. Let us also remove our eyes from the spectacles, indeed from the offenses of Egypt, the arenas, the circuses, the theaters, and all things that defile the purity of the soul and enter into the mind through the senses; and what is written is fulfilled: Death has entered through your windows (Jeremiah IX, 21).


<h2 id='tocuniq211'>(Vers. 8.)</h2>

(Verse 8.) And they provoked me. LXX: And they turned away from me. Or as Symmachus interpreted: They did not find rest in me. And immediately called, they depart from God, so that there is no interval between calling and departing. And it should be noted that no one departs from God unless they were previously with him. Hence, in the book of Job, the dragon is called an apostate, a transgressor, and one who departs (Job XXXIV).

And they did not want to listen to me. Each one did not cast away the abominations of their eyes, nor did they abandon the idols of Egypt. LXX: And they did not want to listen to me. They did not cast away the abominations of their eyes, and they did not abandon the inventions of Egypt. Therefore, they provoked me, and they turned away from me, because they did not want to listen to me, while the free will of man is preserved: and they did everything that I commanded them not to do by law: immediately despairing of salvation, and murmuring against Moses, and doubting the promises of God. Unde sequitur:

And I said that I would pour out my indignation on them, and vent my anger against them in the midst of the land of Egypt. But as soon as I commanded them to leave and cast away the offenses of their eyes, and not defile themselves with the idols of Egypt, they provoked me and refused to listen to what I said. Instead, they did the opposite of what I commanded not to be done. Therefore, I resolved to pour out my fury and indignation on them, and vent my anger that I had conceived in my mind in the midst of Egypt. For they had not yet come out of Egypt. For it follows below: 'I have cast them out of the land of Egypt, and have brought them into the desert.' From this it is shown that they had not yet come out of Egypt when He wished to pour out His indignation and fulfill His anger upon them, and strike them down in the midst of the land of Egypt.

<h2 id='tocuniq212'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9) And I did it for the sake of my name, so that it would not be profaned in the sight of the nations among whom they lived, and in whose midst I made myself known to them in order to bring them out of the land of Egypt. But I had planned to do it for the sake of my righteousness, not because of the greatness of my mercy, so that my name would not be defiled and I would appear unable to fulfill what I had promised to Israel. Therefore, I spared my name, so that the nations among whom I became known to them in the land of Egypt would not have an opportunity to blaspheme." } The prophet describes what God had promised to them while they were in the land of Egypt, how they immediately offended God, what God had planned against them, but ultimately did not do. The following events occurred after they left Egypt.

<h2 id='tocuniq213'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 and following) So I expelled them from the land of Egypt and brought them into the desert. I gave them my commandments and showed them my judgments, which a man should do and live by them. Furthermore, I gave them my Sabbaths as a sign between me and them, so that they would know that I am the Lord who sanctifies them. But the house of Israel provoked me in the desert: they did not walk in my commandments and cast aside my judgments, which a man should do and live by them, and they greatly violated my Sabbaths. Therefore I said that I would pour out my fury upon them in the wilderness, to consume them. And I have done it for the sake of my name, that it might not be profaned before the nations, from whose presence I have cast them out. These things are said to those who were brought out of Egypt into the wilderness, that having been freed from the vices of the Egyptians, they might more easily fulfill the precepts of God in solitude, and observe his judgments and sabbaths. These were given as a sign between him who gave them and those to whom they were given, as the Scripture says: 'And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: You also command the children of Israel, saying: See that you keep my sabbaths, because it is a sign between me and you throughout your generations, so that you may know that I am the Lord who sanctifies you, and keep the sabbath, for it is holy to you.' Whoever violates it shall die by death. Anyone who works on it shall be killed, and their soul shall be destroyed from among their people (Exodus 31:13, 14). Therefore, the Sabbath and circumcision were given as a sign of the true Sabbath and true circumcision: so that we may know to rest from the works of the world on the perfect and eternal Sabbath, and not to be uncircumcised in heart but to circumcise our hearts. Therefore, in six days we work, and on the seventh day we rest, so that we may do nothing else day and night except recognize that everything we live is owed to the Lord, and when the week returns, we consecrate ourselves entirely to His name, so that through the sanctification of the day, we may remember the Lord who sanctifies us. These precepts and justifications, and the observance of the Sabbath, the Lord gave in the desert, so that those who do them may live by them: not to go beyond them to greater things, as it is promised in the Gospel. Those who violated them did so not once or a little, but greatly, so that the intensity of the violation might be shown. Therefore, He spoke and in His mind decided to pour out His fury upon them in the desert and consume them, when He spoke to Moses: 'Leave me, and in my anger I will destroy them' (Exodus 32:10). But he did not want to do it, sparing the Egyptians and the other nations, so that they would not be scandalized, and waiting for the repentance of those who had converted. And it should be noted that when he spoke to the established in Egypt after the offense: I did it, he said, for the sake of my name, so that it would not be violated in the presence of the nations from whom I had driven them out. For at that time they were still in the midst, because they had not yet gone out. But now, after they have gone out, it is said, from whom I had driven them out in the presence of the nations.


<h2 id='tocuniq214'>(Vers. 15.)</h2>

(Verse 15) Therefore, I lifted my hand against them in the wilderness, to not bring them into the land which I had given them, flowing with milk and honey, the choicest of all lands, because they rejected my judgments and did not walk in my statutes, and they profaned my Sabbaths. For their hearts followed after idols, and my eye spared them from destruction, and I did not consume them in the wilderness. Septuagint: And I lifted my hand against them in the wilderness, to not bring them into the land which I had given them, a land flowing with milk and honey; it is a land of abundance beyond all lands, because they rejected my statutes and did not walk in my commandments, and they profaned my Sabbaths, and they followed after the intentions of their hearts. And my eye spared them, so that I would not destroy them, and I did not kill them in the desert. I indeed resolved to pour out my fury upon them and consume them: but I did it for the sake of my name, so that it would not be profaned among the nations, namely the Amalekites and others (Exodus XVII; Numbers XIV), who fought against them in the wilderness, in order to prevent them from entering the land that I had promised to them, a land flowing with milk and honey, which is the choicest of all lands, a land of abundance. But the cause of punishment is this sentence, because they rejected my judgments and did not walk in my commandments, and violated my Sabbaths. And the cause of this cause is that they did not do these things, because their heart followed Egyptian idols. But my eye spared them, saying, that I would not kill them and destroy them altogether. It is questioned, however, how I spared them, whose corpses fell in the wilderness, and except for Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh, no one entered the promised land. From this we understand that those people are not reserved for eternal punishments, nor are they deleted from the book of the living, nor are they consumed before the face of the Lord. For if they were not admitted into the promised land, they are believed to have perished: therefore, Moses also perished, who only saw the promised land but did not enter it. Concerning whom the Lord Jesus speaks in the book of Joshua: 'My servant Moses is dead' (Deuteronomy 34:5). And in Malachi: Remember the law of Moses my servant (Malachi 4:4). And in Jeremiah, God speaks as if to a friend and intimate: If Moses and Samuel stood before me (Jeremiah 15:1). Otherwise, it must be believed that the prayers of Moses were heard when, interceding for the people, he said: If you forgive them their sin, forgive them; but if you do not want to, then erase me from the book you have written (Exodus 32:32, 33). But so that we may know that the intention of God towards His sons and servants is not for their destruction, but for their correction, let us listen to the testimonies of Scripture. Son, do not be discouraged by the discipline of the Lord, and do not grow weary when you are reproved by Him (Prov. 3:11). For the Lord corrects those whom He loves, and chastises every son whom He receives (Heb. 12:6). And in another place it is written: When He slew them, then they sought Him (Ps. 78:34). And in the Song of Deuteronomy: I will kill, and I will make alive (Deut. XII, 39). We can also say, according to the letter, that He has not destroyed them, nor consumed them with their posterity and progeny, but after killing the fathers, He spared the sons, whom He brought into the promised land.

<h2 id='tocuniq215'>(Vers. 18 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 18 seqq.) But I said to their children in the wilderness: Do not follow the commands (or laws) of your fathers, nor keep their judgments, nor be polluted by their idols (or thoughts). I am the Lord your God. Walk in my commands, and keep my judgments, and do them, and sanctify my Sabbaths, so that it may be a sign between me and you, and it may be known (or that you may know) that I am the Lord your God. After the killing of the fathers who fell in the wilderness, he gives instructions to the sons, in whose salvation the fathers had mercy. And he said, 'The eye of the Lord has spared them so as not to completely destroy and erase them, but to reserve the fathers in the sons.' And he testifies the same things that he spoke to the fathers, so that after they have walked in his instructions and kept his judgments, and have reserved the sanctification of the Sabbath, which is a sign given, then they will know that he is their Lord God. However, the precepts and legitimate practices of the fathers and their judgments signify an unusual error: that they should not imitate the sins of those whose torments they witness.

<h2 id='tocuniq216'>(Vers. 21, 22.)</h2>

(Verse 21, 22.) And my children have angered me, they have not walked in my commandments, and they have not kept my judgments, to do the things that when a man does them, he shall live in them, and they have violated my sabbaths. And I threatened to pour out my fury upon them, and to fulfill my anger against them in the wilderness. But I turned my hand, and I acted for the sake of my name, so that it would not be violated before the nations from whom I expelled them in their sight. But the sons, he said, followed in the footsteps of their parents, and they did everything that they had done: therefore they deserved a similar sentence; but for the same reasons by which I had mercy on their fathers, they were saved by the greatness of my mercy, and for the same causes for which I had mercy on their fathers: so that as the one and same Creator of both, I could mitigate my anger with the patience of similarity. We have gone through the obvious, and we have transitioned to the more obscure.

<h2 id='tocuniq217'>(Vers. 23, 24 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 23, 24 onward) Again I raised my hand against them in the wilderness, to scatter them among the nations and disperse them in the lands, because they had not observed my judgments and had rejected my commandments and violated my Sabbaths, and their eyes had been turned towards the idols or thoughts of their fathers. Therefore, I also gave them statutes that were not good and judgments by which they could not live; I defiled them with their own gifts when they offered or passed through everything that opens the womb because of their sins (for which the Septuagint translated, to destroy them and what they had neglected). And they shall know that I am the Lord. Where in the Old Testament, when the Lord stretched out his hand to scatter their children who had fallen in the wilderness, Scripture does not say, but we must believe that it happened as is here related. Or does this mean that after they entered the promised land, at different times and for many sins, they were handed over to various nations and kings, and during that time the commandments of the Lord which were by nature good and the judgments in which believers could live, were not good for them, since they were not able to keep the commandments of the law in captivity and to do what the divine word commanded. Nor did he say, 'I gave them evil precepts,' but 'not good.' For it does not immediately follow that what is not good is evil, as the Apostle teaches: it is good for a man not to touch a woman, but because of incontinence let each man have his own wife in sanctification and chastity (I Cor. VII). If he does not do this, it is neither good nor evil. Therefore, God gave them, dispersed among the nations, not good precepts, that is, He let them follow their own thoughts and desires to do things that are not fitting. And he defiles them in his gifts, just as a priest separates lepers from the people and shows that they are defiled; while they offer to idols what they should offer to God. And they pass through every opening of the womb by fire to Baal, that is, their firstborn; so that after they have been deserted by God and handed over to the worship of idols, then they may understand that He is the Lord, whom they have provoked to anger by their own fault. This place was more clearly interpreted by Symmachus, putting the future in place of the past. Therefore, I will also give them statutes that are not good and judgments by which they will not live. I will defile them by their own gifts, by causing every firstborn to pass through the fire, so that I may make them desolate and they will know that I am the Lord. The meaning is this: Because I saw the sons of the fathers being equal to their wickedness and doing the same things for which they had offended God, I desired to divide them into nations and scatter them throughout the whole world, and to give them statutes that are not good and judgments by which they will not live, in order to defile them with their own gifts. They were consecrating everything that opens the womb to idols, and I wanted to destroy them completely so that they would know that I am the Lord. Through these things he shows that he did not give them good commandments who were dwelling in the wilderness, but those whom he wanted to scatter among the nations and make foreigners in the whole world, he gave them commands which he did not give: so that there, by their own fault, they would do good commandments of God which were not good, while they exhibit to idols what God had commanded to be exhibited to himself. This can also be said, that before the offense, they only received the Ten Commandments; but after idolatry, they also received multiplied ceremonies of the law, so that they would rather offer victims to God which they were offering to demons, and by comparison with sacrilege, it became lighter what was not inherently good, and by no means evil, because it was offered to God, and yet not good, because they had offended the author of good.


<h2 id='tocuniq218'>(Vers. 27, 29 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 27, 29 onwards) Therefore speak to the house of Israel, son of man, and you shall say to them: Thus says the Lord God: Even in this they have blasphemed me, your fathers, when they have despised me and rejected me, and I had brought them into the land over which I had raised my hand to give them ((the Vulgate adds 'it')). They saw every high hill and every leafy tree, and there they offered their sacrifices, and there they provoked me with their offerings, and there they placed the fragrance of their sweetness, and there they poured out ((the Vulgate is silent on 'there')) their libations. And I said to them, 'What is the high place to which you go?' And its name was called the high place until this day. Therefore speak to the house of Israel, son of man, and say to them, 'Thus says the Lord God: "Your fathers have provoked Me to anger with their deeds, which they have committed against Me; and I have brought them into the land which I swore to give them, which is flowing with milk and honey, and it is the glory of all lands." And they saw every high hill and every thick tree, and there they offered their sacrifices. There they presented the provocation of their offering; there they also made their soothing aroma and poured out their drink offerings.' And I said to them: What is abba, that you enter there? And they called its name abba until this day. I wanted, he says, to scatter them in the wilderness, to disperse them to all the nations, and to give them not good precepts, so that they would sacrifice to idols what they should have offered to me, and consecrate all their firstborn to them through fire, so that I would kill them and wipe them out. But when he says, 'I wanted,' he shows that he did not do what he wanted. And that which follows, 'And they shall know that I am the Lord', is not found in the Septuagint. For it did not seem fitting to them that it should be known after the killing, that he himself is the Lord. But you, son of man, speak again to them, that is, to the elders of the house of Israel, who have come to inquire of you: Your fathers, of whose descent you are, have also blasphemed against me in this, and have regarded it as nothing; after I had brought them into the land which I had given them to possess, which I had given them to possess, they turned it into a provocation against me. For when they saw every high hill and leafy tree, they would sacrifice on the mountains and in the groves and thickets, and offer victims to idols and pour out libations. When I saw this, I said to them, 'What is this, Bama?' (which is translated as high place). Why do you go to such a place that you have chosen for yourselves on all the hills, so that to this day it is called Bamoth, and the ancient error holds the original name? For Bama, which we translate as 'high place,' there is an error in the Septuagint edition, where it is written as ἀββανὰ, which means nothing in Hebrew. Bama (), if you divide the word into two syllables, can mean 'in which,' but in this context, that sense does not fit. However, wherever it is written in the books of Kings and Chronicles: 'The people still sacrificed and made offerings at the high places,' Bama in the singular and Bamoth () in the plural mean 'high places.'


<h2 id='tocuniq219'>(Vers. 30, 31.)</h2>

(Verse 30, 31.) Therefore say to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord God (the Vulgate adds 'Certainly'): By the way of your fathers you are defiled, and after their abominations you commit adultery. And in offering your gifts, when you pass your children through the fire, you defile yourselves with all your idols to this day. Shall I answer you, O house of Israel? As I live, says the Lord God, I will not answer you. You imitate the vices of your fathers and walk in the same paths, so that similar sins may deserve similar punishment. And you have advanced to such an extent in wickedness that you consecrate your children to demons through fire: and it is not enough to have done this once, but you continue to do the same even now. Not because the elders do these things in captivity, but because those who dwell in Jerusalem and to whom captivity threatens do not cease to do all these things. And when you are bound by so many sins, you seek my response? As I live, says the Lord God, I will not answer you, and what follows:

<h2 id='tocuniq220'>(Vers. 32, 33.)</h2>

(Verse 32, 33.) And the thought of your mind will not be, saying, we will be like the nations, and like the kindred of the earth, to worship wood and stones. As I live, says the Lord God, surely with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, and with outpoured wrath, I will reign over you. This is the meaning: Do not think that your thoughts, by which you blaspheme against me, can be fulfilled; for it is said: We do not want to be under the Lord, nor to be called his people; but like all nations in the whole world, and every nation lives according to its own will, to worship wood and stones, and to serve idols, even we will be one nation among many.
