To which God responds, and swears by Himself, saying: I will not forsake you nor despise you, as negligent and fleeting servants of a master often despise, but I will restore you to my rule, with my arm outstretched and striking, with fury unleashed, and I will bring you back to your former servitude, and I will reign over you: whether you want it or not, you will have me as your king, and you will feel the wrath of the king, whose clemency you have neglected.

<h2 id='tocuniq221'>(Vers. 34.)</h2>

(Verse 34.) And I will bring you out from the peoples, and gather you from the lands where you were scattered: with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, and with poured-out wrath I will reign over you. I will not allow you to be among the nations, nor be held captive forever, but I will bring you out from the peoples and gather you from the lands where hostile necessity has dispersed you to serve. However, I will do this not to destroy and annihilate you, but to be your king. From this we understand that they also call the cruelty of the Creator the mercy: while he is angry and rages and pours out his whole fury, in order to draw them back to his kingdom, who have chosen to serve the tyranny of the demons.

<h2 id='tocuniq222'>(Vers. 35, 36, seq.)</h2>

(Verse 35, 36, etc.) And I will bring you into the wilderness of the peoples, and I will judge you there face to face. As I contended with your fathers in the wilderness of the land of Egypt, so I will contend with you, declares the Lord. And I will subject you to my scepter, and I will bring you into the bond of the covenant, and I will choose from among you transgressors and wicked ones: I will bring them out from their dwelling place, and they shall not enter the land of Israel, and you shall know that I am the Lord. Thus says the Lord: I will make for those of you who are in Babylon, and now serve idols, what I did for your fathers in Egypt, that I will lead you into the desert of the peoples, and there I will judge with you face to face, just as I contended with them in judgment when they came out of Egypt. And after I have judged you, I will subjugate you with my scepter and authority, and I will make a covenant with you, and bring you into your own land in the bonds of love, so that bound by my love, you cannot turn away from me. But I will choose from among you the transgressors and the wicked, who persist in the hardness of their hearts in evil deeds, not for possession, but for rejection. And I will indeed bring them out of the land of their dwelling, so that when they are brought out, they may not enter the land of Israel; but they shall perish in various regions. And by the distinction between good and evil, you shall know that I am the Lord, who does all things with judgment. The rest of the prayer hastens, and we briefly go through each thing, so that we may provide only the meaning to those who read.


<h2 id='tocuniq223'>(Vers. 39.)</h2>

(Verse 39.) And you, house of Israel, thus says the Lord God: Each one of you, walk after your idols and serve them. But if you will not listen to me in this, and you will profane my holy name further in your gifts and in your idols. LXX: And you, house of Israel, thus says Adonai the Lord: Each one of you, take away your inventions, and after this, if you will listen to me and not profane my holy name further in your gifts and in your pursuits. Symmachus has interpreted this place more clearly: Each person going to his own idols, serve, because you did not want to hear me: but do not pollute my holy name with your offerings and statues. But on my holy mountain, on the lofty mountain of Israel, says the Lord God, there all the house of Israel will serve me. Symmachus' translation has this meaning: Since you do not want to serve me, go and serve idols, and trample the footsteps of your statues. For you do not wish to listen to me, that you may not offer sacrifices to me, nor burn incense, nor call yourselves my people. For my worshipers do not serve me in the places of light, and temples, and idols, as you do: but on my holy mountain, on the lofty mountain of Israel. Moreover, the Septuagint explains the meaning. Abandon your former thoughts, and remove the sins of evil inventions: and if you listen to me after this, and do not defile my name in your offerings and idols, then you shall offer sacrifices to me on my holy mountain, and all the house of Israel shall serve me. But the eagle, truly agreeing with Symmachus in part, disagrees in part: Go, he says, after your idols, and serve them, because you are unworthy of my rule, and your worship does not please me. But if you will not even hear me in this, but you will defile my holy name, while pretending to offer to me what you offer to idols, and you make blasphemy only against my name, so that you who are worshippers of idols claim to be mine; know this, that on my holy mountain, on the lofty mountain of Israel, there all the house of Israel will serve me, not you who serve idols: but all the house of Israel that will believe after.


<h2 id='tocuniq224'>(Vers. 40, 41.)</h2>

(Verse 40, 41.) But on my holy mountain, on the mountain of the height of Israel, says the Lord God, there all the house of Israel shall serve me: all, I say, in the land where they shall please me, and there I will require your first fruits, and the beginning of your tithes, in all your sanctifications: I will receive you with a sweet odor, when I shall have brought you out from the people, and gathered you out of the lands into which you were scattered, and I will be sanctified in you in the sight of the nations: and you shall know that I am the Lord. About this mountain on which the whole house of Israel will serve God, Isaiah and Micah sang with the same voice: In the last days the mountain of the house of the Lord will be manifest on the top of the mountains, and it will be raised up above the hills, and all nations will flow to it, and many peoples will come and say: Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, and to the house (or mountain) of the God of Jacob, and he will teach us his ways, and we will walk in his paths. For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem (Isaiah 2 seq.; Micah 4:1-2). And again Isaiah says: 'Ascend to the high mountain, you who proclaim Zion; lift up your voice with strength, you who bring good news to Jerusalem' (Isaiah 40). By this mountain, we understand either the Church, which is interpreted as a "watchtower" and is established on the heights of holy teachings, or the Lord Himself, the Savior, in whom the firstfruits, tithes, and all offerings are transformed into a sweet-smelling aroma. So that all nations around, seeing that the people of the Lord are saved, may glorify God and recognize those who have been saved, that He is the Lord.


<h2 id='tocuniq225'>(Vers. 42.)</h2>

(Verse 42) When I bring you into the land of Israel, the land that I raised my hand to give to your fathers, then you will know that I am the Lord. This is the land that your fathers lost because of their own fault, and you, not on your own merit, but by my mercy, have received.

<h2 id='tocuniq226'>(Vers. 43, 44.)</h2>

(Verses 43, 44.) And you shall remember your ways and all your sins with which you have defiled yourselves; and you shall be displeased with yourselves in your own sight for all the evils that you have committed. And you shall know that I am the Lord, when I deal with you for the sake of my name, not according to your evil ways and corrupt deeds, O house of Israel, says the Lord God. We cannot remember our sins and vices unless we are led into the land of Israel, and there placed we may say with the Apostle: I am not worthy to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God (I Corinthians 15:9). And you will displease, he says, in your own sight in all your evils which you have done. As Symmachus interpreted. And you will appear little to yourselves because of all your evils which you have worked (Jacob. IV), so that after they have become distinguished, they may believe themselves to be humble: because the Lord gives grace to the humble. And in another place it is written: Before contrition, the heart of a man will be exalted, and before height, it will be humiliated (Prov. XVIII, 12). For the breaking of pride is humility, and exaltation follows. And you shall know that I am the Lord, when I do good to you. And we come to know the Lord our Savior more when He does good to us, and when He suffers for our sins, and bears our iniquities, and grieves for us; not for any merit of those who are saved, but for the sake of His name. Otherwise, our ways and most wicked crimes have not deserved mercy, but punishment. But whatever we have said about the people of Israel, who were freed from Egypt, committed many sins in the desert, and offended God, and later were led into the promised land, worshipped idols, wood and stones, and were preserved by the mercy of God: let us recount to those who were freed from Egypt by the mighty hand of the Lord in this age, and led into the wilderness of vices, they again sighed for Egypt, and did the things for which they deserved to be punished: but nevertheless, they were preserved not by their own merit, but by the mercy of the Lord through repentance.


<h2 id='tocuniq227'>Book Seven</h2>

Book Seven

239-240. Once we read as boys: Nothing is so easy, that it does not become difficult when you do it unwillingly. I confess that I promised explanations in Ezekiel a long time ago, and due to the occupation of those coming from all over the world, I cannot fulfill them. For there is no hour, no moment, in which we do not encounter crowds of brothers and exchange the solitude of the monastery for the frequent presence of guests. To the extent that either we must close the door, or we must abandon the study of the Scriptures, through which the doors are opened. Therefore, during profitable, or rather stolen, hours of the night, which have become longer with winter approaching, we attempt to dictate these things in whatever manner to a small lamp, and to alleviate the weariness of a restless mind through interpretation. We do not boast, as some may suspect, of receiving the brotherhood, but we simply confess the reasons for our delay: especially since the flight of the Westerners and the congestion of holy places surpass the rage of the Barbarians in both nudity and the wounds of the needy. Because we cannot see without tears and groaning, that former power and ignorance of wealth have come to such poverty that she needs a roof, food, and clothing; and yet the hard and cruel minds of some are in no way softened while they cast off their little cloths and bags, seeking gold in captivity. This difficulty of dictation is added to, that with eyes dimmed by old age, and sustaining something blessed Isaac (Gen. XXVII), we are unable to read Hebrew volumes by the light of the night, which are also blinded to us by the smallness of the letters even by the brightness of the sun and day. But we only know the commentaries of the Greeks through the voices of the brothers. There is no doubt that they cause nausea to those who eat food chewed by someone else's teeth. Therefore, I beg you, daughter Eustochium, to begin with those things which we write with the pen of notaries and for which we hardly have time to correct, that is, the seventh. And as I have already said, if the brevity or length of the books are unequal to each other, attribute the brevity or length to the visions, or rather to the hypotheses, since we do not want to separate what is joined together and to compress discord into a single mass." }


<h2 id='tocuniq228'>(Vers. 45 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 45 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, turn your face towards the way of the South, and drop towards the South wind, and prophesy against the forest of the South field. And say to the forest of the South: Hear the word of the Lord: thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will kindle a fire in you, and it will burn up every green tree and every dry tree in you. The flame of the fire will not be quenched, and it will consume every face from the South to the North. And all flesh shall see that I, the Lord, have kindled it; it shall not be quenched. And I said, ah, ah, ah, O Lord God; they say of me, Does he not speak in parables? LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying, Son of man, set your face against Theman, and look towards Darom, and prophesy against the forest of the south field, and say to the forest of the south field, Hear the word of the Lord, thus says the Lord: Behold, I will kindle a fire in you, and it shall devour every green tree in you, and every dry tree. The kindled flame will not be extinguished, and it will burn in it all faces from south to north: and all flesh will know that I, the Lord, have kindled it: it will not be extinguished. And I said: Certainly not, Lord, Lord: they say to me: Is it not a parable that is spoken? What does 'put' or 'harden your face' mean, above we have spoken more fully. For by the hardening of the face and the hardness of the forehead, the Prophet needs to speak boldly, especially when sad tidings have been announced to the entire multitude of the people. But our translation has expressed what they said, that 'Nageb' better conveys the meaning of 'leader' in Hebrew, or more specifically, of the southern region. For it is not 'Sare' (), as the LXX mistakenly thought, which means 'leader' or 'prince', but it is written as 'Sade', which properly signifies 'field' or 'region', and because of the similarity between the letters 'Daleth' and 'Res', the error has persisted. Now the divine word speaks metaphorically of the leap against Jerusalem, which is the dwelling place of beasts and fierce men. It sets it on fire and all its wood will be consumed, not calling them trees that needed fruits, but wood prepared for the fire. And first it burns the green wood in it, secondly what we read in this same Prophet: 'Begin with my holy ones'; and afterwards the dry wood, which could not have any life in itself, namely the saints and sinners together, so that some may escape the evils of captivity by death, and others may be handed over to eternal punishments. And what it implies: From the South to the North, this indicates from Jerusalem to Babylon: so that the complete journey of those going into captivity, falling by sword, famine, and pestilence. For those who are in Babylon, Jerusalem is situated to the South; just as in the case of the pot in Jeremiah which signifies Jerusalem, it is set on fire from the face of the North, that is, Babylon (Jerem. I). And beautifully in the beginning: a drop, he says, towards the West; so that the full wrath of God does not seem to be poured out, but rather a certain drop and part." } But if the drop of such cruelty is so great, what should be considered in all the rainstorms? That all flesh, which is going to witness the salvation of God, may recognize that He Himself is the Lord through the burning of the forests and the flame, which is not extinguished by any help. Understanding this, the Prophet responds, ah, ah, ah, O Lord God, or as the Seventy translators rendered it, by no means, O Lord, O Lord. And he adds: And they say to me: Does this man not speak in parables? And what is this parable called? And the meaning is: Speak more plainly, we do not understand what you are saying in a parable: reveal to us the meaning in clear language. However, Theman and Nageb and Darom can be understood tropologically, Egypt being referred to: for we read in Daniel that the south often signifies Egypt (Dan. XI), and Egypt is referred to the narrowness of this world. Therefore, Ezekiel prophesies the future evils that will come to the world, which he calls a desert, lacking fruit-bearing trees but inhabited by beasts. About which it is said in the 243rd Psalm: The voice of the Lord finishing the deer, and he will reveal the hidden things of the woods (Verse 9). These are the woods and groves that devoured more from the army of Absalom in battle than the sword killed (2 Kings 18). And in the groves is first kindled a green wood, and then a dry one, symbolizing those who live in evil and those who have died to righteousness. And what is said: And every face will be burned from the south to the north, this means: From those who seemed to be fervent in spirit to those who, with the increasing iniquity and the cooling of the love of many, have lost their former warmth; so that all flesh may see the flame of the Lord not extinguished. And the prophet prays that what the Lord has threatened may not happen: that is, that the forest may not be set on fire and all the trees may not be consumed; so that either they may still have the opportunity for repentance, or they may not be compelled to announce sorrowful things to themselves, especially since the people do not understand them, and by the obscurity of his words, are rather provoked to madness.

<h2 id='tocuniq229'>(Cap. XXI.—Vers. 1 seq.)</h2>

(Chapter 21, Verses 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face towards Jerusalem and drop [tears] towards the sanctuaries, and prophesy against the land of Israel, and say to the land of Israel: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, and I will unsheathe my sword out of its sheath and will kill both the righteous and the wicked in you. Because I will kill both the righteous and the wicked in you, therefore my sword shall go out of its sheath against all flesh, from the south to the north." } And all flesh shall know that I am the Lord, for I have drawn my sword from its sheath forever. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Therefore, prophesy, son of man, and make your face strong against Jerusalem, and look towards their holy places, and prophesy against the land of Israel, and say to the land of Israel: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, and I will draw my sword from its sheath, and I will cut off from you the wicked and the unjust. Thus my sword shall go forth from its sheath over all flesh from the South to the North, and all flesh shall know that I, the Lord, have drawn my sword from its sheath: it shall not return again. For it was said above: They say of me, 'Does he not speak in parables?' and the people demanded a clear explanation. Therefore, what the Lord spoke in metaphor or parable, and as others translate it, a proverb, 244 is now spoken more openly: that the Nageb and Darom and Theman are Jerusalem, and its temple, the Holy of Holies, and the whole land of Judah; and the flame which will consume the wilderness is understood as the sword that devours, which has been drawn from its sheath to destroy the righteous and the wicked. For this is a green wood and a dry wood. Hence also the Lord: If they do these things in a green wood, what will they do in the dry? (Luke 23:31). Concerning this, I do not know what they wanted, the Seventy interpreted unfairly and unjustly, as if both did not mean the same thing. And what he had said there: And all flesh shall see, that I the Lord have kindled it, that is, the forest or the flame, and it shall not be quenched, he speaks in other words here: So that all flesh may know, that I the Lord have drawn my sword out of its sheath and it shall not be put back again. Truly, there is no fire extinguished against Jerusalem, nor an extinguished fire, nor a recalled sword, because there is little time in between, and Jerusalem with its temple was set on fire by the Babylonian flame.

<h2 id='tocuniq230'>(Vers. 6, 7.)</h2>

(Vers. 6, 7.) And you, son of man, groan with broken loins, and groan with bitterness before them. And when they say to you, 'Why do you groan?' you shall say: 'Because of the hearing, for it comes, and every heart shall faint, and all hands shall be weakened, and every spirit shall be weakened, and water shall flow through all knees.' Behold, it comes and shall be done, says the Lord (Vulgate adds God). LXX: And you, son of man, groan with broken loins, and groan in pains before them. And if they say to you, 'Why do you moan?' you shall say, 'Because of the news that has come. Every heart will faint and all hands will hang limp; every spirit will become weak and every knee will turn to water.' Surely it is coming and it will be fulfilled, declares the Lord God. First he said, 'Prophesy, or drop as a dew, to the South, to the South-West and to the South-East; and to the extreme South.' Because it seemed obscure, and the people did not understand the words of the prophet, it is further clarified, that the extreme South refers to Jerusalem, and all the unfruitful trees, on whose roots the axe is placed, symbolize its inhabitants; and the sword is interpreted as fire. Thirdly, the prophet is commanded, while they remain silent and do not ask, to do those things by which he may be questioned, and to respond what the Lord has spoken. 'Groan,' he says, 'wail with a loud voice, not with moderate grief, but with contrition of the loins, so that your groaning may be brought forth from the depths of your bowels and the bitterness of your soul. And you shall do this before them, so that when they have asked you why you are worn out with so much groaning, and what evil has befallen you that you moan thus, you may respond to them in my words: Therefore, I mourn, and I cannot conceal the pain of my heart, because the hearing that always resounded in my ears is being fulfilled by action and comes to pass: namely, the impending army of the raging Babylonians.' When he comes and surrounds Jerusalem, then all hearts will faint and all hands will be dissolved, so that, with fear seizing the minds of men, no one will dare to resist. For the spirit of all warriors will be weakened, and such great trepidation and fear will occupy everyone, so that, with fear compelling them, their limbs and intestines will dissolve, and the bladder will not be able to hold urine: so that urine will pollute the knees. For it is natural, when fear compels, for the bladder to relax, and humor to flow contrary to the will of man. Indeed, this often happens in the severity of illnesses, that after the strength of the sick has failed, not only their knees, but also their beds are soiled. Look, he says, it is happening as I have often foretold, and it is being accomplished and will be done, not by me, but by the Lord who spoke. I know someone who, in the bending of the loins and flowing waters, has recounted many testimonies, so that the purity of the prophets may be fulfilled, and the bitterness of the soul and the internal pain of the mind, that the waters of the seeds may soil the knees. But this explanation does not pertain to the current place.

<h2 id='tocuniq231'>(Vers. 8 seqq.)</h2>

(V. 8 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy and say: Thus says the Lord God, speak: A sword, a sharpened sword, and polished, to slaughter victims, it has been sharpened, and to shine, it has been polished: you who wield the scepter of my son, you have cut down every tree. And I have given it to be polished, to be held in the hand: this sword has been sharpened, and this sword has been polished, to be in the hand of the one who kills. Cry out and howl, son of man, for this has happened among my people, even among all the princes of Israel. Those who fled have been delivered up to the sword along with my people. Therefore, clap your hands upon your thigh, for it has been proven, and when the scepter is overturned, it will no longer be, says the Lord God. As for you, son of man, you are a prophet, and strike your hand against your hand, and let the sword be doubled and tripled for the slayers. This is the sword of great slaughter, which causes them to be dumbfounded, and makes their hearts melt, and multiplies their ruins." } In all their gates I have set the disturbance of a sharp and polished sword to flash: clothed for slaughter. Sharpen, go to the right or to the left, wherever your face desires. Moreover, I will clap my hands hand to hand, and satisfy my indignation, I the Lord have spoken. It is much if I present both editions, and the length of the books is extended: especially where there is either no distance or a small one. Therefore, I will present some things that differ. For what we said: 'Whoever moves the scepter of my son, you have cut down all the wood,' they translated: 'Kill, despise, repel all wood.' Again, when we said: 'Those who had fled were handed over by the sword,' they and others translated: 'My guests, or residents.' And where we said: 'Applaud on the thigh,' they put: 'Strike with the hand.' And where we translated: 'And when he overturns this with the scepter, their edition is: It is rejected by the three.' But he speaks to the sword of Nebuchadnezzar, that it may come against Jerusalem, to be sharpened and polished, for many are to be slaughtered; and he addresses himself to it. You are the one who moves and overturns the scepter of my son, the kingdom of the people of Israel, and you cut down every tree, the entire multitude of the people. I have given, he says, that sword, to be held in the hand of Nebuchadnezzar; and let it be in the hand of the most powerful man. Therefore, O prophet, cry out and howl, and with the force of a mournful voice bear witness to the impending evils. This sword spared no one and left no one untouched by impending evils. It was made among the people, made among the leaders of Israel, made among my guests and priests who dwelled in my temple. Therefore, strike your thigh or your hand, and assume the attire of mourning. For this sword has been tested by me, and by it my scepter and kingdom will be overthrown, and it will not exist anymore. It will be concluded with King Zedekiah. Again, I command you, prophet, to strike the thigh, which you have struck before in astonishment and wonder, and also strike the hand, so that not only once, but a second and third time, the sword comes to kill. First, indeed, came Nebuchadnezzar when he took Jehoiachin; and secondly, when Joachim reigned for 247 years; thirdly, when Zedekiah reigned. And this is the tripled sword, when a great slaughter was made, and it multiplied ruins to such an extent that they were amazed in their minds and wasted away in their hearts, and gave confusion in all their gates. Therefore it is commanded to him, that is, with a sharp and polished sword to shine, and being clothed and unencumbered, and prepared for slaughter, to go either to the right or to the left. Whichever way, he says, your face pleases, boldly enter, having me as your leader, as your helper. I will clap hand to hand, as if I were your supporter and encourager, to urge you on against my adversaries who are raging against you. Do not hesitate, do not fear, and endure what Sennacherib has suffered: I am the Lord who spoke, you are the servant of my will, fulfill my command. We are able, according to the anagoge, to take up a sharp and prepared sword for the slaughter of the devil, about whom the Apostle says: Deliver such a one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved (1 Cor. 5:5). And in another place: Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme (1 Tim. 1:20). And in the Psalms it is written: He sent forth his anger and wrath and trouble, a mission by the agency of evil angels (Ps. 78:49). Some people think that this sword was in the hand of an angel when Jerusalem was struck under David (2 Kings 24). Others suspect that it refers to the sword mentioned in the Gospel: 'I did not come to bring peace but a sword' (Matthew 10:34), to divide all affection of kinship between them, so that the wicked may fall and the holy may rise. But it is wicked to believe this about the sword of the Savior, rather than about the devil, who overturns the scepters of the Lord in the Church, who kills everyone in the people, and the leaders, and the guests of God. And it is approved by the Lord when he overturns Judas the betrayer and his like (John 13). After he ate the morsel, Satan entered into him. And the sword of the killers is doubled and tripled, in order to release the sin of Jerusalem, because he has taken upon himself his double sins from the hand of the Lord. But the Lord rejoices and exults, and he encourages the raging sword to go either to the right or to the left, and wherever his desire takes it, so that the evil ones may be killed, and the good ones may remain, and that which is written may be fulfilled: What does chaff have to do with wheat? Thus says the Lord (Jeremiah 23:32).

<h2 id='tocuniq232'>(Vers. 18 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 18 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: And you, son of man, set yourself two ways, and let the sword of the king of Babylon come. From one land they shall both come out, and by his hand he shall take the lot: he shall throw it upon the head of the road of the city. You shall set a way for the sword to come to Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and to Judah, and to the fortified Jerusalem. For the king of Babylon stood in the fork of the road, seeking divination, mixing arrows. He consulted the idols, examined the entrails. To his right a divination was made concerning Jerusalem, so that he may set up battering rams, open the mouth in slaughter, raise the voice in howling, set up battering rams against the gates, heap up a siege ramp, build fortifications. And it will be as if consulting an oracle in vain in their eyes, and imitating the rest of the Sabbath, but he himself will remember the iniquity to capture. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because you have brought your iniquities to remembrance, and have revealed your transgressions, and your sins have appeared in all your thoughts; because, I say, you have brought them to remembrance, you will be captured by the hand. I know that in this place, according to the Septuagint interpreters, I have read a multifarious exposition of the law, referring to the people of the Gentiles: but Judah and Jerusalem to those who gather under the name of Christ, and by their deeds give honor to his name, with the devil, the king of confusion, standing at the head of every road, and plotting in secret; and they fulfill that verse: They have placed a stumbling block for me along the path (Psalm 139); and they make him stand at the crossroads, desiring to hold those who are his own or acquire new servitude for themselves; and to always proceed to the right, namely, those who are positioned on the right, in order to conquer them, to exult in slaughter, to capture miserable Jerusalem with rams and the accumulation of earthly works; and first of all, to appear to be doing nothing, and to strive in vain. But by recalling their iniquities, those who dwell in the Church, or rather, who bring adversaries to mind through evil deeds, expose all the sins of the people and their thoughts; and for this reason they are captured, because they have added new offenses to old ones. Another person may have said this, the truth of our history must be pursued. When, he said to me, the divine word had spoken: Prophet, son of man, speak to the sword and say: Sword, sword, and the rest that the prophecy of the sword contains; a second time the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Do you want, son of man, to know who this sword is, and to learn more clearly the persona of the raging sword? Listen to what I say: set up two roads, so that through them the sword of the king of Babylon may come, who will indeed go by one route of the Chaldeans, but when he comes through the desert and wilderness to the crossroads of the land of Arabia, which is called the land of the Ammonites, one road leads to Jerusalem on the right side, but the other to Rabbath of the Ammonites, which is the capital city and is today called Philadelphia. He said, remember the massacre that happened to the Assyrian king when one hundred and eighty-five thousand were killed in one night; he will fear to turn to the right and go against the highly fortified Jerusalem. But he will stand at the crossroads and consult the oracle of his people's customs, to send his arrows into the quiver and mix them, whether inscribed or marked with the names of individuals, so that he may see which arrow comes out and which city he should attack first. The Greeks call this βελομαντία, or ῥαβδομαντία. So the idols were asked questions and the entrails were consulted. The divination turned to the right, indicating that they should march against Jerusalem, besiege it, build up ramparts, set up battering rams, construct fortifications, enclose the city, open their mouths in slaughter, and stir up the shouting and howling of a triumphant army. By doing this, he said, the inhabitants of Jerusalem will appear to consult the oracle in vain; and as if wasting the Sabbath rest, they will play, of course, and accomplish nothing. But the king of Babylon, not relying on his own strength, but on the iniquity of the people, which he knows has offended God, and has accumulated sins upon sins, and all their transgressions have been exposed; and therefore he will not doubt his victory, because he trusts in the wickedness of Jerusalem. These things, according to the Hebrew text, differ from the Septuagint not so much in meaning as in wording in many places.

<h2 id='tocuniq233'>(Vers. 25 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 25 and following) 250 But you, profane and wicked leader of Israel, whose day has come at the appointed time of injustice. This is what the Lord God says: Remove the turban, take off the crown. Is this not the one who exalted the lowly and humbled the exalted? I will bring iniquity upon iniquity upon iniquity, and this will not happen until the one whose judgment it is comes and I will deliver it to him. Septuagint: And you, profane and unjust leader of Israel, whose day has come at the end of the time of injustice. Thus says the Lord God: You have removed the crown and set it aside. This will not be the same. You have humbled the exalted and lifted up the lowly. I will bring upon her iniquity, iniquity, and this will not be so until the one to whom it belongs comes: and I will give it to him. Symmachus interpreted this passage as follows: But you, profane and unjust ruler of Israel, whose day has come at the appointed time of iniquity: Thus says the Lord God: He has removed the crown and taken it: neither this nor that: he will lift up the lowly and humble the exalted. I will bring iniquity upon it, I will bring iniquity upon it, I will bring iniquity upon it. And it was not this one, whose judgment it is, whom I will give. After the destruction and captivity of the city of Jerusalem and of the people, the speech is directed to the leader of Israel, whom no one doubts is signified as Zedekiah, in whom the kingship of Israel from the lineage of David is ended. The day has come to you, it says, which has been appointed for a long time in you, and because of you the priesthood and kingdom of the people of Judah has perished. For the mitre is the distinctive sign of the Pope, that is, the crown or diadem, the symbol of a king. Is this not the mitre, and this the crown, which has done nothing by judgment; but in imitation of the king of Babylon, whom he wished to exalt and whom he wished to humble? Therefore, not once, nor twice according to the Septuagint, but for a third time I will place before you wickedness forever, which was not immediately reckoned to you, but until Christ comes, whose judgment it is, and the Father gives him the kingdom and the priesthood, or the Church gathered from the nations. For the Father does not judge anyone, but he has given all judgment to the Son (John 5:22). And in another place: 'Give your judgement to the king, O God, and your justice to the son of a king' (Ps. LXXI, 1). This is the one to whom authority and eternal priesthood have been entrusted, of whom Jacob spoke: 'The ruler shall not fail from Juda, nor the leader from his thigh, till he come that is to be sent, and he shall be the expectation of nations' (Gen. XLIX, 10). In the place where we have interpreted it: 'Is not this,' translated Symmachus excellently, 'whether this or that.' For as He had said, 'Take away the diadem, remove the crown,' He added, 'Neither this nor that,' that is, the kingdom will not cease and neither will the priesthood. Therefore, those who were kings and priests after that until the coming of Christ, one of whom was the high priest Hyrcanus who placed the diadem on his head in vain sought to claim both this and that when the kingdom was not owed to him after Zedekiah, but to the one to whom it was entrusted, and who was the expectation of the nations, of whom Malachi speaks, 'You priests who defile my name' (Malachi 1:6). And after a little while: It is not my will in you, and I will not accept victims from your hands. From the rising of the sun to its setting, my name is great among the nations, and in every place a clean offering is sacrificed and offered to my name. This clean offering, without the blood of goats, rams, and bulls (Ps. 49), is fulfilled in the coming of Christ, when he came as the long-awaited one for the nations, and the sun of righteousness rose, in whose wings there is healing (Haggai 2).


<h2 id='tocuniq234'>(Vers. 28 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 28 and following) And you, son of man, prophet, say: Thus says the Lord God to the sons of Ammon, and to their reproach. And you shall say: Sword, sword, unsheathe yourself for the purpose of killing; sharpen yourself to destroy and to shine. When they seemed to you to be empty and their divinations to be lies, in order that you may be given over upon the necks of the wicked butchers, whose day has come at the appointed time of iniquity. Return to your sheath, to the place where you were created: in the land of your birth I will judge you. And I will pour out my indignation upon you, in the fire of my wrath I will blow upon you, and I will give you into the hands of foolish people, and skillful craftsmen who will bring about destruction. You will be fuel for the fire; your blood shall be in the midst of the earth. You will be forgotten, for I the Lord have spoken. The sword of the king of Babylon stood at the head of the two roads, at the fork in the road, where one led to Jerusalem and the other to Rabbath of the Ammonites. He consulted the oracle, and it was determined to go to Jerusalem first, as we read above. After it has been attacked and captured, it declares that his kingdom and priesthood have also been destroyed forever. The remaining portion belonged to the sons of Ammon, and even their division demanded what had been done on the left-hand side. Hence the prophet is commanded to speak to the sons of Ammon, and to their disgrace, that they themselves may be captured and the same sword directs its discourse: O sword, sword, you who are prepared for slaughter, who are polished so as to shine and kill; although idols may have responded to you, and everything that is answered by demons is vain, that is, in order that you may threaten the necks of the wounded, and through you may accomplish what the Lord had threatened long before; nevertheless, after completing your work, which you have done against the sons of Ammon, return to your sheath, that is, to Babylon, to the place where you were made and created: so that in the land of your birth I may judge you, and pour out my indignation upon you, and you may be captured by the power of the Medes and Persians. That which is said more fully in the book of Isaiah, in the vision against Babylon: Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them. And after a little while: And Babylon, that glorious city among kingdoms, that renowned city of the Chaldeans, shall be like when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah: it shall never be inhabited, neither shall it be settled from generation to generation (Isa. 13:17-22). And because once he spoke in the person of the sword concerning the king, or rather the kingdom of Babylon, he preserves the metaphor. In the fire, he says, of my wrath I will breathe upon you; so that I may consume you with fire, and deliver you into the hands of stupid and foolish men, who have no skill in forging swords and sharpening them; so that you shall no longer be sharpened, polished, and shining for slaying; but you shall be the food of fire, and your blood, which you poured out before all who watched, shall rather abound in you; and you shall be consigned to eternal oblivion, and shall perish forever, for I the Lord have spoken, whose word, once spoken, is fulfilled.


<h2 id='tocuniq235'>(Cap. XXII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 22, Verses 1 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: And you, son of man, do you not judge the city of blood, and show her all her abominations? And you shall say: Thus says the Lord God: The city that sheds blood within herself, that her time may come, and that makes idols against herself to defile herself. In your blood that you have shed, you have become guilty, and in your idols that you have made, you have defiled yourself, and you have brought near your days, and have come to your years; therefore I have made you a reproach to the nations, and a mockery to all the countries. Those who are near and those who are far from you will triumph over you (or mock you), you sordid noble, great in destruction. Behold, the princes of Israel, each with his own arm, were in you to shed blood. They have treated father and mother with contempt in you (or cursed father and mother). They have slandered the stranger among you. They have troubled (or oppressed) the orphan and the widow among you. You have despised my sanctuaries (or you have rejected and defiled), you have profaned my Sabbaths. There were detractors (or thieves) in you to shed blood, and they ate on the mountains in you. They committed a crime (or, as it is more significant in Hebrew, Zemma, that is, incest) in your midst. They uncovered the more shameful things of their father in you, and they humiliated the filthiness of menstruating women in you, and each one committed an abomination with the wife of his neighbor, and the father-in-law defiled his daughter-in-law wickedly. He oppressed (or humiliated) his own sister, the daughter of his own father, in you. They accepted bribes from you to shed blood. You received interest and excessive profits, and greedily slandered your neighbors (or and I will complete the full measure of your wickedness in your oppression); you have forgotten me, says the Lord God. Behold, I will clap my hands on your greed that you have committed, and on the blood that has been shed in your midst. Will your heart endure, or will your hands prevail in the days that I will bring upon you? I the Lord have spoken, and I will do it. I will disperse you among the nations and scatter you among the countries, and I will put an end to your uncleanness. And I will possess you in the sight of the nations, and you shall know that I am the Lord. And you, he said, son of man (for I will use the customary term with you), judge the city of bloodshed, and show her all her abominations, so that she may know that she is deserving of imminent captivity and has brought upon herself the time of her ruin with much bloodshed. Firstly, among all your sins, you have worshipped idols instead of God; and you have defiled the works of your hands, and have hastened the coming of the years that were spoken of for a long time and delayed, in order to bring about repentance. But you, according to your unrepentant heart, store up wrath for yourself on the day of wrath (Romans II). Therefore, I have made you a disgrace among the nations and a mockery in all the lands that surround you, both near and far. They will triumph over you and mock you. You are filthy, noble, and great in your destruction. Filthy, because you have ceased to be pure. Noble in evil, you who once surpassed all cities in nobility in righteousness. Great destruction: the higher you were, the more strongly you fell. And in the meantime, without mentioning other things, I will mention a few that were in you. Your leaders, judging not by justice but by the strength and might of their arm, shed innocent blood in you. Others dishonored their father and mother, either by cursing or speaking ill of their parents, as Scripture says: Whoever curses father or mother must be put to death (Exodus 21:17). They oppressed the foreigner and the stranger in your midst, as if their journey and exile from their homeland were not enough for them. They distressed and oppressed the orphan and the widow, as if those whose whole estate is in the justice of the law should not only be distressed but also oppressed by you. You have despised my sanctuaries, or holy things, and you have defiled my Sabbaths, so that you do not distinguish between that which is holy and that which is profane, between the appointed day of religion and the rest of the Sabbath for the worship of God, and the other days on which it is permitted by law to work and serve the needs of the flesh. Detractors, according to Symmachus and Theodotion, were deceitful, blaspheming God or committing all kinds of deceit or violence. They feasted on the high mountains, wise and proud, committing abominable acts of wickedness or incest in your midst. They did openly what is rarely done in secret corners, when evildoers try to avoid the prying eyes of conscious men. The following passage explains what incest is: They have exposed more shameful things before you, the father and stepmother having engaged in unlawful and immoral relations, and have humiliated the impurity of the menstruating woman within, not sparing nature and not granting respite to immorality, and clinging to the wife of their nearest relative. And what is even more heinous, the father-in-law has become inflamed with desire for his daughter-in-law, and the brother has disregarded the laws of his sister: he violated his sister not as a half-sister, but as one with the same father. They accepted gifts; to shed innocent blood. They turned the need of the poor into profit, to collect interest and excess; and because of greed, they slandered friends. But you have done this, oh Jerusalem, because you have forgotten me. For the memory of God excludes all wickedness. Therefore, I have taken on the appearance of an angry Lord, and I have clapped my hands against your greed, and against the blood that has been shed among you; so that you may understand and know, whether with your mind or with your hands, if I can bear anger. For I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will act. And after you have been captured, Jerusalem, I will scatter you among the nations and fan you away in the air, like useless chaff to be tossed here and there. Such is my mercy, that my cruelty may be turned into compassion. For I will do all things to remove your impurity from you, and to restore your former purity. And when you have received it, I will possess you in the sight of all the nations, so that when you are possessed by me, then you may understand that I am the Lord. But if we follow the interpretation of Symmachus and Theodotion, one of whom says, 'And I will wound you, or strike through:' the other, 'I will defile you before the Gentiles, and all things that are to be reported to an evil purpose:' although this is contrary to the meaning here given, which says above, 'And I will cause your uncleanness to cease from you.' For the ceasing of uncleanness is the restoration of purity. I have discussed both editions equally, in order to avoid the prolixity of the books.


<h2 id='tocuniq236'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 17 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, the house of Israel has become dross to me; all of them, bronze and tin and iron and lead in the midst of the furnace; they have become the dross of silver. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because you have all become dross, therefore behold, I will gather you into the midst of Jerusalem as silver and bronze and iron and tin and lead are gathered into the midst of the furnace, to blow the fire on it to melt it. So I will gather you in my fury, and in my wrath, and I will rest, and burn you, and I will set you on fire in the heat of my anger, and you will be melted in the midst of it, as silver is melted in the midst of a furnace: so you will be in the midst of it, and you will know that I am the Lord, when I have poured out my indignation upon you. The Hebrew word Sig (), Symmachus translates as scum, the first edition of Aquila translates as grape skin and grape stalk, both of which mean grape kernel. However, its second translation, and the Septuagint version, implies a mixture. Furthermore, scum, impurities, and waste of metals are meant; so that subsequently, with the neighboring captivity, or rather with the imminent destruction of the city, fire is applied: so that during the process of mixing, pure silver remains, which had been mixed and contaminated with copper, tin, iron, and lead: of which three, copper, tin, and lead, are fusible materials and are dissolved by fire. But indeed, iron between an anvil and a hammer becomes soft and thin, and takes on various shapes, according to the will of the craftsman. Just as silver, which the aforementioned metals have violated, is placed in a furnace, so that it remains pure after the impurities and foreign materials have been removed: so, he says, I will gather you in the midst of Jerusalem, and I will surround Babylon with siege, in order to kindle a fire in you for melting. And just as there the immense heat of flames makes [silver] into liquid, so hunger and pestilence will do here: so that after I have gathered you and set you on fire with the fire of fury, then I will rest, and I will alleviate the contempt of pain, and I will restrain your punishments by their finality. And I will do all this, so that after I have poured out my indignation on you, the end of your torment will be known to me: and you shall know that I am the Lord, the judge of all and the avenger. Moreover, what is said to be the blower, we read in many other places, but especially in Malachi and Isaiah, of whom one says: Behold, the Lord is coming forth like the fire of a blower and like the herb of washers, and he shall sit down blowing like gold and silver, and he shall blow the sons of Levi. Another [passage]: 'And the Lord will wash away the filth of the sons and daughters of Zion, and will cleanse the blood from their midst with the spirit of judgment and the spirit of burning' (Isaiah 4:4). And I believe it to sound like what is said in the Psalms: 'Examine me, O Lord, and try me' (Psalm 26:2). After which it is added: 'Burn my reins and my heart, so that all the harmful moisture of the loins, and their sins, may be dried up, and the covering that is placed upon [them]' (257). Let us understand about the state of souls, which were created pure by God: they have received gold in sense and wisdom, and silver in speech and eloquence, so that they may explain with words what they have conceived in their mind. Concerning silver, we read: The words of the Lord are pure words: silver tried by fire, purified seven times (Psalm 12:6). Likewise, the sixty-seventh psalm contains about gold and silver, where it is written: If ye have slept among the midst of lots, the wings of a dove, covered with silver, and her hinder parts in the paleness of gold (Psalm 77:14). For all the glory of the king's daughter inwards (Psalm 44:14), who speaks in the Song of Songs: The king has brought me into his chamber (Song of Songs 1:3). And whoever sleeps and rests between the two Testaments, immediately assumes the silver wings of a dove and shines with the brightness of gold in the treasure of his heart. I believe that this should be understood in the sense that heaven is brass and earth is iron for sinners and those who have earned the wrath of God, especially the land of Egypt, from which the Lord brought forth Israel, as if from an iron furnace. In Zacharia also wickedness sits upon a talent of lead (Zech. 5). And in the song of Exodus it is said: They sank like lead in the violent water (Exod. 15, 10). For they were weighed down by the heavy burden of sins, and they could say: Heavy burdens have been placed upon me (Ps. 38, 6). And just as the appearance of gold disguises the adulterous nature of brass, so does tin imitate the whiteness of silver, which the simple and rustic person cannot easily discern. And it often happens that gold and silver mixed with heretical wickedness are separated by the fire of the Holy Spirit and the judgment of the Lord, and pure gold remains, and silver, of which the prophet says: I gave them silver and gold; but they made Baal from them (Hosea II, 8). Similar to this is: I brought them out in silver and gold, and there was no weak one among their tribes (Psalm CV, 37): and may the end of all punishments be to know that He Himself is the Lord. We have interpreted what the stone of tin, or tin mass, signifies in its proper place, as we read in Zachariah (Zech. IV).

<h2 id='tocuniq237'>(Vers. 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, say to him: You are unclean earth, not washed on the day of fury. The conspiracy of the prophets in its midst, like a roaring lion tearing its prey: they have devoured souls, taken riches and treasures, and multiplied its widows in its midst. Its priests have despised my law and defiled my sanctuaries. They have not kept a distinction between the holy and the profane, and have not understood the difference between the unclean and the clean. They have turned their eyes away from my Sabbaths, and I have become defiled among them. Its leaders in its midst are like wolves tearing prey, shedding blood, destroying souls, and greedily pursuing profits. Its prophets coat them with false visions and prophesy lies, saying: Thus says the Lord God, when the Lord has not spoken. They slander the people of the land and violently seize their possessions. They oppress the needy and the poor, and mistreat the strangers without justice. And I sought from them a man who would stand in the breach and stand against me for the land, so that I would not destroy it, and I did not find one. So I poured out my indignation on them, I consumed them in the fire of my wrath. I have repaid their way on their own heads, says the Lord God. The diligent listener could inquire what the dross is, which has violated the purity of silver and has mixed it with copper, lead, tin, and iron. Therefore, what is expressed there under the person of the city and the furnace, and under the appearance of unwatered earth, which has not received rain, is preached. We must understand those rains about which it is written: I will command the clouds that they rain no shower upon it (Isa. V, 6): which we await, when temporary and late rain is given to us, about which it is written: You will make a voluntary rain, O God, to your inheritance (Ps. LXVII, 10). However, there is a day of wrath, which each person attracts to themselves with a multitude of sins. We desire to know what the scum of the city is, which is like the hardest of lands and full of thorns and foul-smelling weeds. He said, 'The conspiracy of the prophets, or according to the Septuagint, the leaders within it have the likeness of a lion, about which Peter also writes: 'Our adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, goes about' (1 Peter 5:8). This lion and all its companions do not seek to devour bodies, but souls; they receive rewards and judge everything by money. There is no doubt that this happened to the Jewish people in that time. For the Lord brought evil upon them because of the priests, princes, and prophets.' But in our Jerusalem we often see this: those who, according to the Septuagint, devour souls in power, and receive payment of 259, in order to make many widows who have lost the Lord as their bridegroom. However, this is the faction and conspiracy of these prophets, that they may be supporters of each other and do all things for the sake of disgraceful gain. The priests who should be the leaders of the temple, and from whose mouth the knowledge of the Law is sought, violate the sanctuaries, and have no distinction between the holy and the profane, except for money. They turn their eyes away from the sabbath, and do not recognize the rest of God which is in the knowledge of the Scriptures; neither do they say with the prophet: Open my eyes, and I will consider the wonders of your law (Psalm CXVIII, 18). Nor that of the Apostle: But we all, with unveiled face, beholding the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image (2 Corinthians III, 18). Among such prophets and priests, the middle Lord is defiled, of whom it is written: There stands among you one whom you do not know (John I, 26). Therefore, prophets or leaders are compared to lions. But the rulers whom we understand as people of lower rank imitate the rapaciousness of wolves, so that they may shed not the blood of bodies, but of souls, and greedily pursue gains, not at all content with that: 'Those who serve at the altar, live from the altar' (1 Cor. 9:13); but once they have entered into the ministry of God, they gather the riches of Croesus. Those prophets who foretell the future also anointed them without moderation, about which we have also spoken above, the prophesying prophets who anointed the wall without the mixture of chaff, which is scattered by the rain. They see such things in vain, and they do not so much prophesy as they divinely foretell falsehood, saying to the miserable earth: Thus says the Lord, the Lord promises these things, when the Lord has not spoken to them. But the people of the earth is not of God, but of earthly works, being envious of princes and priests, and by deceit and power they did everything: not oppressing the rich, but the poor, of whom it is written: But the poor cannot endure intimidation. Moreover, the redemption of a man's soul is his own wealth (Prov. XIII, 8). They also oppressed a stranger and a foreigner, who had not yet become a citizen of the Church, but only a listener, and had the beginnings of faith, in order that after they had traveled across the sea and the dry land, they would make him a proselyte and make him a child of Gehenna. Among such a multitude of vices and crimes, I sought for a man who could resist my anger, and who could oppose my fire and burning like Moses, Aaron, and Samuel; and I could not find one. Whereas he spoke to Moses: Let me alone, that I may destroy this people (Exod. XXXII, 10). And because I could not find anyone resisting and holding me back, therefore I poured out all my wrath upon them and consumed them, not without measure and judgment, but to repay their ways upon their heads, attributing their own sins to them as the authors, or certainly to the heads of the people, their leader, ruler, and prophets, none of whom dared to resist the angry Lord, and because of whom the land became barren and desolate, not deserving to receive the rain of the Lord.


<h2 id='tocuniq238'>(Cap. XXIII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 23, Verses 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, there were two women, the daughters of one mother. They committed adultery in Egypt; in their youth, they were promiscuous. There their breasts were fondled, and their virgin bosoms were pressed. (Or, as in the Septuagint, Their breasts were crushed there, and there they lost their virginity). Their names were Oholah the elder (or older) and Oholibah her sister. And I had them (or they were made for me), and they bore sons and daughters. And their names were Samaria Oolla, and Jerusalem Ooliba. Therefore, Oolla fornicated above me, and she went insane (or went away) to her lovers in Assyria, who approached (or were approaching) her, dressed in hyacinth (blue), princes and magistrates, all the young chosen men, cavalry riders. And she bestowed her harlotries upon the chosen sons of Assyria, all of whom she had desired, with all their idols she defiled herself. Moreover, she did not abandon her harlotries which she had practiced in Egypt; for in her youth men had lain with her, and they uncovered her virgin bosom and poured out their harlotry upon her. Therefore I delivered her into the hands of her lovers, into the hands of the sons of Assyria, upon whom she doted. They uncovered her shame, they took away her sons and her daughters; and her they slew with the sword. And she became famous among women (or became infamous among women); and they executed judgments (or avenged themselves) upon her. The Scripture attests that the twelve tribes of Israel, who were joined together in Egypt, were afterwards divided into two and ten tribes, called Judah and Israel, as recorded in the Books of Kings and Chronicles. Judah ruled from the lineage of David, Rehoboam the son of Solomon in Jerusalem, where the temple and priests were, and a large part of the tribe of Levi. However, to the ten tribes in Samaria, Jeroboam the son of Nabat from the tribe of Ephraim and Joseph; of which Samaria is now called Oolla, which in our language means tabernacle: but Jerusalem is called Ooliba, which is, my tabernacle in her. Indeed, even in the ten tribes there was a tabernacle not of God, but of idols. For Jeroboam, in order to turn the people away from the worship of God, placed golden calves in Dan and Bethel. Let us speak therefore about each of them. Those two women, Samaria and Jerusalem, were daughters of the same mother, born from the lineage of Israel, and they committed adultery in Egypt in their youth. For they would not have received the Law brought out of Egypt on Mount Sinai, which prohibited them from worshiping idols, unless they had worshiped the Egyptian abominations in Egypt. However, the mother of both can be Chethaea, of whom we read above: Your father was Amorrhæus, and your mother Chethaea (Above, XVI, 3). But also when it is said: Let each one remove the abominations of Egypt from his sight, this signifies that the Israelites served idols in Egypt, and there they fell, whether their breasts of virginity were broken, and Samaria is said to be greater and older, either because of the multitude of the ten tribes, or because after the death of Moses, Jesus the son of Nave ruled over the people of the tribe of Ephraim: hence we read that Jeroboam, who split them, was from the house of David (3 Kings, XII). And God had them, whether they were made by him, when they groaned from the works of Egypt, serving mud and clay. And later they bore sons and daughters to him, either in the wilderness or in the promised land. And first Oolla, that is, Samaria, fornicated against God when she went mad for the Assyrians, who were dressed in her hyacinth robes, not just anyone from the people, but rulers and officials, not old ones, but all young men, chosen horsemen, from whom she followed idols, and from whom she asked for help against the command of God. Those who came and defiled her, so that they would not leave whatever she had done in her youth in Egypt, 262. For even the Egyptians had intercourse with her in her youth, whose idols she worshipped; and there she was deflowered, and her breasts were broken. And there was such an abundance of fornication that it is said that they did not fornicate with her, but poured out their own fornication upon her. Therefore she was handed over to her lovers, Phul and Theglathphalassar, and Salmanasar, in whose madness they uncovered her shame, metaphorically, as if she were a prostitute (2 Kings 17 and 18, 1 Chronicles 5). But the revelation of the city is captivity, those who took their sons and daughters captive and killed the city itself with the sword, so that it was slaughtered as an example to all women; and it is celebrated in the conversation of all in a negative sense. Those who executed judgments and punishments in it left nothing of salvation in it; but even today the ten tribes are held captive in the mountains and cities of the Medes, to where they were transferred. We have discussed in more detail in the anagoge of the prophet Hosea what Joseph, Ephraim, Samaria, Jezreel, and Israel signify, and how they are contrary to the house of David and Jerusalem, which signifies the Church. Of whom the seventy-seventh psalm speaks: The sons of Ephraim, being armed and carrying bows, turned back in the day of battle (Ps. LXXVI, 9). And again: He refused the tabernacle of Joseph, and chose not the tribe of Ephraim (Ibid., 67). For God has chosen the house of confession, the Church, and has rejected the tabernacle of Joseph, which is interpreted as increase. They, neglecting the Law of God, added to their golden calves of worship, and are called Oolla, that is, tabernacle, not of God, but of error and demons. And the older and elder sister, because of the multitude and captivity by the Assyrians, committed fornication against God, because she abandoned the truth of the faith, and went mad for the leaders of heretics, who were dressed in purple, promising her high and heavenly things; and companions, of whom it is said: These in chariots, and in horses (Ps. XIX, 8), choosing the sons of the Assyrians and the leaders and magistrates, who promise knowledge and eloquence to themselves. But he did this because he practiced the same fornications that he had in Egypt, that is, before he believed, and he still lived in the world, and he also engaged in heresy. And she was defiled (or 'they were defiled') by Assyrian men who persist in wickedness, 263 or by avengers. For our adversary the devil himself is an enemy and avenger (1 Peter 5). They shattered the breasts of Samaria, and they destroyed her virginity that she had in the Church. Therefore she was given over to her lovers, just as the Apostle wrote: I delivered them to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme (I Tim. I, 20). And: I delivered them to the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved (I Cor. V, 5). They uncovered the shame of wretched Samaria, and they displayed all her turpitude, leading captive the sons and daughters who were born to her, endowed with knowledge, and they deceived the simple and inexperienced, and they killed her by the spiritual sword. They are celebrated in a bad way by the entire world and become famous among all the teachings of this age, so that the turpitude of that woman may be punished as an example to all women.


<h2 id='tocuniq239'>(Vers. 11 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 11 and following) When her sister Oholibah saw this, she became more insane with lust than she was. She shamelessly engaged in prostitution with the Assyrians, offering herself for sex to their sons. She attracted the attention of the leaders and officials who came to her, dressed in various (or precious) garments, riding on horses with riders, and accompanied by exceptionally attractive young men. And I saw that both of them had defiled the same path, and she increased her acts of prostitution. And when he saw the painted men on the wall, images of the Chaldeans depicted in colors, and their loins girded with belts, and their heads adorned with dyed turbans: in the likeness of all the nobles (or all the wise men) of the sons of Babylon, and of the land of the Chaldeans, from which they were born: and he was inflamed with desire for them, and sent messengers to them in Chaldea. And when the sons of Babylon came to her to her bed  (or to her dwelling place), they defiled her with their fornication, and she was polluted with them, and her soul turned away from them. And she uncovered her fornications, and exposed her disgrace; and my soul departed from her, as my soul departed from her sister. For she multiplied her fornications, remembering the days of her youth, when she played the harlot in the land of Egypt. And she became obsessed with desire for their concubines, whose flesh is like the flesh of donkeys and whose emission is like the emission of horses. And you visited the wickedness of your youth: when your breasts were pressed in Egypt, and your maiden breasts were broken. According to the letter, the easy interpretation is that Oholibah, that is, Jerusalem, where the tabernacle of God was, saw the wounds of her sister and was not warned by the example to turn her foot away from error, but rather increased her sister's prostitution. For she once made idols outside in Dan and Bethel: but she frequently worshiped the statue of Baal in the high places and in the temple of God, and fornicated with the Assyrians. But the idol of Baal, or Bel, and (to speak more plainly) Belis, is the religion of the Assyrians, consecrated by Ninus the son of Belis in honor of his father. And it shamelessly displayed its fornication to the Assyrians, to the leaders and magistrates, who were dressed in various and multicolored garments, to the horsemen and to the young men, all of them outstanding in appearance, so that the fornication of both sisters became one. Furthermore, it increased its own fornications in Jerusalem, for when it saw in the walls the images of the Chaldeans, it was driven mad with lust and, deceived by their appearance and dress, it sent messengers to them, asking for help: they came and defiled it. And because pleasure is not everlasting, but quickly brings satiety: being polluted and saturated with such things, she departed from their company. And I, seeing all the infamous acts and fornications publicly displayed by everyone, also departed from her, so that I might surpass the crimes of my sister by the magnitude of her punishments. Such was the audacity of her vice, that she committed all the errors of her youth in a more serious age: and she indulged in Egyptian vices as well as the lusts of the Chaldeans. For he once went mad in the company of the Egyptians, whose flesh resembles that of donkeys, and whose semen flows so abundantly, and their genitals are so large, that they exceed even the ugliness of horses. Nor did his wickedness cease in his youth: rather, it returned after it happened to me, so that he surpassed his former lust both in the wilderness and in the land of promise, where he lost her virginity and her breasts were broken, and all the beauty of her virginity perished. Furthermore, according to the allegory, it is difficult to understand how the Church overcomes heretical lust, unless perhaps we can say this, that the servant who knows the will of his master and does not do it, will be beaten with many lashes (Luke XII, 47): and that heretics commit abominable things outside the ark and perish in the shipwreck: but if the followers of Ecclesiastes imitate the true faith, let them imitate the vices of Assyria and Chaldea and follow the colorless images of sins, they will be worthy of greater torments. We do not send messengers to the Chaldeans, who interpret like demons, when we open ourselves to them, and offer them our breasts to be broken in the chest where the abode of the mind is, and being satisfied with pleasures, we move from one to another; and we desire not so much fornication as the number of prostitutes, and we come to such frenzy that after a long time of servitude to the Lord, we return to Egypt and do the things we did in the world before we received the name of faith.


<h2 id='tocuniq240'>(Vers. 22 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 22 and following) Therefore, Oholibah, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will stir up all your lovers against you, from whom your soul is satiated, and I will gather them against you from all around: the sons of Babylon and all the Chaldeans, nobles, tyrants, and princes, all the sons of Assyria with their handsome appearance, governors and officials, all the princes of princes and renowned horsemen. And they shall come against you with chariots and wheels, and with a multitude of peoples armed with breastplate, shield, and helmet from all sides. And I will give them judgment, and they will judge you with their judgments, and I will put my zeal in you, which they exercise with you in fury. They will cut off your nose and your ears, and what remains, they will cut off with a sword. They will take your sons and daughters, and your last one will be devoured by fire, and they will strip you of your garments, and they will take away the vessels of your glory. And they will make your wickedness cease from you, and your fornication from the land of Egypt: you will not lift your eyes to them, and you will no longer remember Egypt. LXX: Therefore, Oholibah, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will stir up your lovers against you, from whom your soul has turned away, and I will bring them against you from every side— the sons of Babylon and all the Chaldeans, φακοὺθ and συὲ and κοὺθ, and all the sons of Assyria with them, the young men, the chosen ones, the governors, and the officials, all of them riding on horses. They shall come against you with weapons, chariots, and wheels, and with a host of people; they shall set themselves against you on every side with buckler, shield, and helmet; and I will commit the judgment to them, and they shall judge you according to their judgments. And I will put judgment before their face, and they shall judge thee by their judgments. And I will set my zeal against thee, and they shall deal furiously with thee: they shall take away thy nose and thy ears; and thy remains shall be cast forth by the sword; they shall take thy sons and thy daughters; and thy residue shall be devoured by fire. And they shall strip thee of thy garments, and shall take away the instruments of thy glory. And I will take away thy wickedness out of thee: and thou shalt no more bring to mind the land of Egypt. And thou shalt not lift up thy eyes to them: neither shalt thou remember Egypt any more. Because you remembered the meat of the Egyptians, and imitated the filthiness of the unclean nation, which worships the images of all beasts: therefore I will bring against you your lovers, with whom you have been satiated, and I will make you turn from the love that you had into great hatred. The sons, I say, of Babylon, and all the Chaldeans, the nobles and princes; for whom in the Hebrew language it is written, Phacud () and Sue () and Cue (), which the multitudes of the East understand when such names are mentioned, but we cannot find them in the book of Kings, or in the Chronicles, or even in Jeremiah, who describes the captivity of Jerusalem, or in any place of Holy Scripture. No wonder, if the Septuagint itself used Hebrew names, since Symmachus and Theodotion also agree on the same words. They all, he says, the Assyrians, the cavalry, and the youths, in distinguished form, the leaders and officials, or the mourners, whom we have interpreted as the princes of princes. Concerning whom we also read in Exodus (Exod. XV, 4). Chosen lifters-up of the mourners (τριστάτας), for whom Latin simplicity has translated three supporters. But the name is Tristatae among the Greeks, the second rank after the royal dignity. Of whom it is written: Yet he did not reach the top three, who were the leaders of cavalry and infantry and tribunes (Or tribunes) (I Par. XII, II Reg. XXIII): whom we call magistrates of both military branches, and prefects of the grain supply. All, he says, in chariots and on horses, armed with armor, helmet, and shield, surrounded you in a circle, and I will give them judgement, so that you will be judged by those whom you have left, and by the ones whose pact you have nullified: and they will judge you with their own judgements as an adulteress. And I will set my zeal upon you, which they exercise against you in fury. For my zeal is among the enemies, even among those who have not kept faith. They will cut off your nose and your ears, like adulteresses caught in adultery, so that you will cease to please in your disfigurement. For just as all the beauty of the face depends on the adornment of the nose, and in the ears, on which women wear their earrings and pearls, so the dignity of the king and the judges, which is demonstrated in their words and in their hearing, will be cut off by their sword. They will take your sons and daughters. 'Yours,' he said, 'not mine,' because they were conceived in adultery, and they will be devoured by fire, and they will uncover you, and your adornments, with which I had adorned you, and the vessels of your glory, which I had granted to you, golden and silver, for the ceremonies of the temple, of which it is written: 'I gave them gold and silver, and they made them for Baal' (Hosea 2:8). But I will do all these things, so that with your lost beauty and your poisoned face, your wickedness may finally rest, and the fornication that you learned and practiced in Egypt: so that after you have lost your nose and ears, you will not dare to lift your eyes to the Chaldeans, and show your ugliness to your former lovers; nor will you remember any longer the lust of the Egyptians, whose abundance of flesh delighted you. Whatsoever is spoken in a figure τροπικῶς concerning Jerusalem, and may be referred to the soul, which, being joined to the embraces of God, afterward committed adultery with vices, and departed from Him, and having openly displayed all her wickedness, was stripped and defiled and shown to all, that she might desist somewhat from her wickedness; nor may she glory in the dignity of her name, but, on account of her evil conscience and the remembrance of Egypt, may she not dare to lift up her eyes to heaven. And so his nose is cut off, and his ears are amputated, because he had turned the scent of good fragrance into stench, and he had heard the judgment of blood, which we understand not only by scent and hearing, but also by sight, through which Samson and Zedekiah are deprived because they had abused it. God also made them deaf and mute (Exod. IV, 11): so that their language does not penetrate to the earth, and every sense is taken away from those who have completely lost their life. And these things will be done, so that all things may be cleansed by fire, and the fornication of Egypt may perish: and it will no longer be able to lift its eyes to evil.

<h2 id='tocuniq241'>(Vers. 28 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 28 and following) For thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will deliver you into the hands of those whom you hate, into the hands of those from whom your soul is satisfied. And they will deal with you in hatred, and they will take away all your labors, and they will leave you naked and full of shame, and the shame of your fornications will be revealed. Your wickedness and your fornications have brought this upon you, because you have played the harlot with the nations among whom you have defiled yourself with their idols. You walked in the way of your sister, and I will give her cup into your hand. Thus says the Lord God: You shall drink the deep and wide cup of your sister. You shall be a derision and a scorn, which is full to the brim. You will be filled with drunkenness and sorrow, with the cup of mourning and grief, the cup of your sister Samaria. And you shall drink it and drain it to the dregs, and you shall devour its fragments, and you shall tear your breasts (or as the Septuagint has translated: I will take away her feasts and her new moons); because I have spoken, says the Lord (Vulgate adds God). Therefore, thus says the Lord God. Because you have forgotten me and cast me behind your back, you also bear your wickedness and your harlotry.
