It is profitable for Jerusalem to have enmity against the Assyrians and the Chaldeans and not to remember Egypt; but rather to be delivered into their hands for punishment, those who hated her: to whom she was not delivered before, unless her soul was satisfied with them, so that after she repented of her old sins, she would be cleansed by punishments, and would destroy all the labor she acquired by her harlotry; and she would see her nakedness and shame, and would know that the Lord did not do all these things to her, but rather her own harlotry, by which she played the harlot with the nations mentioned above, in order to worship their idols. On the roads, he says, you walked of your sister Samaria: therefore you must drink the cup of her, whose sins you have followed. However, there are many examples of the cup, which is often taken for punishments and torments, among which is this: The cup in the hand of the Lord is full of mixed wine, and he pours from this into that: nevertheless its dregs are not emptied out, all the sinners of the earth drink from it (Psalm LXXIV, 9, 10). And in Isaiah it is called the cup of ruin and the goblet of fury (Isaiah LI, 17). And God spoke to Jeremiah: Take the cup of wine from my hand and make all the nations, to which I will send you, drink it. They will drink, vomit, and go mad. Just as certain purgatives are given to remove harmful humors from the body, so the Lord gives the cup of most bitter torments to take away all bitterness and restore sinners to their former health. And the cup itself will be deep and wide. Deep, in the magnitude of punishments: wide in the time of captivity. But when, he says, you have become drunk and seized by sorrow, and you will drink the cup until the dregs, and you will have consumed it to the point of devouring even the fragments of the cup itself: then you will be disgusted by your former fornication, and you will tear apart the breasts that were broken in Egypt, and that were subjugated and bruised by your lovers: whether I take away all your festivities, and new moons, so that instead of celebration and joy, you shall have eternal lamentation and mourning. Therefore, because you have done these things and have forgotten about me, and have cast me behind your body, whether backwards on account of the corruptions of the body or after the genitals, by which the filthiness of immorality is indicated: therefore the gate of your wickedness and impiety, namely the punishments which you have deserved on account of impiety and wickedness, can be expressed significantly. This that is said can be understood significantly about Jerusalem, which drank the cup of her sister Samaria's last, and as it were has drunk the dregs of her torments down to the bottom.


<h2 id='tocuniq242'>(Vers. 36, 37 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 36, 37 and following) And the Lord said to me, saying: Son of man, do you judge Oolla and Oolibah, and announce their crimes (or iniquities) to them: for they are adulterous ((Vulgate: adulterated)), and there is blood on their hands, and they have committed fornication with their idols (or inventions): moreover, they offered to me the sons they had borne to be devoured (or led away) by fire. But they also did this to me, they defiled my sanctuary on that day, and profaned my Sabbaths. And when they sacrificed their sons to their idols and entered my sanctuary on that day, defiling it, they also did these things in the midst of my house. They sent for men coming from afar, to whom they had sent messengers. So behold, they have come, whom you bathed (or, when they arrived, you immediately bathed): and you painted your eyes and adorned yourself with women's attire. You sat on a beautiful bed, and a table was set before you. You have placed my incense and my perfume on her, and there was a voice of a multitude rejoicing in her (or the voice of a composed multitude resounded); And indeed, crowds of people were brought in among the men, and they came from the desert (or drunken from the desert): they put bracelets on their hands, and most beautiful crowns on their heads. And I said about her who was worn out with adultery: Now she will also commit fornication in her own fornication. And they entered into it as one goes to a harlot; so they entered into Oollam and Oolibah, the wicked women. Therefore, righteous men (the Vulgate will insert this) will judge them with the judgment of adulterers and the judgment of those who shed blood, for they are adulterers, and blood is on their hands. For thus says the Lord God: Bring a multitude against them and deliver them to tumult and plunder, and they shall be stoned with the stones of the people, and pierced with their swords. They shall kill their sons and daughters, and burn their houses with fire, and I will remove wickedness (or impiety) from the land, and all women shall learn not to do according to their wickedness (or impiety). And they will bring your wickedness (or impiety) upon you, and you will bear the sins of your idols, and you will know that I am the Lord God. As I have often mentioned, I have connected the slight discrepancies between the Hebrew and the Septuagint edition, taking care not to bore the reader. Consequently, the one who described the adulteries of Samaria and Jerusalem separately would also announce their punishments together. 271 However, everything is said as if to adulteresses, and the crimes are briefly presented, so that stoning by the people may be rightly carried out against them, according to the command of the Law. Therefore, since they are adulteresses, bring forth a just sentence. For they are committing adultery in idols, and blood is on their hands, namely the blood of those whom they offered to idols, so that the children whom they had borne to me would be consecrated to demons. They did not do this outside and in the mountains and groves, as they often used to do, but in the end they defiled my temple, so that they would set up a statue of Baal in it. And they profaned my Sabbaths, so that neither the place, nor the time, nor the religion would be observed among them. But they were not satisfied with present adulteries alone, nor was it enough for them that they sacrificed my sons to their idols or demons; but they also indulged in foreign pleasures, venerating the images of the Assyrians and Chaldeans. When they came, Oholibah, you filled every adulterous attire and adorned yourself with makeup, so that you might wash your body, line your eyes with antimony: so that you might assume the attire of a woman, sit on a bed prepared for lust, and offer feasts to replenish the strength of your lovers who were broken by desire; my incense and the ointment which I had ordered to be made for me, and the soul that desired to do this for private use, you offered to idols; to gather a crowd of people and sing all kinds of music: so that you might please your lovers not only by sight, but also by hearing and smell, and all the senses, who came to you drunk: not preferring any urban elegance, but the attire of the desert and solitude, resembling that of peasants and robbers. And you, wicked sisters, have fallen into such great madness of pleasures, that you put your bracelets and necklaces on the hands and heads of your lovers, whether it be for yourselves, so that you may defile yourselves in full adornment. Therefore, I said to her, whether it be to Jerusalem or to Samaria, or to both: You have burned your forehead in such a way that you are not at all polluted in secret, but you avoid the gaze of your husbands and men; instead, you openly prostitute yourselves like public harlots, eagerly desiring to be defiled by those who enter to you, as if to harlots. So I will hand you over to be punished by those to whom you have willingly surrendered yourselves for defilement. For they are just men, who, at my command, torment adulteresses and murderers. For thus says the Lord God: By the request of your voice, O prophet, gather a multitude of peoples against them, and let all their possessions be plundered; then let them be stoned and pierced with swords, and let their sons and daughters be killed, and let their houses be burned. And all these things will be done so that wickedness may be removed from the earth; and all women and all the distant provinces may learn to avoid punishments similar to theirs: so that after you have received what you deserve, and have carried the crimes of your idols, then you may know that I am the Lord. But all these things were said tropologically and under the guise of adulterers against Samaria and Jerusalem, because they were delivered to the Assyrians and Chaldeans, and led into captivity, and their cities were consumed by fire: the people who worshiped the idols of demons instead of God were destroyed. These things can also be understood after the coming of Christ, in that the just men from the nations themselves judge the Samaritans and the Jews by comparison with themselves and deliver them to be devoured, to whom the Lord had said (Matt. XXIII, 38): Your house will be abandoned to you. And: When you see Jerusalem surrounded by an army, know that its desolation is near (Luke XXI, 22). For even to this day they are adulterated and oppressed by the stones of the whole world. Since they sent messengers to those who were far away, and could not say: I am a God who is drawing near, not a God from afar, says the Lord (Jeremiah 23:23). And they prepared themselves for their lovers, the demons, and turned all the worship and adornment that they had received from God as a natural good into the worship of demons. And they offered it to their adulterous lovers, whose punishment is a source of fear for the nations, yes, even for those who believed from the nations, lest they suffer similar things if they do what Samaria and Jerusalem did. From whom then their impieties will be taken away when they have received their crimes, and have taken away the veil that was placed before the face of Moses (Exod. XXXIV), from their eyes, so that they may know that He is the Lord Jesus Christ, whom they denied to be the Son of God (II Cor. III).

<h2 id='tocuniq243'>(Cap. XXIV. Vers. 1 seq.)</h2>

(Chapter 24, Verse 1ff). And the word of the Lord came to me in the ninth year, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, saying: Son of man, write down the name of this day, on which the king of Babylon has besieged Jerusalem this day. And you shall speak a parable against the rebellious house, and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: Set a pot, set it on, and pour water into it. Gather its pieces into it, every good piece, the thigh and the shoulder; fill it with choice bones. Take the choicest of the flock, pile up the bones under it; boil its contents well, and let its bones be cooked in its midst. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Woe to the city of blood, the pot whose rust is in it, and its rust has not gone out of it: part by part, throw it out and its pieces; the lot has not fallen upon it. For its blood is in the midst of it; upon a very clear rock it poured it out; it did not pour it out upon the earth, that it might be covered with dust. In order to bring My indignation to bear and take vengeance: I have given its blood upon a very clear rock, so that it would not be covered. Because of this, says the Lord God: Woe to the city of blood, on which I will make a great fire. Heap up the bones to be burned with fire; the flesh will be consumed, and the whole composition will be cooked, and the bones will decay. Also, place it on empty coals, so that its bronze may become hot and melt, and the filth of it may be consumed in its midst, and its rust may be destroyed. Much effort has been exerted; and its excessive rust has not gone out from it, nor has it been cleansed by fire. Your abominable impurity, because I wanted to cleanse you, and you were not cleansed from your filth; but you will not be cleansed until I make my indignation cease in you. I am the Lord, I have spoken: it will come to pass, and I will not pass by, nor pity, nor be appeased. According to your ways and your deeds I have judged you, says the Lord. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me in the ninth year, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, saying: Son of man, write for yourself the day on which the king of Babylon has hardened himself against Jerusalem from this day onward, and speak to the rebellious house a parable, and say to them: Thus says the Lord God: 274 Put the pot on and pour water into it, and put in it the pieces, every good piece, the thigh and the shoulder, separated from the bones of the chosen sheep, and burn the bones underneath it: it boiled, and its bones are cooked in the midst of it. Therefore thus says the Lord God: O city of blood, a pot in which rust is, and the rust has not come out of it, it has brought it out in its parts; the lot has not fallen upon it, because its blood is in the midst of it. I have set it upon the smooth rock: I have not poured it upon the ground, that it might be covered with dust. That fury may ascend for vengeance: I have given its blood upon the clear rock, that it might not be covered. Therefore thus says the Lord God: Woe to the city of blood, in which I will increase the terror, and multiply the wood, and kindle the fire, so that flesh may rot, and the juice may be reduced, and bones may be congealed, and stand upon its coals. It is kindled so that it may be burned and cooled, and its brass may be congealed in its midst, and its impurity may solidify, and its rust may fail. Rust will be humbled, and much of its rust will not come out of it: its rust will be confounded. Your impurity, Zemma, be brought low, because you have been defiled, and you have not been cleansed from your impurity. And what will happen if you are not cleansed anymore, until I have fulfilled my fury on you? I, the Lord, have spoken, and it will come to pass; I will not delay, nor will I have pity, nor will I relent. According to your ways and your deeds I will judge you, says the Lord God. Therefore I will judge you according to your blood and according to your wicked thoughts; you are impure and infamous, and you have multiplied your abominations to provoke me. (Many of these phrases have been added from Theodotion, and the Hebrew word Zemma (), which we have interpreted as abominable impurity.) And it has been added by them, which is not found in Hebrew, and it must be marked with an obelus: Therefore I will judge you according to your blood, and I will judge you according to your thoughts, unclean and infamous, and excessive for provocation. So let us speak about each one. In the ninth year of the captivity of King Joachim (for he began to prophesy in the fifth year), and in the tenth month of the same ninth year, on the tenth day of the tenth month, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Ezekiel, in the region of Babylon, and He said to him: Son of man, write down this very day for yourself, and know that today the king of Babylon has begun to besiege Jerusalem in the region of Judah, and to surround it with an army; and describe this siege as a parable and proverb, which in this present place signifies metaphor and translation. He said, 'Place a bronze pot, that is, a lebes, and pour water into it, and cut the bodies of the fattest animals into pieces, both the thigh and leg and arm, and carefully separate the flesh from the bones, and after the flesh has been put into the lebes, place or arrange the bones under the lebes, and make a heap, and piles of bones, so that the cooking of the lebes may boil not once, but frequently, and the meat may be cooked thoroughly internally, and the bones may be burned beneath.' But you want to know, prophet, who this potter's vessel is, or what kind of flesh or bones? Speak these things, says the Lord God: Woe to the city of blood, that is Jerusalem, to the potter's vessel, whose rust, that is extreme wickedness, and even though fire has been set to it, its rust has not gone out of it. For they have persisted even though captured and tortured in their former wickedness. Consume it in parts and one by one, let no one remain for salvation. The fate did not fall upon her so that some would perish and others would be saved, but a common destruction came to all. For her blood, that is, murders and the deaths of her sons, are in her midst. She spilled this blood over the clearest rock, so that it would be open to all and not be covered by earth or dust: so that my anger would not pass, but my revenge would hasten over the most obvious blood. For it is the nature that if blood is poured on the ground, the earth absorbs the moisture of the blood, or gradually the earth is covered and covered with dust. But when blood is shed upon a most clear and unyielding rock devoid of any pit, it flows and occupies a wide seat. But this indicates that he has not committed hidden but public homicides, according to that which is said to Cain: The blood of your brother cries out to me (Gen. IV, 10): therefore say to the city, not of one blood, but of many bloods: Behold, I will make a great pyre or tower in you, which the common people call a bonfire, and I will kindle not only soft and tender flesh in you, but also the hardest bones, so that nothing remains in you that is not consumed by the fire. And when both the flesh and bones have been consumed and burned, place the empty cauldron on the embers, so that its bronze may also become hot and be consumed, and when the bronze is consumed, let its rust also perish, that is, let it be consumed by the fire that burned the city, and let malice perish with the city. But what profit is there in having done what was ordered? Not even by fire could the rust and malice of the cauldron, and of the city, be removed; but it remains in that unholy and accursed defilement: for this is what the leprosy signifies. And he makes an apostrophe to the very city itself, that is, to the city itself. I wanted to cleanse you, but you have not been cleansed of your filth, nor will you be able to be cleansed until I fulfill my indignation against you. I, the Lord, have spoken, and my sentence cannot be disregarded. The siege of the city has now come, and I will do as I have threatened: I will not pass over your crimes, as I have often done in the past. And I will no longer spare you, nor will I be appeased by your prayers, even if you multiply them. Instead, I will repay you for your ways and your inventions. Indeed, I will judge you according to your works and your thoughts, so that even in this I may demonstrate my mercy, like a doctor who does not spare rotten flesh in order to save healthy limbs: he does not spare in order to spare; he is cruel in order to show pity; he does not consider the pain of the patient, but rather the health of the wound, according to the saying in the Gospel: he would rather let one member perish than the whole body be destroyed (Matthew 5). Also note how from the beginning of the prophecy until the present day, when Jerusalem began to be besieged, the order of the captivity comes. First the sword is provoked; then two ways are set, let Ammonite Jerusalem, on the right side of which the lot falls to Nebuchadnezzar; silver is melted in the city, brass, tin, lead and iron; the land is also not watered, but occupied by thorns: afterwards, under the name of the two sisters Oolla and Oolibah, the sins of Samaria and Jerusalem are narrated, how the former was captured, and the latter will be captured. At the end of the ninth year, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, when Ezekiel and those with him were in captivity and had surrendered to King Jehoiachin, it is shown on what day the city began to be besieged, and a representation of a cooking pot is set up; just as meat and bones piled up in the pot are burned by fire, so the whole city with its inhabitants will perish, and none of those who are besieged will remain, but they will be consumed by famine, sword, and plague, and the remaining part will be taken captive to Babylon. Can this same prophecy pertain also to the time of the Lord's passion, for which Jerusalem was surrounded by an army and its children were killed, and with Titus, the son of Vespasian, besieging it, no one escaped for salvation, and the temple was destroyed; and after fifty years, under Hadrian, the city was consumed by eternal fire. But when Ezekiel saw this present captivity in Babylon, and Jeremiah puts it at the beginning of his book: What do you see, Jeremiah? And he answering, said, A boiling pot and the face thereof from the face of the north. (Jeremiah 1:13) Some, according to tropology, transfer the whole passage to the end of the world (the age), and they interpret the number nine, which in the holy Scriptures represents punishments and sorrows, and always follows justice, as the mercy of the tenth month and the tenth day. Therefore, punishments are inflicted on the sick, so that health may follow pain. Therefore, the world that is situated in evil (1 John 5:19) is set ablaze by the divine fire of judgment; and the city of blood is placed upon the coals of fire, so that what is written in Isaiah may be fulfilled: You have coals of fire, sit upon them: they shall be a help to you (Isaiah 47:14). And this is the difficult thing, that even though coals and bones are consumed, with which the Pharisees are also full, to whom the Lord speaks in the Gospel: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, who are like whitewashed sepulchers: which are within full of filth, and of dead men's bones (Matthew 23:27), it is now said that the rust and filth of the world are not consumed, but that malice remains even after the severity of judgment. What is easily solved, if we understand the saying of the Apostle: God has concluded all under sin, that he may have mercy on all (Galatians 3:22). For the creature is subject to vanity (Romans 8:28). And the blood that was shed is set before the face of the whole creation, that the sins of all may be made manifest. But we can receive the most pure rock, and the Lord Savior, who followed the people of Israel in the wilderness, of whom it is written: They drank of that spiritual rock that followed them: and that rock was Christ (1 Corinthians 10:4): so that all things may be revealed in Him; and that which is written may be fulfilled: There is nothing hidden that shall not be revealed. And he said that the Lord does not show mercy, nor overlook the sins of the world; nor spare the wicked, nor be appeased, so that the ways of the wicked may perish, according to what is placed at the end of the first psalm: And the way of the wicked will perish.

<h2 id='tocuniq244'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, behold, I am taking away from you the desire of your eyes with a stroke, and you shall not mourn or weep, nor shall your tears flow. Sigh in silence, make no mourning for the dead. Let your turban be on your head, and your sandals on your feet; do not cover your lips, nor eat the bread of mourners. So I spoke to the people in the morning, and in the evening my wife died. And I did in the morning as I was commanded. And the people said to me: Why do you not tell us what these things mean, that you are doing? And I said to them: The word of the Lord came to me saying: Speak to the house of Israel: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will profane my sanctuary, the pride of your power, and the desire of your eyes, and that which your soul fears, and your sons and daughters whom you have left behind shall fall by the sword. And you shall do as I have done: you shall not cover your lips, nor eat the bread of mourners. You will wear crowns on your heads and sandals on your feet. You will not mourn or weep, but will waste away because of your sins; you will groan among yourselves. Ezekiel will be a sign to you; you will do just as he has done. When this happens, you will know that I am the Lord God. And you, son of man, on the day I take away their stronghold, their joy and glory, the delight of their eyes, their sons and daughters, On that day, when the fugitive comes to you to bring you news, on that day, I say, your mouth will be opened with the one who is fleeing, and you shall speak and be silent no more. You will be a sign to them, and they shall know that I am the Lord. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, behold, I will take away from you the desire of your eyes with a stroke (or in preparation); you shall not mourn or weep, and tears shall not come to you. Groaning in your heart, but not lamentation for the loss of your loved ones. Your hair will be bound upon you, and your shoes on your feet; you will not mourn or weep, but you will pine away in your iniquities and groan to one another. Thus I have spoken to the people in the morning, as I was commanded; and in the evening my wife died. So I did in the morning as I was commanded. Then the people said to me, 'Will you not tell us what these things signify for us, that you are acting this way?' Then I said to them, 'Thus says the Lord God: "I will profane My sanctuaries, man's arrogant pride, the desire of your eyes, and the longing of your souls."' Your sons and daughters whom you have left behind will fall by the sword, and you will do as I have done. Their mouths will not be comforted, and you will not eat the bread of men. Your hair will be on your heads, and your shoes on your feet. You will not weep or mourn, and you will be consumed by your iniquities, and each one will comfort his brother, and Jezechiel will be a sign to you. You will do according to all that he has done. And when these things come, you will know that I am Adonai the Lord. And you, son of man, on the day when I take away their strength, the pride of their glory, the desire of their eyes, and the arrogance of their soul, their sons and daughters, on that day the one who has been saved will come to you to announce it in your ears. On that day your mouth will be opened to speak to the one who has escaped, and you shall no longer be silent, and you shall be a sign to them, and they will know that I am the Lord. Above the cooking pot and the burning oils, she had shown the siege of the city, now she shows it captured and destroyed, and the entire population either killed by the sword or taken into captivity, the prophetic discourse attests. And first, according to our custom, let us lay the foundations of the history. Son, he said, behold, I will take away from your sight whatever is desirable to you, and I will take it to a place, or as the LXX has translated, in preparation: so that you may prepare yourself not to do those things which are accustomed to be done in mourning. Do not lament, nor will you weep, nor will flowing tears reveal the pain of the heart: but if perhaps you are overwhelmed by excessive sadness, keep silent groans, and do not burst forth in words. You will not mourn the dead, or, in the words of the Septuagint, the groaning of blood, but it is the lamentation of the kidneys. Through this, it shows that his wife is about to die. For immediately it follows: And my wife died in the evening (Prov. XIX); which specifically pertains to the connection of the kidneys. For there is nothing more pleasing to a man than a good and beloved wife, who is provided by God for man, and is united to him by the law of the Lord, and together with her, becomes one body. And what follows: 'Let your crown be bound around you, and let your shoes be on your feet,' signifies this: You will have hair that is cut in mourning, and shoes on your feet, which mourners usually cast off. Hence, David, fleeing from Absalom, his son, and repenting for the death of Uriah, walked with bare feet (1 Samuel 12:15, 18)." } The Hebrews say that the Babylonian masters, who observe the precepts of the Law, write the Ten Commandments on small scrolls and wrap them around their heads, and these are to be displayed before their eyes and on their foreheads, so that they always see the precepts. And because Ezekiel was a priest, he should not remove the crown of glory from his head, but have it bound. This is what they have said. However, according to the LXX, we understand the crown of hair to be the hair: although their interpretation does not accurately express the meaning of the Hebrew language. He said, 'You will neither cover your face with a veil nor eat the foods of mourners, which are done in mourning, to cover the face, and the Greeks call them 'περίδειπνα', let them be received by the consolers. I spoke, he said, to the people in the morning, what the Lord had commanded me, and in the evening my beloved wife died, the desire of my eyes, and the sorrow of my loins and blood. And immediately on the next day in the morning I did everything that was commanded to me: and the people asked me why I acted against the custom of everyone.' And to those who were seeking the causes of such great patience, I replied: The word of the Lord that was spoken to me, so that I may speak to the people of Israel, commanded me thus: Behold, I, that is, will now defile my sanctuary, so that the temple may be set on fire and open to all foreigners and profane, and in it you had pride, that is, confidence and hope and desire for your salvation, and for the sake of which your souls were trembling in fear; and I will also consume with the sword the sons and daughters whom famine and pestilence have made for you. Whatever I have done, you will also do. When custom is observed in mourning, the pain is moderate; but when such a great necessity of evils weighs down, so that the mourning of each person is greater than any other, and each person is anxious about their own necessity, they do not moan over the miseries of even those who are closest to them. 'You will not do anything that is usual to do in mourning,' he says, 'but with the city and temple set on fire, you will be astonished at the magnitude of the evils. You will not be thunderstruck, nor will you walk with bare feet, nor will you weep, nor will you veil your faces with a garment, nor will you take food from those who would console you. But you will waste away and be consumed by your iniquities, and you will hardly have the freedom to groan, lest you offend the pride of the conquerors if you are seen publicly weeping; so that the prophet Ezekiel may be a portent to you, and that you do not do all the things that he did not do upon the death of his wife, in the destruction of the city and temple.' And even more clearly: \"Oh,\" he said, \"son of man, in the time when I take from them their strength, the temple, as we have said, their confidence and the joy of their dignity, and in which they had only hope, and the desire in which their souls found rest, and also their sons and daughters, as is understood from earlier, when I take them away. In that time, when someone comes to you fleeing from Jerusalem, or one who has escaped, saying the city has been destroyed, then you, who were previously silent and had no freedom to groan, and showed such great patience that you did not shed a tear even in the death of your wife and the pain in your loins, you will open your mouth and speak, not to him who comes, but with him: so that whatever you had previously foretold, he will now report as fulfilled, and you will no longer be silent; but you will accuse them and say that everything has happened to them justly, so that you may be a sign to them, according to what is written in Zechariah: 'Behold, I send my messenger, and he will prepare the way before me' (Zech. III, 8). And the Lord speaks elsewhere: 'I have become like a mirror-image in the hands of the prophets.' (Hosea 12:10) Let these things be said according to the historical account. Let us come to the anagogy (if it has not seemed too violent to the cautious reader's prudence). That the Son of Man is called the Lord Savior, there is no doubt, who in the last hour, that is, at the evening of this world, lost his former wife, did not weep for her, did not cover his face with mourning clothes, did not receive any human consolation, and predicted these things that were to come in the morning, which were fulfilled in the evening, and again in the morning, he proved in his second coming the things he had predicted would come, that the sanctuary of the Jews, and what they had desired in their eyes, and over which their souls trembled, have become defiled: and that their sons and daughters were killed by the Roman sword. But when it is said, 'You will have a crown on your heads, and sandals on your feet,' we refer that to the fact that they should by no means grieve, nor assume signs of mourning, once they have received the truth in shadow, and have become Nazarenes, and each one will console his brother, so that Ezekiel, whom God the Father strengthened, may be a sign to them, foretelling the future, and after Jerusalem has been overthrown and the temple burned, and the whole world has heard of this, and the dispersion of Israel, which inhabits the borders of the earth, then the words of the Lord will be fulfilled by their actions, they will have freedom, and with His sanctuary defiled, the Law completed or destroyed according to the letter, the glory of the Gospel will be revealed, and Israel will recognize that He Himself is the Lord and God, who predicted these things that will come in the morning, and in the evening, and in the consummation of the world, and confirmed them by His coming.


<h2 id='tocuniq245'>Book Eight</h2>

Book Eight

What benefit does our dictation have on the prophets, it is the judgment of God, and the conscience of those who, by setting aside declamations and applause and the composition of words, desire to know what their speech either tells of the past, or accuses of the present, or predicts of the future. In the meantime, it benefits us: for while we do this, and think of nothing else, we approach the explanations in a way that resembles theft, and we compensate for the miseries of days with the study of nights: the mind is nourished and forgets the calamities of the world, which in the extreme end already laid down groans and gives birth (II Thess. II), until he who restrains is taken out of the midst, and the feet of the once iron statue are crushed by the frailty of clay fingers. The world falls, and the upright neck does not bend. Wealth perishes, and greed does not cease in any way. They hurry to gather what can be occupied again by others. Tears have dried up, all piety has been taken away. Many beg, few give. We are not ashamed, preferring poverty to a cheap cloak, to lie in the lap of wealth like Croesus; and to guard famine and the destruction of many in our own treasuries, following after that rich man clothed in purple, whom Scripture testifies has done nothing else, for neither his robberies nor his injustices. His cruelty and pride knew no bounds: he did not even order to be given to Lazarus, who was lying at his door in front of him, not even the things that are thrown to the dogs. How many now lie like Lazarus, and how many are clothed in garments of various colors of purple, not even converting them to their own uses, but preserving what will perish! This, Eustochium, a virgin of Christ, spoke from the abundance of her heart, and we shall say a little more freely than is fitting for our humility. Moreover, the eighth book in the book of Ezekiel, which contains the reproach of the sons of Ammon and other nations, and the prophecy of future events, will have this beginning.


<h2 id='tocuniq246'>(Cap. XXV.)</h2>

(Chapter 25) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against the sons of Ammon, and prophesy against them. Say to the sons of Ammon: Hear the word of the Lord God. Thus says the Lord God: Because you said, 'Aha!' over my sanctuary when it was profaned, and over the land of Israel when it was desolate, and over the house of Judah when they went into exile, therefore behold, I am giving you to the people of the east for a possession, and they shall set their encampments in you and make their dwellings in you. They shall eat your fruit, and they shall drink your milk. I will make Rabbah a pasture for camels and the city of Ammon a place for flocks. Then you will know that I am the Lord. Because this is what the Lord God says: Because you clapped your hands and stomped your feet and rejoiced with all your heart and mocked the land of Israel, therefore I will stretch out my hand against you and deliver you to the plunder of the nations, and I will cut you off from the peoples and remove you from the lands. And you will know that I am the Lord. When Jerusalem was captured or besieged and those who could escape came to Babylon and reported that the city was about to be taken or that the temple had been destroyed, as was customary for all the prophets against the other surrounding nations who had mocked the ruins of Jerusalem and the burning of the temple, the prophetic message turns first against the sons of Ammon, who had a metropolis called Rabbath, which today is called Philadelphia by the king of Egypt, Ptolemy by the name of Philadelphus, who ruled Arabia with Judaea. Son, says he, of man, set your face against the sons of Ammon, who are descended from Lot, and say to them: Thus says the Lord God (these are not the words of prophets, but of the Lord. Concerning the hardening of the face, we have discussed this more fully in the same prophet): Because you have said: Aha, Aha, or you have insulted and rejoiced, because my temple and sanctuary have been defiled by the invasion of enemies, and over the land of Israel, because it is desolate, and especially over the house of Judah, that is, the two tribes that are now led into captivity: therefore I will also deliver you to the sons of Edom, whom we have interpreted as the Easterners. There is no doubt, O Midianites, that they border the entire wilderness of the land of Arabia, who have herds of camels, and multitudes of sheep and goats, and live by these resources. This is also narrated in the book of Judges (Judg. 6) as happening to the land of Israel, when the Midianites came and devoured all their regions as far as Gaza. Therefore, metaphorically speaking, by the Midianites, we understand the Ishmaelites and the Hagarenes, who are now called Saracens, taking for themselves the false name of Sarah, so that they may appear to have been born of a free and noble mistress. And it is said in reference to King Nebuchadnezzar and all his army, that he will come and take the city of Rabbath, which is either properly called by this name or because of its greatness. For Rabbath is said to be very great. And lest we doubt that Nebuchadnezzar overthrew Arabia after Jerusalem was captured, the Scripture testifies above: 'And you, son of man, set yourself two ways, Ammon and Jerusalem, and the sword of the king of Babylon will come.' And again: 'At the head of the road to the city he will cast it, and he will set the road so that the sword will come to Rabbath of the sons of Ammon, and to Judah in most fortified Jerusalem.' (Ezekiel, XXI, 19, 20). And again: Thus saith the Lord God to the children of Ammon, and to their reproach (vers. 28). So the sons of Cedem shall come and set up their tents, like shepherds, and they shall pitch their tents. They shall destroy your crops, and drink the milk and abundance of the land, bringing flocks of camels and people from all nations, so that the children of Ammon shall become a dwelling place for livestock, and by the necessity of evil they shall understand that the Lord himself is the one who predicted the future and ordered it to happen. But this was not enough for the sons of Ammon, that they insulted and said: 'Hooray, hooray over the temple and sanctuary of the Lord, which was polluted by the entrance of various nations'; but such was the lasciviousness of their insults, that the whole people clapped their hands and feet together, and with all the affection of their hearts cried out: because the land of Israel was desolate. Therefore, not by angels, nor by other ministries, but by the Lord himself, extending his hand to strike, he will deliver it to be plundered, not by camels and flocks of sheep, but more openly to the nations, so that it may be completely uprooted from the number of peoples, and perish, and be reduced to nothingness; and after it has been crushed, then it will understand that he himself is the Lord who judges all things, and has power over all the lands. We can understand, according to typology, the sons of Ammon, who were born from Lot in the cave, descendants of incest and drunkenness, as all heretics of whom Scripture and Apostle John say: 'They went out from us, but they were not of us. For if they had been of us, they would have continued with us' (1 John 2:19). These individuals were born from a deviant inclination, which is translated into our language as: 'Because they have all turned aside, together they have become useless; there is none who does good, not even one' (Psalm 14:3). Against these, the prophetic face is placed or strengthened, so that it may crush them with its severity, and it says to them: 'Because you insulted my Church during the time of persecution, because my sanctuary was polluted by the fault of various people, whether it be the fault of those who served me, or the cruelty of the enemies who persecuted me: even the land of Israel, which saw and understood God, is now desolate, devoid of the choir of virtues; and how the sons of the house of Judah, that is, those who confess God and have true faith and right confession, were led into captivity and ceased to serve the Lord': therefore, O everyone who insults, you will be handed over to the Eastern sons who have come from the true light and you will be handed over as an inheritance, so that you too may learn to confess the Lord. And by translation it is said that the sons of the East will place their tents over them, and pitch their tents, and drink milk, and eat fruits, and the city of former pride will become a dwelling place for camels, who, having laid aside the burden of sins, can enter through the eye of a needle (Matthew 19), and into the bed of the animals, which are led by a good shepherd (John 10), so that when they have done this, mixed and handed over to the shepherds of the East, they may understand that He himself is the Lord. And again he reproaches them, for why they insulted with excessive affection of heart the ruins of the people of God, and they considered the land of Israel completely deserted: for which they deserve the avenging hand of God, as those who had exceeded the measure of rejoicing and joy over the destruction of the house of Judah, should by no means be handed over to the sons of the East, but should be for the plundering of all nations, and should be killed from the peoples, and should perish, and should be crushed, and should by no means be considered from the offspring of Abraham, but should be believed to be so for all nations, and then they will know the magnitude of their evils, and their own destruction, and the killing of the people, that he himself is the Lord. What we understand in general about the Church can be understood about each individual saint, whom the people of the world and the enemy powers rejoice in their ruin, if they have lost their modesty over a long period of time: while the evil think of it as a consolation for their crimes if they have more partners in their crimes and punishment: and no one does this except the son of Ammon, that is, the son of the people, who is born in their decline.


<h2 id='tocuniq247'>(Vers. 8 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 8 and following) Thus says the Lord God: Because Moab and Seir said, 'Behold, like all the nations is the house of Judah,' therefore, behold, I will lay open the shoulder of Moab from the cities, namely, its 288 cities, and the glory of the land, Beth Jesimoth, Baal Meon, and Kiriathaim. And I will give it along with the sons of the East, as a possession, so that the sons of Ammon may not be remembered among the nations anymore. And I will execute judgments upon Moab, and they shall know that I am the Lord. LXX: This is what the Lord God says: Because Moab and Seir said, + 'Look, like all the nations, the house of Judah.' Therefore, behold, I will break the shoulder of Moab from its cities, the chosen land, the house of Beth Jasimoth, over the fountain of the sea city. I have given the sons of the East as an inheritance to the sons of Ammon, so that the name of the sons of Ammon will not be remembered among the nations. And I will execute judgments on Moab, and they shall know that I am the Lord. What we have interpreted and added from the edition of Theodotion is not found in the LXX. But in this place the Hebrews tell a fable. After the city was opened and the temple was unlocked, the sons of Ammon, Moab, and Seir entered the temple and saw the Cherubim protecting the mercy seat. And they said: Just as all nations worship idols, so Judah also has its own religious idols; and therefore, they say, the Lord is angry and has delivered them into captivity. But we say this, that they insulted the house of Judah when it was captured by the Chaldeans, thinking that, like in other nations, there was no help of God there. And therefore, the kingdom of Judah, and Jerusalem, deprived of the protection of God, fell under the power of Babylon. Therefore, not long afterwards, but at present, the Lord threatens that he will destroy, or rather open, the shoulder, namely the strength and power of Moab from its cities, so that even the victorious Babylonians may enter and the cities in Moab may cease to exist, and the famous cities within its borders and boundaries may be destroyed: among which are mentioned the names Beth Jesimoth, Beelmeon, and Kiriathaim: for which the Seventy have translated something unknown, the house of Beth Iasimuth, which this word signifies a deserted town: and Beelmeon, until today, is a very large village, which they translated as 'over 289 fountain', and Kiriathaim, a maritime city: and it is reported that it along with the sons of Ammon from the East, namely the Babylonians, according to the interpretation we have given against the sons of Ammon. And I will give, says the Lord, Moab as an inheritance, so that just as there is no longer any memory of the children of Ammon among the nations, so also I will do vengeance and judgments on Moab, so that they may know that I am the Lord, who delivered Judah because of sin, and I will be the avenger on the children of Ammon and on Moab. However, to this day Moab, which is interpreted as 'from the father,' and Seir, which is translated as 'hairy' and 'rough,' despises and looks down upon the house of Judah, in which the true confession is, and thinks that it can be easily destroyed as the defenses of other cities are destroyed. And the Lord threatens to open himself up, or to break down all the strength of the Moabites, so that the cities may cease to exist, and they may not at all trust in the art of dialectic. But all those boundaries, which they call promontories for the purpose of illusion of the waves, shall be destroyed; and the famous and chosen land of Beth Jesimoth, which translates to 'house of solitude and desert,' and Beelmeon, which also means having a spring, or above a spring, and Cariathaim, which the LXX translated as a maritime city, shall perish. Although they may have the strength of warriors, and they continue to excel in the art of fighting, and they walk surrounded and fortified on all sides, yet their famous land is not a home of habitation, but a home of solitude. And what they think they possess as a source of knowledge, and a maritime city, which can withstand all the storms of the world, promising themselves patience and fortitude: yet they will be turned there, to be handed over to the children of the East, the true light in Christ; just as the sons of Ammon were handed over, who trusted in themselves in the multitude of heresy. And let us consider the progress, and in the very threat the mercy of God, so that the sons of Ammon, the sons of the East, are delivered as an inheritance; and let no heresy be named among the Gentiles; but by their acts, let them know that the Lord, who manages all things, will bring them to an end with his judgments and punishments for their arrogance. But to prove that in this place Moab is understood as the pride of philosophers, concerning whom it is said: I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and the discernment of the discerning I will thwart (1 Corinthians 1:19), a few examples from the prophets must be repeated. Amos speaks: Thus says the Lord: Concerning the three transgressions of Moab, and concerning the four I will not revoke the punishment, because he burned the bones of the king of Edom to lime  (Amos 2:1). Truly, whatever is of perverse doctrine in the world, whatever pertains to earthly knowledge, and is considered to be strong, is subverted by the art of dialectic, and is dissolved like fire into ashes and embers; so that what was thought to be the strongest may be proven to be nothing. But Isaiah reproves the pride of Moab, saying: We have heard the pride of Moab, he is exceedingly proud: his pride is taken away. (Isaiah 16). Jeremiah also, prophesying against all the nations, speaks specifically to Moab: Because you trusted in your fortresses. (Jeremiah 48:7). And a little later: You will have confidence in your glory. And again: How do you say, We are mighty? And then: The day of Moab is approaching, and its malice is very swift. (Ibid. 14:10). And more clearly: Say how the glorious staff is broken, the rod of magnificence (Ibid., 20)? And again: The horn of Moab is broken. But these things are said, so that under the name of Moab, the foolishness of the world, exalting itself to heaven, may be crushed by pride.

<h2 id='tocuniq248'>(Vers. 12, 13, seqq.)</h2>

(Verses 12, 13, and following) Thus says the Lord God: Because Edom has acted vengefully and has taken revenge on the people of Judah, thus they have incurred guilt by their acts of disobedience, and have sought vengeance against them. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: I will stretch out my hand against Edom and cut off from it both man and beast. I will make it a desolation from the south, and those who are in Dedan shall fall by the sword. I will execute my vengeance upon Edom by the hand of my people Israel. I will deal with Edom according to my anger and my wrath, and they shall know my indignation, declares the Lord God. LXX: Thus says the Lord God: Because Edom acted revengefully against the house of Judah and incurred grievous guilt by taking vengeance upon them, therefore thus says the Lord God, I will stretch out my hand against Edom, and cut off from it humans and animals, and make it desolate; from Teman to Dedan they shall fall by the sword. I will execute my vengeance upon Edom by the hand of my people Israel; and they shall act in Edom according to my anger and according to my wrath; and they shall know my vengeance, says the Lord God. Above, they have proposed two things: because they said Moab and Seir, and later about Seir, remaining silent, he only spoke against Moab: now he returns to the problem that Seir, that is, Edom, has made. Whoever has knowledge of the Scriptures should have no doubt that Esau and Seir, and Edom, and Idumea, and Duma, are all one people. And not to mention the other prophets, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Amos, who prophesied against Idumea, Duma, and Edom: Obadiah directs his whole prophecy against this nation, which we have discussed before as much as we could. Seir, who was hairy, received the name 'hairy' and Edom the bloody, who lost his birthright because of the cooking of a red lentil, received his name from his hunger. Esau's actions are also interpreted. And it should be known that in Hebrew it is never written Idumaea, but always Edom, which the Greek translation expressed as Idumaea. Therefore, it is by no means Idumaea (Edom), as Moab spoke, but he took vengeance on the children of Judah: and he sinned, or held the memory of ancient pain, in order to take vengeance on them, from whom he was supplanted in the womb. Therefore, not through angels, nor through any other: but the Lord himself, stretching out his hand over Edom, took away from it man and beast, and reduced its cities into a desert, that is, Themam, which we turn into the south: from which and from another city Dedan, they will be slain with the sword. And when they have taken vengeance on Judah, I will give vengeance upon the Edomites by the hand of my people Israel: that they may do justice upon them, in whom they have exercised vengeance. Those who act in Edom, or Idumea, according to my anger and fury, to fulfill my indignation, and through the hands of my people Israel, let my wrath rage against the enemy nation, and they will understand that my just vengeance was against the unjust revenge of Idumea, says the Lord Adonai. According to allegory, this is the meaning that seems to me. Idumea is called earthly and carnal, which rises against the spirit, so that we do not do things that are of the spirit, and it hastens to draw the soul placed in its midst to itself; and it seeks to render vengeance, to which it had previously been subjected by the sons of Judah, and it remembers the ancient pain, that it did not have its own power, and therefore it sought vengeance against those who, departing from the flesh, followed the spirit. Therefore the Lord himself, being the avenger of the children of Judah, stretched forth his hand upon Edom, and took away the man and the beast out of it, so that it became a desolation. And from Theman, which signifies failing, and from Dedan, which also signifies kindred, he destroyed them all by the sword, whom he had appointed in the hand of his people Israel, that they might subvert Edom, and that Edom might know his wrath and anger, and understand his revenge, so that it may serve the house of Judah. This is that which the Apostle disputes about, writing: Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated (Rom. IX, 13). But Jacob is loved, because he supplants and overcomes the carnal and earthly, and deserves to receive his blessings. First we live according to the flesh, and afterwards according to the spirit. Before vices, and then virtues, by which vices are destroyed, because the heart of man is inclined towards wickedness from childhood, and the mature age condemns the errors of youth (Genes. VIII). And David also said: Remember not the sins of my youth, nor my ignorance (Psalm 24:7). And yet it should be known that Jacob received the first blessing, Esau the second. And what is said about him at the end: You will be your brother's servant (Genesis 27:40), this signifies that after the flesh is subjected to the spirit and joined to it, it ceases to be flesh and transitions from Edom to Judah.

<h2 id='tocuniq249'>(Vers. 15, 16.)</h2>

(v. 15, 16) Thus says the Lord God: Because the Philistines acted in vengeance and took revenge with wholehearted malice, destroying in their anger and perpetuating ancient hostilities. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will stretch out my hand against the Philistines and cut off the killers, and I will destroy the remaining inhabitants of the coast. I will execute great acts of vengeance upon them with furious rebukes, and they shall know that I am the Lord when I lay my vengeance upon them. LXX: Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because the foreigners have executed vengeance and provoked insult from the heart in order to destroy forever, therefore thus says the Lord God: Indeed, I will stretch out my hand against the foreigners and I will destroy them, I will even slay the Philistines and I will exterminate the remnant of the coastal region, and I will execute great vengeance upon them with furious wrath, and they will know that I am the Lord God when I execute my vengeance upon them. After the sons of Ammon, Moab, and Seir, who themselves are Edomites, associate with the people of Israel through Lot and Esau, and with the house of Judah through kinship, they came to the Philistines, whom the Seventy translated as 'foreigners,' that is, aliens, not under the general name of all the nations that are not of the Jewish race, but under the specific name of their own nation, which is now called Palestine, with the letter 'P' changed to 'Pi' (π), according to the Greek custom, just as among us the Hebrew word 'Phase' is celebrated in Greek and Latin as 'Pascha.' The Philistines are interpreted as those who fall by a cup, who themselves were also intoxicated by the golden cup of Babylon, and rage, and insult with all their hearts, remembering the ancient hostilities against Israel, by which they were separated from the people of God. And when the Lord says: Vengeance is mine, and I will repay (Deut. XXXII, 35), they take revenge by killing and fulfilling ancient hatred. Therefore, they will experience the outstretched hand of the Lord upon them, which will kill the killers. For concerning the Seventy, I do not know what they wanted, the Cretans had interpreted, when both Aquila and Symmachus, and Theodotion himself had translated the Hebrew word Chorethim as either murderers or murder, not only in the present place, but also in Zephaniah, where these things are said against the Palestinians: Gaza shall be plundered, and Ascalon unto desolation, and Ashdod and Ekron shall be rooted out. Woe to the inhabitants of the sea-coast, the people of the Cretans! The word of the Lord is upon you, O Canaan, the land of the foreigners, and I will destroy you from your dwellings, and Crete shall be for the pasture of shepherds, and the fold of sheep (Zephaniah 2:4-9). And here, indeed, when the Seventy translated it into Greek, the other translators rendered 'ὄλεθρον' ((Al. κάῤῥον)) as 'interfection' or 'perdition'. Concerning this, in the aforementioned prophet, by God's favor, we have said what seemed right to us. Therefore, even the two legions of David, one of which was called Phelethi and the other Cerethi (2 Samuel 15), earned the name of Cherethim ((Al. Cherethim)), meaning 'slayers', from their last act of killing and slaying 294 people. And the Lord will destroy all the remnants of the maritime region, which is pounded by salty [or false] waves, and He will exact not small, but great vengeance in His fury, so that His fury may have an end of mercy, and after He has taken revenge, reproving with fury, then the Philistines will know that He Himself is the Lord.

<h2 id='tocuniq250'>(Cap. XXVI.)</h2>

(Chapter 26) And it came to pass in the eleventh year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, because Tyre (or Sor) has said of Jerusalem: Aha, the gates of the peoples (or nations) are broken, she has turned to me, I will be replenished, she is made desolate (or she who was full is now desolate); therefore thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, Tyre (or Sor), and I will bring many nations against you, as the sea raises its waves. And they shall break down the walls of Tyre, and destroy its towers, and I will scrape away its dust from it, and I will make it a shining rock. The drying up of the nets will be in the midst of the sea, for I have spoken, says the Lord God, and it will be for the plundering of the nations. Also, her daughters who are in the field will be killed by the sword, and they will know that I am the Lord. Then the order of the prophecies will be fulfilled. He spoke against the sons of Ammon and Moab and Seir, who themselves are Edomites, and against the Philistines who are on the coast and hold the same boundary by the sea. After the Philistines, the region of Phoenicia follows, whose metropolis is the city of Tyre, which is called Tyre in Hebrew and Syriac. And because Jerusalem was captured, it also rejoiced and taunted, saying: 'The gates of the peoples are broken, I have the safest harbor, and when it is overthrown, all the multitude turned to me, which was governed at its pleasure, and because it is deserted, therefore I will be filled, and whatever was full before will be reduced to solitude.' Therefore, since you have said these things and have insulted the ruins of Jerusalem, which was destroyed by the judgment of God because of its sins, I will not send messengers or anyone else, but I myself will be against you, Tyre, and I will make the Babylonians rise up like the waves of the sea against you, along with many nations. They will destroy your walls and towers in such a way that they will fall to the ground and their dust will be scraped away or scattered in various directions. And so, it will be humbled, like the most shining stone, and there will be such a desolation in the once bustling city, that fishing nets will be spread out and dried in its midst. For I, the Lord, have spoken, and my words cannot be in vain, and I will deliver it into the hands of the nations for plunder. Also, her daughters, who are in the field or in the countryside, that is, on the coast of Phoenicia, cities and towns, villages and castles, will be slain by the sword. Metaphorically, because he called them daughters, he puts the killing by the sword, so that they may know at the end of things that I am the Lord, who commanded these things to happen. According to the allegory, because 'Sor' in Hebrew means 'anguish,' every soul that is occupied with disturbances can be called 'Sor,' which, when it sees Jerusalem overturned by God's judgment for its own faults and sins, in which there was the temple and the vision of peace, rejoices and thinks that the empire of the once famous city is to be transferred to itself. And this is accepted in opposing doctrines and in the people of the world, when they see a holy person fall through negligence and rejoice and exult, as if their fall were their own resurrection. Therefore the Lord threatens that He Himself will fight against such people and will cause many nations to rise up against them like the waves of the sea, which will destroy whatever seems most fortified and firm in them, and thus overthrow all their arguments, reducing them to dust. He should also make the nets and fishing gear with which they previously deceived the multitude cease, and spread them out and dry them in the deserted soil of the city, so that other fishermen may take their place, whom the Lord has sent to fish. And let his daughters, who were previously kept as if in a chamber and were not easily believed in mystical and more secret teachings, be brought forth and prolonged in public, and be cut down by the sword of the Church, so that they may understand that He himself is the Lord, who both temporarily left Jerusalem for sins, and destroyed the fortifications of Tyre for its insolence and joy.


<h2 id='tocuniq251'>296 (Vers. 6 seq.)</h2>

296 (Verse 6 onwards) For thus says the Lord: Behold, I will bring against Tyre (or against you, O Tyre) Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon from the north, the king of kings, with horses and chariots, and with horsemen and a great army. He will kill your daughters who are in the field with the sword, and he will build siege works against you, and raise up a siege mound against you, and raise up a shield against you. He will make weapons of war against your walls, and destroy your towers with his armor. The inundation of his horses will cover you with their dust, your walls will be shaken by the sound of the horses, chariots, and wheels, when he enters your gates as if entering a destroyed city (or as if entering a city from the countryside). With the hooves of his horses, he will trample all your streets; he will kill your people with the sword, and your noble statues will fall to the ground (or your sources of strength will be brought down to the ground). They will plunder (or ravage) your wealth and destroy (or demolish) your merchandise, and tear down (or destroy) your walls, and overthrow (or turn over) your splendid (or desirable) houses, and they will place (or throw) your stones and wood and dust in the middle of the waters (or in the middle of the sea). And I will make the multitude of your singers (or destroy the multitude of your musicians), and the sound of your harps (or the voice of your organs) will not be heard anymore. And I will make you into the most transparent (or most shining) rock. You will be the drying up of the snares, and you will no longer be built upon, for I have spoken, says the Lord God. I have joined together both editions in the usual manner, and in those things in which they differ, I have brought them together on the side, providing for the brevity of volumes. Therefore, what he had said, I will make many nations ascend to you as the fluctuating sea ascends, and Tyre will be a spoil for the nations, then he explains more clearly that the Lord will bring King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon from the North, the king of kings, with horses and chariots, and with an infinite multitude of troops, who will first overthrow the cities and fortresses subject to Tyre on the shoreline, and afterwards make Tyre be besieged, and he will assault it with an army and siege ramps, and fortifications, and vines and rams and destroy the walls, and his cavalry will be so numerous that the foundations of the city will be moved by the dust of the cavalry, the noise of the howling army, and the sound of the wheels and the neighing of the horses, and thus he will enter the city with the walls scattered, as if entering from the field without fear, and there will be such security for the victorious army that the hooves of the horses will trample the streets of Tyre, and all the people in the middle of the city will fall, and the once noble statues, or all the wealth, will fall to the ground, and none of the former riches will be preserved in the conquered city, but even the noble houses will be destroyed along with the walls, and there will be such cruelty of the victors that the remaining wood and stones that were burned will be thrown into the middle of the sea, and either Nebuchadnezzar or the Lord himself will cause all the joy of the city, which was once resounding in songs and psalms, to cease, and it will be reduced to the drying up of the snares. And what follows: 'You shall not be built up any more,' seems to raise the question of how Tyre, which we see today as the most famous and beautiful city of the Phoenicians, was not built up. From this, some suppose that in the latter days Tyre will suffer these things, which will not be rebuilt afterwards. But how can they preserve the persona of Nebuchadnezzar, especially since we read in the following passages that Nebuchadnezzar besieged Tyre and did not receive the reward of his labor, and for this reason Egypt was handed over to him, because he served God's purpose in the siege of Tyre? The Greeks and Phoenicians, and especially Nicolaus Damascenus, and others of the Barbarians, who contradict this history, are said to have read the histories and to have found nothing about the siege of the city of Tyre by the Chaldeans, when we can prove that many things are said in the Scriptures which are not found in the Greek books; nor should we submit to their authority, whose treachery and lies we detest. Therefore, the statement, 'you shall be built no more,' can be understood to mean that she will no longer be the queen of peoples, nor will she have her own empire, as she had under Hiram and the other kings; but rather that she will be subject to the Chaldeans, or the Macedonians, or the Ptolemies, and finally to the Roman kings. But there is no doubt that by anagoge we understand King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, who came from the North, as the devil, who, although he is a very harsh and evil wind, is called by the name "right" because he presumes for himself the dignity of a name, and is the king of kings and of all kingdoms, which he shows to the Lord, and he said to him: All these things have been given to me, which I will give you if you fall down and worship me (Matt. 4:9). This one has horses and chariots, of which it is written: A deceitful horse for salvation (Ps. 32:17). And: All who ascended horses slept (Ps. LXXV). And in another place: He threw horse and rider into the sea (Exod. XV, 1). This one kills the daughters of Tyre, souls confined in distress and in a certain prison of sin, in the field and widest plain, and surrounds Tyre with its fortifications, so as to keep it closed and no one can escape the authority of the Babylonian king. He will destroy walls and overthrow towers, and whatever he had by way of teachings, he will shake with the flood of his horses and the sound of the horses' hooves and the noise of the chariots, and he will enter its gates, with no one to prohibit, and the streets of the city: For the way is broad and spacious that leads to death (Matth. VII, 13), his horses' hooves will trample it, and all his possessions or noble statues, for which they had made false images for themselves, of which it is written: O Lord, in your city you will dissipate their images (Ps. LXXII, 20), he will cast down to the ground, and with the walls destroyed, the noble houses will also be overthrown, which he had prepared for himself, and in which he rejoiced, and it will come to such great desolation that its stones and the wood with which he built the walls, and the cement he used, will be thrown into the abyss, and his songs and music, in which he placed his trust in the wisdom of this world, and the sound of all the harps will no longer be heard, and his fishing will cease, and he will be brought low, like the drying up of reeds, and will be built no more, for according to the judgement of the Lord, it has been completely overthrown, as the Apostle also says: Whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme (I Tim. I, 20). The places are difficult, and a wise and diligent reader must forgive my effort. Or if he can find something better, I will defer to his judgment, as long as he knows the forgiveness he will grant me, he will receive it from others.

<h2 id='tocuniq252'>(Vers. 15 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 and following) Thus says the Lord God to Tyre: Will not the sound of your destruction, and the groaning of those slain in your midst, shake the islands? And all the princes of the sea will descend from their thrones, and they will take off their garments and cast away their beautiful clothes, and they will be clothed with astonishment. They will sit on the ground, and be astonished at your sudden downfall. They will take up a lamentation over you, and say to you: How you have perished, you prominent city, you strong city, which was feared by all its inhabitants! Now the ships will be astonished on the day of your terror, and the islands in the sea will be disturbed, because no one will come out from you. LXX: For thus says the Lord God Sor. Will they not groan at the sound of your ruin, when your wounded ones groan, when the sword is drawn out in your midst, the islands will be moved, and all the princes of the sea will come down from their thrones, and they will take off their crowns, and they will be stripped of their various garments? They will rage with fury: they will sit on the ground, and they will fear for their destruction, and they will groan over you, and they will take up a lamentation for you, and they will say to you: How you have perished and been destroyed in the sea, O praised city, that was strong in the sea itself, and its inhabitants, who gave their fear to all its inhabitants? And the islands will tremble on the day of your ruin, and the islands in the sea will be disturbed at your departure. First, let us explain the meaning of these words briefly by providing a brief translation. Thus says the Lord God to Tyre, which is called Sor in Hebrew (): Will the islands not be shaken on the day of your ruin, when Nebuchadnezzar attacks, and when you fall in the midst of the groans of the wounded or killed, will the islands not be disturbed? And all the kings will descend from their seats, or thrones, and the princes of the sea who rule over various islands, and they will take off the diadems from their heads, laying aside all the glory of reigning and the most precious garments, shining with incredible variety. They will cast them away and, overwhelmed by the magnitude of their astonishment, they will turn to madness, and, humbled, they will sit on the ground. And when they see you have fallen, they will fear something similar for themselves. And they will think that nothing in the goods of the earth is perpetual, but instead they will take up a lamentation and sing a mournful song, saying: How have you perished, you who dwelled (Alternative: you who dwelt) in the sea, renowned or praised city?" } For we read in Greek, Latin, and Barbarian histories that Tyre was indeed an island and had no entrance from the land. But later, it was either thrown up by king Nebuchadnezzar of the Chaldeans or, as some affirm, by Alexander the Great, king of the Macedonians, with mounds being thrown up and a place being prepared for the assault with engines of war and towers. Thus, the island became a peninsula. Therefore, oh Tyre, oh Sor, who once were the strongest of all islands, praised by the voice of all people, both in cities and with your inhabitants, whom all feared, how did you suddenly fall? Now the islands will be astonished or terrified over you, and as it is better understood in Hebrew, ships, on the day of your terror and ruin, and the islands in the sea will be troubled. Therefore, it is more fitting to read 'ships' instead of 'islands' so that they are not placed in a favorable position; because no one will go out from you, or as the Septuagint translated, on the day of your departure: when you are led captive. These, for now, have been laid as certain foundations of history: now we will strive to place the spiritual pinnacle. Imagine someone who, having preserved their chastity for a long time and excelled in many virtues, later collapsed into a serious and mortal sin. Will not all the islands be moved by the sound of his ruin and the death of his virtues? Especially those who are battered by the salty and bitter waves of this world. And the princes who seemed to be rulers in the filth of this age will descend from their thrones, humbled by their pride. They will remove the crowns from their heads, which seemed to possess good works, and cast off the various garments of virtue. They will be clothed in amazement, a kind of madness born from fear. They will sit on the ground, stunned by his sudden fall, and admire him in astonishment. So much so that everyone will assume mourning and lamentation for him who has fallen, saying: How did you perish, who were once saved? How you have fallen, who stood for so long, who among all the illustrious in the sea of this world were considered strong, who were thought to be strong by everyone! And your inhabitants, these are the most valiant thoughts, resisting all the fiery darts of the devil, which were previously feared by all adversaries, have been turned to astonishment. But even the ships, all of them holy, which cross the waves of this world, will be amazed when they see you have fallen. On the day of your panic and ruin, the islands will be thrown into confusion, lest they suffer the same. For the ruins of others are examples of the righteous, while we all dwell in a weak and feeble state, and never is our victory certain and secure: when those who stood before will depart from you; or in your departure; in the end and consummation of your time. For we are judged not by the past, but by the present. And caution must be observed, and always feared, lest it undermine old glory and solid steadfastness, the storms of a single hour.

<h2 id='tocuniq253'>(Vers. 19 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 19 onwards) For thus saith the Lord (the Vulgate adds God): When I shall make thee a desolate city, like the cities that are not inhabited, and shall bring upon thee the deep, and many waters shall cover thee; and I shall bring thee down with those that descend into the pit (or to them that descend into the pit), to the people of old, and shall place thee in the lowest parts of the earth (or in the depths of the earth), like the ancient wilderness, with those that are brought down into the pit (or descend into the pit), that thou mayest not be inhabited, and (the Vulgate adds moreover) when I shall give glory in the land of the living (or that thou mayest not rise again in the land of the living), I shall bring thee to nothing (or give thee destruction), and thou shalt not be, and thou shalt not be sought for (the Vulgate adds anymore) forever, saith the Lord God. When I deliver you, O Tyre, a city devastated forever, just like there are other cities that are not inhabited at all, and when I bring upon you the abyss and many waters cover you, or countless hordes of enemies, or certainly the one who speaks of the island and compares the frequency of adversaries to the waves of the abyss surging against the city on the island in a metaphorical sense; and when I drag you down with those who descend into the pit or the abyss, to those who are in the underworld, of whom we read in the Psalms: They will go down to the depths of the earth; they will be given into the hands of the sword, their portion will be as prey for foxes (Ps. 62:10-11); to the eternal people, where there is weeping of the eyes and gnashing of teeth, and when I place you in the last land, where the ancient dragon is established, and it is like the ancient deserts and wastelands, where there is no memory of good things, but rather eternal punishments, and I will not allow you to rise again in the land of the living, as it is written: Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth (Matthew 5:4) . And in another place: I shall please the Lord in the land of the living (Ps. CXIV, 9): then you shall be reduced to nothing, or perish forever, and you will be no more, according to what is written in another psalm: Grant me respite before I depart, and I shall be no more (Ps. XXXVIII, 14). Not that one who is in eternal punishment ceases to exist, but that one who does not live for God, is said in the Holy Scriptures not to subsist. And Esther also speaking against idols: Do not give your scepter, she says, to those who are not (Esther XIV). Surely there were those to whom she pleaded not to give it; but they were not of God, who had ceased to have virtues and to be alive in God. And it should be noted that Tyre is sought by him who comes to seek and save what was lost, and ninety-nine sheep were left on the mountains, he seeks one lost sheep (Luke XIX). Also, a woman who had lost one drachma seeks, finds it, and calls her neighbors to share in the joy (Ibid., 15). But if Tyrus is not found, it is not the fault of the seeker, but of the one who has fled the hand of the good shepherd. And moreover, he says, you will not be forever; whether it is written in Hebrew as 'Lolam', or in Greek as 'αἰῶν', it signifies one age, according to the saying of Isaiah, who after seventy years says that Tyre will be restored to its former state (Isaiah 23). However, they say that one age, that is, the time span of a human life, is calculated by the number of seventy years, as the Psalmist says: The days of our years are seventy years." } But in the rulers, eighty years, whatever is above, is labor and pain (Ps.
