LXXXIX, 10). This we have briefly said in a metaphrastic way about Tyre. Which can also be referred to those who are placed in the narrowness of this world, are led to the underworld, and are covered by the abyss and the waves of punishments, and are drawn to the depths of the earth, and are united with those who are in the old solitude, and are led into the lake, or into the eternal pit, so that they are no longer inhabited by the Holy Spirit. Of which it is written: When the wicked falls into the depth of evils, he despises (Prov. XVIII, 3). They will no longer exist on the land of the living, but they will perish and be reduced to nothing, and they will cease to be with God. They misuse these testimonies, who say that the punishments of the wicked and not of the sinners are eternal: those who sought from God, were not found, and have ceased to exist forever: for they have lost him by their own vice, who says: I am the life (John XIV, 6).


<h2 id='tocuniq254'>(Cap. XXVII.)</h2>

(Chapter 27) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Therefore, son of man, take up a lamentation for Tyre, and say to Tyre, who dwells at the entrance of the sea, conducting trade with many peoples (or from many islands). Thus says the Lord God: If I were to summarize the entire prophecy against Tyre, or concerning the lamentation for Tyre, in one discourse, it would be lengthy and difficult for the reader to understand; for one cannot retain everything at once in the mind, especially regarding the discrepancies between the Hebrew and Septuagint versions in this passage, namely, what they have added or subtracted. So we will be content with our interpretation, and wherever there is disagreement, we will connect it from the side, leaving the perfect knowledge of God to all: and we will briefly remind what seems to us in each. He who is mourned, is still cared for by the one who mourns. Hence Samuel wept and mourned for Saul (2 Samuel 15). And the apostle Paul laments and grieves for those who have fornicated and have not repented (2 Corinthians 12). And Jeremiah wrote Lamentations on the destruction of Jerusalem in four alphabets. He dwells, therefore, in Tyre, or Sor, in the entranceways, following the order of the alphabet: either because it was formerly an island, or because it receives ships coming from the deep into a very safe harbor, and it is a place of trade for many peoples, or from many islands. Indeed, this continues even today, so that the commerce of almost all nations is carried out there. But following the interpretation that has been started, whatever is said about Tyre, let us refer it to 'narrowness,' that is, the narrowness of this world, which is situated in the wicked one, and is confined and beaten by various disturbances, like waves. Of such merchants is told in mystical language in the psalm: 'They that go down to the sea in ships, doing business in the great waters. These have seen the works of the Lord, and his wonders in the deep.' (Psalm 106:23-24).

<h2 id='tocuniq255'>(Vers. 3.)</h2>

(Verse 3.) O Tyre, you have said, 'I am the perfection of beauty' (or you have said, 'I have surrounded myself with beauty') and situated in the heart of the sea. The first crime of Tyre is to think that if it possesses anything good, it is not from God but from itself, and to consider all the beauty that comes to it from various regions as a result of its own diligence and virtue. For it has said: 'I am the perfection of beauty' or 'I have surrounded myself with beauty', even though it is situated in the heart, that is, in the middle of the sea, and like an island it moves, and it is tossed by waves, and it is shattered by the crashing of the waves." } But as for the heart of the sea, it signifies the middle, and that prophetic speech demonstrates: Therefore we shall not fear when the earth is troubled, and the mountains are carried into the heart of the sea. Their waters have roared and been troubled (Psalm 45:2-3). But our Lord is said to have descended into the heart of the earth, that is, into the middle and the underworld. However, true and perfect beauty is found in no man, except in the body of Christ, which is interpreted as the Church, and is gathered by the virtues of many saints. And he himself speaks to the bride: You are all beautiful, my love, and there is no blemish in you (Song of Solomon 4:7).

<h2 id='tocuniq256'>(Vers. 4, 5.)</h2>

(Verse 4, 5) Your neighbors who built you have adorned you. They built you with cedars from Mount Hermon and with all the boards of the sea. They took cedar from Lebanon to make mischief for you. As for what they desired, I do not know, but the Septuagint translates it as: Your sons of Baalim surrounded you with adornment; cedar from Mount Hermon was built for you; they took fine cypress boards from Lebanon to make evil for you with fir. For the speech of Baal is not found in this place among the Hebrews, but it is written 'Gebulaic', which means 'your borders'. Moreover, your sons have been deceived by the ambiguity of the word and the similarity of the writing, as the same letters are read as both 'builders' and 'sons', 'Bonaich' and 'Benaich', due to their different pronunciation. Therefore, O Tyre, who have boasted in pride, I am the perfect beauty, or I have surrounded myself with beauty, listen to how much God's generosity has been bestowed upon you, even though you are situated in the middle of the sea. Your neighbors and bordering people, who are not from distant regions but from nearby, have filled your decoration, and you think what is yours is actually someone else's? And he speaks metaphorically, comparing the city to a ship, signifying its beauty and abundance of all things. After he describes the entire furniture of the ship - mast, sails, oars, rudder, keel, ropes, coverings, hides, and other things that the use of a well-equipped ship requires - he announces that a storm and a south wind, which will stir up very high waves, will come and cause it to suffer shipwreck. Through these things, the destruction of the Tyrian city is signified by King Nebuchadnezzar, or, as many think, by Alexander, the king of the Macedonians, who is said to have besieged and captured the city herself for six months after he defeated Darius in Lycia. According to mystical interpretation, the planks of the Tyrian ship are cut from the fir or cedar trees of Senir, with which it is woven and joined together, and the mast of it is made of cedar or cypress from Lebanon: the fir trees because of their lightness and the softness of the joints of the planks, which fit together gently and bite into each other; or cedar, because it is an incorruptible wood. But Sanir is said to mean 'the way of the lamp', or as we think more accurately, 'the tooth of the watchmen', because all the prosperity and enlightenment of a ship comes from true light. Sanir, however, is the mountain itself, which is also called Hermon, or what others call Sanior. Read the history. Lebanon means whiteness or bleaching, which itself contributes to beauty coming from elsewhere.

<h2 id='tocuniq257'>(Vers. 6.)</h2>

(Verse 6.) The oaks of Bashan have flexed against your oars: they made your benches out of Indian ivory, and the cabins out of the islands of Italy. LXX: They made your oars and your temples out of Bashan, and they made wild homes for you out of ivory from the islands of the Hittites. What beauty the ship has, and its furnishings, to have oars made of cedar, not just any, but from Bashan, and ivory benches, and cabins, or cellars, in which the most precious merchandise is stored, from the islands of the Hittites, which we turn towards Italy: from that region which is closer to Greece, understanding all the western parts of the islands. Let us say, therefore, according to the anagoge, that the oars of the Tyrian ship are made from Bazan, of which it is also written in the Psalms: 'The Lord has said, I will turn Bazan from the depth of the sea' (Ps. LXVII, 23). Bazan, in our language, means ignominy. Therefore, God turns those who were in the depth of the sea, and the ignominy of sins, into oars, so that, sailing with the Apostles, they may be able to reach the land and the shores; and the oars are made of ivory, when they have mortified their bodies; or they may turn the use of their teeth to the praise of God, and the little cribs or cellars of the isles of “Chettiim,” which, according to the etymology of the Hebrew language, is translated as smitten, so that it may not only be killed by the blows of the devil, but also approved. We can speak of the houses made of ivory, and the wild homes of the Chettiim islands, which the heretics attempt to build not in the house of God, but on a Tyrian ship. And they, having their own language and tongues, building temples of God contrary to the temple, and wild homes, dwellings of beasts, when the Scripture says that groves, woods, and forests are not to be planted in the house of God (Deut. XII).

<h2 id='tocuniq258'>(Vers. 7.)</h2>

(Verse 7.) Various byssus woven in Egypt is made into a veil for you, to be placed in a vessel: hyacinth and purple from the islands of Elisa have become your covering. LXX: Byssus with variety from Egypt is made into a bed for you, to surround you with glory, and to cover you with hyacinth and purple, made from the islands of Elissa are your coverings. Because Tyre had said, I am perfect in beauty, or I have surrounded myself with beauty, it is pointed out what it has received from each region, according to the Scripture: What do you have that you did not receive? But if you have received, why do you boast as if you have not received (1 Cor. 4:7)? Therefore, it is described what each province should send, according to that of Virgil (Georg., 1st book):

India sends ivory, soft incense from the Sabaeans; the Chalybes send hard iron, and Pontus its men skilled in Castor's art, and so on. Fine linen grows in abundance in Egypt, from which the sail of Tyrian ships is woven, which is hung from the mast, and its covering, which provides shade to sailors and passengers in the heat and calm of the sun, is made from hyacinth and purple dye; these come from the Elisa islands, which are called the islands of the Ionian Sea. Moreover, next to the seventy byssus are woven into a layer, and into the rest of the Tyrian ship's coverings, so that it may be more glorious covered with them, and have a more beautiful appearance surrounded by a garment. However, byssus is said to come from the earth, because it originates from the earth, and hyacinth from the air, purple from the sea from which it is made, with the addition of double-dyed scarlet, with which the vestments of the Pontiff are woven, we have often reminded that they symbolize the four elements: earth, fire, air, and water, from which all things consist, which Tyre assumes for herself, not using them with grace for God's creatures, but saying: I am the perfect beauty: or, I have surrounded myself with beauty.


<h2 id='tocuniq259'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Verse 8, 9.) The inhabitants of Sidon and Arad were your oarsmen. Your wise men, Tyre, became your helmsmen. The elders of Biblus and its wise men provided sailors for the various goods of your inventory. All the ships of the sea, and their sailors, were among the people of your commerce. LXX: Your princes dwelt in Sidon, and the oarsmen were from Arvad. Your wise men, O Tyre, were your helmsmen. The elders of the Bible, and its wise men, were in you; they fortified your counsel, and all the ships of the sea, and their rowers became yours to the farthest west. It had been said before: Your neighbors who built you up, completed your adornment: before those who lived far away come to you, it describes the help of neighboring provinces. Your inhabitants, it says, or the leaders of Sidon and Arad, which is a nearby island, your rowers. Your wise men, O Tyre, have become your navigators. For the governance properly belongs to the wise, as the Scripture says: 'Where there is no guidance, a people falls, but in an abundance of counselors there is safety' (Prov. XI, sec. LXX). The elders or seniors of the Bible, and its wise men, provided sailors for your service, or strengthened the council of Tyre, and supplied various goods: and all the ships of the sea, and their sailors were in the people of Tyrian trade, or in the farthest west. In the literal sense, for the time being. However, according to the mystical interpretations, because they are understood as hunters of Sidonius and Aradius, we will say that Tyre, the glorious and most proud city, which, with the wind blowing, will be greatly hunted, has citizens or princes as hunters, about whom it is written: Our soul has been snatched away like a sparrow from the snare of the hunters. For where we read 'hunters,' it is written in Hebrew, 'of the Sidonians.' These come upon unwary souls, established in lofty places, in order to lead them down to earthly things, and they become rowers, to guide them to shipwrecks. But the wise men of Tyre, who are taken in an evil sense, by whom they are wiser than the children of light, they themselves govern Tyre prepared for shipwreck. The elders of the Bible and its prudent ones provided sailors to Tyre for service, or they strengthened its counsel. The sacred history narrates that there were many seniors rejected by the Lord, and the juniors chosen as a representation of the Synagogue and the Church. Senior Cain is added, and junior Abel is chosen (Gen. IV): Ishmael, the son of Abraham, is estranged from his father, and junior Isaac inherits (Gen. XXI). Of the sons of Isaac, senior Esau is a hunter and roams in the fields, while junior Jacob simply dwells at home (Gen. XXV). And it is written in Malachi: 'Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated' (Mal. 1:2). And rightly according to the Apostle (Rom. 9:13), they had done nothing good or evil in the womb of their mother, neither had they merit or offense, so that one might be chosen and the other rejected, except in the case of a symbol, as we have said, of the Synagogue and the Church, the elder is repelled and the younger is taken. 'All the ships of the sea and sailors of Tyre were in the people of Tyre's business, or in the West of the West.' How is the Song of Songs, and the age of ages, and the work of works said; in such a way that the greater song is preferred over other songs, and the longer age over other ages, and the more useful work over other works: thus the West of the West is called, to signify the magnitude of the Western parts. And the ships of the sea, and their sailors, and the rowers who are in the help of the Tyrian ship, do not go towards the East, or towards the rising of the light, where the sun of justice is born, but towards the West of the West, where the light sets, and where the beginning of darkness is.


<h2 id='tocuniq260'>(Vers. 10.)</h2>

(Verse 10) Persians and Lydians (or Lydia) and Libyans were in your army, your warrior men: they hung up their shield and helmet for your adornment (or shields, and helmets they hung up for your glory). The Persians were the strongest, whose king Cyrus, as prophesied by Isaiah (Isa. XLV), overthrew Astyages, the king of the Medes, and captured Babylon, as both sacred and secular history narrate. And at that time they were considered the strongest among the nations, of whom King Croesus was captured by the same Cyrus, as Xenophon writes in great detail. And we read in the book of Chronicles (2 Chronicles 12) that the Libyans came with the Troglodytes and Ethiopians against Jerusalem, who were very prosperous in those times, famous as warriors in battle, and are remembered as defenders of the city of Tyre, who hung shields and helmets on the ramparts to frighten the enemies. But spiritual intelligence means that the Persians, who are called 'tentatives' or 'tentative ones'; and the Lydians, whom we understand to be born; and the Libyans, who are referred to as 'Phuth' in Hebrew and are translated as 'from the mouth' (not from the bone); attempt in vain to defend Tyre, being overcome by temptation, and serve their generation and lust, and they only multiply empty words, not having the helmet of salvation nor the shield of faith (Ephesians 6); but they only pretend glory and noise of words to adorn that.


<h2 id='tocuniq261'>(Vers. 11.)</h2>

(Verse 11) The sons of Aradius, together with your army (or their own), were on your walls all around. And the Pygmies who were in your towers hung their quivers (or yours) on your walls in a circle, they enhanced your beauty. LXX: The sons of the Aradians, and your strength on your walls, were guardians all around in your towers. They hung their quivers on your battlements in a circle. They have accomplished your splendor. The Word of Gamadim (), the first edition of Aquila, the Pygmies: Symmachus, the Medes: The Septuagint, the guardians: Theodotius Gamadim, the Hebrew itself, have been interpreted. We still see the island of Aradus which is entirely a city, and the opposite town of Antaradus, and it is near Tyre, and it extends along the shore of Phoenicia for 310 miles of the mainland, and to this day: these are the guards of the city of Tyre and the custodians of its towers, and they hang their quivers around their waist and complete its beauty, so that they may be known as archers, whether they are pygmies, that is, warriors, and very ready for war, from the Pygmean, which is translated into Greek as a contest. But if they sound the trumpets of Aradius, let those who claim knowledge of a false name be called Aradius, who have in the quiver of their chest the fiery arrows of the devil, with which they wound and inflame the hearts of the deceived. For he desires to depose those who strive to ascend to lofty heights, and he completes the beauty of Tyre, of which it is written in Proverbs: Do not let the desire for beauty deceive you, lest you be captivated by your own eyes (Prov. 6:25). And again: Just as a gold earring in a pig's snout, so is beauty to a woman without discretion (Ibid. XI, 22).

<h2 id='tocuniq262'>(Vers. 12.)</h2>

(V. 12) Your Carthaginian merchants have filled your markets with a multitude of all kinds of riches, with silver, iron, tin, and lead. Not only in the present place, but also in Isaiah, where it is written: Howl, ships of Carthage (Isa. XXIII, 14), the other interpreters have translated the Hebrew word as Tharsis, which is undoubtedly a colony of Tyre. They themselves from the western regions have filled Tyre's markets with silver, iron, tin, and lead. Tarsis in our language signifies the exploration of joy. However, here we must understand explorers not in a positive sense, such as those whom Moses sent to explore the promised land (Num. XIII), but in a negative sense, as the Apostle says we should avoid: Because of false brethren secretly brought in, who came in to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ (Galat. II, 4): and concerning whom Joseph spoke: You are spies: to see the nakedness of the land you are come (Gen. XLII, 9). And his brothers, understanding that the crime was not small, began to investigate the plot of others. They replied: Your servants are not spies. Therefore, these people multiply the Tyrian markets not with gold or precious stone, but with silver, iron, tin, and lead, possessing the charm of eloquence and weapons for conquering. And in their lead they mimic the appearance of silver, and in their tin the utmost wickedness, according to Zechariah (Zech. 5), where a woman sat on a lead weight, and the Egyptians sank deep like lead. The discussion of each metal is long, but we must strive for brevity.

<h2 id='tocuniq263'>(Vers. 13, 14.)</h2>

(Verse 13, 14) Greece, Tubal, and Meshech themselves, your merchants, brought slaves and bronze vessels to your people. From the house of Togorma they brought horses, horsemen, and mules to your marketplace. Septuagint: Greece and its neighboring regions, your merchants in the souls of men and bronze vessels supplied your market. From the house of Togorma they supplied horses, horsemen, and mules for your trading. Jones says that in Hebrew they are called Javan, and Thubal, that is, Eastern Iberians, or the people of Hispania from the western parts, who are named after the Iber River by this term, and Meshech, whom we understand as Cappadocians, whose capital, which was later called Caesarea by Augustus Caesar, is still called Mazaca in their language: they made precious commerce with Tyre, so that they would bring slaves and bronze vessels from Corinth to Tyre, and from the house of Togorma, that is, from Phrygia, horses, horsemen, and mules, of which that province once had a great abundance. The Hebrews say that Greece, that is, Javan, means both 'is' and 'is not,' which properly refers to worldly wisdom. In this wisdom, if they find something to be correct, they call it 'is'; if they find it to be incorrect, they call it 'is not.' For they speak much about the good of nature and about duties, self-control, and despising wealth. These things the Stoics properly claim for themselves, and they seem to enrich the souls of the people they deceive. They also have bronze vessels that resemble gold, which they give to the people of Tyre to deceive them with false doctrine. Moreover, from the house called Thogorma, which means stranger and foreigner, horses are also brought to the market and fair, and both horsemen and mules, of which it is written: The deceitful horse brings salvation (Ps. 32:17). And in another place: All who mount horses have slumbered (Ps. 75:7). And in the Psalms: Do not be like a horse or mule, without understanding (Ps. 32:9). Therefore, Doeg, the accuser and killer of the priests, was the leader of many, as well (2 Sam. 22), and these belong to the house of foreigners and strangers, who do not eat the meat of the lamb, of which it is written: No foreigner or hired worker shall eat of it (Exod. 12:43); so that all the markets of Tyre may be filled with these goods.


Your sons, O Dadan, are merchants. Concerning them, the Seventy interpreted the sons of the Rhodians, unless perhaps by the false similarity of the first letters (et) they read 'Radan' instead of 'Dadan', which itself is the greatest of the Cyclades and once a very powerful city in the Ionian Sea, renowned for its naval competition and the safest harbor, the haven of all merchants. And because the Rhodians are translated into our language, it is now said tropologically about those who perceive the truth of judgment but do not practice it, as the Apostle says: therefore you are inexcusable, O man, whoever judges. For in whatever way you judge another, you condemn yourself. For you do the same things that you judge (Rom. II, 1). But it is better to give another's name to Dadan, as it is also in Hebrew, and is held by other interpreters.

<h2 id='tocuniq264'>(Vers. 15, 16.)</h2>

(Verse 15, 16.) Many islands have traded with your merchandise: they have exchanged ivory and ebony for your price. Your merchant, Syria, because of the multitude of your works, has presented droplets, purple, embroidered garments, fine linen, silk, and coral, in your market. Seventy: Your merchandise has multiplied from the islands: you have paid your wages with elephant tusks and those who were introduced. The men of your trading have bought your merchandise from a multitude: in Aphek, Stacte, and Polymita from Tharsis and Ramoth and Chodchod they have given to your markets. In the present place the Septuagint edition differs greatly from the Hebrew; therefore a few things must be said according to each: lest, occupied with Tyrian merchandise, we pass more slowly to the remaining prophecies. The sons of Dedan were the merchants of Tyre, and they multiplied their merchandise in many islands, so that they would give elephant tusks to those who came to trade with them, and they would have men in the markets because of the multitude of their merchandise. However, in Aphek there were 313, which is added in Theodotion's edition to the Septuagint: for which Symmachus translates as polymita. Stacte also, for which all others interpret as purple, which is called Argaman in Hebrew (): and varieties from Tharsis, for which in Hebrew it is called Bus (), which has been translated by all into byssus. However, Tharsis is not found at all in the present place. And they gave ramoth and chodchod in your markets; which is thus found in Hebrew, except that for ramoth, Aquila translates as silk or fine. Indeed, all the interpreters, as it is written in Hebrew (), have translated it. Therefore, according to the Septuagint, the sons of the merchants of Rhodes multiplied his trade from many islands: according to the Hebrew, after the sons of Dedan, his merchants also increased the variety of his merchandise, bringing ivory tusks from India, and ebony wood, which is of the most precious black color, and exchanged them with other Tyrian goods. Syrus was also a merchant from Tyre: for which reason in Hebrew it is called Aram (), in place of which the Seventy men interpreted Hebrew as Adam, and Res and Daleth of letters, as stated above, being deceived by similarity. However, even to this day the innate eagerness for trade persists among the Syrians, who, driven by the desire for profit, roam through the whole world, and have such a madness for trading that, now that they have occupied the Roman world, they seek wealth among swords and the deaths of the wretched, and they flee poverty through dangers. Of this kind are the merchants of Tyre, who trade in fine fabrics, purple dye, and embroidered goods. They also offer linen and silk, and display precious stones in their market. Concerning purple, which all have interpreted, the Septuagint translated it as stacte, that is, a drop. However, I have not been able to find the meaning of chodchod until now. The Hebrews say that all precious goods are signified by this name, or that it is a kind of precious merchandise that the Latin language does not resonate with, or the common term of peddlers. But from many islands, as we move on to anagogy, which are pounded by the salty and bitter waves of this age, merchants from Dedan bring ivory teeth, promising the whiteness of eloquence; about whom it is written: From ivory houses from which the daughters of kings pleased you in your honor (Ps. LIV, 9). But they are not pure, nor do they imitate the bride, of whom it is said: Who is this that comes up whitened, leaning upon her brother (Cant. VIII, 5)? But the blackness of the Ethiopian, which cannot change its blackness, as Jeremiah says: 'Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?' (Jer. XIII, 21). Also, Syrus, that is, Aram, which means exalted, and is swollen with pride, is a merchant of Tyre, and in the multitude of the works of the Tyrians he boasts a false knowledge of his name, promising many varieties and the most excellent fragrance of myrrh, and the purple of royal dignity, and the checkered pattern of the dialectic art, and fine linen, for which the Septuagint translates 'Tharsis,' dedicated to the works of the earth: and silk, for which it is written in Hebrew 'Ramoth,' which means the vision of death. For all earthly works rush toward destruction; and chodchod, whatever that is which is understood, sets forth in the bazaars of Tyre. Now, by the goods which are said to be brought from those regions and islands, either the region of India must be understood, or that of the Edomites and the vast wilderness, as some think, and it has a sound like a relationship, so that we may recognize a similarity of divine teachings in heretics.

<h2 id='tocuniq265'>(Vers. 17.)</h2>

(Verse 17) Judah and the land of Israel, they themselves, your stewards, offered in your markets: balsam and honey, and oil, and resin. LXX: Judah and the sons of Israel, these your merchants in the grain trade and in ointments: first honey and oil, and resin they gave in your markets. The Hebrew word Phanag () Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion translated as it is written among the Hebrews: for which LXX translates ointments, we translate balsam. It is said, however, that the land of Judaea, which is now called Palestine, is abundant in resources, such as wheat, balsam, honey, oil, and resin, which are brought from Judah and Israel to the markets of Tyre. And when the literal sense is clear, according to the spiritual sense we will say that the land of confession and of understanding God, which is referred to the Church, should not bring wheat to Tyre first, which when it falls to the ground, multiplies and is taken as the word of God: For man does not live by bread alone, but by every word of God (Deuteronomy VIII, 3). Then the balsam that grows in the vineyards of Engedi, or the ointment, of which it is written: Like the ointment on the head, that runs down the beard, the beard of Aaron (Ps. 132:2). And honey, of which Solomon speaks: You have found honey, eat what is enough. For if you eat too much, you will vomit it (Prov. 25:16), as excessive satiety turns honey into wormwood. And the oil, with which the lamp in the tabernacle of God is lit, lest we be subject to that prophecy: You sold oil in Egypt (Hosea 12:1). But if it were in Egypt and in Tyre, it will be turned upside down, and it will be said of it, The oil of the sinner shall not impregnate my head (Ps. 140:5). But resin is also gentle (or light), suitable for bodies, and is used as medicine. Hence it is written in Jeremiah: Is there no resin in Gilead, or a physician? Why then has the healing of the daughter of my people not gone up (Jer. 8:22)? Jacob also had this resin, which he sent to his son Joseph with honey, balsam, nuts, and stacte (Gen. 43). The Ishmaelites who bought Joseph from the land of Israel, were carrying these things into Egypt: spices, balm, resin of Gilead, and myrrh. And so that we may better understand what wheat, balsam, honey, and oil, and resin are brought to the market of Tyre, let us hear the words of the Lord saying: Do not give what is holy to dogs, nor cast your pearls before swine. Also, to the Canaanite woman who was praying for her daughter, saying: My daughter is severely possessed by a demon, the Lord replied: It is not right to take the food of children and give it to dogs. But because she had come out of the regions of Tyre and Sidon, and was approaching the land of Israel, therefore what she had asked for was granted.

<h2 id='tocuniq266'>(Vers. 18.)</h2>

(Verse 18.) Your merchant from Damascus in the multitude of your works: in the abundance of various goods: in fine wine, in the best colored wool. LXX: Your merchant from Damascus with the multitude of your works, from the multitude of all your strength: wine from Helbon, and wool from Mileto. For fine wine, which is interpreted by Symmachus, and by Aquila and Theodotion, and in the Hebrew itself, wine from Helbon. And again, when we arrived in the land of the best-colored wool, either shining or with splendid hues, Aquila and Theodotius transferred us to the land of Soor. It signifies that among other trades of Tyre, the finest wine and the finest wool were brought from Damascus to its market. And we still see this today. Now if Damascus is interpreted as 'drinking blood,' and the true tradition of the Hebrews is that the field in which Abel was killed by the parricide Cain (Gen. IV) was in Damascus, hence the place is called by this significant name, rightly so, and after the execution of Stephen, the first martyr in Christ, Paul went to Damascus, under the mercy of God who made the blind see and the sighted lose their sight, so that he could receive the insight of the mind. And the scales of the dragon fell from his eyes, with which he had lost the light of truth, so that he could go to the street called Straight and find Ananias, which means 'obedient' in our language (Act. IX). Therefore, from this cursed land, to which it is said: 'Cursed is the ground because of you; through painful toil you will eat food from it all the days of your life' (Genesis 3:17), the Tyrian merchants gather, bringing fine wine and shining wool. The wine comes from Chelbon, which means 'milky'. Seventy are chosen for their excellent wool, which comes from Miletus or Tyre. Miletus is not mentioned in Hebrew, but because excellent wool is brought from there, they interpreted Miletus as Tyre. From this it is clear that Tyre feeds on milk in infancy and does not have its own clothing, but obtains it from elsewhere and from various provinces. That which Damascus interprets as the blood of Cilicia and the blood of kisses does not fit the present place. For Hebrew names are often interpreted in various ways due to differences in accents and changes in letters and vowels, especially those that have their own peculiarities among them.


<h2 id='tocuniq267'>(Vers. 19.)</h2>

(Verse 19) Both Greece and Mozel have put forth wrought iron on your markets: stacte  317 and cinnamon in your trade. LXX: + Both Greece and Mozel have put forth wrought iron on your markets, which were added in their edition of Theodotion. Iron made by work, and a wheel in your mixture is. From the name of the patriarch Dan and the tribe, and the place where the tribe dwelt, it received its name, where today Paneas is, which was formerly called Caesarea Philippi. And so the river Jordan obtained its name, Jor, meaning stream, Dan, which flows from Lebanon. Javan, on the other hand, denotes Greece, which as we have said, both is and is not. Symmachus also translated Mozel as deferring, so the sense is: Dan and Greece brought to your markets wrought iron, and so forth. Aquila, on the other hand, substituted Uzal for Mozel. From these regions, it is believed that iron, stacte, and reed were brought to the Tyrian markets. Let us say that Greece, that is, Javan, has iron made by craftsmen, and is very ready for war, and boasting that it presents everything with judgment and reason through the art of debate, and promises a vocal sound, which is interpreted on paper, and the scent of the best incense, whether it is iron made by craftsmen, and a wheel that turns with the arrangement of words, and has the flow of speech.

<h2 id='tocuniq268'>(Vers. 20.)</h2>

(Verse 20) Your traders, Dedan, sit on carpets. LXX: Your traders, Dedan, with selected animals for chariots. There is a significant difference between the Hebrew and the Septuagint in this passage, except for the name of the region, which is close to Dedan and Dadan. There is indeed a vast difference between sitting on carpets and using selected animals for chariots. There is no doubt that chariots and horses are considered negative if they are earthly. Moreover, both Elijah and Elisha are taken to the heavenly chariot, and Elijah is called the father, father, charioteer, and chariot of Israel (2 Kings 2:12). And Gehazi's eyes are opened to see the chariot on the mountain and the horses prepared for the Lord's ride without riders (ibid. 6). But in the tapestries, the beauty of the words is shown; in them, the merchants of Dedan are carried and rest, having come to the market of Tyre.


<h2 id='tocuniq269'>(Vers. 21.)</h2>

(Verse 21.) Arabia and all the princes of Kedar themselves, 318 merchants of your hand, came to you with lambs, and rams, and goats. Concerning the lambs, rams, and goats, 70 camels and rams, and lambs were interpreted. But Arabia and the princes of Kedar (which today is the region of the Saracens, as is most fully demonstrated in Jeremiah's discourse, which is written against Kedar) abound in these animals, namely lambs, rams, and goats, and they multiply the Tyrian markets by means of this transportation (Jeremiah 49). But also, the region of the camels is very fertile because of the expanses of pastures, the mildness of the air, which this animal delights in. Arabia, however, means 'evening', and Cedar means 'darkness'. Concerning this, it is also said in the Psalms: 'I dwell among the inhabitants of Cedar' (Ps. CXIX, 5). These regions provide Tyre with camels burdened by the heaviest weights of sins, whether lambs, and rams, and goats, which they sacrifice on their altars, which they have fabricated from their wicked and rebellious hearts. But we also read in this same prophet in a vision of shepherds, rams stirring up the purest waters and pushing the sheep with their sides and fighting with their horns (Ezekiel 34): also young goats, which are accustomed to stand on the left, and lambs that pretend to be a lamb (Matthew 25): of whom it is written, Behold the Lamb of God, behold him who taketh away the sins of the world (John 1:29). But Isaiah writes favorably about camels (Isaiah 60), concerning Midian, which is interpreted as the judgment of the Lord coming to Jerusalem, and Ephah, and rams from Nebaioth, and Sabah bearing gold and frankincense: the last two of which are also offered to the Lord by the Magi (Matthew 2). And there camels, with the burden of sins laid down, can enter the narrow and narrow path, which leads to life (Matthew VII and XIX).

<h2 id='tocuniq270'>(Vers. 22.)</h2>

(Verse 22) The merchants of Sheba and Raamah, your own traders, brought you the finest spices, precious stones, and gold, which they offered in your market. In the Psalms, where it is written, 'The kings of Arabia and Sheba shall bring gifts to you' (Psalm 72:10), in Hebrew it says, 'The kings of Sheba and Sheba shall bring gifts to you.' One is written with the letter Sin, the other with Samech, which is similar to our letter S. Therefore, since 'Saba' is interpreted as conversion, it must be said that in this present passage it does not signify conversion but rather aversion, from which gifts are brought from Tyre with all kinds of spices and the best smells, and with a precious stone and gold, all of which are offered for sale in the markets of Tyre. And they themselves falsely claim the best smell and the precious stone with which they strive to build up their perversity in the churches, and the gold which they promise in a sensual way, and all these things are perverse. For they do not receive anything for free, nor do they give anything for free, but they purchase everything, just as the kings of the Arabs and Saba offer gifts to Christ for free. These are the ones who do everything for the sake of filthy profit: and they have received these gifts from Him who says in the Gospel: 'All these things I will give to you, if you fall down and worship me' (Matthew 4:9). Reama, or according to the Septuagint Rhegma, I could not find in any other place in the Scriptures, nor what region it is, nor what it signifies; except that it is clear, and from what is connected, that Saba is a neighboring region to this province.


<h2 id='tocuniq271'>(Vers. 23, 24.)</h2>

(Verses 23, 24.) Aran, and Channe, and Eden, your merchants, Saba, Assur, Chelmad, your sellers: these are your merchants of various woven fabrics of hyacinth, and of precious multi-colored garments, which were wrapped and bound with ropes. LXX: Charran, and Chana, and Edne, these are your merchants: Sabba, Assur, and Chalman, your intruders, bringing merchandise + to Machalim, and to Galima ** hyacinth, and + multicolored ** treasures bound together with ropes. And these are the names of the different places. As for what is added to Theodotion in the Septuagint, it is interpreted by Symmachus as precious coverings. We have also added Polymita, which Theodotion interprets in various ways, from Aquila and Symmachus. The merchant's precious clothes were so highly valued that they were tied with hyacinth-colored ropes. Aran, or as the Septuagint says, Charran, means holes in our language. Channe means preparation. Eden means delights. As for Edne, which is not found in Hebrew, we do not know its meaning, and we should not seek the etymology of a fictitious name. Therefore, in the negotiation of Tyre, the preparation of the whole world is indicated by the fleshy senses which are displayed on the protrusions, for those who think that the sole delights are to increase the commerce of the Tyrian city. We have mentioned about Sabaeans above. Assur is interpreted as the leader: Chelmad, or as it is contained in some copies, Cherma, is transferred to the vineyards: without a doubt, those from Sodom who come to the market of Tyre, in order to direct wickedness, indeed, to accuse with punishments, and to correct what had been depraved, according to that which is said in the Psalms: "You will destroy the enemy and avenger" (Psalm 8:3). And they have in many different ways a variety of furniture, distinct by an incredible variety, which is bound by the coverings of the hyacinth; whether their treasures are bound with ropes, which they have amassed for themselves on earth, according to what is written: By the ropes of their sins each one is bound (Prov. 5:22). And they did not have free trade, but they bound everything with the chains of sins. Let us refer the hyacinthine coverings, because of their similarity in color, to the airy powers, which lavish their treasures in the markets of the world.


They also had cedar in your trade. Ships of the sea (or as it is written in Hebrew, Tarshish), your princes in your trade. Regarding cedars, Seventy cypresses were transported. And since we have already mentioned both, it is unnecessary to increase the reader's boredom.

<h2 id='tocuniq272'>(Vers. 25.)</h2>

(Verse 25.) And you were filled, and greatly glorified (or burdened) in the heart of the sea. Nothing, he says, was lacking for you in regard to the riches of the islands. Yet this glorification was a burden for the possessor, since you cannot bear riches in moderation, although often temptation also comes with poverty (Prov. 30). Therefore, Solomon asks only for what is necessary; he equally detests riches and poverty, so that pride does not creep in with one, and impatience and falsehood with the other.


<h2 id='tocuniq273'>(Vers. 26.)</h2>

(Verse 26.) Your oarsmen have brought you in many waters. Above the oarsmen we read of the Tyrians from the city of Sidon, and the people of Aradus, of whom the former are hunters and the latter are said to be interpreters. For they hunt the souls of those whom the waves of this world carry at their own will, not raising them up to lofty heights, but sinking them into the depths. They do not imitate those who, sailing until the morning watch, broke the raging waves of the sea and deserved to receive the Lord and Savior, and immediately arrived at the harbor of rest with such a pilot and companion. About which it is written more fully in the Gospel.

The south wind drives you in the heart of the sea (Matthew 14). All the wealth of Tyre perishes when the south wind blows, which more significantly is interpreted as scorching heat in Greek, καύσων (); which we can translate into a burning wind. Concerning this, the holy David said: The sun shall not strike you by day, nor the moon by night (Psalm 121:6). Jacob was scorched by this wind, yet not broken, as he speaks: By day I was consumed by burning heat, and by night by frost (Genesis 31:40). Those who were hired from the first hour endured the heat and the burning heat of the whole day, and yet they receive a denarius because they are burned but not broken. Therefore, the bride says in the Song of Songs: I am black but beautiful, because the sun has looked upon me (Song of Songs 1:4), or, more accurately in Hebrew, the sun has discolored me.

Your riches and treasures, and your abundant possessions. Many read it like this: In the heart of the sea are your riches and treasures, and your abundant possessions; so that all the riches and treasures of Tyre, and all its substance, are placed in the heart of the sea, and are overwhelmed by the waves of time, and its inhabitants have nothing stable or permanent, fulfilling that Gospel: Fool, tonight they will take your soul from you, and to whom will belong what you have prepared? (Luke XII, 20). And in that apostolic (scripture): Those who want to become rich fall into temptation and many traps, and are dragged into the depths (I Tim. VI, 9). The story is clear; therefore, we join together short sentences almost verse by verse. For now, the discourse hastens to the end of the book.

<h2 id='tocuniq274'>(Vers. 27)</h2>

(Verse 27) Your sailors (or rowers) and your pilots, who held your merchandise and ruled over your people: and your warriors who were in you, together with all your multitude which is in your midst, will fall in the heart of the sea on the day of your downfall. We read about the sailors or rowers of the city of Tyre, the Sidonians and the Aradians, about whom it has already been mentioned; and according to the Septuagint edition, the counselors of Byblos, which is called Gebal in Hebrew: as well as its warriors, Persians, Lydians, and Libyans, who will all fall and be shown to be nothing, when Tyre falls and all its glory comes to an end in ruins. But the multitude which the Seventy translated as 'commixtionem' signifies the common people; who, without the name of dignities, are crushed by similar judgment. And the prophecy is mixed between the city and the ship, so that from one you may understand the other: and yet both pertain to the end of the age, and to shipwreck.

<h2 id='tocuniq275'>(Vers. 28, 29.)</h2>

(Verse 28, 29.) From the sound of the outcry of your helmsmen, the ships will be thrown into confusion, and all who held the oars will disembark from their ships. The sailors, and all the helmsmen of the sea, the sailors and the rowers, will stand on land and wail loudly, and they will cry bitterly: and they will throw dust on their heads, and will be covered in ashes (or will spread ashes on themselves). And what follows: And they will shave their heads because of you, and they will put on sackcloth; and they will mourn for you with the bitterness of their souls, with the most bitter lamentation, and they will take up a funeral song for you, and they will lament for you. It is not found in the Septuagint, but it was added from Theodotion's edition. When Tyre falls, its governors will be troubled, and they will come down from their ships, as will the rowers, sailors, and pilots, and all the governors of the sea shaken by the waves, will eventually find a stable position; and they will wail with a loud voice over it, which they used to enrich with their merchandise, and they will indicate the bitterness of their minds with their outcry; they will also throw dust or dirt on their heads, doing penance for earthly works. And they shall be sprinkled with ashes, either of heifers as prescribed by the Law (Num. XX), for purification, or they shall sprinkle ashes upon themselves, as it is said to Jerusalem: Sprinkle the earth on your head, and spread ashes upon yourself, and make mourning (Jeremiah VI, 16). And it is written in the Gospel: If the miracles that were done in Tyre and Sidon had been done in Sodom, they would have repented in sackcloth and ashes (Luke X, 13). And the Psalmist says: I have eaten ashes like bread (Psalm CI, 10). And they will graze over Tyre's head, and they will make a baldness, which is accustomed to be done in mourning, at that time when the greatness of pain has expelled all joy. And indeed the apostles counted their hairs, because they had consecrated their hair to the Lord in the manner of the Nazarenes (Matthew 10; Luke 6). And as long as Samson had his hair, he possessed strength, but when his hair was taken away, he was captured by the Philistines (Judges 16). Moreover, when it is said, 'and they will gird themselves with sackcloth,' the old lust of the loins is condemned, so that those who had lived in luxury, afterwards, repenting, may live in austerity and harshness. The people of Nineveh had sacks (Jonah 3). And again in Jerusalem it is said: 'Lament to me like a bride dressed in sackcloth over her husband, a virgin' (Joel 1:8). And they will mourn you, he says, with bitterness of soul and with very bitter weeping. For it is better to enter into the house of mourning than into the house of feasting (Sirach 7): so that they may mourn for Tyre, and sing a mournful song, which the following Scripture adds. But so that we may know the progress of those who mourn for its downfall, and who before dwelled in its heart and in its midst, let the prophets teach us by their example: who themselves are commanded to mourn for Tyre, so that, after a time of repentance is fulfilled, it may be restored to its former state and, taking up the harp, may sing to the Lord. Read Isaiah. Some people, in a ridiculous (but nonetheless, worth mentioning) way, interpret governors as bishops of heretics, advisors as priests, helmsmen as archdeacons, oarsmen and sailors as deacons, and carriers as the entire population. And if they had added the shipmaster as the devil, they would have completed the tragedy. All of them will wail together and mourn bitterly, and they will repent after they have realized the shipwreck of their own ship and have stood on land, and they will have lost all the beauty of the false name of knowledge. And instead of joy and happiness, they will mark repentance with bitterness in their hearts.


<h2 id='tocuniq276'>(Vers. 33 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 33 and following) Who is like Tyre, who has become silent in the midst of the sea? (Which is not found in the Septuagint.) Who filled the sea with your merchandise and enriched many peoples with your abundant wealth? In the multitude of your riches and the multitude of your traders, you have made kings wealthy. Now you are shattered by the sea in the depths of the waters, along with all your merchandise and all the multitude in your midst have fallen. All the inhabitants of the islands were astonished (or were crushed) on account of you, and all their kings were struck (or were turned into madness) by the tempest, they changed their countenances (or they wept). The merchants of the nations (or of the peoples) hissed at you, you have been reduced to nothing (or have become a ruin: and you will no longer be 324 beyond (the Vulgate is silent beyond) forever (or for eternity). The governors, the sailors, the pilots, and the passengers will remember with lamentation those things in Tyre, which so silenced the speech of other cities, that it had no confidence in speaking; and it would hear that Gospel saying, Be silent, and be still (Mark 4:39). And concerning the Psalms: But to the sinner, God said, Why do you proclaim my justices, and take my covenant in your mouth? (Ps. 46:16) How much merchandise, O Tyre, have you become enriched with? And why have you sought with such great labor, to gather what will perish in shipwreck, both day and night? You have indeed filled many peoples, and enriched kings with your wealth, of whom it is written: The kings of the earth stood up, and the princes met together against the Lord, and against his Christ. (Ps. 2:2) But now you are crushed in the sea, and in the depths of the waters, just as it is written about Pharaoh: The chariots of Pharaoh and his army he has cast into the sea (Exod. XV, 4). He sank into the depths like a stone, and he could say: I have come into the depths of the sea, and the tempest has engulfed me (Ps. XIV, 4). All the islands, or the inhabitants of the islands, which are battered by the waves of this world, will be astonished at you, and their kings, struck by the storm, will feel their own destruction, imitating the voice of the snake, they will hiss and say: You have been brought down to nothingness, or you have been made into destruction; so that you may not have the nature of destruction, but the will. And you will not be. But if he had said this up to now, a great question would arise, how it is not, which we now see built. But from what follows: Forever, it shows the time of one age, which is reckoned in a circle according to the age of a man of seventy years. Whether you will not be with God, the Apostle says: Who called those things that were not (Rom. 4:17). And Isaiah the prophet: Behold, all your adversaries will be confounded and ashamed. For they shall be as if they were not (Isa. XLI, 11): And Esther according to the Septuagint Interpreters: Do not give your scepter to those who are not (Esther XIV, 11). And in the Psalm: Allow me to refresh myself before I depart, and I shall be no more (Ps. XXXV, 14). We have already explained in what sense these testimonies should be understood. However, all these things can be referred to the person of heretics, who, in the contrition of Tyre and shipwreck, feel their own error and, being placed in the middle of the sea, desire to free their souls and lament the ill-gotten riches with which they had enriched many kings, namely, their own patriarchs and the common people, whose wealth will be lost in the middle of the sea. Moreover, the inhabitants of all the islands (if, however, we choose to interpret in a favorable sense what has been said) will be amazed at the destruction of Tyre, and the kings of all the islands, struck as if by a storm, will change their countenance, or certainly reveal the grief of their hearts with weeping and tears, and they will testify to the greatness of their astonishment with astonishment and hissing, demonstrating how worthless it has become, and how it has perished which promised salvation to many nations. And beyond there will no longer be, at any fixed time, for us to interpret αἰῶνα as 'age'; but forever: because the same word signifies both.

<h2 id='tocuniq277'>Book Nine</h2>

Book Nine

325-326 It followed, my daughter Eustochium, that I should include the prophecy of Tyre and the prince of Tyre in one volume, and not separate them by the order of books, but by the connected places and prophecies. But because there are many things that are said, and exceed the measure of my prolixity, therefore the explanation has been extended to the ninth book, which we believe will reach the end with your prayers and those of all the saints: so that we may discuss also Pharaoh and all Egypt, which are written in Ezekiel. Which, even itself, needs to be divided into ten books for the sake of maintaining the measurement among the volumes, and so that the labor of the speaker, writer, and reader can be relieved by being divided into parts.

<h2 id='tocuniq278'>(Cap. XXVIII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 28, Verses 1 onwards) 'And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, say to the prince of Tyre: Thus says the Lord God: Because your heart is lifted up, and you have said: I am God, and I sit in the seat of God, in the heart of the sea, whereas you are a man, and not God: and you have set your heart as if it were the heart of God: behold you are wiser than Daniel? No secret is hidden from you! By your wisdom and understanding you have acquired riches for yourself and gathered gold and silver in your treasuries.' In the multitude of your wisdom and in your trading you have multiplied strength for yourself, and your heart is lifted up because of your strength. Therefore thus says the Lord (Vulg. adds God): Because your heart is lifted up like the heart of God, behold, I will bring foreigners against you, the most terrible of the nations, and they shall draw their swords against the beauty of your wisdom and defile your splendor. They shall kill you and bring you down, and you shall die the death of the slain in the heart of the sea. Are you saying in your heart: 'I am God, when you are being killed by those who kill you, even though you are a man and not God, in the hand of those who kill you? You will die the death of the uncircumcised at the hands of foreigners, for I have spoken,' says the Lord God. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: 'You, son of man, say to the prince of Tyre: Thus says the Lord God: Because your heart is lifted up, and you have said, 'I am God, I inhabit the heart of the seas,' yet you are a man, and not God, and you have set your heart as the heart of God, are you wiser than Daniel?' The wise have not taught you their discipline. Did you make strength for yourself in your learning or wisdom? Did you accumulate gold and silver in your treasuries or increase your strength through much learning and trade? Your heart is lifted up in your strength, therefore thus says the Lord God: Because you have made your heart like the heart of God, behold, I will bring foreigners against you, the deadly ones of the nations, and they shall draw their swords against your beauty of knowledge, and they shall humble your beauty in destruction. They shall bring you down and dispose of you, and you shall die the death of those who are slain in the heart of the sea. Will you say, 'I am God,' when you face your killers? But you are a man, not a god, surrounded by those who wound you. You will die at the hands of uncircumcised foreigners, for I have spoken, says the Lord God. Wherever the Lord is written in the Septuagint as the second name, the first name is the tetragrammaton (), which properly belongs to God and is ineffable. The second name is the common (), which is often found in humans. However, the city of Tyre is described under the figure of a ship, first in its wealth, then in its destruction and lamentation: thus, a prophetic speech is directed to the prince of Tyre, stating that he became arrogant and misused the riches he had; then, there is mourning and lamentation, about how great goods have turned into great evils. Therefore, the things to be mentioned first are these: It is written in Isaiah (Isa. IV) to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, that he equated himself with the power of God and became so lifted up in pride that he dared to say: 'I will ascend above the stars of heaven and will be like the Most High.' And he was cast down from his throne, deserving to hear: How has Lucifer fallen, who rose in the morning? And of Pharaoh in the same prophet: The rivers are mine, and I made them (Isaiah 29:9). And of the prince of Tyre, who, with an uplifted heart, arrogantly said: I am a god, and I sit in the seat of God, and dwell in the habitation of God, though he is a man, and not God. And although these things may seem to exceed the powers of human frailty, and to be the words not of men but of raving demons, nevertheless we must understand the hyperbole, that they have swelled to such an extent, and have not known their own measure, that, swelled up with the happiness and power of the world, while they think present good things to be eternal, they have not known themselves to be men, and have claimed eternal sovereignty for themselves. Although under the type of rulers, kings, and individual (or particular) cities or provinces, opposing powers are demonstrated, about which the apostle Paul also writes: Our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this dark world and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms (Ephesians 6:12). And in another place: We speak wisdom among the mature, but not the wisdom of this world or of the rulers of this age, who are coming to nothing (1 Corinthians 2:6). And again, speaking about wisdom, he says, which none of the rulers of this world has known. For if they had known, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory (I Cor. II, 8). In the prophecy of Daniel it is also clear that the Prince of the Israelite people is Michael, and the prince of Greece, and the prince of Persia (Dan. X). And Moses writes more clearly in the Song of Deuteronomy: When the Most High divided the nations, and scattered the sons of Adam, he established the boundaries of nations, according to the number of God's angels (Deut. XXXII, 8); or as it is better understood in Hebrew: according to the number of the sons of Israel. And a part of the Lord's people became His Jacob, His inheritance in Israel. And we should not be surprised that on the opposite side the worst kings would precede the princes in the likeness of the transgressors, since in the same way we ought to proclaim the best kings David, Solomon, and Josiah, together with the patriarchs and prophets, as foreshadowing the Lord and Savior. Therefore, according to both interpretations, let us discuss the writings about both proud kings and apostate princes. He says therefore (Al. Cum sit, ait): It is allowed for you, even though you are held in the narrowness of the middle of the sea and surrounded by islands, to say more, since you are a man and encompassed by the fragility of human flesh, swelled up with arrogance of heart, that you dwell on the throne of God, believe yourself to be in the heavens. And at the same time, because you boast of wisdom to such an extent that the men of your kingdom provoke Solomon with riddles: are you wiser than Daniel, who, by the grace of God, conquered all the magicians and soothsayers, and is now the wisest in Babylon? Or, to understand it in this way: Even if you are wiser than Daniel, who is acknowledged by all to be the wisest, and even if you desire to be equal in power to God in his greatness of wealth and power, you will still be taken captive by your adversaries, and the city will be destroyed, and you will be wounded by many blows. And then you will no longer say, 'I am a god,' but in your destruction, you will learn that you are a man, not a god. However, if we want to say that the same power is being referred to as the prince of Tyre, to whom the city itself, or the province, was given by God, let us take that testimony. I said, 'You are gods, and all of you are sons of the Most High. Nevertheless, you will die like men and fall like one of the princes' (Psalm 82:7). For they were given the provinces to govern as judges by the Emperor. But they, forgetting their honor and being influenced by a higher command, like Heraclianus in Africa, rose up with a tyrannical mindset against their king and Lord. They scattered throughout the whole world, assuming the names of idols for themselves under the guise of idolatry, and, swollen with pride, fell into the judgment of the devil and the snare. Concerning this, the Savior spoke in the Gospel: 'I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven' (Luke 10:18).

<h2 id='tocuniq279'>(Vers. 11 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 11 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, raise a lamentation over the king of Tyre, and say to him: Thus says the Lord God: You were the signet of perfection, full of wisdom and perfect in beauty. You were in Eden, the garden of God; every precious stone was your covering: carnelian, topaz, and jasper, chrysolite, onyx, and beryl, sapphire, emerald, and carbuncle; and crafted in gold were your settings and your engravings. On the day that you were created they were prepared. You, Cherub, stretched out and protecting, I have set you on God's holy mountain. You walked among the fiery stones: perfect in your ways, from the day of your creation, until iniquity was found in you. In the abundance of your trading, your heart was filled with iniquity, and you sinned, and I cast you out from the mountain of God, and I destroyed you, O Cherub, protecting from among the fiery stones. And your heart was lifted up because of your beauty. You have corrupted your wisdom because of your splendor, I have cast you to the ground. I have made you a spectacle before kings, that they may see you. In the multitude of your iniquities and the injustice of your dealings, you have defiled your sanctification. Therefore, I will bring fire from your midst that will consume you, and I will turn you into ashes upon the earth in the sight of all who see you. All who see you among the nations will be astonished at you. You have become nothing, and you will not be forever. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, take up a lamentation over the prince of Tyre and say to him: Thus says the Lord God: You seal of similarity, full of wisdom and adorned with a crown, you were in the delights of the paradise of God. You were surrounded by every good stone: sardius and topaz, and emerald, and carbuncle, and sapphire, and jasper, and silver, and gold, and chrysolite, and agate, and amethyst, and chrysoprase, and beryl, and onyx, and your treasury was filled with gold, and your storehouses in you, from the day you were created, they were prepared with the anointed Cherub from God, and dwelling in the tabernacle, I have set you on the holy mountain of God: you became in the midst of burning stones. You were blameless in your days, from the day you were created, until iniquities were found in you. By the abundance of your trading, you were filled with iniquity and sinned. Therefore, I cast you to the ground and exposed you before kings, to disgrace you. Because of the multitude of your sins, and the unjust practices of your business, I have defiled your sanctuaries. And I will bring fire in the midst of you, it shall devour you. And I will make you ashes upon the earth in the sight of all who see you, and all who know you among the nations shall be dismayed at you. You have become a ruin, and you shall be no more forever. For we have spoken of the prince of Tyre, and how he has fallen through his pride, let us acknowledge his lamentations over his former glory. First, let it be understood what it was, so that he may grieve for having lost what he had. 'You,' she says, 'are the seal of likeness'; according to that which John the Evangelist properly says about the Savior: 'For Him has God the Father set His seal' (John 6:27). And about humans: 'He has set His seal, because God is true' (John 3:33). And in the Psalms: 'The light of your face, O Lord, has been sealed upon us' (Psalm 4:7). And in another place: 'Beloved, now we are children of God, and what we will be has not yet appeared.' We know that when he appears, we shall be like him (1 John 3:2). Hence it is said to God: Who is like you? (Psalm 35:10). For likeness is one thing, equality another. Therefore, the most savage heresy is the one that confesses only the Father's likeness in Christ and denies his nature. But we not only say likeness in the Son, but also equality. For this reason the Jews persecuted him, because not only did he break the Sabbath, but he also made himself equal to God (John 5). But where there is equality, there is the same nature and one substance. This is what the Apostle speaks of in terms of similarity: My little children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you (Galatians 4:19), so that you may receive, namely, His likeness, which you lost through your own fault. And because in Latin codices the word for seal is ‘resignaculum,’ while expressing the Greek word κακοζήλως word for word, which is translated according to the Septuagint version as ‘ἀποσφράγισμα’ or seal. And some people understand it in this way, that the seal of God and the figure which was expressed as if in the softest wax, the king of Tyre has cancelled and lost, so that he has made a counter-seal in place of the seal, not having the image and likeness of God, by which the first man was created, as God says: Let us make man in our image and likeness (Gen. 1:26). And it should be noted that the image was made at that time only, but the likeness is fulfilled in the baptism of Christ. And consequently to whom it was said: You are a seal of likeness, joined, full of wisdom, perfect in beauty, or, a crown of adornment. For where the likeness of God is, there is also the fullness of wisdom, and perfect beauty, or like a crown adorned with different flowers, which the diligent increases with their own effort, while the industrious nourish the good of nature, and the negligent diminish it, according to what is said in Proverbs under the figure of a beautiful and ill-behaved woman: As a gold ring in a pig's snout, so is the beauty of an ill-behaved woman (Prov. XI, 22). It follows: In the delights of the paradise of God you were: for which in Hebrew it is called Eden, which also the story of Genesis narrates. Eden, however, is translated into delights. And beautifully, it is named paradise of God as a distinction, to show that there is a contrary paradise not of God, among those who exchange the truth for falsehood (Rom. I), and boast of having paradise. By this speech, he shows that it is by no means a man about whom it is written, but a contrary strength, which once dwelled in the paradise of God: although the Jews think that this is prophesied about King Hiram of Tyre in a manner called hyperbole. But to whom is it said: You were in the delights of the paradise of God, or you became, it shows what he had, or what he lost. Moreover, as for the dwelling of paradise, every precious stone is your covering, or your binding, and encircling, sardius, topaz, and jasper, chrysolite, and onyx, and beryl, sapphire, and carbuncle, and emerald, or, as in the Septuagint, in a different order and with other names, twelve stones are contained, it must be observed that not every precious stone surrounded or covered the king of Tyre, but every stone he had was precious. Moreover, there are many precious stones that are not mentioned in Scripture, such as chalcedony, sardonyx, chrysoprase, hyacinth, crystal, and the most precious pearl. Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotio also differ greatly from each other in both order and number in the present place, and the Septuagint translators not only differ in order but also in names. In the Book of Revelation, where the living stones of Jerusalem are mentioned as being built, there is a slight change in order in the outer parts, and the same stones are placed in its foundations, so that the gates are said to be constructed with the light of crystal (Rev. 21). But also in the breast of the high priest, according to the four orders in the Ephod (Exodus 28), the same stones are described, and on his shoulders two onyx stones, on which the names of the twelve patriarchs are written, which the true high priest, of whom it is written: You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek (Psalm 110:4), carries in his breast, carries on his shoulders, to represent the number of the twelve stones of the apostles; and in the two sacraments of both Testaments, one of which John the Evangelist reclined on his breast, to draw from the wellsprings of wisdom, and be able to say: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God; this was in the beginning with God (John 1:1-2). These are the living stones, from which the Church is built, and 333 of which the Apostle Peter writes: If you have believed, because the Lord is sweet: approaching him as a living stone, indeed rejected by men, but chosen and honored by God, and you yourselves as living stones, are being built into a spiritual house for a holy priesthood, to offer spiritual sacrifices pleasing to God through Jesus Christ: for it is written (Isaiah 28:16): Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone, a cornerstone chosen and precious, and whoever believes in him will not be put to shame (1 Peter 2:3 et seqq.). Moreover, by this vessel of election, He alluded to us, by saying: Them that were built upon the foundation of the Apostles and Prophets, Himself being the chief cornerstone, in whom all the builded frame groweth up into a holy temple to the Lord (Ephes. II, 10). These are the stones, of which we also read in another place: And they shall be carried as in a sling, and they shall be set as a spire-stone, yet a little dust, and they shall roll on and on, hastening to heaven with restless motion (Zach. IX, 16). Of which the Scripture also makes mention: Behold I will lay thy stones in order, and will lay thy foundations with sapphires, and I will make thy bulwarks of jasper, and thy gates of graven stones, and all thy borders of desirable stones. And all thy children shall be taught of the Lord: and great shall be the peace of thy children. And thou shalt be founded in justice: depart far from oppression, for thou shalt not fear, and from terror, for it shall not come near thee. (Isaiah 54:11-13). Concerning which, what it may seem to us, we have declared in the explanations of the same prophet. The 20th Psalm sings of such stones: 'O Lord, in your strength the king will rejoice, and greatly exult in your salvation. You have granted him the desire of his soul and have not withheld the request of his lips. For you meet him with rich blessings; you set a crown of fine gold upon his head.' (Psalm XX, 1ff.) These are the pearls of the prophets and apostles, which, in comparison to Christ, are all sold in the Gospel, in order to buy the most precious pearl, and the stone of which Zacharias writes, that it has seven eyes, that is, the seven graces of the Holy Spirit. (Zechariah III and IV). Read Isaiah. And it is placed by the apostle Paul in the foundation of the Church, on which gold, silver, and precious stones are built (I Cor. III): the colors, natures, and efficacies of each of which, it is not the time of this world to discuss; but they require their own volume: so that in Ezekiel, and in Exodus, and in Revelation and in Isaiah, all the stones and orders of stones compared to themselves, make a great question for reading and discussing. The holy bishop Epiphanius also gave me his own volume. And Pliny the Elder's 37th book, Natural History, discusses gems and stones after a thorough knowledge of all things. The reader should be informed about these. Furthermore, Symmachus's interpretation describes this Tyrian prince as having a precious necklace adorned with stones. Lastly, he calls it a golden ornament, in which the stones are embedded. And according to the Hebrew it follows: The gold is the work of your adornment, and your openings were prepared on the day you were buried. This is why the Septuagint translates it: You filled your treasures and storehouses with gold, indicating the understanding and intention that his thinking had through divine sacraments, and he gathered for himself spiritual riches, about which the Lord commanded: Store up treasures for yourselves in heaven, where neither rust nor moth destroys, and where thieves do not dig and steal. Where your treasure is, there your heart is also (Matt. VI, 21). This is the hidden treasure, of which it also speaks in the Gospel: The kingdom of heaven is like a treasure hidden in a field, which a person finds and hides again, and out of joy, goes and sells everything they have, and buys that field (Ibid., 13). However, the storehouses or granaries are, about which it is written in another place: Blessed shall be your storehouses and your remaining goods (Deut. XXVIII, 5). After this it is said, according to the Hebrew: You are the Cherub stretched out and protecting, the ark of God and the mercy seat are understood as subauditions, or according to the Septuagint, which itself is anointed and created with the Cherub. From this it is shown that this does not pertain to a human prince of the city of Tyre, but to the former and principal strength, which is positioned as the prince of the city of Tyre. And I have set you, he says, on the holy mountain of God; undoubtedly he signifies paradise, to which, after the third heaven, the Apostle Paul says he was caught up (I Cor. XII). But Cherub, of the masculine gender, is said in the singular and plural number, and it is interpreted as a multitude of knowledge. On them God rests and sits, and uses this chariot, as the prophet says to Him: You who are enthroned upon the Cherubim, reveal yourself. And in another place: He mounted the Cherubim and flew; he soared on the wings of the wind. This Cherub, or created with Cherub, extends and protects the sacraments, and is placed on the holy mountain of God, of which we have frequently spoken. And the apostle Paul speaks, if anyone however receives the Letter to the Hebrews: You have come to Mount Zion and the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to thousands of angels (Heb. XII, 22). Or certainly the holy mountain of God, paradise (as we have said) is to be understood. He also walked among fiery stones, of which it is written: He makes His angels spirits, and His ministers flaming fire (Ps. CIII, 4). And not only God, who is called consuming fire, should consume hay, wood, and straw (Deut. IV): but also the angels, who are called fiery stones and are fervent in spirit. Therefore, the Lord says: I came to cast fire upon the earth, and how I wish it were already kindled (Luke XII). And what follows: Perfect in your ways from the day of your creation (for which the Septuagint has: You were blameless in your days, from the day you were created), until evil was found in you, shows that every good creature created by God had perfection and virtue, and that the prince of Tyre was also blameless, so that the stain that follows is not one of nature, but of will. When iniquity was discovered in you, it was discovered by God, which was held captive in the treasures of your heart through pride and the abuse of the power that you had received. In the multitude of his transactions, the inner parts of it, or the storehouses, were filled with iniquity. For while he sought after many things and was not satisfied with the knowledge he had acquired, nor with the power he had been entrusted with, he filled the storehouses and the inner parts of his heart, so that, being satiated and made fat, he kicked against his Creator. For Jacob ate and was satisfied, and the beloved one kicked; he grew fat and plump and stuffed; and he deserted the God who made him (Deut. XXXII, 15). And out of the heart come evil thoughts (Matth. XV, 19). Because of these, God says: You have sinned and I have cast you out from the mountain of God, or you have been wounded by the mountain of God, which, when we read it, we are compelled to fear. For if the extended and protecting Cherub, placed on the holy mountain of God, and perfect and immaculate in the midst of the burning stones, filled his inner being with iniquity and sinned, and was cast out from the mountain of God, that is, from the dwelling place of paradise, or if he was wounded by the mountain of God, who is clearly understood to be Christ, or if he was indeed situated and dwelling on the mountain of God and wounded by himself, and feeling remorse in his conscience for his evil, as he understands himself unworthy of the dwelling place of the mountain: what should we think of ourselves? Because of this, it is said to him: And I have lost you, Cherub, protecting [you] from the midst of the fiery stones, so that you would not remain among the fiery stones, but would perish. O Cherub himself, or Cherubim, who was protecting you, I have brought you out from the midst of the fiery stones, according to that which is also written about Adam: He cast out Adam, and placed [him] (or, Cherubim) opposite the paradise of delights (Genesis 3:24). And it provides the reasons why he was brought out or cast out from the midst of the fiery stones. For your heart has been lifted up in your beauty; you think that what belongs to God is yours. Hence the apostle says that he received a thorn in the flesh, an angel of Satan, to beat him, lest he should be proud of the greatness of his revelations and fall into the judgment of the devil (2 Corinthians 12). And therefore your doctrine is corrupted, he says, with your beauty, or you have lost your wisdom in your beauty: so that while you desire to be more than you were created, and to know more than you received from God, you also lose what you had, and for the sake of beauty and doctrine, deformity and foolishness possess you: hence you are cast down to the earth, who once dwelt on the mountain of God.
