Of which Isaiah writes: How you have fallen from heaven, O morning star, son of the dawn! (Isa. XIV, 12)? And the Savior in the Gospel: I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven (Luke X). And Jeremiah speaks to Jerusalem: How the Lord has covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in his anger! He has hurled down from heaven to earth the splendor of Israel (Lam. II, 1)? But you have been cast out in the sight of all kings, that they might be terrified by your example, whether good kings, whose hearts are in the hand of God (Prov. XXI), or evil ones, whose kingdoms the devil showed to the Savior (Matt. IV): who met the king of Babylon, saying: You too have become weak like us, and you have been counted among us. Therefore, he defiled his sanctification, which he had when he lived on the mountain and walked among the burning stones. It follows: I will bring fire in your midst that will devour you. This fire was ignited in the heart of the king of Tyre by the one whose arrows are aflame, of whom it is written: All of them are like an oven; their hearts are like a burning hearth (Hosea). This fire is also mentioned by Isaiah: Walk in the light of your fire and in the flame you have kindled (Isaiah 50), so that when you go out, it may devour those who possess you, according to what is written in the same Isaiah: It devoured like hay the fuel (Isaiah 5). On that day the mountains, and hills, and forests will be extinguished, and it will consume from the soul even to the flesh. Nadab and Abihu offered this fire, which is called alien, at the altar of the Lord, and for this reason they were consumed by divine fire (Leviticus 10). Hence Moses says: This is the word that the Lord spoke: In those who come near to me I will be sanctified. But the sanctification of God is the punishment of sinners. After this it is said: And I will make you into ashes, so that everything you have built, your evil conscience will be consumed by fire. When you were supposed to rest on the Sabbath and not do any servile work, you gathered wood on the Sabbath so that there would be fuel for the fire that you would devour in your heart. It will also destroy all evil works, turning them into ashes, so that the harmful fire may be completely extinguished, so that all may see and be amazed that the king of Tyre has perished and has become nothing, not in many centuries, but in one, or certainly forever, so that what is written may be fulfilled: I will not spare you, and I will not have pity. The Hebrews are accustomed, among their other fables and genealogies and endless questions, to understand these words spoken against King Hiram of Tyre, when from Solomon to Ezekiel there are many years, which at that time it is clear that men did not live: and thus to pronounce, as if the prophet speaks to him ironically: Are you the seal of the likeness of God, full of wisdom and perfect in beauty? You adorned with all precious stones, you are a cherub, or were you created with a cherub? When, on the contrary, you sinned, and you shall be dissolved into ashes? And they add a marvel to their story, that, contrary to Scripture, or rather, without the authority of Scripture, they say that Hiram lived a thousand years. But the prudent reader understands how violent this interpretation is, without our judgment.

<h2 id='tocuniq280'>(Vers. 20 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 20 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set (or strengthen) your face against Sidon, and prophesy against it, and say: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, Sidon, and I will be glorified in you (or in your midst), and they shall know that I am the Lord when I execute judgments in it (or in you) and am sanctified in it (or in you). And I will send pestilence into it (or into you), and blood shall be in its (or your) streets, and the slain (or wounded) shall fall in its (or your) midst by the sword (or swords) all around, and they shall know that I am the Lord. And there will no longer be a stumbling block of bitterness and a thorn causing pain on every side for the house of Israel (or those who have insulted them); and they will know that I am the Lord God. Thus says the Lord God: When I gather the house of Israel from the peoples (or from the nations) among whom they were scattered, I will be sanctified in them before the nations. And they will dwell in their own land, which I gave to my servant Jacob, and they will dwell in it securely (or in hope). And they will build houses and plant vineyards, and they will dwell confidently (or in hope) when I execute judgments on all those who oppose them (Vulgate adds 'and those who have insulted them') on every side; and they will know that I am their Lord God. And what follows, according to the Septuagint: 'And you, the God of their fathers,' is not found in the Hebrew. Furthermore, after Tyre, mention is made of Sidon; for both cities are in the same province. And in the Gospel, Tyre and Sidon are mentioned together: 'If the miracles done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon' (Matthew 11:21). Therefore, even the Canaanite woman, whose daughter was possessed by a demon, because she came from the region of Tyre and Sidon, obtained what she asked for (ibid., 15). But the divine word predicts that Babylon itself will be captured and will experience the weight of its sins, because the Lord Himself will judge it and sanctify it. It will be consumed by hunger, pestilence, and the sword, so that it will fall in its streets and no longer be a stumbling block to the people of God, nor will it frequently attack them. But when this is done, the people of Israel, whom the Lord had dispersed among different nations, will return to their own land and be sanctified in them. They will not be a bad influence like Sidon, but a good one, because the Lord will have shown them mercy. They will dwell in the land that their father Jacob was given, and they will dwell securely and confidently in the Lord. They will build houses and plant vineyards, fulfilling the promises made to them. And then they will know that the Lord Himself is the one whose promises are most steadfast. As for those who refer many things to the time of Zerubbabel, Ezra, and Nehemiah, when the people of Israel returned and dwelt in the land of Judah, others, however, hope for the fulfillment of these things in the last time and in a thousand years. Moreover, according to spiritual understanding, this seems to us to be the meaning here. They are interpreted as the hunters of Sidon, of whom it is also written in the Psalms: Our soul has been rescued like a bird from the snare of hunters (Psalm 123:7). And in Proverbs: The eye of a harlot is a snare for the sinner (Prov. XXIII, 27). But there are also hunters on the good side, about whom Jeremiah writes: Behold, I will send fishermen and hunters, who will hunt you from every hill and mountain (Jerem. XVI, 16): whom the Lord also sends to fish, and makes them fishers of men (Matthew IV). Hence the village of Peter and Andrew is called by this name: For Bethsaida in our language is interpreted as the house of hunters. Therefore, against these very wicked hunters, the word of God is directed and the prophet is commanded to set his face against Sidon, and not to be swayed by every wind of doctrine, but to stand firm in the truth and destroy his adversaries. What are the threats that the Lord is making against Sidon? Behold, I myself will come to you, and I will be glorified in you when I have killed you, and all who are alive will know that I am the Lord when I repay you according to what you deserve. And I will send pestilence and blood into your streets. And rightly are they called broad streets [platēae] of Sidon ... For wide and spacious is the road that leads to death (Matth. VII). And those who stood wrongly will fall, pierced by a sword that goes around: that sword which the Lord will send upon the earth to separate what is wrongly joined together, and let those who remain know that He is the Lord. And when those [340] have given way, there will no longer be a stumbling block of bitterness, nor a thorn of pain that pierces and wounds the people of God. But all these things are said against the opposing powers, so that in the end times they may be destroyed, and there may be eternal security when the Lord gathers the house of Israel, those who perceive God with understanding. And he will be sanctified in them, and what is written will be fulfilled: Be holy, for I am holy (Leviticus 19:2). And they will dwell in their land, of which we read elsewhere: I believe that I shall see the goodness of the Lord in the land of the living (Psalm 16:13). Jacob, who supplanted his brother before, gave what was his own and deserved to receive the firstfruits. And they will dwell in it, secure in hope, and they will build houses, plant vineyards, and dwell securely in hope, according to what is read in Isaiah: 'O children who have been weaned from milk, who have been taken from the breast, wait for tribulation upon tribulation, and hope upon hope' (Isa. 60). They will build houses, which are also built in the Gospel by him who sets the foundations not on sand, but on rock (Matt. 7). Concerning which it is written: Unless the Lord builds the house, those who build it labor in vain (Psalm 127:1). And in Exodus, according to the Septuagint: Because the midwives feared God, they built houses for themselves (Exodus 1:21), and many similar things. But when the Lord executes judgment against those who oppose or afflict Israel with insults, then every creature will recognize that He is the Lord, whose judgments are true and justified in themselves.


<h2 id='tocuniq281'>(Cap. XXIX.—Vers. 1, 2.)</h2>

(Chapter 29, Verses 1, 2.) In the tenth year (or according to the Septuagint, the twelfth) in the tenth month (or according to the Hebrew, the twelfth), on the first (or on one) day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against Pharaoh king of Egypt and prophesy against him and against all Egypt. Speak and say: Thus says the Lord God. After Sidon, which is also situated on the coast of Phoenicia, the word of the Lord came to the prophet in the tenth year of King Joachim's captivity, in the twelfth month, on the first day of the month, to set his face against Pharaoh king of Egypt and speak of him and of all Egypt, or against all Egypt. For on the other side of Judah, situated on the same coast, there is the province of Egypt, and he shall prophesy about what will come upon them. But if we must say something about the numbers, it is the place of the tenth day among the ten: hence it is not said at the beginning of Genesis: And there was evening and there was morning, the first day, but the one day (Gen. 1), to always indicate the repetition of the same day. The same order among the ten decades, that is, the hundred number, is held by the tenth number, which is considered for the sacrifice of the lamb to be offered on the fourteenth day, and in this way, up to a thousand and ten thousand, and a hundred thousand, and beyond, the order of their numbers proceeds through the decades. After the tenth year, the twelfth month is placed, in order to represent the perfect number of the twelve apostles and prophets (who are contained in one volume). Moreover, according to the Septuagint, the tenth month, which is called Tebeth in Hebrew (), and in Egyptian τυβὶ, is called January by the Romans, because it is the gateway of the year for them: with all heat removed, it contains the dominion of winter cold. Let this be sufficient said about the numbers. Furthermore, that must be especially investigated, whether the person mentioned is Pharaoh himself who is referred to in Exodus, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, and many other places, and in the Song of Songs: I have compared you, my love, to Pharaoh's chariots (Song 1): or is it someone else entirely? It seems to me that it is not just one person, but rather this term is used to denote royal dignity among the Egyptians, just as among the Romans, their emperors and kings are called by the name of the first Gaius Caesar and the second his adopted son Octavian, who was later named Augustus; and among the Syrians, Antioch, among the Persians, the Arsacids, among the Philistines, Abimelech, and after Alexander, the Ptolemies in Egypt until Cleopatra, who, having been defeated at Actium, made Egypt a Roman province. Therefore, in the present time, the word of the Lord is directed against every king of Egypt, which is interpreted as 'the scatterer', clearly meaning the killer and destroyer, who cuts down and separates everything with a sword. This can be understood in a mystical sense as referring to the power to which Egypt is subject. For no man would dare to say: 'The rivers are mine, and I made them', nor would he be called a great dragon, sitting in the midst of his rivers. But Egypt is called 'Mesraim' in Hebrew, which is translated in our language as 'the constrictor' and 'the oppressor', clearly referring to its subjugated people, who are not allowed to lift their eyes to heaven but, in accordance with the Gospel and the example of that woman whom the devil had bowed down for eighteen years, are always sinking into earthly things. Let us therefore see what the threat is against Pharaoh and all of Egypt.

<h2 id='tocuniq282'>(Vers. 3 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 3 onwards) Behold, I am coming to you, Pharaoh king of Egypt, great dragon, who lies (or sits) in the midst of your rivers, and you say: The river is mine, and I have made it for myself (or them). And I will put a bridle (or snare) in your jaws, and I will stick the fish of your rivers to your scales (or feathers), and I will draw you out from the midst of your rivers; and all your fish shall stick to your scales. And I will cast (or throw) you out quickly (or into the desert); and all the fish of your river shall die on the face of the earth (or your land). You shall neither be gathered nor assembled; I have given you to the beasts of the earth and the birds of the air for devouring. And all the inhabitants of Egypt shall know that I am the Lord, because you have become (or were) a staff (or reed) of the house of Israel, when they took (or took hold of) you with their hand (Vulgate is silent on "their"), and you were broken, and tore every shoulder of theirs, and as they leaned on you, you were crushed, and you shattered (or broke) all their loins. We combine both editions of brevitas, where they do not differ much from each other. Otherwise, when there is a great difference, we present both. However, it speaks against Pharaoh, the ruler of Egypt, and under his likeness speaks to great power, which Egypt was given to govern, and yet it proudly claims dominion over its Creator, claiming for itself the rule of the land and handing itself over to be worshipped by the Egyptian peoples. And it speaks according to the location of the province, as if to a king, that it relies on the inundation of the Nile and does not greatly desire rains from the sky, and it believes itself to be the author of itself, or the channels and streams of the Nile, which it boasts are made by itself. No, he said, I will not send an Angel, but, o great dragon, who live and reside in the midst of your rivers, I myself will come to punish you. For you have dared to say: The Nile river is mine, and I am its creator: or, I have made the river by which all of Egypt is irrigated. And when I come, I will put a bit in your jaws: whether I tie your mouth with cords, with which you boasted magnificently, and make all your companions and leaders, whom you call fish, adhere to your feathers or scales, so that you are pulled out of the river and thrown away or cast down. For you have exalted yourself exceedingly in the desert. And you shall fall on the face of the field, or your land, because Egypt is a flat province. Your corpse will not be gathered, nor will you be gathered, that is, you will not be buried, but I will give you to be devoured by beasts and birds of the sky, so that when the inhabitants of Egypt see these judgments executed on you, they may recognize that I am the Lord. But these things will happen to you because you have deceived my people Israel with your assistance, so that they would not trust in their God, the creator, but in you. You were to them a staff made of reed, as Isaiah says (Isa. XXX), or a hollow rod, and a very fragile reed, on which leaners would find no support, so that when they leaned on it, it would break and pierce the shoulder and the hand that held it, and while they trusted in you, all the loins of those who fell to the ground would be crushed, and those seeking help would receive wounds. But these things are said metaphorically to the king of Egypt, because that province was never an enemy to Israel, but while it made great promises, it would separate them from God's help. But according to anagoge, we often read about the opposing power of the dragon. And so Pharaoh is said to be a scatterer, who separates and disconnects from God, and Egypt, that is, Egypt, is turned into tribulation and affliction, namely those whom it can subjugate. This dragon is a transgressor, about whom Job speaks most fully (Job XL, 41). And in the Psalms it is written: You have smashed the heads of the dragon, you have given him as food to the people of Ethiopia (Ps. LXXIII, 14). And the great dragon is said to be compared to the lesser dragons, about which it is sung in the psalm: You have crushed the heads of the dragons in the waters (Ibid.). And in another place: This great and spacious sea, there the creeping things, of which there is no number: small animals with big ones, there ships will pass through: This dragon, whom You have formed to mock him (Ibid., CIII, 25 seqq.). Of whom it is also said in another place: He is the king of all that are in the waters, and the beginning of the representation of the Lord, who became, that he might be mocked by his angels (Job. XLI, 24, sec. LXX). But he sits or lies down, in the midst of his rivers, not of one river, but of many, which we understand to represent various heresies, through which he flowed into Egypt of this present age, and watered the souls of the seduced, not with the rains coming down from heaven, but with the muddy waters from the earth, which Jeremiah does not prohibit to drink, saying: What to you and the ways of Egypt, that you may drink the water of Geon? (Jer. 11:18). Instead of which, in Hebrew it is written Sior (), which word is translated to mean 'muddy' and 'muddy'. But in order to understand what the rivers of the Egyptian dragon are, we can know from opposites. The Lord speaks about His rivers: Whoever believes in me, rivers of living water will flow from his belly (John 7:37). And to the Samaritan woman: Whoever drinks from the water that I will give him will never thirst again, but it will become in him a well of water springing up to eternal life (John 4:13-14). These are the rivers coming from heaven, of which David sings: The streams of the river make the city of God glad (Psalm 46:4): undoubtedly it signifies the Church. Let us therefore consider what punishment the dragon receives, or what torture it is. Next follows: And I will put a bridle or a noose in your jaws. Similar to this is what Job says: But you shall draw in the serpent with a hook, and put a bridle about his nostrils. It trusts that the Jordan may enter into its mouth; it will receive him in its eye. But a bracelet will pierce its nostrils, and its lips (Job 40:19). The Lord puts a bridle in the jaws of this dragon, and pierces its lips and restrains it with a circle of a bracelet, when through the Ecclesiastical men, who are learned in the holy Scriptures, he imposes silence upon it, and all the teachings of wickedness are dissolved. And the fish of its rivers are congealed by its own wings or scales, with which the heretics, in their arrogance, hasten to the heights, so that they, too, bound with the dragon, may make one body with it and be joined to it either in the fellowship of error or in the likeness of punishment. Just as one who adheres to the Lord is one spirit (1 Corinthians 6:17). And indeed the Egyptian dragon has not one river, but many rivers, with which it waters lowly and desolate Egypt, having nothing within it of mountains, nor does it possess the waters of Siloam, which flow silently, but turbid and muddy waters (Isaiah 8). And the Lord will remove him from the midst of his rivers, so that he shall not have dominion over them, nor sit upon them: and all the fishes of the rivers shall stick to his scales. According to the greatness of his vices is he dragged, and as his sin is, so also shall his strength be. The scales of his flesh shall stick together as with a brazen strong shield. His heart shall be as hard as a stone, and as firm as a smith's anvil. When he shall raise him up, the angels shall fear, and being affrighted shall purify themselves. The sword of him that layeth at him shall not be able to hold, the spear, the dart, nor the breastplate. He shall esteem iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood. The archer shall not put him to flight, the stones of the sling are to him like stubble. As stubble will he esteem the hammer, and he will laugh him to scorn who shaketh the spear. The beams of the sun shall be under him, and he shall strew gold under him like mire. He shall make the deep sea to boil as a pot, and shall make it as when ointments boil. A path shall shine after him, he shall esteem the deep as growing old. There is nothing upon earth like to him, who was made to fear no one. He beholdeth every high thing, he is king over all the children of pride. Indeed, I will cast you down from the pinnacle of your pride, and I will cast you down swiftly, according to the words of the Apostle: 'And the God of peace shall bruise Satan under your feet speedily' (Rom. XVI, 20); so that the dragon may be crushed and cast down, and the fishes of that river may also be cast down, and the author of crimes may fall, who once thought himself to stand and to travel throughout the whole world. Let him fall upon the face of his own land, to which he was precipitated from heaven, so that he may by no means be gathered any longer in the Churches of heretics, neither be assembled nor buried among those who have believed in him, since they have been freed from him, but let him be given to be devoured by the beasts of the earth and the birds of the air. Regarding the beasts, it is written: 'Do not deliver the soul confessing to you to the beasts' (Psalm 73:19). And concerning the birds of the air, which eat the seed by the roadside and are interpreted to be the devils by the Savior (Matthew 13). For not only the prince of evil, but also his disciples are called devils, as it is said of Judas: 'Have I not chosen you twelve, and one of you is a devil?' (John 6:71). And the birds of the air are called the heavens, because they promise themselves lofty things, so that after the dragon is cast down with his fish and delivered to be devoured by the beasts of the earth, which have no gentleness in themselves, and by those who are carried about by every wind of doctrine (Ephesians 4), then all the inhabitants of this world shall understand that he is the Lord. But the reason for punishments is that the house of Israel sought aid in vain and there was for them a rod, or a reed staff, empty and devoid of anything fullness, because it could not say: But of His fullness we all have received (John 1:16); since the Scripture commands: You shall not appear before the sight of the Lord your God empty or devoid (Exodus 23:15). And the Scripture elsewhere testifies that we should not seek aid from Egypt: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help (Isaiah 31:1). He taunts Hezekiah, the king of Judah, with a reed staff, mocking his trust in it, saying that it is broken and useless against Egypt. He warns that whoever relies on it will fall into his power. This is what Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, does to all who trust in him (Isa. 36:6). He falsely accuses the righteous king, who is symbolized by the staff, of being a drunkard. Hezekiah was deceived by the golden cup of Babylon and used his own possessions to appease the people who praised the Lord. But here the pharaoh is reproached because the house of Israel trusted in a rod or staff made of reed, which promised them empty and fragile assistance that would quickly be broken. However, in order to understand what the rod made of reed is, on which the house of Israel should not trust, we can understand the opposite by means of the rod and staff of the Lord, of which it is said to the Lord, 'Your rod and your staff, they have comforted me.' (Psalm 23:4). Aaron also had this staff, which devoured the Egyptian dragons, and when he struck the banks of the Nile, gnats were generated in all of Egypt. Moses also, according to the Septuagint, extended this staff and raised it to the sky, and the Lord brought a south wind upon the land all that day and all that night, and in the morning the wind lifted and brought locusts upon all the land of Egypt. I think that this staff is also mentioned in the Book of Numbers, that it blossomed and bore almonds or almond nuts. The Apostle also had this when he said, 'What do you want? Shall I come to you with a rod, or in love and a spirit of gentleness?' (1 Corinthians 4:21) And those who celebrated the Passover held staffs in their hands, without which they could not eat the flesh of the lamb, which sustains the weakness of the human body. This is the rod from the root of Jesse, upon which the seven spirits rested. But it is not like the rod of Pharaoh, nor the Egyptian staff, nor the reed staff that deceives those who hold it, and tears their shoulders, that is, their strength." } And whoever relies on it, their loins are weakened and they cannot stand, nor can they celebrate the Passover with their loins girded. This applies to those whose hearts and kidneys are searched by God.

<h2 id='tocuniq283'>(Vers. 8 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 8 onwards) 347 Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will bring a sword upon you and cut off from you man and beast. And the land of Egypt shall become a desolation (or a waste) and a wilderness. Then they will know that I am the Lord, because they said (or you said), 'The Nile is mine, and I made it' (or 'The rivers are mine, and I made them'). Therefore, behold, I am against you and against your rivers, and I will make the land of Egypt an utter waste, devastated by the sword, from Migdol to Syene (or from Migdol to Syene and even to the border of Ethiopia). The foot of man shall not pass through it, and the foot of beast shall not tread in it: and it shall be uninhabited forty years. And I will make the land of Egypt utterly waste in the midst of the countries that are waste, and her cities among the cities that are desolate shall be laid waste forty years: and I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and will disperse them through the countries. For thus saith the Lord God: After the end of forty years I will gather the Egyptians together from the people among whom they had been scattered. And I will bring back the captivity of Egypt, and I will settle them in the land of Phatures, in the land of their birth (or in the land from which they were taken). And they will be there in a humble kingdom (or principality), among the other kingdoms it will be the humblest (or most humble). And they will no longer be exalted above the nations, and I will diminish them, so that they do not rule over the nations (or so that they are not many among the nations). Nor will they be a confidence (or in hope) to the house of Israel, teaching iniquity, to escap and pursue them (or to bring them to the remembrance of iniquity, to pursue them). And they will know that I am the Lord God. You were a reed staff to the house of Israel, and not only were you broken in his hand, but according to Isaiah (Isa. XXXVI), you pierced his hand and now lacerated his shoulder, and you yourself were shattered, and you dissolved the loins of those who relied on you: therefore I will bring a sword of enemies upon you, and I will devastate both men and animals, and the land of Egypt will be reduced to desolation, and the Egyptians will know for a second time that I am the Lord. I will not be satisfied with this end; but because he burst forth into such blasphemy, claiming that the rivers and all the abundance of Egypt were his own, therefore I will take away even him who claimed to be the Creator, and the rivers that he boasted were created by him, and I will reduce the land of Egypt to a vast wilderness, destroyed by the sword, from the tower of Syene to the borders of Ethiopia. For the tower which is called Magdal () in Hebrew, the LXX assigned the name, so that they would write Μαγδαλὸν. However, the tower of Syene remains to this day, a fortress under Roman rule, where the cataracts of the Nile are located, and it is the furthest point navigable from our sea. He says that the whole of Egypt should be depopulated as far as the borders of Ethiopia, where the furthest region of Egypt is joined, so that no foreigner may enter Egypt, and no animals are found there, and it is not inhabited for forty years. However, they spare the Egyptians, and because Israel once had been guests, the punishment is for a shorter period of time. Tyrus kept its Sabbaths for seventy years, and thus it was restored to its ancient state. The captivity of Judaea and the destruction of the temple lasted for seventy years until the reign of Cyrus, the king of Persia. For the mighty will endure mighty torments (Wisdom 6:7). And when it says, 'I will make the land of Egypt desolate among desolate lands,' it refers to the Palestinians, the Edomites, the Moabites, and all the other regions against which the prophecy of the prophets above stands. Then he will scatter or spread the Egyptians into nations, and he will scatter them into lands. For the Lord is merciful and compassionate, patient and full of mercy. After forty years, the restoration of Egypt will occur, and all the captivity will be brought back to its original land and placed in the metropolis city called Phatures, where it originated and where it came from. However, in order to benefit themselves, they will lose their ancient pride and become a humble kingdom, even the humblest of all nations. They will no longer rise above other nations or have dominion over them; instead, they will be reduced in number and not deceive the house of Israel with their confidence, nor teach them iniquity or remind them of their iniquities when they sought help from Egypt after abandoning the assistance of God. And all these things will happen so that the Egyptians may know on the third day that He is the Lord. We have briefly touched on these matters, laying the foundations of the story. Now it is necessary to expound on the allegory, and we will attempt to avoid lengthening the explanation with the same brevity. The speech is directed at the dragon, who had said, 'The rivers are mine, and I have made them' (Supra, eod.): which indicates that the Lord Himself will bring a sword upon him, concerning which it is written in Isaiah: 'My sword is drunk in heaven; now it will descend upon the earth to destroy both man and beast from it' (Isa. XXXIV, 5), whatever appears to have either reason or simplicity. And it will destroy, not absolutely, but the dragon, so that the dragons may perish and may live in God, and let the land of Egypt become a ruin, according to the higher sense, so that the dragon may perish, and after its destruction be reduced to desolation, ceasing to have the worst possible guest. And then men and animals will know, and the earth will be scattered, that He is the Lord: in the sense in which it is written in the seventy-seventh Psalm: When He slew them, then they sought Him (Ps. 77:34). For whoever seeks, finds. It is indeed a mercy of God that the abundance of this world perishes, and the streams of Egypt are dried up, nay, that their land becomes a wilderness, and the plan of the Lord is scattered from the tower of Syene, which means a circle, so that it may have nothing in it that is right, even to the land of the Ethiopians, who are called humble, so that all pride that has exalted itself against the knowledge of God may be destroyed, and humbled unto its salvation. Neither the foot of man, which is a rational being, may pass through Egypt, nor may the foot of an animal tread upon it, so that it may not even hold the innocent ones whom Pharaoh desired to retain in Egypt after the people were dismissed, with Moses opposing him and desiring that the animals too be liberated from Egyptian captivity. And, He said, 'They shall not dwell there for forty years,' which number always represents affliction and punishment. Therefore, both Moses and Elijah, and even the Savior Himself, fasted for forty days and nights, and the people spent forty years in the wilderness, so that they might later be circumcised in Gilgal and be delivered from the reproach and ignominy of Egypt. In the sacrament of this number, and the same prophet here, for the tribe of Judah, sleeps for forty days on the right side, and it is announced that the people will serve in Egypt for four hundred years (Gen. VII): those who make forty centuries, or four centurias. Rainstorms also flood the world for forty days. For it was just that the one who offends God by loving and nurturing the four elements of the world, by which all things are said to consist, should be punished in that very number: and Israel, who sinned on the Sabbath, endured a punishment of seven decades, that is, seventy years. And the land of Egypt will be given and its deserts, and its cities in the midst of the land and the cities that have been destroyed, which are not built of stones but of mud and straw, so that Egypt, which had been wrongly joined together, may be scattered and blown away into the lands, and the grain may be separated from the straw, and when the forty years are completed, there will be the restoration of Egypt, and its captivity will be brought back, and it will be placed in the land of Phatures, which means trampled bread; where that bread which said, 'I am the bread which came down from heaven' (John 6:5), was trampled by heretical wickedness: so that when they come to the Church, they may dwell in trampled bread, and may not be lifted up in pride, but may be in a humble kingdom. And so, even when they are restored to their original state, they humble themselves through humility, because they have lived in Egypt and built brick cities, and among many kingdoms they are humble to the Church, and they know against whom they have sinned, and Egypt shall no longer rise above the Churches divided throughout the world, but it shall be reduced to few, and only a few shall remain among the nations, according to what is written: Give them, O Lord. What will you give them? Give them a barren womb, and dry breasts (Hosea 9:4): so that they may not rejoice and exult in the multitude of the deceived, but be reduced to few: For many are called, but few are chosen (Matthew 20). And let them no longer deceive the house of Israel, that is, the Church; nor promise them vain hope and confidence, teaching iniquity, so that they may escape Ecclesiastical discipline and follow Egyptian pleasures. But these things will happen so that the Egyptians may know on the third day that He is the Lord. This seems to me to be said for this reason: the first knowledge of the Egyptians is in the flesh, the second in the soul, and the third in the spirit. First, on the earth, second, after the conversation of this world is finished, third, after the resurrection.

<h2 id='tocuniq284'>(Vers. 17 seq.)</h2>

(Vers. 17 seq.)  351 And it came to pass in the twenty-seventh year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon caused his army to serve a great service against Tyre: every head was made bald, and every shoulder was rubbed bare, and there was no wages given to him, nor to his army, for the service that he served against it. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will give Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, the land of Egypt, and he shall carry off its multitude, and plunder its spoil, and take its prey; and it shall be the wages for his army. I have given him the land of Egypt as his payment for which he served me, declares the Lord God. In that day I will cause a horn to sprout for the house of Israel, and I will open your mouth in the midst of them. And they shall know that I am the Lord. It is asked how, after ten years from the previous discourse, immediately the twenty-seventh year is mentioned, and in the following, the tenth and twelfth, and in the final description of the temple, the twenty-fifth. But the solution is simple. For since it covers both Egypt and the superior part, and what is now called prophecy, although it is made at different times, it is united because it prophesies about one province. And as we frequently read in Jeremiah, the order of events is described in a reverse order. For the deeds of Zedekiah are reported first, and then those of Jehoiachin who came before him. But in the Psalms, because it is a lyric poem, the order of the events is not sought. Let us therefore speak first according to the literal interpretation. When Nebuchadnezzar besieged Tyre, and because it was surrounded by the sea, he could not bring rams, machines, and siege towers close to the walls, he ordered an infinite multitude of the army to bring stones and earthworks, and with the middle of the sea filled, indeed with the narrowest strait, he made the adjacent shore into a continuous island (or, neighboring shore into a connected one). When the Tyrians saw that the city was now completely finished and that the foundations of the walls were being shaken by the battering ram, they loaded onto ships whatever precious things the nobility had in gold, silver, clothing, and various furnishings, and carried them to the islands, so that when the city was captured, Nebuchadnezzar found nothing worthy of his efforts. And because he had obeyed God's will in this matter, after several years of Tyrian captivity, Egypt was given to him, and Tyre was much more cruel to Egypt. For she was besieging Jerusalem; this one was making empty promises of help. For it is one thing to deceive weakness with hope, and another to fight against the people of God. This is therefore what Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, says: in the siege of Tyre he made his army serve me, so that I might fulfill my will: Every head is shaved, and every shoulder is depilated, carrying loads of earth, and stones with which shoulders are shaved, and the head is shaved; and yet neither he nor his army found anything worthy in Tyre. And when he has served me in this, and fulfilled my will against Tyre, therefore I will give him the land of Egypt. Some say that this was accomplished under Nebuchadnezzar: others under Cambyses, the son of Cyrus, who devastated Egypt up to Ethiopia, so that he killed Apis and destroyed all their idols. For this reason, they think that he was turned into madness by the accident of a horse, and stabbed himself with his own dagger. Herodotus narrates this story in great detail: where all of Egypt is described by towns, castles, and villages, and the origin of the Nile and the nation of its people, and the measurement of the land around to the desert of Ethiopia, and the shores of the Great Sea, and the borders of Libya and Arabia. But the cause of the Lord's anger against Egypt is that it deceived His people and prevented them from hoping in God, and it provoked Him to anger. On that day when Egypt is captured, the horn of the house of Israel will sprout: undoubtedly symbolizing the royal lineage. Some refer this to Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, who was descended from the Davidic line through Jeconiah, while others refer it to the final times, when they think that Elijah will come. But we, understanding the horn of the Lord to be Christ, take hold of the present story. And when, he says, this has first been fulfilled, then your mouth will be opened, and your prophecy will hang not on doubtful promise, but will be seen accomplished by the work: so that all who hear may know that I am the Lord, whose words have been spoken and actions performed. These things have been said according to the letter, indeed, according to the truth of the prophecies. Furthermore, from the fact that Nebuchadnezzar received a reward for good work, we also understand that even the Gentiles, if they do something good, are not overlooked by God's judgment without a reward. Therefore, through Jeremiah, Nebuchadnezzar is called the dove of God because he served the will of the sinful people of God. And he says, 'I will bring my servant Nebuchadnezzar' (Jeremiah 25). From this it is clear that we are condemned in comparison to the Gentiles, if they do the natural law, which we also neglect the written law. About which Paul the apostle disputes extensively with the Romans. And lest we seem to pass over anything according to spiritual understanding, we ask where we may read this number, that is, the twenty-seventh. In the book of Genesis, Scripture testifies (Gen. VII) that in the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the second month, the waters of the flood were brought upon the face of the earth, and after the seventh month of the same year, which is close to the sabbath, and on the twenty-seventh day of the same seventh month, the waters of the flood ceased, and Noah's ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat, which are interpreted as Armenia. From this we understand that the number is intermediate and can be applied to both, since in this both the anger of God begins with the flood, and his mercy is demonstrated in the seventh month in the same number of days. And because among the Hebrews the month, which among us is counted by the Kalends, Nones, and Ides, is calculated according to the course of the moon: hence also in the Greek word μήνη, that is, moon, has received its name from the month, it is said on the twenty-seventh day of the moon that a little of its light remains, so that his anger may not be without mercy. But when the entire orbit of the moon is completed, then Easter and all the greatest solemnities are celebrated. We have laid it down precisely so that we may know that in this number, both good and evil are equally contained. Good for Nebuchadnezzar, whose labor is rewarded; evil for the Egyptians, whose destruction is announced.

<h2 id='tocuniq285'>(Cap. XXX.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter XXX—Verse 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy and say: Thus says the Lord God: Wail, woe to the day! For the day is near, even the day of the Lord is near, a day of clouds, it will be the time of the nations. And the sword will come upon Egypt, and there will be panic in Ethiopia when the slain fall in Egypt, and its multitude is taken away, and its foundations are destroyed. Ethiopia, Libya, Lydia, and all the mixed people, and Chub, and the sons of the land of the covenant with them will fall by the sword. Thus says the Lord God: The supports of Egypt will fall, and the pride of its power will be destroyed. From the tower of Syene they will fall by the sword, says the Lord of hosts. They will be scattered in the midst of desolate lands, and its cities will become deserted. And they will know that I am the Lord when I set fire to Egypt and all its helpers are crushed. On that day messengers will go out from me in ships to terrify the confidence of Cush, and there will be panic among them on the day of Egypt's fall, for it is certain to come. Thus says the Lord God: And I will cause the multitude of Egypt to cease by the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon: he and his people with him, the strongest of the nations, shall be brought to destroy the land. And they shall unsheath their swords against Egypt, and fill the land with the slain. And I will make the rivers dry, and deliver the land into the hand of wicked men, and will scatter the land and its abundance into the hands of strangers: I the Lord have spoken. Thus says the Lord God: I will destroy the idols and put an end to the idols of Memphis, and there will no longer be a leader in the land of Egypt, and I will bring terror to the land of Egypt. I will destroy the land of Pathros and set fire to Taphnis, and I will bring judgments upon Alexandria, and I will pour out my fury upon Pelusium, the stronghold of Egypt, and I will kill the multitude of Alexandria, and I will set fire to Egypt. Like a woman in labor, Pelusium will mourn, and Alexandria will be laid waste, and there will be daily distress in Memphis. The young men of Heliopolis and Bubastis will fall by the sword, and the captives themselves will be led away. And in Taphnis the day will darken when I shatter the scepters of Egypt, and the pride of its power will fail in it. The cloud will cover it, and its daughters will be led into captivity. And I will execute judgments in Egypt, and they will know that I am the Lord. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy and say: Thus says the Lord God: O day, behold, it is near, and the day of the Lord is close; a day of clouds, the end of the nations. And a sword will come upon the Egyptians, and there will be turmoil in Ethiopia. And the wounded will fall in Egypt, and they will take away its multitude, and its foundations will be cut down. Persians, and Cretans, and Lydians, and Libyans, and all who are mixed, and the sons of my covenant will fall by the sword. Thus says the Lord God. And the pillars of Egypt will fall, and the pride of its strength will come down from Migdol to Syene. They will fall by the sword in it, says the Lord God. And it shall be desolate in the midst of desolate regions, and its cities shall be in the midst of deserted cities, and they shall know that I am the Lord, when I set fire to Egypt, and all who help her are broken. In that day there shall go forth messengers from before my face in haste, to destroy the hope of Ethiopia, and there shall be consternation among them in the day of Egypt, for it is coming. Thus says the Lord God. And I will destroy the multitude of the Egyptians by the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon himself, and his people with him, pestilences that come from the nations to destroy the land. And they shall unsheathe all their swords against Egypt, and the land shall be filled with the wounded. And I will make their rivers dry, and I will deliver the land into the hand of the wicked, and I will destroy the land, and its fullness will be in the hands of foreigners: I the Lord have spoken. For thus saith the Lord God: And I will destroy abominations, and I will cause the nobles of Memphis to fail, and the princes of the land of Egypt, and they shall be no more. And I will bring terror upon the land of Egypt, and I will destroy the land of Pathros, and I will bring fire upon Zoan, and I will execute judgments in Thebes, and I will pour out my wrath upon Sin, the stronghold of Egypt, and I will destroy the multitude of No. And I will send fire upon Egypt, and Sais shall be in great anguish, and there shall be a split in Diospolis, and the waters shall be scattered. The young men of Heliopolis and Bubastis shall fall by the sword, and the women shall be taken captive, and in Taphnis the day shall become dark, when I break the scepters of Egypt there, and the pride of its strength shall come to an end, and a cloud shall cover it, and its daughters shall be led away captive, and I will execute judgments on Egypt, and they shall know that I am the Lord. After the twenty-seventh year of the captivity of King Joachim, we return to the present time when he began prophesying against Egypt, that is, in the tenth year and tenth month, on the eleventh day of the month. And the Lord commanded him to speak to all nations, especially to Egypt. What, therefore, does he say? Wail, alas, alas for the day, for the day of the Lord is near; it is approaching like a storm, not with bright shining sun, but with clouds covering it, and bringing a tempest upon Babylon. And when the sword begins to devastate Egypt, there will be panic in Ethiopia, which is near Egypt, lest the Babylonian blade reach even to them. For the wounded will fall in Egypt, and its multitude will be taken away, and everything will be destroyed to its foundations, so that if anyone is found in Egypt from Ethiopia, and Libya, and Lydia, and in general from various peoples and from Chub, which Symmachus translates as Arabia, and from the sons of the land of the covenant, that is, from the people of Judah, they will fall by that sword. For which nations, seventy were set, Persians, and Cretans, and Lydians, and Libyans, and all mixed people, and the sons of my Testament, they shall fall by the sword. And that we may know that all these nations were in aid to Egypt, the following discourse demonstrates: And those who supported Egypt shall fall, that is, her allies, and all the pride of her empire, or the insult of her strength shall be destroyed and cast down from the tower of Syene, which we said is situated in the farthest borders of Egypt, from Magdalo to Syene, as the seventy have translated: all the cities of Egypt shall be deserted, that they may acknowledge the Lord, when the fire of the Chaldeans has devastated all, and all its helpers are crushed, and messengers arrive according to the Aquila and Theodotion (whom Symmachus translated), hastening: we have turned to the triremes; for thus we have learned from the Hebrews: that all the confidence of Ethiopia may be shattered, and when the neighboring province has been laid waste, fear may seize the closest. But in order to know who this sword was, which devastated Egypt and terrified Ethiopia, it follows more clearly: And I will make the multitude of Egypt cease in the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, who will not only come, but will come with many accompanying nations, so that all Egypt will be filled with the blood of the slain, and the anger of the Lord will be so great that the channels of the rivers, that is, the canals of the Nile, will dry up to the ground, and in the hand of the pests, or the fullness of the worst men, Egypt will be deserted. For my words cannot be in vain, and therefore indignation will advance there, so that the images of Egypt are scattered, and the idols of Memphis cease, which until now is the metropolis of Egyptian superstition, whether the nobles and leaders of Memphis, and of the land of Egypt. But such terror will possess all of Egypt, that the whole land of Phatur will perish, and fire will ravage Taphnis, or as the Seventy have translated, Tanin. And he said, I will make judgments in Alexandria, which is called so today. However, it has the ancient name of No, which Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotio translated as it is written in Hebrew. For this reason, I do not know what the Seventy translators, also known as the Septuagint, intended and said the small city of Diospolis, which is in Egypt, instead of No. But we have chosen Alexandria for No, by anticipation, which is called 'πρόληψις' in Greek, according to that Virgilian verse (Aeneid. book IV):

And Lavinia came to the shores; not at the time when Aeneas came to Latium, they were called Lavinia; but those which were afterwards called Lavinia, in order to make the location more apparent to the understanding of the reader. And I will pour out, he says, my indignation upon Sain, which we turn into Pelusium, and it is called the strength of Egypt, because it has the safest port, and sea trade is especially carried on there. Hence the poet calls it Pelusiac lentil (Virgil. I Georg.), not because this type of legume is produced there, or especially so; but because it is brought there most abundantly from Thebaid and all of Egypt through the stream of the Nile. And he said, 'I will destroy the multitude of Alexandria, which is again placed in Hebrew No, not in Diospolis, as mentioned above, but in Memphis, they transferred to the LXX. And to show that the city was populous at that time, 'I will destroy the multitude of No (); and I will give fire, that is, the king of Babylon in Egypt, who will devastate everything like fire. Sain, that is, Pelusium, will suffer like a woman in labor: or will be disturbed by turmoil; and in Alexandria, that is, in No, there will be a fissure, and the waters will be dispersed, for which they transferred to Diospolis again, the LXX. However, it is the custom of the Egyptians, because of the flooding of the Nile, to build high embankments along the banks of the Nile. If these embankments are breached due to the negligence of the guards or the excessive size of the water, the surrounding fields are not irrigated by water, but rather they are overwhelmed and devastated. By this it is signified how Egypt is usually occupied by the Chaldean army, just as it is accustomed to be covered and corrupted when the waters of the Nile overflow and increase beyond measure. Concerning the flooding of the waters, and the breaking and breach of the embankments, it is written in Hebrew: 'There shall be daily distress in Memphis, where the Nile is divided, and where the temple of Apis is, and where the oracles give their answers, there shall daily distresses arise. The young men also of Heliopolis, which in Hebrew is called On, and of Bubastus another city, shall fall by the sword: so that the cities themselves, that is, their inhabitants or women, shall be led into captivity, who are of the female sex and subject to injury.' But in Taphnis, which is the royal city, the scepters of Egypt, that is, the entire royal race, will be crushed. And when its power, with the princes slain, shall have failed, then the day shall grow dark, and all things shall be filled with gloom and darkness, so that the city itself shall be covered with a cloud of mourning and lamentation, and its daughters, that is, the remaining towns, shall be led into captivity. So after I have executed judgments in Egypt and shown myself to be the judge to all, then the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord. We have described these elements as if for little children, so that they may progress to the reading of prose or poetry through letters, syllables, words, and the arrangement of words. Now let us venture into anthropology, and in a brief, almost pictorial manner, let us demonstrate the widest ocean of discussion. The speech of the Lord, who was always in the Father, became that of a prophet, and He called Himself not by His own name, but the Son of Man. This is always understood in a positive sense in the Holy Scriptures, only in the singular number, as in this same prophet, and in Daniel, and in the Gospel. Moreover, in the plural number it is read in the opposite way, as in this: Sons of men, their teeth are weapons and arrows, and their tongue is a sharp sword (Psalm 56:5). And again: Sons of men, how long will you have a heavy heart? (Psalm 4:3). For the lion will roar, and who will not fear? The Lord has spoken, and who will not prophesy? (Amos 3:8). Howl, they say, woe, woe to the day because it is near, and it comes, says the Lord, a day of clouds, a time or end of nations it will be. Duplex consummation is either general of all, when the end comes, or specific of each, when the time of death arrives. It is called duplex because, in comparison to eternity, all time is short. Hence Jacob said that his 130 years are few and evil days. And the Psalmist, speaking of the fragility of the whole human race, says: Our days have passed away like a shadow. Considering this, we will not be lifted up by power, nor will we dwell on riches, nor will we rejoice in happiness, knowing that everything must quickly be taken away. And the day of the Lord is said to be beautiful, when the whole conversation of the world will be destroyed, and with error removed, truth will appear as one, and the days of clouds and fog. For no one fearless and uncertain waits for the judgment from the judge without fear. And the time or end of the nations will not be of one Egyptian nation, but of all, so that it may be clearly foretold about all the nations. Following, there will come to Egypt a sword, a fiery versatile sword, the divine word that separates the good from the evil and consumes the wicked with its fire. But in Egypt of this age, it will be a terror, like in Ethiopia, where they wander through Egypt in the darkness of error and stay in the shadows, and their darkness does not easily or at all turn into light. And those who stood in wickedness will fall wounded in Egypt. And the multitude of Egypt shall be taken away. For wide is the gate and broad is the way that leads to destruction (Matthew 7:13). And its foundations shall be destroyed, so that nothing of the former stability remains in Egypt. But let the worst foundations be abandoned, and let the foundation of Christ be laid upon which the Church shall be built. For every plantation which the Heavenly Father has not planted shall be uprooted (Matthew 7). Therefore, Jeremiah is commanded to destroy what has been built, in order to build better things (Jeremiah 1). The Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians will also perish in Egypt, or according to the Septuagint, the Persians, Cretans, Lydians, Libyans, and Chub, that is, the Arabs, and all the remaining common people whom the Seventy translated as hybrids and mixtures. All of these, depending on the variety of vices and the interpretation of names that we have set forth in the vision of Tyre, we can understand as different nations. Hence, the Apostle says: You, he says, gentiles in the flesh, who are called Uncircumcision (Ephesians 2:11). For he never would have spoken of nations in the flesh, unless there were others in the spirit, as in another place: Behold Israel according to the flesh. Therefore, great care must be taken that we do not turn back in our hearts to Egypt, from which we once came out, and that we do not find ourselves among other nations; and that we do not perish by the sword, about which it is said in the following: The youths of Heliopolis and Bubastis shall fall by the sword, especially when the sons of the land of the covenant, or of my Testament, shall be struck with the sword at the same time, of whom it is written: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help and rely on horses and chariots  (Isaiah 31:1). But if the men of other nations are slaughtered in Egypt, how much more the sons of the land of the covenant and Testament of God, who, despising the bread of angels, have remembered the pumpkins, and onions, and garlic, and shallots, and cucumbers of Egypt (Num. 11). Then the supports and props of Egypt, which sustained it in wickedness, will collapse, the subtleties of the dialecticians and the sophistries of the philosophers. Also, the contemptuous and proud empire will be destroyed, those who speak about everything with arrogance and consider Ecclesiastical simplicity as nothing. For indeed, towers fall in those places which are at the extreme boundaries of Egypt, near Syene, Ethiopia, and the Blemmyae: where the Nile is unnavigable, and there is the roar of cataracts, and everything is impassable and full of serpents and venomous animals. But if, as we said above, Magnesia signifies magnificence, and Syene signifies a round course, it is clear that the resources of Egypt, and its insolent strength and magnificence, that is, its boasting and exaltations, will perish by violence as far as the round course of Egypt, where nothing is stable; but it is swept away by an uncertain fall, and comes to ruin. Then the cities of Egypt will be scattered and the land will be deserted, and no assembly will remain, having any stability, so that they may know at the end of things that He himself is the Lord, when He sends fire into Egypt, which the Lord desires to burn, like hay, wood, and straw, which are built upon the foundation of Christ, and all the helpers of perverse doctrines are crushed. From this it is to be understood that the knowledge of false name and those about whom it is written: Scatter the nations that want war (Ps. LXVII, 32), are called allies and helpers of Egypt. In that day, says he, those messengers shall go forth from the face of God, of whom it is written in the Gospel: Their angels always see the face of my Father who is in heaven (Matt. XVIII, 20). And in the parable of the seed, the reapers are the angels, that is, those who are messengers, are sent to gather together all scandals and cast them into the furnace of fire, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth (Ibid. XIII). And they will hasten to fulfill the commandment, to deter or crush the confidence of Ethiopia, who have reached the summit of malice, so that in the overthrow of Egypt Ethiopia may be crushed and may fear, because the day of the Lord is a day of vengeance and retribution, when the darkness of sins will flee and the light of virtues will remain. And I will make the multitude of Egypt cease, says the Lord, in the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, to punish them. For he is an enemy and avenger who has also received payment, because he served in the conquest of Tyre, the multitude of Egypt: so that many in Egypt may cease to exist, who have always been there. But if someone opposes, how can it be said in Deuteronomy: Your fathers went down to Egypt with seventy persons: and now the Lord your God has made you as the stars of heaven in multitude (Deut. X, 22): this is easily resolved. For he did not set forth an example of an earthly multitude, but of a heavenly one, which shines with virtues and is full of light, above which multitude the mightiest of nations are brought, so that they might disperse the land, for whom the Seventy render a pestilent interpretation. I do not know how this agrees with those who are brought by the Lord, unless perhaps according to that example, the sending forth through wicked Angels (Psalm 77:19): who shall unsheath their swords upon Egypt, and shall fill the land with the slain or wounded, so that they may perceive themselves to have killed and wounded, and to such an extent Egypt is destroyed and reduced to nothing, that all the rivers of eloquence with which the errors of the Egyptians were watered, the reed and the calamus, may dry up, and be handed over into the hand of the wicked, who may torture them, and the fullness of the land of Egypt, which had grown in evil, may be destroyed in the hand of foreign gods. For it is not the good, but the evil angels who are put in charge of torments. This is necessary for them to know, because the Lord has spoken. And this is often assumed, so that those who hear may know that these are not the words of prophets, but of the Lord, whose commandments cannot be in vain. It follows: And I will destroy the idols, which are abominations. The Septuagint translates: And I will cause the idols or the nobles of Memphis to cease, and the leader or prince in the land of Egypt will be no more. For it is the very nature of the most merciful Lord to overthrow false things, so that no likeness which falsely imitates the image of truth remains in Egypt: let the nobles of Memphis also perish, which is interpreted 'from the mouth'; of which they have made all the idols, so that without heads and masters of idols, there may be no ruler in Egypt, and all Egypt may be filled with terror and destruction. Concerning its cities it is said: 'And I will destroy the land of Pathros, and I will give fire in Taphnes, or in Tanis, and I will execute judgments in No, which the Seventy translated as Diospolis; and I will pour out my indignation upon Pelusium, the strength of Egypt.' Phatures is interpreted as the trampling of bread; Taphnis, the humble commandment; Diospolis, for which it is written in Hebrew, rest. Sain, temptation: by which names the various assemblies of heretics and all the gatherings of lies are shown. They trample on the ecclesiastical bread and despise it, and they follow the humble commandment, which does not lead to heavenly things, and they indulge in pleasures, and they are at rest; such as we read in the Gospel of the rich purple-clad man (Luke 10); and they serve the tempters, of whom one sought from the Lord the power to tempt Job. The Lord will destroy and burn all these things, and pour out His wrath upon them, and He will scatter the strength of Egypt, so that, reduced to nothingness, they may in no way trouble the people of God, and make them rely on their own help; so that, forsaking the truth, they may seek falsehood, and with their own weak support, be wounded like a reed staff. After this, it is said: And I will destroy or scatter the multitude of Mempheos, which in Hebrew is called No, as translated above by the same Seventy interpreters as Diospolis, which means rest. For there are many who seek rest, and they want to lie on ivory beds and eat suckling lambs. Or according to the Seventy, who are translated as Mempheos, there are many who speak with futile words: Remove that speck from your eye, when they themselves have a beam in theirs. And there is a fire given in Egypt, which consumes vain talk and pleasures with its burning. The whole temptation will grieve, and in Diospolis, which is not mentioned again in Hebrew, there will be a division; so that the waters may be poured out and every evil assembly may be scattered, and may perish here and there. In Memphis, there will be daily distresses according to the Hebrew, in order to render an account for every idle word, so that they understand that nothing of their Lord's judgment will pass by. The young men of Heliopolis and Bubastus will also fall by the sword. Heliopolis is called On in Hebrew, which means pain. But Bubastus, according to the Egyptian language, is a test of speech. All those who could not bear the pain of the world, but pursued the pleasures of Diospolis, and trusted in the volubility of words, disputing against other doctrines, had the experiences of victory. The sword of God's word will cut them down, and those who are called not young men, but weak-minded women, will be led captive. Or the cities themselves, boasting of their pain and mouths, will be led into captivity. And in Taphnis, he says, the day will turn black. Taphnis is interpreted as yielding to the mouth, and the devil is understood: those who yield to him will lose the light of truth, and they will change day into night, and they will perceive that the scepters of Egypt and all its power have been shattered in Taphnis, so that its contemptible strength or the pride of its power will fail, and the rays of the sun of justice will be obscured in the cloud, and it will not be women but daughters who will be led into captivity; and may the Lord not bring just one judgment, but many judgments upon Egypt. For just as there are many dwelling places for the blessed with the Father, so too there are diverse judgments of punishments for the Egyptians, so that when all these things have happened, the Egyptians may know that He Himself is the Lord, whose judgments are true and justified in themselves.

<h2 id='tocuniq286'>(Vers. 20 seq.)</h2>

(Verse 20 and following) And it came to pass in the eleventh year, in the first month (the Vulgate adds 'month'), on the seventh day of the month, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and behold, it is not bound up, to be healed, and to be wrapped with bandages, or to be strengthened with liniments (or to be given a plaster); so that it could hold the sword. Therefore thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against Pharaoh king of Egypt, and I will break his strong arms, and that which is broken (or the strong arms that are in place), and I will cause the sword to fall from his hand, and I will scatter (or disperse) Egypt among the nations, and I will disperse them (or scatter them) through the lands (the Vulgate adds 'lands'). And I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon, and I will put my sword in his hand, and I will break the arms of Pharaoh, and they will groan with the groaning of those who are slain before his face (or as it is in the Septuagint: And he will bring the sword upon Egypt, and he will plunder its spoil, and he will take its plunder. It follows): And I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon, and the arms of Pharaoh will fall: and they will know that I am the Lord, when I give my sword into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he stretches it out upon the land of Egypt, and I will scatter (Vulgate: destroy) Egypt among the nations, and disperse them into the lands, and they will know that I am the Lord. He returns to the order of the prophecies; for after the twenty-seventh year, he now sets down the eleventh. This question is also contained in the preceding [psalms]. For when the word of the Lord was spoken against Tyre in the eleventh year, which came before, in the following [psalms] he speaks to Pharaoh in the tenth year; and again he sets down the twenty-seventh year, as we have said, and now the eleventh. Let me pass over the other things that are contained in the order of the psalms. It is asked, how the third psalm is placed before these psalms, in which David changed his appearance before Abimelech and about Doeg the Edomite, and when he was found in the cave, and the fiftieth of repentance, in the title of which it is shown that he entered in to Bathsheba, the wife of Uriah, while the previous [psalms] are earlier than the third, in which it is noted that he fled from the face of his son Absalom. But in the Psalms the answer is easy, for it is a lyric poem, and in such a work the order of history is not sought; but rather the songs of individual events. However, in history it must be said that those things which are said about one thing at different times should not be divided by speech, but concluded by a narrative of one place. For example, so that those things said about Egypt at one time and another may be understood in the order of reading. When we have said these things, nevertheless the question remains: Why in this same place was the speech of the Lord to Pharaoh first made in the eleventh year, and afterward in the twenty-seventh year, and then in the tenth year, when surely according to the order, the eleventh year should have been marked first, the twenty-seventh year second, and the tenth year third, in each prophecy. To this we can respond: Oh, the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments and how inscrutable his ways! (Rom. 11:33). And in another place: Who can plumb the depths of wisdom? (Sirach 1:2, 3). But we can say this, that even in the Prophets, the order of history is not always observed, at least not in all cases. For they do not narrate the past, but rather they foretell the future according to the will of the Holy Spirit. But in history, as there are the five books of Moses, and Joshua, and the volumes of the Judges, as well as Ruth and Esther, Samuel and the Books of Kings, the Book of Chronicles and Ezra, along with Nehemiah, there is no disordered narration to be found. This is sufficient to say about the order of years. Now let us see what is the prophecy against Pharaoh or about Pharaoh. It is said that his arm is broken, and it is not wrapped or bound, nor is it healed with ointment, according to what is written: 'It is not fitting to apply ointment, nor oil, nor bandages' (Isa. 1, LXX). But if it had happened that, with strength regained, he could hold the sword and advance to war. Therefore, God, who is kind and merciful, once again shattered his arm or arms so that the sword would completely fall from his hand and be scattered among the peoples of Egypt and blown away by the wind. But in your arm, take strength and courage, as the Scripture says: Break the arm of the sinner and the evil one (Psalm 9:15). What is broken in our adversaries, when they pursue us, they are unable to overcome. And for the salvation of the servants of God against Pharaoh, the King of Babylon often rises up to oppress the powerful with a more powerful one, and the wicked are handed over to the more wicked, with God strengthening the arms of the worst, so that he who is freed may know that he himself is the Lord. And it is profitable for virtue to know that he himself is the Lord. On the other hand, we can say: The sons of Eli, the sons of pestilence, not knowing God (1 Samuel 2:22). And concerning the kings who have done right in the sight of God, it is written that they may know the Lord. However, that which is said in the Septuagint, 'And I will break his strong and ordered arms,' which in Greek is said 'τεταγμένα,' has been corrupted by the error of the scribes. For they interpreted it not as 'τεταγμένα,' but as 'τεταμένα,' which means not ordered, but extended. For this reason, according to their custom, other interpreters have rendered it as 'exalted.'

<h2 id='tocuniq287'>Book Ten</h2>

Book Ten

I wish, as I have already said, to explain the prophecies against a single province or a single king in the same books and not at all to divide the meaning of the reader. But what shall I do with the length, which, unless it is divided into parts, exceeds the measure of a volume; and an infinite mass, as troublesome to the speaker as to the listener? Therefore, after the discourse against Egypt and its lamentation, and against the king of Egypt, whose arm is neither wrapped nor restored to its former health, we have said in the last part of the ninth book, we move to the beginning of the tenth book against the same Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who is compared to the king of Assyria, and after a very long prophecy, a lamentation is made about the same, and then against all of Egypt. In discussing these matters, O virgin of Christ, Eustochium, raise your hands with Moses so that the fruit of our victory may be the result of your prayers. For it is not of the one who wills or of the one who runs, but of the merciful God who speaks to the prophet: 'Open your mouth and I will fill it' (Psalm 80:11); the prophet responds to the Lord: 'I opened my mouth and drew in the breath' (Psalm 118:131); he breathes where he wills. But where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom (John 3:8; 2 Corinthians 3:17), the freedom with which the Lord has gifted us. How vainly the Jews boasted, saying: We are the seed of Abraham, and have never been in bondage to any man (John 8:33), subject to many vices and sins, and ignorant of that saying: by whom a man is overcome, of the same he is also the bond-slave (2 Peter 2:19).

<h2 id='tocuniq288'>(Cap. XXXI.)</h2>

(Chapter XXXI.) And it came to pass in the eleventh year, in the third month, on the first day of the month, that the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt and to his people: To whom have you compared yourself in your greatness? Behold, Assyria, like a cedar in Lebanon, beautiful in its branches, thick with foliage, and towering in height; its top was among the clouds. The waters nourished him: the deep exalted him: his rivers flowed round about his roots, and he sent forth his rivulets to all the trees of the country. Therefore was his height lifted up above all the trees of the country, and his branches were multiplied, and his boughs were elevated because of many waters. And when he had spread forth his shadow, all the fowls of the air made their nests in his branches, and all the beasts of the field brought forth their young under his shadow, and a great people abode under his branches. And it was most beautiful in its size and in the spreading (or multitude) of its shrubs (or branches): for its roots were near the waters. Cedars (or Cypresses) were not taller than it in the garden of God, and firs (or pines) did not reach its height, and plane trees (or firs) were not equal (or similar) to its leaves (or branches). Every tree of the garden of God (or in the garden of God) was not compared to it in beauty and splendor, because I made it beautiful (or him), with many dense branches, and all the trees of pleasure (or delights) that were in the garden (or adding God) were jealous of it. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because it has exalted itself to the height and has set its top among the thick clouds, and its heart is proud of its height, I will deliver it into the hand of a mighty one of the nations. He shall surely deal with it as its wickedness deserves. I have cast it out for its wickedness. And strangers, the most ruthless of nations, shall cut it down and leave it. They shall cast it down to the mountains, and its branches shall fall in all the valleys, and its boughs shall be broken in all the ravines of the land, and all the peoples of the earth shall be withdrawn from its shadow and leave it behind. In its ruins dwelt (or rested) all the birds of the sky, and on its branches were all the beasts of the region. Therefore, all the wood of the waters will not be raised in its height, nor will they set their loftiness among the wooded and leafy (or in the clouds): nor will they stand in their height (or in their exaltation) all those that are watered by the waters, for all have been delivered to death to the lowest earth, in the midst of the children of men, to those who descend into the pit. Thus says the Lord God: on the day when he descended to the underworld, I declared mourning (or the depths mourned) for him; I covered him with the depths and restrained its rivers, and I held back its many waters. Lebanon was shattered (or darkened) over him, and all the trees of the field fainted (or failed). From the sound of its downfall, nations were moved (or were shaken), when I brought him (or her) down to the underworld with those who descend (or descend) into the pit; and all the choice and splendid trees of Lebanon were comforted on the infirm ground, and they were watered by the waters. For even they themselves, along with her (or with him), will descend (or have descended) into the underworld to the dead (or to the wounded) by the sword, and the arm (or the seed) of each inhabitant under her shade, perished in the midst of the nations (or of their own lives). To whom have you likened yourself, O illustrious one, and sublime among the trees of pleasure! Behold, you have been brought down with the trees of pleasure to the uttermost earth, you will sleep among the uncircumcised, with those who have been killed by the sword. So Pharaoh and all his multitude, says the Lord God. I have mixed both editions according to custom, where they nevertheless disagreed greatly, so that the double account would not increase the magnitude of the books. And first it should be known that whatever is said about the future king of the Assyrians is mentioned in the Septuagint as if it had already happened, and thus it speaks both to the tree and to the leader of the Assyrians, so that it is understood, in both masculine and feminine gender, about one person, while the tree is referred to the Assyrian, and the Assyrian is named in the tree.
