And there is no mention in the present discourse of the Babylonian king, lest it seem to provoke the anger of the Chaldeans, who have placed the captive people in Chaldea, against their lords and rulers. Instead, it is said of the king of the Assyrians, who at that time had already been captured by the Chaldeans, and all the might of the Assyrians was subject to the Babylonian empire. Hence, the ten tribes, that is, Israel, are taken captive by the Assyrians; but the Chaldeans overpower the two tribes, that is, Judah and Benjamin, and overthrow the city of Jerusalem. Therefore, speaking against Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and his people, God used the following divine speech against him: 'To whom have you been compared in your greatness? Look, Assyria is like a cedar of Lebanon, and so on.' And the meaning is: Do not be surprised if you are to be defeated and perish by the Babylonians, and if your empire is to be destroyed and all the wealth of Egypt is to be destroyed, since Assyria, much stronger than you, was destroyed by the same Chaldeans. And it describes the power of the king of Assyria under the figure of a cedar tree, according to the Hebrew text, according to the LXX, Cypress, situated on Mount Lebanon, which is beautiful with branches and thick with foliage, and reaching up to the clouds, which grew so much not by water, but by the depths, that is, by very abundant waters. For the depths are a multitude of the sound of waters, so that all the birds have made nests in its branches, and all the beasts of the field have bred under its foliage. And so that we would not doubt what were the flying creatures of the sky, or the beasts of the woods, he clearly stated: And under his shade dwelt a multitude of diverse nations. Cedars, he said, and cypresses, firs, either pines or plane trees, or cypresses, did not equal the branches of that tree. And so that he would not separately speak of all the trees, he said that all the trees of the paradise of God are not similar to it, nor to its beauty. Through which some understand that it is not said about the Assyrian king, but about the opposite strength, which is said to have been born in the speech of Tyre among the Cherubim, and distinguished by precious stones, and thereafter to have fallen to the earth due to its own fault, who is also called Lucifer in Isaiah (XIV), and is indicated in the Gospel by the Lord: I saw Satan falling like lightning from heaven (Luke X, 12). But let us understand all these things as an interim history of hyperbolic sayings, that the Assyrian was of such great power, and thus he oppressed all nations, comparing himself to the strength of the Angels. However, everything metaphorically is said to be under the highest cedar, or cypress, referring to the Assyrian, and his killing is called the cutting down. And what follows: I have delivered her into the hand of the strongest nations, it calls the king of Babylon, so that what conquered the Assyrian, it understands not as its own strength, but as divine power. According to him, I expelled her because of her impiety, in order to secretly warn Babylon that it should not be cruel or oppress the people of God who had been handed over to it, lest it suffer the same fate as Assyria, which was cruel and impious. And strangers will cut her down, the most cruel among the nations, or, according to the Septuagint, the most pestilent: something that he would never say ((Alt. wanted to say) being in Chaldea so as not to stir up his own people against him. She is also cast onto the mountains, and her branches fall down the steep valleys without delay, and they are broken against the rocks, and she is abandoned by all the peoples, that is, by the birds of the air and the beasts of the field, and she will come to such destruction that all the trees that were thought to be tall compared to the tree of Assyria, by their example, will be raised up and reach even higher, and no longer remain in their height, but once cut down, all will be cut down in fear together. And what was said through the translation becomes clearer. All, he says, were handed over (understood: kings to death) to the farthest land (that is, to the underworld), in the midst of human children (not among trees) to those who descend into the pit. There is no doubt that this signifies the infernal regions. After the cutting down of the Assyrian tree, or on the day when the Assyrian descends to the underworld, and the Lord inflicted mourning (or, commanded mourning), again through the translation he speaks of him being covered by the abyss, according to what is written: “I came to the depth of the sea, and the storm has submerged me” (Ps. 68:3); and all the rivers, that is, all the nations, have ceased to water him beyond, and he, that is, the Assyrian, be made sad or darkened upon it, that is, the tree, or him, that is, the Assyrian, like Lebanon. Lest we think that there is discourse about a tree, it follows: I moved nations with the sound of its collapse. For what great collapse of one tree can there be, such that all nations are moved by its sound? When I led it down to the underworld, according to the word, a tree cannot be led down to the underworld with the others who descended into the lake, that is, into the underworld. And the lowest parts of the earth were consoled, namely in the heart of the earth, with all the trees of pleasure, or delights, which is called Eden in Hebrew, so that it signifies delightful and excellent groves and forests, which were in Lebanon and were watered by waters. For even the trees themselves, along with it, that is, the Assyrian, descend into the underworld, to the killed or wounded with a sword. The trees are not wounded by swords, but cut down, nor do they descend into the underworld. And the arm, he says, or the offspring (since in Hebrew the word "Zara" (seed) means both), will rest in its shadow in the midst of nations, not of forests, but of peoples. Finally, there is an apostrophe to the Assyrian himself, or to Pharaoh. To whom are you likened, o illustrious one, and sublime among the trees of pleasure? None were equal to you, they say, but you surpassed all kings in power, and yet, among the other kings who were in your retinue to the farthest lands, that is, to the underworld, you were led, as the Scripture says: They will enter the furthest reaches of the earth; they will be delivered into the hands of the sword; they will be the prey of foxes (Ps. 62:10-11). In the midst, it is said, you will sleep with the uncircumcised, with those who were slain by the sword. It showed what were the trees, whether cedar or cypress, wounded by swords, and lying with the uncircumcised. And he would join the extreme parts to the front, because he had said above: To whom have you been made like in your greatness: Behold the Assyrian, as a cedar of Lebanon, fair in branches and in leaves, and the rest, now brings down: So is Pharaoh, and all his multitude, says the Lord. How, he says, the Assyrian, cedar and cypress, having fallen by the Babylonian, is brought down: so Pharaoh and his people, that is, the very tree and the branches thereof shall be cut down by the Babylonian. These things, therefore, are said according to history, which most people understand to happen in the consummation of the world and to compare the king of Egypt, that is, the power to which Egypt is subject, with the most powerful king of the Assyrians, that is, the Antichrist: if he falls, surely other rulers of these darknesses and princes of the world will fall more easily. So let us speak briefly about each one, touching on everything, so that we do not so much discuss and explain the obscure as we seem to have given material to those desiring to explain. And first, let us discuss why in the eleventh year, on the third month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to Ezekiel, saying: Son of man, speak to Pharaoh of Egypt and his multitude. When speaking to Pharaoh, it was in the eleventh year that the word of the Lord was spoken, for it had not yet come to the twelfth year, which is the number of complete and perfected power. Therefore, there are also twelve sons of Jacob (Genesis 35), from whom later the twelve names of the prophets are contained in one volume. And there are twelve apostles (Luke 6), of whom one, Judas the betrayer, is replaced by Matthias. And the synagogue ruler's twelve-year-old daughter is raised to life by the Lord (Mark 5). The woman with the hemorrhage also receives healing in the twelfth year. But because Pharaoh is punished and bewailed afterwards, therefore the third month and the eleventh day of the eleventh year are linked in number. Hence, in the following twelfth year, in the twelfth month, on the first day of the month, the word of the Lord comes to Ezekiel, saying: Son of man, lament over Pharaoh king of Egypt and say to him. For the one who mourns, mourns in order to understand how great the goods they have lost; and yet because Pharaoh was there, and his arm had not yet been bound, nor had he regained his former strength: therefore, in the twelfth year and month, twenty-nine days still remain, in order to complete the number of twelve years. Therefore, on one day of the month, the word of the Lord came to the Prophet, and he was commanded to speak to the king of Egypt and his multitude. It is remarkable that the four interpreters did not say 'people', but 'multitude'. For many are called, but few are chosen (Matthew XXII, 14). And in the law it is written: 'You shall not be with the multitude in doing evil.' And it is said to the king of Egypt: 'To whom have you likened yourself in greatness or in height?' For he himself has exalted himself and is subject to that sentence: 'Everyone who exalts himself will be humbled' (Luke XIV, 11); but let him not be like his height, who was like a cedar or a cypress in Lebanon, beautiful with branches and leafy with foliage; and he has raised his head in height even to the clouds, to which, according to David (Psalm XXXV), the truth of God reaches, and upon which he commands that they do not rain rain upon Israel. Beauty is also praised, which, when corrupt will, has been turned into ugliness (Ps. 77); so that it is said of it: The Lord will break the cedars of Lebanon (Ps. 28, 5): and he himself, being exalted on the highest mountain of Lebanon, the higher he was, the stronger he would fall. The Holy Scripture, wishing to show its height, calls it a great cedar, which the waters nourished, not the waters of Siloe that go silently (Is. 8), but the waters of Rasin and the waters of Egypt, of which it is written: What is there to you to drink the waters of Geon (Jeremiah 2, 18), or Sion? He who makes the turbulent waters sound. The abyss also lifted him up above which in the beginning of the world darkness was carried (Gen. I), and to which in the Gospel the demons beg not to be sent (Luke VIII). The rivers of the same abyss were around its roots, about which it is said: What is it to you and the ways of the Assyrians, that you drink the waters of the rivers (Jer. II, 18)? And in another place: Behold, the Lord will bring upon you a strong and plentiful river water, the king of the Assyrians and all his glory (Isa. VIII, 7). The abyss also sent forth its rivers to all the trees of the region, so that it might water not only the prince of this world, but also his companions. Therefore, it was exalted and grew above all the tallest trees, and its shrubs multiplied, and it possessed the empire of the whole world, saying: All these things have been handed over to me (Matthew 4:9). And its branches were lifted up, for all those who were watered by the abyss. It extended, or spread, its shade in order to subject everyone to its rule. On his branches all the birds of the air have made their nests. For everyone who commits sin is born of the devil, and is counted among his branches. And those birds have made their nests in his branches, which, according to the Gospel, devour the seed by the wayside. It may be because all have sinned and are in need of God's mercy, as it is written: They have all fallen away, and have become useless together. Therefore, they have made their nests on his branches. It follows: And under its branches all the beasts of the forest that have lost the meekness of Christ were born, and under its shade dwelt a multitude of nations, so that there was none who was not sheltered by its shade, except him who said: Behold, the prince of this world is coming: and he will find nothing in me (John XIV, 30). For by one man sin entered into the world, and by sin death (Rom. V, 12); and thus death has passed upon all men, in whom all have sinned, and in Adam all die, and we all have sinned, and we need the glory of God (I Cor. XV). And yet, within the same dwelling, there are different conditions. Some dwell in its branches like birds, boasting knowledge in philosophy and the dogmas of heretics. Others are like wild and cruel beasts, while others are like a multitude of diverse nations, signifying a mixture of various vices and sins. However, Assyria was most beautiful in its size and the spread of its foliage, as its roots were watered by many waters, to such an extent that in the paradise of God, there was no cedar or cypress taller, nor did the firs or pines match its height; nor were plane trees equal in their foliage to it. Therefore, no tree of plants in Paradise was suitable for him, because every tree of God's Paradise is not comparable to him and his beauty. For they were not elevated by pride, but they knew their own humility, nor did they attempt to claim the likeness of God with a sacrilegious spirit. And what follows: And all the trees of delight in Paradise were jealous of her, let us explain: The trees of Paradise were jealous of the abundance of its branches: For many are called, but few are chosen (Matthew 20:16). And; The broad and spacious road that leads to death (Ibid. VII, 13). For he desires to have as many for salvation as Assyria had for destruction. Therefore, because Assyria was exalted in height, and extended its lofty and thick foliage, even to the top of the clouds, and his heart was lifted up, saying: I will be like the Most High (Isa. XIV, 14), therefore he was delivered into the hand of the strongest of nations: which we understand to be another detestable power, to whom he is delivered for punishment: for he himself is an enemy and avenger; so that Assyria may be understood as the Antichrist, and the strongest of nations to whom he is delivered, Satan, according to the saying of the Apostle: Whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme (I Tim. II, 20): Who will do to him whatever has been commanded by the Lord. But this cypress was expelled from the paradise of God because of its impiety; and strangers and cruel ones, or pests among the nations, will cut it down, so that what is written may be fulfilled: The fool, when punished, will become wiser (Prov. XIX, 25). And again: The axe is already laid to the root of the trees (Matth. III, 10); those who will cut it down on the mountains, so that it may fall in its pride. Indeed, all its branches will fall in every valley, so that all those who were in its company may be led to Tartarus and depart from its shade, and leave it behind: so that the birds of the air and the beasts of the land, which were previously under it and were covered by its shade, may afterwards share in its punishments. And when they see that the other trees of the forest, or of paradise, have fallen by the judgment of God, the cypress of Assyria will not be lifted up in pride, nor will they consider themselves to be anything, nor will they think their own irrigation of water to be riches: because all the branches and the birds of the sky, and the beasts of the earth, that were under the dominion of Assyria, will be brought down to the final earth in death. Of them it is written: In his sight, all who descend to the earth will fall. And in another place: They will come to the ends of the earth (Ps. 62:10): and they will not be with the angels, but with the sons of men, who descend into the lake or into the eternal pit. But when he descends to the ends of the earth, and a part of foxes will be among those from whom he is to be torn apart: then there will be mourning either of all his companions, or of the holy strengths, which will grieve that he has descended into the underworld. Hence the Lord says: I have covered him with the abyss, whose waters he had been nurtured by before; and I have forbidden his rivers, that is the abyss, and I have restrained many waters, so that they may not water him, but instead overwhelm him. Lebanon was made sad because of him, where the proud ones lived. All the trees of the forest were shaken, and they were afraid of being cut down. The crashing of its downfall made the nations tremble, so that no one could ignore its destruction and its descent into the underworld with its companions. All the trees of Eden were comforted, the choicest and the best in Lebanon. They too were consoled when they saw that the wicked were being punished and the righteous were being restored. But these trees of Lebanon were watered by the streams of the Lord, and they were the same trees that had fallen. Whether all the trees, which once were good and were watered by the waters, and dwelt in the height of Lebanon, will receive consolation, when they see their prince suffering similar torments. For they themselves will descend into hell, to the slain by the sword of the Lord, and all the might of the trees will dwell under his shadow, that is, in punishment, in the midst of all the nations which shall be shut up in the prison of hell. After this, the discourse turns to Pharaoh himself, to whom it had been said in the beginning, with whom have you become like in your greatness? And it is said to him: To whom have you been likened, o illustrious one, and sublime among the trees of pleasure? Surely to the Assyrian who fell. And you were illustrious and sublime among the trees of Eden, that is, of delights and paradise, and behold, you have been cast down like the Assyrian, with all the trees that were once in delights, to the ultimate land and to the underworld, and you shall not sleep in rest, but in punishments amidst the uncircumcised, that is, the unclean, and with those who have fallen by the sword of the Lord. And so that we may know who he is whom he said: O illustrious and sublime among the trees of pleasure, he puts it more clearly: He is Pharaoh, and all his multitude. Or according to the Septuagint, it is thus Pharaoh, and all his multitude, just as just as the Assyrian above was chopped down and fell, so may the Egyptian also be overthrown.

<h2 id='tocuniq289'>(Cap. XXXII.—Vers. 1 seq.)</h2>

(Chapter XXXII, Verses 1 onwards) And it came to pass in the twelfth year, in the twelfth month (or tenth), on the first day of the month (the Vulgate is silent on the day of the month), the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, take up a lamentation for Pharaoh king of Egypt, and say to him: You are like a lion among the nations, and like a dragon in the seas, and you stirred up your rivers and troubled the waters with your feet, and trampled their (or your) streams. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: I will spread my net over you with a multitude of many peoples, and I will draw you up in my snare (or I will draw you up with a hook). And I will cast you on the ground: on the surface of the field I will throw you (or your fields will be filled). And I will make all the birds of the sky dwell (or sit) upon you, and I will satisfy all the beasts of the whole earth with you, and I will give your flesh on the mountains, and I will fill the hills (Vulgate adds yours) (or valleys) with your filth (or your blood) and I will water the land (or the land will be watered) with the stench (or odor) of your blood (or your dung) on the mountains, and the valleys (378) will be filled from you. And when you are extinguished, I will cover the sky and make its stars darken: I will cover the sun with a cloud, and the moon will not give its light. I will make all the lights of the heavens mourn (or grow dim) over you: and I will bring darkness over your land, says the Lord God. And I will provoke the heart of many peoples when I bring your destruction (or captivity) among the nations in lands (or in the land) that you do not know. And the people (or many nations) will be astounded over you, and their kings will be greatly terrified when my sword begins to fly against their faces and they suddenly become dumbfounded, each one for their own life, on the day of your ruin (or waiting for their own ruin from the day of your ruin). Because thus says the Lord God: The sword of the king of Babylon will come against you. With the swords of the mighty ones (or giants), I will cast down your multitude (or strength): all these nations are invincible (or pestilential from all nations): and they will devastate (or destroy) the pride (or injustice) of Egypt, and its multitude (or all its strength) will be dispersed (or crushed). And I will destroy all its animals that were on many waters (or on many waters): and the foot of man will no longer disturb them, nor will the hoof of animals trample them. Then I will make their waters pure (or so that their waters may rest), and I will bring their rivers like oil (or so that oil may flow), says the Lord God, when I have made the land of Egypt desolate (or destroyed). But the land will be deserted from its abundance (or with abundance) when I strike (or scatter) all its inhabitants; and they will know that I am the Lord. The daughters of the nations will lament him, and the multitude of Egypt (or all its might) will lament him, says the Lord God. We mix both editions, only in those places where they differ. Otherwise, when there is one meaning, we follow the Hebrew. However, in many copies, according to the Septuagint, the twelfth year and tenth month is placed; according to other interpreters, the tenth year and twelfth month, so that either Jerusalem has already been captured, and Pharaoh's joy is taken away from him in the face of impending evils, or it is certainly to be captured, and it should grieve more for its own miseries than rejoice in the captivity of others. And meanwhile, laying the foundations of a certain history briefly, let us explore what the Hebrews understand in this place. Pharaoh is compared to a lion, not of one nation, but of many nations; or to a dragon in the sea, who possessed the land and waters by the irrigation of rivers, and was raised up in pride, which is called a horn, and with the multitude of his army, he could disturb all the waters: therefore, he says that his net is spread out over his multitude, and he would draw him out with his dragnet or hook, and cast him, or stretch him out upon the land, he who had been wrapped up like a serpent with many coils, so that he may be devoured by all the birds of the sky. And when not only the birds, but all the beasts of the earth have torn him apart, the remaining flesh of him will fill the mountains, valleys, and fields, so that everything will teem with worms. However, this is spoken metaphorically, so that after the birds of the sky and the beasts have been satiated with his flesh, that is, his army, and the rest of the multitude will be transformed into worms and putrefaction. Then it says, the heavens will be enveloped in darkness: the sun, and the moon, and other lights will not give their light, but everything will blacken upon you: and nothing joyful will be left for you, and for your destruction all the peoples and all their kings will be greatly frightened, seeing my sword flying to and fro and sparing no one, and they will fear a similar destruction in your ruin. But so that you may know what this sword is, listen more clearly: The sword of the king of Babylon will come to you. In the swords of the brave, or giants, I will throw down all your multitude. These giants are invincible nations, which were held by the army of the Babylonian king. They will devastate or scatter the pride of Egypt, and all its multitude. And nothing will remain in Egypt, but both men and beasts of burden and wild animals will be taken away together. And there will be such solitude in Egypt that neither the foot of a man nor the hoof of a beast will disturb its waters, but everything will be calm. And its river waters will flow like pure and shining oil, with no one passing through them or disturbing their flow. This will happen because of the solitude of Egypt, which will be transformed into a desert by the Lord, striking its inhabitants so that those who remain may understand that He is the Lord. Therefore, the mourning of Pharaoh is justified, and the daughters of nations mourn around him. But not only for him, but also for his multitude, which was destroyed by the devastating Lord. Let it suffice to say briefly about this simple letter, let us move on to the spiritual understanding. Nor do I think it is of great importance to know who the Pharaoh of Egypt is, since we have already explained more fully, namely that power to which Egypt is entrusted; either one province, or Egypt of the whole world, which is not founded by a lion, but assimilated to the lion of nations by its own vice. For when man was in honor, he did not understand; he was compared to dumb beasts, and became like them (Psalm 48, 13). On this the lion and Peter speak: Our adversary, the devil, as a roaring lion, goes about seeking whom he may devour (1 Peter 5, 8). And in the ninth psalm (Verse 9) it is written: He lies in wait secretly as a lion in his den; he lies in wait to catch the poor. And in Jeremiah the Holy Spirit says: A lion out of the forest has struck them (Jeremiah 5, 6). But the dragon is said to be the devil (for which reason the eagle is interpreted as Leviathan, explaining the name of the dragon), as I have taught with many testimonies according to the earlier explanation, which says: 'The rivers are mine, and I made them.' Therefore, this dragon, like with its horns, struck many nations, which we can understand to be Marcion, Valentinus, Arius, Eunomius, and the other princes of heresies, who imitate the ecclesiastical men, saying to the Lord and Savior: 'We will strike our enemies with the horn in you' (Psalm 44:6); and they do not strike for salvation, to lift them from earth to heaven, but to cast them into the depths. Finally, it follows: And you troubled the waters with your feet; according to the words of the Apostle: But whoever troubles you will bear judgment (Gal. 5:10). For He does not want to drink the waters of Siloam, which flow silently (Isa. 8), but the turbid and muddy waters of Egypt, which before they were trampled underfoot by the dragon, were pure and flowed in their own order; but after they were troubled by his feet, they lost their course. For heretics do not make use of the testimonies of the Scriptures that are consistent with themselves, but they confuse everything. And because he is an enemy and avenger, the Egyptian dragon not only disturbs foreign waters with his feet, but he tramples upon his own rivers, so that he does not spare those whom he has once reduced under his power. 381 The righteous, desiring to avoid this, prays: Let not the foot of pride come against me (Ps. XXXV, 12). And in another place, the trampled one asks not to be trampled again: Have mercy on me, O Lord, for man has trampled upon me (Ps. LV, 1). But the enemy is the devil, of whom the other psalm speaks: Let not man be exalted upon the earth. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: I will spread my net upon you, in the multitude of many peoples (Ps. IX, 18). The net of the Lord, woven with the reason of the Old and New Testament, is cast upon the dragon, who dwells among the multitude of peoples, and always delights in crowds and the multitude of peoples: that he may draw him into his snare, or into his hook. This is the net that is cast into the sea of this world, and it gathers many fish to be chosen and others to be cast away (Matthew 13). Or this is the hook, of which it is written in Job: You shall bring forth the dragon by the hook, etc., you shall surround its nose with a bridle (Job 40:19); which was interpreted by Aquila: You shall draw out Leviathan by the hook, and bind its tongue with cords. Now the dragon, or Leviathan, is drawn out of the sea by the hook or net of the Lord, in order to be cast out or stretched upon the earth, and all its coils, with which it concealed its snares, may be opened and brought forth into the open, and be cast upon the earth, and may lay down the one that had set its mouth in heaven and boasted of being like the Most High. And it follows: And I will make all the birds of the sky to dwell or sit upon you, and I will satisfy all the beasts of the earth with you, according to what is written: You have given him as food for the people of Ethiopia (Ps. 73:14). Those are either called birds or beasts of the earth (Matt. 13; Luke 8). Birds, which snatch the seed, as we have said, along the way. Beasts of the earth, in reference to heretics and pagans who are given over to vices. But what follows - And I will give your flesh on the mountains, and fill your hills with your rottenness; or, I will fill the valleys with your blood - has this meaning: that by the birds of the air and the beasts of the earth, we understand the deceived peoples and the cruelty of the Gentiles, and by the mountains we refer to the leaders of heresies such as Valentinus and Marcion, and by the hills we refer to their successors who are filled with the rottenness of the dragon, or the valleys, which are filled with the blood of the dragon, we refer to the lower class of believers. Certainly, there are opposing powers in the mountains that roam through the air, and valleys that descend into the depths of hell, bound by eternal torments. Moreover, when it is said, 'And I will water the earth with the stench of your blood upon the mountains,' or, 'The earth will be watered with your excrement upon the mountains, and the valleys will be filled with you,' it signifies that all the pride and arrogant swelling of heretical faction is not filled with vital and pure blood, but with putrid and stinking blood, as it is written, 'Make them like refuse on the ground.' (Ps. LXXXII, 11). Concerning whom the Holy One is delivered by the Lord, who raises up the poor from the earth, and lifts up the needy from the heap of refuse. To seat him with princes, with the princes of his people. The valleys in the depths, as we said above, signify either the infernal regions or the humble sense of the heretics on account of their desire for pleasure and worldly wealth, do all these things. But as for what is joined: And I will cover the heavens when you are extinguished, and I will make his stars dark, I will cover the sun with a cloud and the moon will not give its light, I will cause all the luminaries of the sky to mourn or dark to fall upon you, and I will bring darkness upon your land, says the Lord God, if we follow the literal meaning, it cannot be fully understood. For when Pharaoh, or the scorching sun, and the moon, and the stars did not give their light, and the sky was covered in darkness, according to that poetic line (Virgil, Georgics I):

And the impious feared the eternal night. Therefore it must be said that with the extinguishing of Pharaoh, who transformed himself into an angel of light, of whom it is written elsewhere: The light of the wicked will be extinguished (Job XVIII), the heavens or the sky will be covered in darkness. Concerning this, Paul also speaks: And the spiritual wickedness in heavenly places (Ephesians VI, 12). And the Lord will cause his stars, or the dragon, or the sky, to become black. About this, Judas the Apostle also writes: Wandering stars, for whom the blackness of darkness is reserved forever (Jude XIII). The sun is also covered by a cloud, the sun of iniquity, which opposes the sun of justice, but the cloud, or even the Lord Savior himself, who descended upon Egypt on a light cloud (Isa. XIX), not burdened by the weight of sin, or the prophets and apostles, of whom we read: 'I will command the clouds not to rain upon it' (Isa. V, 6). And in the Psalms: 'Your truth reaches to the clouds' (Ps. XXXV, 6). But when the sun of iniquity is obscured, the moon, which we perceive as the Church of heretics, and which was thought to receive the light of iniquity from the sun, will not give its light, nor will the knowledge of a false name deceive believers. And all the lights and whatever is seen to be in the doctrines of heretics will be extinguished with the dragon destroyed, and they will dry up, mourning the lost leader, so that the Lord himself may cover the land of heretics with darkness, the ignorance of truth, so that the blind may lead the blind into the pit, and the inhabitants of the earth may be thrown into outer darkness, where there is weeping and gnashing of teeth. After this it is said: 'And I will provoke the heart of many peoples, when I bring your affliction or captivity among the nations over the land that you do not know, so that those who had previously served Pharaoh may be angry against him, seeing that his captivity has been brought to another land, which the dragon did not know.' And we must not doubt that the lands are good, which Pharaoh does not know, namely when the captivity of Pharaoh is changed into another captivity, of which it is said to the Savior: Ascending on high, he led captivity captive: he received (or, according to the Apostle, gave) gifts to men. And I will cause many peoples to be amazed at you, so that those who previously admired Pharaoh's power will then admire that he has fallen from his own summit. The kings of the peoples will also be frightfully feared over him, whose kingdoms the devil shows to the Lord, and of whom it is said in the psalm: The kings of the earth stood up, and the rulers gathered together in one (Ps. II, 2). But this will happen when the sword of the Lord begins to fly over their faces, the faces of kings or peoples are understood. And the sword of the Lord is to be understood as the living word of God, and effective, and sharp on both sides, which flies and runs and stings the eyes of those who see and deters their faces, so that, astonished by the ruin of Pharaoh, they see themselves thrown down in him. And indeed, the sword of the Lord, of which it is written: Behold, he is set for the fall and for the resurrection of many (Luke 2:34), lifts up those who are lying down, and changes those who are badly erected with humility. But the sword of the king of Babylon shall come upon the Egyptian dragon, so that the Lord may cast down the multitude of him, who followed the king of Egypt, with the swords of the mighty men or giants. Indomitable, therefore, or pestilent from the nations, all these, that they may be handed over to worse evils for punishment, of which it is written: He sent forth upon them the wrath of his indignation, indignation, and trouble by evil angels (Psalm 78:49). And the Apostle says: 'Whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme; or to the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved.' (I Tim. I, 20). But when the pride of Egypt, represented by these ministers, has been cast down, and its multitude scattered, all its beasts, which were upon many waters, shall perish, and the foot of man shall no more disturb them. For if it is blessed to sow upon the waters where the ox and the ass tread (Isa. XXXII), then, on the other hand, unhappy is he who, by his own persistent error, keeps the simple in his error, so that even the foot of man treads not upon them, lest the waters of Egypt seem to have any sign of wisdom and reason in themselves. The hoof of the beasts also shall not trouble them, so as to make them troubled and muddy, out of the most clear and shining make them troubled and muddy. Then the most pure waters, which were troubled by the dominion of the dragon, shall be restored, not by another, but by the Lord Himself: so that their rivers shall run forth as oil, and the light shall be their eternal nourishment. But these things shall come to pass, when the Lord shall have made the land of Egypt desolate, and shall have destroyed the multitude thereof, and shall have smitten all the inhabitants thereof, so that by this proceeding they may know that He Himself is the Lord. But what is joined together: it is a lamentation, and the daughters of the nations shall lament over Egypt and over its multitude, says the Lord God. It is clear that the souls of all the nations, who were previously oppressed, whether of those nations that did not dwell in Egypt at all, but lived in the region of the living, shall lament the slain dragon and all its multitude: not in hope of salvation, but because it has been cast down into eternal punishment due to its great power and pride.


<h2 id='tocuniq290'>(Vers. 17, seq.)</h2>

(V. 17, seq.) 'And it came to pass in the twelfth year, in the fifteenth month, the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy against the multitude of Egypt and drag her down, along with the daughters of mighty nations, to the farthest land, with those who descend to the pit. How beautiful you are, descend and lie with the uncircumcised. In the midst of those slain by the sword they shall fall: the sword is given, they have drawn her and all her people.' The most powerful of the strong will speak to him from the midst of the underworld, who descended with his helpers (or his own) and slept with the uncircumcised, and those slain by the sword. There Asshur and all his multitude, all around his grave, all who were slain, and those who fell by the sword, whose graves were given in the depths of the pit: and his multitude was made all around his tomb, all the slain and fallen by the sword who once caused terror in the land of the living. There Aela and all its multitude around its tomb: all of these were killed and fell by the sword, those uncircumcised who descended to the nether world, who spread terror in the land of the living and bore their disgrace with those who descend to the pit. In the midst of the slain they made her a bed among all her people, around her tomb. All of these were uncircumcised, killed by the sword. For they have caused terror in the land of the living, and have carried their disgrace with those who descend into the grave. They were placed in the midst of the slain. There Mosoch and Thubal, and all their multitude, surrounded their graves. All these were uncircumcised and were killed by the sword, those who caused terror in the land of the living. They will not sleep with the mighty, the fallen, and the uncircumcised, who have descended to the underworld with their weapons and have placed their swords under their heads. Their wickedness is in their bones, for they have become a terror to the land of the living. And so you will be crushed in the midst of the uncircumcised, and you will sleep with those slain by the sword. There Edom and its kings, and all its princes, who gave their might with their armies, along with those slain by the sword, and who slept with the uncircumcised, and with those who descended into the pit. There are all the princes of the north, and all the Sidonians, who have gone down with the slain, in shame, despite their might, because they slept uncircumcised with those slain by the sword, and they bear their shame with those who descend into the pit. Pharaoh saw them, and he took comfort over his whole multitude, which was killed by the sword, Pharaoh and all his army, says the Lord God. For I have given ((or gave)) my terror in the land of the living, and he slept in the midst of the uncircumcised, with those killed by the sword, Pharaoh and all his multitude, says the Lord God.» The Septuagint edition differs greatly in this place both in order and translation, and certain things have been added to it from Theodotion. Where we found it necessary to include the text itself, not at all sparing in length, and serving the diligence of the attentive reader.

LXX. And it came to pass in the twelfth year, in the fifteenth month, that the word of the Lord came unto me, saying: Son of man, weep for the multitude of Egypt, and they shall bring down her daughters as the nations of the dead into the depth of the earth, with those who descend into the pit (Moreover, under the asterisks it is added: + Descend from the beautiful water; + and sleep with the uncircumcised ** Again it follows in order): In the midst of the slain by the sword, they shall fall with him, and all his strength shall sleep, and the giants in the depth of the pit shall say to thee, descend, for thou art better, descend, and sleep with the uncircumcised in the midst of the slain by the sword. There Assur, and all his congregation. (And what follows: ÷ All the wounded were given there, ÷ and his tomb in the depths of the pit, ÷ and his congregation was made ** which is not found in the Hebrew, but was added by the Septuagint. Again it is said): Around his tomb all the wounded who had fallen by the sword. (And again it was added from Theodotion's Edition under asterisks: + They gave his tombs on the sides of the lake; + and his congregation was made around his tomb. + All these wounded, and falling by the sword. After these, the seventy placed): They gave their fear upon the land of the living. There Aelam, and all its strength around its tomb, all wounded, and falling by the sword: and those who descend uncircumcised into the depths of the earth, who have brought their terror upon the land of the living, and have received their torment with those who descend into the pit among the wounded. There were given Mosoch, and Thubal, and all their strength around their tomb, all their 387 wounded, all uncircumcised, and wounded by the sword, who have brought their terror upon the land of the living, and have not slept with the giants who have fallen from ancient times: who have descended into hell with the weapons they used for war, and have placed their swords under their heads, and their iniquities have become their bones, because they have terrified the giants in their life. And you will be crushed in the midst of the uncircumcised, and you will sleep with those who are wounded by the sword. There are Edom and its kings, and all the princes of Assyria, who gave their strength to it in its sword wound. These slept with the wounded, with those who went down to the pit. There are all the princes of the north, all the officials of Assyria, who were wounded and terrified, and who slept in their confusion, uncircumcised with the wounded by the sword, and they took their shame with those who went down to the pit. Pharaoh will see them, and he will receive consolation for all their strength: Pharaoh, wounded by the sword, and all his strength, says the Lord God. For I have placed fear of him over the land of the living, and he will sleep in the midst of the uncircumcised, with those wounded by the sword, Pharaoh and all his multitude, says the Lord God. I am not unaware that such a great discrepancy between two editions will be displeasing to the delicate reader. But what shall I do with my detractors, who, if I remove anything from the translation of the Seventy interpreters, accuse me of sacrilege and shout without fear of the Lord, especially since they disagree in the truth of faith and follow the errors of the Manichaeans, stirring the souls of the unlearned when they are able to show any change in the old customs, desiring to wander more willingly than to learn anything true from their rival. And meanwhile, according to the history, the meaning is clear. In the same twelfth year, and in the same, as we suppose, month, but not on the same, as above, day, but on the fifteenth day, not against Pharaoh, but against the strength or multitude of Egypt, a lamentation is taken up, which is removed from its pride together with all its daughters, or the strong nations, to the farthest land, that is, to the depths of hell, and it is said to the king of Egypt: How much better are you, that you deserve to escape death? For when Assur, and Elam, that is, the Persians, and Mosoch, which are interpreted Cappadocians, and Thubal, which others will have to be Iberians, others Italians: 388 Also Idumeans, and the princes of the north, with the Sidonians, with all their armies, who by their assistance terrified all nations, are dead, and slain by the sword, and have laid down their swords under their heads, which is to be understood more emphatically, will you alone be able not to bear the same things? Moreover, when you see such a great multitude of sleeping souls with you in the underworld, and your tomb surrounded by the memories of once mighty princes, you will find comfort, considering the lesser torments in the company of many. For now, let it suffice to have spoken these things succinctly according to the simple meaning. Now, let us briefly expound on the same matter as much as the difficulty of explanation allows, embracing spiritual understanding and the highest knowledge. On the first day of the month, the word of the Lord came to the Prophet, this being the fifteenth. But in the first place, that is, on the Kalends, the beginning of the month is. On the fifteenth, when the whole orb of the moon is filled, and if it is the first month, it is the first day of unleavened bread; but if it is the seventh, it is the day of tent pitching (which are the most solemnities among the Hebrews). But lamentation is made over the strength of Egypt, so that it ceases to be strong in evil: and it receives weakness, and when it is weaker, then it is stronger. For the fortitude of Egypt, in Hebrew it has a multitude. For the gate is wide and the way is broad that leads to destruction, and many enter through it (Matthew 7:13). In contrast, it is said to Israel: But you are few among all the nations (Deuteronomy 28). For virtue is always rare, and the way that leads to life is narrow and difficult, and few are those who enter through it. And as for the mourning of Egypt and her dead daughters, according to the Septuagint, whether it is the daughters of strong nations that are led to the ultimate land, in the lake or in the deepest pit, it signifies the souls dwelling in Egypt of this world, who have lost the one who says: I am the life (John 14:6), and being dead in their sins, they are dragged down to the depths by the weight of their offenses, as the sinner says: For my iniquities have risen above my head, like a heavy burden they press me down (Psalm 38:5). These are the ones about whom it is written elsewhere: They will go down into the depths of the earth, they will be delivered into the hands of the sword, they will become the prey of foxes (Ps. 62:10). For whoever digs a pit, will fall into it (Sirach 27:29; Ps. 7:16). Hence we also read: He opened a pit and dug it, and he fell into the hole he had made. And what follows: How beautiful you are, come down and sleep with the uncircumcised, is specifically directed to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, or as the addition in the Septuagint of Theodotion states, to Egypt itself: Come down from the most beautiful water and sleep with the uncircumcised. Regarding specifically to the one who is reborn in the baptism of Christ and hears with the Church: 'Who is this that ascends, adorned in white, leaning upon her beloved?' (Song of Songs 8:5) Afterward, whether through fornication or other vices, he is cast out of the Church and it is said to him: 'Come down from the most beautiful water and sleep with the uncircumcised,' that is, with the impure, according to the sense which the Apostle gives: 'We are the circumcision' (Philippians 3:3), who serve in the Spirit of God and glory in Christ Jesus, not relying on the flesh. Hi all in the midst of the wounded or slain will fall with Pharaoh, by that sword which the Lord is coming to send upon the earth. For just as the sword of Christ separates the good from the evil, saying: I have not come to send peace upon the earth, but a sword (Matthew X, 34): so the sword of heretics cuts off all people and leads the wounded into hell. These are the most powerful and rebellious giants, and they lift up their mouths in arrogance, and the higher they raise themselves in pride, the lower they are dragged down into the depths of the pit and the ultimate hell, all of whom are killed by the sword. And so that Pharaoh or all the power of Egypt would know, which has been drawn down to the underworld, who it had as partners in punishment, the following discourse demonstrates: There is Assur, and all his multitude, or his assembly. For indeed, the leader of the heretics is the devil, whose true assembly is the synagogue, of which it is said in the Apocalypse: They are the synagogues of Satan (Apoc. II, 9). But I think the following verses, which are marked with an obelus, should be skipped, and it should be said that what is contained in Hebrew is: Around that place, their tombs, namely the tombs of those deceived by him. Those who were wounded or killed by the sword and therefore fell, their tombs were given in the very depths of the lake. But that the lake is called infernus is clearly shown in that psalm, in which the repentant one speaks: 'I am reckoned among those who go down to the pit' (Psalm 27:1). By no means should we understand it according to the proper meaning of the Latin word which is called λίμνη in Greek, as in the lake of Tiberias, and Lake Como, and Lake Van, and many others, but which we do not usually call cisterns. The Scriptures testify that sinners and all heretics dig up the lakes, which cool the waters and take away all heat from them, and as far as my memory serves me, no holy lake, that is, cistern, has been dug. But all sinners, among whom was King Uzziah, afflicted with leprosy and who fell because of his pride, of whom it is written that he was a man lying in the works of the earth, and built many towers of pride in the corners, and dug up lakes (2 Chronicles 26). On the contrary to the just person it says: 'Drink water from your vessels, and from the fountains of your wells.' (Prov. V, 15) And again: 'Let your fountain be your own.' Therefore the Lord speaks: 'They have forsaken me, the fountain of living water, and have dug for themselves broken cisterns, that hold no water.' (Jer. III, 13) It follows: 'And its multitude became round about its grave.' All these surround Assyria, and their multitude is very great, all of them wounded and slain, and falling by the sword. For none of them can stand with Moses, nor hear: Ye that stand in the house of the Lord. (Psalm CXXXIV, 2); but all are wounded and slain, and they fall who once inspired fear in the land of the living, but now inspire fear in those who are governors of the Churches, lest they make the people of the living to be like the dead, and deceive even the simple. Hence Paul also said: But I fear, lest as the serpent deceived Eve by his cunning, so your minds may be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ. (II Corinthians XI, 3). But here this fear is mitigated by the hope of the Lord, as Ecclesiasticus says: The Lord is my light and my salvation, whom shall I fear? The Lord is the protector of my life, from whom shall I tremble? (Ps. XXVI, 1, 2) After this it is said: There is Aelam (or Assyria), and all its multitude around its tomb, undoubtedly Assyrians. Aelam is translated into our language as their ascent. For all those who, despising the humility of Christ, rise up in the pride of the devil and consider themselves something in the knowledge of false names, are to be called Aelamites, who surround the tomb of the Assyrian king, and they were killed and wounded with the sword. And although they have set their mouths on high, they have descended unclean and uncircumcised to the lowest earth, so that the higher they were elevated, the more forcefully they would fall. These ones have not only imposed their terror once, but a second time on the land of the living. For who among the Ecclesiastics is secure from the terror of such Aelamites, and has not lost someone of his flock? And fittingly the Church of Christ is called the land of the living, so on the contrary, the gatherings of heretics are believed to be the land of the dead. And they carried, he says, their shame, and their torment with those whom they dragged with them into the lake, and into the deep of hell: of which the bed is among the midst of the killers: namely, those whom they cut their throats with their sword, and they surround such peoples. These peoples are the peoples of the Assyrian king, and although they boast to be circumcised: nevertheless, they were killed uncircumcised by the sword, and for the third time they caused terror and fear in the land of the living. Where they carried their torment and punishment in the midst of those whom they deceived with their trickery. There, too, is, that is to say, near Assyria, Mosoch, and Thubal, and all his multitude around his tomb: all uncircumcised and killed, and falling by the sword, who had brought their fear upon the land of the living. For Mosoch and Thubal, Symmachus and Theodotius are interpreted as their dwelling places, so as to show the dwellings of heretics, or rather eternal pits, are the punishments of the Assyrian king. Mosoch is interpreted as madness: Thubal, conversion, not from evil to good, but from good to evil; or all things, so that it offends all heretics to be insane, and with equal zeal to be turned to worse things (Rom. XII). It is not surprising if the insane, and gathered together in evil, have a multitude, since they are partners of the Egyptian king, who delights in multitude. All of these were killed by the sword, who had given their fear, not once, nor twice, but for the third time, in the land of the living, of whom we have spoken more fully above. It follows: And they do not sleep with the mighty, or with the fallen giants, and not with the circumcised, who descended to the underworld with their weapons: and they placed their swords under their heads; and their wickedness was in their bones; because the terror of the mighty has become in the land of the living. These, he says, who had been leaders of heretics, have reached such a height and torment of evil, that they do not deserve to suffer similar punishments even with the mighty and giants who fell from the beginning. Those who, never repenting for their own errors, descended to the underworld with their weapons, rebelled against God and His Church; carrying weapons with them, of which it is written: 'The teeth of men are their weapons and arrows' (Psalm 56:5); and they placed, it is said, their swords under their heads, resting in their minds to be destroyed; and embracing the spears of their opinions as their greatest victory, to the extent that their iniquities were in their bones, that is, possessing the strongest fabrications and doctrines of their own error. Because the strong have become terrified in their lives, whether on the earth of the living. The fourth says this, so that they may terrify the strongest men, and those who have knowledge of the Scriptures, and those who would be from the region of the living, with their wickedness, as they descend into hell with their weapons, and place their swords under their heads, and their iniquities reach even to their bones. After this it is written: And so you shall be crushed in the midst of the uncircumcised (Rom. 16:20), which is said either against Pharaoh or against the strength or multitude of Egypt, and that she herself may be crushed, according to what is written: But may God quickly crush Satan under your feet. And you shall sleep, says he, with the sword having been killed, in eternal sleep. There, with the Assyrian, and with the Egyptian multitude, there shall be Edom, and its kings, all who served earthly works or delighted in blood. Indeed, Edom signifies earthly and bloody things. All the kings and all the rulers, whom the Apostle often speaks of (Phil. III), while indulging in earthly works and daily shedding the blood of those they deceived through their deceit, slept with the uncircumcised and impure, and with those who descended into the lake, of whom we have spoken above. In that very province, there will be the princes of the North, from whom evils blaze upon the earth. And it is from whom, either in Jeremiah (Jer. 1), or in the same prophet (Above XXII), that that pot full of flesh and bones is set on fire. And not only the princes of the North, but all the 393 magistrates of Assyria, for which it is more accurately expressed in Hebrew, all the Sidonians, whom we translate as hunters, according to that which is written: Our soul has been rescued like a bird from the snare of the hunters (Ps. 124:7), for which it is expressed in Hebrew as Sidonians. Those of Sidon, or hunters, will be led trembling to the underworld, having once relied on their own strength, and they will sleep in uncleanness, and they will carry their confusion or torment, having the eternal penance of a guilty conscience, so that their fire is not extinguished (Isaiah 66), and their worm does not die (Mark 9). When Pharaoh sees all of them, he will be comforted, either still having his former wickedness or realizing that he has many companions in his punishment, or certainly he was comforted, seeing them also confounded in their punishments and terrors above his entire multitude that was killed by the sword, namely, Pharaoh's, or all his companions, especially the king of Assyria, and Meshech and Tubal and the Edomites, and the princes of the North, and the Sidonians. For they had instilled their terror in the land of the living. As the fifth says, we should beware and flee all such nations that have deceived our every sense and that we know to be frightful and not easily avoided unless we guard our hearts with utmost caution. He slept, so they say, and Pharaoh himself was slain with his allies by the sword, his allies being a multitude, as they journeyed along a wide and spacious path towards eternal punishments.


<h2 id='tocuniq291'>(Cap. XXXIII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 33, verses 1 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, speak to the children of your people, and say to them: When I bring a sword upon a land, and the people of the land take a man from among them and make him their watchman; and he sees the sword coming upon the land, and blows the trumpet, and warns the people. If anyone hears the sound of the trumpet but does not take warning, and the sword comes and takes him away, his blood shall be upon his own head. He heard the sound (or voice) of the trumpet, and did not take notice, his blood shall be upon himself: but if he take notice and watch to save his soul, his blood shall be upon him. But if the watchman see the sword coming, and sound not the trumpet: and the people look not to themselves, and the sword come and cut off a soul from among them: he indeed is taken away in his iniquity, but I will require his blood at the hand of the watchman. And thou, O son of man, I have made thee a watchman to the house of Israel. Therefore, hear the word from my mouth and announce it to them from me. If I say to the wicked, 'You will surely die,' and you do not speak to warn the wicked to turn from their ways, the wicked person will die for their sin, and I will hold you accountable for their blood. But if you do warn the wicked to turn from their ways and they do not do so, they will die for their sin, but you will have saved yourself. Again, the word of the Lord came to the prophet, who had been silent for a while because a prophet cannot always bear the weight of continuous prophecy due to human weakness. He speaks the same things that were said before. Son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel. You will hear a word from me and deliver a warning from me. If you do not warn the wicked person about their iniquity, they will die because of their iniquity, but I will hold you responsible for their blood. However, if you warn the wicked person and they do not turn from their wicked ways, they will die because of their iniquity, but you have saved yourself. And if you announce to the wicked, and he does not turn from his wickedness and his way, that wicked person shall die in his iniquity, but you have delivered your soul. If you carefully examine them, you understand that they are indeed similar, but not the same, as they differ in many respects. And we must observe this in all the holy Scriptures, where there seems to be some similarity in the message, not everything is said in the same way, but many things are either subtracted or added, and the arrangement of the different words have their own logic. And meanwhile, before we go on to higher things, a brief statement must be explained. If a lookout has been stationed among the people to announce the sword of the Lord and the coming wrath, and when he announces it the people refuse to listen, the lookout will be free, but the one who is caught by the sword will bear the guilt of his own blood. But if the lookout does not blow the trumpet and the people do not take notice of the approaching sword and are therefore not warned, the people will indeed die in their iniquity, but I will hold the lookout accountable for their blood. And so that the prophet Ezekiel would know that the general dispute pertained to him above all. And you, he said, son of man, you were not appointed from the land and the people of the land, as I said before, but from me, you were appointed as a watcher over the house of Israel. So if I say to the wicked: Wicked one, you shall surely die, and you do not speak to warn him to keep himself from his wicked ways, and he dies in his iniquity, his blood will I require at your hand. But if you announce and command the impious one to turn away from his worst ways, and he refuses to do so, he will indeed die in his iniquity; but you will be saved from the destruction of negligence in your own soul. From these words we learn that a man, even if wicked and impious, can be saved from his impiety if he hears the words of the teacher and repents. But the teacher is also at risk if he refuses to teach, either out of fear of consequences or despair of the sinner. The teacher is responsible for the blood of the one who could have been saved and rescued from death if the teacher had not remained silent. Both the teacher's choice to remain silent or speak and the listener's choice to hear, act, and be saved or despise and perish are free. And immediately it does not follow that what the prophet predicts will come to pass. For he does not predict in order that it may come, but in order that it may not come; and because God speaks, it is not necessary that what he threatens will happen, but he threatens in order that the one to whom he threatens may be converted to repentance, and that what is foretold may not happen if the words of the Lord are despised. Now we can explain this passage in three ways: either according to the literal sense, that the land which appoints a lookout for itself is the land of Judah; or according to the spiritual interpretation, the Church, which often chooses a lookout for itself regarding the last things of its people, namely, whom the Apostle, writing to the Corinthians, takes as a judge (1 Corinthians 15); or certainly, the soul of the believer, which places its mind and reason above the thoughts of the people and crowd of its own thoughts, so that it may not accept all the incitements of its thoughts but may judge and discern which ones ought to be followed and which ones ought to be avoided. The speculator of the land of Judea can be understood either as a king or a prophet. But the speculator of the Church, that is, the bishop or the presbyter, is chosen by the people and is knowledgeable in the reading of the Scriptures, foreseeing what is to come. He announces to the people and corrects the wrongdoer. Therefore, it is greatly to be feared that we approach this office unworthy and chosen by the people, giving ourselves to negligence and laziness. And what is worse, serving in pleasures, belly, and leisure, we think that we have received honor, not ministry. For the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve (Matt. 20:28); and he washed the feet of the disciples (John 13), to show that all filth and vices should be washed away and cleansed by the teachers in the disciples. And let us not immediately respond, what is the profit of teaching if the listener does not want to do what you have taught? For each person is judged according to their own mind and duty. You, if you have not spoken, and he, if he has contemptuously refused to listen. Concerning negligent magistrates, Solomon speaks: Hidden wisdom and secret treasure, what use is there in both? (Ecclus. XX, 32). This means something similar in the Gospel (Mark IX), that whoever causes scandal to one of the least of the Church, it would be better for him to be tied to his neck an ass’s millstone and be thrown into the deep, rather than, placed on a pedestal, cause damage to many.

<h2 id='tocuniq292'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 and following) Therefore, son of man, say to the house of Israel, Thus you have said: 'Our transgressions and our sins are upon us, and we waste away because of them; how then can we live?' Say to them, As I live, declares the Lord God, I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but that the wicked turn from his way and live; turn back, turn back from your evil ways, for why will you die, O house of Israel? And you, son of man, say to the people of your people, The righteousness of the righteous shall not deliver him when he transgresses, and as for the wickedness of the wicked, he shall not fall by it when he turns from his wickedness, and the righteous shall not be able to live by his righteousness when he sins on any day." } Even if he says that life must be lived justly, and trusting in his own justice commits iniquity, all his righteousness will be forgotten, and he will die in the iniquity that he has worked. But if he says to the wicked, 'You will surely die,' and he repents of his sin, and practices judgment and righteousness, restores what he has taken by robbery, walks in the commandments of life, and does not commit any injustice, he will live and not die. All sins (Vulg. adds \"of his\") that he has committed will not be attributed to him: he has done judgment and justice, he will live: And the children of your people say: The way of the Lord is not equal, and their own way is unjust. For when the just shall depart from his justice, and commit iniquities, he shall die in them. And when the wicked shall depart from his wickedness, and shall do judgment and justice, he shall live in them. And you say: The way of the Lord is not right. I will judge each of you according to your ways, O house of Israel. If we read negligently, the same prophecy seems to us to say what is said above, namely: \"Do I have any pleasure in the death of the wicked, declares the Lord God, and not rather that he should turn from his way and live?\" (Ezekiel 18:23) And at the end of the same prophecy: \"Turn away from all your transgressions, and they shall not be a stumbling block to you of iniquity\" (ibid., 8). For there the conversation takes place with those who want to do penance and erase their sins with justice, so that they may convert with confidence and repent with a full heart. However, here he speaks to those who, due to the magnitude of their sins, or rather their impieties, despair of salvation and say: Our iniquities and sins are upon us, and we waste away in them. How then can we live? And the meaning is: Since death has once been proposed to us, and there is no medicine that can restore health to our wounds, why must we labor and be consumed in vain and not spend this present life in despair, so that we may at least enjoy this, since we have lost the future? To those whom God responds, he does not desire the death of the wicked, but rather that they should turn back and live. And he makes an appeal to the desperate wicked: Turn away from your worst ways. And in order for us to know who the wicked are to whom he speaks, the following discourse demonstrates: Why should you die, house of Israel? However, life and death in this context do not signify the common law of nature by which we all either live or are dissolved by death, like animals; but rather that which is written, I will please the Lord in the land of the living (Psalm 114:9); and, The soul that sins, it shall die. And from a special reminder that he was speaking to the house of Israel, he transitions to a general discussion: that past righteousness does not save from present injustice, if one is occupied with new crimes, and they do not erase the sins of an old sinner or impious person if they have corrected their past mistakes with righteous actions. And God does not judge in both cases based on the past, but on the present. If I say, he says, to the righteous, you shall live, and if I have promised the rewards of righteousness to him, and if he, relying on that, sins, all of his past righteousness will be forgotten, and he will die in his present wickedness. And my opinion has not changed, since I cannot fulfill what I promised to the same sinful person as to the righteous person. But if I threaten sinners and the wicked, saying, 'In three days Nineveh will be overthrown,' and that person repents and corrects their past mistakes through good deeds, acting justly and restoring what was taken, walking in the commandments of life and doing nothing unjust, should not the life that is in Christ live and never die, since the punishment of the sinner should not fall upon the righteous? This is what the divine speech says to Jeremiah when he goes down to the house of the potter and hears either the promises or the threats of God. It is done in order to either provoke people to salvation or to deter them from sin (Jeremiah XVIII). Therefore, those who say 'The way of the Lord is not fair' are argued against, as their own judgment is unjust, their eyes are very bad, and they do not judge with anything new, but with the old judgments. All of these things demonstrate that a sinner should not despair of salvation if he repents, nor should the righteous person rely on his own righteousness if he carelessly loses what he had acquired with great effort. We race through the manifest, so that we may dwell in the more obscure matters, in which the present prophecy differs from the past, and in which it speaks of similar things, the comparison of both can indicate. Moreover, what it means to judge and to do justice, to restore a pledge, to give back what was stolen, to walk in the commands of life, and other things, we have already mentioned in this same prophet.

<h2 id='tocuniq293'>(Vers. 21, 22.)</h2>

(Verses 21, 22.) And it came to pass in the twelfth year, in the tenth month (the Vulgate is silent about the month), on the fifth day of the month of our transmigration (or captivity): the one who had fled (or been saved) from Jerusalem came to me, saying, 'The city has been devastated (or captured).' But the hand of the Lord had come upon me in the evening before the one who had fled came: and he opened my mouth until morning and with my mouth open, I did not remain silent any longer. In the eleventh year of the reign of Zedekiah, in the fifth month, the city of Jerusalem was captured. This prophecy, however, in the twelfth year, in the tenth month, on the fifth day of the month of captivity or migration, when Jechoniah was captured, shows that one year, four months, and twenty-five days after the capture of Jerusalem, a citizen of Jerusalem came to Babylon to announce the captured and devastated city. But one day before the one who was to narrate this arrived, in the evening the hand of the Lord came upon the prophet Ezekiel, who opened his mouth which had been closed for a long time, and whatever he was going to say, the one who made this happen replied beforehand: nor did he remain silent any longer, seeing his prophecy fulfilled in action, and having no doubt at all about the people who were in Babylon, or those who were taken captive from the prophetic prediction. For then the mouth of the prophet is opened, when what he had previously announced is shown in action: and he proclaims with complete freedom, who demonstrates not things that will happen in the future, but either things that are present or things that have already happened. This according to the letter. Moreover, according to the anagoge, if Ezekiel is interpreted as the strength of God: but Christ is the power and wisdom of God (I Cor. I, 24), this is to be understood, that when Jerusalem was captured and destroyed, whoever could escape the perfidy of the Jews, like the apostles and the relics that were saved, he himself announces to Christ that all the ceremonies of the Jews have been destroyed, which some still think should be observed today, not hearing the Apostle's words: You have fallen from grace, you who are justified by the Law (Galat. V, 4). And why not, when the stubbornness of men wishes to defend in word what they dare not fulfill in deed, except perhaps under the disguise of sheepskin, that is, of Christians, the wolves of the Jews hide? What does the defender (or rather, the accuser) of the synagogue proclaim in the Churches of Christ? Therefore, with Jerusalem captured and destroyed, the mouth of the Lord is opened through the apostles and the apostolic men, who can say: My mouth is open to you, O Corinthians; and: A great and powerful door has opened to me (II Cor. VI, 11). And this: I opened my mouth and drew in breath (Psalm 118, 131), which will never be silent, nor be heard with Israel: Hear, O Israel, and be silent: but it will resound throughout the whole world, and will open (or be opened) the Gospel of Christ to the Gentiles. Therefore, according to this understanding, the twelfth year refers to the twelve tribes, and the tenth month to the time of Jewish propitiation, which is called ἱλασμός in Greek; and the fifth day of the month refers to carnal senses, which we have shown were all destroyed and passed away, with Jerusalem being captured and the Gospel succeeding; and in the evening, that is, at the consummation of the world, the hand of the true Ezekiel, who had foretold the future destruction of the city through the prophets, and showed that the prophecies had been fulfilled in the morning.


<h2 id='tocuniq294'>(Vers. 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 and following) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, those who dwell in these ruined places in the land of Israel are saying: Abraham was alone, and he possessed the land; but we are many, the land has been given to us for possession. Therefore, you shall say to them: Thus says the Lord God: You who eat meat with blood, and lift up your eyes to your idols, and shed blood, shall you possess the land as an inheritance? You have stood with your swords, you have committed abominations, and each one of you has defiled his neighbor's wife, and shall you possess the land as an inheritance? You shall say this to them: Thus says the Lord God: As I live, surely those who dwell in the ruins shall fall by the sword, and he who is in the open field I will give to the beasts to be devoured, and those who are in strongholds and in caves shall die of the plague. And I will make the land a desolation and a waste, and the pride of its power shall cease, and the mountains of Israel shall be desolate, so that no one will pass through them. And they shall know that I am the Lord, when I make their land desolate and deserted because of all their abominations that they have committed. And you, son of man, the children of your people speak about you by the walls and in the doors of houses, and they say to one another, each to his neighbor, speaking: Come, let us hear what word is coming forth from the Lord. And they come to you as the people usually gather, and they sit before you as my people, and they hear your words, but they do not do them, for they turn them into a song of their mouth, and their heart follows their greed (or as it is contained in the Septuagint: For they themselves make falsehood in their mouth, and after their abominations their heart walks. Followed): And you will be to them like a musical chant that is sung with a sweet and pleasant sound, and they will hear your words, but they will not do them, and when the predicted thing comes, behold, it is coming: then they will know that there is a prophet among them. Firstly, it must be understood that about eight more or less lines have been added to the place that we have set. Those who dine on blood, and you lift your eyes to your impurities, up to the place where it is written: These things you shall say to them, thus says the Lord God, it is not found in the Septuagint, which, along with many others, have overlooked these things or, translated by them, have gradually been removed due to error. And our Latin authors, or rather envious Christians, or, to speak more plainly, the heirs of the Grunnian faction, bark against us because we discuss according to the Hebrew text: as if food is being forced upon unwilling recipients, and that these feasts are not prepared for those who receive them with thanksgiving. Certainly, if they do not believe us, let them read other editions, of Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion; let them question Hebrews from different regions, not just the ones I have redeemed, but from various provinces; and when they see that everyone agrees with my error or ignorance, then they will understand that they are too wise and prefer to sleep rather than learn; and let them live in the seventy cells of the Alexandrian Pharos, so they do not lose their sails from their ships and sigh over the damage of their ropes. This, on the other hand, is spoken against the envious: now let us discuss what we have proposed. After Jerusalem was captured and the temple was destroyed, the poor of the land, about whom Jeremiah writes,  were the only ones left in Jerusalem who cultivated vineyards and fields and lived in the ruins of the burned city. And although they should have repented for the things that led to their captivity, deceiving themselves with false hope, they said: Our father Abraham was one, and yet he possessed this land as an inheritance, not because he himself possessed it, but because his seed received the land of promise. If, therefore, he alone was multiplied into so many peoples, we who are left in the land of Judah, and dwell in deserted and ruined cities, will certainly be multiplied much more, so that we may possess more than he possessed alone. To whom the Lord responded: Abraham possessed the land of promise by faith alone. For Abraham believed in God, and it was counted to him as righteousness (Genesis XV, 8). However, these people, occupied with disbelief and wickedness, even if they are many, will not be able to possess. At the same time, he enumerates what the sinners do to offend God, namely six kinds of sins.
