Those who eat flesh with blood, and lift up your eyes to impurities, that is, to your idols, and spill blood, that is, perpetrate murder: can those who do these things retain the land as their inheritance? Not content with this, you also stand with your swords every day, ready to kill, and imitating Esau, who stood and lived by his sword, you commit incredible abominations, namely shameful lusts, and each one defiles his neighbor's wife; so that in this you are more wicked, because he defiles the wife of his friend and neighbor. And when you do these things, do you think that you will retain the land as an inheritance? Therefore, respond to them, O prophet, and bring forth this judgment upon them from my word. I swear by myself that those who dwell in ruins and walls shall fall by the sword, and those who are in the fields or in the open country shall be devoured by beasts. And those who are in fortified cities or in strongholds and caves shall not be able to escape the wrath of God, but instead shall die by famine and pestilence. And I will make the land of Judah a desolation, so that the proud strength of Judah shall be brought low. But God resists the proud and gives grace to the humble (James 4:6). Even the mountains and all things will be deserted, and there will be such a great desolation that no one will pass through them. And then those who have relied on their multitude will have no confidence, only a few who remain. But they will come to know the magnitude of the desolation and that I am the Lord, who have made the land a desert because of all the abominations they have committed. Let these words be spoken against those who, after Jerusalem was captured and the entire region of Judea was laid waste, lived in ruins and in deserted cities and villages. Now let us turn to tropology, and according to our custom, let us engage in a wide-ranging discussion rather than a dissertation. Every heretic dwells in walls and deserts, and thinks that he possesses the land of Israel, and he says: If Abraham, through his faith alone, came to such great blessedness that his offspring would be multiplied like the sand of the sea and like the stars of the heavens, how much more will we, who are more numerous, possess the land of Israel, that is, the land of those who see God, and the land of the confession of the Lord? To which the Lord responded: He possessed the land of faith deservedly; but your unfaithfulness, rather blasphemy, will not be able to possess the land of Israel, that is, the Church. For first you eat in blood, pouring out their blood, whom you scandalize. Then you lift your eyes to your uncleannesses or abominations, which you have fixed in your mind: when you ought to imitate the ecclesiastical man, and say: To you I have lifted up my eyes, who dwell in heaven (Psalm 122:1). Thirdly, you shed blood, not giving life to those whom you have deceived, but killing. Nor is it enough for you to have done these three things, but you stand with your swords, that is, you persist in the wickedness of your judgment, and you are prepared for murders, and you commit abominations, doing those things in your bedrooms which it is shameful to speak of, and you defile the wife of your neighbor, specifically the ecclesiastical way of life, hastening daily to deceive and snatch away those embraced by Christ. And when you have done these things, do you think you will inherit the land of Israel? To whom God speaks, that whoever dwells in the ruinous gatherings of heretics, shall fall by the sword, as it is written: They have swords doubled-edged in their hands (Ps. CXLIX, 6). And in the Gospel: I come not to send peace, but a sword (Matth. X). And the servant who indulges in luxury and idleness, shall be divided, that is, shall be struck with a sword, and his portion shall be with the unbelievers (Luc. XII). And he who is in the field or in an open area, will be given to the beasts to be devoured, which the prophet, desiring to avoid, prays: Do not deliver the soul of the one confessing to you to the beasts (Ps. LXXIII, 19). But he who is in strongholds and fortified cities, of which it is written: The righteous ascends to secure cities, and he destroyed their fortifications in which the wicked trusted (Prov. XXI, 22); and he dwells in caves, of which it is said: It is written, My Father's house will be called a house of prayer, but you have made it a den of thieves (Matt. XXI, 33): this person will die from the famine of the word of the Lord and the plague, and the entire earth of heretics will be turned into a desert, so that their pride will be broken, and the mountains that they promised to raise in their knowledge will be reduced to a desert. Those mountains are called Israel, because under the name of Christ they deceive and supplant those who are deceived: and no one will pass through them, nor will anyone be able to say what Moses said: 'Going through, I will see this great vision' (Exod. III, 1); for the inhabitants are of the corrupt mountains, not strangers and sojourners: so that when these things have been suffered, they may then know that He Himself is the Lord, who has made their land a desert because of the abominations they have committed. It follows: On the same day and at the same time, that is, in the twelfth year, in the tenth month, on the fifth day of the month, when he who had fled from Jerusalem came and when the prophet spoke to those who were in the land of Judah and promised them the hope of eternal possession, and he orders the prophet to speak to the people who are in Babylon and live with him, and he rebukes them for their deceptive schemes, who desire to hear the prophet's words, not for the salvation of their souls, but for the pleasure of their ears. They were sitting beside the walls and at the doorways of houses, not desiring to enter into the understanding of the prophet; but they encourage one another and say: Come and let us hear what word comes forth from the Lord; and thus they come as a people who enter into the Church of God, and they sit before you, my people, who claim to be mine, and they do not want to do what they have heard. They seem to me to be like those who are amused by theatrical songs: and they either listen to tragedy or to comedies, and there they are delighting themselves with pleasure: so that when they have left you, they repeat those things and sing them, and with sweet sound they deceive themselves. And they will listen, he says, to your words but not do them. Such are many in the Churches even to this day, who say: Come, let us hear him, and him, rolling the words of his preaching with wondrous eloquence: they stir up applause, and shout, and wave their hands, and those things which they had neglected in their actions, once they learn that he has arrived (for it is necessary that what the prophet of God proclaims with his word should come to pass), then they will begin to approve and know that all the things they had heard were not the words of a man, but of the Lord, who spoke through the prophet and the man of the Church.


<h2 id='tocuniq295'>Book Eleven</h2>

Book Eleven

405-406 The eleventh book of explanations in Ezekiel will contain a prophecy against Gog and Magog in the final part, and it will come up to the beginning of the city situated on the mountain, and of the temple situated in it. If, with the help of the Lord and by explaining its mysteries, I can bring it all the way to the end, it will be a long and difficult task for me, and I will have to consider whether I should lay hands on the spiritual temple or openly admit my ignorance. Especially since both among the Jews and among us there is a great silence regarding its interpretation: some believe that it should be constructed in the future, while others, with good intentions but lacking knowledge, understand that what is said are spiritual things, yet they themselves do not know how they should be explained. And meanwhile, so that the care of the present work may hold us, know, O Virgin of Christ Eustochium, that you should pray for us. In a very difficult prophecy, I briefly remind you that a man of our time, not of noble birth, writing to the Emperor, said about this nation: That one is Gog, the Goth; how all the things written about it can be connected is not for me to discuss, but for those who believe this.

<h2 id='tocuniq296'>(Cap. XXXIV.)</h2>

And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds (or to the shepherds) of Israel, prophesy, and say to the shepherds: Thus says the Lord God: Woe to the shepherds of Israel who have been feeding themselves. (Or: O shepherds of Israel, do the shepherds not feed themselves?) Are not the flocks fed by the shepherds? (Or do the sheep not feed the shepherds?) You ate the curds, you clothed yourselves with the wool, and you slaughtered the fat animals, but you did not feed my flock. You did not strengthen what was weak (or comforted); and you did not heal what was sick; you did not bind up what was broken, and you did not bring back what was cast away (or wandered); you did not seek what was lost; but you commanded them with harshness, and with power (or by force) you afflicted them with labor. And my sheep were scattered because there was no shepherd (or shepherds), and they became food for all the beasts of the field, and they were scattered. My flocks (or sheep) had wandered on all the mountains and on every high hill, and my flocks (or sheep) were scattered over the face of the earth, and there was no one who sought them, I mean, there was no one who sought them (or who would bring them back). Therefore, O shepherds, hear the word of the Lord: As I live, says the Lord God, because my flocks (or sheep) have become a prey, and my sheep have become food for all the wild beasts of the field, because there was no shepherd (or shepherds), since the shepherds (Vulgate adds 'of mine') did not seek my flock, but they fed themselves and did not feed my flocks. Therefore, shepherds, hear the word of the Lord. Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I myself will search for my flock and will rescue them from the hand of their shepherds, and I will make them cease from feeding the flock so that they will no longer be fed. I will not allow the shepherds to feed themselves (or the sheep) any longer, and I will deliver my flock (or sheep) from their mouths, and they will no longer be food for them. For thus says the Lord God: Behold, I myself will search for my sheep and will visit them as a shepherd visits his flock on the day when he is in the midst of his scattered sheep (or when it is dark and clouds are separating his sheep): thus I will visit my sheep and will deliver them from all the places where they were dispersed on the day of cloud and darkness. And I will bring them (whether female or male) from the peoples (or from the nations), and gather them (whether female or male) from the lands (or regions), and bring them (whether female or male) into their own land, and feed them (whether female or male) on the mountains of Israel, in the rivers and in all the habitations of the land. In the most fertile pastures I will feed them (whether female or male), and on the high mountains of Israel their pastures (or flocks) will be: there they will rest in green grass, and in rich pastures they will graze on the mountains of Israel. I will feed my sheep, and I will make them lie down (or rest), says the Lord God. What was lost, I will seek, and what was rejected (or gone astray), I will bring back; and what was broken, I will bind up, and what was weak, I will strengthen (or comfort); and what was fat and strong, I will watch over, and I will feed them with justice (or with judgment). But you, my flock (or my sheep), thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will judge between sheep and sheep, between rams and goats. Was it not enough for you to feed on good pastures? Moreover, you trampled the leftovers of your pastures under your feet, and while you drank pure water, you disturbed the rest with your feet. And my sheep, which were trampled by your feet, were being fed, and those that disturbed your feet were drinking. Therefore, thus says the Lord God to you: Behold, I myself will judge between the fat sheep and the lean (or between the strong and the weak): because you were pushing with your sides and shoulders, and with your horns you were butting all the weak animals until they were scattered abroad. I will save my flock, and it will no longer be a prey, and I will judge between sheep and sheep (or between ram and ram). And I will raise up over them (or over it) one shepherd who will feed them (or it), My servant David: he will feed them (or it), and he will be their shepherd. But I, the Lord, will be their God, and My servant David will be their prince in their midst. I, the Lord, have spoken. And I will make a covenant (or testament) of peace with them, and I will cause the most harmful beasts to cease from the land, and those who dwell in the wilderness will sleep securely in the meadows. And I will place them around my hill as a blessing, and I will give rain in its season, it will be a blessing of rain. And the trees of the field will yield their fruit, and the earth will bring forth its produce (or strength); and they will dwell in their land without fear (or in the hope of peace); and they will know that I am the Lord, when I break the chains (or yoke) of their burden, and I deliver them from the hand of those who make them serve (or oppress them). And they shall no longer be a prey to the nations, neither shall the beasts of the earth devour them: but they shall dwell securely (or in hope) without any fear. And I will raise up for them a name (or a planting of peace): and they shall no longer be consumed (or destroyed) by hunger in the land, neither shall they bear any more the reproach of the nations. And they shall know that I am the Lord their God, who is with them, and they themselves are my people, the house of Israel, says the Lord God. But you, my flock, the flock of my pasture (or sheep), you are human beings, and I am the Lord your God, says the Lord God. Often I have urged each edition to mix both, so that the magnitude of the books' vine, only in those things that do not differ much from themselves in translation. After the capture of Jerusalem, after he announced in Babylon who had fled, he spoke of those who lived in ruined Jerusalem, and then to those who were placed in captivity but nevertheless persisted in wickedness, not wanting to hear the words of the prophets: now he directs his speech to the shepherds, that is, to the leaders, whose fault the sheep, that is, the people, have been scattered. And it is to be noted that from the twelfth year, tenth month, fifth month of migration or captivity of Jechoniah, and those who were taken captive with him, until the twenty-fifth year when the temple of the city was built on the mountain and the incredible sacraments of the Church were revealed, there is no middle year, no specific time period; rather it is simply said: The word of the Lord came to me, saying, Son of man, speak to them and to those, that we may understand everything that is read for thirteen years, in different times spoken; and yet they do not have certain intervals of time between them. But the word is directed to the shepherds of Israel, whom we must understand as either kings or princes, scribes and Pharisees, and teachers of the Jewish people. Or certainly in the Evangelical people, bishops, priests, and deacons: or according to a mystical understanding, the Angels of the individual Churches, to whom John wrote in his Apocalypse (Apoc. I), and whose Angels daily behold the face of God (Matth. XVIII). And it is said first: Woe to the shepherds of Israel, who must pasture the flock of the Lord, and provide for its salvation, but hasten instead towards their own luxury. Wherefore great caution is to be exercised, and those precepts observed: Seek not to be made a judge, lest perhaps thou mayest not be able to take away iniquities (Eccli. VII, 6). And again: The greater thou art, the more humble thyself in all things, and thou shalt find grace before God (Ibid. III, 29). And again: They have made thee a ruler, despise not; but be among them as one of them (Eccli. XXXII, 1). Wherefore even the Apostle says of himself that he is as a little child and as one that is still nourished by milk among the disciples (I Cor. III). And what follows: You were eating milk, and you were clothing yourselves in wool, by metaphor of shepherds speaking to princes, of whom it is also written elsewhere: Who devour my people as bread (Ps. LII, 5). Understand all food in milk: in wool, the diverse variety of clothing. But what is said: And you were slaughtering what was fat, speaks of the rich people of the populace, whom evil princes are said to slaughter in the churches, while they preach to them and dare not rebuke their vices. Concerning whom the prophet also says: My people, those who call you blessed, deceive you and overthrow the path of your feet (Isa. III, 12). Concerning whom also James speaks (James II, 3), that when they enter unto them, being adorned with costly garments and a golden ring, they are honored, and it is said to the holy poor: But you, sit on a stool, or on the ground, or stand. They do not strengthen or consolidate that which is weak. And Paul also speaks: Receive the weak (Rom. XIV, 1). And: receive the weak in faith. And: Many among you are weak and sick. To whom the divine word is sent, of which it is written in the Psalms: He sent his word, and healed them, and delivered them from their destructions (Ps. CV, 10). And he says that what is broken, they do not bind: not at all considering mortal wounds in the people, such as adultery, murder, sacrilege. And what is despicable, or what they have seen to be in error, they do not bring back, allowing them to be deceived by heretics. And what is lost, they do not seek, not desiring to save those who are lost, but rather to devour those who are in the Churches: but ruling over them with severity and power, which properly belongs to the arrogance of bishops, namely those who bring dishonor to the dignity of their name with their actions, and assume pride for humility, thinking that they have obtained honor, not burden: and whoever they see in the Church with authority and having the word of God, they strive to oppress. Whereas it is written in the Septuagint: And you have been tormenting what was perhaps weak. And the people of God have been scattered, either by vices or by the error of heretics: because there was not a good shepherd who would lay down his life for the sheep: but all are hirelings, who consider only their own gain from the flocks, and when they see the wolf, they flee. Because of their negligence, the flock of the Lord is devoured by the beasts of the field, of which it is written: You have set darkness, and it has become night: therein shall all the beasts of the field pass over, the lion's whelps roaring, that they may snatch, and seek from God food for themselves (Ps. 103: 20, 21). And they are scattered and wander on all the mountains, which rise up against the knowledge of God and the high hill, which through heretical pride despise the simplicity of the Church. And they are scattered over the whole face of the earth, seeking earthly things and not heavenly things. And there was no one to seek or to bring back, because they are occupied with pleasures and do not care about the losses of the flock of the Lord. Therefore, the word of the Lord is spoken against the wicked shepherds, because you have done these things that I have explained above and that are enumerated a second time: Behold, I myself will come to the shepherds and will seek my flock from their hand. It is expedient that a millstone be hung around their necks, so as not to scandalize the least of my people. And this will be their punishment, or rather their greatest punishment, that they will no longer feed my flock; that they will not feed themselves under the pretext of caring for the sheep, and gather wealth. And I will free my people from their mouths. As he says, I will seek from their hand, and I will free from their mouth what is devoured by greedy jaws. But when he seeks the sheep, he visits them as if they were sickly and emaciated, and scattered by the negligence of the shepherds; and he will free them from all places in the day of cloud and darkness, of which Joel speaks: The day of the Lord is coming, and it is near, a day of darkness and gloom, a day of cloud and mist (Joel. II, 1, 2). Then they shall be brought forth from the lands, to be led into their own land, which is the land of the living: and He Himself shall feed them on the mountains of Israel, of which David speaks: I lift up my eyes to the mountains, from where shall come my help (Ps. 121:1). And not only on the mountains, but also in the rivers, and in all the seats of the earth, in abundant pastures, and on the high mountain, of which Isaiah, and Micah prophesy more fully (Isa. 2; Mic. 4, 7): whether on the high mountains of Israel. There they will rest on green herbs, and they will say: The Lord feeds me, and nothing will be lacking to me; in the place of pasture he has placed me: He has led me up above the waters of refreshment (Ps. 22:1-2). And they will be pastured in the richest pastures on the mountains of Israel. It is an infinite promise and a hope of blessedness, when the Lord himself promises, saying: I will feed my sheep, and I will not at all commit them to evil shepherds, and I will make them to lie down, says the Lord God, so that they may rest in the bosom of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Then what was lost among the people of the nations will be sought after, and what was led astray by the persuasion of heretics will be brought back, and what was broken will be restored, and what was crushed and weak will be strengthened, so that what is written may be fulfilled: He heals their diseases and binds up their wounds (Psalm 147:3). For God does not despise a contrite and humble heart (Psalm 51:19). Therefore, the saint also says: Heal me, O Lord, for my bones are troubled (Psalm 6:2). And in the thirty-seventh Psalm (verse 4), the penitent says: There is no peace in my bones from the face of my sins; and what is fat, he says, and strong, I will keep, lest it be devoured by beasts. And he will feed his sheep in judgment, knowing to which sheep the pastures should be given. For there are different mansions with the Father (John 14). And: The Father judges no one, but has given all judgment to the Son (ibid., 5). But these things he spoke against the shepherds; now he speaks to the sheep, that is, to the people; and to the flock of both kinds of livestock, that is, of sheep and goats; and not only to the sheep and goats, but also to the rams and he-goats, who are the leaders in the flocks, to whom he says: Was it not enough for you that you were fed with the good pastures of the Scriptures? But furthermore, you trampled on the remnants of your pastures with your feet. And while you drank the pure waters of God's words, you disturbed the remaining waters with your feet, so that my people would eat and drink trampled pastures and turbid waters, and would accept your vice, which in itself was good, as corrupted and violated. Indeed, all heretics do this, in order to misconstrue the words of the Scriptures and, as much as they can, defile them. But even ecclesiastical men who do not guard the truth of the doctrines, but fabricate from their own heart, and hold their own presumption, are misled by a similar error. When they have persuaded the people that what they have made up is true, and have incited applause and cheers in a theatrical manner, they become forgetful of their own ignorance, and assuming a haughty expression, with studied words, and carefully chosen arguments, they assume the authority of masters for themselves. Let us therefore see what judgment there is between one beast and another beast: and by what judgment the good and true shepherd, who has received all judgment from the Father, judges them. Behold, he says, I myself judge between the fat beast and the lean, or between the strong and the weak. For the strong push and collide against the weak animals with their sides and shoulders, and they toss them with their horns, not knowing that according to the law the bull must be punished with the horned heifer (Exodus 21). But they were pushing on the sides, and they were fanning with horns, until they dispersed, and they drove the sheep out. For the pride of the elders, and the injustice of the leaders, they are often driven out of the Church: so that they may be scattered by the Lord, whom he himself saved. But the Lord will no longer let them go unpunished, and he will judge between sheep and sheep: not between the names of dignitaries, by whom the leaders are swollen; but between man and man, according to what each servant is of the Lord. Then he will raise up one shepherd, who says in the Gospel: I am the good shepherd (John 10:11); his servant David according to what form a servant is worthy to assume (Philippians 2); who is interpreted as David, the man of strong hand. He will feed them, and the Lord will be their God, either the Son and the Father, or certainly the shepherd according to the assumed flesh: 413 However, the Lord and God, according to the Word that was in the beginning with God. David, as the rational animal surpasses the irrational animals, will never be called a shepherd, but a prince among them, as it is written: 'One stands among you whom you do not know' (John 1:26). Then he will establish a covenant of peace with them, not of wars and discord, for his dwelling place has been made in peace (Psalm 76). But it is the peace of Christ, which surpasses all understanding (Philippians 4), who says: 'My peace I give to you; my peace I leave with you' (John 14:27). And he will cause the most malicious beasts of the earth, vices, or disturbances, by which human souls are tormented: or opposing powers, by which they are attacked, to cease. And those who dwell in the desert will sleep securely in the forests. For the Lord will reveal the hidden places of the woods, and in his temple all will declare glory (Psalm 29:9). But once the beasts are driven away, and the land is reduced to solitude, those secure in such creatures will sleep and say: The Lord is my light and my salvation; whom shall I fear? (Psalm 26:1) And He will place them, who sleep securely around their mountain or hill, and they shall be blessed. Then he will give rain in its season, and there shall be blessings of rains, which are promised in the blessings of Deuteronomy (Deut. XXVIII). And He will give, as it is said, the tree of life, of which it is written in Genesis (Genes. II): and the tree of wisdom, of which it is said, It is a tree of life to all who take hold of it (Prov. III, 18). And He will give its fruit, when the earth also gives its fruit: whether it be the trees of the regions, a great multitude of the saints. And the earth will give its fruit: For truth has risen from the earth (Psalm 84:12). And they shall be in their land without fear, with hope for peace, in the land of the living, in the land of the gentle, of which it is written: Blessed are the meek; for they shall inherit the earth (Matthew 5:4): so that they may know by the happiness of all things that He is the Lord: when He breaks the chains, or the iron circle of their continual oppression, by which they were almost crushed under a very grievous rule, and He will deliver them from the hand of their oppressors, or from the affliction of their servitude. For each person is a servant to the one by whom they are overcome. And the demoniac peoples will no longer be a prey; nor will the beasts of the earth devour those of whom we have spoken. But they will dwell confidently without any fear, according to the previous exposition. And, as it is said, I will raise up for them a named shoot, or a planting of peace, which is spoken of in the Gospel: I am the true vine (John 15:1). And they will no longer be diminished by hunger in the land. Therefore, hunger in earthly matters is hunger to hear the word of God, which, under a good shepherd, is celebrated with a named germ and the speech of all, and the planting of peace. It will by no means be on the earth anymore, nor will they be subjected to the reproaches of the nations, saying, 'Where is their God, the Lord?' (Psalm 113:10). And after all these things, it is known that not only is He the Lord, which He has also said above; but with the addition that He is the Lord of all, their God, with those who say in the Gospel to the Apostles, 'Behold, I am with you all days, even to the consummation of the world' (Matthew 28:20). But when He Himself shall be their Lord God, then also they shall be His people, not all, but those who have deserved to be called the house of Israel. And lest we should think that all the things which were said belong to the shepherds, and the sheep, and the goats, and the rams, He solves the enigma, or rather the metaphor, and expresses it more clearly: But ye are My sheep, and the sheep of My pasture; ye are men. Therefore every divine discourse is for men, to whom He says: I am your Lord God, saith the Lord God.


<h2 id='tocuniq297'>(Cap. XXXV.)</h2>

(Chapter XXXV.) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against Mount Seir, and prophesy against it, and say to it, thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, Mount Seir, and I will stretch out my hand against you, and I will make you desolate and a wasteland. I will demolish your cities and make you deserted, and you will know that I am the Lord; because you have been an everlasting enemy and have confined the sons of Israel in the hand of the sword, and have acted deceitfully against the house of Israel in the time of their affliction, in the time of extreme wickedness. Therefore, I live, says the Lord God, because I will deliver you to bloodshed (or because you have sinned in blood) and blood will pursue you. And when you hate blood, blood will pursue you. And I will make Mount Seir desolate and deserted, and I will remove from it those going and returning (or men and beasts). And I will fill its mountains with the slain (or wounded): on your hills, and in your valleys, and in the ravines, those killed by the sword will fall. I will deliver you into eternal desolation, and your cities will not be inhabited: and you will know (or you will know) that I am the Lord (Vulgate adds God); because you have said: Two nations and two lands (or regions) will be mine, and I will possess them by inheritance, when the Lord was there. Therefore, as I live, says the Lord God, I will deal with you according to your anger (or enmity): and according to your zeal, which you have made, I will become known to you (Vulgate adds through them) when I judge you, and you will know that I am the Lord. I have heard all your reproaches (or the voice of your blasphemies) that you have spoken (or because you have spoken) against the mountains of Israel, saying, 'The deserts have been given to us to devour,' and you have risen up (or have vigorously spoken against me) with your mouth; and you have derogated against me (or have shouted against me) with your words: I have heard. Thus says the Lord God: Rejoicing in all the earth, I will reduce you to a wilderness: just as you have rejoiced over the inheritance of the house of Israel because it has been scattered; so I will do to you: You will be scattered, O Mount Seir, and all Edom, and they will know that I am the Lord. But that which is added in the LXX, 'and they shall be consumed', is not in the Hebrew. If the word of God were always in the prophets and had a constant lodging in their hearts, Ezekiel would never so often have said, 'And the word of the Lord came to me saying'. But because of human frailty and the necessities of this life, it sometimes departed from them. Therefore, John the Baptist speaks: 'He who sent me to baptize, said to me: On whom you shall see the Spirit descending, and remaining upon him, it is he (John 1:33)'." } For it would never be proper in Christ what is added, and remaining in him, unless sometimes it would depart from others. Otherwise, God speaks to Moses: I will take away from the spirit that is in you (Num. XI, 17): which certainly he would not have, unless it descended to him from the Lord. But the prophecy of this whole chapter is against mount Seir, namely the sons of Esau and Edom, who are called Idumeans in Greek and in our language, because in a time of necessity and distress, when Judah was being captured by the Babylonians, they insulted them and they thought that the land was handed over to them to possess, and not only did they not receive their brothers, namely the sons of Jacob, but they persecuted them and they delivered them into the hands of the sword. Where Symmachus has interpreted more clearly: You have hated your own blood, and blood will persecute you. However, it is prophesied that he himself will be captured and brought into eternal solitude, and at the end of things, he will recognize that God is the judge, because he has said: There are two nations and two regions that belong to me; either the Edomites and the Jews, or certainly the Jews and the Israelites, specifically the twelve tribes. And you have spoken concerning the mountains of Israel, saying: Desolate places have been given to us to devour, not realizing that this blasphemy was against God. And it follows: Let all the earth rejoice, I will bring you into solitude. And the meaning is: when all the earth of Judaea will have received its former state, you will remain in eternal solitude. And what is implied: Just as you rejoiced over the inheritance of the house of Israel, because it had been scattered, so I will do to you. In the LXX it is not included, but it is added with asterisks from Theodotion's edition. But all the wrath of God advances there against the mountain of Seir, so that when it is scattered, both it and all of Edom may know that he is the Lord. I have said these things quickly according to the history and the meaning rather than the words. I will move on to anagoge and, in the interest of brevity, I will briefly touch on a few points. Put, he says, or turn your face towards Mount Seir. And significantly he says, turn, from one prophecy to another prophecy. But it is not the face of the body, but of the soul, about which the Apostle says: But we all, with unveiled face, beholding as in a mirror the glory of the Lord (II Cor. III, 18). But Mount Seir, which means rough and hairy, should be understood in a negative sense, as it presided over the people of the sons of Esau, and stood against the people of Judah, that is, the confession and true faith. But if a wise reader opposes this, how Seir, that is, rough and hairy, can be understood in a negative sense, since Elijah was also called a hairy man (2 Kings 1): I will briefly answer, it is written of Esau that he was red, and like a hairy skin (Genesis 25): but of Elijah, that he was only a hairy man. In Esau, who was bloodthirsty and violent, he is compared to the roughness of a hairy skin, which is a sign of human works and of his own death; in Elijah, it is an indication of manliness. Therefore, his dwelling in solitude and his austere way of life demonstrated not only a man, but a very strong man. Furthermore, Jacob, who had supplanted Esau and received his birthright (Genesis, X), is called light and polished because he simply lived at home and was not a hunter like the giant Nimrod. Therefore let us see what God commands to be said to the mountain, or against the mountain of Seir. Behold, I will not send Angels to you, O mountain of Seir, nor will I make use of ministers, but I myself will come to you, and I will stretch out my hand upon you, and I will assume the appearance of one striking, and I will make you desolate and deserted, who were dwelt in wickedly, and had many partners in your impiety, to the extent that you even built cities and claimed them as your own empire. Now, when you are desolate with your cities, which Jeremiah is ordered to destroy and uncover (Jerem. I, LI), in that you will succeed in building good cities in their place, you will know that I am the Lord, whom you could not know before your solitude. But the whole cause of sin is that you have been an eternal enemy. Hence the psalm says, 'Be angry and do not sin' (Psalm 4:5), so that we may quickly reconcile with our enemies and turn hatred into love. However, Seir is not such a mountain that encloses eternal enmities or besieges the children of Israel with deceit and the sword in hand. From this we understand that whoever takes up the sword against the children of God, acts deceitfully, besieges them, shall be handed over to the sword, just as Seir did in times of extreme wickedness, when the days are evil and the world is placed in the hands of the wicked (1 John 5), and with the increase of wickedness, the love of many grows cold. But there is another sin of Mount Seir: that because he hated the blood of the just, which he desired to shed in every persecution, he himself suffers persecution from that blood. And so the souls under the altar of the saints cry out and implore vengeance from the Lord for their blood (Apoc. VI). And they are taken away from Mount Seir, going and returning, that is, every inhabitant, whether men or animals that are saved in the Church, of whom it is written: You will save men and animals, O Lord (Psal. XXXV, 5). What is destroyed on Mount Seir is both those who seem to have some reason; and those who are content with simple faith, at God's command, may perish. And his mountains are filled with the wounded and the slain. And not only the mountains, which have reached the peak of impiety: but also the hills, which are the lower disciples of Mount Seir, and the valleys that are depressed in the depths, or the torrents, which have turbid waters, collected here and there, coming from pride, or, according to the LXX, the fields (or plains), which are in the middle between hills and valleys. All those who are killed will fall by the sword of the Lord, and his outstretched hand, striking them, so that they may be reduced to eternal desolation; and if they were cities, that is, the meeting places of evil dwellings, let them perish and cease to have a consensus in the wrong direction, and let their languages be divided (Gen. XI), so that they may not be able to build a tower of blasphemy against God; and reduced to desolation and wilderness, let them know that he himself is the Lord. It is not enough to have said so much about Mount Seir, as the previous discourse narrated; but he also spoke this through pride: 'I have two nations, and two lands or regions, namely Idumea and Judaea, and I will possess heretics and the Ecclesiastics equally.' And this, he said, when the Lord was there, who presided over his people. Therefore the Lord swears and says: 'As I live, says the Lord God, I will make myself known to you, and you will know that I have known your reproaches and blasphemies, not from any other person, but from myself, I have heard what you have spoken against the mountains of Israel, saying: 'They have been given to us as a desert to devour.' We must receive the mountains of Israel, Moses, prophets, and apostles, whom heretics and the prince of heretics think they have handed over to devour: when either rarely or not at all is found in the church, who can fight for the mountains of the Lord and defend their tearing with their own voice. And you have risen up, he says, against me with your mouth, whether you have spoken magnificently, not as you think against the mountains, but through them against me, and you have asked (or rather demanded) against me or cried out against me. For all your prayers, O mountain of Seir, and the companions of the mountain of Seir, of which it was said above (above, in the same place): I will fill its mountains, and hills, and valleys, and plains, or torrents, were against me: certainly not prayers and supplications, as you think towards God, but shouts, vociferations, and blasphemies. Therefore, the Lord threatens and says: Just as you rejoiced over the inheritance of the house of Israel, when it was scattered and torn apart by your persecutions and dispersed throughout the whole world: so I will do to you. For the whole earth of the living rejoices, and the land of the saints, and all those converted to the service of God, you will be scattered, O rough mountain, O hairy mountain, and all of Edom, dedicated as they are to earthly works, and given to bloodshed and slaughter, so that you may then know that I am the Lord, who spoke elsewhere: I am the Lord your God.

<h2 id='tocuniq298'>(Cap. XXXVI.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 36, Verses 1 and following) 'And you, son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel, and say: Mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord. Thus says the Lord God: Because the enemy has said of you, 'Aha!' and, 'The ancient heights have become our possession,' therefore prophesy, and say: Thus says the Lord God: Because you have been desolate and crushed on all sides, and become a possession of the rest of the nations, and you have become the talk and evil gossip of the people (or nations).' Therefore, O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God: Thus says the Lord God to the mountains, the hills, the rivers, the valleys, and the desolate and forsaken walls and the cities that have been depopulated and mocked (or trampled) by the remaining nations all around. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Because I have spoken in the fire of my zeal concerning the remaining nations and all of Edom, who have taken possession of my land for themselves with joy (or with a sword), and with all their heart and soul, and have cast it out to devastate (or despise with hatred the souls, to overthrow them in destruction). Therefore he says (( Vulg. he is silent)), prophesy over the land of Israel, and say to the mountains and hills, to the ridges and valleys, thus says the Lord God: Behold, in my zeal and in my fury I have spoken, because you have endured the disgrace (or reproach) of the nations. Therefore thus says the Lord God (or Adonai the Lord): I have lifted (or will lift) my hand, that the nations around you themselves may bear their disgrace (or shame). But you, O mountains of Israel, shall shoot forth your branches and yield your fruit to my people Israel, for they are about to come. For behold, I am for you, and I will turn to you, and you shall be tilled and sown. And I will multiply people on you, the whole house of Israel, all of it. The cities shall be inhabited and the waste places rebuilt. And I will multiply on you man and beast, and they shall multiply and be fruitful. And I will cause you to be inhabited as in your former times, and will do more good to you than ever before. Then you will know that I am the Lord. And I will bring (or generate) upon you, my people Israel, and they shall possess you (or you), and you shall (or you will) become an inheritance, and you shall no longer be without them (or they shall no longer make you childless). Thus says the Lord God: Because they have said of you (or to you), devourer of men and suffocater of your nation: therefore you shall no longer eat men, and you shall no longer kill your nation, says the Lord God: and I will no longer make you (or make you) a hearer of the confusion (or disgrace) of nations, and you shall not bear (or you shall not bear) the reproaches of peoples, and you shall no longer lose your nation (or your nation shall no longer be without children), says the Lord God. Above is set forth the face of the prophet, or rather, he turns towards Mount Seir: here the Son of Man speaks to the mountains, or rather, above the mountains of Israel, which are commanded to hear the word of God. And so that I may delay the allegory for a little while, the brief meaning of all the prophecies concerning the mountains of Israel is this: Because the enemy, that is, Mount Seir, has insulted you and thought that he would possess you forever, and the once lofty heights of the Lord now deserted have become his inheritance, and not only has he said this, but he has also possessed you for some time, to the extent that he spoke arrogantly against you, so that you would be a disgrace to all nations. Therefore, thus says the Lord God, not only to Mount Seir, but also to its mountains and hills, its torrents and valleys, its desolate and devastated places, and its abandoned cities: because of the fire of his jealousy, and indeed against all nations, but particularly against Edom, which, he says, along with the other nations, has possessed my land and possessed it with the sword, and possessed it with all his heart, in order to drive out the inhabitants and lay waste to the land. Therefore, speak, says the prophet, concerning the land of Israel, and you will say to the mountains, and the hills, and the ridges (which in the Septuagint are interpreted as 'wooded places,' which we understand as forested areas) and the valleys. This is what the Lord God says: in my zeal and in my fury, I will be the avenger of your disgrace, and I will raise my hand, so that the nations around you may bear their shame and confusion: but you, O mountains of Israel, will bring forth branches and send out shoots, or as in the Septuagint, produce grapes, with which my people Israel will be satisfied. What you may not think will happen after a long time, is near, imminent, and will come. And so that this does not seem difficult to you, I myself will come to you, and those who have gone away from you will return to you, so that you may reclaim your former culture, and all things may be filled with seed, so that many may be among you, and cities that were previously destroyed may be inhabited. And I will not only multiply men, but also animals will multiply and increase, and I will make you dwell as in the beginning, when Moses led two and a half tribes across the Jordan to take possession, across the Jordan (Num. XXXII), and under Joshua the son of Nun, the other nine and a half tribes possessed the land of Judah (Jos. I, and XIII): and I will give you much greater blessings than you had in the beginning before you experienced various captivities. And when I have done this to you, then you will know that I am the Lord. And you, O land of Israel, will be filled, says the Lord God of My people, who will inherit you. And you will be their possession, and you will no longer be without children. But when your inhabitants multiply, O mountains of Israel, then your enemies will no longer say that you devour men and are without children, but instead you will multiply men, and your posterity will produce a very large offspring. You will no longer hear, he said, nor will you endure the confusion of the nations, but you will not lose your people, so that you may one day endure captivity, because the Lord has spoken. This we will say in a paraphrased manner according to the Jewish custom, which they expect in the kingdom of a thousand years, when they assert that the city of Jerusalem will be rebuilt, and the temple, which is described at the end of this volume, and the happiness of all things, which some believe were fulfilled under Zerubbabel. But how can this be fulfilled, when it is said: 'And I will cause you to dwell as in the beginning, and I will give you greater blessings than you had from the beginning?' For under Zerubbabel, Ezra, and Nehemiah, only a few of the people were restored, and they themselves obeyed the Medes and Persians, and later the Macedonians, Egyptians, and Romans, and served various foreign kings, up to Titus and Vespasian, and continue to serve even now. So it is impossible for the last prophecy to be fulfilled: 'You will no longer bear the reproach of the nations, and you will not lose your people anymore.' And because it is now lengthy to speak against the Jewish teaching and their indulgence in food and drink, who desire everything earthly and say, 'Let us eat and drink,' of whom the Apostle also speaks: 'Food is for the stomach and the stomach for food,' but God will destroy both it and them (I Cor. VI, 13), let us briefly explain: now let us move on to spiritual understanding, according to which we have also interpreted the later parts of Isaiah. For we do not, like the Jews, await a Jerusalem adorned and golden from heaven, which they call the 'second Law', nor will we once again endure the injury of circumcision, nor offer the sacrifices of bulls and rams, nor will we sleep in the leisure of the Sabbath. This is also the belief of many of our people, especially Tertullian's book, titled 'On the Hope of the Faithful', and Lactantius' seventh volume of 'Institutions', as well as the frequent explanations of Victorinus of Pettau, and our recent Severus in a dialogue titled 'To Gallicus'. And in order to mention both Greeks, and the first and the last, [let us speak of] Irenaeus and Apollinarius. 423 So we, the mountains of Israel, will say that the prophets and apostles are those who hear the word of God, and to whom the enemy devil insulted, saying: ‘Well done, once high mountains, about which it is written: “Mountains are around it and the Lord is around his people”’ (Ps. CXXIV, 2). They were given to me as a possession when they were devastated by the narrowness of persecution, trampled around, made an inheritance to the remaining nations, and blasphemed by all. Therefore, the Lord speaks of the mountains and desolate places, not only the mountains, but also the lower places and through each level in the land of Judah, that is, on the mountain of the Church, of which it is written: A city placed on a mountain cannot be hidden (Matth. V, 14); and on hills and valleys, in which faith is increased by the winter of persecutions and the storm of afflictions. Also, in these valleys, which are depressed by humility, and in the deserted Churches and walls, and in the whole world, where the gatherings of Churches are abandoned: such as the persecution was under Diocletian and Maximian in the whole world, by which the Churches were proscribed and devastated: when all the nations of the Gentiles and the heretics mocked the Church around, because it spoke in the fire of its zeal, and specifically against Edom, which wanted to carry the image of the earthly, having set aside the image of the heavenly (I Cor. XV). For they have given the land of God as their inheritance, and with all their heart and soul they have persecuted the Church of the Lord, and have driven it out of its seats, and have laid it waste. But what profit have the nations gained, what benefit have the heathen peoples obtained by insulting the land of the Lord, when the Lord speaks to it, and to its mountains, hills, and ridges, or to the wooded places that were flourishing with the beauty of paradise; and to the hills that we have mentioned above, He has spoken in His zeal and rage, and has lifted His hand against the adversaries who have persecuted the Church, to bring them confusion and disgrace? Then, with the persecutors killed and peace restored to the Church, the mountains of Israel, namely the Apostles and Apostolic men, will produce their trees and extend their branches, bringing forth grapes to be crushed in the winepress of the Lord, from which the must is poured, which will intoxicate the peoples of the believers, and the wine that rejoices the heart of man (Psalm 103): so that all the fruit of the mountains, from which the bread that comes down from heaven is made, may be eaten by the people of God, Israel. And let us not perhaps despair in persecutions, it is added: The time is near for it to come. For he who is coming will come, and will not delay (Habakkuk II, 3). Therefore, he promises his coming to the mountains, and to those who have endured in tribulations, and he promises that after the heat of persecution, the earth, previously harvested by the plow of Christ, will exercise all the virtues and receive the seed from which men and the whole house of Israel will be born and multiplied. And when the cities, that is, the Churches of the believers, were inhabited again by returning crowds, then not only men who were knowledgeable in Scriptures, but also animals and the simple believers will multiply and grow, and the Churches will be inhabited as in the beginning, that is, before the persecution existed, and they will flourish with greater goods than they had from the beginning, adorned with the victories of martyrs. And then they will know that He is the Lord, who restores His people to their former state, that they may possess the Churches, and that the Churches themselves may be the inheritance of the Church, and no longer without children, whom they had lost in persecution. Therefore, the prophet is commanded to speak to the land of the meek, the land of the living, or to the mountains of Israel, and to say: You shall no longer suffer the reproach of the persecutors, nor shall they insult your slain people, as though they were sheep for slaughter. For with peace restored, all disgrace shall cease, nor shall you endure confusion and shame among the various circuitings, but you shall have your nation and your people, for the truth of the promise, as spoken by the Lord, is confirmed.

<h2 id='tocuniq299'>(Vers. 16 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 16 onwards) And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, the house of Israel have dwelt (or dwells) in their own land and have defiled it with their ways and their idols. Their ways have become unclean before me, like the uncleanness of a woman during her menstrual period. And I poured out my fury (or anger) upon them, because of the blood they had shed on the land. They defiled it with their idols, and I scattered them among the nations and dispersed them in various countries (or regions) according to their ways. I judged them for their sins, 425 and they entered the nations where they had gone and defiled my holy name, so that it was said of them, 'This is the people of the Lord, and they have come out of his land.' And I spared my holy name (or I spared them for the sake of my holy name) which the house of Israel had defiled among the nations they entered. Therefore, say to the house of Israel, thus says the Lord God: It is not for your sake, house of Israel, that I will act, but for the sake of my holy name, which you have defiled among the nations where you have entered. And I will sanctify my great name, which has been defiled among the nations, which you have defiled in their midst, so that they may know (Vulg. adds nations) that I am the Lord, says the Lord of hosts, when I have been sanctified in you before their eyes. For I will take you from among the nations, and gather you out of all countries, and will bring you into your own land. And I will sprinkle clean water upon you, and you shall be cleansed from all your filthiness, and I will cleanse you from all your idols. And I will give you a new heart, and a new spirit I will put within you, and I will take away the stony heart out of your flesh, and I will give you a heart of flesh. And I will put my spirit in the midst of you (or give it to you), and I will cause you to walk in my statutes (or my justifications), and you shall keep my judgments, and do them (or make them) (Vulg. is silent about them). And you shall dwell in the land that I gave to your fathers, and you shall be my people, and I will be your God. And I will save you (or I will make you safe) from all your uncleanness (or impurities), and I will call for the grain, and multiply it, and I will not give you hunger, and I will multiply the fruit of the tree, and the increase of the field, so that you will no longer bear the reproach of famine among the nations. And you shall remember your evil ways, and your doings that were not good, and shall loathe yourselves in your own sight for your iniquities and for your abominations. Not for your sakes do I this, saith the Lord God, be it known unto you: be ashamed and confounded for your own ways, O house of Israel. Thus saith the Lord God; In the day that I shall have cleansed you from all your iniquities I will also cause you to dwell in the cities, and the wastes shall be builded. And the desolate land shall be tilled, whereas it lay desolate in the sight of all that passed by. And they shall say, This land that was desolate is become like the garden of Eden; and the waste and desolate and ruined cities are become fenced, and are inhabited. And the nations shall know that have been left around you, that I the Lord have built the things that were destroyed, and have planted the things that were desolate: I the Lord have spoken, and I will do it. Thus saith the Lord God: Moreover in this shall the house of Israel find me, that I will do it for them: I will multiply them as a flock of men (or as holy sheep), as a flock of holy sheep, as the flock of Jerusalem in her solemn feasts: so shall the desolate cities be filled with flocks of men (or sheep), and they shall know that I am the Lord. The things that are spoken are clear, and all the senses of the mountains of Israel, which were previously deserted and later restored, are now placed more clearly. And God gives reasons why he delivered the people of Israel into captivity, and promises, because of his mercy, to bring them back to the land of Judah and to give them much greater things than he had taken away. Some Jews attribute this to the times of Zerubbabel, when, with Cyrus, the king of the Persians loosening their captivity, many from the tribe of Judah and Benjamin were brought back to Judah. But others refer to a kingdom of a thousand years, when under Christ, whom they believe is to come, the city of Jerusalem will be built, and the temple erected, of which we will speak in the final part of this prophecy. And meanwhile, leaving aside the Jewish fables and endless genealogies, according to our custom, let us briefly go through the summary of this chapter, and discuss what it seems to us, according to ecclesiastical understanding. The house of Israel, that is, the people of the Jews, once dwelt in their land, that is, in the land of Judea, when they were brought out of Egypt; but they defiled it with their ways and their pursuits, or their idols, and they became so polluted that they were compared to the uncleanness of a menstruating woman. Because of this, God poured out his wrath upon them, for the blood of the prophets and the righteous, which they had shed upon the earth, as the Savior said in the Gospel: 'Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those who are sent to you' (Matthew 23:37). And again (V. 35): Amen, amen I say to you: the blood of Abel the just shall be required of this generation, from the blood of Abel unto the blood of Zacharias, who was slain between the altar and the temple. Yea I say to you, all these things shall come upon this generation. O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets and stonest them that are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered together thy children, as the hen doth gather her chickens under her wings, and thou wouldest not? Behold, your house shall be left to you, desolate (Matt. 23). When I saw this, he said, I spared them not for their sake, but for the sake of my holy name (for I am the Creator of all) and I sanctified them and restored them to their former glory, so that I could pour out the clean water of saving Baptism upon believers and those converted from error, and cleanse them from their abominations and from all the errors with which they were occupied, and give them a new heart, that they may believe in the Son of God, and a new spirit, of which David speaks: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me (Psalm 51:10). And it should be considered that a new heart and a new spirit is given through the pouring and sprinkling of water. But when the new heart and new spirit are given, then all hardness, which is compared to stone, will be removed from the Jewish heart, so that the heart may be like flesh, soft and tender, able to receive the spirit of God within itself, and to be inscribed with healing words. Then they will walk in the commandments of the Lord, and keep His judgments, and dwell in the land of confession, which He had given to their fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and to all the holy ones and prophets, and they will be a people of God, and the Lord will be their God, which is proven in the present time. And when they are saved, the Lord will call forth the grain and multiply it. For unless a grain of wheat falls into the ground and dies, it remains alone (John 12:24). And they will not tolerate hunger, not hunger for bread and thirst for water, but hunger to hear the word of God, which he endured, who came forth from the Father, and wasted all the substance he had received: when a pressing need for hunger, he fed on the husks of swine (Luke 15). Then the fruit of the tree, that is, wisdom, will be multiplied, of which it is written: The tree of life is for all who seek it (Prov. III, 18); and the produce of the field will be like Jacob, whose scent was like the scent of a full field, whom the Lord blessed (Genes. XXVII, 27). They will no longer bear the reproach of famine among the nations, which the incredulity of the Jews suffers today. But once they have attained blessedness, they will imitate the Apostle who says: I am not worthy to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God (I Cor. XV, 9). And they will remember their worst ways and their ungood studies, by which they offended God. And their iniquities and their crimes, by which they previously erred, will displease them. But the Lord will attribute all these things, not for those who perished by their own error, but for the sake of his holy name. Therefore, he provokes the house of Israel to be confused and ashamed about their previous faults, and to understand their Creator. But after he has cleansed the people who believe from their sins and has caused the cities of the Church to be inhabited and has restored the ruins which had fallen in the synagogues, and the land of confession has been cultivated with the ceremonies of God, which once appeared desolate to all the holy ones who pass by the works of earthly conversation: then all will say, How is it that the land of Judah, which was once uncultivated, now has the likeness of the paradise of God; and the cities of Judah, which were deserted and deprived, and buried in their disbelief, are now upright and fortified in confession, and in the name of the Lord, the Savior? So that every creature may know, and the multitudes of angels that surround the land of Israel, that the Lord has rebuilt the cities that were laid waste, and has planted the uncultivated regions, and has fulfilled what he had promised through the prophets. And this will not be the extent of his generosity towards the people he has saved, but he will bestow far greater things. For there will be found among the house of Israel one who had been sought for a long time, and had not been found. And after he finds them, he will multiply them like sheep: not of brute animals, but of the sheep of men, which are full of reason and confession, like holy sheep and flocks of Jerusalem, in which proper worship of God and the vision of peace are, in its solemnities, when we eat the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth (1 Cor. 5), and we feed on the flesh of the Lamb and drink his blood, and in the seven weeks, and in the tabernacles of this world, we celebrate the Lord's Day, so that once deserted cities may be filled with flocks of men, and by this means they may know that he himself is the Lord, who has provided all things. According to the truth of history, or rather according to the faith of prophecy: how the people of Israel will be restored to their original state, and the remnant of the people of Judah will be saved in the Apostle Paul, and in all those who believed in the beginning from the Jews, and even today return to the Church, it is enough to say briefly. Now the same sense must be opened in the same brevity of tropology. Whoever is from the house of Israel, and sees the peace of Christ, which surpasses all understanding, dwells in his own land, that is, the Church, or in the lodging of the flesh, which was given to him by God. But if he pollutes both lands with his wicked ways, and is compared to the impurity of a menstruating woman: God will pour out his anger upon him, for the blood, either his own or that of those he has scandalized, and will pour it out upon the land, and with the perverse thoughts with which he has polluted it. Then he will be scattered among the nations, to be leveled with unbelievers, and will be winnowed in the land like chaff, to be separated from the wheat of the Church, and will be judged according to his ways. But if they do not recognize their sin in this way, but defile his holy name, then all those among whom he has lived will say: Behold the people of God, behold one who has come out of his land, indeed one who has been cast out. But if they repent and I am sanctified in their midst, then every multitude of the Gentiles will know that I will take them from the lands in which they were dispersed and bring them back to the land of the Church, and I will pour out upon them not the waters of saving Baptism, but the waters of doctrine and the word of God; and I will cleanse them from all their iniquities and from all the idols and errors they had simulated in their deceitful heart. And I will give them a new heart, which they had lost through sin, and I will renew the right spirit within their hearts. And I will remove their heart of stone, the unbelieving heart; and I will give them a heart of flesh, soft and tender; so that they may receive God's commandments; so that they may walk in my commandments and observe my judgments; which they had previously neglected, and they shall dwell in the land which I had given to their fathers, namely, the land of their masters and teachers; and once again they shall be the people of God, and the Lord shall turn to them as their God, whom they had previously offended. Then they will be saved from all their defilements, and their grain will multiply, from which heavenly bread is made; and they will no longer endure hunger for the word of God; and the tree of wisdom will multiply among them, and their chests will be filled with offspring. They will no longer be a reproach among the nations; but after God has shown them mercy, they will remember their worst ways, and they will know where they have been, and they will be displeased with their iniquities. What the Lord says, he does not do for them, but for his own mercy. Therefore, he encourages the wanderers to be confused and ashamed in their ways, and to return to the cities of the Church, which will once again be inhabited by them, and to rebuild everything that has been destroyed in them. They should return to their previous ceremonies, and the land, which was once deserted and seen as desolate by both residents and foreigners passing through, should return to its former state. And everyone will marvel and say: 'Once a barren land, a deserted land, in which all virtues perished, now it has become like a garden of pleasure and the paradise of God.' And the once deserted cities, which did not have God as their guest and were deprived of the Holy Spirit, and were buried in unbelief, will be fortified by the faith of Christ, so that all around may know that the Lord has built up scattered souls, planted in them, and nurtured the trees of all virtues. And he himself will fulfill the things he promised with his words. And again, the prophetic discourse exhorts the penitents, that even when they have returned to the Church, they always seek the Lord, and find Him: so that the flocks of those returning may multiply, not of beasts and brute animals, but flocks of men, who are full of faith and reason, holy flocks, flocks of the city of Jerusalem, in all the solemnities which the mercy of God has received; so that after the multitude of such flocks has filled the cities of the Lord, then all may know that He is the Lord.


<h2 id='tocuniq300'>(Cap. XXXVII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 37, Verses 1 and following) In 431, the hand of the Lord came upon me, and He led me in the Spirit of the Lord and placed me in the middle of a field that was full of bones. He guided me around and around among them. There were many bones lying on the surface of the land, and they were very dry. Then He asked me, 'Son of man, can these bones live?' And I replied, 'O Lord God, You alone know the answer to that.' Then He said to me, 'Prophesy to these bones and say to them, 'Dry bones, listen to the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord God says to these bones: I will make breath enter you, and you will come to life. I will attach tendons to you and make flesh grow on you and cover you with skin. I will put breath in you, and you will come to life. Then you will know that I am the Lord.' And I prophesied as He commanded me: and there was a noise and behold a commotion and the bones came together, each one to its joint. And I saw, and behold, upon them there were sinews, and flesh came up, and skin was stretched out over them above, but there was no breath in them. And He said to me: Prophesy to the spirit, prophesy, son of man, and say to the spirit: Thus says the Lord God: Come from the four winds, O spirit, and breathe upon these slain, that they may live. And I prophesied as he commanded me, and the spirit came into them, and they lived: and there stood up upon their feet an exceeding great army. Then he said unto me, Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel: behold, they say, Our bones are dried, and our hope is lost: we are cut off for our parts. Therefore prophesy and say unto them, Thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, O my people, I will open your graves, and cause you to come up out of your graves, and bring you into the land of Israel. And ye shall know that I am the LORD, when I have opened your graves, O my people, and brought you up out of your graves, And shall put my spirit in you, and ye shall live, and I shall place you in your own land: then shall ye know that I the LORD have spoken it, and performed it, saith the LORD. LXX: And the hand of the Lord came upon me, and he led me out in the spirit of the Lord, and he set me down in the middle of a field, and it was full of human bones. And he led me around among them, and behold, there were very many on the surface of the field, and they were very dry. And he said to me, 'Son of man, can these bones live?' And I answered, 'O Lord God, you know.' Then he said to me, 'Prophesy over these bones, and say to them, O dry bones, hear the word of the Lord. Thus says the Lord God to these bones: 432 Behold, I will bring upon you the breath of life, and I will lay sinews upon you, and will cause flesh to come upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and you shall live, and you shall know that I am the Lord.' And I prophesied as he commanded me: and there was a voice when I prophesied, and behold a commotion: and the bones came together, bone to his bone. And I saw, and behold the sinews and the flesh came up upon them: and the skin stretched out over them, but there was no spirit in them. And he said to me: Prophesy to the spirit, prophesy, O son of man, and say to the spirit: Thus saith the Lord God: Come, spirit, from the four winds, and blow upon these slain, and let them live. And I prophesied as He commanded me, and the spirit entered into them, and they lived and stood up upon their feet: an exceeding great army. Then He said unto me, Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel: behold, they say, Our bones are dried, and our hope is lost: we are cut off for our parts. Therefore prophesy and say unto them, Thus saith the Lord God; Behold, O my people, I will open your graves, and cause you to come up out of your graves, and bring you into the land of Israel. And ye shall know that I am the Lord, when I have opened your graves, O my people, and brought you up out of your graves, And shall put my spirit in you, and ye shall live, and I shall place you in your own land: then shall ye know that I the Lord have spoken it, and performed it, saith the Lord God. The vision is famous and celebrated by the reading of all the Churches of Christ; for this very reason I have placed both editions in their entirety, so that no false accusation may be made against us by the Hebrews, if, at least, there may be any discrepancy in the words. For they are accustomed to laugh at us, and to raise their eyebrows and to belch out a knowledge of the Scriptures with inflated cheeks, if I may not say a disagreement of meanings (which, if there is, is rightly condemned), if they are able to demonstrate any dissonance of words in our books. Those who believe in the resurrection, which is believed by both Jews and Christians to be a word of God, often say the following: 'The hand of the Lord has come upon the prophet,' that is, the Lord and Savior through whom the Father has done all things. For all things were made through him, and without him, nothing that was made exists. And he said, 'The spirit of the Lord lifted me up,' and it is understood that it was the hand of the Lord. But he was lifted up in the spirit, not in the body, but outside of the body, and he was placed, or rather, sent in the middle of a field that was full of human bones. Rest was not allowed for him, but he made all the bones go around, which were not covered by the ground but were lying on the field. And there were not just a few, but very many, and due to their age, they were extremely dry and had no moisture in them. And when the divine word had asked him whether he believed that these bones could live, he answered: Lord God, you know, who possess full knowledge of things to come. And the Lord said to him: Prophesy concerning these bones, and say to them: Dry bones, hear the word of the Lord. It is truly amazing how he spoke to dry bones, which before had no nerves, flesh, skin, or life-giving spirit from God, and they were able to hear the word. And first the bones are bound together with the ligaments of the nerves; then they are filled with flesh, and above that the skin is stretched out for beauty, which covers the ugliness of the exposed flesh; and then they receive a spirit, which makes them alive, and after they have lived, then they know that He is the Lord. Thus, as the prophet had commanded, there was immediately a shaking, and the bones were joined together, bound with nerves, filled with flesh, covered with skin; and human bodies lay there without breath. Therefore, the prophet prophesies concerning the spirit, and says: Thus says the Lord God: Come, spirit, from the four winds, that is, from the four corners of the world, so that just as in the first creation of man, God breathed into his face and he became a living soul (Gen. 2:7), so also in the second creation, that is, the resurrection of the dead, by the breath of the spirit, may they be made alive; those who entered human bodies immediately lived and stood on their feet. And the resurrection of the dead is called a gathering, or the Church of many (Psalm 103:30), and as it is stated in Hebrew, a great army; and it is fulfilled in time: Send forth Your spirit, and they shall be created, and You shall renew the face of the earth. But what follows: And He said to me: Son of man, these bones are the whole house of Israel, seems to raise a question, because it is not about the general resurrection, but specifically about the resurrection of the house of Israel, which says: Our bones are dried up, and our hope is lost, and we are completely cut off. With those saying these things, Ezekiel is compelled to prophesy a third time, and to say to the dry bones: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will open your graves. In which it is asked: If he opens the tombs, how did he say before: There were indeed many things over the face of the field, and very dry. And I will bring you out of your tombs, my people, according to that which is written in the Gospel: The hour is coming; when those who are in the tombs will hear the voice of the Son of God, and they will come forth who have done good to the resurrection of life (John 5:28-29). And again: Those who have heard will live (Ibid.). And if, as some believe, the divine discourse speaks of the general resurrection, why was it necessary to say specifically: And I will bring you into the land of Israel, when the dead should rise from all parts of the world in which they were buried? And when, he says, I bring you out of your tombs, and I give my spirit in you, and you live, then I will make you rest upon your own soil; so that after you have rested in the land of Israel, then you may know that I am the Lord, who has fulfilled my promises by my actions. Therefore, when they understand these things about the general resurrection, that which seems to pose a question is this: 'These bones are the whole house of Israel; they refer to the resurrection of the saints, of which the Apostle John also speaks in the Apocalypse: Blessed and holy is he who has a part in the first resurrection; over him, the second death has no power.' (Rev. 20:6) This clearly indicates that there is a different resurrection for the saints and a different one for the sinners. And in the first psalm it is said: The wicked do not rise in judgment, nor sinners in the council of the just. But the land of Israel, which the Lord promises to those who rise, they confirm to be that about which it is written: Blessed are the meek, for they shall possess the land. (Matt. 5:4). And: I will please the Lord in the land of the living (Ps. 114:9). These things are spoken by those who assume that Ezekiel wrote about the general resurrection, as we have said. But those who interpret in this way should not cause us envy, because by interpreting this passage differently, we seemed to deny the resurrection. For we know that there are much stronger testimonies, in which there is no doubt, found in the Holy Scriptures, such as this from Job: 'You will raise up (or 'raise me up') my flesh, which supports all this' (Job 19). And in Daniel: 'Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth will rise, some to everlasting life, and some to shame, and everlasting contempt' (Daniel 12:2). And in the Gospel: Do not fear those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul; rather fear him who can destroy both soul and body in hell (Matt. X, 28). And the apostle Paul: He who will give life to your mortal bodies because of his Spirit dwelling in you (Rom. VIII, 11), and many others. From which it is clear that we do not deny the resurrection, but we do not contend with these unwritten things about the resurrection, and through the parable of the resurrection, it is prophesied about the restoration of Israel, which was captive in Babylon at that time. And we will not immediately give occasion to heretics, if we deny that these things are understood of the common resurrection.
