For the likeness of the resurrection is never set forth to signify the restoration of the Israelitish people, unless the resurrection itself be valid and future belief secured; because no one confirms uncertainties concerning things that do not exist. And our whole assertion tends to this, that just as it seems incredible that a resurrection should be promised to bones that are dry and consumed with age, yet what is promised will certainly come to pass; so the restoration also of the people of Israel, who were led into captivity and are scattered throughout the whole world, seems indeed incredible to those who do not know the power of God, yet it will come to pass; because, says He, 'I am the Lord; I have spoken, and I will do as I have promised.' Finally, in the earlier prophecy, in which the ancient status of Israel is promised on the mountains, the Lord says to them: And I will turn to you and you shall be tilled and sown, and I will multiply men upon you, all the house of Israel (Ezekiel 36:9-10): and again, that the house of Israel will dwell in its own land, which was once uncultivated, but will become like a garden of delight, and the deserted and destitute cities will be fortified; and the house of Israel will multiply in them, like a flock of sheep, and other things that pertain to the same meaning, which is now said figuratively and metaphorically of dry bones, and those who have no moisture of life, fulfilling what is written in the Gospel: What is impossible with men is possible with God (Matthew 19:26). But all these things confirm the Jews, either under Zerubbabel, as I said before, when a great commotion occurred; and the kingdom of the Chaldeans was transferred to the Medes and Persians: or in the presence of their Christ, whom they believe is to come. But we, spiritually, after the completion of the Lord Savior's cross, commemorate; and daily this happens, especially to those who, like Lazarus, are bound by the bands of their sins, are raised up at the voice of the Lord (John 11); and they truly are the house of Israel, once desolate, and having no hope of salvation: but when the spirit of grace enters into themselves, and the Lord stretches out his hand, they are liberated from the depths of hell: and those who previously said, 'Lord God, you know these things,' afterwards hear, being delivered: 'O you of little faith, why did you doubt?' (Matthew 14:31).


<h2 id='tocuniq301'>(Vers. 15, seq.)</h2>

(Verse 15, onward) 'And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: And you, son of man, take for yourself one piece of wood and write on it 'Judah' and the children of Israel, his companions, and take another piece of wood and write on it 'Joseph,' the wood of Ephraim, and all the house of Israel, his companions. And join them together as one piece of wood in your hand. But when the children of your people speak to you, saying: Will you not tell us what you mean by these?' You shall speak to them: thus says the Lord God: Behold, I will take the wood of Joseph, which is in the hand of Ephraim, and the tribes of Israel, which are joined to him: and I will give them together with the wood of Juda, and I will make them one wood: and they shall be one in my hand. And the woods upon which thou hast written shall be in thy hand before their eyes: and thou shalt say to them: Thus saith the Lord God: Behold, I will take the children of Israel from the midst of the nations, whither they are gone: and I will gather them on every side, and will bring them to their own land. And I will make them one nation in the land on the mountains of Israel, and one king shall be king over them all. And there shall no longer be two nations, nor shall they be divided into two kingdoms any more; neither shall they defile themselves any more with their idols, and with their abominations, and with all their iniquities. And I will save them out of all their dwellingplaces, wherein they have sinned, and will cleanse them: and they shall be my people, and I will be their God. And my servant David shall be king over them; and they all shall have one shepherd: they shall also walk in my judgments, and observe my statutes, and do them. And they shall dwell upon the land which I have given to my servant Jacob, where your fathers have dwelt, and they shall dwell upon it, they and their children, and their children's children, forever. And my servant David shall be their prince forever. And I will establish a covenant of peace with them; it shall be an everlasting covenant with them, and I will bless them and multiply them, and I will put my sanctuary in their midst forever. And my tabernacle shall be with them, and I will be their God, and they shall be my people. And the nations shall know that I am the Lord who sanctifies Israel, when my sanctification is in their midst forever. LXX: And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: And you, son of man, take for yourself one staff, and write on it: Judah, and the children of Israel who are associated with him. And take for yourself another staff, and write on it: Joseph, the staff of Ephraim and all the children of Israel who are associated with him, and join them together in one staff for yourself, so that you may connect them, and they shall be in your hand. And it shall come to pass, when the children of Israel shall say unto thee, Wilt thou not shew us what thou meanest by these? And thou shalt say unto them, Thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, I will take the stick of Joseph, which is in the hand of Ephraim, and the tribes of Israel his fellows, and will put them with him, even with the stick of Judah, and make them one stick, and they shall be one in mine hand. And the sticks whereon thou writest shall be in thine hand before their eyes. And say unto them, Thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, I will take the children of Israel from among the heathen, whither they be gone, and will gather them on every side, and bring them into their own land: And I will make them one nation in the land upon the mountains of Israel; and one king shall be king to them all. And they shall no longer be divided into two nations, nor shall they be divided into two kingdoms, so that they may no longer defile themselves with their idols and their stumbling blocks, and with all their abominations. And I will deliver them from all their iniquities, in which they have sinned, and I will cleanse them and they shall be to me a people, and I will be to them a God. And my servant David shall be their prince in the midst of them, and there shall be one shepherd for all them, because they shall walk in my commandments and keep my judgments, and do them. And they shall dwell in the land that I gave to my servant Jacob, where their fathers dwelt, and they shall dwell in it, they and their children, and their children’s children, for ever: and my servant David shall be their prince for ever. And I will make a covenant of peace with them; it shall be an everlasting covenant with them: and I will establish them, and multiply them, and will set my sanctuary in the midst of them for evermore. And my tabernacle shall be with them: and I will be their God, and they shall be my people. And the nations shall know that I am the Lord who sanctifies you, when my sanctuaries are in their midst forever." (Ezekiel 37) The history of the Kings (3 Kings 12) tells that under Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, the twelve tribes were divided, and two, namely Judah and Benjamin, followed Rehoboam, who reigned in Jerusalem, and his kingdom was called Judah. But the other ten tribes, who said, "We have no portion in David, nor inheritance in the son of Jesse," submitted their necks and served Jeroboam, the son of Nebat from the tribe of Ephraim, who was the son of Joseph. They were mostly called the people of old by the name of Israel. And for a long time, the kingdom of Judah and Israel had strife against each other and obeyed their own kings (4 Kings 25). And the first ten tribes were captured by the Assyrians, and after some time, those who were called Judah were taken captive by the Chaldeans and brought into Babylon, and the tribe of Judah was restored to the ancient land after seventy years. But the ten tribes that were called Israel still serve as captives in the mountains and cities of Media to this day (4 Kings 25). Therefore, the present prophecy promises from the mouth of the Lord that both kingdoms, that is, the kingdom of Judah and the kingdom of Israel, will be joined together; and the scepter of Ephraim, who is descended from the line of Joseph, will be taken away, along with the other tribes that are united with him, and be joined to the scepter of Judah, so that they are not called Judah and Israel, but are called Judah by one name; and under the figure of the prophet who precedes in the type of the Lord Savior, they are held not with two hands, but with the one hand of Christ. For he says that he will gather the children of Israel from among the nations to which they were carried captive, and will bring them back to the land and mountains of Israel, of which we have read above; and that he will call them one nation, to be ruled by one king; so that they may no longer defile themselves with idols and their abominations, but when they have been freed from the seats of captivity in which they have sinned, they may be cleansed from all their vices and become the people of God, so that the Lord may be their God. And the servant, he said, David, my king, will reign over them (Luke I). Concerning whom the Angel speaks in the Gospel, that he will reign over the house of Jacob, and his kingdom will have no end: and his mercy will be so great that he will be called not only king, but also shepherd, because he softens the proud name of emperor with the name of shepherd. After they have become one nation, and have dwelt in the land of Israel and the mountains, they will walk in all the judgments of the Lord and keep his commandments; but they will not dwell in any other land, but in the one that he gave to his servant Jacob, in which their fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and the rest of the saints lived, and not only will they themselves dwell there, but also their sons and grandsons, according to that passage from Virgil (Aeneid, Book IV):

And of the sons who will be born from them; and let them dwell not for a short time, but forever. But you want to know, he says, who this king and shepherd is? He is the one of whom I have spoken before, my servant David. Though he was in the form of God, he did not consider equality with God something to be grasped; but he emptied himself, taking the form of a slave, and became obedient to the Father unto death, even death on a cross (Philippians 2:6-8). And when they are under such a king, I will make a covenant of peace with them, not like in the Old Testament of strife and wars, but a covenant of peace that surpasses all understanding, of which the Savior speaks to the Apostles: My peace I give to you, my peace I leave with you (John 14:27). And the prophet says: His dwelling place is in peace (Psalm 76:2). When he has established and strengthened them in the Church, so that they can say: He set my feet upon a rock (Psalm 40:3), then they will increase either in number of believers or in the multiplication of virtues. And I will give, he says, my sanctification, or sanctuary among them forever, which the Jews interpret as the temple that was built by Zerubbabel. But how can this be fulfilled, when that temple that was built by Zerubbabel and later restored by many was burned by the Roman fire? All of these things must be referred to the Church and to the times of the Savior, when his tabernacle was placed in the Church: where he became our God, and we became his people. And the progress of all is that they may know that He Himself is the Lord and He Himself sanctifies Israel, not according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit. When His sanctification was made in the midst of the believers forever. But when the Lord rejected the tribe of Ephraim and chose the tribe of Judah, and in the Psalms we read, in which it is written: And He rejected the tent of Joseph and did not choose the tribe of Ephraim; but He chose the tribe of Judah (Ps. LXXVII, 67, 68), of which it is written: The prince shall not fail from Judah, nor a ruler from his thighs, until He comes to whom it is reserved, and He shall be the expectation of the nations (Gen. XLIX, 10). For truly in the coming of the Savior Lord, two rods, and as it is written in Hebrew, two pieces of wood are joined together in one scepter, and in the baptism of Christ they are formerly separated and united: so that they may become one new man, and one nation, neither polluted any longer with idols and abominations; but may be the people of God, and Christ shall rule over them, and they shall dwell upon the gentle earth, the land of the living, which he had given to his servant Jacob, who supplanted the people of Israel in the womb of their mother. But if we wish to understand according to the prophecy of Hosea, which is directed almost entirely to the ten tribes, that is, to Joseph and Ephraim, and Samaria, and Israel, the false knowledge of the name, and the various heretical sects, we shall say this: in the last time, when the fullness of the Gentiles has entered, and all Israel has been saved (Rom. 11), then also the adversaries of the people, who have fought against the house of Judah and the confession of the Church, shall submit to the Church's faith, and abandoning all errors and the princes of this world who are destroyed, and their patriarchs, who have led them into the abyss of blasphemies, shall arise and forsake their idols and abominations, which they have devised in their hearts, and from all the places where they have sinned, they shall pass over to the Church's faith, and be cleansed, and be the people of Christ, and He shall be their God: these things I know that the prophet Hosea has spoken more fully. But if the Jews and the Christians who Judaize wish to refer this to a thousand years, they are compelled by necessity to undertake all these things: to receive all those who will be saved and to dwell in the land of Israel, to build Jerusalem, to construct the temple, to perform all the ceremonies of the Law, to observe the Sabbath, to accept the injury of circumcision, to eat and drink, and to consider abundance of wealth as the highest blessedness and as the measure of all resources. Yet the Apostle says: Food is for the stomach, and the stomach is for food; and God will destroy both one and the other (1 Corinthians 6:13). But just as in the type of the resurrection the superior prophetic sermon demonstrated the resurrection of the Jewish people, not carnal but spiritual: so this prophecy pertains not at all to the flesh but to the happiness of the soul, and to the faith of Christ, by which we are cleansed in baptism, whose kingdom is everlasting, so that we do not expect things that have already happened, and we know that they are transacted daily.

<h2 id='tocuniq302'>(Cap. XXXVIII.)</h2>

(Chapter XXXVIII.) \"And the word of the Lord came to me, saying: Son of man, set your face against Gog, the land of Magog, the chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, and prophesy against him. And you shall say to him: Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, O Gog, chief prince of Meshech and Tubal, and I will turn you around and put hooks into your jaws, and I will bring you out, and all your army, horses and horsemen, all of them clothed in full armor, a great multitude with bucklers and shields, wielding swords: Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya, all of them with shield and helmet; Gomer and all its troops; the house of Togarmah from the far north and all its troops, and many peoples with you.\ Prepare and equip yourself, and all your multitude that has gathered to you, and be a commandment to them (or and you will be for me a custody). After many days you will be visited: in the last ((or last)) years you will come to the land that has turned (or perverted) by the sword: and it has gathered from many peoples to the mountain ((or mountains)) (or land) of Israel, who have been desert always: this has been brought out from the peoples and all will confidently dwell [or have dwelt] in it. But when you come like a storm, and like a cloud, to cover the earth you and all your armies, and many peoples (or nations) with you. Thus says the Lord God: On that day, thoughts will rise up in your heart, etcogitabis cogitationem pessimam, et dices: Ascendam ad terram (sive super terram) absque muro (sive abjectam): veniam ad quiescentes habitantesque secure (sive in pace): omnes ((Vulg. addit hi)) habitant sine muro, vectes et portae non sunt eis: ut diripias spolia, et invadas praedam: ut inferas manum tuam super eos qui deserti fuerant, et postea restituti, et super populum qui est congregatus ex gentibus, qui possidere coepit, et esse habitator umbilici terrae. Sabaet Dedan, et negotiatores Tharsis (sive Carthaginenses et omnes leones villae) ejus dicent tibi: Numquid ad sumenda spolia tu venis? Ecce ad diripiendam praedam congregasti multitudinem tuam, ut tollas argentum et aurum, et auferas supellectilem atque substantiam, et diripias manubias infinitas. Therefore prophesy, son of man, and say to Gog: Thus says the Lord God: Will you not know on that day when my people Israel dwells confidently (or in peace)? And you will come from your place from the sides (or from the farthest parts) of the north, you and many peoples with you, all riding on horses, a great assembly, and a mighty army. And you will come up against my people Israel like a cloud, to cover the land. In the latter days you will be (or it will be), and I will bring you against my land, so that the nations may know me, when I show myself holy through you in their eyes, O Gog. Thus says the Lord God: So you are the one about whom I spoke in the ancient days through my servants, the prophets of Israel, who prophesied in those days and times (or years), that I would bring you against them? And it shall come to pass on that day, on the day of the coming of Gog over the land of Israel, says the Lord God: My wrath shall rise in my fury. And in my zeal, in the fire of my anger, I have spoken, for on that day there shall be a great commotion on the land of Israel, and the fish of the sea, the birds of the sky, and the beasts of the field (or the plains), and every creeping thing that moves on the ground shall be stirred up before me: and all the people who are on the face of the earth shall be shaken, and the mountains shall be torn apart (or the valleys shall fall), and every wall shall fall to the ground. And I will summon against him on all my mountains the sword (or every terror of the sword), says the Lord God. Each person's sword (or man's) shall be directed against his brother. And I will judge him with pestilence (or death), and with vehement rain and immense stones (or hail). I will rain fire and brimstone upon him, and upon his army (or upon all that are with him), and upon many people that are with him. And I will be magnified, and sanctified, and I will be known in the sight of (or before) many nations, and they shall know that I am the Lord.» The first foundations of the history must be laid, and it must be known that this final discourse of the Lord is to the prophet Ezekiel. For after this we can find nothing similar, except for that which is written in the twenty-fifth year of the captivity of Jehoiachin: The hand of the Lord came upon me, and he brought me there, that is, to the land of Israel, when the building of the temple is described, and the order of its ceremonies is narrated. Then it must be observed that the face of the prophet is set or confirmed against Gog of the land, or the land of Magog. For by confirmation and careful consideration, it is necessary to understand what is said according to the words of the Apostle: But we all, with unveiled face, beholding the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from glory to glory, even as from the Lord, the Spirit. Therefore, the Jews and our Judaizers believe that the nations of Gog are the Scythians, cruel and innumerable, who extend beyond the Caucasus Mountain, the marsh of Maeotis, and near the Caspian Sea, all the way to India. And after a thousand years of reign, they are to be stirred up by the devil and come into the land of Israel to fight against the saints, gathered with many nations. First, Mosoch, whom Josephus interprets as Cappadocians, then Thubal, whom the same people suspect to be Iberians or Spaniards, the Hebrews suspect to be Italians, having Persians, Ethiopians, and Libyans with them in their army: also Gomer and Thogorma, whom they interpret as Gauls and Phrygians: also the Sabaeans and Dedan and the Carthaginians, or Tarsus, which John also mentions in his Apocalypse: 'And when the thousand years are completed, Satan will be released from his prison and will come out to deceive the nations that are at the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them for battle, their number is like the sand of the sea. And they marched up over the broad plain of the earth and surrounded the camp of the saints and the beloved city.' And fire came down from God out of heaven, and devoured them: and the devil, who seduced them, was cast into the pool of fire and brimstone, where both the beast And the false prophet shall be tormented day and night forever and ever (Apoc. X, 7 seqq.).» Not understanding the whole volume of John, which is designated by the title of Revelation, to be mystical, and that we need revelation in order to be able to say with the prophet: Reveal my eyes, and I shall contemplate the wonders of your law (Ps. CXVIII, 18). But others, abandoning earthly sense, and indulging in Jewish and old wives' fables which are harmful (1 Tim. 4), and relying on themselves, they dive into the depths, ascend too high, and invent much worse things, so that in heavenly Jerusalem they describe the wars of the devil and all his army, and interpret under the headings of the particular nations the spiritual wickednesses in heavenly places. All these things, leaving them to the judgment of the reader, we will endeavor not so much to condemn as to affirm the ecclesiastical explanation. From the Greek word δόμα, Gog is said to mean "gift," and Magog means "uncovered. Therefore, all pride and knowledge of false names, which elevates itself against the knowledge of truth, is demonstrated by these names. These are the roofs that Isaiah speaks about in his vision against the Valley of Zion: What has happened to you now, since you have all gone up into empty roofs? (Isaiah 22:1). And we interpret the roofs as the leaders of heretics, and those who have received their teachings from them. And beautifully, after many mystical prophecies in this volume, the final prophecy is against Gog and Magog. For if it is the time of judgment, according to Peter, it must begin with the house of God, as also according to the same Ezekiel who says: And begin with My holy ones (above, 9:6), and the last enemy to be destroyed is death (1 Peter 4). Also, in Isaiah, the first speech is against Judah, in which the confession of the Lord is, and the last against the wild animals that are in the desert (Isaiah 2). And rightly here, too, the final speech is against Gog and Magog, who attack the city of God, which the rush of the river makes joyful (Psalm 46). And what is said in Isaiah: I am the first city, which is attacked (Isaiah 27:10). And concerning which it is written in the Gospel: A city situated on a mountain cannot be hidden (Matt. 5:14). And more fully in the psalm: Jerusalem, which is built as a city, whose participation is in unity (Psalm 122:3). Its mountains are round about it, and the Lord is round about His people (Psalm 124:1). Moreover, that in the army of Gog, or Magog, who according to the Septuagint, Symmachus, and Theodotion, is the prince of Ros, Mosoch, and Thubal: the first nation, Ros, is interpreted as head by Aquila, which we have also followed, so that the sense is: The prince of the head, Mosoch, and Thubal. And truly, neither in Genesis, nor in any other place in Scripture, nor even in Josephus, who sets forth the names of all the Hebrew nations in the first book of Antiquities, could we find this nation. From which it is clear that Ros does not signify a nation, but a head. It must also briefly be noted that in Ezekiel, Gog is said to be the prince of the land of Magog. Moreover, the Apocalypse mentions both Gog and Magog as nations, which come forth from the four corners of the earth (Apoc. 10). And just as from Jacob, who was afterwards called Israel, the entire people of the Hebrews received the name Israel (Gen. 32), and from Aram, Syria, and from Mesraim, Egypt, whose names are written in Genesis (ibid., 10): so also from the prince Gog, all who are subject to him are called Magog. However, Mosoch is interpreted as insanity, and Thubal as everything or all. Therefore, the leader and head of arrogant insanity, and of all evils, are called Gog and Magog, according to what is written: The world is set in wickedness (1 John 5:19). These nations, hostile and adversarial to the saints, come out from the corners of the earth, leaving the straight path and the arrangement of God's camps, as narrated in the Book of Numbers, and not knowing that testimony: Many will come from the east and the west, from the north and the south, and will recline with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of God (Matthew 8:11). And in another place: I will say to the north, 'Give up,' and to the south, 'Do not withhold; bring my sons from afar and my daughters from the ends of the earth, everyone who is called by my name.' (Isaiah 43:6). But these are not the corners of the earth from which Gog and Magog come forth: next to these corners stands the harlot in Proverbs (Prov. 23), who, passing through the streets, namely the wide and spacious road that leads to death, hastens to deceive foolish young men. The scribes and Pharisees also pray in the corners of the streets, to be seen by men, who have received their reward (Matthew 6). So what is the threatening prophecy against Gog? I will cause you to wander and turn you around, and I will put a bit in your jaws. First, I will make you waver in your decision and turn back. And I will put a bit in your jaws, as it is written: 'Put a bridle on their jaws, those who do not come near to you' (Psalms 32:9); so that the untamed and unruly horse, running off cliffs, may be subdued by the Lord's bridle. To whom the prophet says: 'Ride on your horses, and let your chariot be your protection' (Habakkuk 3:8). And to Job it is said through the cloud and the storm: 'Have you given strength to the horse?' (Job 39:19). Such were the horses and horsemen; the multitude of them that John saw in heaven (Revelation 6). Therefore, it says to Gog: I will bring you out, or gather you and all your army, or your strength. One who is brought out and gathered together from dispersion is drawn back to salvation, according to what is promised in the law: 'If your dispersion is from one end of the heavens to the other, from there I will gather you' (Deuteronomy 30:3). They also boast of having horses and cavalry dressed in armor that imitates the apostle's, and they claim to have breastplates of righteousness (Ephesians 6). The multitude is excessive, and they all seize the shield and sword against the Church, and there are fierce and hostile nations, Persians, Ethiopians, and Libyans, whose wars against the people of God are recounted in the Holy Scriptures. Gomer and the house of Togarmah also, who come from the sides of the North, which is the coldest wind, and is called the Wind of the North, and the whole strength of Magog, and all the peoples who are subject to them, will come with him to battle. It is said to him ironically: prepare yourself, equip yourself, and gather to yourself all your multitude that obeys your commands; and know that after many days you will be visited, according to what is written: I will visit their iniquities with a rod and their sins with blows (Psalm 88:33). In the last, it says, you will come in the year. Hence, even John speaks: Little children, it is the last hour (1 John 2:18). And at the eleventh hour, the people of the nations are hired to work in the vineyard (Matt. XX), and they come to the land, that is, the land of meekness, and the land of the saints, which brings forth one hundred and sixty and thirty and thirty fruits, to be conquered by Gog, which has turned back or turned away from the sword. For it is written: Scatter, O Lord, the nations that desire war (Ps. LXVII, 32). And it is in peace and is gathered from many peoples and nations, so that, with the error of the nations disregarded, it may come to the mountains of Israel, namely the patriarchs and prophets, who were once deserted constantly without the law and commandments of God; to whom it is later said: More are the children of the deserted one than of her who has a husband (Isa. LIV, 1). These are the deserts and waterless places in which the devil could not find a place, because they were called to salvation, and after he took on seven other more wicked demons, he returned to his own house (Matt. XI), namely to the nation of Israel. This, he says, is brought out from the peoples, and the land is understood; or here, he is brought out from the nations, so that the people of believers who dwelled in peace and trusted in the Lord may be understood. But when Gog ascends with his entire army, he will come like a storm and like a cloud, to cover the land of the believers. For who is not like a storm coming against the Church, and like a cloud with his words, rushing to oppress and cover even the simplest of believers? Thus it is said to him: As much as you can, you will cover everything and all your armies, and many peoples with you. And Gog, ascending beautifully, does not have voluntary rain, nor temporary and late rain that would rejoice the dry fields, but storm and darkness, to confuse everything with darkness and error. Therefore, the Lord God speaks to him: In that time, that is, in the last days, words will arise in your heart, and you will contemplate evil thoughts, as Scripture says: If the spirit of the one who has power wants to ascend upon you, do not leave your place (Eccle. X, 4). On the contrary, God ascends in the heart of the holy one, of whom it is written: He has set ascents in his heart (Ps. LXXXIII, 6). And Gog says: I will ascend to the land without a wall, or a fortification, that is, the one deprived of the help of God, and not fortified by dialectic arguments; I will come to those who are at rest, and those who dwell securely, that is, in peace. For our king is a peaceful one, and his dwelling place is in peace (Psalm 75). 'All,' he says, 'dwell without walls, they have no bars or gates.' This is what the devil, the prince of heretics, speaks, that the Church has no defenses; nor worldly wisdom, which is foolishness before God, in order to plunder spoils and invade the Church's prey, and lay his hand upon those who had been abandoned when they did not have knowledge of God: and afterwards restored through Christ, they come to the Father, to whom he speaks in the Gospel: 'Father, I have revealed your name to men' (John 17:6). And so that we may know that the people who had been abandoned and later restored signify the Christian people, it follows: 'And upon the people who are gathered from the nations' (Psalm 73:12). This people began to possess the inheritance of Christ, and to be inhabitants of the navel of the earth, about which it is written: 'He has worked salvation in the midst of the earth. For truth has arisen from the earth' (Psalm 84:1); which says in the Gospel: 'I am the way, and the truth, and the life' (John 14:6). While he was thinking about these things, and saying, and hastening to seize possession of the Church, the nations that had been converted from their ancient error to salvation, Saba and Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish, of Carthage, or of the sea who seek merchandise in the waves of this world with good works, and all their cities, whether lions or lion cubs, as it is written in Hebrew, will speak to him what follows. However, regarding the lion cubs, which are called Caphir in Hebrew, it is clear error that the Seventy and Theodotion translate as cities. For if you write it with the letter chi, it is called lion cub; but if you write it with the letter ce, which is called Coph in Hebrew, it means field and city. Therefore, Capernaum is said to be a beautiful field. So Saba and Dedan, and the merchants of Tarshish, and all the saints who are called lion cubs, or certainly the dwellings and habitations of believers, will say: O Gog, do you come for the purpose of plundering the Church, and have you gathered this multitude so that it becomes your inheritance of Christ? Or do you think that you will possess the silver and gold, which are understood in speech and meaning, of the Church, so that you may take away all the furniture and infinite treasures that have been gathered by Christ's victories? Therefore, O Prophet Ezekiel, who is called son of man in the typology of Christ, speak to Gog and say to him: Thus says the Lord God, when the error of the whole world is removed, my people Israel, who perceives God with the mind, will confidently dwell in the Church, or in peace. Then you shall know, or rather arise, and come from your place. But the following words show where the place of heretical depravity is: From the sides of the North, which tries to cool all the heat of believers. And many people will come with him, all riders of horses, of whom it is written: He has thrown the horse and its rider into the sea (Exodus 15:1): a great gathering and a fierce army, with whom he goes up, saying, over my people Israel like a cloud and darkness, to cover my land, of which it was said above: In the latter days you shall be, when the Gospel preaching: and I will bring you upon my land. For it is necessary that there be heresies, so that those who are approved may become manifest (1 Corinthians 11:19), and by the will of God the devil and all perversities of doctrine have been abandoned: so that all nations may know and understand me, when I have been sanctified in you in their sight, O Gog, that is, when they shall have understood me as their judge in your punishments. And he says an apostrophe to Gog himself; Are you not the one about whom I spoke in ancient days, through the hands of my servants the prophets of Israel? Namely, Moses, who said in the Book of Numbers, specifically according to the LXX: A man will come forth from his lineage, and he will rule over many nations, and his kingdom will be exalted, and his kingdom will grow (Num. XXIV, 7). However, according to the Hebrew text, I found it written as follows: Therefore, his king Agag will be removed (Vulgate: Gog), and his kingdom will be taken away, because the kingdom of Israel was destroyed by Saul because of King Agag of Amalek. And in another place: He will cleanse the land of His people (Joel 3). Joel also describes the gathering of the peoples in the valley of Jehoshaphat, which is the judgment of God. And Isaiah and all the prophets, in whose hands the word of the Lord is spoken through good works. So when you come upon the land of Israel, my indignation will rise up in my anger against you, and in my zeal for my people. In the fire of my wrath I have spoken, which will consume all the wood of your vices. At that time there will be a great upheaval upon the land of Israel. For as the devil is unleashed, there will be frequent persecution against the Church: which when it is subdued, and overcome by the protection of God, then the fish of the sea, the birds of the sky, the animals of the field, and every creeping thing that moves on the earth, and all the people who are upon the face of the earth will be disturbed before him. This is clearly demonstrated by the inhabitants of the Church: some are like fish of the sea; some are like birds of the sky; some are like beasts of the field and all the crawling creatures that move upon the earth; some, however, inhabit the face of the earth, retaining the dignity of man. Furthermore, the diversity of customs is designated by various names, as the Apostle writes to the Corinthians, distinguishing between heavenly bodies and earthly bodies after the resurrection (1 Cor. 15); and the body of a fish is different from that of a bird, and the body of a beast is different from that of a reptile, and the body of a man is different from that of the others who have preserved their original form. In the Acts of the Apostles, that linen cloth which is shown to the Apostle Peter by the four principles (Acts 10) also signifies the variety of believers, which is also contained in the Ark of the Flood. Then the face of the Lord and the majesty of his presence will overthrow the mountains that rise up against the knowledge of God. And the hedges or valleys that have been submerged in the depths of ignorance will fall, as well as the fortifications that promise something in order to imitate the Church of God, of which it is said: 'Whoever destroys a hedge, a snake will bite him' (Sirach 10:8). And all the walls will fall to the ground. For when the strength of the words of Ecclesiasticus appears, all the fortifications of heretics will collapse. And I will call, he says, against him, that is, the prince of the heretics Gog, a sword on all his mountains, so that the leaders of his army will be defeated by the sword of the Lord. Then heresy will fight against heresy, and their struggle with each other is our victory. And I will judge him, says the Lord, with death, or with pestilence, and with blood, and with a violent rain, and with immense stones, or hailstones. But Gog will be judged with his own death, and with the blood that he has shed, and with a violent rain, by the words of learned and perfect men, and with immense stones, which will bury him under the testimonies of the Scriptures, or hailstones, which will cool his heat. For all those who commit adultery, their hearts are like an oven (Hosea 7:4). Fire, he said, and sulfur will rain down upon him: by which the punishment of eternal judgment is demonstrated. And not only upon him, who was the author of wickedness, but also upon the entire army and multitude with him, and upon many peoples, who are with him. For indeed heretics have many companions, and even the devil, their prince, is surrounded by an infinite multitude. With every error removed, and with the leaders of the heretics punished and destroyed, the Lord is magnified and sanctified among the believers, and is made known in the eyes of many nations, who have believed in his faith: and both from the blessedness of himself and from the punishments of his adversaries, they will know and understand that he himself is the Lord. We have interpreted these things as best we could, obeying that command: You shall not turn aside to the right or to the left, but you shall walk in the straight path (Deuteronomy 28:14). But if anyone criticizes our words, let them either propose better things for us to follow, or if they have nothing to say, let them leave the complete knowledge of God to Him. However, let them know that there is no strength in us, but it is the mind that is to be judged.

<h2 id='tocuniq303'>(Cap. XXXIX.—Vers. 1 seq.)</h2>

(Chapter 39, Verses 1 onwards) \"But you, son of man, prophesy against Gog and say: 'Thus says the Lord God: Behold, I am against you, O Gog, chief prince of Meshech and Tubal; and I will turn you around and lead you out, and bring you up from the far north, and bring you against the mountains of Israel. And I will strike down your bow in your left hand, and cause your arrows to fall out of your right hand. You shall fall on the mountains of Israel, you and all your troops and the nations that are with you.\ I will give you as food to the wild animals, birds, and all flying creatures, and to the animals on the ground. You will fall on the open field or in the countryside, because I, the Lord God, have spoken. I will send fire on Magog and on those who live securely in the islands. Then they will know that I am the Lord. I will make my holy name known among my people Israel, and I will not let it be dishonored anymore. The nations will know that I am the Lord, the holy God of Israel. Behold, he is coming, and it has happened (or you will know that it will happen), says the Lord (the Vulgate adds God): this is the day of which I have spoken. And the inhabitants of the cities of Israel will come out and burn weapons, shield and spears (or shields and spears), bow and arrows, staffs of the hand (the Vulgate manus): and spears (or lances): and they will burn them with fire for seven years. And they will not take wood from the regions (or from the fields), nor cut from the forests: for the weapons will be burned with fire, and they will plunder those who plundered them; and they will spoil their devastators, says the Lord God. And it shall come to pass in that day, that I will give Gog a place for burial in Israel, the valley of the travelers east of the sea, which will astonish those who pass by; and they shall build a wall around the mouth of the valley, and bury there Gog and all his multitude; and it shall be called the valley of the multitude of Gog. And the house of Israel shall bury them, in order to cleanse the land for seven months. But all the people of the earth will bury them, and there will be a day named for them, in which I have been glorified, says the Lord God. And they will continually appoint men, going around the land, to bury and search for those who remain on the face of the earth, to cleanse it. But after seven months they will begin to search. And they will go around exploring the land. And when they see the bones of a man, they will set up a marker next to it, until the cleansers in the valley of the multitude of Gog bury it. The name of the city is Amona (or Polyandrion), and they will cleanse the land (or the land will be cleansed). And the heirs of this Jewish tradition, and the disciples of endless fables, contend that after a thousand years of reign, Gog, the prince of Ros, Mosoch, and Thubal will be killed in the borders of Israel; and they will be devoured by all the birds and beasts. And the inhabitants of the cities of Israel will not use wood for seven years, but rather the weapons of Gog, namely shields and spears, arrows and staffs or javelins. And Gog himself will be buried in a valley, which is called Ge in Hebrew, and the name of his tomb will be called Polyandrion, where a great multitude of people will be buried. But he is to be buried by the house of Israel for seven months, so that the land may be cleansed. And on a glorious day to come, when Gog is killed, those who are appointed to diligently search for and bury the bones will be established, so that nothing remains unburied on the land. After the months, or in the seven months, the land will be greatly enlarged; and wherever they see a human bone, they are to mark it with a sign, so that it may be buried later by those in charge of this task. The city is to be called Amona, which is Greek for 'multitude of buried people,' and thus the land will be cleansed. They said this to him. But we, understanding the meaning of the beginning of the explanation, discussed each thing that we proposed. Gog himself also has his own trinity: Ros, Mosoch, and Thubal; head, that is, and insanity, and everything; so that there is no vice that does not consist in the possession of Gog. This one will be raised up, whether he will be moved around, and he will feel, or he will be suckled: in hope of victory, he will be led to battle to be killed. And he will ascend from the sides, or from the uttermost parts of the North, from whence evils break forth upon the whole earth. And he himself will be led over the mountains of Israel: which we must understand as the apostles and apostolic men, and ecclesiastics, so that after he has been led to the mountains of Israel, then the bow, which is in his left hand, and the arrows, which are held in his right hand, will be struck. And he himself, in mimicking those whom he has deceived, will have weapons in his left and right hands, through good and bad reputation. These arrows are the same as the darts, of which the Psalmist speaks: Behold, sinners have bent the bow; they have prepared their arrows in a quiver, to shoot in the dark at the upright of heart (Ps. 10:2). The fiery darts of the devil must be extinguished by the shield of faith (Ephes. VI). However, Gog, who had ascended the mountains of Israel, will be cast down or will fall, in the very mountains with all his army and all his troops; and he will be food for the wild beasts, birds, and all the flying creatures of the earth: namely, the adversaries, the powers, who by the wayside devour the seed, and the bloodthirsty beasts. For just as it is written about the dragon: You have given him as food to the peoples of Ethiopia (Ps. LXXIII, 14); so those who have been deceived by heretics are the food of demons. But Gog is a cadet, either in the width of the field or in the cultivated field that is tended by the farmers of God. For it is impossible for the words of the Lord to be in vain. Then fire will be sent to Magog, namely to those who have received Gog's teaching, and to those who are beaten by the waves of the world like the likeness of islands, and who think that they should be secure. That fire of which the Lord speaks: I came to cast fire upon the earth; and how I wish it to be kindled (Luke XII, 49); so that all may know and understand that I am the Lord, and that the name of holiness may be made known in the midst of my people, who have not been deceived by Gog's authority: and so that my name may no longer be polluted by the opportunity of a false name of knowledge among heretics; and so that the nations, which are around, may know that I am the Lord. But what follows, 'Behold, he comes, and it is done,' is said of the judgment of Christ: 'He that cometh will come, and will not delay' (Habakkuk 2:3). And this is the day of punishment and vengeance, of which the Lord spoke through all the prophets. And the inhabitants of the cities of Israel, the people of believers, will go out; but by the cities of Israel we understand the Churches of the right faith. And they will kindle and burn the weapons, of which it is written in another place: 'He will break the bow and smash the weapons, and burn the shields and spears with fire' (Psalm 44:10), the shields and spears, the bow and arrows, the staffs of the hands, on which they celebrated the perverse Passover, the lances or poles with which they inflicted wide and incurable wounds of false doctrines, and the shields, bows, and arrows, of which it was said above. And what follows: And these things shall happen for seven years, it must be explained from Exodus and Leviticus (Exod. XXI; Levit. XXV), in which the Law prescribes that in the seventh year of remission, when freedom is restored to Hebrew slaves and all debts are paid, the ancient possession returns to the owners, and the land rests, and all produce is pardoned for the poor, so that in the holy and perfect number of seven years the armor of the heretics may perish, and the ecclesiastical men may by no means cut down trees from the fields and regions, woods and forests of the nations, whom they desire to save rather than destroy; but from the heretics whom they have conquered, using shields, spears, arrows, staffs, poles, and lances. For they themselves have various weapons to attack the Church of Christ, which must be ignited by the learned men with the fire of the Holy Spirit; namely, the ecclesiastical discourses, which those who possess can say: Was not our heart burning within us while He was speaking to us on the road, while He was opening the Scriptures to us? (Luke 24:32) We cannot have full peace and confidence of dwelling unless we plunder all the furniture of the adversaries, so that everything may perish and turn into ashes; and we plunder those who had plundered us before, and we lay waste to those who had previously devastated the Church. In Dieilla, in the clear light of preaching: 'I will give', he says, 'to Gog a named place, a tomb in Israel, near the Hebrew, the valley of travelers towards the East of the sea, which causes those passing by to be amazed.' The meaning of this speech is that the tomb of Gog will not be in the mountains, but in the low valleys and in rugged places, which in Hebrew are called Ge (Jah). The heretics, even though they are in the West, pretend that these places are in the East, in order to deceive travelers, who are passing through this world and are not inhabitants but strangers, saying that prophetic verse: 'I am a stranger and a sojourner, like all my fathers.' For who, passing by, of whom it is written: 'And they that passed by, have not said: The blessing of the Lord be upon you' (Ps. 128:8), does not marvel and stand amazed when he sees the valley of travelers, which appears as a valley to travelers, but as a mountain to its inhabitants? This according to the Hebrew. However, the Seventy translated it as the gathering of those who come to the sea; and they shall build around the entrance of the valley. For it is the labor of those who go out from the cities of Israel, to enclose and build around every entrance and exit of heretical wickedness that comes to the sea, and they delighted in its bitterness, and with the heaps of water and the cruelty of shipwreck, they may shut it up and build around it, and bury it in the depths of the earth, so that they may no longer be able to come out and deceive others with their deception. Therefore, there Gog and all his multitude will be buried, with which the heretics are always delighted. And the name of that valley in which Gog is buried will be called Ge, or πολυάνδριον, which means the tomb of a great multitude. And as we said above, the weapons of the adversaries will burn for seven years: and so the land will be cleansed from the filth of the heretics for seven months. For from the first month, when we celebrate the Passover of the Lord and avoid the destroyer of Egypt, the lambs with the blood on our doorposts, until the end of the year, that is, until the seventh month, when we set up the tabernacles and protect ourselves with the branches of palm trees among the other branches: so that a complete victory against the enemies may be demonstrated, we observe all the festivities among the people. It will not only be done by the teachers, but also by the whole people, to bury Gog and cover the land and not allow the free air to be taken. But after the death and killing, or burial of Gog, men of the Church shall be chosen, who have the task of ensuring that nothing of the ancient filth remains on the land of Israel, and that no dead bodies are left. They shall search the land, looking for the dead, and bury them, so that the land of the Church may be purified. But if, after seven months, when everything should be cleansed, those who travel and go around the land find anywhere the bones of a man, that is, the hardness of heretical wickedness, or anything of the dead doctrine still remaining, they shall place it beside that place, or build a memorial, so that once those who are of such kind are marked, they may be cleansed or buried with Gog, and they shall be cast into the tomb (or crowd) of his burial. But the name of the city, where the victory of the Lord's servants is, and the adversaries lie down, and the whole multitude of its enemies is prostrate, will be called Amona, or Polyandrion: so that the end of all things may be the restoration of purity. Finally it follows: And they will cleanse the earth; no doubt those about whom it is written above: They will begin to seek, and the wanderers will go around the earth.

<h2 id='tocuniq304'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Vv. 17 et seq.) \"Therefore, son of man, thus says the Lord God: Speak to every bird and to all the birds of the air, and to all the beasts of the field: Gather and come together; gather from all around to my sacrifice that I have prepared for you, a great sacrifice on the mountains of Israel, so that you may eat flesh and drink blood. You shall eat the flesh of the mighty and drink the blood of the princes of the earth: of rams, lambs, and goats, of fat bulls and all the fattened animals.\ And you will eat the fat in abundance, and you will drink the blood in drunkenness, from the sacrifice which I have offered to you. And you will be satisfied at my table with horse and with strong horsemen (or giants): and with all the mighty warriors, says the Lord God. And I will put (or give) my glory in the nations (or in you): and all the nations will see my judgment which I have done, and my hand which I have placed (or brought) upon them. And the house of Israel shall know that I am the Lord their God from that day forward. And all the nations shall know that the house of Israel was taken captive because of their iniquities, because they have forsaken me, and I have hidden my face from them and have given them into the hand of their enemies, and they have all fallen by the sword. According to their uncleanness and their transgressions I have dealt with them, and I have hidden my face from them. Therefore, thus says the Lord God: Now I will restore the captivity of Jacob, and I will have mercy on the whole house of Israel, and I will be zealous for my holy name. And they will bear their confusion (or disgrace), and all the transgressions by which they have transgressed against me, when they dwelled confidently (or in peace) in their own land, fearing no one. And I will bring them back from the peoples (or nations), and I will gather them from the lands of their enemies (or from the regions of the nations), and I will be sanctified in them in the eyes (or in the sight) of many nations. And they shall know that I am the Lord their God, when I have scattered them among the nations and have gathered them together upon their own land, and have not left any of them there. Nor will I hide my face from them any more, for I have poured out my Spirit upon the house of Israel, says the Lord God. This translation, according to the Hebrew, is that I will gather them upon their own land, and will not leave any of them there. This is not found in the Septuagint. And again, what is placed next to the Hebrews for a blessing, because I have poured out my spirit, the LXX translated as fury, which pertains to anger, especially since in Hebrew it is written Ruhi, which properly means my spirit, and by no means my fury. But everything up to that point, where the building of the temple follows, those whom we mentioned above, the Jews and our Judaizers, refer to the final time: that Gog with all his army should be saturated like the fattest sacrifices of birds and beasts, and that Israel should be restored to its former state, and no longer be conquered by the nations, but that God should pour out his spirit upon them, so that they may dwell in their land: not all nations, but specifically the house of Israel. But following the begun tropology, we will say that the Lord summons all birds and all beasts to deliver to them the leaders of heretics, like very fat victims to be devoured. Birds and beasts, however, are called such either because of their swiftness in running everywhere or because of their fierceness and cruelty, to whom adversaries are handed over for the destruction of the flesh, so that the spirit may be saved, and they may learn not to blaspheme (I Tim. I). But they will eat a large and very fat victim; not elsewhere, but above the mountains of Israel, which we must understand as the prophets, apostles, and holy men. For in them the teachers of contrary doctrines fall, and are destroyed by the wounded themselves, upon whom the Church is built: or rather, upon the mountain of mountains, of which Isaiah and Micah speak: Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, and to the house of the God of Jacob, and he will show us his ways (Isa. II, 3; Mic. IV, 2). But these birds and these animals, swift and cruel, feed on flesh and drink blood, which cannot possess the kingdom of God: the flesh of the mighty or giants who rebelled against the knowledge of God, and the blood of princes, not of heaven, but of the earth, who have savored all earthly things: the blood of rams, and lambs, and goats, or according to the Septuagint, rams, calves, and goats, to signify three types of animals that are sacrificed in the name of God. For heretics also imitate the gentleness of the Church, but their offering does not profit for the worship of God, but for the food of demons, which is their fattest offering. They are satiated with fatness and drink the blood of deceivers to the point of drunkenness. But God offers this victim through ecclesiastical men, so that the multitude of deceivers may be satiated as the worst guests, and they may drink to the point of vomiting and drunkenness. When you see holy men, educated in the divine Scriptures, cutting down the horses of heretics and their riders, of whom it is written: He has cast the horse and his rider into the sea (Exodus 15:1), and slaying all rebels and giants with his sword, and shedding the blood of all 460 warriors of false knowledge: then know that the Lord's table is prepared, that he may place his glory in all nations, who believe in his name, and understand the judgement of his holy Church, which they have passed upon their adversaries, and the strong hand with which they have struck them. And let the house of Israel know and understand, that he himself is their Lord God, who has said: I am the Lord your God, from the day of the Lord's victory until eternity. And let them remember that the house of Israel was once captured by the heretics, and dispersed throughout the whole world of perverse doctrines, because they abandoned him, who for a little while hid or turned his face away from them, and delivered them into the hands of heretics, and they fell pierced by their sword because of their impurities and injustices, which was the reason he hid and turned his face away from them. But after presenting the arguments, according to what is written: It is necessary that there be heresies, so that those who are approved may become manifest (1 Corinthians 11:19), the captivity of Israel, namely the Church, in which they dwell, beholding God: now promises that it will bring back into the Church the captivity of Jacob, who had supplanted the Jewish people, and was later supplanted by the frauds of the heretics: and will have mercy on the whole house of Israel, not according to the flesh, but according to the spirit. And I will take up my zeal for my holy name, which was blasphemed among the nations because of the heretics: so that after I have delivered them, they may be ashamed and confounded, for they have transgressed against me by abandoning the faith of the Church. But let them be confounded and greatly ashamed when they dwell in their own land, a land of meekness and a land of saints, and they dwell confidently, in peace, not fearing the snares of the heretics (Psalm VI). Then they shall be brought back from the peoples, and gathered from the lands of their enemies into their own land, and the Lord shall be sanctified in them in the sight of many nations, who themselves shall also believe in the Lord. And the end of blessedness shall be to know and recognize that He is their Lord God, because He has appeared to them among the nations, whether He has transferred them from the nations and gathered them onto their own land, the land of Judah, the land of confession, the land of gentleness, and the land of the living, and has not left even one to heretical depravity. And He will no longer hide His face from them, nor turn away from them, because He has poured out the spirit of His grace, of which the prophet Joel also speaks: 'And in the last days I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh' (Joel 2:28); but He poured it out upon the whole house of Israel. But if, according to the Septuagint, we interpret 'fury' as referring to the Spirit, which is not found in Hebrew, it must be understood that God will no longer hide his face from those on whom he had previously poured out his fury. Up to this point, we have spoken concerning the prophet Ezekiel, with the help and inspiration of God, may he assist us, without opposing the opinions of others who have written before us or in the future, if they should write, but affirming whatever is our own. But in the construction of the temple, and the order of the priests, and the division of the holy land, and the flow of the river from the temple, and the evergreen trees on both banks, and the fruit brought forth each month, and the rest contained in the prophetic volume until the end, we openly confess our ignorance, considering it better to say nothing than to say too little.

<h2 id='tocuniq305'>Book Twelve</h2>

Book Twelve

Your prayers, daughter Eustochium, and the promises of the Lord have overcome my fear in explaining the temple of Ezekiel, or rather my persistence in remaining silent, saying: Ask, and it shall be given you: seek, and you shall find: knock, and it shall be opened to you (Matt. VII, 7). And as we excuse ourselves, as we stated at the end of the previous volume, it is better to say nothing than to say too little; you have turned it around, so that you should at least be considered as saying too little rather than nothing: for in the former case, there is a willing spirit, whereas in the latter there is despair of the entire work. And you mention that it is the nature of such people not to have as much gratitude for what you have given as sorrow for what you have denied. For we praise virtues with less enthusiasm than we condemn vices: and although bodies may be beautiful, they become more noticeable due to the wickedness and deformity of one part. Therefore, I will obey your will, and with the Holy Spirit blowing, I will set sail, ignorant of the shores I will reach, and shouting with the same prophet, I come from the four winds, O spirit; and to the fastidious reader, or rather to the mind that is eager to learn from our words, I declare with complete freedom in explaining the temple, that if he desires truth, he should seek it from others. However, we simply confess and declare those things which we can suspect in the most difficult work, giving thanks to the Lord, if He has not opened the doors of knowledge to us in all things, which is impossible, but in most things. For, as the exalted speaker says, it is honorable even to persevere in pursuing and standing by second or lesser matters.

<h2 id='tocuniq306'>(Cap. XL.—Vers. 1 seq.)</h2>

(Chapter 40, verses 1 onward) 'In the twenty-fifth year of our exile (or captivity), at the beginning of the year (or the first month), on the tenth day of the month, fourteen years after the city was struck down (or captured), on that very day (or on that day), the hand of the Lord was upon me, and he brought me there. In a vision (or in a vision from God), he brought me to the land of Israel and set me down (or placed me) on a very high mountain, on which was a structure like a city, towards the south (or in the southern region).' And he brought me there, and behold, a man whose appearance was like the appearance of bronze (or shining bronze); and a measuring line (or mason's line) was in his hand, and a measuring rod (or reed) in his hand. He was standing in the gateway, and he spoke to me, the same man: Son of man, see with your eyes, and hear with your ears, and set your heart on all that I show you (or set in your heart all that I will show you), for you were brought here in order to be shown it (or to enter here): declare (or show) to the house of Israel everything you see. If, in the fifth year of the captivity or exile of King Joachin, in the fourth month, in the fifth day of the month, the heavens were opened to the prophet Ezekiel by the river Chebar and he saw visions of God; and now it is said that in the twenty-fifth year of the same captivity of Jehoiachin, in the beginning of the year, in the tenth month, the hand of the Lord came upon him and he was brought to the land of Israel and placed on a very high mountain, so that he could see the building of the city leaning towards the south, there is no doubt that his entire prophecy is composed of nineteen years, nine months, and five days of the twentieth year. Now, if according to Theodotion, who interpreted it in the beginning of the year, in the new year, on the tenth day of the month (which is called the seventh month among the Hebrews, and has the Hebrew word 'Thesri' as its name), on the Kalends of the seventh month, there is the sound of trumpets, and on the tenth day of the same month, there is a day of fasting and atonement; and on the fifteenth day, when the entire lunar cycle is completed, there are the boisterous feasts. It is understood that on the tenth day of the Day of Atonement, Ezekiel saw the building of the city. And just as he demonstrated the restoration of the people, indeed the resurrection of life in the bones of the field under the image of resurrection, so now the Lord promises the restoration of the city that was destroyed by the Babylonians fourteen years ago, under its description, so that just as the type of captivity and destruction, shown by the boiling pot from the face of the North, and the truth of prophecy was proven by deeds, so the truth of future rebuilding would be proven by the faith of past events. 464 And this is not said about that time, as some ignorant Jews would have it, when the temple was rebuilt under Zorobabel and under Jesus, son of Josedech, the high priest, with the prophets Haggai and Zechariah prophesying. For this temple that is now described, and the order of the priesthood, and the division of the land and its fertility, are much more magnificent than what Solomon built. But that which was built under Zorobabel was so small and insignificant compared to the former, that those who had seen the former temple and then beheld this one wailed and testified to their grief with tears, and the wailing of the mourners would be much louder than the blast of trumpets. Read the book of Ezra. Furthermore, what is added, in the fourteenth year after the city was struck (or captured) (3 Esdras 5), according to mystical understanding, fourteen signifies generations: when they are completed from David until the birth of Christ, the restoration of the city is promised by him, of whom it is written: He will build my city and bring back the captivity of my people (Isaiah 45:13). And again: He came to preach remission to the captives and sight to the blind, saying to those who were in chains, come out, and to those who were in darkness, be revealed (Ibid., 61:1). But the hand of the Lord was upon him, so that he would come to the land of Israel in the spirit while he was physically located in Babylon. And not just in a single vision, but in multiple visions from God, he would be placed upon a very high mountain, of which Isaiah and Micah prophesy: 'Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob' (Isa. II, 3; Mic. IV, 2). For this mountain is exceedingly high, in comparison to the other mountains, as the prophet testifies, saying: 'I lift up my eyes to the mountains, from where will my help come?' (Ps. CXX, 1). And in another place: Mountains are round about it, and the Lord is round about his people (Ps. 124:2). Of this it is also said in Isaiah: Go up into a high mountain, thou that bringest good tidings to Zion (Isa. 40:9). Upon this mountain the building of the city is shown, according to the Septuagint and Aquila, on the east side, and opposite to the north, from where the prophet came to the land of Israel; but according to Theodotion and Symmachus, it is inclined towards the south, where there is full light, and the sun of justice is placed on the highest point of the sky. And in the Song of Songs it is said: Arise, north wind, and come, south wind; blow on my garden, that its fragrance may spread (Song 4.16). For the north wind, a very harsh wind, is driven away from the garden of the Lord, lest the heat of love be cooled and the flowers wither. And when it is said: Like a building of a city, not truly a city, but the likeness of a city is shown, of which it is written: Glorious things are said of you, city of God (Ps. 86.2): which is Jerusalem, built as a city, whose participation is in itself, and in which the great Lord is exceedingly praiseworthy, in the city of our God, on His holy mountain (Ps. 48). And in the towers of this city, God is known, when He will receive her. Of her and elsewhere: The rush of a river makes the city of God rejoice (Ps. XLV, 4). And: A city set on a hill cannot be hidden (Matt. V, 14), which speaks in Isaiah: I am a fortified city, a city under siege (Isa. XXIII). It did not say conquered, but besieged: which is built upon a rock, and is not shaken by any storm. It follows: And He led me there, the hand of God is understood. There, however, to the building of the city, in order that He might show me all the things that were inside. And behold, he said, a man, whose appearance or vision was like the shining of bright bronze, that is, the one of whom it is written: Behold the man, his name is the East (Zach. VI, 12). But he did not have the appearance of amber, as is said at the beginning of this volume, nor was he girded with a golden belt, as is contained in the Apocalypse of John (Apoc. I); but he had an appearance like that of bronze according to the Hebrew. For this material is more resonant than all metals, and it resounds far with a ringing sound. Hence in Daniel, in the image that was made of gold, silver, bronze, and iron, the kingdom of Alexander and the Greeks is represented in the likeness of bronze (Daniel II); so that the eloquence of the Greek language might be signified: by which it is evident that they still need instruction, who have not yet fully understood the mysteries of spiritually building the temple. There was also a line (funiculus) made of linen in his hand, as described in the book of Zachariah (Zech. II), which symbolizes the geometric measuring line he used to measure the width and length of the city. The line represents either the masons who serve God's commandments, or the angels who serve God's commandments, or Moses, and all the prophets and apostles who build the city of God and are helpers or ministers of the Lord's will. As the apostle Paul said: We are God's field, God's building (1 Cor. III, 9). And the pen in his hand signifies prophetic grace, of which it is written in the forty-fourth psalm: My tongue is the pen of a skillful scribe (Psalm 44:2). And about John the prophet and the Baptist: What did you go out to the desert to see? A reed shaken by the wind (Matthew 11:7). Those who desire to imitate this reed are the ones who write iniquity while they write, and to whom the prophet curses: Rebuke the beasts of the reeds (Psalm 68:31). But he was standing at the gate; for through him we enter to the Father, and without him we cannot enter the city of God, so that he may receive the worthy and reject the unworthy. There is also judgment at the gate. Thus, the prophet says: They hate those who accuse at the gate (Isa. 29:21). And in another place: He will not be put to shame when he speaks to his enemies at the gate (Ps. 127:5). Here, a man spoke to the prophet, in whose hand was a measuring line, and whose appearance was like bronze, and who held a reed in his hand. He spoke to Ezekiel of the true architect, whom Paul the apostle imitated, saying: 'Like a wise architect, I have laid the foundation' (I Cor. III, 10). But he calls the wise architect, in distinction to the one who is foolish, and he is called the senseless shepherd in Zechariah; but he spoke the following: 'Son of man, see with your eyes, and hear with your ears' (Zech. XI): not with the eyes of the flesh, but with the spirit; not with the ears of the body, but with the soul. Lift up, he says, your eyes and see that the harvest is already white for harvesting (John 4:35). And: He who has ears to hear, let him hear (Luke 8:8). And the building of the city appears, and the order of the ceremonies and priests is heard, and the description of the land. It is not enough to command to see with the eyes and hear with the ears; but he added: And set your heart on everything; or, and set in your heart everything that I will show you. For seeing and hearing is of no use, unless you store in the treasure of memory what you have seen and heard. But when He says, 'All that I shall show thee,' He makes the hearer attentive, He also prepares the eyes of the heart, that they may retain in memory what they are about to see; because thou art led hither, that all things may be shown thee. Wherefore, having said this, He shows particularly that nothing is sweeter than theory and knowledge, which the prophet desires, saying: 'One thing have I desired of the Lord, this will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life.' To see the beauty of the Lord, and to visit his temple (Psalm 26:4,5). Therefore, he joins and says: O Lord, I have loved the beauty of your house, and the place of the habitation of your glory. Announce, he says, all that you see to the house of Israel, so that those who cannot see for themselves may learn from you what is demonstrated to you by the Lord. And to the house of Israel belong those who see God with their minds, among whom was Nathanael, who earnestly sought Christ and deserved to hear: Behold, a true Israelite, in whom there is no deceit (John 1:47)."  }


<h2 id='tocuniq307'>(Vers. 5 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 5 and following) And behold, there was a wall on the outside surrounding the house all around, and in the man's hand was a measuring reed of six cubits and a handbreadth, and he measured the width of the building with the reed, one reed wide, and also the height with the reed. And he came to the gate that faced the eastern way, and he went up its steps, and he measured the threshold of the gate with the reed, one reed wide, that is, one threshold the width of one reed, and a chamber one reed long and one reed wide, and between the chambers was a span of five cubits, and the threshold of the gate next to the vestibule of the gate on the inside was measured with one reed. And the vestibule of the gate was eight cubits, and its front was two cubits: the vestibule of the gate was on the inside. And the chambers of the gate toward the east were three on this side and three on that side; they had the same measurement on each side as well as the same measurement of the front. And the breadth of the entrance was ten cubits, and the length of the gate was thirteen cubits. And there was a margin in front of the chambers of one cubit, and one cubit was the end on each side: and the chambers were six cubits on one side, and six cubits on the other side. And he measured the gate from the roof of the chamber to its roof, a width of twenty-five cubits, door opposite door. 70: And behold, there was a wall outside the house all around, and in the man's hand was a measuring rod of six cubits, and he measured the wall, a width equal to the rod, and its height according to the rod. Then he went into the gate that faced east, and went up its seven steps, and measured the threshold ÷ six cubits wide, and six cubits wide at the other side of the gate. The gate had the same measurement as the rod in length, and the same measurement as the rod in width, and a threshold of six cubits on each side. And he measured the gate, which faced east, seventy-five cubits in length, and twenty-five cubits in width, with a threshold of six cubits on each side. And the third part equal to three in width, and equal to three in length, and the gate's lintel which is next to the gate's lintel to be eight cubits, and the lintel of two cubits, and the gate's interior lintel, and the gate's threshold in the 468th region, three on this side, and three on that side, and the measure of the entrance: one measure of the lintel on both sides. The width of the gate's entrance was ten cubits, and the width of the gate was thirteen cubits, and one cubit was equal to the view of the third cubit, and one cubit's end on both sides, and three cubits on this side, and three cubits on that side. And it was measured from the gate of the wall to the wall, a width of twenty-five cubits. This gate is opposite the gate.» While I was a boy in Rome, and being educated in liberal studies, I used to go around the tombs of the apostles and martyrs with others of the same age and purpose on Sundays; and frequently, I would enter the crypts, which are dug deep into the earth, and on both sides of those who enter, they have the bodies of the buried, and everything is so dark that the prophetic saying is almost fulfilled: 'Let the living descend to the underworld' (Psalm 55, 16); and rarely does light enter from above, tempering the horror of the darkness, so that it is not so much a window as a hole through which light is let in: and once again, we approach slowly, and in the pitch-black night, that Virgilian verse is presented: 'Fear surrounds us, and the gloom of the night' (Aeneid, Book II).

Horror everywhere terrifies the soul, even the silence itself. Let this statement be for me, so that the wise reader understands my opinion on the explanation of the temple of God in Ezekiel, concerning which it is written: 'Clouds and darkness are under his feet' (Psalm 97:2). And again: 'Darkness is his hiding place' (Psalm 18:12). Therefore, Moses also entered the cloud and the darkness, in order to contemplate the divine mysteries, which the distant and lowly people could not see (Exodus 24 and 34). Finally, after forty days, the common people were unable to see the face of Moses, as his eyes were veiled, because it was glorified, or as it is written in Hebrew, Moses had a horned face. Similarly, as I was reading the description of the mystical temple (which the Jews believe should be built literally during the coming of their Christ, whom we consider to be the Antichrist, but we refer to the Church of Christ and see it being built in his saints every day), wherever the eye of the heart opens, I happened to think I saw and possessed the bridegroom, and joyfully said, 'I have found the one whom my soul seeks, I will hold him, and I will not let him go' (Song of Solomon 3:4); but again the divine word abandons me, and the bridegroom flees from my hands, and my eyes are closed by blindness, so that I am forced to say, 'Oh, the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God!'" } How unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! (Rom. XI, 33) And what is written elsewhere: The judgments of the Lord are a great deep. (Ps. XXXV, 7) And: Out of the depths have I cried unto thee, O Lord, O Lord, hear my voice. (Ps. CXXIX, 1) And that of Elisha, who followed with his eyes the rapture of his master, saying: My father, my father: the chariot of Israel and the driver thereof.
