(IV Kings II, 12) Therefore it is necessary for me to confess that I do not wish rashly to discuss the temple of the blessed Ezekiel, which all ages have kept silence about, but to show the readers the conjecture of my soul with faith and fear of God; as if I were to offer to the tabernacle of God skins of goats and hair, by which the thorns and thistles of sins may be defended against and the rains and storms prevented: let another who is rich, according to the measure of his merits, offer iron or copper or silver, gold and precious stones, and not despise ours, because they are inferior; but rejoice in his own wealth. For unless the foundation is built, the upper parts cannot exist; and in order for the larger parts to be praised, they are enhanced by comparison with the smaller. Let us therefore see what Ezekiel saw first upon entering the city building that faces south, then what he heard: 'And behold,' he says, 'a wall surrounding the house on all sides.' Instead of 'wall,' which Aquila and Theodotion interpreted as, Symmachus and the Seventy used the word 'περίβολον' meaning 'surrounding.' Therefore, the wall or 'περίβολον' enclosed the entire house, that is, the temple of the Lord, and it had a man whose appearance was like the appearance of bronze, and he not only carried a measuring line used by geometers and masons, but also held a reed in his hand, the length of which was unspoken, and is now reckoned as six cubits and a palm, which is more accurately called a 'παλαιστή' in Greek, and is the sixth part of a cubit. Furthermore, the palmus is equivalent to the σπιθαμὴν, which some call the palm to distinguish it. Similarly, they used to call the wrestler a palmus. Therefore, the width and height of the wall were measured with a reed, and both, that is, the width and height, were six cubits and one palm. And since there were many gates, he did not enter through the other gates, but through the one that faced the East. And because the place was not level, and the wall was circular, and the house of God was built in higher places, he entered, or rather ascended, by steps. These steps are called seventy-seven, only because we read in Hebrew and in other translations the word 'steps' without a number. And upon entering the gate, he immediately measured the threshold of the gate, which the seventy gods call: for which it is written in Hebrew as Seph. And I think it is necessary to remind the diligent and studious reader: if, however, he is led by the knowledge of the Scriptures and not by the empty declamations of orators, that he may know that almost all the Hebrew words and names, which are placed in the Greek and Latin translation, have been corruptly altered by excessive antiquity, and have been distorted by the fault of the writers, and while they are written without correction, they become even more uncorrected, and the Hebrew words have become Sarmatian, indeed, of no nation, since they have ceased to be Hebrew and have not begun to be foreign. Therefore, the threshold of the gate, whether it be called θεὲ, or rather seph, which Symmachus interpreted as οὐδὸν, had one reed, that is, six cubits and a palm in width. For this reason, the LXX, I know not for what reason, added six cubits on each side. After the threshold of the gate, according to the Hebrew, it was measured as a chamber or room, as Symmachus translated, with παραστάδας, that is, posts on each side of one reed, both in length and width. And they also translated 'aelam' (αἰλὰμ) as 'ailam', which Symmachus interpreted as 'antechamber' in the following. Between the two chambers, or bedrooms, and the corresponding arches, there were five cubits, and another doorway next to the entrance inside with a single reed. The third vestibule of the doorway also had eight cubits, and on its front, or on its margins, two cubits. And lest anyone think that this vestibule is the same as the one above, he added: Moreover, it was the interior vestibule of the doorway: for which the first, second, and third vestibules were translated as seventy." } However, the thalami, that is, the bedrooms, which were built after the Eastern gate in the vestibules, faced the Eastern road. And in order to know how many thalami there were, it is connected: three on this side and three on the other, namely facing North and South, and the Eastern road; and one measurement of the front was on both sides. He also measured the width of the threshold of the gate and found it to be ten cubits, and the length thirteen cubits, and the ends of the thalami were narrowed to one cubit, or as Symmachus translated, 'παραστάδων', and each front had one cubit. However, the thalami, or παραστάδες, and as the LXX have put it, θεηλὰθ, had six cubits on each side. And the gate was measured from the ceiling of the thalami, or παραστάδος, to the ceiling or wall of it, and it was found to be twenty-five cubits in width between the ceilings. For there was only this much space between the door and the door, or between the gate and the gate. These things we have briefly spoken with a mind more inclined to divine than to explain, desiring to portray the obscure and almost imperceptible picture according to the literal sense. But few things, which we can suspect, we will set forth strictly and doubtingly. The Apostle Paul, wanting the Ephesians (Chapter III) to know more sacred things, prays for them to be filled with the wisdom and love of the Lord, so that rooted and grounded, they may be able to know and comprehend the length, and width, and height, and depth of his riches, and he speaks to them: Therefore, you are by no means strangers, but fellow citizens of the saints and members of the household of God, built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, with Jesus Christ himself being the chief cornerstone, in whom all the building is fitly framed together and grows into a holy temple in the Lord: in whom you also are being built together for a dwelling place of God through the Holy Spirit (Ephesians 3:2). Peter the apostle also speaks in almost the same words, because of the same spirit, in his letter: 'if indeed you have tasted that the Lord is good, approaching him, as to a living stone, rejected by men indeed, but chosen, and honored by God, and you yourselves as living stones are being built into a spiritual house, for a holy priesthood, offering spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.' (1 Peter 2:3-5). From this it is clear that the Lord and Savior, who is the true architect, would evaluate stones that could be placed in the foundations of the temple, both in the middle and in the upper and lower parts, for a measure of 472, or of less solid strength in the wall, and placed outside the temple in the surrounding area. For it is not of small strength or minimal firmness to support stones placed upon it. Hence the Apostle writes to the believers: Bear one another's burdens (Galatians VI, 2). And in another place it is written: we should not take on a burden that we cannot bear. However, the measuring reed, which had six cubits and one palm, signifies that our conversation is known to God, which is contained within the six days in which the world was made, and signifies the order of our works, so that one thing pertains to the works and another to the mind. Hence, the width is equal to the height: the width refers to the works, as we have said; the height refers to the mind, which hastens to lofty things. But let it suffice to have once warned: to know that "cubitus" both denotes a measurement and is of neutral gender, but for the sake of simplicity and ease of understanding, and for the common usage, we prefer to use the masculine gender. For we do not care to avoid errors in speech, but rather to discuss the obscurity of Holy Scripture with whatever words are available. Therefore, a man whose name is "Oriens" enters through the Eastern gate to enlighten those whom he finds in the first section of the vestibule, whether at the entrance of the gate itself or within. He ascends not by one step, but by several steps, the number of which is silent, so that the difficulty of ascent may become apparent, and whatever number of steps you propose, know that it is less than what is left uncertain. I consider this gate, of which it is sung in the Psalms: This is the gate of the Lord, the righteous shall enter through it. And the threshold of the gate is measured, so that we may know that all the knowledge of God is open. This threshold is said to be one reed in width, and it is not mentioned in terms of height or length. For it is both the way and the entrance, and through it one must advance to the interior (although in this place the Seventy needlessly say 'length' or, as is contained in most manuscripts, 'height'); but the chambers, that is, the rooms and recesses, should have individual reeds both in length and in width, but between chamber and chamber there should be only five cubits, so that the inner chambers may have a full measure of a reed, that is, six cubits and one palm, as the work and the plan equally agree. But those things that are external, that is, between chamber and chamber, are five cubits; for the secrets of Christ have not yet penetrated, nor can they say: The king brought me into his chamber (Song of Songs 1:3). And elsewhere: All the glory of the daughter of the king is inward (Psalm 45:14). But while the disciples are staying at home with Christ, they cannot hear his mysteries, and they desire to go outside themselves to hear the word of God, and for this reason the measure of five cubits is placed in them, so that they may be taught to refer all things to the five senses. The threshold of the other gate, as it is contained in the Septuagint, is also of the same measurement as the second and third vestibules of the same pen. After which, in the entrance of its vestibule, that is, the threshold of the gate, eight cubits are placed, so that the inner parts of the vestibule may hold not a sevenfold, but an eightfold number, namely, six cubits and one palm, which pertain to the sacrament of the resurrection and the Lord's Day. And on the front, it says, of the same vestibule there were two cubits, which pertain to both Instruments, or to the letter and the spirit, or to the mystery of the tongs, which in Isaiah is understood concerning the altar of coal, and is carried to cleanse the lips of the prophet. And so that we may know what this vestibule is, which is terminated by eight and two cubits, he explains more clearly: The vestibule of the gate was inside, through which we reached the temple of God. There were also chambers and rooms along the way of the eastern gate, which Seventy Elau writes about. There were three on one side and three on the other, measuring one rod, that is, one reed, which had six cubits and one palm, as mentioned above: And one rod on its length, and one rod on its width, and five cubits between the chambers. Therefore, let us not think that there are only two bedrooms, but he placed three on each side to demonstrate the number six, which is also indicated in the water jars of the Gospel (John 8), in which water was turned into wine, and daily the Jewish waters are turned into wine, which gladdens the heart of man, and becomes sweeter with the blood of Christ. He also measured the width of the threshold of the gate, which is ten cubits, a perfect number that is either contained in the Ten Commandments or in the sacrament of the four Gospels. Starting from one, it reaches four in such a way as to complete the number ten. Its length was thirteen cubits: for which reason its width is also placed at seventy, which seems to me to be distorted by the negligence of the scribes. For Scripture would not have stated the width in one place, and then the width again as ten or thirteen cubits. However, the gate of the threshold, in which the number of the old and new Testaments is consecrated, or the Lord himself, who says, 'I am the door' (John 10:9), can be understood; or certainly all the saints, through whom we enter into the knowledge of God, of whom the Apostle Paul spoke: 'My mouth is open to you, Corinthians'; and 'Widen yourselves also' (2 Corinthians 6:11). But thirteen cubits after the number of eight, the books of Moses contain a sacrament, which is also shown in the five loaves (Matthew 14), and in the Samaritan woman of the Gospel (John 4), who is accused of having had five husbands, and the sixth whom she thought she had, she did not have. And yet the number eight and the number five are completed with one cubit, that is, the thirteenth (or third) one: because in Christ all things are recapitulated. It is said: 'And one cubit on each side; thus both the old and the new Testament are comprised in the one measure of Christ, and one cubit includes the height of the ark of Noah, which is thirty cubits.' But as for the chambers, as the Seventy (the Septuagint) have rendered the Hebrew word, either 'thalami' or 'thee,' they were six cubits on each side, changing and varying in each place as they pleased, and they had no span or height added above, which would symbolize the present conversation leading to future blessedness, but only six cubits. And he measured the gate from the ceiling of the chamber to the ceiling of the wall, and found it to be twenty-five cubits in width. This number, though multiplied by four, still corresponds to reality. For if you arrange five cubits against themselves five times, you will produce the number twenty-five, which is between the ceiling of the chambers and the ceiling; and yet both, positioned opposite one another, have a doorway facing a doorway from the highest parts. These may not seem trivial to the reader, even though they displease me myself, feeling like I am knocking on a closed door; but they are to be read with permission: otherwise, I could simply confess my ignorance and cut off all desire of students. For as we are far from perfect knowledge, we consider a lighter fault at least somewhat, rather than saying nothing at all.

<h2 id='tocuniq308'>(Vers. 14 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 14 seqq.) And he made frontals of sixty cubits, and all around the front of the courtyard of the gate. And before the face of the gate, which reached up to the face of the inner vestibule gate, there were fifty cubits, and oblique windows in the chambers, and on their front sides which were within the gate, all around. Likewise, there were also windows within the vestibules in a circular shape on the inside, and in front of the frontals there were depictions of palm trees. LXX: And under the sky, the height of the gate was sixty cubits, and the threshold of the court gate all around. And under the sky, the court gate on the outside was fifty cubits, and hidden windows above the threshold, and on the inside of the gate of the court all around. And similarly the side chambers and the windows all around on the inside, and above the palm trees on each side.\" Symmachus interpreted this passage as follows: And he made enclosures, which we can call surroundings: for which in Hebrew, it has Elim (), which Aquila interpreted as κρίωμα, and we translated as front. Again, when the Seventy placed the veil in front of the atrium, in Hebrew it has the singular number El, which Symmachus translated as near the atrium, Aquila κρίωμα, that is, the front of the atrium. Under the sky also, the threshold of the gate, Aquila, in front of the gate posts: Symmachus, opposite the face of the gate vestibule, interpreted. The hidden windows which are called Atemoth in Hebrew, Symmachus translated as τοξικὰς. And where the Seventy said, above the veil, and above the threshold, the same Symmachus placed posts, and surroundings; Aquila, chambers, and their fronts: for which it is written in Hebrew Theim and Ele. Furthermore, Elamoth, which were also translated by the Septuagint and Theodotion in a similar manner; Symmachus rendered 'circumstances,' Aquila rendered 'forefronts.' However, Aelam, which is written as 'El' in Hebrew (Mss. Ul), means 'gate' or 'entrance.' As for palm trees, it is written as 'Thamarim' in Hebrew, in the plural form, because in the singular form it is called 'Thamar.' I know that this might be annoying to a fastidious reader, but I wanted to briefly show how much the ancient translation deviates from Hebrew truth due to the length of time and, dare I say, the fault of the scribes, especially in Hebrew names, which we have expressed in the Latin language not so much as an explanation of the words, but rather as an indication of our simple suspicion. But I think that outside the wall of the temple, around it, and in the courtyard, that is, in the middle, there were certain things placed for decoration, which Symmachus interprets as surroundings, that is, certain standing objects, and erected from the ground up, and these occupy a space of sixty cubits. And again, for those exiting from the inner gate towards the front of the vestibule, which faced the outer gate, there was a space of fifty cubits, in which there were oblique windows, which Symmachus calls arch-shaped. And in these windows were in the chambers, that is, in each bedroom, and in the porches that extended before the bedrooms, occupying fifty cubits. These windows, which were slanted or arched, hence obtained the name from arrows, because they let in a narrow light into the house, resembling the shape of arrows, and they enlarged from the inside: and all things around were full of such windows. And in front, he said, of the porches, there were paintings or carvings of palm trees: through which it is shown at the entrance of the gate, and immediately upon entering, there is a wall that meets sixty cubits with various ornaments, which refer to the condition of the world, so that the Creator may be understood from the creatures: and they show the variety of the world in order and in a rational manner, which among the Greeks is called "kosmos" and received its name from adornment: and it was made in six days, so that through each day, ten decades are counted, which perfect number we mentioned above. After this, as we enter the inner atrium, we encounter before us the vestibule of the inner gate of the bedroom with oblique windows, covering a space of fifty cubits, which itself is a sacred number. And after seven full weeks of festivities and joy, the first day of the Octave begins, which is the day of resurrection, and it brings us to the vicinity of the temple. When we have done everything, repenting for the error of the previous week, then we become close and near to God, as in the outer atrium, the order of creatures teaches us about the knowledge of the Creator and constancy, and in the inner atrium the true jubilee, in which all that is owed to us is forgiven, instructs us in theology and leads us to the Holy of Holies. It should also be noted that the inner atrium has several windows, not direct and equal, but oblique and narrow on the outside, and widening on the inside, so that through small openings we can penetrate into the interior, and reach the fullness of the brightest light that moves in the temple. Finally, after sixty and fifty cubits, and bedrooms, and porticos, and facades of the porticos, and many windows around, the carving or painting of palm trees is shown to us, so that as victors of the world, we may be worthy to see the palms of virtues.


<h2 id='tocuniq309'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 17 onwards) 'And he brought me to the outer court, and there were treasuries, and a paved floor made of stone in the court all around; there were thirty treasuries around the floor. And the floor in front of the gates, facing the interior court outside, was lower. And he measured the distance from the front of the lower gate to the front of the inner court outside, one hundred cubits to the east and to the north. Seventy: And he brought me to the inner court, and there were chambers, and the columns of the court all around, thirty chambers on the columns, and after the gates there were porticoes in the length of the gates facing the columns below.' And the width of the atrium was measured from the place that was under the outer gate to the inner gate, under the outer gate that faced the outside, one hundred cubits long, and it inclined towards the east. For the thirty chambers, which the Seventy translated as gazophylacia and cellars, as Aquila interpreted, Symmachus placed ἐξέδρας. And for the one hundred cubits of exterior space that extended to the eastern gate, the same number of cubits is stated in Hebrew, and it is said to extend to the north: but in the Seventy, the name of the north has been removed. So that man who had the measuring line of masons in his hand, and the measuring reed, and stood in the gate, showed in his vision, among other things, after the courtyard of sixty cubits, and another vestibule of the inner gate which was fifty cubits long, he brought out the prophet to the outer courtyard, or as it is written in the Septuagint, he brought him into the inner courtyard. And I am quite amazed, according to the literal interpretation and the Septuagint, how after the outer courtyards, which measured sixty and fifty cubits, there is an inner courtyard that extends in width one hundred cubits: unless perhaps, in a mystical and progressive sense, the inner teachings are broader for those who enter. But upon entering the inner courtyard, or being led to the outer courtyard, as is described in Hebrew, he immediately saw thirty chambers or storerooms, or as Symmachus interprets, exedrae, which had been prepared for the dwelling of the Levites and priests, and the floor adorned with living stones or intercolumns, in order to show that the inner or outer courtyard had an arrangement of columns in front of the doors, and a floor in front of the gates, or a portico behind the gates. In these porticoes I believe that the columns were arranged in order, so that there were porticoes in front of the treasury, and columns supporting the porticoes in the fronts of the porticoes. The pavement, which was laid with stones, extended in front of the atrium porticoes, lower in the ascent of the porticoes, and had the same length as the building of the chambers. And the same man measured, in whose hand was a measuring line and a reed, from the face of the lower gate, or as the Seventy interpret, the outer gate, to the front of the atrium or the inner gate, one hundred cubits to the east, and as it is said in Hebrew, and to the north. From which we understand the Gospel that is narrated by the Savior (Matthew XV), about sowing seeds in good soil, which multiplies fruits according to the variety of virtues in thirtyfold, sixtyfold, and hundredfold. This prophecy of this place is fulfilled by these thirty, sixty, and hundred numbers, so that we may be able to reach perfect knowledge through these stages. Only in such a way that the fiftieth number leads us to the inner parts of the Church, which, after the completion of the Sabbath of the seven weeks, burst forth into the day of resurrection. But they are called gazophylacia, which are full of spiritual riches, as it is written: The redemption of a man's soul is his own wealth (Prov. 13:8). On this Paul the Apostle also congratulates his disciples, that they are full of all speech and all knowledge (Phil. 1:). But in the Persian language, treasuries are called 'gaza'. Or certainly the chambers, which are called παστοφόρια in Greek, show the rooms prepared for the arrival of the bridegroom, which were in the number of thirty, in order to demonstrate the complete age of the inhabitants. And the pavement was laid with stone: so that the feet of those who dwell in sin might not be polluted by mud, and earth, and the dust of sinners; but that they might walk upon living stones, with which the temple of God is built: Whether there were intercolumniations before the doors of the chambers, which supported the building placed on top. These are the pillars, of which also the Apostle Paul writes: They gave to me and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship, James and John that seemed to be pillars (Gal. II, 9). And in another place: Column and buttress of truth (I Tim. III, 15). And in the Apocalypse of John we read: He who conquers, I will make him a pillar in the temple of my God, and he shall never go out of it (Apoc. III, 12). Therefore, the pavement that was in front of the gates, of which we have already spoken, or the portico behind the gates, which protected the inhabitants of the rooms from the rain, was lower. For those things that are lower are always placed in higher places, so that we may be able to reach by ascent and steps the mystical and secret things, and those full of spiritual riches." } And the number in the ten is full and perfect in its set of ten, which also multiplies the seed of Isaac by a hundredfold (Genesis 26). But because he was in a foreign land, he could still say: I am a stranger, and a wanderer like all my fathers (Psalm 38:13). It is said that he sowed barley and harvested a hundredfold (Matthew 13, John 12), before the grain of wheat had died in the ground, which would produce many crops. And the hunger of the Jewish people to hear the word of God was satisfied with the bread that came down from heaven (Amos 8, John 6). However, how one hundred cubits were not only to the Eastern gate, but also to the Northern gate, the following testimony will demonstrate.

<h2 id='tocuniq310'>(Vers. 20, 21.)</h2>

(Verse 20, 21) The gate that faced the way of the north of the outer court was measured in length and width, and it had three chambers on either side, and the front and vestibule were of the same size as the front gate, measuring 50 cubits in length and 25 cubits in width. Its windows, vestibule, and carvings were of the same size as the gate that faced east. There were seven steps in its ascent, and a vestibule before it. And the gate of the inner court was opposite the gate of the north and the east. And he measured from gate to gate one hundred cubits. Seventy: And he brought me to the north, and behold, there was a gate that faced the outer court. And he measured it in length, and in width, and its threshold was three cubits on this side and three cubits on that side, and its height was five cubits, and its doorposts were a palm in width (which is not found in Hebrew). And the measurement of the gate that faced the east was fifty cubits in length and twenty-five cubits in width. And its windows, and its porches, and its palm trees were like the gate that faced the east; and there were seven steps leading up to it, and its porches were on the inside, and it had a gate that faced the inner court facing north (and which in Hebrew is not found, as the gate that faces east). And the outer court was measured from gate to gate, one hundred cubits: What the Hebrew words thee, and elau, and elamoth signify, we have already explained more fully: but our translation will now teach their comparison. Now the man whose measuring line was in his hand, the door of the outer court that faces north, he brought the prophet in through the door that faces north to the outer court. It should be noted that he is first brought in through the door that faces north, secondly, through the door that faces south, and thirdly, through the eastern door. For from the north evil breaks forth on the inhabitants of the land (Jeremiah 1:14). And it is clear that one who is a resident of the land, and not a stranger or a foreigner, is exposed to the javelins of one who comes from the north, whose javelins are set ablaze, which, as the Apostle says, are extinguished by the shield of faith (Ephesians 6). And to the north is called the outer courtyard, but to the south, that is, to the south, not the outer courtyard, but the inner courtyard. For the Scripture says: And it led me to the inner courtyard to the South gate, which is also found written similarly in the Eastern courtyard. For the first one entered with strength, treading on the North with his feet, and after fifty-one, 481 and twenty-five, reaching the top of the hundred: then being led to the South side and expelling the cold of the North: and then coming to perfect strength, that is, to the Eastern gate, in which the sun of justice rises, and through which only the high priest enters. And this must be observed, that although there are four cardinal directions, no mention is made of the Western gate, which is written at the beginning of the sixty-seventh psalm: Make a way for him who ascends from the West, his name is the Lord (Psalm 7:5); so that after we have prepared a way for the Lord and fulfilled what John the Baptist proclaims in the wilderness: Prepare the way for the Lord, make his paths straight (Matthew 3:3), we may be able to hear what is said at the end of the same psalm: Sing to God, sing praises to the Lord, who ascends above the highest heavens to the East (Psalm 68:33). But what is said of the three chambers here and three chambers there teaches that both the letter and the spirit, and both understanding and tropology, pertain to the sacraments of the Trinity. And that which is said, 'And its front and vestibule according to the measure of the previous gate,' signifies the Eastern gate, which is called first not by order but by merit. And it had, he says, fifty cubits in length and twenty-five in width, so that in fifty weeks after seven hebdomads eternal rest is demonstrated: stretching throughout the day of resurrection to the kingdoms of heaven, in which true rest is. But in twenty-five, as we have already mentioned, let the measurement of the five senses be preserved by the five orders of the square, of which one is adapted to length and the other to width; so that in length there may be rest and delight in a more sacred science, and in width there may be a demonstration of the present things that pertain to the senses. And it is implied: And its windows, and vestibules, and sculptures, or as the Seventy added, palms, were according to the measurement of the gate that looked toward the East, this is subtly indicated, that whoever is positioned at the entrance of virtues may have entered three and three chambers, and may recognize the front and vestibule of the measurement of the former gate, and proceed to those things, and behold what has been most fully contained in the Eastern gate. Furthermore, what follows: And there were seven steps to its ascent, and a vestibule in front of it, or inside, it has this meaning, that through the seven steps of the week, and the lamps that are lit from the face of the North, and the ceremonies of the Jews, for which God gave commandments that are not good, and the justifications in which they do not live, we climb to higher things and to its vestibule, that is, its gates, for which the Seventy Elders translated. The vestibule before the gate is both inward and outward. There is not only one gate of the North, which is called the outer gate, but also another gate within, which resembles the gate of the East, as the Seventy have made more manifest. And the inner gate of the court faces the gate of the North, just as the gate that faced the East did. And the measurement was from the outer gate of the North to its inner gate, one hundred cubits: so that departing from the outer gate, we may come to the inner gate by these as it were steps and measurements, the secret of whose number has been mentioned above.


<h2 id='tocuniq311'>(Vers 24 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 24 onwards) 'And he brought me to the south gate, and behold, there was a gate that faced south. And its front and vestibule were measured according to the higher measurements, and it had windows and vestibules all around, like the other windows. Its length was fifty cubits and its width twenty-five cubits, and there were seven steps leading up to it, and there was a vestibule before its doors, and carved palm trees on its front, one on each side.' And the gate of the inner court facing south measured from gate to gate one hundred cubits. Then he brought me into the inner court by the south gate, and he measured the south gate according to the same measurements. Its rooms, its posts, and its vestibule were of the same measurements. And there were windows in it and in its vestibule all around, fifty cubits long and twenty-five cubits wide. And a vestibule of twenty-five cubits in length, and five cubits in width. And its vestibule faced the outer court, and its columns were in front, and it had eight steps by which one could ascend to it.» 483 Seventy agree in the same words, except thee, elau, and elamoth, and elam, for which ulam is used in Hebrew. Thee, however, is interpreted as threshold or front; elau, around it or supports; elamoth, gateways or vestibules; ulam means entrance, that is, before the doors. But what we have placed next to the Hebrew: And the vestibule, or πρόπυλον, in a circle of twenty-five cubits in length, and five cubits in width, is not found in the Septuagint. But it is also to be noted that in the south gate according to the Septuagint it is not called a road, but simply: and he led me to the south, and behold, a gate facing south. Therefore, through each entrance Ezekiel, whom God strengthened, for this is the meaning of his name, is led, and from the north gate he passes to the southern gate, whose fronts, and thresholds τροπύλαια, or vestibules, and windows around had similar measurements, fifty cubits in length and twenty-five cubits in width, and it was ascended to by seven steps, that is, to the southern gate, and its vestibule, that is, elamoth, before its doors, and there were also two carved palms, of which we have spoken in the gate of the northern region. And let this be sufficient to remind, that whatever is placed there, according to a lower intelligence, that is, according to the literal sense, we understand at the southern gate according to the spiritual sense. For in the same lines, both history and tropology run: but the former is humble, the latter sublime: the former clings to the earth, the latter soars to the heavens. And all things were filled with light around through the windows. For each πρόβλημα has its own limits, and through it the light proper to the believing soul enters: especially if the length of his life, that is, fifty years, has been prolonged by the mystery of a jubilee, and has been able to reach the breadth of a more divine sense. In this latitude and on these streets wisdom confidently prevails, and with a lofty voice, it cries out: it enters by seven steps, that it may reach the vestibule, and by the palms of its purpose and efforts, it may hold eternal victory. And lest we think that there is only one atrium to the south, about the second atrium it is said: And the door of the inner atrium is on the 484th street to the south, and it is measured from the door to the gate on the southern street a hundred cubits; so that after the weeks and sacraments of the old instrument, it may reach good soil and the grace of the Gospel. Not only is there a second atrium in the southern gate, but also a third, about which it is now said: 'And he brought me into the inner atrium at the southern gate, and measured the gate according to the upper measures, etc. For each atrium has its own measures and arrangements, and in these measures there is a different grace, as we know the same things differently at the beginning, in progress, and at the end. However, what is not found in the Septuagint, and the vestibule, or πρόπυλον, in a circular shape, with a length of twenty-five cubits and a width of five cubits, seems to raise a question, because it is not mentioned in the old interpretation, how twenty-five cubits and five are placed after the progress of the third step.' But it removes the ambiguity what follows: And its entrance to the outer courtyard: and its palms on the front; so that this courtyard, which had a length of twenty-five cubits, and a width of five, is not of the inner courtyard, but of the outer courtyard, so that it possesses the width of the previous courtyard, that is, twenty-five cubits, and holds a length of the outer courtyard, and a width of five cubits. These measurements, that is, twenty-five and five, we refer to the same senses, namely, sight, hearing, taste, smell, and touch. And if we ascend to higher things, we double them five times and make them spiritual from bodily senses, as it is said: Lift up your eyes and see that the fields are already white for harvest (John 4:35), And: He who has ears to hear, let him hear (Luke 8:8). And: Taste and see that the Lord is good (Psalm 34:8). And: We are the sweet odor of Christ to God in those who believe (2 Corinthians 2:15). And in the Epistle of John it is said: That which we have heard and seen, and our hands have touched, about the Word of life (1 John 1:1). And finally, just as in the northern region seven degrees are not sufficient, but after seven comes the number eight, so we transition from the Synagogue to the Church, from the old testament to the new, from earthly things to heavenly things.


<h2 id='tocuniq312'>(Vers. 28 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 28 seqq.) And he led me into the inner courtyard through the Eastern gate, and he measured the gate according to the upper measurements; its chambers, its façade, and its vestibule as above, and its windows and vestibules all around, with a length of fifty cubits and a width of twenty-five cubits. And its vestibule, that is, the outer courtyard" (for which the LXX and Symmachus have put "inner"), "and carved palm trees on its façade on both sides, and an ascent of eight steps. » From the Northern side, where only seven steps were ascended into the atrium, one passes to the Southern gate and the atrium of the same side, which is ascended not only by seven, as before, but by eight steps: namely, that we may pass from the old to the new; and to speak more clearly, that we may come through the patriarchs and prophets to the apostles: so that in one week there may be the hebdomad, and in the other, the octave. But now it comes to the last, or rather to the highest, and introduces the prophet by the way of the inner gate, or through the atrium, to which one goes by the way of the East. In this place, the way is only known by the road that says: I am the way, the truth, and the life (John 14:6) in the Eastern part, so that we may understand that in the Northern and Southern regions it is completely silent. Through Him we come to the Father, and it is written about Him: Blessed are the undefiled in the way (Psalm 119:1), who do not perceive anything of Christ as sinister, but their faith is pure and not polluted by the filth of heretics. And the number of chambers, fronts, vestibules, windows, and their respective measurements of length and width are the same: namely, fifty and twenty-five cubits, preserving the sacredness, and the vestibule of its gate or inner court, which is placed on the outside according to the Hebrew, so that all things may be kept enclosed in the Eastern light, according to what is written: Nor is there anyone who can hide from its heat (Psalm XIX, 7). But if we understand the atrium both externally and internally, we must understand that God is both surrounding and indwelling, as the prophet says: 'He holds the heavens in the palm of His hand, and the earth in His fist' (Isaiah 40:12), so that all things are seen to be encompassed by Him. And again: 'Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool' (Isaiah 66:1), so that He is believed to be present within all things, according to that Virgilian verse (Aeneid, Book VI).

At the beginning, the sky and the earth, and the flowing fields, and the shining globe of the moon, and the stars of Titan, the spirit drives from within: it infuses all through the limbs, the mind moves the mass, and mingles itself with the great body.

And when, through the weapons of justice, on the right and on the left, through glory and shame, through good and bad reputation, through praise and blame, we have achieved victory over this world (2 Corinthians 6): then palms are given to us on both sides, which neither joys nor sorrows nor successes nor adversities have changed; and not through seven (or rather eight) steps, as in the northern region, nor through seven and eight, as in the southern region, but only through eight (or rather seven) steps do we ascend to the highest point; whereby the number eight is sufficient for us, that is, the sacrament of the Gospel; so that we can say, according to the Apostle: Even though we knew Christ according to the flesh, yet now we no longer know Him (2 Corinthians 5:16), and it is understood 'according to the flesh'.


<h2 id='tocuniq313'>(Vers. 35 seqq.)</h2>

(v. 35 onwards) 'And he brought me to the gate that faces north, and measured its upper chambers, its front, its vestibule, and its windows all around: its length was fifty cubits and its width twenty-five cubits. Its vestibule faced the outer court, and palm tree decorations were on its front, on both sides, and its ascent had eight steps.' And for each treasury there is a door in the gates (in the Vulgate, fronts): there they shall wash the burnt offering. And in the vestibule of the gate, on this side and on that side, there are two tables, on which the burnt offering, and the sin offering, and the guilt offering shall be sacrificed. And on the outer side, which goes up to the gate that faces north, there are two tables, and on the other side before the vestibule of the gate, there are two tables. Four tables on this side, and four tables on that side: on the sides of the gate, there were eight tables, on which they would sacrifice (in the Vulgate, would sacrifice): but four tables were built for the burnt offering of square stones, with a length of one and a half cubits, and a width of one and a half cubits, and a height of one cubit, on which they would place (in the Vulgate, they would place) the vessels in which the burnt offering and the victims are sacrificed. And their lips were one palm in circumference, turned inward all around; and on the tables were the offerings of meat.» In this testimony, the Hebrew Truth is greatly different from the edition of the Seventy Interpreters. For what we have said: There they shall wash the burnt offering, and in the vestibule there are two tables here, and again: So that the burnt offering and the sin offering may be offered on them, it is not found in the Seventy [version]: but it is added in many manuscripts from Theodotion. Again, when we said: And their lips were turned inward in a circle of one palm, they transferred it to seventy, and having the shape of a false god inward in a circle. Whether this word is Hebrew or Greek, we do not know, except only that for 'false god,' Symmachus and Theodotion translated it as 'lips'; the first edition of Aquila, with the plural form, 'epistases'; the second edition translated it as 'lips': for which in Hebrew it is written Asephathaim(). And where we have spoken, on the tables however the meats of the offering, the Seventy put from their own (translation), and on the tables (they) covered from above, that they may be protected from rain and drought. However, what they have produced in Hebrew names, Thee, and Elau, and Elalamoth, and Aelam, what they signify, and we have warned above, and our translation can show in turn: And it is not necessary to frequently warn the reader about this, and to distrust his wisdom and diligence. Therefore, it is introduced again to the gate that looked towards the North: but not as before to the outer courtyard, but to the inner one. For in what is said afterwards: Its vestibule looked towards the outer courtyard, it is shown that this courtyard was inside. Through which the progress of the one entering is shown; as in each place there are appropriate names and measurements, and the windows all around are full of light, showing the whole extent of knowledge, and through fifty and twenty-five cubits the sacraments of divine senses and remission are placed, as we see in the vestibule of the inner courtyard: contemplating the knowledge of the past and present, through which we come to the twofold palms and victories, and understand the mysteries of the eight degrees, having entered the treasuries, in which the riches of the temple are contained, and our prayers are cleansed from every stain of sin; and on either side of the tables two are placed, so that the first offering may be sacrificed.

The vigilant herdsman follows his father's custom, and the barking Gesacus, and the barking Sidonian, and so on. That the sacred fire may assume the whole, first for sin, and finally for ignorance: either because we have committed it knowingly, or unknowingly. On the outer side also, next to the Seventy, there was a stream made by the workman, which carried away the ashes of the burnt offerings, and the foulness of the flesh on the outside: whether there were two altars, and on the other side of the vestibule of the same gate were two altars, that is, four on each side, four on this side and four on that side, and behind, or on the side of them were eight other altars: so that they make sixteen altars together: by this number the mysteries of the prophets are shown, so that whatever we offer through the Gospel's proclamation, we confirm by their prophecies. And there are four tables made of square stones, and these themselves are for sacrifice and burnt offering. These are living stones that roll upon the earth and they have with them a corner stone, by which the walls of the old and new Instruments are contained. And the number four represents the sacraments of the Gospel, having a length and width of one and a half cubit, meaning, in square form, which, when joined together, make three cubits, which have one cubit in height; so that the mysteries of the Trinity may preserve the measurement of divine majesty, as the Lord says to the disciples: Go, baptize all nations in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit (Matthew 28:19). But the name of God, as it were, is of one cubit in height, which encompasses 489 three properties, and always receives the holocaust offering of our oblations. Moreover, on top of these four tables made of living stones, the length, width, and height of which are described, vessels are placed in which the holocaust of the martyrs is sacrificed, of whom it is said: Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of his saints (Ps. 116:15); and their victims, who sacrifice their souls to the Lord with continence and the holiness of the body. I believe that the name of these tables is mentioned in the Gospel of Matthew, Luke, Mark, and John, where a crown is bent inwardly over their circumference, enclosing the margins, so as to hold the sacrifices inside and not allow them to flow around freely. It also held the meat offerings, or as translated by the Septuagint: 'And the tables themselves were covered from above, because of the violence of the rain and the excessive dryness of the summer sun, so that the meat placed on top could say with the prophet: 'The sun shall not strike us by day, nor the moon by night' (Ps. 120:6)." } One of these, with excessive rain and storms, dissolves offerings of tribulations; the other, with intense heat of persecutions, dries up whatever has been offered. Forgive, reader, the difficulty of the passages: or if you can find something better, teach: we gladly learn what we do not know.

<h2 id='tocuniq314'>(Vers. 44 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 44 and following) 'And outside the front gate of the treasury of the singers in the inner court, which was on the side of the gate facing north, and their faces were towards the south: one on the side of the east gate, which faced the way of the north. And he said to me: 'This is the treasury that faces the south, for the priests who keep watch at the temple. And the treasury that faces the way of the north shall be for the priests who keep watch at the altar: These are the sons of Zadok who approach from the sons of Levi to the Lord, to minister to him.' And he measured the atrium in length one hundred cubits, and in width one hundred cubits, squared, and the altar before the face of the temple. And he brought me into the vestibule of the temple: and he measured the vestibule five cubits on this side, and five cubits on that side: and the breadth of the gate three cubits on this side, and three cubits on that side. And the length of the vestibule twenty cubits, and the breadth eleven cubits, and they went up to it by eight steps, and the columns thereof (thus in the manuscripts. But the Vulgate has "were") on the front of them, one on this side, and another on that side. 490. Regarding the treasuries, the Seventy translated the exedrae. And that which we have said about the exedrae, or the treasuries of the singers, was omitted by them. Again, after the measurement of the vestibule of fifty cubits here and fifty cubits there, they added from their own, and the width of the gate is fourteen cubits, while in the Hebrew it is only mentioned as the width of three cubits here and three cubits there. I have reminded the reader of these things so that they may not be disturbed by the diversity of translations, but may be content with the Hebrew truth, especially in matters of the measurements of the temple. Therefore, after the wall, which the Septuagint translated as 'περίβολον' and which went around the entire temple in a square shape, we read about the prophet being led into the inner courtyard, and then to the North, and to the South, and to the Eastern gate, and again to the North. We have spoken about these things as best we could, and the previous discourse showed us the differences in names and measurements that we observed. The meaning of these, as briefly shown by the testimony of the Savior, is: 'In my Father's house are many mansions' (John 14:2). With these things being completed, he enters the temple, that is, the Holy of Holies, of which it is now said, and within the inner gate, the treasuries, or the singers' exedra. To them is that command given. Sing to the Lord a new song (Ps. XCV, 1). They cry out with the angels: Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace to people of good will (Luke II, 14). The inner courtyard was located on the side of the gate that looked toward the north, and toward the south, and toward the east; so that the singers of the Lord always remember, and those who are occupied in the office of angels, through whom they have reached the highest steps; and that they may carefully understand the mysteries of each place. Finally, that man whose pen and rope were in hand, having led the prophet into the inner courtyard which overlooks the southern road, spoke these words: 'This is the treasury or chamber; and as Theodotius established it, it is the chamber that is separate for the dwelling of the priests, who keep watch in the guard posts of the temple. Furthermore, the treasury that overlooks the northern road will be for the priests who keep watch for the service of the altar.' In which it should be noted that the priests to whom the custody of the temple is delegated dwell in the south treasury, which overlooks the southern road where the light is fullest. And those who stand guard at the altar, where the sacrifices for sin are offered, should dwell in the north treasury, which overlooks the northern road and where those coming from the north offer sacrifices for their sins, desiring to receive salvation. Both of these groups, serving the Lord in their respective duties, are called sons of Zadok, which means just or righteous, for they justify the Almighty God, as it is written: The Lord is just and loves justice; his countenance beholds equity (Psalm 10:8). But these are the sons of Sadoc, of the sons of Levi, who is interpreted as 'assumed': and they themselves are assumed by the Lord, so that they may approach Him, and it is not said of them alone, as of Moses: Moses approached the Lord; but also all those who serve and minister to Him are said to draw near to the Lord. But this man who brought Ezekiel into the inner court, and so to speak, to the Holy of Holies, measured the court itself, in which there were two chambers or treasuries assigned to the temple guards, or the dwellings of the altar, and he found it to be two hundred cubits in length and in width, forming a square: so that the priests of God who serve in ministry, and who have entered through a narrow and restricted way, may have spacious walkways and may dwell in a perfect and complete number of virtues. And in the atrium itself there was an altar before the face of the temple, so that the prayer of the saints to God never ceases. The aforementioned man also brought Ezekiel into the vestibule, or πρόπυλον of the temple, which was measured five cubits from here and five cubits from there, for the one who was brought in had been instructed in divine senses and knew neither right nor left, but entered by the royal way. And the width of the gate itself, through which there was an entrance to the vestibule of the temple, measured three cubits from here to there. In the observance of the Holy Scriptures, it is proper not to say 'right' or 'left' in order not to mention anything sinister in the Holy of Holies, but rather 'from here' and 'from there', that is, from both sides. And immediately the discerning reader understands that the number three pertains to the mystery of the Trinity, which is the gate for those who approach God, for the Father is in the Son, and the Son is in the Father, and the Holy Spirit is in both. The number three is the one door of those who, after the baptism of the Trinity, come to salvation. But what follows: The length of the vestibule is twenty cubits, and the width is eleven cubits, seems to raise the question of how the dual number, which refers to two decades, and the eleventh, which seems to have one less, can be said to complete the sacred number of twelve in the vestibule of the temple. Most people solve this as follows: Although the priests are holy and placed in the ministries of the temple, and offer daily sacrifices to Christ: nevertheless, because they dwell in this mortal and fragile body, subject to illnesses and vices, they have the number twenty and eleven. Whereas the Apostle says: 'Wretched man that I am, who will deliver me from the body of this death?' (Rom. VII, 24). Not that we believe, according to the most savage heresy, that bodies are to be abolished; but that it is ours to put on, not to strip off, and to receive immortality in this mortal state, and to put on incorruption in this corruptible state. However, what follows, 'And he ascended by eight degrees to it' (I Cor. XV), that is, to the inner gate, presents a great difficulty to those who know the Hebrew language. Finally, Symmachus, whom we have followed in this place, placed eight steps: Seventy, ten; Theodotion and Aquila's second edition, eleven; however, the first edition did not indicate a number, but simply said, and the steps by which it was ascended: so that either according to the custom of the previous gates, we understand eight steps, as Symmachus understood, or certainly those which the inner gate had, whose number Scripture did not mention (for which in Hebrew it is written, Urob (), that is, width, Aste (), Esre (). But if it is read this way, undecim signifies: 493; but if we read it as Esre, which means ten, we do not read Eser (ten), but a pronoun. These may seem like delusions to experts in the Hebrew language, but we are not now writing about controversies or speeches, which often involve the arrangement of words, but rather explanations and commentaries on Hebrew books. But let us return to what we started. The perfect number, whether eight or ten steps, or eleven as we have already mentioned, is ascended to the gate of the holy ones, on the front of which there were columns, one on this side and another on that side. He did not say 'two' so as not to incur a dual number, but 'one and one,' which is a perfect number and imitates the unity of God. These were the two pillars, of which it is also said in the Apocalypse: 'He who conquers, I will make him a pillar in the temple of my God, and he shall go out no more' (Rev. 3:12). And Peter and John are called the pillars of the Church (Gal. 2), through whom we enter into the Holy of Holies, and by whose doctrine our entrance to Christ is made.


<h2 id='tocuniq315'>(Cap. XLI.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter XLI - Verses 1 and following) 'And he brought me into the temple and measured the front of the six cubits wide on one side and the front of the six cubits wide on the other side, the width of the tabernacle. And the width of the gate was ten cubits, and the sides (or shoulders) of the gate were five cubits on one side and five cubits on the other side. And he measured its length of forty cubits and its width of twenty cubits.' After many mysteries and various entrances, and the peculiarities of each place, finally, at last, a man came, whose line was that of a mason, and a measuring rod in his hand, he brought the prophet Ezekiel into the temple and measured the front of the temple. For which reason, the Septuagint translated it as 'threshold', and Theodotian as 'post', and Symmachus as 'entrance'. And on both sides the breadth of the tabernacle was six cubits, containing the symbol of all creatures: for in six days the world was made. Through the knowledge of which we enter into the temple of God, and by the order and constancy of creatures we come to know the Creator. And the breadth of the gate of the temple was ten cubits, which is a sacred and perfect number, and in which, on the seventh month, on the tenth day of the month, there is fasting and propitiation. On the tenth day of the first month, which is called Nisan, the lamb is taken for sacrifice and the preparation of the Passover. Then, on the seventh month, tithes are offered in the storehouses of God, or, as Scripture commonly refers to them, winepresses. Hence the Apostle says: 'Be ye also enlarged' (2 Corinthians 6), meaning that after entering the temple through ten cubit-wide gates, the sides of the gates themselves, or as it is properly said in Hebrew, the shoulders, are measured, which always pertain to works. And Isachar desired the good (Gen. XLIX), resting among the clergy, and seeing rest, because it is good, and the land, because it is fertile, he placed his shoulder to the work, and became a farmer. And in the vestment of the high priest, the shoulder piece is bound to the breastplate, so that the works of reason may be united, and the man of the Church can say: I have understood from your commandments (Ps. CXVIII, 104). The gates of the shoulders, on either side, had five porches, so that through earthly and divine senses, about which we have often written, we may enter the innermost part of the temple, whose measurements are forty cubits in length and twenty cubits in width, or more accurately, the length and width of the gates: because he had spoken only of the width and shoulders above. But there is no doubt that the number which makes 20800, which is close to eighty, is significant. Hence in Ecclesiastes it is commanded: Give a portion to seven and also to eight (Eccl. XI, 2). I am aware that there has been frequent discussion about the mystery of this number, whether it is because through tribulations and hardships of this world we enter into the sanctuary of the Lord, thus the gate had a length of forty cubits, a number always associated with labor. Wherefore both Moses and Elias fasted forty days, not eating bread, nor drinking water, as it is written, Deuteronomy 9, 3 Kings 19. Likewise, the people of Israel were vexed and tried for forty years in the wilderness, and after many labors, entered the land of promise. And the Lord and Savior, in the weakness of assumed flesh, was tempted for forty days in the wilderness, so that after victory, angels might come and minister to Him, as it is written, Matthew 4. But when we are able to say with the Apostle through tribulations and distress: In all things we suffer tribulation, but are not crushed, 2 Corinthians 4. And with the Prophet: In tribulation, Thou hast made me wide, Psalm 4. Then for us the widest entrance is opened, which has a width of twenty cubits, so that after overcoming the struggles and earthly things, which themselves are the number two, we may enter the innermost parts of the temple and hear the Lord commanding His disciples: Have confidence, I have overcome the world, John 16." }


<h2 id='tocuniq316'>(Vers. 3, 4.)</h2>

(Verse 3, 4.) And he entered inside (or into the inner courtyard) and measured the front (or threshold) of the gate, two cubits, and the gate, six (alternative: ten) cubits, and the width of the gate, seven cubits (or the width of the gateposts, seven cubits on either side). And he measured its (or the doors') length, twenty cubits, and its width, twenty cubits before the face of the temple. And he said to me: This is the Most Holy Place. Let us make progress, always a greater progress is opening up for us. Therefore, after entering the temple, we enter again inside, or as the Seventy translated, the inner courtyard, in front of which, or Ael, instead of Symmachus, around the gate, Theodotion the Aelam, the Hebrew Ul (), the entrance Aquila, we interpret as 'the front'. There were two cubits: so that according to the higher sense we enter through the dual number to that place where the Holy of Holies is. And the gate itself was six cubits wide, through which we entered and obtained eternal rest, which is shown in the number seven. For this reason, the Seventy translated it, and placed a width of seven cubits on both sides of the gate, in Hebrew and other editions only once, seven cubits, on the width of the gate. But what follows: And its length was measured, or as the Seventy translated, the doors were twenty cubits, for which in most codices forty are contained according to the Seventy, it also signifies a width of twenty cubits in front of the face of the temple, that which always meets us as a measure of past labor and struggle before the face and entrance of the temple. For just as the number duplex possesses a certain ratio in individual numbers, so do two have the same ratio in tens. And this should be considered, that entering inward through the gate of two cubits in front, and having six cubits, and seven on each side in width, and twenty cubits in length, and 496 as many in the very doors of the temple, let the prophet be taught what that place is, or by what name it is called. For he said to me: This is the Holy of Holies. But if before the temple, or as Scripture calls it, before the face of the Holy of Holies, how great a beatitude should we consider in the innermost parts of the temple! About which the prophet speaks: This is my labor in my sight, until I enter into the sanctuary of God, and understand their last things (Ps. LXXVII, 16, 17). But it is also worth noting that in the description of the tabernacle, they are called Holy of Holies, in the plural number; here, however, it is Holy of Holies, in the singular number, so that after the sacred things we come to the holy things: just as after many songs we come to the Song of Songs, which is the song of all songs, and in which, as we sing, we are joined in embrace with the Bridegroom.


<h2 id='tocuniq317'>(Vers. 5 seqq.)</h2>

(v. 5-6) And he measured the wall of the house, six cubits wide; and the width of each side chamber, four cubits, all around the house on every side. The side chambers were in three stories, one above the other, thirty chambers in each story; they rested on ledges which were for the side chambers all around, that they might be supported, but not fastened to the wall of the temple. As one went up from story to story, each story was wider than the one below, corresponding to the structure of the house, and therefore ascending in a spiral running around the house; ascending round and round, from the lowest story to the highest, the rooms were wider at every successive level, because the structure of the house was such that the greater were the increments of the height, the greater was the width." } Therefore, the temple was wider in the upper parts, and thus, from the lower parts, it was ascended to the upper parts in the middle, and from the middle to the narrower parts and Thrael. However, what is placed in the Septuagint, 'And from the middle to the narrower parts', that is, to three chambers, and Thrael, is not found in Hebrew. Instead of Thrael (which I do not know what it means, for it is not found in Hebrew), it is read among them, the Uraithi (), which both we and others have translated, and I saw that it follows the order of the testimony.


<h2 id='tocuniq318'>(Vers. 8 seqq.)</h2>

(Verset 8 et suivants) 'And I saw in the house a height all around, with foundations of six cubits in size, and a width on the outside wall of five cubits. And the interior of the house had side chambers all around, with a width of twenty cubits around the house on every side. And there were doors for the side chambers toward the prayer area, one door toward the north and one door toward the south. And the width of the prayer area was five cubits all around.' (which is not included in the Septuagint). And the building that was separate and facing the road towards the sea, was seventy cubits wide: but the wall of the building was five cubits wide all around, and its length was ninety cubits. After reaching the Holy of Holies, which we mentioned above, that venerable man measured the wall of the Holy of Holies, which, because of the structure of the world and every visible creature, which was created in six days, had a height of six cubits and a width of one cubit on each side, not on one side, but all around. But the width of the house all around was four cubits, so as to represent the four elements from which all things are composed, especially the human bodies which the holy ones fight against and subject their souls to the power, deserving to enter the interior and know the secrets of the Lord. The sides of the house that were around it, and were separated from the walls of the temple by a space of four cubits, were joined together: so that one side would touch the other side, and have in length not thirty-three cubits, but twice thirty-three, that is, sixty-six. In the book of Leviticus, the Old Testament speaks of the birth of a child, after seven days by the sea, and the mother and the child must wait for thirty-three days to be purified (Lev. XII). However, if the child is a female, the number is doubled, that is, sixty-six days. And because, in order to enter the holy of holies, we need not only the first birth but also a second, to be born in the flesh and be reborn in the spirit: therefore, the number is not sixty-six but twice thirty-three, as both births are owed to God the Creator and His mercy, and they surround the two sides of the house that support the temple building with a double wall. And what follows according to the Hebrew: 'And there were certain prominences that would come out through the wall of the house on the sides all around, so that they would contain and not touch the wall of the temple,' that signifies that holy men burst forth from the wall of the temple in the multitude of believers, namely through all the sides around, and they hold the foundations of the Church, and yet do not touch the wall of the temple: only being content to have seen so much and from afar to have adored the unspeakable mysteries. For now we see through a glass darkly, and cannot fully touch and comprehend the truth. But that which was a square in shape, ascending upward in a spiral, and leading into the upper room of the temple in a circle: and therefore the temple was wider in the upper areas, and thus one ascended from the lower to the higher and middle parts: I believe it is clear to the reader, that those things which are below, namely fasting and self-control in eating, are always narrower, and gradually as we ascend to the highest things, a wider path is opened to us, and we are filled with what is written: In my distress you have enlarged me (Ps. 4:1). But we ascend to the upper room of the temple by a round and winding staircase, which, among all forms, is approved as more beautiful even by the philosophers of this age: while both the sky, and the sun, and the moon, and the other stars, and the point of the earth, in human bodies also, the eyes, as if other stars, and the shape of the head, which is the receptacle of all the senses, and the smooth fingers, and women, and arms, exhibit this roundness. Furthermore, I think that the upper room of the temple, which we ascend from lower to higher, is the same that Elias and Eliseus had in the book of Kings, and that Tabitha, which means 'gazelle' in Greek, and our damsel possessed in the Acts of the Apostles, who had reached the heights through her good works (1 Kings 17; 2 Kings 4; Acts 9; Acts 10). But the Apostle Peter, on whom the Lord established the foundations of the Church, surpassed the upper room and came to the roof, which is more significantly called 'δῶμα' in Greek, that is, the roof terrace: and he learned the mysteries of the Church, which were previously unknown to the world. The Savior also made the Passover in the upper room, and in a large and wide upper room, and having cleaned and prepared it from all filth, and having spread a spiritual banquet, where he handed over to his disciples the mystery of his body and blood, and left to us the eternal feast of the spotless lamb. And he added: And from the middle to the saddest, that is, the third upper rooms and Thrael, it seems to me that it should be marked with an obelus. For why is it necessary to discuss uncertain and unwritten things, when we should focus on the books that the Hebrews hold? It follows: 'And I saw in the temple a height founded on 499 cubits all around, with a span of six cubits; and on the outer side of the wall of the temple, a width of five cubits; and between the treasure chambers (which Symmachus calls exedrae) a width of twenty cubits all around the temple. These numbers show that by means of this world and earthly senses, and by means of the dual number of two decades, which relates to twenty, we not only deserve to ascend to the Holy of Holies and their rooms, but also to always remember that through the six days of our condition and the five senses, and through the twenty cubits of width, we ascend to the room of the temple, leaving behind earthly humility and the sense of the letter, and pass over to the summit of the Church, rejoicing in the fellowship of the Holy Spirit.' And the doorway, he says, of the side facing the north (Jer. 1:14), from which evil spreads over all the earth, and which the Lord promises to drive away from us, saying: And I will drive away the one who is from the north from you (Joel 2:20). And it is a beautiful place for prayer at the door facing the north, as the Apostle says (1 Thess. 5), let us pray without ceasing, and let us say with Jeremiah: Let not the pupil of my eye be silent (Lam. 2:18), either desiring to avoid present evils or giving thanks for past ones. For as long as we are in the tabernacle of this body, we groan and say: Wretched man that I am, who will deliver me from this body of death? (Rom. VII, 24). But there was also a door leading to the southern road, which itself had a place of prayer next to it in the Hebrew manner, extending five cubits all around. For after the cold of the North, we pass to the warmth of the South, and yet we again seek a place of prayer, at the door of the North, in order to escape dangers; in the South, to give thanks for what is past and to have a secure possession of victory. But the five cubits, which in this place indicate divine senses, by which we ascend from earthly things to higher things. And the building, he says, which was separate and turned towards the road facing the sea, was seventy cubits wide: so that after labors and dangers, and the waves and shipwrecks of this age, and the seventy years, about which Jeremiah writes, and Daniel, and Zachariah (Jeremiah 25 and 29; Daniel 9, Zechariah 9); but also the lawful Sabbaths of the seven decades we attain 500: so that we may have eternal rest, and through the five cubits in width we may come to a length of ninety cubits: in which age Sarah gave birth to a son according to the promise, who, at the age of ninety years, that is, nine decades, Isaac was born, joined to Abraham, who had reached one hundred years, that is, ten decades, bearing a mystery. (Genesis 21) The following Scripture will show what the number signifies.

(Verse 13 and following) And the house was measured in length one hundred cubits. And the separate building, and its walls, were one hundred cubits in length. And the width of the front of the house, and that which was separate opposite the East, one hundred cubits. And the length of the building opposite its face, which was separate at the back, was one hundred cubits. And there was an outstanding (that is, prominent) projection on both sides of one hundred cubits. And there was an inner temple and vestibules of the courtyard." } Thresholds and slanting windows are displayed, forming a loop around each threshold, and a wooden floor surrounds the loop. The ground extends up to the windows, and the windows are closed. Above the doors, extending to the inner house, and outside, around every wall, inside and out, to the measure. Cherubim and palm trees are carved, with a palm tree between each cherub. Each cherub has the face of a man next to the palm tree on one side, and the face of a lion next to the palm tree on the other side. These carvings are throughout the entire house. From the ground up to the top of the entrance were carved cherubim and palm trees on the wall of the temple. The threshold was square. The appearance of the sanctuary was facing the appearance of the wooden altar, with a height of three cubits and a length of two cubits. And its angles, and its length, and its walls were wooden. Seventy cubits: And it was measured against the length of the house, which was one hundred cubits: and the remaining parts and separations and its walls, in the length of one hundred cubits: And the width against the face of the temple, and the remaining parts against one hundred cubits. And he measured the length of the wall separating the face of the others, which were behind the back of that house, and the rest from here and there a length of one hundred cubits. And the temple and the corners, and the outer Aela paved with wood, and three windows made like a net, for light to shine through, so that one could look through them. And the house, and those things which were close by, were paved with wood all around. And the floor, 501, and from the floor to the windows. And the windows were made in three layers, so that one could see through them: both to the inner and outer house, and through the entire surrounding wall on the inside and outside, with measurements and carvings of cherubim and palm trees between the cherubim. There were two cherubim faces: a human face towards one palm tree, and a lion face towards the other palm tree. The entire wall was carved all around, from the floor up to the cherubim's ceiling, with carved palm trees. And the sanctuary and the temple were opened on all four sides opposite the face of the saints: a vision like the appearance of a wooden altar: its height was three cubits, and its length two cubits: and its width two cubits: and it had horns, and its bases and walls were wooden. The word 'contra', which the Septuagint translated at the beginning of the testimony, where it is written: 'And he measured against the house', is not found in Hebrew, and therefore it should be marked with a dagger: so that it is more accurate and truer, and it was measured against the house with a length of one hundred cubits, and the rest. The Holy of Holies and the inner temple are described as having a length of ninety cubits and a width of three hundred cubits, which is the perfect number of ten decades. This is so that we may serve the Lord in mind, speech, and deeds, remembering the example of the Apostle who said: 'So that we may know the breadth and length and depth and height' (Ephesians 3:18). In Hebrew, the term 'separate structure' and its walls are interpreted by the Septuagint as separating and not attaching to the walls of the temple, but having their own nearby walls. The temple itself, including its corners and the porch, which is also called πρόπυλον or vestibule, was covered with wood, symbolizing wisdom. This recalls the wood of life located in paradise, as mentioned in the Scriptures (Gen. II). The windows were made like nets, resembling lattices, so that they would be closed with interlaced and decorated wooden shutters, and not with stone or glass. The Hebrew language refers to these as oblique windows, which were only present in three parts of the temple: on the right, on the left, and at the back, that is, to the south, north, and west. But the eastern part did not have windows, because it let in bright light from within, and all the interior of the temple was filled with the light of the doors, so that one could see inside through each window and hole in the barriers. And not only were the exterior surfaces covered in wood, but there was such an abundance of wood all around, that the floors and everything from the floor to the windows were connected with wood. The windows next to the Seventy were opened in three ways: so that when they were opened, a triple intelligence in the Temple of God would be revealed, according to what is said elsewhere: But you, describe them in three ways (Prov. 22:20). And through them, both the interior and the exterior are seen: so that we may know the invisible things that are within, and the visible things that are outside: so that one thing may show the mind, another the flesh, another the spiritual intelligence, and another the simple history, and through all the surrounding walls, both inside and outside, their measures were observed. For nothing is done without reason and measure in the temple of God, and especially in the holy of holies, which was made by God. The Cherubim were also carved, undoubtedly from wood, reaching from the floor to the windows, and the carvings were so well done that they appeared to be attached rather than sculpted. The Cherubim are interpreted as a multitude of knowledge. Therefore, inside the inner parts of the temple, after the multitude of knowledge, palm trees were carved, in which the sign of victory is, as the Apostle says: 'But I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus' (Philippians 3:14). What palm trees were between the Cherub and the Cherub, so that one Cherub would be surrounded on both sides by two palm trees. This Cherub did not, as we read in the beginning of this prophet, have four faces, namely, of a man, lion, calf, and eagle, but only two, that is, of a man and lion, of which the first pertains to reason, the following to fury, which is more significantly called θυμὸς in Greek.
