By fury, however, we mean not that which is close to disturbance and vice, but that which strengthens the softness of the mind and makes the spirit of the combatant stronger." } For in the beginning we are subject to concupiscence, which is related to the calf, because of earthly works; and there are other things that are carnal, others that are spiritual, of which the last is attributed to the eagle. But when we enter the holy of holies, and possess the inner chambers of the temple, we have no need for anything else but reason and fortitude, of which one is related to perception and prudence, the other to the perseverance of the soul. Therefore, every wall around the temple, from the floor to the ceiling, had cherubim and palms intricately carved: after which the sanctuary and temple were opened at the four corners opposite the face of the saints. For we first have a multitude of knowledge, through which we achieve victory over the enemy, and then a sanctuary and temple are opened to us, which has four corners, and a very strong position, and which is inclined in no direction. For it has the nature of a square measurement, to stand firm on its base, and in a mystical number, which is clear to a wise reader, it possesses the four elements from which everything is composed, solid and enduring. And they looked at everything in front of the face of the sanctuary: in front of which the sanctuary, or in which the sanctuary was, the appearance of a wooden altar three cubits high, two cubits long, two cubits wide, which, when joined together, make seven cubits. This altar had horns; and both its bases and walls, that is, its sides, were made of wood, in which the mysteries of the Holy Scriptures, human speech cannot explain: how the altar, in which the fire had to be kindled, namely the table of incense, should suffer nothing from the fire, but, so to speak, become purer through the fire. For just as the works of the saints, about which the Apostle writes: The fire will test the quality of each one's work (1 Corinthians 3:13), do not perish, but are made clearer through the fire, so also the wood of the altar, which is from the trees of paradise, is not consumed by nearby fire, but is made purer. And it is not surprising to believe this about the sanctuary, and the inner parts of the temple and the altar of incense, since even linen, which is a type of flax or has a resemblance to flax, the more it is burned, the cleaner it is found. Forgive, reader, the difficulty, and grant pardon to the poverty of understanding. For through oblique windows made in the manner of a net, and that are always closed, we can barely introduce the eye of our inner heart into the house, so that everything we perceive, we see in shadow and in image, and with the Apostle we cry out: O the depth of the riches of wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways are past finding out (Rom. XI, 13)! And: Who has known the mind of God (Isaiah XL, 13), except for he who is the angel of great counsel, and can reveal his mysteries to those worthy? Moreover, in Rome, they call the raised portions on the walls of dining rooms solaria, or Meniana from the one who first invented them, which some of the Greeks call ἐξώστρας.

<h2 id='tocuniq319'>(Vers. 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 onwards) And he spoke to me: This is the table before the Lord, and there were two doors in the temple and in the sanctuary, and in the two doors on each side there were two smaller doors that folded into each other. For there were two doors on each side of the larger doors, and in these temple doors there were carvings of Cherubim and palm trees, just as there were also carvings on the walls. Therefore, the wood on the front of the vestibule was thicker: on it, there were oblique windows, and palm tree designs on the shoulders of the vestibule, on both sides of the width and length of the walls of the house. In this place, the Septuagint edition disagrees greatly with the Hebrew truth. Hence, I will only point out that they have translated 'crassioribus lignis' as 'σπουδαῖα', which means necessary or worthy of care, and 'obliquis fenestris' as 'absconditas'. Also, at the end of the testimony, they have measured the 'laquearia superliminaris' or vestibule, and the 'latera domus compacta' or joined sides, which they called 'ἐζυγωμένα', and for which we can translate as of equal weight. Therefore, that man who had led the prophet into the hidden part of the temple, and had shown him among other things a wooden altar, which had both angles and horns according to the LXX, and had wooden walls, said to him: This altar that you behold is the table before the Lord, which burns in the likeness of a ruby and is not consumed; concerning which the holy one speaks to God: You have prepared a table before me, against those who afflict me (Ps. XXII, 5). There were also two doors in the temple and in the sanctuary itself, through which the sacraments of both instruments are shown, and in the two doors on each side there were two small doors that folded inward upon themselves: so that in the history you may have a spiritual understanding, and in the tropology the truth of the history, of which each one requires the other, and if one is lacking, knowledge is imperfect. What follows, that there were two doors on each side of the doors, is clear according to the letter. For in the larger dining rooms, it is customary for two to stick together and join each other so that the main entrance is not closed or opened with two large doors, but with four smaller ones. In these doorways of the temple, or holy of holies, there were carved cherubim, about which we have already spoken, and sculptures of palm trees, so that after a multitude of knowledge, victory would be offered to those entering. These sculptures of palm trees were also present on all the walls of the temple. And the reasons why the Cherubim were carved on the very doors, and the likenesses of palm trees were carved out. And also why the woods in the vestibule of the outer gate were thicker, so that they might have strength and be able to receive carvings. And beautifully, according to spiritual understanding, the doors are stronger and carved, so that they may have strength and beauty, so that no one can break into the holy of holies like Uzziah and claim priesthood for himself (2 Chronicles 26). Moreover, the windows which were there were oblique or hidden, so that even the light which was offered from within did not have perfect knowledge, nor clear light, and was hidden in large part. Now, we see in an enigma (1 Cor. XIII, 12); and we do not yet know as we ought to know: but when that which is perfect is come, then that which was in part shall be destroyed. And there was a likeness of palms on either side. Gracefully within the interior of the Temple, and in the Holy of Holies, the right and left were not placed: so that nothing left-handed would seem to be said about those things which are great and mysterious; but on either side, according to what is written in the Gospel: 'If someone strikes you on your right cheek, turn to him the other also' (Matthew 5:39). Could he not have said 'left cheek' as well? But when the right cheek is struck, the other right cheek is offered: because in a holy man, both right sides are perfect. And in the shoulders of the vestibule on both sides of the house, and the width of the walls: for which seventy were transferred, in the ceilings of Aela, that is, the propylaea or entrance hall, and the sides of the house, of equal weight or measurement: through which it is secretly shown that the posts above the threshold or vestibule (for this is what the shoulders seem to signify), and the sides of the house, and the width of the walls, are all full of reason and measurement, and nothing is found in the temple of the Lord that is not established without measurement and wisdom.


<h2 id='tocuniq320'>Book Thirteen</h2>

Book Thirteen.

505-506 Thirteenth Book of Explanations on the Book of Ezekiel, the second is an exposition of the temple, which I also desire, with the help of our Savior, to dictate to the end, calling it the fourteenth. In the fourteenth psalm, David sings this same number: Lord, who shall dwell in thy tabernacle, or who shall rest in thy holy mountain? (Psalm 14:1). We must understand this as difficult and even impossible. Hence, in another place, he earnestly prays as if a man of desires and says: One thing I have asked of the Lord, this will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life, that I may see the delight of the Lord, and may visit his holy temple (Psalm 26:4-5). And again: How lovely are your tabernacles, O Lord of hosts: my soul longs and faints for the courts of the Lord. I go before the curses of my rivals, those who consider not what they themselves can do, but what I cannot do; and though they judge our actions, they do not offer their own actions to be judged. They never fight in the battle, but judge those who do with idle and even arrogant minds. It is easy to dictate to the people, to criticize each blow, to laugh at the blood of others, and to speak like an inexperienced trainer about where the wound should be inflicted. In my explanation of the temple of Ezekiel, and the other things that pertain to the end of that volume, I confess that I write nothing worthy of the magnitude of the subject, and in a few [words], if I should receive any thanks, to give them to the Savior. For it is written: Unless you believe, you shall not understand (Isaiah 6). And in another place: If you have faith like a mustard seed, and you say to this mountain, 'Move from here to there,' it shall be done (Matthew 17:19). And how does the Apostle commemorate the mustard seed as not a small portion of faith, but as the whole faith, saying: And if I have all faith, so as to remove mountains (I Cor. XIII, 2)? Therefore, this mustard seed, even if it is small, grows into a great tree, and the birds of the sky dwell in its branches (Luke XIII). Therefore, to you, daughter Eustochium, who gladly receive whatever may be ours, I want to testify, and I briefly remind you of that of the rhetorician Victorinus, so that you may know that obscurity in books arises from three things: either from the magnitude of the subject matter, or from the incompetence of the teacher, or from the hardness of the listener. Of these three, I readily confess the first and the second in this work; the third, your keen intellect and desire for the Scriptures easily reject: you, who possess God not as a mere occasional guest, but as a constant resident, by virtue of your virginity and continence. Therefore, let us proceed to the thirteenth chapter of the book of Ezekiel, whose beginning is as follows:

<h2 id='tocuniq321'>(Cap. XLII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 42 — Verses 1 and following) 'And he brought me to the outer courtyard by way of the north, and he led me into the treasury which was opposite the separate building, and facing the temple towards the north. The width of the entrance of the north gate was one hundred cubits, and the length fifty cubits, opposite the twenty cubits of the inner courtyard, and opposite the stone pavement of the outer courtyard, where there was a portico joining the triple portico.' And before the treasuries was a walkway ten cubits wide, looking towards the interior of the road with a width of one cubit; and their doors were facing the North, where there were treasuries that were lower in the upper parts, because the porches that protruded from the lower and middle parts of the building supported them. For they were narrow, and they did not have columns like the columns of the courtyards: therefore, they protruded from the lower and middle parts of the building from the ground by fifty cubits. And the outer court had chambers before the courtyard's gates, which were in the way of the outer court: the length of these chambers was fifty cubits. For the length of the chambers of the outer court was fifty cubits, and the length before the face of the temple was one hundred cubits. And there was an entrance below these chambers on the east side for those entering from the outer court: in the width of the court's enclosure, which was opposite the eastern way, facing the separate building. And there were before the building treasuries, and a road before their face, according to the likeness of treasuries, which were on the north side, according to their length, and so was their breadth. And every entrance thereof, and the likeness, and their doors, according to the doors of the treasuries that were toward the south ( Vulgate: the Known), to the entrance at the head of the way, that ( Vulgate: adds way) was before the separate vestibule by the eastern way for those entering. LXX: And he led me into the outer courtyard opposite the north gate, and he brought me in, and behold, there were five alcoves on the side of the building, and a separate building next to the north side. And it was fifty cubits long towards the north, and fifty cubits wide, with the same measurements as the gates of the inner courtyard and the columns of the outer courtyard, arranged in order facing the portico. And there was a walkway ten cubits wide in front of the alcoves, one hundred cubits long, leading to the inner courtyard, with its entrance facing north. And the walkways of the dining rooms were similarly constructed, as the columns of the upper floors stood out from the lower columns, creating a similar space. And there were triple porticoes, which did not have columns like the ones on the outer side, so they stood out from the lower ones, and in the middle of the ground was a space of fifty cubits, and the external light was like that of the atrium of the outer exedras, which faced the exedras of the North, with a length of fifty cubits. The length of the projecting porticos overlooking the outer courtyard was fifty cubits. And these are opposite their faces, all one hundred cubits, and the entrance of these porticos is towards the Eastern entrance, so that one may enter through them into the outer courtyard, according to the light that was at the beginning of the walkway towards the South, opposite the southern face of the rest of the building, and separate. And the porticos and the walkway are opposite their faces, according to the measurements of the porticos and the path towards the North, and their length and width and all their exits and entrances, and the light fixtures, and the entrance of the porticos towards the South, and the entrance from the beginning of the walkway to the space of the pen: and to go towards the East through them. » What the LXX translated to the East is not in Hebrew, and it is clearly superfluous. For how is it brought out to the outer gate to the East when it follows against the gate of the North? That which we have placed above, and in this place: And he brought me into the treasury, which will be opposite the separate building, and opposite the temple facing the North, for which it is held in the LXX: And he brought me: and behold, there are five chambers remaining from the building and next to the separate building to the North: for the separate, which Aquila and Symmachus translated, the second edition of Aquila, and Theodotion put the same word, Gezer [], in all places expressing similarly: and many other things that are placed in the present place between Hebrew and LXX not only in order, but also in number, and in the interpretation of words, they differ, so if we wanted to stick to each one, and seek and explain the reason for their diversity, we would deviate greatly from the purpose. And I wanted to pass over in silence the present testimony of despair and greatness, but I considered it better to say anything than to say nothing at all, taking up that Socratic principle: I know that I don't know. For it is part of knowledge to know that you don't know. Therefore, after contemplating more carefully the things that were inside, the prophet was led by a man, whose cord and reed were in his hand, to the outer courtyard, along the road that leads to the North, which he had already seen from above before he entered the inner parts. But we see things differently when it comes to perfect knowledge, compared to the beginning of learning. And it is necessary that whoever has seen the inner secrets, according to the same form and measures, also sees what is external. However, he was taken into the treasury, or as the Septuagint translated it, the exedra, or as Theodotius, the pastophorion, which is turned into a chamber: which was a separate building. But what the Septuagint added for the treasury, five exedras, is not found in Hebrew. The treasury was a separate building, as we have already mentioned. Gazera. It was separate, receiving those who came from the North, and it was facing the North, that is, it looked towards the parts of the North, but it was not located in the North, so that it would be easier for those who were leaving the cold of the North, from which evils come forth upon the earth (Jeremiah 1). We read in the book of Numbers that the tribes of Dan and Naphtali, and the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, the handmaids of Rachel and Leah, held their camps on the northern side. Now also the face of the entrance to the North was a hundred cubits in length and fifty in width: so that from the ten decades, a square and perfect number, and from the seven weeks, which is the number of remission, and into the beginning of unity, that is, the eighth, the spaces for the priestly duties in the temple of God were shown. And that which is connected to it according to the Hebrew version, opposite the twenty cubits of the inner courtyard, which the Seventy translated, were described as the gates of the inner courtyard, has this meaning: that the number of the outer courtyard, consisting of one hundred and fifty, is the same as the number of the inner courtyard, which is twenty. For if you calculate four times fifty in the number twenty, you will find both Testaments: so that the Law is kept in the Gospel and the Gospel is born from the root of the Law. For the number seventy, they have interpreted the likeness of the interior court, perhaps fearing the number twenty, in which the gifts of Esau are offered in the interior court. It follows: And against the pavement laid with stone of the exterior court, where there was a porch, joined to a triple porch; for which seventy have translated: And as the columns of the exterior court were placed in order, opposite the face of the triple porches. But it signifies that the pavement of the exterior court was laid with living stone: so that the feet of the priests might not be defiled with the dust of summer or the mud of winter. And so, as the Lord was about to ascend to the Father, he washes the feet of the Apostles (John 13), so that with clean and purified steps they may ascend to the kingdoms of heaven. And he commands the Apostles that when they enter any city and are not received, they should shake off the dust from their feet (Matthew 10; and Mark 6), so that they allow no earthly possessions to remain with them. And not only was the pavement covered with stone, but there was also a triple portico attached to the portico. A Portico, protecting priests from rain and heat, and joined to a triple portico, demonstrates the mystery of the Trinity, which, though divided into the names of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, is nevertheless joined in one divinity. There was also, before the treasury or the exedra or the chamber, a walkway ten cubits wide, looking towards the interior, a cubit in length. And what was added by the Septuagint is: By a hundred cubits of length, it is excessive: because in Hebrew it is not found, which the translators took away, looking towards the interior, a cubit in length, which we have translated from the truth of the Hebrew. However, it signifies that before the doors of all the treasuries, whether exedrae or chambers, there was a walkway, having a width of ten cubits, which is a perfect number itself, either because of the Decalogue or because of the sacrament of the Gospel. For if you come from one to two and three to the fourth number, the number becomes ten, the decimal (also called "denary") number of the Gospels: on the width of which the priests walk, progressing before each treasury. In this way, they always look towards the interior of the path that leads to the one cubit, namely the worship of one divinity, as the Son says to the Father: I have revealed your name to men (John 17:6). For she is the way, looking inward, which says in the Gospel: I am the way, and the truth, and the life (John 14:6): because no one comes to the knowledge of the Father, except through the Son. It follows: And their doors to the north, where there were treasure rooms in the lower and middle parts: because the porticos that emerged from the lower and middle parts of the building supported them. For they were lower and did not have columns like the columns of the courts: therefore they rose from the lower and middle parts, fifty cubits from the ground. What is joined: the doors of them, it is understood, of the exedras, or of the treasuries, about which there was talk above. The treasuries were in the higher parts, that is, in the lower dining rooms. To these dining rooms Elijah and Elisha went up (2 Kings 4:10-11; 1 Kings 17:19) and the Lord, when he was to celebrate the Passover with his disciples (Mark 14:14), and Tabitha, who, by the faith of the Apostle and the merit of her virtues, was raised from the dead (Acts 9:36-41). These are the dining rooms of which it is written in the psalm: He waters the mountains from his dining rooms (Psalm 103:13). For unless a mountain has been made, and has risen to higher things, it will not be watered by the rains of the Lord, which are watered in the first, second, and third upper rooms by the diversity of merits. The treasure houses themselves, that is, the treasuries of the Lord's treasures, are in the higher things of a humbler nature (Ephesians III). However much someone may be higher, they are thrown down with humility, along with the Apostle, saying: I am not worthy to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God (I Corinthians I, 95). However, the treasuries themselves were located in the lower rooms because they supported the porticos that protruded from the lower and middle parts of the building. And the reason why the treasuries were placed in the lower rooms and were lower was because they supported the porticos, which enjoyed the freedom of air and protruded from the lower and middle parts of the building. Thus, the second treasury would be higher than the floor of the first room, and the third treasury would be higher than the second room, and the higher one ascended, the higher treasury they used, which increased in humility, as the Lord says: 'If anyone wishes to be first, he shall be the last of all and the servant of all' (Mark 9:34). For they were not carried by other columns, as we read in the columns of the atriums, but they projected from the lower and middle parts of the earth by fifty cubits, as a symbol of the remission of all debts. These are the deep and hidden things, about which it is commanded: Describe them in threefold manner, with counsel and knowledge, so that you may respond with words of truth to those things which are presented to you (Prov. 22:20-21). Therefore, the lower and outer parts of the columns need support, but the higher and inner parts, namely the columns, do not need the help of others. After this it is said: And there was an outer narthex beside the treasuries, which were in the way of the outer court before the treasuries; the length thereof was fifty cubits: for the length of the treasuries of the outer court was fifty cubits, and the length before the face of the temple, a hundred cubits. Peribolus signifies a wall that was on the outside, and surrounded the treasuries in the way of the outer court, having a length of fifty cubits: of which number's mystery we have frequently spoken. Moreover, the length in front of the face of the temple was not fifty cubits, as before the treasury, but one hundred cubits; as after the remission of all sins, we await perfect rewards in the number one hundred (Leviticus 12). Concerning the perimeter, or wall, which in Hebrew is called Gader, the Septuagint interprets it as light, which comes from outside and illuminates the eyes of our hearts: our natural light, which operates in the senses, is not sufficient to have the perfect brilliance of knowledge unless it enters from outside through the grace of God. The first thing that illuminates the eyes of our hearts and makes the outer atrium, which stretches out with a width of fifty cubits, shine is the atrium itself. Afterwards, when we come before the face of the temple, we will receive the rewards in the perfect number of one hundred. Now, there was an entrance beneath the treasury from the East for those entering from the outer atrium. For it is necessary for us to possess the riches of God, and to find the entrance beneath the treasury of the East from the outer atrium, and to come through the width of the courtyard, which faces the way of the East, to the building that is separated for the holy ones, before which are the treasuries, and in the same way, along the way, are the treasuries that were in the way of the North. For even though we may reach the entrance to the East, the similarity of the ancestors is found in the smaller things, and we cannot reach the light of the East except through the way of the North, that is, by striving from the smaller and lower things to the greater and higher things. In the very entrance, however, the length was the same as the width, that is, the same measurement on all sides: and every entrance and similarity, and the doors themselves had the same measurement and similarity as the treasuries that were on the way facing the South. Indeed, by the East we withstand the cold of the North, and we arrive at the South, where the bridegroom reclines at noon and is surrounded by full light. But at the beginning of this same way, that is, the Eastern, which is open to those entering, there is a door, which unless it is opened by the one who says, 'I am the door' (John 10:9) and who holds the key of David, separated from the vestibule of the holy virtues, and which receives those coming from the North, we cannot arrive (Isaiah 22). It is unnecessary to discuss in detail each word of this passage according to the LXX: for even the things that have been said are not lacking in obscurity, and those things which we are silent about are nearly similar to those that we have mentioned.

<h2 id='tocuniq322'>(Vers. 13, 14.)</h2>

(Verse 13, 14.) And he said to me: The treasuries of the north, and the treasuries of the south which are before the separate building, these are the holy treasuries in which the priests who approach the Lord in the holy of holies eat. There they shall put the holy of holies, and the offering for sin and for guilt: for it is a holy place. But when the priests enter, they shall not go out from the holy place into the outer court, and there they shall put on their garments in which they minister, for they are holy: and they shall put on other garments, and thus they shall go out to the people. That man, who was a leader and prophet, after he had led him into the outer courtyard, and showed him all the things that the previous discourse had narrated, including the treasuries and the halls, where he stayed for a long time, said to him: These are the treasuries, or halls, and chambers to the North and to the South, which are in front of the separate building, and are called the holy treasuries, in which the priests who approach the Lord in the holy of holies eat. From these things we learn that there are many diversities of foods, which priests are allowed or not allowed to eat, and among those which are allowed to be consumed as food, they are not consumed in all places, nor by all, nor at all times. I believe that the treasuries of the North and South contain either the simplicity of history or the mysteries of spiritual understanding, so that through the North we may come to the South. For the letter should not be read in such a way, and the foundations of history should not be laid, that we do not reach the heights; nor should the roof of a most beautiful building be placed in such a way that the foundations are not solid." } But the priests who eat in the cellars, in which many riches are contained, they themselves are the ones who approach the Lord: of whom Scripture testifies (Exod. XXIV), that Moses approached the Lord, and the others could not approach. In the construction of the mystical temple, and in the sacrament of the Church, there are many priests and apostolic men who approach the Lord, and not in any place, but in the holy of holies. And that which is said in the Septuagint: Sons of Sadoc, which is interpreted as just, is not in Hebrew. There, he says, the priests shall place the holy of holies, and the offering, that is, the victim of burnt offering, both for sin and for ignorance: so that they may not only continually offer sacrifice, but may also, by the diversity of times and the quality of sin and ignorance, know how to appease the Lord, because that place itself is holy, and the priestly dignity dwells in it, which is able to intercede for others. But when it is necessary to proceed to those who cannot penetrate the inner recesses of the temple, nor know the secrets of divine knowledge: let the priests go out, he says, to them in the outer court: by no means with the garments with which they were adorned on the inside, namely the bowels of mercy, and the Lord Savior, of whom it is written: Clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ (Rom. XIII, 14); nor should they use the words about which God speaks: My mystery for myself and mine: so that they do not fall into that which the Savior prohibits, saying: Do not give what is holy to dogs, nor throw your pearls before swine (Matth. VII, 6). But they shall put their garments inside, with which they are clothed when they serve in the innermost parts of the temple; for they are holy, and should not be shown to those who do not have perfect sanctity: and they shall receive other garments, and thus proceed to the people. Thus, they shall speak to the people, as the people can hear. Hence, even the Apostle spoke to the Corinthians (1 Cor. 5), among whom there was heard fornication, and such fornication, which not even among the Gentiles: I gave you milk to drink, not solid food: for you were not yet able to digest it (1 Cor. 3:2). To them he says again: My little children, for whom I am again in the pain of childbirth until Christ is formed in you (Gal. IV, 19). For little ones and infants, solid food is not only not beneficial, but it kills them, as it is suitable for adults of mature age. However, what is added by the Seventy is this: Therefore the priests shall not go forth into the outer court, so that those who offer may always be holy, let us mark with a footnote, because it is not found in the Hebrew.


<h2 id='tocuniq323'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 and following) When he had finished measuring the interior of the house, he led me along the way of the gate that faced east, and he measured it all around. It had the same measurements on all sides (the house had a circular shape). He measured it against the east wind (while standing at the back of the gate facing east) with a measuring rod that was 500 cubits long. He measured the circumference of the house with the measuring rod. And measured against the north wind, he measured five hundred cubits, measuring with a reed in a circuit. And against the south wind, he measured five hundred cubits, measuring with a reed in a circuit. And against the west wind, he measured five hundred cubits, measuring with a reed. He measured the wall on all four sides, with a length of five hundred cubits and a width of five hundred cubits, dividing between the sanctuary and the area of the common people. ((The Vulgate adds this))" } It should be known that after the East and North winds, the South and West winds have a reversed order among the Seventy. For they first placed the West, that is the sea, and then the South, while among the Hebrews the South wind is placed first, and then the West. And what the Scripture now says: 'When he had completed the measurements of the inner house, he led me along the way of the gate which faces toward the East, and showed me all that has been mentioned, both inside and outside, and in the interior of the temple, that is, the holy of holies, which properly pertains to the building of the temple and the inner temple.' And now it follows: He led me along the way of the gate, which overlooked the Eastern way, and he measured it all around, resembling a house. By this it is shown that it is not the house itself, but the likeness of the house that is seen: for now we see through a glass darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known. (I Cor. XIII). Therefore, Moses in the tabernacle and Solomon in the building made not the truth of the temple tent, but the likeness and figure: so that through those things which are smaller and earthly, we may understand those things which are in the heavenly and spiritual building." } But the man who led the prophet, not at all to the outer courtyard, but through the gate that faced the Eastern road, first measured against the Eastern wind, that is, towards the East, five hundred paces around; second, towards the North; third, towards the South; fourth, towards the sea, that is, towards the West, in the four principal directions, a wall around, both in length and width, that is to say: a square wall that had two thousand paces. But if the reed was six cubits long, and a παλαιστῇ [a Greek unit of measure] is one-sixth of a cubit, it is clear that the outer wall had a circumference of two thousand reeds, which makes twelve thousand three hundred and thirty-three cubits, plus a third of two thousand. The wise and diligent reader should read the book of Joshua and will find how this measurement is observed in the outskirts. Hence, even the legion of demons chose this number in the suffocation of the pigs (Luke 8), so that the one who was separated from the servants of God by the command of the Lord would be turned in the opposite direction to the destruction of those who lead a life worthy of filth and squalor. But every outer wall, which has a very spacious length and width in the shape of a square, contains the number of the apostles, that is, twelve hundred and eighteen thousand: so that a thousand number is assigned to each apostle, and yet it does not reach the measure of the fullness of Christ and the perfect man, unless the wrestler, who is three hundred and thirty-three cubits long and a cubit and a third, is joined to it: through which the mystery of the holy and venerable Trinity is demonstrated, which surrounds and fortifies all things, and makes the inhabitants of its temple most secure. Where the ark of Noah has a length of three hundred cubits, and a height of thirty cubits, which is completed in one cubit (Gen. 5). But what is added there, fifty cubits in width, signifies the sacrament of remission (as we often say). Hence, the Lord came to baptism at the age of thirty, and this very prophet at the beginning of his book puts his thirtieth year: which, adding three hundred and thirtieth, is completed with the addition of three and a third. But what our translation and the Septuagint have, for the sake of simplicity of interpretation, while paying little attention to the speed of dictation, is that its wall runs all around it, with a length of five hundred cubits and a width of five hundred cubits. The Hebrew text, however, does not include the word 'cubits', but simply 'length of five hundred' and 'width of five hundred', with the understanding that it refers to reeds. As mentioned earlier, in the fourth instance, it was stated that the wall of each section was measured by the person holding the reed, towards the east wind, the north wind, the south wind, and the sea, with five hundred reeds. But the number five hundred, which is close to fifty, which pertains to the remission of all sins, is not only demonstrated by the ancient Scripture (Leviticus 25), but also by the words of the Savior in the Gospel, saying: 'There were two debtors to a certain lender: one owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty' (Luke 7:41). And a wall divides between the sanctuary and the common place. From this we understand that all the description above the temple, the ministry was delegated to the Priests, who are the sons of Zadok. However, this wall, which extends over such a large space and surrounds everything, separates the sanctuary from the area of the common people.

<h2 id='tocuniq324'>(Cap. XLIII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 43, verses 1 and following) 'And he brought me to the gate that looked towards the East: and behold, the glory of the God of Israel was entering by the way of the East, and there was a sound like the noise of many waters, and the earth shone with his majesty. And I saw a vision like the one I had seen when he came to destroy the city, and a vision like the one I had seen by the river Chebar. And I fell upon my face.' And the majesty of the Lord entered the temple through the gate that faced east. And the Spirit lifted me up and brought me into the inner court, and behold, the glory of the Lord filled the house. And I heard someone speaking to me from the house. And the man standing beside me said to me, 'Son of man, this is the place of my throne and the place for the soles of my feet, where I will dwell in the midst of the children of Israel forever. And the house of Israel shall no longer defile my holy name, they and their kings, by their whoredom and by the dead bodies of their kings on their high places, by setting their threshold by my threshold and their doorposts beside my doorposts, with only a wall between me and them. They have defiled my holy name by their abominations that they have committed, so I have consumed them in my anger.' Now therefore, remove far away her prostitution, and the ruins of her kings from me, and I will dwell in their midst forever. LXX: And he brought me to the gate, which looked toward the east, and he led me out, and behold the glory of the God of Israel was coming by way of the east, and the voice of the camps was like the voice of many moaning, and the earth shone like lightning from glory all around. And the vision that I saw was according to the vision that I saw when I entered to anoint the city. And the vision of the chariot that I saw, according to the vision that I saw above the river Chobar, and I fell on my face. And the glory of the Lord entered the house by way of the gate that faced east. And the Spirit lifted me up and brought me into the inner court; and behold, the glory of the Lord filled the house. And I stood there, and behold, a voice came from the house, speaking to me; and a man stood beside me, and said to me: Son of man, have you seen the place of my throne and the place of the soles of my feet, where my name will dwell in the midst of the house of Israel forever. And they shall no longer defile my holy name, both they and their leaders, in their promiscuity and in the murder of their leaders among them, when they set my threshold next to their thresholds, and my doorposts beside their doorposts. They made their wall between me and themselves like a connecting wall, and they defiled my holy name with their iniquities that they committed. So I consumed them in my anger and in my wrath. Now let them put away their promiscuity and the murder of their leaders from me, and I will dwell among them forever. First, we must discuss the variation in the translation. This phrase that the Septuagint includes, 'And he led me,' is not found in the Hebrew text. For if he had been brought to the gate facing east, why was it necessary for him to be led out, since he was brought in specifically to see what was happening at the eastern gate? Furthermore, when it says, 'The voice was like the sound of many waters,' it is undoubtedly the voice of God, as John also confirms in his Revelation. The Septuagint translates it as, 'And the voice of the camps was like the sound of many voices.' (Apoc. 14)." } In the third place, it is stated in Hebrew: I saw a vision according to the appearance that I had seen when he came to destroy the city. But he came, clothed in linen as he was in the beginning of this prophet, and he had an inkwell at his waist, along with six others, to destroy the city, not to anoint it, as the Septuagint translated, who said in the fourth place: And the vision of the chariot which I had seen, which is not found in Hebrew. Let us speak separately about each one, as far as the difficulty of explanation allows: lest, while we strive for brevity, the veil remains not only in Moses, but also in Ezekiel the prophet, in us who desire to contemplate the revealed truth of the Lord (Exod. 34; 2 Cor. 3). Therefore, the glory of the God of Israel entered by the Eastern way, by which it had also departed when the city of the Lord was struck by fury. Indeed, it enters, or rather returns to it because it had shown the temple of the Lord built on the mountain. And yet there is much more that is said in the following: The spirit lifted me up and brought me into the outer court, and behold the glory of the Lord filled the house. For here only does the glory of the God of Israel enter; but there it is said that the fullness of the glory of the Lord was in the Temple, of which Isaiah also writes: I saw the Lord sitting on a high and elevated throne, and the house was full of His glory (Is. 6:1); when beholding the revealed face, we are transformed into the image of the Creator. The voice also was of God, as the voice of many waters, of all the 521 peoples of the whole world, as John the Evangelist interprets (Apoc. XIV): or as the voice of armies, and as the voice of many that set up a shout, that the army of God might know the sacraments. Which, understanding, Jacob called the name of that place, camps (Genes. XXXII). Of which it is also written elsewhere: The chariots of God are ten thousandfold, thousands of them that rejoice (Ps. LXVII, 18). But there is another voice called the voice of the camp and the multitude, because of the unanimous praise of God. And the voice of those who sing is doubled to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit: Holy, holy, holy is the Lord God of Sabaoth, the earth is full of His glory (Isaiah VI, 3). It follows: And the earth was resplendent with His majesty (Psalm XIX). This was properly fulfilled in the coming of Christ; when the sound of the apostles went out into all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world (Romans XVIII): and it is fulfilled in believers every day, and will be completely fulfilled when this corruptible body shall put on incorruption, and this mortal body shall put on immortality (I Corinthians XV). But what is inferred: And I saw a vision according to the appearance that I had seen, when it came to destroy the city; for which the Seventy translated: when I entered to anoint the city, as it is clear according to the Hebrew; according to the Septuagint it has the greatest obscurity: how Ezekiel entered to anoint the city; to the prophecy and threat of which he fell; unless perhaps we may say that the rebuke of the prophet is the anointing of the city, and the anointing of the oil of priestly and royal gladness, so that those who willingly receive and desire to hear become the anointed ones of the Lord, concerning whom it is written: Do not touch my anointed ones, and do no harm to my prophets (Psalm 105:15). But he can anoint the city according to the anagoge, of which it is written: Glorious things have been said of you, O city of God (Psalm 86:2); he who saw the vision of the chariot and the mysteries of God, which Ezekiel beheld upon the river Chebar, which signifies burden and weight. For what is heavier than the rivers of Babylon, over which David sat and wept when he remembered Zion? Of which it is written: The figure of this world passes away (Psalm 136). And I think that nothing is perpetual in the confusion of this world, but everything passes away and flows (1 Corinthians 7:31). And whoever considers this will fall on their face, understanding how far they are from the majesty of God, and will bend their knees to the Father in the name of Jesus Christ. When I fell, the majesty of the Lord entered the temple through the gate that faced east, and immediately the Spirit lifted me up (for I was unable to rise on my own), and He brought me into the court of death, for I had fallen outside. And behold, the glory of the Lord that I had seen coming from the east, the glory of the God of Israel, filled His house, and I heard a voice speaking to me from the inner house. What she said is not mentioned in Scripture, unless perhaps that of the Apostle: And I heard unspeakable words, which it is not lawful for a man to utter (2 Cor. XII, 4). But the man, he says, who stood next to the prophet, said to him: we clearly understand the Lord. For who else can it be applicable to what follows: Son of man, the place of my throne, and the place of the soles of my feet, where I dwell in the midst of the children of Israel forever, except those who dwell in the Church in the midst of the children of Israel who see God, and dwell forever, not according to the temple of Solomon for a time? And his place is that of which it is written: And his place was in peace (Ps. 75:2), which surpasses all understanding. And the place of his feet, as the Apostles say: Let us worship in the place where his feet stood (Ps. 32:7). And well said, they stood: for the feet of the Lord stand in the Church, they walk in the synagogue and pass by. But so that we may know that this is said about the Church, it is joined: And they shall no longer defile my holy name, the house of Israel: which properly belongs to those who dwell in holy conversation in the Church. But those who defiled the holy name of God are clearly identified: they and their kings, both the people and the priests, in their own fornications in which they fornicated against God; and in the ruins of their kings, who vainly assume the royal name through their pride. Furthermore, it follows: And in the highest places. For a haughty mind offends God; a humble one calls upon His mercy. Indeed, those who, after pride, or rather through pride, made their threshold beside the threshold of God, and their doorposts beside His doorposts. Let them hear these things, letter by letter, women burdened with sins, who are carried about by every wind of doctrine, always learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth; having a mind joined to God, not to the proximity of the churches, and having a dwelling place next to God, to provoke His mercy upon themselves; rather, they are moved by the indignation of the Lord, when an unworthy inhabitant is in consecrated places of God. They have made, she says, their threshold next to my threshold, so that there is no difference between the sacred and the profane, and their doorposts next to my doorposts, so that there is one entrance for laity and priests." } And so the Apostle says: But let a man prove himself, and so let him approach the body and blood of the Lord (I Cor. XI, 28). And to make what he said more serious, he adds the following verse: And there was a wall between me and them, so that the shortest wall would separate the priestly sacrifices and the places of the sacraments of the body and blood of Christ. And they have defiled, he says, my holy name with the abominations they have done. What profit is there in residing near the house, and with a wall between our chamber and the Lord's altar, when in the things which we do in secret, and it is even shameful to mention them, the name of the Lord is contaminated and defiled? I believe this, that the name of the Lord is not polluted, unless he who has seen his name believes in it, and is counted by that name. And just as he who previously believed in Christ pollutes the name of God and makes the members of a prostitute, so does he pollute the name of God who first received the faith in his name. Otherwise, even though they are polluted and contaminated, the Gentiles and Jews cannot pollute and contaminate the name of God, because they pollute those to whom it is said: 'My name is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you' (Rom. II, 24). Therefore, for these reasons, I consumed them in my anger because they did the things we have mentioned. And yet, the merciful Lord again commands the prophets to tell them to remove their former fornications from themselves and to abandon the ruins of their kings and princes, and to drive them away not so much from themselves as from God. And he immediately promises rewards for good works, saying, 'And I will dwell in their midst', of which it is said in the Gospel: 'There stands among you one whom you do not know' (John 1:26). And he will dwell not for a short time, as in the Synagogue, but forever, which is proven in the Church of Christ.


<h2 id='tocuniq325'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 10 and following) But as for you, son of man, show the house of Israel the temple, and let them be ashamed of their iniquities and measure the blueprint, and let them be ashamed of all that they have done. Show them the structure of the house and its blueprint, its entrances and exits, and every detail of it, and all its instructions. Show them the entire order and all its laws, and write it in front of their eyes, so that they may observe all its arrangements and its instructions, and follow them. This is the law of the house on the top of the mountain: All its boundaries are around it, it shall be most holy. This is therefore the law of the house. LXX: And you, son of man, show the house to the house of Israel, and they will cease from their sins, and its vision and arrangement: and they themselves will endure their torment for all that they have done. And describe the house and its preparation, and its exits and entrances, and its substance and all its instructions, and all its regulations, and all its laws you will show to them, and describe before them: and they will keep all my ordinances and all my commandments, and they will do them, and the description of the house on the top of the mountain, all its borders around it are most holy. This is the law of the house. It is no small task to demonstrate to those who see with their eyes or with their minds and hear with their ears, so that they themselves may seem to have seen with you. Therefore, Josephus writes that those who were sent by Jesus son of Nave to describe the land were geometers and had the art which is now proper to philosophers, the art of Geometry. Therefore, to the house of Israel, those who perceive God with their souls, the house is shown, that is, the temple which Ezekiel saw situated on the mountain, and not only on any mountain, but as it is now called, on the summit of the mountain. Let us by no means think that it is the temple which is narrated as being constructed by Solomon in the books of Kings and Chronicles. For it belongs to another order and measure, and in each [temple] it has great diversity: and so much inferior to the temple which is now shown in Ezekiel, that not only its worshippers and ministers, but even its builder Solomon sinned and offended God, though he later repented, writing in Proverbs: Finally, I repented and looked to choose discipline (Prov. XXIV, 2). But this vision of Ezekiel, and through Ezekiel to the house of Israel, is such: that whoever contemplates it with their mind, shall cease from their iniquities, not some, but all: or as it is said in Hebrew, they shall be confounded and endure their torment for all they have done. Those who cease from committing past sins endure the torment of their iniquities, and greatly benefits the one who has sinned before, to see the house of God and understand the plan of all its construction, so that they may cease to sin and, having a desire for it, say to the Lord: Lord, I have loved the beauty of your house, and the place of your glory's habitation (Psalm 25:8). And again: One thing I have asked of the Lord, this I will seek: that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life (Psalm 27:4), when I begin to live and be with Christ, who is the life of the believers. It follows: Its exits and entrances, the underlying meaning being the house. The exits, however, are those who go out to those who are outside, and the entrances are those who penetrate inward through the discipline of the masters. And every description of it, or rather its substance, as the Septuagint has translated, refers not so much to the nature of the house, as to its furnishings and riches. And you will show them all the precepts, the entire order, and all the laws of the temple, to those who have carried the burden of their iniquities and have ceased or been confused about what they had done before. Therefore, show it to them so that they may keep all the commandments that have been given. For it is of no benefit to know the description of the house and all its arrangements, as it is written: In my Father's house there are many dwelling places (John 14:2). And again: He established the boundaries of the nations according to the number of the children of Israel, even the angels of God (Deut. XXXII), unless you do what is commanded. But the house and law of God's commandments, and the city which is established on the top of the mountain, that is to be believed, of which it is written: A city that is set on a hill cannot be hidden (Matth. I, 14). And: The streams of the river shall make glad the city of God (Ps. XLV, 4): which clearly refers to the Church, and is situated on that mountain, which is the highest of all mountains, and from which the prince of Tyre was wounded: and all the boundaries and territories of this house are holy of holies. In that house, that is, in the tabernacle that Moses built, and in the temple that was constructed by Solomon, only the inner parts, where there were 526 Cherubim, and the mercy seat, and the ark of the covenant, and the table of incense, were called holy of holies. But in this house which is shown to Ezekiel, and which is situated on the top of the mountain, all its boundaries are considered holy of holies. And what is being brought in: This is the law of the house, either it pertains to the past, about which it has already been said, or it pertains to those things that will be said later.


<h2 id='tocuniq326'>(Vers. 13 seqq.)</h2>

(V. 13 seqq.) These are the measurements of the altar: the exact cubit, which had a cubit and a handbreadth (or παλαιστὴν) in its length, and a cubit in its width. The definition (Vulg. adds 'of it') was from its lip around one handbreadth (Vulg. one handbreadth). This was also the ditch of the altar. And from the base of the land to the lowest step were two cubits, and the width of one cubit. And from the smaller step to the larger step were four cubits, and the width of one cubit. But the altar itself was four cubits, and from the altar upward there were four horns. The altar was twelve cubits long, twelve cubits wide, square on all sides. The projecting ledge was fourteen cubits long and fourteen cubits wide on all four sides, and the surrounding border was half a cubit wide, with a rim of one cubit all around. But its steps were turned towards the East. 70: And this is the measure of the altar in exact cubits and παλαιστῆς, its height all around and a cubit of width, and a rim around it like the edge of a hand. And this is the height of the altar from the base of the riser to its upper edge, which was under two cubits, and a cubit of width. And from the smaller riser to the larger riser, four cubits of width and a cubit of height, and a space of four cubits for the hearth. And from the hearth to the upper parts of the horns, a cubit of distance. But the ark had twelve cubits in length, and twelve cubits in width, and the propitiatory of fourteen cubits in width by four parts thereof, and its railing by the circuit half a cubit, and the circuit thereof cubit: the steps of the entrance thereof were turned towards the east. And: O the depth of the wisdom and knowledge of God (Rom. XI, 33): 'Whose depth is so profound, and who shall find it?' It is much if we desire to compare the temple of Solomon and all its parts and tabernacles to this temple. Since this is very difficult, for now let us briefly compare the altar shown to Ezekiel, the altar we read about in Exodus. There the altar is described as five cubits in length and five cubits in width, that is, a quadrangle, and three cubits in height. But here, departing from the senses, it tends towards union, in which the perfect cubit, or the truest, is put, to which a handbreadth is added, that is, the παλαιστὴ, making the sixth part of a cubit, as we have said above. But in its bosom, that is, the altar, there was an elbow, which indeed received the things that were consumed by fire, and in its width another elbow: so that the inner parts, that is, the secrets, and the spaces of the altar which are shown in width, would be finished in one elbow. But what follows: And the boundary extends to its edge, for which Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion placed a boundary, the Seventy translated as measure again. The reason for this word, as I have already said, I cannot know; nor can I confidently say in what language it is spoken, unless I remind the reader that when I interpreted the definition above, I transferred it beyond the crown. And this is briefly demonstrated, that around the altar itself, that is, on the edge and in a circular form, there was a lip or a circle spread out, and like the crown of a lily, having a lot of beauty in appearance. This definition or measurement extended either around the palms of one hand, or with a width of a παλαιστῆς. The bottom and depths, and the earth attached to it, are contained in the number two, which is also assigned to unclean animals (Genesis VII). The upper part, reaching to the threshold or propitiatory, which Theodotius himself called Azara in Hebrew, has a width of one cubit, so that the number two transitions to solitude; and the lower part, which is inferior, reaches the bliss of unity. 528. And that which follows: And from the smaller step to the larger step, four cubits in width, and the length of one cubit, for which it is stated in the Septuagint: And from the smaller propitiatory to the larger propitiatory; and Theodotion translated it as: from the lesser propitiatory to the greater propitiatory. In both instances, Azara is to be understood, that the smaller propitiatory is a stone cut from the mountain without hands, and the larger propitiatory is the stone itself which grew into a great mountain and filled the whole earth (Dan. II). Or, in another sense, it is a lesser propitiatory when assuming the form of a servant (Philippians 2), and a greater propitiatory when receiving the glory that it had with the Father before the world began (John 17). For we first understand the more humble aspects of Christ, and thus we reach the height of his divinity; and yet, the propitiatory of both natures, that is, the lesser and the greater, belongs to the sacrament of one altar. Between the two propitiatory parts, smaller and larger, there were four cubits, signifying the four elements of the world, which themselves reach the height of one cubit. And it must be observed that in the measurement of the altar, the first cubit in width is not joined to any other, but is complete in itself; but the second cubit in width, after two cubits, increases to the top, and the third cubit, after the propitiatory part, smaller and larger through the four elements, tends to the mystery of one cubit; and the first, second, and third cubits in the altar of the Lord are by no means the first, second, and third; but one and one, and one is said to be one. But Ariel was also four cubits high, and from Ariel up to the top of the horns there were four cubits: or as it is said in the Septuagint, from Ariel up to the upper part of the horns one cubit. Ariel, as most believe, is interpreted as 'my light is God'. Concerning this, in the prophecy of Isaiah, it is written: 'Woe to you, Ariel, the city that David besieged, or surrounded', as we have explained more fully. But as I understand it, it means 'lion' or 'mighty one of God', which name is properly attributed to the altar, in which either the illumination of God is, or his lion-like nature and strength, as Jacob said to Judah: 'Judah, you are like a lion's cub; you have gone up from the prey, my son. He stooped down; he crouched as a lion and as a lioness; who dares to rouse him?' But it has four cubits, and it has four corners; or the upper parts of the four corners are finished with one cubit, so that the measure of the Gospels and the strength running throughout the whole world may be shown under the illumination of God and the strength of the lion, so that they may reach the divine confession of one cubit. And so that the gradually increasing obscurity of the present place may become clearer, it follows: And Ariel is twelve cubits in length, with twelve cubits in width, a square with equal sides. It is not doubted that the twelve tribes mentioned in the book of Revelation and the number of the Apostles, whose sacrament I remember having mentioned above (Rev. VII), belong to the twelve tribes. However, on the four sides of the world, the twelve cubits together make forty-eight cubits of the priestly cities, so that with these foundations divided throughout the whole world, the strength of the Church may be solidified. Furthermore, the rim, for which the Septuagint translates 'propitiatory' and Theodotion translates 'azara,' Symmachus translates as 'peridromē,' which means 'circuit,' was fourteen cubits in length and fourteen cubits in width, with four corners, and a crown around it half a cubit in circumference. For which again the Septuagint translates as 'gisum' and 'sinus,' or according to Symmachus, its completion and perfection, one cubit around, secretly shows that our Lord, who is truly called the propitiatory not only for our sins but for the whole world, came through fourteen generations from Abraham to David; and again through another fourteen generations to the captivity of Jechoniah, and by the sacrament of the same number descended to earthly things: so that in the third 'tessarakaidēs,' and by the sacrament of the divine gift, he may save the four corners of the world, about which it is written: 'Many will come from the East and West, and from the North and South, and will sit down with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob in the kingdom of heaven' (Matt. VIII, 11). And what follows, the crown, or gisus around it, is understood to represent the propitiatory, which had a half cubit, and the curve of the propitiatory, or the completion and perfection, which Symmachus interpreted as 'peridromē,' had one cubit. This signifies that both sinners and the righteous are saved by the propitiation of the Lord, as the Apostle Paul says: 'For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son' (Romans 5:10). And concerning sinners, it is said that they have a measurement of half a cubit around; however, they are saved by the mercy of the Creator, according to what is written in the Psalms: 'You will save them for nothing.' (Psalm 55:8) As for the righteous, they are saved in one solitary and perfect number, and they imitate one divinity, as the same Apostle says: 'God was in Christ, reconciling the world to Himself.' (2 Corinthians 5:19) And what is placed at the end of this testimony, and its steps turned towards the East, the steps of this propitiatory or the twenty-four books of the Old Testament should be understood: those who had harps in the Apocalypse of John (Chapter 5), and crowns on their heads, or the mystery of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, in which true propitiation is given to us. And to speak more openly, the number of steps is left uncertain, so that no matter how much effort we can climb to higher things, we may think ourselves placed in lower things, and consider that of the Psalmist: They will go from strength to strength (Ps. 83:8).

<h2 id='tocuniq327'>(Vers. 18 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 18 seqq.) And he said to me: Son of man, thus says the Lord God: These are the rituals of the altar, on whatever day it is made, to offer a burnt offering on it and pour out the blood. And you shall give to the priests, the Levites who are of the seed of Zadok, who approach me, says the Lord God: to offer me a bull from the herd for sin. And you shall take some of its blood, put it on the four horns and on the four corners of the ledge, and on the rim all around; and you shall cleanse it and make atonement. And you shall take the calf that is offered for the sin, and burn it in a separate place of the house outside the sanctuary. And on the second day you shall offer a male goat without blemish for the sin, and they shall make atonement for the altar as they made atonement with the calf. LXX: 531 And he said to me: Son of man, thus says the Lord God: These are the precepts of the altar on the day it is made, that burnt offerings may be offered on it, and blood poured out on it. And you shall give to the Levitical priests, who are of the seed of Sadduc, and approach to me, says the Lord God, to minister to me a calf from the cow for sin; and they shall take its blood and put it on the four horns of the altar, and on its base around, and they shall cleanse and make atonement for it. And they shall take a goat for sin, and it shall be burned in a separate place outside the holy house. And on the second day they shall take two immaculate goats from the goats for sin, and they shall make atonement for the altar as they made atonement with the calf. After the prophet showed the altar and its cubit, two cubits and again a third cubit, and twelve cubits by twelve others, and four horns of the altar: Ariel also, twelve cubits, by twelve cubits, and a footrest, that is, a mercy seat fourteen cubits, by fourteen cubits: also its crown, and a hem of half a cubit and one cubit all around: and steps to the East, the number of which is uncertain, a man spoke, whose pen and cord were in his hand, and he instructed him how, with the work of the altar completed, the altar should be expiated and consecrated. And first a victim is offered, and it is given to the priests from the tribe of Levi, who are from the seed of Zadok, whom the Seventy call Sadduc, which I am not able to understand. But Zadok is interpreted as just: and according to the Seventy and Theodotion, a calf is offered; according to Symmachus, a bull, which is called Pharus in Hebrew. But the calf that was sacrificed for us, and many passages of Scripture, and the principal Epistle of Barnabas, which is found among the apocryphal writings, mention. And on the second day, a male goat from the goats is offered. Therefore, those who are going to celebrate the Passover take a lamb and a young goat from the flock, and those who could not celebrate the first Passover in the first month, celebrate it in the second month: one offering is for the righteous, and the other is for those who are repenting. But if we prefer the interpretation of the Seventy who said: 'On the second day, they shall take two unblemished young goats as a sin offering,' it is indeed bold what we are about to say, but the simple opinion of others must be put forth, who say that two unblemished young goats were offered on the altar of the Lord after the passion of the Lord, Jacob and Stephen: the former of whom was part of the number of the apostles, and the latter was the leader of the seven chosen for the ministry of the Lord (Acts 22). This is James who saw the transformed Savior on the mountain (cf. Matthew 17), who witnessed the rising of the synagogue leader's daughter with the Lord Peter and John (Matthew 17), who is listed first among the apostles with his brother (Mark 9). Herod killed him (Matthew 9), and like an unblemished lamb, he sacrificed himself on the day after the Savior's passion (Mark 3). The Jews also stoned Stephen, whose wisdom and teachings no one could resist (Acts 14), and he saw the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God, and said (Acts 14:7): 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.' The Jews stoned him with stones. And just as the Apostle mentions the firstfruits of believers in Achaia and Asia (1 Corinthians 16), so too were these the first fruits of the martyrs, whom the confession of Christ later crowned. And it should be noted that the whole calf is offered as a burnt offering, and the thickness of its body is consumed by divine fire. For we knew Christ according to the flesh: but now we no longer know Him according to the flesh (II Cor. V, 16). But James and Stephen, who were offered on the second day, either a goat, which is mentioned in the Hebrew offering, is indeed offered as a victim, but the burnt offering is reserved for the presence of the Lord. And as for the blood that Peter speaks of, 'You were redeemed from your futile way of life inherited from your fathers, not with perishable things like silver or gold, but with the precious blood of Christ' (I Peter I). And the apostle Paul teaches: 'You were bought with a price' (I Cor. VII, 23); and in another place: 'Making peace through the blood of His cross, whether on earth or in heaven' (Coloss. I, 20), that signifies that by the blood of the Savior, the four corners of the altar are purified, that is, the four wounds of the world: and the crown of the mercy seat, or the bases around, are sprinkled, so that everything may be purified and the propitiation may be firm. Therefore, on the second day, either two young goats, of which we have spoken above, or a male goat is taken; because this animal always hastens to high places and sustains no danger on steep slopes, and there it finds a path where destruction is for other animals. Hence, in the Greek language, the herd of goats and male goats is called 'sublimium conversatio', that is, 'aipolion' as if 'aipopoulion', since 'aipos' means high and 'polein' means conversation. Furthermore, the altar of Christ is cleansed by His blood, so that the prayers of the saints may reach God pure. It should also be noted that, according to the Hebrew text itself, Ezekiel is commanded to assume the role of a priest and offer a young bull as a burnt offering, and sprinkle its blood around the altar, the corners, and the crown, or base. However, the Septuagint interpreters show other priests performing this act, of whom it is said: You shall give the Levite priests who are of the seed of Zadok, who come near to me.


<h2 id='tocuniq328'>(Vers. 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 onwards) 'And once you have finished cleansing it, you shall offer an unblemished calf from the herd and an unblemished ram from the flock. You shall present them before the Lord, and the priests shall sprinkle salt on them and offer them as a burnt offering to the Lord. For seven days you shall make a sin offering each day, a male goat, and an unblemished calf and ram from the flock. For seven days they shall make atonement for the altar and cleanse it, and they shall consecrate it and fill its hand. After the days are completed, on the eighth day and beyond, the priests shall offer your burnt offerings on the altar, and also the peace offerings, and I will be appeased towards you, says the Lord God. LXX: And when you have completed the atonement, you shall offer an unblemished calf from the herd, and an unblemished ram from the flock, and you shall present them before the Lord, and the priests shall sprinkle salt on them; and they shall offer them as burnt offerings to the Lord. For seven days you shall make a sin offering of a goat daily, and a calf from the herd, and an unblemished ram from the flock they shall make for seven days. And they shall make atonement for the altar, and cleanse it, and fill their hands, and complete the days. And it shall come to pass from the eighth day and beyond, the priests shall offer your burnt offerings on the altar, for your salvation, and I will accept you, says the Lord God. After the altar and its measurements were shown on the top of the mountain; and again, the expiation and consecration of the prophet were shown, through an unblemished calf and a goat, or two young goats, the first of which were brought to the Lord Savior, the two following to the apostles and ministers, so that in the consecration of the spiritual altar, which properly belongs to the Church, the law and the prophets are not thought to be excluded, therefore, after the altar is consecrated, an unblemished calf and a ram are offered before the Lord; and the sons of Zadok, that is, the righteous priests, sprinkle salt on their heads, so that both the Law and the Prophets may be seasoned with the taste of the Gospel. And there is no sacrifice (according to the command of the law and the interpretation of the Apostle, who says (Col. IV, 6): Let your speech be seasoned with salt) that lacks salt. But both offerings are made as a burnt offering to the Lord, like the fatty substance of the letter, which is signified in the Law, and the cloudy prophecy, with the fire of the Lord, that is, the Holy Spirit, of whom Paul says, fervent in spirit (Rom. XII, 11), they are transformed into a spiritual and subtle substance. We want to know more clearly who the calf from the spotless herd is, and the ram with the purest fleece from the sheep, let us understand Moses and Elijah (Num. XII, III Reg. XIX); the former of whom was the gentlest among all men who dwelt on the earth; the latter being similar to Moses in fervor of faith. Hence he dared to say: I am left alone. But as for what is written in Hebrew: You shall offer a calf, in the Septuagint, the priests shall offer, there is no question. And indeed Ezekiel, to whom these things are said, is from the number of the priests, of full and perfect age; and by the grace of the priesthood, he increased in the degree of prophecy. And Moses and Elijah are seen on the mountain with the Lord, that is, the law and the prophets, who foretold to him what he would suffer in Jerusalem. But after the altar is cleansed, for seven days a goat or young goat is offered for sin daily, and a calf from the herd, and an unblemished ram from the flock, so that through these sacrifices for seven days the altar may be perfectly expiated. In seven days, the Sabbath is shown which, according to the Apostle (Hebrews IV), is reserved for the people of God: in which we hope for eternal and true rest, and we do not engage in the servile work of sins. But in the goat, and the calf, and the ram, three general sins are demonstrated, to which all mortal kind is subject. For we sin either in thoughts, or in speech, or in action. Thought is referred to the ram, which is the first of all sins, and from which the other two sins arise. But the kid, or the goat, is skilled in speech and discourse, always discussing lofty matters. However, the work itself is properly attributed to the calf: because he is devoted to the plow and both physical and earthly labor. Therefore, we must offer these pure sacrifices for seven days of true and complete Sabbath, and cleanse the altar, so that our prayer may reach God in a pure form. And the phrase, 'they shall cleanse it and fill his hand,' which is translated from Hebrew by other interpreters, signifies that the gifts for the altar itself, for the sake of which the sacrifice is offered, must also be fulfilled, just as it is offered for the priests and the people and the high priest; lest anything appear to have been left empty in the sight of the Lord. For which reason, the Seventy will place it: and they will purify it, and they will fill their hands, so that the priests may be heard, who, when they are full of good works, for this, their hands will be full, the Sabbath being completed, they may come to the eighth day of the resurrection, and may say with the Apostle: We have risen with Christ (Rom. 6, Col. 3); and beyond the eighth day, they may strive for heavenly things, and may offer burnt offerings for us, or those which are for the peace and salvation of our sins: so that through the fire of the Holy Spirit, everything we think, say, and do may be transformed into a spiritual substance: and may the Lord, pleased with such sacrifices, become merciful to us.


<h2 id='tocuniq329'>(Cap. XLIV.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 44, verses 1 onwards) And he brought me back to the outer gate of the sanctuary, which faces eastward and was shut. And the Lord said to me: This gate shall be shut; it shall not be opened, and no man shall enter by it, for the Lord, the God of Israel, has entered (or will enter) by it; therefore it shall remain shut. Only the prince may sit in it, to eat bread before the Lord. He shall enter by the way of the vestibule (that is, the porch of the gate) and shall go out by the same way. Concerning that which is written in Hebrew: It shall be closed to the prince, the LXX translated it: It shall be closed, for the leader himself shall sit in it. There are many gates that the Scripture of Ezekiel mentions in the description of the temple, both inside and outside. The previous discourse also discusses the form of the altar, its consecration, and the sacrifices. When this was finished, he came to the outer sanctuary gate, which faced east and was closed. Immediately, that man who was the prophet's guide and showed him everything spoke to him: This gate that you see closed will always be closed and will not be opened, and no man shall pass through it. And it renders the reason why it is always closed: because the Lord God of Israel has entered, or will enter through it: and it will be closed according to the Hebrew, for the prince, whom the LXX translated as 'leader'. This prince and leader, that is, the Prince, will sit in it to eat bread before the Lord: and he will enter through the way of the gate's vestibule, and he will go out through it. What gate is this, which is always closed, and only the Lord God of Israel enters through it? Indeed, those of which the Savior speaks in the Gospel: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites, and woe to you, teachers of the law, who take away the key of knowledge. You yourselves do not enter, and you hinder those who are entering (Matthew 23:23). Isaiah also writes about this under the same name of the book: The words of this book are like the words of a sealed book. When you give it to a man who is not learned, saying, Read this, please, he will say, I do not know how to read. And they will give the man who knows letters, saying: Read; and he will say: I cannot read, for it is sealed (Isaiah 29:11).
