But this book is one that no one can loose and open the seals, neither in heaven, nor on earth, nor under the earth, unless it be the one of whom it is said in the Apocalypse of John: Behold, the lion of the tribe of Judah, the root and the offspring of David, has conquered so as to open the book and its seals (Revelation 5:5). For before the Savior assumed human flesh and humbled himself, taking the form of a servant (Phil. 2), the Law and the Prophets and all the knowledge of the Scriptures were closed, and paradise was closed. But after he hung on the cross and spoke to the thief, 'Today you will be with me in paradise' (Luke 23:43), immediately the veil of the temple was torn and everything was opened. And with the veil removed, we say: But we all, with unveiled face, beholding as in a mirror the glory of the Lord, are transformed into the same image from glory to glory (2 Cor. 3:18)." } But if all things are revealed, for in Christ, according to the word of Paul, all things are revealed (Ibid., XIII), how will the gate be closed and not opened, and the man not pass through it? From these things we learn, although we have come to the highest knowledge, by comparison to divine knowledge, now we know in part and partially understand; but when that which is perfect comes, then that which is in part will be destroyed. Hence, in another place, the Apostle himself speaks of being imperfect and again being perfect. But if it lacks interpretation, it seems to be the opposite. For he says: Not that I have already obtained it, or have already become perfect. Brothers, I do not consider myself to have taken hold of it; but one thing I do: forgetting what lies behind and reaching forward to what lies ahead, I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus. And let us keep thinking this way, if we are perfect. But the meaning of this place is as follows: In comparison with other people who do not have knowledge of the Scriptures and the mysteries of God, I admit that I am perfect; but as far as the knowledge of the divine majesty is concerned, now I see it in an enigma and through a cloud and darkness, and I say with the prophet: Your knowledge is wonderful for me, it is strengthened, and I will not be able to reach it (Ps. 138:6). Therefore, this gate, which is closed to everyone (for no man should pass through it and perish), will be closed to the prince or the leader, and it will be opened by his coming, who will sit in it to eat bread before the Lord, about whom he himself professes in the Gospel, saying: My food is to do the will of Him who sent me, and to complete His work (John 4:34). He is both a prince and a pontiff according to the order of Melchizedek, and a sacrifice and a priest, who in the presence of the Father eats heavenly bread with us, and drinks wine, of which he speaks in the Gospel: I will not drink from the fruit of this vine until I drink it new in my Father's kingdom (Matt. XXVI, 29): namely, in that kingdom about which he and others also say: The kingdom of God is within you (Luke XVII, 21). And the gate will be closed. For no one can know the passions of the Lord, and his body and blood, as the sacraments of the majesty, and so great is our prince of goodness and clemency, that even though he sits alone at the door which is closed, and eats bread before the Lord, he desires to have many participants at his table and feast, and says: Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if anyone opens to me, I will enter in to him and will sup with him, and he with me. (Apoc. III, 20). But He alone eats bread in the presence of the Lord, because His substance and divine nature are separate from all the substances of creatures. He enters and exits through the same gate of the vestibule: because He is both inside and outside, that is, infused and encompassing all things. He enters through the gate in order to bring with Him those who cannot enter without His teaching and help; and He exits in order to bring in others again; and to speak to those who do not grasp more difficult things. But as for the Eastern gate, it is always closed beyond the boundaries of the world, and it is not open to human sight. The Gospel of John proves this, saying: No one has ever seen God; the only Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, he has made him known (John 1:18). In other words, it will be closed to all except the ruler. The ruler alone will sit within it, to partake of the bread of perfect and complete knowledge. For no one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son, and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him (Matthew 11:27)." } Beautifully, certain ones understand the closed gate, through which only the Lord God of Israel enters, and the leader to whom the gate is closed, to be the Virgin Mary, who both before and after giving birth remained a virgin. For at the time when the angel was speaking: The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Highest will overshadow you; therefore, the holy child who will be born from you will be called the Son of God (Luke 1:35), and when he was born, the virgin remained eternal to confound those who think that after the birth of the Savior she had sons from Joseph, on account of his brothers who are mentioned in the Gospel (Mark 3). I know that in my youth, at Rome, I wrote a small book against Helvidius, a heretic of that time.

<h2 id='tocuniq330'>(Vers. 4 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 4 and following) And he brought me by the way of the north gate into the presence of the house, and I saw, and behold, the glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord, and I fell on my face. And the Lord said to me, Son of man, set your heart, and see with your eyes, and hear with your ears, all that I am speaking to you concerning all the statutes of the house of the Lord and all its laws, and set your heart to the ways of the temple through all its exits of the sanctuary. The man who is the leader of the prophet, and who knows everything in the temple by showing it, after he had shown the closed gate that should never be opened, and yet it was open to him who entered through the closed doors, leads the prophet to the way of the gate 539 of the North, which itself must undoubtedly signify the temple, being also in view of the house. And when the prophet saw the house of the Lord full of the glory of the Lord, namely the same house that he saw opposite in the North, he immediately fell on his face, unable to bear the majesty of the glory of the Lord. And since he had been cast down in humility, he says to him, not as a man, but as the Lord: Son of man, set your heart, and the rest. In the consummation of the tabernacle and the building of the temple that was constructed by Solomon, the glory of the Lord appeared, which was later destroyed in comparison to the glory of the Gospel, as the Apostle says: For that which was glorified has not been glorified in this part, because of the excellent glory. For if that which is destroyed is through glory, much more that which remains is in glory (2 Corinthians 3:10). And we must be careful not to think that the destruction of the former glory is an abolition; but rather we must understand that after the perfect has come, that which was in part will be destroyed. Just as if you compare the rays of the sun to a lamp, or the light of a lamp to a lantern. Therefore, it is also said about John the Baptist: He was a shining lamp in the house (John 5:35). But when the sun of justice came, the light of the lamp was hidden, as the prophet himself and John the Baptist said: He must increase, but I must decrease (John 3:30). But the prophet fell on his face, lest, desiring to see more than human frailty can behold, he should lose even the light of his eyes. Therefore the Lord familiarly calls him the son of man, and commands him to set his heart, and see with his eyes, and hear with his ears. For first the mind must be opened to understand what is said; secondly, the heart must be understood as the eyes, of which it is said to Abraham: Lift up your eyes and look at the stars of heaven (Gen. 15:5); thirdly, to be heard with these ears, of which the Savior says: He who has ears to hear, let him hear (Luke 8:8); so that he may understand all the ceremonies of the temple and its lawful observances, and finally set his heart in the ways of the temple, because there are different entrances to God. Whether it signifies the paths of the temple, the order of ceremonies, or the exits of the sanctuary. Therefore, it is a prologue and preparation for the prophet, to understand what he will later learn about the order of the temple. And it should be noted that in the plight of this world, which is situated in evil and set in the cold of the North, the celestial order of ceremonies is shown to us.

(V. 6 seqq.) And you shall say to the rebellious house of Israel: Thus says the Lord God: Enough of all your sins, O house of Israel, because you bring in foreign sons (or foreigners) uncircumcised in heart and uncircumcised in flesh, to be in my sanctuary and to defile my house, and you offer my bread, the fat and the blood, and you nullify (or transgress) my covenant in all your sins; and you have not kept the precepts of my sanctuary, and you have appointed guards of my observances in my sanctuary for yourselves. When he says, 'Let all your sins and iniquities be enough for you, and let us exhort penance for past sins, so that we do not increase sins with sins, and so that we provide material for future fire,' but let us hear that which Isaiah speaks: 'Woe to those who draw sins like a long rope, and like the yoke of a calf's strap iniquities' (Isaiah 5:18). And the first sin is that they bring in alien sons, or strangers uncircumcised in heart and uncircumcised in flesh, so that they may be in the sanctuary of God, and defile the house of God. For a little leaven corrupteth the whole lump (1 Cor. V, 6); and in some copies it is found in Proverbs: Do not introduce the wicked into the tents of the righteous. We are pressed in this place by the Jews and Ebionites, who accept the circumcision of the flesh: how can we explain this passage to those uncircumcised in heart and uncircumcised in flesh? by which, clearly, after spiritual understanding, we must also receive circumcision of the flesh. But those of us who read Paul saying: But as for me, I bear witness to every man who is circumcised, that if you become circumcised, Christ will benefit you nothing (Gal. V, 2). And Jeremiah said: Behold, your ears are uncircumcised, and you do not want to listen (Jer. VI, 10). And in Exodus, Moses spoke before the Lord, saying: Behold, the children of Israel did not listen to me; how then will Pharaoh listen to me? But I am of slow speech (Exod. VI, 12), which the seventy translated as: Am I not rational? This is better understood in Hebrew: But I am uncircumcised in lips, let us inquire of them, or rather force them to circumcise their ears and cut off their lips, so that they may appear to fulfill the Scripture. But if they begin to interpret the circumcision of the ears, since we do not tolerate hearing anything shameful and dishonorable, and the circumcision of the lips, since we do not speak anything indecent: let us tell them that they must also observe the same exposition in their hearts and in their flesh. We circumcise the heart with the knife of God, and the foreskin is removed from our hearts, when shameful thoughts never come out of our hearts, nor is it said of us: 'The heart of this people has become fat, and their ears they have made heavy' (Acts 28:27). Therefore, the flesh is likewise circumcised so that we do not perform earthly works, which we are compelled to do out of bodily necessity, such as eating, drinking, sleeping, and wearing clothes. We circumcise these things, not for indulgence, luxury, and laziness, but for the sustenance of nature and the support of this body. Whoever drinks wine in moderation for the sake of the stomach and frequent illnesses, and detests drunkenness, circumcises their own flesh (I Tim. V). He who sleeps as much as nature requires, will hear from Solomon: If you sit down, you will be without fear. If you sleep, you will sleep soundly and you will not fear the coming of terror, nor the attacks of the wicked (Prov. III, 24). And he who flees from fornication and returns to his wife's bed, so as not to be tempted by Satan (I Cor. VII), will hear with the people of Israel: On this day I have taken away the reproach of Egypt from you. He will also use clothing that repels the cold; not those that reveal bodies with thinness. The flesh, weakened by fasting and restrained by continence, avoids the reproach of the Egyptians who delight in abundant flesh, and that can be said which is read in many according to the Septuagint edition: 'Just as my flesh grew weak in a deserted, impassable, and waterless land, so I appeared to you in holiness.' If and when, therefore, we desire to introduce aliens into the temple of God, let us circumcise their ears, and lips, and heart, and all flesh, and eyes, taste and smell, so that we may do all things with the fear and understanding of God. Let the bishops, presbyters, and all the ecclesiastical order hear this, so that they may not bring in uncircumcised sons in heart and uncircumcised in flesh, lest they be defiled in the sanctuary of God and defile his house. For if they do this, what follows will be applicable to them: And you offer my bread, that is, the loaves of the offering, in all the churches and throughout the world, budding from one loaf, and not only loaves, but also the fat which is written: He satisfied them with the fat of wheat (Ps. 80:17), and the blood which was shed in Christ's passion. And it should be read thus, and the order of reading should be restored thus: When you bring in uncircumcised foreign sons into my sanctuary in heart and body, and you defile my house, do you dare to offer bread and fat and blood, mystical sacraments, and not understand that you have violated, and surpassed, my covenant in all your sins and impieties, and have not kept the precepts of my sanctuary, nor have you placed the keepers of my ceremonies in my sanctuary. But there is a threat against those who have not heard the Apostle forewarning: Do not lay hands quickly on anyone, nor share in the sins of others (1 Timothy 5:22). Or certainly it should be understood like this: You have disregarded my covenant in all your crimes, and have not kept the precepts of my sanctuary, and you dare to appoint unworthy and foreign guards to observe my sanctuary for yourselves, so that it is understood, not for me. And there is a sense: They who serve and minister to you in carnal things, and defile my sanctuary for your refreshments.

<h2 id='tocuniq331'>(Vers. 9, seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 9, seqq.) Thus says the Lord God: Every uncircumcised foreigner, both in heart and in flesh, shall not enter my sanctuary; every foreign son, who is among the sons of Israel. But even the Levites who have gone far from me and have wandered after their idols, they shall bear their iniquity, who were in my sanctuary, serving as gatekeepers of the house and ministers of the house; they themselves were sacrificing burnt offerings and sacrifices of the people, and they stood before them to minister for them. Therefore, because they ministered to them in the presence of their idols, and the house of Israel became a stumbling block of iniquity, therefore I have lifted my hand against them, says the Lord God, and they shall bear their iniquity. And they shall not come near me to serve as priests, nor shall they come near any of my sanctuaries, as the Most Holy Place. But they shall bear their disgrace and the sins they have committed. And I will give them keepers of the house for all its services and for everything that is done in it. But the Levite priests, the sons of Zadok, who kept the charge of my sanctuary when the children of Israel strayed from me, they shall come near me to minister to me; and they shall stand before me to offer to me the fat and the blood, says the Lord God. They shall enter into my sanctuary, and they shall come near to my table to minister to me, and they shall keep my ordinances. LXX: Therefore thus says the Lord: Every foreign-born son, uncircumcised in heart and uncircumcised in flesh, shall not enter into my holy places among all the foreign-born sons who are in the midst of the house of Israel, but also the Levites who have strayed far from me when Israel went astray from me after their own thoughts, and they shall bear their iniquity and shall be ministers in my holy places, gatekeepers at the gates of the house, and servants of the house. These people will offer burnt offerings and sacrifices to the people, and these people will stand before the people to serve them. Because they served them before their idols, and the house of Israel became a torment of iniquity. Therefore, I have raised my hand against them, says the Lord God, and they will bear their iniquity. They will not come near to me to serve as priests, nor to offer to all the holy things of the children of Israel, nor to the most holy things of mine. And they will bear their disgrace in the error in which they have gone astray. And they shall set them to keep the watch of the house, for all the service thereof, and for all that shall be done therein. The priests the Levites, the sons of Zadok, that kept the charge of my sanctuary when the children of Israel went astray from me, they shall come near to me to minister unto me, and they shall stand before me to offer unto me the fat and the blood, saith the Lord GOD. They shall enter into my sanctuary, and they shall come near to my table, to minister unto me, and they shall keep my charge. I have provided evidence based on both editions, so that from the comparison of them we may be able to know what the LXX have understood and what the Hebrew text holds. The Septuagint signifies this, that foreigners who are uncircumcised in heart and flesh, who dwell in the midst of the children of Israel, should not enter the sanctuary of God. But the Levites, that is, the priestly class, who have strayed far from the Lord in the error of the children of Israel and have wandered after their idols, after they have received their iniquity, let them stand in the sanctuary of the Lord, being priests and gatekeepers, ministers of the house, and let them offer holocausts and sacrifices for the people. And let these ones be before their eyes to minister to them what they have ministered to them in the presence of their idols, and let the house of Israel become a torment of iniquity for them. And therefore, the Lord God says that he has lifted up his hand against them, so that they may not approach him and serve as priests, nor offer to him in the Most Holy Place, and let them bear their disgrace in the error in which they have strayed, so that they may be placed in the observance of the house's guards in all its works, and in everything that is done in the house. But if this is so, how can it be possible for the Levites, who have strayed far from God and have gone astray after their idols, to serve in the house and sacrifice burnt offerings and the sacrifices of the people, and for them to stand in their presence to serve them? For what more will the priests, the sons of Zadok, who have kept the ceremonies of the sanctuary of God, do, of whom it is said: They will approach me to serve me, and they will stand in my presence to offer me fat and the rest? But this is the meaning of the Hebrew: Every uncircumcised foreigner in heart and flesh shall not enter my sanctuary, even though he may seem to be with the people of Israel. But the Levites, that is, the priestly order, who have gone far astray from me in the error of the sons of Israel, and have followed idols, shall bear their iniquity because they have been serving in my sanctuary as gatekeepers of the house, and as its ministers. For they themselves offered burnt offerings and the sacrifices of the people, and they stood in their presence to minister to them. Therefore, because they ministered before their idols and became a stumbling block of iniquity to the house of Israel, therefore I have stretched out my hand against them, says the Lord God, and they shall bear their iniquity and shall not approach me to serve as priests, nor shall they come near to any of my sanctuaries, even to the most holy place, but they shall bear their shame and the sins they have committed. For those who were accustomed to offer burnt offerings and sacrifices and all kinds of offerings as part of their priestly duties shall be brought to the lowest rank and shall be gatekeepers in the house, a perpetual disgrace, so that they may be seen by the entire people as they enter and leave, and understand the lowly position to which they have been reduced. But the priests, he said, that is, the Levites, who are the sons of Zadok, that is, the righteous, or the righteous of God, and who during the time of the error of all the Israelites, guarded the ceremonies of my sanctuary, they themselves shall approach me to minister to me, and stand in my sight, and offer me the fat, that is, the fattest sacrifice and blood, namely, the living and pleasing sacrifice to God, and they themselves shall enter my sanctuary, and approach my table, to burn incense to me, and observe all the rites of the sacrifice. But if this is so, that those who in the time of error and persecution followed idols which they had devised from their own heart, and not only asserted with their voice, but also confirmed with the subscription of their hand, that the Son of God is a creature, and served the creature more than the Creator, who is blessed forever, how do they assume for themselves the summit of the priesthood and the pontificate, and dare to offer victims to God, once worshippers of idols? But, as the most fervent poet testifies,

Whatever is done by many goes unpunished: The multitude of sinners has made it easier for the impious to obtain forgiveness, so that those who should have been made to repent for their sacrilege are now reclining on the pontifical throne, and regurgitating the nausea of false faith, rather the open shortcuts of hidden perfidy. Let them at least hear and observe the commandments of the almighty God. No uncircumcised foreigner, both in heart and in flesh, shall enter my sanctuary. Although he may be a son, although he may be joined by blood, although he may cling to us through ancient kinship: if he is uncircumcised in heart or in flesh, he shall not be admitted into the sanctuary of God: lest we make ministers of Christ, our ministers, and defile the altars of the Lord with carnal refreshments. Therefore, because we have set them aside: And I will give them as keepers of the house in all its services, and in all that is done in it: namely, the Levites who have strayed far from God in the error of the sons of Israel, and have followed idols to which they offered sacrifices. Taking into account the order of reading and the overall sense, Symmachus interpreted more accurately, saying: For I have appointed them as guardians of the doors of the entire ministry and all that is done in it, so that it does not pertain to those who are to come in the future, but to those who have been.

<h2 id='tocuniq332'>(Vers. 17 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 17 seqq.) When they enter the gates of the inner courtyard, they shall be dressed in linen garments (or robes): and they shall not wear anything made of wool (or they shall not be dressed in garments made of wool) when they serve at the gates (or near the gates) of the inner courtyard and inside. Linen turbans shall be on their heads (or they shall have linen turbans on their heads) and linen undergarments shall be around their waists, and they shall not be bound in sweat (or forcibly). And when they go out of the outer court to the people, they shall put off their garments wherein they ministered, and lay them up in the holy chambers, and they shall put on other garments; and they shall not sanctify the people with their garments. Neither shall they shave their heads, nor shall they suffer their hair to grow long, but they shall only poll their heads (or they shall not shave their heads, and shall not cut their hair close: they shall cover their heads). And not every priest shall drink wine when he enters the inner courtyard. First, the words of the story must be revealed. Among other things that the Lord's discourse instructs the priests is also this to be observed, that they should be clothed in linen garments at the very gates of the inner courtyard, that is, in tunics: neither should they use woolen garments either at the gates of the inner courtyard or inside, that is, in the adyta and holy of holies: and the headbands or linen veils should be on their heads, and the linen undergarments around their loins. And what follows according to the Septuagint: 'And they shall not be girded violently,' for which Aquila and Symmachus translated as 'in sweat.' Theodotion, expressing the Hebrew word itself, placed it as 'in Jeze (): Aquila's second edition, Busa ((Al. Buza)),' which means that they should not be girded violently, tightly like prisoners, lest they become unfit for priestly and Levitical duties, such as holding and slaughtering victims, and also unable to drag and run. And because he had once commanded what garments the priests should wear when they were inside the ministries, he now commands that, when they go out to the treasure chambers or unburned places of the saints, they should take off their former clothes and put on others, so that if they have holy garments, they should not sanctify the people outside who are not yet sanctified and have not prepared themselves for the sanctification of the temple, in which the Nazarite of the Lord shall be. Through this we learn that we should not enter the holy of holies in everyday and any common clothes that are defiled for everyday use, but with a clean conscience and clean garments, hold the sacraments of the Lord. And what follows: 'But they shall not shave their heads, nor let their hair grow long, but they shall trim their heads,' is clearly shown that we should not have shaved heads like priests and worshipers of Isis and Serapis, nor again let our hair grow long, which is properly luxurious, and that of barbarians and fighters; but so that the honorable appearance of priests may be shown on their faces. For the LXX said, 'They shall not shave their heads, nor let their hair grow long, but they shall cover their heads,' from which we learn that baldness should not be made with a razor, nor the head so closely shorn that we appear to be like the shaven, but only to the extent that the hair is allowed to grow so that the skin is covered. Or certainly priests should always cover their heads, according to that saying of Virgil (Aeneid. lib. III):

To veil his hair with a purple covering. But this is a violent interpretation. However, not only do priests and Levites not drink wine in their ministry, but they do not even enter the holy of holies, lest their minds be oppressed and their senses become dulled. Hence the Apostle says: It is good, he says, not to drink wine and not to eat meat (Rom. XIV, 21). And in another place: And do not be drunk with wine, in which there is debauchery (Ephes. V, 18). For the people ate and drank, and they rose up to play. And he clearly demonstrates why he granted Timothy permission to drink a little wine: because of his stomach and frequent illnesses (I Tim. 5). The Egyptian priests use linen garments not only on the inside but also on the outside. Furthermore, divine worship has one attire for ministry and another for common use in life. Undergarments are rightly worn to preserve modesty and decorum, so that when ascending the steps of the altar and moving about in ministry, they do not reveal indecency. Superstition of the pagans has a rocky head. But as far as my knowledge is concerned, I do not think anyone abstains from wine among the pagans. What the whole will indicate according to reason, the following words will show. To be holy and spiritual garments, the Apostle teaches, saying: Put on the Lord Jesus Christ (Rom. XIII, 14). And in another place: Put on compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience (Coloss. III, 12). And again: Having stripped off the old man with his works, and having put on the new one who is renewed in knowledge, according to the image of the Creator (1 Corinthians 15:54); which I also think signifies this: For it is necessary for this corruptible to put on incorruption, and this mortal to put on immortality. But when this corruptible has put on incorruption, and this mortal has put on immortality, then the saying that is written will come to pass, and the rest. Concerning the priestly garments in Exodus, it is written more fully (Exodus 28); and we once published a book (Epistle 64, to Fabiola), for the interpretation of which a diligent reader should be sent. For we cannot grasp a broad subject in a short discourse. We make these garments with our own labor, which are woven upon, such as the tunic that the Lord had, which could not be torn (John 18); with which we are clothed when we know the secret and hidden mysteries of the Lord, and we have a spirit that searches even the deep and profound things of God, which are not to be shown to the common people, nor to be spoken to the multitude, who are not sanctified and prepared for the holiness of the Lord. Lest if they hear greater things, they may not be able to bear the majesty of knowledge and be overwhelmed as if with solid food, when they are still nourished with the milk of infancy. However, on the contrary, Scripture teaches that evil clothing is the worst, as it is sung in the Psalms about the traitor Judah: 'He was clothed with curses as with a garment' (Psalm 108:29). And a little later: 'Let it be to him as a garment with which he is girded, and as a belt with which he is always girded' (Psalm 109:19). Therefore, even the Lord, who suffered for us and bore our sins, is said to have dirty garments in Zechariah, about which it is written: 'And Jesus had dirty clothes' (Zechariah 3:4), which he later takes off, as Scripture says: 'Take away from him the filthy garments, and clothe him with clean clothes,' etc. But what follows: Vittae, or ribbons, will be on their heads, I think it signifies a crown of grace, of which it is written: For thy crown shall receive the grace. Neither will it make a question for us concerning the covered and uncovered head, which the Apostle speaks of: A woman ought to have a covering over her head, because of the angels. For if a woman is not covered, let her be shorn. But if it is shameful for a woman to be shorn or shaven, let her be covered. For a man ought not to cover his head, being the image and glory of God: but the woman is the glory of the man (2 Cor. XI, 10). For if it is the men's responsibility not to cover their heads, it seems contradictory that now priests are required to cover their heads. But if we read more carefully, the present issue is resolved by the previous statements. For it is said above: When they minister in the gates of the inner court, and inwardly. For if we enter into holy places and stand in the presence of the Lord, we ought to cover our heads: For no living creature shall be justified in the sight of the Lord (Ps. CXLII, 2)." } And: From infancy, the heart of man is inclined towards evil. Finally, we also use our female members inwardly, so that no impurity of conscience or shameful act of marriage may appear in the sight of God. The Savior wants the apostles to gird themselves with these female members, saying: Let your loins be girded, and your lamps burning in your hands (Luke 12:35). And the Apostle speaks to the believers, saying: Therefore, gird up your loins with truth (Ephesians 6:14). And the imitators of Christ hear that which is written of him: He will be girded with righteousness and surrounded with truth (Isaiah XI, 5). And by this same belt, the one who is holy and has ascended to the summit of virtues is not forcefully constrained: so that he may not seem unwilling to observe the good of self-control and to eat bread in the sweat of his face, but rather to do the commandment of the Lord willingly. Furthermore, when he goes outside and mingles with the people, he takes off his priestly vestments in the treasury, where the Lord's riches are kept; and the priests use other clothing and a different teaching for the common people, so that the people may not be sanctified by their robes. It is burdensome for a multitude to take on a task beyond their capacity, as Solomon says: 'The net is for men, to quickly sanctify what is theirs; for when he makes a vow, repentance quickly takes it away' (Prov. XX, 25, sec. LXX). Moreover, the Nazarenes offer themselves willingly, and whoever makes a vow and does not fulfill it is guilty of breaking the vow. Therefore, concerning widows it is said: 'When they have grown wanton, they desire to marry in Christ, having condemnation because they have set aside their first faith' (I Tim. V, 11, 12). It is better not to promise, than to promise and not do. Anna offered Samuel, who remained in eternal sanctity (I Reg. I). And Manoah offered Samson his son, but the lust of Delilah defiled the sanctification of his hair (Judg. XIII). Finally, the Lord left him and was condemned to blindness, except that later, as his hair grew, he regained his former strength and killed many more foreigners dead than alive, as a foreshadowing of Christ. But the Lord wants his priests to have perpetual locks of sanctity, and to cover their heads not with any external covering, but with their natural hair, not for the sake of adornment and luxury, but for the sake of decency. Therefore, even the hair of the apostles' heads is counted, as the Savior says: But the very hairs of your head are all numbered (Mat. X, 30). Of that head, of which it is written in Ecclesiastes: The wise man's eyes are in his head (Eccl. II, 14). But the head of man is Christ, whom the sinner tramples upon and despises, and, so to speak, shaves with a razor, and takes away his beauty. This was also done by the sons of Ammon to those whom David had sent as messengers (2 Kings 10). But if the transgression of the law dishonors God, consequently, he honors Him who keeps the precepts of the law, so that what is written may be fulfilled: That all may honor the Son just as they honor the Father (John 5:23). Furthermore, what follows is clear: Every priest, when about to enter the inner atrium, should not drink wine. It is evident that the state of the mind is overturned in drunkenness and debauchery, and we do not fully understand when the mind is occupied with the satisfaction of wine. But drunkenness is shown not only in the drinking of wine, but also in all things by which the mind is intoxicated and fluctuates in contracts and worldly affairs, in losses and gains, love and hatred, and it cannot maintain its state. And because we are surrounded by frail flesh and are forced to do some things that pertain to the body, such as providing for our food, clothing, and other necessities, it is at least required of us that when we return to ourselves and understand why we were born, and when we enter the innermost parts of the temple, we depart from the vices of the world and do not even commit the smallest sins. Through this, it is shown that we both commit small sins out of necessity for the flesh and that there is also a time when, entering the inner courtyard, we must be free from all worldly and foreign drunkenness.


<h2 id='tocuniq333'>(Vers. 22 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 22 and following) They shall not take as wives widows and those who have been divorced (or expelled), but virgins (The Vulgate reads 'virgins') from the seed of the house of Israel. But they shall take the widow who has been widowed by a priest: and they shall teach my people what is holy and what is impure, and they shall show them the difference between clean and unclean. And when there is a dispute (as added in the Septuagint, of blood), they shall stand in my judgments and shall judge my laws, and they shall keep my ordinances in all my appointed feasts. This place contains the instructions of the priests, who, after many things which we have already explained above, are commanded not to take widows, divorced women, or women who have been rejected as wives. The widow and the divorced woman are the synagogue, that is, the congregation of the Jews, which did not receive the Lord. Therefore, it is rightly called the rejected woman or the widow synagogue. But the crowd of heretics, who went out from us because they were not of us, is called the rejected woman. But he says, 'I want to present all of you as a holy virgin to Christ,' concerning the virgin from the seed of the house of Israel, who was nurtured in the house of God, in the law and the prophets, about whom the Apostle also speaks (2 Cor. XI, 2). This is the virgin of whom the divine word speaks elsewhere: Love her, and she will keep you; embrace her, and she will exalt you; honor her, so that she may embrace you (Prov. IV, 8). But who is the virgin that should be loved and that keeps her lover, will be known by whoever reads it: I loved her and sought her from my youth, and I sought to take her as my spouse, and I became a lover of her beauty (Wisdom VIII, 2). And again: And the Lord loved her above all things. Not only should priests marry a virgin, but also a widow who was previously the wife of another priest; namely the knowledge that another worshipper of God discovered. For we should not only be satisfied with new doctrine, but also cultivate the old and join it to our company, if she has been educated in sacred worship. It is also the duty of a priest to teach the people what is holy and profane, clean and unclean; so that we first refer to the teachings, and then to the works that are done through the flesh. For who understands sins? And when there is a controversy about every matter, whether as the Seventy translated it, of blood, that is, what pertains to mortal crime, the priests shall stand in my judgments, so that they do not judge according to honor, nor show partiality to the poor or the rich in judgment: but rather, they shall stand in the judgments of God, and remember that Psalm: God stands in the assembly of the gods, and in the midst of gods he judges, calling gods those who have the power to judge over men: for with what judgment they judge, they shall be judged (Mat. VII). The laws, he says, and my precepts are to be observed by all in my solemnities, so that they may know how Christ has been sacrificed as our Passover; how we ought to fulfill the seven weeks of joy and gladness, and to humble our souls in fasting; and to understand the sound of the trumpets and the spiritual tabernacles, in which we say: I am a stranger and a pilgrim like all my fathers (Ps. XXXVIII, 13). These are the true solemnities of God, which someone interpreting the Pentateuch will explain consecutively. The first duty of a priest is not only to teach what he knows, but also to keep all the feasts of God, so that he can instruct others on what they should observe, having observed them himself. The duty of priests is to have knowledge of the law, and we learn in Malachi, who says: The lips of the priest shall keep knowledge, and they shall seek the law at his mouth: because he is the angel of the Lord of hosts (Mal. II, 7).

<h2 id='tocuniq334'>(Vers. 25 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 25 seqq.) And they shall sanctify my Sabbaths, and they shall not enter the dead person, lest they be defiled (for which the Seventy translated, and they shall not enter upon the soul of the man, lest they be defiled): except for the father, he said, and the mother, the son and the daughter, the brother and the sister who does not have a husband, they shall be defiled. And after he has been cleansed, seven days shall be numbered for him, and on the day of his entry into the sanctuary and into the inner court, so that he may minister to me in the sanctuary, he shall offer a sacrifice for his sin to the Lord God (or he shall offer appeasement). But they will not have an inheritance; I am their inheritance, and you shall not give them any possessions in Israel; I am their possession. Furthermore, it is commanded to the priests: in which it must be observed, that it is not said absolutely: and they shall sanctify the Sabbaths; or according to Isaiah: My soul hates your New Moons and Sabbaths (Isaiah 1:13): but with a distinction, my Sabbaths. Therefore, it is also written in the Gospel: The priests in the temple violate the Sabbath, and they are without guilt (Matthew 12:5): not the Sabbath of God, but the Sabbath of the law, the Sabbath of the Jews, which they rightly violate who are the chosen race, royal and priestly. Furthermore, let us understand the Sabbath that has been sanctified, as the Apostle also teaches, to be left for the people of God, of whom it is said: 'If they shall enter into my rest' (Ps. 94:11), which is called Sabbath in Hebrew. But the Sabbath of God sanctifies, who does not bear the burden of sin on the Sabbath, nor says: 'As heavy burdens, they have pressed upon me' (Ps. 37:5). He who is such does not gather wood on the Sabbath; nor does he build upon the foundation of Jesus Christ wood, hay, straw (1 Cor. 3); nor does he kindle a fire to consume useless material, and remains in one place on the Sabbath day; nor does he go outside, but remains like a column placed in the temple of God, upon which John writes in the Apocalypse: 'He who conquers, I will make him a column in the temple of my God, and he shall go out no more' (Rev. 3:12). And what follows: They shall not enter a house where there is a dead man, lest they be defiled: it belongs properly to the priestly office not to touch the dead, so that he who intercedes for the sins of others may himself approach the altar in purity. Concerning these dead ones, the Savior speaks in the Gospel: Let the dead bury their own dead (Matt. VIII, 22). They become defiled in their dead father when they abandon their Creator, and in their dead mother when they depart from the Church; and in their son and daughter, this pertains to different thoughts and different actions, which is more significantly expressed in Greek as τὰ νοητὰ καὶ αἰσθητά. Moreover, if a brother and sister, who are reborn in the same spirit, believe that one of them is dead, they defile themselves by such a belief; but this only applies if the sister remains a virgin and has not been stained by the touch of any man. From this we understand the privilege of virginity, which is taken away by the touch of any man, whether rightly or wrongly spoken, we leave it to the judgment of the reader. This is also confirmed by the natural affection in this matter, as written in the order of charity: Love me in order (Song of Songs 2:4), after God the creator of all things, the father and mother of the flesh should be loved; son and daughter; brother and sister; but only if they do not venture outside the home or come under the power of another. But after the priest has been purified according to the order of purification that is written in the Mosaic law, seven days shall be counted for him, either as a perfect number of repentance, or after the consummation of the world, when we pass into the true octad, so that he may enter the Holy of Holies (for this is the inner court) and be able to minister in the sanctuary and always offer a victim for the sin of conscience: and there should be no time when he does not remember that he was defiled by his father and mother, son and daughter, brother and sister. For we are indeed compelled to do many things in the constraints of this world, either by the condition of the flesh or by the fragility of nature. But whoever has become such that he may minister in the sanctuary, and enter the inner court, and always offer sacrifice to God, so that he may be a true priest, indeed an imitator of Him of whom it is written: You are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek (Ps. 109:4), this one shall have no inheritance except God who is his inheritance; nor shall he receive possession among the people of Israel, that is, among the common folk; but [he shall have] a priestly [inheritance], so that the Lord may say of him: I am the inheritance and I am their possession." } When they find him, they will speak and say: I will hold him, and will not let him go; and they will sing with the prophet: The Lord is my portion (Ps. 2:26).

<h2 id='tocuniq335'>(Vers. 29, 30.)</h2>

(Verse 29, 30.) They themselves shall eat the offering for sin and the offering for guilt (or for ignorance), and every vow (or separation) in Israel shall be theirs. And the firstfruits of all the firstborn and all the offerings of everything they offer shall belong to the priests, and you shall give the priests the firstfruits of your food, that he may put a blessing on your house (or that he may bless your homes). For the victim and sacrifice, which is called Manaa in Hebrew, Aquila and Symmachus interpreted it as a gift. Again, for the vow which the Seventy translated as ἀφόρισμα, which means separation, Aquila and Symmachus and Theodotius interpreted it as a dedication, which is called Herem in Hebrew. And it should be considered that all the things which the Lord now speaks through the prophet, He had already spoken through Moses. And it should be asked why He repeats the same things that were said: so that the things which are in the minds of men, either erased by negligence in reading or despising and forgetting in hearing, may be renewed by the living voice, which is not written with pen and ink, but with the Spirit and Word of God. And so the Savior left no written work of his own, which in many cases the apocryphal writings concoct delusions about: but he speaks to the Father and his Spirit daily in the hearts of believers. And this will be the response against those who slander the prophets, why they repeat what is contained in the Pentateuch in their own writings. Therefore, let the priests eat the victim for sin and transgression, or ignorance, about whom it is written: They shall eat the sins of my people (Hosea IV, 8). There is not so much joy in offering gifts as there is fear of condemnation if we use them unworthily. The first fruits, according to the letter, are those of animals and things that are born first, and those that the earth first produces. The first fruits of our food are also offered to the priests, so that we may not taste any new fruits unless the priest has tasted them first. We do this so that the priest may return the blessing and our offering to his house, or that the Lord may bless our homes according to his own invocation. The dignity of priests is great, but their downfall is also great if they sin. Let us rejoice in their ascent, but let us fear their fall. The joy of having reached great heights is not as great as the sorrow of falling from them. For we will not only give an account for our own sins, but also for the sins of all those whose gifts we misuse, and we are not at all concerned about their salvation.

<h2 id='tocuniq336'>(Vers. 31.)</h2>

(Verse 31.) Priests shall not eat any dead or torn thing from birds or animals. And according to the letter, it is fitting for every chosen type, both royal and priestly, which specifically pertains to Christians, who are anointed with spiritual oil, as it is written: God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of gladness above your companions (Ps. 45:8). These precepts apply, so that the priests do not eat any dead thing, whether from birds or animals, whose blood has not been shed, as it is stated in the Acts of the Apostles that it was strangled. And these things, which must be observed, are warned about in the letter of the Apostles from Jerusalem (Acts 15). And they condemn the priests who do not abstain from eating thrushes, blackbirds, dormice, and other things of this kind out of gluttonous desire." } We can say, according to the anagoge, that the morticinum represents the death of the soul, and it imitates Nabal of Carmel, who is interpreted as foolish. When he heard about David's anger, he trembled with fear, and his heart died within him (1 Samuel 25). But when seized by beasts, so as not to be torn apart by their bites, the prophet sighs, saying: 'Do not deliver the soul of those who confess to you to the beasts' (Psalm 73:19). He is to be called the one devoured by the bites of the lion and the leopard, who does not change its spots, and the she-bear that rages when her cubs are taken, and the wolves of Arabia (the rage of the rabies), and the other beasts that we understand to represent the variation of demons. But we say that birds are those that raise their beaks to the sky, and those animals that bend down towards the earth, only serve their stomachs, and they serve those things that are beneath their stomachs.

<h2 id='tocuniq337'>(Cap. XLV.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 45, verses 1 and following) And when you begin to divide the land as an inheritance, set apart the first fruits, sanctified for the Lord, from the land of twenty-five thousand in length and ten thousand in width. It shall be sanctified in all its borders all around. It shall be sanctified on all sides, five hundred by five hundred, divided into four parts all around, with fifty cubits of outskirts. And you shall measure this according to the standard: the length shall be twenty-five thousand, and the width shall be ten thousand. And in it shall be the sanctuary, the most holy place. It shall be made holy from the ground for the priests who minister in the sanctuary, who draw near to minister to the Lord; and it shall be for them a place for houses and a sanctuary of holiness. The length shall be twenty-five thousand cubits, and the width ten thousand cubits. As for the Levites who minister in the temple, they shall have twenty chambers (for the Septuagint translates it as 'they shall possess the city to live in'). And you shall give a possession of the city five thousand in breadth, and five and twenty thousand in length, over against the oblation of the holy portion: it shall be for the whole house of Israel. And a portion shall be for the prince on both sides of the oblation of the holy portion, and of the possession of the city, before the oblation of the holy portion, and before the possession of the city, from the west side westward, and from the east side eastward: and the length shall be over against one of the portions, from the west border unto the east border. And the land shall be his possession in Israel: and my princes shall no more oppress my people, but they shall give the land to the house of Israel according to their tribes. Regarding the rituals of the priests, their worship, and the food they should consume and avoid: now he describes the land of the holy place, and before he divides it into three parts, he commands that a location be chosen from all the tribes, which should have a length of twenty-five thousand and a width of ten thousand. And because it is not specified whether it is cubits or feet or cubits, it is understood to mean the measuring rod that was in the man's hand, which measured six cubits and one-sixth of a cubit, that is, a παλαιστήν. Let the diligent reader calculate how many paces a mile's worth of reeds cover, and how many thousands in length and width there are. After this description, it again commands that from the consecrated land, chosen from all the tribes of Israel, namely, a length of twenty-five thousand reeds and a width of ten thousand reeds, be selected for building the sanctuary, that is, the temple of the Lord, with an additional inner area of five hundred reeds all around, that is, two thousand in total. And so that other buildings would not be joined to the building of the temple by chance, it is commanded that there be a fifty cubit empty space around the suburb, or as Symmachus and Theodotius and the Seventy translated, in a boundary, and separation, and space. With this description finished, another measure of complete separation of sanctification is commanded, that a piece of land measuring twenty-five thousand reeds in length and ten thousand in width be measured after the upper measure, in which there should be no temple, that is, no holy place, but a holy and most holy place, and the priests who approach the ministry of the Lord shall dwell there. But they dwell in that place, when they fulfill the priestly office, and let it be, as we have said, possession of twenty-five thousand acres in length and ten thousand in width. Moreover, the Levites, who serve the priests and have their own ministries, shall receive a place to build twenty treasuries; next to Aquila, dining halls; next to Symmachus, chambers; next to Theodotion, garrisons, or as the Septuagint translated, a city. By which we understand that a certain separate place for the dwelling of the Levites, called by the name of a city, which place is five thousand cubits in width, and twenty-five thousand in length. But all these, that is, the sanctuary, and the other sanctuary, the holy of holies, and the dwelling places of the priests, and the houses of the Levites who minister to the priests, are called separate and consecrated places for service and for the sanctification of the house of Israel. After the fourfold description of the Holy Land, the fifth division is given. The leader or ruler of the people shall take possession from here and there, that is, from both sides of the sanctuary, and reside in the city. Their possession shall overlook the separate place of the temple and the face of the city. And it shall stretch from the side of the sea, that is, from the west, to the other side of the sea, having a width that the prophet describes later in the description of each tribe. Finally, it follows: In terms of length, each of the 559 parts, which three each receive, from the Western boundary, that is, the sea, to the Eastern boundary, where it ends, we will know in the description of the tribes. And this will be the possession of the duke or prince in the land of Israel. These things have been said for the sake of understanding the simple narrative of history. But if we wish to compare spiritual things with spiritual, and, according to certain interpreters, ascend to higher things, who assert that the future is figured in the present, and that everything that is said pertains to the heavenly Jerusalem, which is the mother of us all, and to the church of the early Christians, it will not indeed be difficult to say what has been said by others: but we fear that a wise reader will by no means accept this kind of interpretation. At the present time, and for the Church which now labors in the world, and for those who hasten to go to heaven, everything should be referred, so that others may be chosen from the whole world to possess God, who are holy; others, who have advanced to greater things, may hold the most holy. In the ministers also there is a different order of priests and Levites, some of whom offer sacrifices to God daily with their prayers and virtues; others are in a lower and lesser degree, so that they may minister to those who have reached the highest peaks of virtue, and in the end there may be a leader or prince who can receive possession against one tribe; he may compensate for the merit of one with the merits of many, and while he is still in the world, possess a width from sea to sea; then from the West, or from the sea to the East, leaving the present and hastening to the future, and have his own assured possession, and never desire the possessions of others, and let each tribe hold its own portion: which can properly refer to bishops and presbyters, of whom it is said that they should not devastate and depopulate beyond the people of God, nor possess the land of Israel as an inheritance: but each should have his own possession which is appointed to his rank. However, twenty-five thousand are referred to the senses, which are repeated four times. Furthermore, ten thousand are for perfect knowledge, so that in one part only simple history is contained, and in the other part there is also discussion about theology and supernatural virtues, because the number ten is perfect. Also, it should be considered that priests, who are in a higher rank, possess twenty-five thousand in length and ten thousand in width. But the Levites, that is, the lower order, have the same number in length, that is, twenty-five thousand: but their width is limited to the number five. Hence only twenty gazophylacia are held: in which number the gifts of Esau are offered. But the true leader in the people, who truly deserves to receive the name of leader, receives possession of the sanctuary from both sides: namely from all those who are subject to his will, and from the city that he inhabits, and he receives the reward of many people's welfare. In the front temple, which is called the sanctuary, five hundred on each side are described by pens; and again fifty cubits, by which all the possession of the priests is separated. But in the second sanctuary, where the holy of holies are, the width of the temple and the space are not described, but the number is uncertain. Indeed, we find this also in the possession of the prince, who has possession in the people of Israel without any number, while the progress of all flows back to the prince: and the salvation of the students is the reward of the teachers.


<h2 id='tocuniq338'>(Vers. 9.)</h2>

(Verse 9.) Thus says the Lord God: Ample for you, O princes of Israel: cease wickedness and plundering, and do justice and righteousness, and separate your borders from my people, says the Lord God. For the plundering have multiplied misery by seventy: for the borders, oppression. The meaning is this: Because you have received your share, O princes, the Scripture says that you will also give to the prince on both sides as a separation of the possession of the sanctuary and the city; and your power is so great that your possession has taken a part of one tribe. Therefore, I command and admonish that your wickedness and plundering suffice up to this point, while you invade and plunder what is not yours. And because it is written: 'Depart from evil, and do good; seek peace, and pursue it.' (Ps. XXXVI, 27), judging the orphan, and defending the widow; separate your borders from my people, so that you do not move the boundaries. And because this very neighborhood oppresses the lowly, who cannot endure the arrogance of the mighty and powerful, so it is said through Isaiah: 'Woe to those who join house to house and field to field, until there is no more room.' Let this be said for the people of that time. Moreover, it can be applied to our leaders, who, like the Pharaohs and the Egyptians, oppress the children of Israel with power, and do not remember the scripture: 'They have made you a ruler, do not exalt yourself, but be among them as one of them' (Eccl. XXXII, 1). And that which the Lord speaks in the Gospel according to Luke: 'But if that servant says in his heart, 'My master is delayed in coming,' and begins to beat the male and female servants, to eat and drink and get drunk, the master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he does not know, and will cut him in pieces and put him with the unfaithful' (Luc. XII, 45, 46). He also instructs his disciples in the Gospel according to Matthew with these precepts: You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them. It shall not be so among you. But whoever would be great among you must be your servant, and whoever would be first among you must be your slave, even as the Son of Man came not to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many (Matthew 20:25). There are many things in Sacred Scripture that, if I were to delve into them, would humble the pride of the great and challenge everyone to humility, as the Lord says: Learn from me, for I am gentle and lowly in heart (Matthew 11:29).


<h2 id='tocuniq339'>Book Fourteen</h2>

Book Fourteen.

What I should have said at the beginning of Ezekiel's temple, I am now going to say out of order at the end, in memory of that verse (Virgil. lib. VI Aeneid.):

This is the labor, that house, and the unfathomable error.

The same poet also sings about this in another place (Aeneid. V).

As once in Crete there was a labyrinth, with winding passages hidden by its walls, and an intricate deception with a thousand paths, where the unsuspecting could be misled by signs and fall into an irretrievable error.

So I also entered into the depths of these Scriptures, the ocean of God's mysteries, so to speak, the labyrinth of which it is written: He made darkness his hiding place; and: Thick clouds surround him (Ps. 18:12). Indeed, I dare not claim to possess a perfect knowledge of the truth, but I have provided some indications of the teaching for those who desire to know, not by my own strength, but by the mercy of Christ, who himself unravels the deceit and ambiguities hidden in our errors, guiding us with the blind footsteps of the Holy Spirit. By following him, we may arrive at the port of explanations of the prophet Ezekiel, in whom the fourteenth and final book is found. If by your request, Virgin of Christ Eustochium, I shall bring my writing to its end, and the Lord of this life shall grant me the time, I shall pass on to Jeremiah, the one prophet who remains for us; his interpretation will indeed be the product of my toil, your prayers, but properly speaking, Christ's mercy.

<h2 id='tocuniq340'>563 (Cap. XLV.—.Vers. 10, seqq.)</h2>

563 (Chapter XLV. Verse 10, etc.) 'A just balance and a just ephah and a just bat shall be to you. The ephah and the bat shall be equal, and one measure shall be for both, so that the bat shall contain the tenth part of a homer, and the ephah the tenth part of a homer: according to the measure of the homer shall be the equal balance. Now a shekel has twenty obols. Furthermore, twenty shekels, and twenty-five shekels, and fifteen shekels make a mina.' LXX: A just balance, and a just measure, and a just dry measure shall be to you: I am the Lord your God, that brought you out of the land of Egypt. And ye shall observe all my statutes, and all my judgments and do them: I am the Lord. Decima pars gomor choenix, et decima pars gomor ephi Gomor erit aequum ad pondus viginti oboli. Viginti sicli: quinque et viginti sicli, et quindecim sicli mina erit vobis.\" This passage in the LXX does not match, and cannot be fully understood, as not only the numbers of measures but also the names have been changed. For they have interpreted pro ephi as a measure, a general name for a specific one, and for bato choenica: for homer as well, which in Hebrew is called κόρος, they translated it as gomor: and again for bato choenica. Let us therefore speak according to the Hebrew and the letter, and let us explain more clearly what seems to us in each case. The scale, which in Hebrew is called Mozene (), is understood in these things which are hung. Ephah, however, which is corrupted in the Greek language as Ἔφι, pertains to the measure of various fruits, for example, wheat, barley, legumes. Furthermore, the bath (which is also the same measure as the ephah) is used only for liquid substances, such as wine and oil, and the like. The cor measures thirty modii and holds the same amount in both dry and liquid substances. One-tenth of a cor, which is measured by the modius, is called an ephah, which is equivalent to three modii. And one-tenth of a cor in liquid substances is called a bath or vadus, so that the ephah and the bath are of the same measure. Furthermore, a sestertius, which is called στατὴρ in Greek, has twenty obols. But a mina, which is called mna, has sixty sestertii, which make twelve hundred obols. However, the mention of twenty sestertii, and twenty-five sestertii, and fifteen sestertii should not confuse the reader as they make a mina. For the difficulty lies in the numbers, to engage the attentive mind of the listener. Therefore, many things are said in parables and riddles so that those who have ears to hear may hear (Luke 8). And all prophecy contains truth in obscurity, so that the disciples may hear inwardly: the common and lowly people, who are outside, may not know what is said. Therefore, divine Scripture commands that the weights be just, saying: There shall not be in your bag a great and a small measure: a true and just balance shall you have, and a true and just measure shall you have ((to oneself)) (Leviticus 19:36). And in Proverbs it is said: Both the great and the small balance are abominable in the sight of God (Proverbs 11:1). Which indeed not only in commerce, and in the use of daily life, is to be observed by us, but in all things justice is to be guarded, the Scripture says: You shall make a balance and weights for your words, and in your words, and in your actions, and in your thoughts, may you do everything with measure and reason. And indeed we read in another place: For a faithful person, the whole world is full of riches: but for one who is unfaithful, not even a tiny coin. He may have said it in different words: The unbeliever possesses nothing in the world: but also needs the smallest portion. About this, it is said in other words in the Gospel: He will not come out from there, unless he gives back the last quarter (Matthew 5:26), that is, even the smallest and most minute coin. We read that ten minas were given to each servant to trade with (Luke 19): and in another parable talents were divided among the servants: and a debtor owed five hundred denarii, and fifty (Matthew 25): and the workers of the vineyard, who each received a denarius (Luke 7): and the widow woman, who had lost a drachma, and barely found it through the lighting of a lamp (Matthew 20, Luke 15). It is not the time to discuss all these things, which have meaning.

<h2 id='tocuniq341'>(Vers. 13, 14)</h2>

And these are the firstfruits which you shall offer: one-sixth of an ephah of wheat from the bushel, and one-sixth of an ephah of barley from the bushel. Also, the measurement of oil: one-tenth of a cor, and ten baths make up a cor, for ten baths fill a cor. LXX: And these are the firstfruits which you shall separate: one-sixth of a measure of wheat from the gomer, and one-sixth of an ephah of barley from the bushel, and a decree of oil, a cotyle, that is, a cyathus, of oil ten cotyles, for ten cotyles are a gomer. 565 And here, in the 70th edition, all the names of measures were confused, so that their meaning cannot be understood. For they had previously called the measure ephi and the choenix measure bato, and the gomer measure coro, and the shekel measure appendiculum, and they now called the measure ephi, and the coro measure gomer, and now they even called it corum. And in the measure of oil they called the bato measure kotyle, which means a cyathus. Let us first say, according to the letter, that the people were supposed to give one-tenth of all their produce to the Levites, as prescribed by the law. Again, from the tithes themselves, the Levites, that is, the lower degree of ministers, gave tithes to the priests: and this is what is called the δευτεροδεκάδη. There were also other tithes, which each person from the people of Israel separated in their own barns, to eat them when they went to the temple in the city of Jerusalem, and in the vestibule of the temple, and the priests and Levites invited them to feasts. There were also other tithes, which were entrusted to the poor, and these are called πτωχοδέκαδαι in Greek. However, the first fruits that were offered from crops were not defined by a specific number, but left to the discretion of the offerer. We have received the tradition of the Hebrews, not commanded by law, but established by the discretion of the teachers: the one who had much would give a fortieth part to the priests, the one who had little would give a sixtieth part, and it was allowed to offer anything between the fortieth and sixtieth parts. Therefore, what was left doubtful in the Pentateuch is specifically defined here due to the greed of the priests, so that they do not demand more from the people in the offering of first fruits, that is, they should offer a sixtieth part of those things that are produced from the earth. For if a corus, which is called in Hebrew Homer (), and is said by the LXX gomor, has thirty modios, both in dry and liquid species: an epha and a batus, as we have said above, are a tenth part of a corus, and it is prescribed that a sixth part of both epha and batus should be given to the priests in the offering of first fruits, which makes half a modium out of three modios, it is clearly calculated that the priests should receive a sixtieth part of the first fruits. For now, let this be sufficient to know and understand the literal and Hebrew truth. Now let us return to spiritual understanding, in which we must first inquire how it is to be done. Honor the Lord with your righteous labors, and give Him the fruits of your righteousness, that your storehouses may be filled with grain and your vats overflow with wine (Prov. III, 9); so that when you have offered the firstfruits of your labors and virtues, and have said, 'Behold, I have brought you the firstfruits of the produce of the land which you have given me, O Lord,' you may deserve to hear: 'Blessed are you in the city, and blessed are you in the field; blessed are the sons of your womb, and the produce of your land, and the increase of your cattle' (Deut. XXVIII, 3), and so on, and possess, according to the Apostle (Ephes. I), every spiritual blessing in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus: considering that whatever you have, you do not consider to be of your own virtue, but of His mercy, who has given the fruits. And if indeed we have such knowledge of the Scriptures that we may unfold and teach the mystical and hidden things to men, that is, to rational animals, we offer the first-fruits of our grain. But if, after the anagoge, we follow only the pure history, which can nourish the simple, according to what is written, 'Thou shalt save man and beast, O Lord' (Ps. 35:7), we offer the first-fruits of our barley, which Isaac sowed, but in a foreign land, and for it there sprang forth a hundred-fold (Gen. 26). The one who gives the firstfruits of barley can say: The Lord feeds me, and nothing will be lacking to me, he has placed me in a place of pasture: he has led me by the waters of refreshment (Ps 22:1, 2). But the one who feeds rational beings turns the sentiment and says: You have prepared a table before me against those who afflict me. And after he has offered the firstfruits of oil and wine, he joins and speaks: You have fattened my head with oil, and your inebriating cup is how excellent it is, with that oil which is most pure without dregs, it is prepared for the lamp of the Lord. He who prepares it, his face is exhilarated with oil; with the oil of exultation with which Christ was anointed before his companions; and the olive will sing like a prophet; But I am like a fruitful olive tree in the house of God (Ps. LI, 10). And with that wine that flows from the true vine in the presses of the Savior, as the Lord says: I am the vine, you are the branches, my Father is the vinedresser (John XV, 5). From these presses, we read three psalms, the eighth, the eightieth, and the eighty-third, which all refer to the sacraments of the Church. And in the old law, things were indeed without measure and innumerable: for God did not give the spirit by measure. But in the second building of the temple, which is contained in the prophecy of Ezekiel, there is a certain measure, that is, the number sixty, by which the world is completed, as it is said to us: With what measure you measure, it shall be measured to you again (Matt. VII, 2).

<h2 id='tocuniq342'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 and following) And one ram from the flock of two hundred, from those which nourish Israel, for a sacrifice, and for a burnt offering, and for peace offerings, to make atonement for them, says the Lord God: All the people of the land shall be bound by these firstfruits to this prince in Israel. And over the prince there shall be burnt offerings, and sacrifice, and drink offerings in the feasts, and in the new moons, and in the Sabbaths, and in all the solemnities of the house of Israel. He himself will make a sacrifice for sin, and a burnt offering, and a peace offering, to make expiation for the house of Israel. Above, it was said what portion of them which are to be offered, the measure both of dry and liquid spices, should be offered to the prince: now he observes the same order of firstfruits in animals: that one from the flock of two hundred rams should be commanded to be offered, which Israel feeds, for a sacrifice and a burnt offering, and a peace offering, to make expiation for the people of Israel, says the Lord God. What we have translated about the provisions for Israel is written in Hebrew as Memmasce, which Aquila and Symmachus interpret as 'from the waters,' and the Septuagint and Theodotion interpret as 'from the sources of drinking water.' One of these interpretations refers to irrigation, and the other to canals or pools, indicating that the first fruits of the ruler should be nurtured only in irrigated areas. Just as we read in previous passages that a sixtieth part should be offered to the ruler from what is attached and subject to measurement, now a two-hundredth part of the animals is commanded to be offered, and by such laws all the people are subject, offering what is necessary to the leader or ruler so that through him burnt offerings, sacrifices, and libations may be offered for the people, and the house of God may be cleansed. From this, it should be noted that just as the people are indebted to offer first fruits to the ruler, so the ruler is indebted to offer sacrifices for the people, whom according to tropology we can understand no other than the Lord Savior. This is the one who receives a ram from 568 animals, or as the Hebrew language more significantly shows, βόσκημα, which can be referred to all animals and not specifically to a ram, and he receives an animal or a ram that has been raised in irrigated places, namely the holy Scriptures, and can say, 'The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want. He makes me lie down in green pastures, he leads me beside still waters' (Psalm 23:1-2). These were wetlands, or rather canals, to which Jacob would lead his flocks so that they could drink and conceive in them, and according to the color of the rods, they would give birth to offspring for the Lord (Gen. XXX). For sacrifice, that is θυσίᾳ, Aquila and Symmachus translate it as a gift: which is called Manaa in Hebrew (), and properly does not pertain to the offering but to those things that are offered in sacrifice, such as flour, porridge, and oil. On the other hand, a burnt offering is that which is offered entirely to God and is consumed by sacred fire. Pacifica, when we are reconciled to God; and the Apostle speaks for us: We pray for Christ, be reconciled to God (2 Cor. 5:20). And in another place: God was in Christ, reconciling the world to himself (Ibid., 19). But this prince, to whom the firstfruits are offered, is also the king, as is shown on the title of the cross in Hebrew, Greek, and Latin letters. And when the Jews insisted that the triumphal title should be removed, the crowd of Gentiles answered Pilate: What I have written, I have written (John 19:22). Under the prince, he says, there will be. The dignity of priesthood will be conferred beautifully, to whom the duty is subject; so that he may know that he should offer sacrifice and libations which are offered from wine (or smoke) for the people in all solemnities: namely, on the calends, that is, on the first day of the month, as well as on the sabbaths: when darkness covers everything, the beginning of lunar light is: and on the rest of the sabbaths: so that he may do it indeed for sin, to atone for the house of Israel, which is the Church of the living God, column and foundation of truth. For this is the house of the living God, and the house of Israel, which is in need of atonement for their sins.

<h2 id='tocuniq343'>(Vers. 18 seqq.)</h2>

(Verses 18 onwards) Thus says the Lord God: In the first month, on the first day of the month, you shall take a young bull without blemish, and you shall cleanse the sanctuary. And the priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering and put it on the doorposts of the house, and on the four corners of the ledge of the altar, and on the doorposts of the gate of the inner court. So you shall do on the seventh day of the month for everyone who has sinned unintentionally or through ignorance, and you shall make atonement for the temple. In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, there will be for you a solemnity of the Passover: you shall eat unleavened bread for seven days. And on that day the prince shall make atonement for himself and for all the people of the land, offering a young bull for sin. And during the seven days of the solemnity, the prince shall offer a burnt offering to the Lord: seven young bulls and seven unblemished rams each day for seven days, and a male goat for sin each day. And he shall offer an ephah of flour with each bull, and an ephah with each ram, and a hin of oil with each ephah. In the seventh month, on the fifteenth day of the month, during the solemnity, he shall do as it was said above for seven days: both for sin and for burnt offering, and in sacrifice and in oil. I have included the entire passage so as not to disturb the reader's attention by dividing it into individual sections. And first, we must speak about the variety of interpretations. Where we rendered it, in the four corners of the base of the altar. The Septuagint translated it as above, and over the four corners of the temple, and over the altar. And where we said, for each one who is ignorant and deceived by error: they substituted for the ignorant and for the child. In that also where we said, the sacrifice of an ephah by a calf, and an ephah by a ram, and a hin of oil for each ephah: their edition maintains: you shall offer the sacrifice, and the cooking of the calf, and the cooking of the ram, and the cooking of the oil. In the last verse also, where we said: in the sacrifice and in the oil: they said, as in manna, as in oil: In the first, he says, month and on the first day of the month (no doubt, meaning Nisan) you shall take a calf from the herd: not one that has been raised at home, but one that is in the herd, that is, from the flock and the number of many. Also on the seventh day of the same month: which two solemnities, namely, the first day of the month and the seventh of the same, are not found in the Mosaic law. But the fourteenth day of the month, on which the Passover is celebrated, and which Moses commanded to be observed, when we eat unleavened bread for seven days.
