And the fourth solemnity, of which it is said: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, in the solemnity (Exodus XII), and so on, seems to me to signify the scenopegia, which he has placed here without a name. Therefore, let us go through each thing and briefly discuss what seems good to us. There are spiritual solemnities, as the Apostle teaches: Therefore let no one judge you in food, or in drink, or in regard to a feast day or a new moon or sabbaths, which are a shadow of things to come (Colossians 2:16). And thus God speaks through Isaiah: I do not accept your new moons, or sabbaths, or great days: your fasts, and holidays, and new moons, and solemnities, my soul hates (Isaiah 1:13). It is clear that whoever hates the Jewish feasts loves his own, namely the Sabbath that was left to the people of God, so that we may see what has been given to us by God, and speak not in the learned words of human wisdom, but in the teaching of the Spirit, comparing spiritual things with spiritual. For in the present age, which is under the power of the evil one, we cannot see good days, but in the new age: of which days the Holy Spirit sings in the Mosaic song: Remember the days of old: understand the years of generation upon generation (Deut. XXXII, 7). Of which Saint spoke in the psalm: In the night I ponder in my heart (Ps. LXXVI, 7). And again: And I have considered eternal years in my mind, and I have pondered (Ibid., 6). Let him who does not accept this understanding answer how he can explain what Isaiah prophesies about the future and the new age: There will be a month from month to month, and a Sabbath from Sabbath to Sabbath: and all flesh will come to worship the Lord (Isa. LXVI, 23): when the true worshipers will no longer worship on Mount Gerizim, nor in Jerusalem, but in spirit and truth (John IV); when there will be a new heaven and a new earth, and all creation will be set free from the bondage of corruption into the freedom of the children of God, and the sun will receive light seven times as much, and the moon will be compared to the sun (Rom. VIII, Isa. LXV). For we have come to Mount Zion, which is the interpretation of the watchtower, and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to thousands of angels in festal gathering. Concerning this festal gathering, another prophet also speaks: What will you do on the days of the assembly and the days of the Lord's festivity? (Hos. 9:5) This is what is also said elsewhere, Celebrate, Judah, your festivities; fulfill your vows. (Num. 1:15) Therefore, if we have learned spiritual festivities, we will also be taught spiritual sacrifices accordingly. A calf is taken from the herd, or a bull, as Symmachus interpreted 571, free and not burdened by yoke, that is, the burden of sins, and blameless: who did not commit sin, nor was deceit found in his mouth, a young calf, bearing horns and hooves: so that in him the sanctuary may be cleansed and atoned for. And the priest will take, he says, from his blood which will be for the sin of all: who in other words is called the lamb in Exodus, and in the Gospel, John the Baptist saying: Behold, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sins of the world (John 1:29). But the blood itself is precious, in which we are redeemed in the passion of the Lord and Savior; by whose flesh we are nourished, and by whose blood we are refreshed; by which the four corners of the altar are touched, which Theodotius placed there, the Hebrew word Azara (), or temple, as the LXX have translated: so that the house and altar may be sanctified. For all the elements of the world are sanctified by this blood: so that when someone is purified and cleansed, they may enter the gate of the inner court and be able to understand the secrets of the Lord, and subsequently come to the seventh day of the first month, and obtain rest, and offer a sacrifice to the Lord, both for their ignorance, of which David speaks: Remember not the sins of my youth, and my ignorances (Psalm 24:7), and for the little one, who, when he reaches the measure of a perfect man, will destroy those things that are of a child, and speak confidently: When I was a child, I spoke as a child, I understood as a child (2 Corinthians 13:11). Or for one who has been deceived by error, and has sinned not so much by will as by a good opinion. But when the two solemnities of the first month are completed, that is, of the first day and of its seventh, he comes to the fourteenth day of the month, in which the solemnity of the Passover is, of which it is written: For Christ our Pasch is sacrificed (1 Cor. 5:7). Then we eat unleavened bread for seven days, in rest and security of all things, when we eat the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth, destroying the leaven of malice and wickedness, our prince offering all these things for us, and first for himself. For he took on the human body, and through sin destroyed sin, he who suffers for us, and carries our infirmities: then, for his house, which is written in the LXX, but is not found in Hebrew, that is, for the Church, and for all the people of the earth, namely the whole human race, 572. For the Savior is the Savior of all men, and especially of the faithful, and he himself is the propitiation for our sins; and not only for ours, but for the whole world. But a calf is offered for the whole people of the earth, and on the remaining seven days of the Lord's passion, seven calves and seven unblemished rams are offered daily, to be consumed as a burnt offering and as the Lord's fire. And there are seven calves and seven rams, which symbolize the Lord's passion, so that they may imitate the true calf and the true ram, and the blood of the martyrs may purge the sins of the whole world for seven days. Also, a goat of the she-goats is offered for sin daily, namely for seven days. And it should be noted carefully that in the sacrifice of the calf, and the ram, and the hin of oil that is offered, these are the precepts of the Law. But in the offering of the goat, neither the hin nor (as the Septuagint has translated it) the preparation is included, which they have interpreted as the hin being πέμμα, that is, preparation. But the hin, which is a certain measure of oil, of which we have already spoken, is taken in the sacrifice of the calf and the ram: so that we may receive the nourishment of eternal light, and rest from labor, and the healing of weariness, after the appeasement of sins. In the seventh month also, on the fifteenth day of the month, which is the Feast of Tabernacles, the same order of offerings and sacrifices must be observed, both for sin and for burnt offering, and in the sacrifice, and in the oil; so that we may celebrate the Lord's feast, with darkness dispersed and the light of oil arisen: and that we may have brighter solemnities, in which all sins are forgiven.

<h2 id='tocuniq344'>(Cap. XLVI.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

Chapter 46, verses 1 and following. Thus says the Lord God: The gate of the inner court that faces east shall be closed for six days, during which the work is done; but on the Sabbath day it shall be opened, and also on the day of the new moon it shall be opened. The prince shall enter by the vestibule of the outer gate, and shall stand at the threshold of the gate; and the priests shall offer his burnt offering and his peace offerings, and he shall worship at the threshold of the gate and then go out; but the gate shall not be shut until evening. And the people of the land shall worship at the gate of that city on the Sabbath and on the first day of the month before the Lord. The prince shall offer this burnt offering to the Lord on the Sabbath day: six unblemished lambs and one unblemished ram, along with a grain offering of one ephah for each ram. The prince shall also offer a grain offering of whatever quantity he desires, along with one hin of oil for each ephah. And on the first day of the month, a young bull from the herd shall be offered, along with six lambs and unblemished rams. And he shall offer an ephah for a bull, and an ephah for a ram, and lambs as his hand shall find, and a hin of oil per ephah. Where we have translated ephah, which is a tenth part of a cor, the LXX translated πέμμα, which in our language means "cooking". And where we have said sacrifice, they have put the Hebrew word Manaa, which Aquila translated as gift or sacrifice, and Theodotion translated as sacrifice. And in the meantime, before we discuss what these things signify, we must explain the words of Scripture themselves in a paraphrastic manner. The gate, he says, of the inner court shall be closed for six days, of which it is written: You shall work for six days and do all your works (Exod. XXIII, 12), and not just any gate, but the one that faces the East, from where the sun of justice rises. But on the Sabbath day, that is the seventh day, on which there is rest, it shall be opened each week, and again, once the thirty days are completed, when the end of one month and the beginning of another is, that is, the new moon, on the day of the kalends, it shall be opened, so that what the seventh day has as a privilege in the week, the beginning of the month also has as a privilege. But why it is opened on the seventh day, and on the kalends day the inner gate of the atrium which looks out to the East is shown, the following discourse will explain. And the prince will enter, he says, through the way of the vestibule gate on the outside, namely of the outer atrium: and he will stand at the threshold of the inner gate of the atrium, which looks out to the East: nor will he enter the inner atrium, but while he stands there, other priests will perform the burnt offering for him, which offering Symmachus interpreted as holocaust: and the peace offerings, or those which pertain to salvation, so that after the prince's victim has been burned with sacred fire, and the leader reconciled to God, then he may be able to worship on the threshold of the inner gate of the atrium on which he has stood, and depart. What then? After the departure of the prince, will the gate be immediately closed? By no means! It will be open until evening; so that after the prince, all the people of the land may worship in front of the gate. They will worship on the Sabbaths and on the first days of the month when the gate is opened. And because he had said before: The priests will offer his burnt offering and his peace offerings, and had not indicated the number of burnt offerings; now he adds: But on the Sabbath day, the prince will offer this burnt offering to the Lord. However, the offering is not made by oneself, but by the priests, of whom it is written: 'And the priests shall offer his burnt offering and his peace offerings: six lambs, he says, without blemish, and one ram without blemish: and the measure of the ephah for the ram, which is called Epha (). But the sacrifice that can be offered by the hands of the one offering shall be six lambs; and for each ephah there shall be the measure of oil, which is called hin. But on the day of the new moon, which is the day of the new month, it shall have an additional privilege from the Sabbath, that a calf shall be sacrificed from the herd, or an unblemished bull.' Moreover, the rest, that is, six unblemished lambs and one unblemished ram, and their sacrifices, shall possess the ritual of the Sabbath: only in such a way that just as in the ram an ephah offering of flour and a hin of oil is offered, so shall it be offered in the calf. These things are set forth for the sake of clarity: now let us, with the gift of the Lord, unlock the spiritual meaning. But when we come to the seventh day, that is, the Sabbath day, on which eternal rest is, or to the first day of the month, when after a dark night and dreadful darkness, the beginning of light is, the Eastern gate is opened to us: and if any of us, through the merits of virtues, has attained the name and dignity of a leader by the way of the entrance-gate from without, that is, by the labors of this world: and shall enter the gate of the Church, which is still placed within earthly limits: not the interior court, for this is written in the present place; but to the threshold of the inner gate, and shall stand in it. But if the prince does not enter the inner courtyard, but stands at its threshold, there is no doubt that for now we see and know partially; and yet, with the face of the Lord not yet revealed, we contemplate His glory. Finally, with the prince standing at the threshold of the inner courtyard gate, the other priests, to whom this duty is delegated (whom we can understand as angelic virtues), will offer a burnt offering and peace offerings on his behalf. For we are born of the mercy of God, and every creature is unclean in comparison to the Creator, and it must be cleansed by divine fire, just as the lips of the prophet Isaiah were cleansed: so that after receiving peace through sacrifice, one may stand at the threshold and worship the omnipotence of God, and acknowledge one's unworthiness to enter the inner court, and then enter immediately. After the first one has exited, the inner gate of the court will not be closed until the evening of this age, but it will remain open: so that the people of the earth may come to the gate and worship Him: not at all times, but only when they have rested from sin and have received the light of faith, dispelling the darkness of ignorance. But this very burnt offering, which the prince offers through the priests on the Sabbath day, is concluded with the number of six unblemished lambs; namely, for the six days in which we work in the world, and a spotless ram, who is the prince of the flock; so that by each ram it is offered in the sacrifice of an ephah, that is, a tenth part of a cor. But in the sacrifice of the six lambs, a certain measure is not specified: but whatever amount the hand of him who offers may give, that is, according to the quality and quantity of the works (Matthew 25). But he shall offer a hin of oil for every ephah, which is the oil that five virgins have prepared for themselves, so that he may anoint the fine flour, or mix it, and every offering of God may be filled with the light of truth, and the face of the offerer may be brightened by the oil. But on the kalends, that is, on the thirtieth day, when the firstborn and the Levites are counted in the Law, apart from all of Israel, of which we have spoken above, an unblemished calf from the herd is offered, about which we have spoken more fully in the preceding chapter, and six lambs, and unblemished rams, and the rest that are offered on the sabbaths, so that we may obtain eternal rest and deserve to hear: Well done, good servant, because you have been faithful in few things, I will set you over many things, enter into the rest of your Lord (Matthew 25:21; Luke 19:17); and not only may we arrive at the gate of the inner court, but we may also enter its innermost sanctuary, and possess it through our actions: Planted in the house of the Lord, they will flourish in the courts of our God (Psalm 92:14).


<h2 id='tocuniq345'>576 (Vers. 8 seqq.)</h2>

576 (Verse 8 onwards) When the prince enters, let him enter through the way of the vestibule of the gate, and let him exit through the same way. And when the people of the land enter in the presence of the Lord during the solemnities, let the one who enters through the North gate to worship, exit through the way of the South gate, and let the one who enters through the way of the South gate, exit through the way of the North gate. He shall not return through the way of the gate through which he entered, but shall exit opposite to it. But the prince, in the midst of them, shall enter when they enter, and shall go out when they go out. And in the markets and solemnities, there shall be a sacrifice of one ephah by a calf, and one ephah by a ram. But the sacrifice of a lamb shall be according to his ability: and there shall be a hin of oil for each ephah. That prince, of whom it is said above: 'And the prince shall enter by the way of the porch of the gate without, and shall go out by the same way, and shall enter by the same gate' (John 10), has free will and the power to lay down his life and to take it up again. And in coming to us, as well as in ascending to heaven, he exercises the same liberty of his majesty. Finally, he does not seek markets or festivities, nor does he observe any difference between days, because every time is a celebration for him. But the people only go to the markets and festivities, and they enter and exit through a different road each time. For it is written: 'And when the people of the land enter before the Lord at the festivities, let the one who enters through the North gate to worship, exit through the South gate, and let the one who enters through the South gate, exit through the North gate. They shall not return through the gate they entered, but shall go out opposite to it.' This is not only commanded to those who depart from Sodom, and it is said to them: Do not look back (Gen. XIX, 17); nor to those who put their hand to the plow, so that they do not look back at what is behind: but also to those who are established in the house of the Lord, it is ordered that they do not look back, and that they do not turn back to the poor and weak elements, and being initiated by the spirit, they are consumed by the flesh (or they are consumed): but that they may also advance from spiritual things to greater things, and say with the Apostle: Forgetting what is behind, and stretching forth to what is before (Phil. III, 13): so that they may not know in part and prophesy in part, but that they may come to perfection according to that perfection which human nature can attain, so that we may understand that Gospel saying: And when you have done all things, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done what we were obliged to do (Luke XVII, 10). And the Apostle, in the same Epistle, speaks of two perfections: for he writes as though he were imperfect, saying: Not as though I had already taken hold, or were already perfect: but I follow after, if I may by any means apprehend that for which also I am apprehended by Christ Jesus (Philippians 3:13). And immediately, as though he were perfect, he says: But one thing I do: forgetting those things which are behind, and stretching forth myself to those things which are before, I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus. Therefore, let us understand this: as many as we are perfect, let us know (Alex. we know) (Ibid. XIV). For how can the idea stand, that the one who said, 'Not because I have already received or because I am already perfect,' dare to say, 'Therefore, as many as we are perfect, let us know?' From this it is clear that every human being, and the whole of creation, although it has come to perfection, still needs the mercy of God and possesses complete perfection from grace, not from merit. And so it is commanded to the people of the land, that if one enters through the gate of the North to worship, they shall exit through the way of the gate of the South. Who is this people to whom this is commanded? Namely, the gentiles; so that anyone who, having forsaken the gate of the North, from which evils are kindled upon the earth, has entered the temple, shall not exit except through the way of the gate of the South, to the gate of light, to the gate of heat, to the gate where the bridegroom lies at midday (Jer. I). Finally, it is said in the same Song of Songs: Arise, north wind, and come, south wind (Song of Songs IV, 16). But he who enters through the southern gate should leave by the northern gate. Who is this people? It is the Jews, who, forsaking the gate of the way of light, go to the gate of the north, of which it is said: The north wind is a very strong wind (Jeremiah I). For even Jeremiah's pot is kindled by the face of the north. Let us also say this in another way: He who forgives sins enters through the northern gate, and he who follows virtues leaves through the southern gate. And on the other hand, if the righteous one should fall into sin, he enters indeed through the southern gate, but he exits through the way of the northern gate. The prince, however, he says, will be in their midst, namely, of those who enter and those who exit, according to what is written: He stands in your midst, whom you do not know (John 1:26). And the Apostle: Do you not know that Christ is in you? (2 Corinthians 13:5). But if it is said to those who do not know that Christ stands in their midst, how much more to those who know! But when Christ stood among the knowledgeable, then the dead body will be made because of sin, and the living spirit because of righteousness. The prince enters with those entering, and exits with those exiting, bearing witness to both virtue and sin. Therefore, in the markets and in the solemnities, namely the Sabbaths, the first days of the month, and all the festivities we have spoken of earlier, both a calf and a ram will be offered in sacrifice, each with a measure of ephah. But in the agnishowever, there will not be a fixed number, nor a most extreme will; but rather, one should use their abilities and act in good conscience: to offer as much as one is able, not as much as one desires, and above all, a hin of oil for each ephah, so that a similar offering may be anointed, and a lamp may be lit in the presence of the Lord; and let the one who uses it be able to say: But as for me, I am like a fruitful olive tree in the house of the Lord (Ps. LI, 10).

<h2 id='tocuniq346'>(Vers. 12 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 12 seqq.) However, when the ruler offers a voluntary burnt offering or a voluntary peace offering to the Lord, the gate that faces east shall be opened for him, and he shall make his burnt offering and peace offering as is customary on the Sabbath day. After he has left, the gate shall be closed. And he shall offer a year-old unblemished lamb as a burnt offering to the Lord every day ((the Vulgate adds always)): he shall offer it in the morning and in the morning he shall offer it again. And he shall offer a sacrifice (or a grain offering) upon it in the morning, one-sixth of an ephah (or measure) of fine flour mixed with a third of a hin of oil, and ((the Vulgate adds that)) it shall be mixed (or according to Symmachus, sprinkled) with a sacrifice (or grain offering) of wheat, a lawful, perpetual offering to the Lord. You shall make a lamb and a sacrifice, and oil every morning, a perpetual burnt offering. Where we read 'immaculate,' it is written in Hebrew 'tamim,' which Aquila interprets as 'perfect.' And where LXX reads 'manah,' Theodotion translates it as 'sacrifice'; Aquila and Symmachus translate it as 'gift.' But for what we said 'spontaneous,' LXX translates it as 'confession,' and for 'prince,' they translated it as 'leader,' for this is what 'nasi' signifies. Moreover, the conversation is still about the prince, about whom Isaiah speaks: Behold, I have given him as a witness to the nations, a leader and teacher to the nations (Isa. 55:4). And Ezekiel: And I will be their God, and David a prince among them (Ezek. 34:24). Therefore, when this prince acts voluntarily and says: Let the voluntary, or spontaneous, pleasing things of my mouth be done, O Lord (Ps. 119:108): the voluntary burnt offering, that he may offer himself completely to God, and the peaceful voluntary, which is not found in the previous texts; for it is written: And the priests shall offer his burnt offering and his peace offering: and with regards to his voluntary and spontaneous offerings, which are now being mentioned, it is completely silent, so that they are not done out of necessity, but out of free will: after the burnt offering, let him offer the peace offering, and be reconciled to God. And where virginity is greater than marriage (I Cor. VII), because it is not demanded, nor restored, but offered. The reconciliations, which in Hebrew are called Selamim, are interpreted by the LXX as salutary: so that the reconciliation itself of the peacemakers may be the salvation of the offerer. Therefore, when the prince does this, the gate will be opened to him; or according to the Seventy, the gate that looks towards the East will be opened to him; that gate, namely, concerning which it is written: This is the gate of the Lord; the righteous shall enter through it (Ps. CXVII, 20), and where the sun of justice rises. And he will make his holocaust and his peace offering, of which we have spoken now. But he will make it, because it is a voluntary sacrifice, and no other priests will make it for him, as is usually done on the Sabbath day. Therefore, at all times, the holocaust and peace offering, which are offered voluntarily, have the gate of the Lord reserved for them; neither does he observe the Sabbath, but all days are considered rest to him. Finally, after he has offered his holocaust and peace offering, he immediately goes out, and the door is closed behind him, or the door is closed: so that his privilege may be preserved for the ruler, and his sacrifices may not be mixed with those of the people. And because he had said in general, a voluntary holocaust, or a peaceful voluntary offering to the Lord, without specifying a bull or a calf, and a ram or a sheep, and a male goat for sin, he teaches what the holocaust itself is: A lamb, he says, a one-year-old unblemished lamb, he shall make a holocaust: and not on specific days, but every day, and not at any hour, but in the morning, yes, in the morning he shall make it: specifically every morning, when the sun rises, the beginning of light. About what does David speak in the psalm: In the morning, you will hear my voice; in the morning, I will stand before you and see. (Ps. 5:4) And in another place: Weeping may stay for the night, but rejoicing comes in the morning. (Ps. 30:6) And again: O God, you are my God; early will I seek you. (Ps. 63:1) But who is this spotless lamb, or perfect and humble, Isaiah explains more fully, saying: He was led like a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before its shearers is silent, so he did not open his mouth. (Isaiah 53:7) And Jeremiah: But I was like a gentle lamb led to the slaughter; I did not know (Jer. XI, 19). And John the Baptist: Behold the Lamb of God, who takes away the sins of the world (John I, 29). This is the Lamb who is sacrificed in Egypt, whose blood arms the doorposts of faith, and the destroyer is excluded (Exod. XII). And the year of the Lord's favor, and the day of retribution were announced. Let not the reader be surprised, if he is also called prince, and priest, and calf, and ram, and lamb, for in the holy Scriptures we read of him as Lord, and God, and man, and prophet, and rod, and root, and flower, and prince, and judge, and king, righteous, and justice, apostle, and bishop, arm, servant, ointment, shepherd, son, and child, only-begotten, and firstborn, door, way, angel, arrow, and wisdom, and many other things, all of which, if I were to present the testimonies, would require a separate book. Therefore, in the holocaust of this immaculate and one-year-old lamb, which is always offered in the morning, the high priest himself will perform the sacrifice, whether it is a Manaa or a similar offering. The morning offering, a sextam partem ephi, is understood to be made of fine flour. And a sexta pars ephi is half a modius. For if an ephi is a tenth part of a corus, that is, three modii, there is no doubt that a sexta pars ephi would make half a modius. From the hin of oil, a third part is offered: to be mixed with or sprinkled on the flour sacrifice to God, a lawful, continual, and perpetual sacrifice, which is not interrupted on any day, but is always offered at all times, when the sun rises, in order to fulfill what is written at the end of this chapter: He shall make a lamb as a sacrificial offering, and oil in the morning, a perpetual holocaust.


<h2 id='tocuniq347'>581 (Vers. 16, 17 et seqq.)</h2>

Verses 16, 17 and so on. Thus says the Lord God: If a prince (or leader) gives a gift to one of his sons, it will be the inheritance of his sons and they will possess it as an inheritance. But if he gives a legacy from his inheritance to one of his servants, it will belong to that servant until the year of remission (for which Theodotius put the Hebrew word, Deror), but then it will return to the prince, and the inheritance will belong to his son. And the ruler shall not take the inheritance of the people by violence, nor from their possession, but shall give his own inheritance to his sons, so that my people may not be scattered, each one from his possession. So far, we have spoken about the ruler, now we turn to his heirs: indeed, about the gifts, inheritance, and legacies that he should give, and whose possession may be temporal or eternal. If, he says, he has given a gift or inheritance to his sons, they shall possess it, because they are entitled to it by succession, and possession cannot pass from one to another. But if he shall give to one of his servants in the name of a legate, he shall possess him as long as the seventh year of remission, which is called the Deror (), or the jubilee, that is, the fiftieth, shall come: when all sale and gift return to the former owners: so that the servant shall have the use for a time, and the ownership of the possession for the son of the prince. But what follows: And the prince shall not take of the inheritance of the people by violence (Lev. XXIII), or as the Seventy have translated, to oppress them, or as Aquila and Symmachus, to afflict and distress them: but he shall give his inheritance to his sons: it rebukes not only the priests and princes of that time, but also ours, who become richer by the dignity of the priesthood, and besides those things which are owed to them by the disposition of the Lord, they take by violence from the poor: or under the name of honor, they plunder the rich, so that they also owe nothing to their own sons, to whom paternal inheritance is due, except what has been left to them by their parents. Therefore, whoever is a rich priest, when he comes to the priesthood, whatever he has in excess, he should not give to his sons, but to the poor, and to the holy brothers, and to the faithful servants, who surpass the merits of children, in order to give back what belongs to the Lord, to his Master, who speaks in the Gospel: Whatever you have done to the least of these, you have done to me (Matthew 25:40). For he himself is received as a guest in the poor; he is visited in prison; he is clothed in nakedness; he drinks when he is thirsty; he is filled when he is hungry. Lest my people be dispersed from their possession, says he. For if the ruler has the power, either to take or to seize, or to hold under the guise of honor that which is not his own, and to leave nothing for his children, then the people who had been gathered in the name of God will be scattered and torn apart: either according to the Law, so that another's inheritance does not gradually pass to another, and the cord of division perishes, through which perhaps the inheritance comes to each one. Therefore, he disperses the people of God and takes away from them eternal possession of faith, who abandons the gifts or goods of others through theft, robbery, flattery, or deception under the guise of religion, to his sons, brothers, and relatives.

<h2 id='tocuniq348'>(Vers. 19 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 19 and following) And he led me through the entrance that was on the side (or behind) the gate, into the storerooms of the sanctuary, to the priests (or into the chambers and rooms) that faced north. And behold, there was a place sloping toward the west (or toward the sea: and as the Septuagint translated, separated). And he said to me: This is the place where the priests boil, for guilt and for sin (or for ignorance and therefore) where they boil the sacrifice (or the manna and the gift) so that they do not carry them to the outer court, and the people may be sanctified. And he led me into the outer court, and he brought me around through the four corners of the court. And behold, there was a small courtyard in the corner of the court, with small courtyards at each corner of the court. The small courtyards were arranged in the four corners of the court, forty cubits long and thirty cubits wide. The measurements of each one were the same: and there was a wall surrounding the four small courtyards. And beneath the porticoes around (or near) were kitchens built (or stalls, which Aquila interpreted as στιβάδας, Symmachus as περιφράγματα, Theodotion translated the Hebrew word as Turoth). And he said, he said to me: This is the house of the kitchens, in which the ministers of the house cook the sacrifices of the people [Vulg. adds to the Lord (or victim): For this in Hebrew signifies Zeba (): The man who held a reed in his hand and a measuring line of the mason, with which he measured the building 583, introduced, he said, me through the entrance, which was on the side of the gate, or behind the gate. And he did not specify whose gate, Eastern, Southern, or of another region: but he left it uncertain, so that I would go to the place of the sanctuary, and to the treasury, or to the chambers of the priests, which looked towards the north and towards the sea: namely, towards the north and towards the west: this Holy Scripture having this custom, that it always calls the western sea according to the position of the land of Judea. And it should be considered that the place of the priests, where for a fault, or ignorance, and for a sin they cook sacrifices, lest they be offered raw, is placed in the outer courtyard towards the North and West: from where the coldest wind rises, and where the light of the sun sets. From which it is shown that whatever pertains to food, is either for error, or for sin. But if a sacrifice is also offered for ignorance, how much more for the conscience of a fault! Therefore Job also offered a daily morning sacrifice for his sons (Job. I), fearing lest they had sinned in ignorance. But that which follows: That they do not offer in the outer courtyard, and the people should be sanctified, who had not been prepared for sanctification, that indicates, that we should not easily give holy things to those who are not sanctified: nor cast, according to the Gospel, pearls before swine, nor give the holy to dogs (Mat. VII). Finally Moses wants the people to be sanctified from every impurity, and from the embrace of wives, so that they may approach Mount Sinai, and sanctified receive the holy things (Exod. XIX). But if they are commanded to be sanctified to hear and receive the words of God, it is clear in the Law that that Apostolic saying is contained: Do not defraud one another, unless perhaps by agreement for a time, so that you may devote yourselves to prayer (I Cor. VII, 5): and by agreement abstain from wives, so that we may devote ourselves to prayer. After this it is written: And he led me into the outer courtyard, and he led me around the four corners of the courtyard: and behold there was a small courtyard in the corner of the courtyard, each small courtyard placed in the four corners of the courtyard. That man whom he often mentions, led him from the place of the priests which turned towards the North, or 584 which was separated, where the priests cook for a fault, and for a sin, or for ignorance: but he led him into the outer courtyard. From which we understand that that courtyard from which he went out was inside, and that there were many courtyards in the Holy Scriptures, of which we read: You who stand in the house of the Lord, in the courtyards of the house of our God (Ps. CXXXIV, 2). And in John: And I have other sheep that are not of this courtyard, and it is necessary for me to bring them: and they will hear my voice, and there will be one courtyard and one shepherd (John. X, 16): for this in Greek means αὐλὴ, which Latin simplicity translates as ovile. But when he says, of this courtyard, he shows that there is another: which is either in the multitude of the Gentiles as a distinction from Israel, or in heaven as a separation from the earthly courtyard: and for the quality of merits each one is entrusted with a courtyard, about which we have already discussed more fully in the preceding. But this courtyard, of which we are now speaking, had small courtyards at each of the four corners, which the LXX call minor, and we, for the sake of ease of understanding, have called small courtyards. They were forty cubits long, and thirty wide. Concerning these numbers, I remember disputing with this same Prophet, that one refers to tribulations and constraints, and the other to perfect age. For forty days Moses, and Elijah, and the Lord and Savior fasted in the desert (Exod. XXXIV; III Reg. XIX; Mat. IV; Luc. III): and they do not approach the priestly office until after the twenty-fifth year of age, but after the thirtieth. Therefore the Lord was thirty years old when he came to baptism: and in this same Prophet the thirtieth year is mentioned at the beginning. Where there is food, there is also distress and temptation, through which food is prepared. And where we have come to the age of a perfect man, there all must be trodden down, and we must say: Having food and clothing, let us be content with these (I Tim. VI, 8). And: If the Lord gives me food to eat, and clothing to cover me (Gen. XXVIII, 20). Or certainly this: Food for the belly, and the belly for food: but God will destroy both it and them (I Cor. VI, 13). For we will not eat and drink in the future, but we will feed on that bread which descends from heaven, of which it is sung in the Psalms: The bread of angels man has eaten (Ps. LXXVI, 25). And: My food is to do the will of him who sent me (John. IV, 34). But that the measure of one small courtyard was four, which possessed the corners of the larger courtyard, signifies the four corners of the world (Genes. III): that in the sweat of our face we may eat bread, and all our labor may profit the belly: which four small courtyards, or one wall surrounded, and the kitchens were built below the porticoes all around, or they had adjacent dining areas: so where there is food, there is also the preparation of measures. And lest the prophet should perhaps not know what he saw, he said to him: This is the house of the kitchens, in which the ministers of the Lord cook the sacrifices of the people. Indeed, the sacrifices of the people, which are offered for a fault, or a sin, and ignorance, are food, and refreshments for the priests: so that they may remember that they should seek nothing else, since even in the temple meats are prepared for their refreshment.

<h2 id='tocuniq349'>(Cap. XLVII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 47, Verses 1 and following.) And he brought me back to the door of the house, and behold, water was flowing out from under the threshold of the house toward the east. The face of the house was toward the east. And the water was flowing down from the right side of the temple toward the south of the altar. Then he brought me out by way of the north gate and led me around to the outer gate facing east. And behold, the water was gushing out on the right side as the man went eastward with a measuring line in his hand. He measured a thousand cubits and led me through the water, and it was ankle-deep (or, the water came up to the ankles). And he measured a thousand cubits, and led me through water up to the knees (or he passed through the water up to the thighs). And he measured a thousand cubits, and led me through water up to the loins (or he passed through the water up to the waist). And he measured a thousand cubits, a river that I could not pass through, for the waters had risen, a deep torrent (Some Greek manuscripts read 'deep water') that could not be crossed. For the LXX translated it: And he measured a thousand cubits, and could not pass through, for the water was carrying like a precipitous torrent, which cannot be crossed. These waters that flowed underground beneath the threshold of the house, that is, the temple, were not carried to the north and to the west, but also to the east and on the right side of the temple, that is, to the south, and specifically to the altar. From this it is clear that these waters are sacred and signify the teaching of our Savior, according to what is written: 'Out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem' (Isaiah 2:3). And in another place: The knowledge of the Lord shall fill the earth as water covers the sea (Isaiah 11:9). Concerning these waters, the Prophet Zechariah prophesied, saying: On that day, living water shall flow out from Jerusalem, half to the eastern sea and half to the western sea (Zechariah 14:8). Concerning these waters, the Lord spoke to the Samaritan woman: If you knew the gift of God and who it is that asks you for a drink, you would have asked him and he would have given you living water (John 4:10). And again: Everyone who drinks of this water will be thirsty again, but whoever drinks of the water that I will give him will never be thirsty again. (John, 4). And in the temple he cried out and said: If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink. Whoever believes in me (as the Scripture has said), 'Out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.' This he said about the Spirit, whom those who believed in him were to receive. (John 7:37-38). These are the waters of which the prophet spoke in the psalm: He leads me beside still waters. (Psalm 23:2). And Ezekiel said: 'I will take you from the nations and gather you from all the countries and I will sprinkle clean water upon you, and you shall be clean from all your uncleannesses. For I will cleanse you from all your idols.' (Ezekiel 36:24, 25) 'The rivers have lifted up, O Lord, the rivers have lifted up their voice, the rivers have lifted up their roaring.' (Psalm 93:3) These are the waters of Siloam that flow gently, of which Isaiah speaks: 'With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation.' (Isaiah 12:3) And the Psalmist says: Bless the Lord from the fountains of Israel (Ps. 68). And likewise Isaiah speaks of the Lord as Savior: This one, he says, shall dwell in the lofty cave of the strongest rock. Bread shall be given to him, and his water shall be faithful (Isa. 33:16). For water gushed forth in the desert, and a valley in a thirsty land. And it is said to those who believe: Do not fear, for I have redeemed you; you are mine, and if you pass through water, I am with you (Isa. 43:1-2). And again: You who thirst, go to the water (Isaiah 55:1): And through Jeremiah God speaks (Isaiah 55:1): My people have committed two evils. They have forsaken me, the fountain of living water, and have dug for themselves cisterns that cannot hold water (Jeremiah 2:13). Therefore, just as we read in a positive sense about the waters that flow out from the threshold of the temple and are brought back to the teaching of the Church, so there are bitter waters and very bad waters which Jeremiah the prophet prohibits us from approaching, saying (Ibid. 18): What to you is the way of Egypt, that you may drink from the waters of Geon? The Hebrew word for 'turbid and muddy' is Sior. Concerning this, God speaks angrily about the heretics: Behold, I will feed them with bitterness and give them poisoned water to drink (Jeremiah 9:15), in which the Egyptian dragon reigns, who says: The rivers are mine, and I have made them; he sees all that is high and he himself is the king of those who are in the waters. Therefore, the man Ecclesiasticus prays to the Lord and says: Save me, Lord, for the waters have come up to my neck. I am stuck in the mire of the deep, and there is no substance, and the storm has engulfed me (Ps. 68:1-2). And again; Deliver me from those who hate me, and from the depths of the waters: let not the waterstorm cast me down, let not the deep swallow me up, nor let the pit close its mouth over me (Ibid. 15:16). And in another psalm: If it had not been that the Lord was on our side, let Israel now say: If it had not been that the Lord was on our side, when men rose up against us, perhaps they would have swallowed us alive." } When their anger was provoked against us, perhaps the water would have engulfed us (Psalm 123:1-3). And the Bride in the Song of Songs: Many waters cannot quench love, nor can rivers drown it (Song of Songs 8:7). This is the water of which Hosea says: The city of Galaad has scorned me, a city that works in vanities, stirring up the water and its men's strength are pirates (Hosea 6:7-8). This water is called Mara, which means bitterness; into it the wood of the Cross is thrown, and the bitter is turned into sweet." } Consider the law of Moses, if it is understood according to the carnal sense of the Jews, how bitter it is, digging out an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth (Exodus XXI): see Thamar's fornication (2 Samuel XIII), and the joining of the harlot by Hosea, Jeremiah's girdle (Hosea I, Jeremiah XIII), Moses' Ethiopian wife, and the killing of the Egyptian, and a thousand other things, which if we understand according to the literal meaning, and not according to the life-giving spirit, are bitter, and do not edify their reader as much as they destroy him (Numbers XII, Exodus II). Therefore, these waters that flow out of the temple of the Lord, and proceed to the East, and descend to the right side of the Temple, to the South altar, where the bridegroom feeds his guests, and reclines. But what follows: And he led me through the way of the North gate, and turned to the way outside the outer gate, the way that faced the East, it secretly shows that we cannot immediately reach the Eastern gate, unless we go through the way of the North gate and come to it in a long circuit. For unless we have overcome the extremely cold wind with the heat of faith, and have tread upon its regions, so that what is written by the Apostle may be fulfilled in us: 'But the God of peace will crush Satan under your feet speedily' (Rom. XVI, 20), we will not be able to enter the gate through which the waters flow and are on the right side. And note that these waters which enter through the gate of the East so flee to the left parts, that they are described as going from the right side of the altar to the South. And the man, he said, who had a rope in his hand, when he led me through the gate on the north side to the road that faced the East, and he himself was in the same place, measured a thousand cubits of the same water; and he led me through the water up to the ankles, which Aquila and Symmachus, and Theodotion have interpreted as ἀστραγάλοι, for which the LXX translated: and he shall pass through the water, the water of remission: which we can understand to signify the first sins of men, which are forgiven by the waters of the Lord as we enter, and show the saving grace of baptism and are the beginnings of progress, yet themselves are exalted. Finally, they reach the ankles, which are close to the heels. This is where the snake bites, as the Lord says: 'You shall strike his head, and he shall strike your heel' (Gen. III, 15, LXX). And in the Psalms concerning Judas the betrayer, it is said: 'Even the one who ate my bread has lifted up his heel against me' (Ps. XL, 10), or his heel, for this is what the Greek word πτέρνη (Mss. πτέρνα) means. After a thousand cubits, they reached the heel and measured another thousand cubits in water, and led me up to the knees. After the remission of sins, and during our journey, when we endeavor to ascend a little from earthly things to higher things, we bend our knees to the Lord, as the Apostle says: 'That at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those that are in heaven, on earth, and under the earth; and that every tongue should confess that the Lord Jesus Christ is in the glory of God the Father' (Philippians 2:10). It is measured as three thousand other cubits, and it carried me through the water up to the kidneys. For we ascend to lofty things by steps: and yet those very lofty things themselves reach to the loins and kidneys, so that every ignoble desire in us may be cut off; and we may possess sanctification of the body, without which no one sees God. Hence also in this same prophet (Supra VIII): from the feet to the loins God of fire is seen. For they need fire, and the purifying works of the loins, as the just one says: For my loins are filled with illusions (Ps. XXXVII, 8), through which the enemy deceives us both in the day and in the night's phantasm. From the loins to the head and the crown, it shines with the gleam of the most precious metal, amber. So that it has nothing filthy in it, nothing of worthlessness. Hence, it is now said for the fourth time: And it was measured as a thousand, the river (which the Seventy did not translate) that I could not cross over: much better than the Seventy who said, and he could not cross over. For the prophet and all human nature, after the loins of the river of thoughts and the impulses of vices in the heart, cannot cross over. But that man who was clothed in Baddim, and a leader of prophets, passed through without difficulty: who did not commit sin, nor was deceit found in his mouth (Isa. 56). And he explains the reasons why the prophet could not pass through a thousand cubits: because, he says, the deep waters of the torrent had swelled, which could not be crossed. And how is it written, as the prophet boasts: Our soul has passed through the torrent (Ps. 124:5)? But it is easily solved if we know that this is written in Hebrew: A torrent has passed through my soul. Isaiah speaks about this torrent: Behold, I will extend peace to them like a river, and the glory like a torrent overflowing (Isa. 66:12). And in the thirty-fifth psalm about the holy ones, it is said: In the protection of your wings they will hope. They will be drunk with the abundance of your house, and you will give them to drink from the torrent of your delights; for with you is the fountain of life (Ps. 36:8-9). And on the one hundred and twenty-fifth: Convert, O Lord, our captivity, like a torrent in the South (Ps. 125:5). And concerning the Savior: He shall drink from the brook by the way (Ps. 110:7). For who among men can boast of having a pure heart (Prov. 20)? Or whose mind, through the windows of the eyes, has not been entered by the death of desire (Jer. 9), and (to say the least) the stimulation of the soul? For the world is placed in wickedness (1 John 5:19); and from childhood, the heart of man is inclined to evil, so that not even for one day from the beginning of his existence, human condition is without sin (Job. 15). And so David confesses in the psalm: Behold, I was conceived in iniquities, and in sins my mother conceived me (Ps. 50:7). Not in the iniquities of my mother, or certainly my own, but in the iniquities of human condition. And so the Apostle says: Death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who did not sin in the likeness of the transgression of Adam (Rom. 5:14). We use the masculine form 'cubitos' instead of the neutral form 'cubita' according to the rules of grammar, as I have taught in previous explanations. We do this not out of ignorance, but out of custom for the sake of the simple and uneducated, of whom there are many in the congregation of the Church.


<h2 id='tocuniq350'>(Vers. 6 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 6 and following) And he said to me: Surely you have seen, son of man; and he brought me out, and turned me toward the bank of the river (or stream). And when I turned (or had turned), behold, on the bank of the river (or stream) there were very many trees (or very many trees) on both sides. And he said to me: These waters that go out to the hills of the East (or to the hills of the East), and go down to the plains of the desert (or this water that goes out into Galilee, which turns toward the East, and goes down to Arabia), will enter the sea, and they will come out, and the waters will be healed. And every living creature (or animal) that moves (or crawls), wherever the stream (or river) goes, will live: and there will be many fish after these waters come there: and they will be healed, and everything will live wherever the stream (or river) goes. And fishermen will stand by it from En-gedi to En-eglaim; it will be a place for spreading nets. Its fish will be of many kinds, like the fish of the Great Sea, exceeding many. But the water that flows out of the swamps and marshes will not be healed; it will be given to the salt pits. And on the bank of the river, on both sides, there will grow all kinds of fruit-bearing trees, whose leaves will not wither and whose fruit will not fail. Each month they will bear fresh fruit, because the water for them flows from the sanctuary. Their fruit will be for food, and their leaves for healing. Although the entire chapter is long, I wanted to present it all together so as not to interrupt the reader's understanding and divide the sequence of reading into parts that confuse the listener's comprehension. First, it should be said that in Hebrew it is called Nehel (נְהֵל), and in Greek it is called χειμάῤῥους. The LXX translated it as 'river'. Then, for Galilee, which is called Galila (גַּלְילָא) in Hebrew, Aquila interpreted it as θίνας, which signifies mounds of sand. Symmachus translated it as μεθόριον, which we can translate as 'border'. Symmachus also transferred to Arabia, an uninhabitable place; Aquila, low or flat; Theodotius, to Arabia. Let us therefore say what seems to us in each (case). That man who was the leader of Ezekiel, advises the prophet to look more carefully and see, and to attend to the hidden mysteries with the eyes of the mind. He calls the son of man, or in the form of the Lord Savior; for indeed Ezekiel is interpreted as strength, or the power of God: or certainly for the sake of the disturbance of human frailty; lest he forget his own condition, while great things are shown to him: and he leads him advisedly, and turns towards the edge of the stream, so that since he could not go across the middle depth, at least he may recognize those things which are on the banks. And when, he said, I turned myself, or he turned me, who was my guide and teacher; behold, on the bank of the torrent, or the river, there were many logs, or very many trees, on either side. This torrent, which is carried away like a torrent by the abundance of waters, and receives rain from the sky, as we mentioned in a previous lecture, is called a river by the LXX, because it has perpetual waters: not from rains collected here and there, but from a living and perpetual source. Of which river we read many things in the Holy Scriptures; but for now, a few things must be said, and firstly this: The rushing of the river gladdens the city of God (Psalm 46:4). And in another place: The river of God is filled with water, you have prepared their food, for so is your provision (Psalm 65:10). And again in the plural: The rivers have lifted up, O Lord, the rivers have lifted up their voices, with the voices of many waters: The mighty waves of the sea are amazing (Psalm 93:2-4). And in Isaiah: I will make a way in the desert, and rivers in the wasteland (Isa. 43:19). And in another place of the same book, more clearly: A glorious river will appear in Zion, flowing through a thirsty land (Isa. 44:3). Along this river, there were many trees on both sides of the bank, like the two instruments, the old and the new, enclosing the flowing river. These trees were abundant, or rather very numerous, perhaps those that Scripture mentions in paradise, abounding with various fruits; and the guiding preceptor and teacher tells the prophet: These waters that come forth, whether into the Galilee of the Gentiles, according to the Septuagint, or (more truly, as it is written in Hebrew) towards the eastern sand hills, and descend to the plains of the desert, or towards Arabia, will enter the sea, or the outlets of the sea, and the waters will be healed. We have already said that water signifies either the grace of baptism or the teaching of the Gospel. If they [the waters] go out from the threshold of the Lord's temple and hold to the Apostolic discipline, they make the barren and infertile hills of sand fruitful and make all the plains and deserts so irrigated that they contain within them the sacrament of the Jericho river (2 Kings 2): which Elisha, representing both the Gospel and the Apostles, healed with Gospel and Apostolic salt, to the extent that where there was barrenness and death before, there would be abundance and life. Not only did they heal the deserts, but they entered the Eastern Sea, namely the Dead Sea in which nothing could be alive, and the most bitter sea, which in Greek is called 'lake of asphalt,' that is, a pool of bitumen. And in a remarkable way, the dead waters are healed by the Gospel waters, which, because they have nothing alive in them, have acquired the name of death. For they did not know Him who says: 'I am the life and the truth' (John XIV, 6). And truly, according to the letter, nothing that breathes and can move can be found in this sea, because of its excessive bitterness: not even small snails, worms, eels, and other types of animals or snakes, whose bodies we can know better than their names. In fact, if the Jordan, swollen by the rain, carries fish there, they immediately die and float on the oily waters. Since these things, as plain speech attests, have no usefulness, even if they happen, as the foolish superstition of the Jews believes, when the river is healed by the spiritual understanding of the Lord, it will have many fish, and all things that the river reaches will live; so that fishermen will stand on the shores from Engedi to En-galim: the former name signifies the source or spring of a young goat, and the latter name signifies the source or spring of young calves. For Engallim is situated at the beginning of the Dead Sea, where the Jordan enters. And Engaddi is situated at its end and termination. But I think that the Dead Sea is the one about which Zacharias speaks: In that day living water will go out from Jerusalem, and half of it toward the eastern sea (Zach. XIV, 8). Daniel also agrees in these words: I saw, and behold, four winds of heaven were struggling on the great sea (Dan. VII, 2). And David: The remarkable waves of the sea (Psal. XCII, 4). And concerning the person of the Savior in the psalm: 'Come into the deep sea and the storm overwhelmed me' (Psalm 68:2). The king of Egypt is also called a dragon according to the same Ezekiel (Ezekiel 32), who dwells in the sea and stirs up the rivers like his horns. And again, 'This great and wide sea' (Psalm 104:25). As long as it does not receive the waters of the river or the torrent, it kills everything it contains. But the Lord, of whom it is said, 'He will strike and heal us after two days; on the third day we shall rise and live in his sight' (Hosea 6:2), He speaks in the same prophet Hosea: 'I have bound up Ephraim, I have taken him up in my arms, and they did not know that I healed them in their corruption' (Hosea 11:9); who was wounded for our sins, and weakened for our iniquities. The discipline of our peace was upon him, and by his lividness, we were healed (Isaiah 53:5). He himself, by his death, healed that sea which is the saltiest and dead by excessive bitterness, who says through Isaiah: The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, therefore he has anointed me; he has sent me to preach to the poor; he has sent me to heal the brokenhearted (Isaiah 61:1). Hence, he cries out through Jeremiah: Return, O apostate sons, and I will heal your regrets (Jeremiah 3:22). For the impatient people said, unable to bear the pain of their wounds any longer: Summer has passed, the harvest is over, and we are not saved. Then the Lord answered them: Is there no balm in Gilead? Is there no physician there? Why then is there no healing for the wound of my people? (Jeremiah 8:22) And Jeremiah himself cried out, saying: Heal me, O Lord, and I shall be healed; save me, and I shall be saved. (Jeremiah 17:14). Finally, the angels who were the guardians of the people of the Jews at that time, when the foolish multitude cried out and said, 'His blood be upon us and upon our children' (Matt. XXVII, 25); and, 'The veil of the temple was torn and all the Hebrew sacraments were revealed,' they answered the Lord's command and said, 'We have healed Babylon and she is not cured: let us abandon her' (Jerem. LI, 9), the city of confusion and vices. And Josephus also tells in his history that after the Lord was crucified and the veil of the temple was torn or the threshold of the temple was shattered, a voice was heard in the innermost part of the temple of heavenly powers, saying, Let us go out from these seats. This whole statement is not made in vain, but necessarily, because the Dead Sea, when the river of the Lord flows into it, is said to be healed. Above this sea, at Engaddi, there is an eye and a fountain of goats, which are always offered for sin at Engallim, the fountain of the calves, which are sacrificed to the Lord and imitate the calf carrying its horns and hooves, which is sacrificed at the altar in the figure of the Savior. They will be fishermen, to whom the Lord Jesus speaks: Come to me, and I will make you fishers of men (Matt. 4:19): of whom also Jeremiah says: Behold, I will send fishermen (Jer. 16:16). And there will be many species, or rather genera, of fish in the once dead sea. These fish were extracted to the right side at the command of the Lord by Peter, and there were 595, one hundred and fifty-three: so that because of their multitude, the nets were torn (John 21). However, those who have written about the natures and properties of animals, and have learned about fishing in both Latin and Greek languages, such as Oppian of Cilicia, a most learned poet, say that there are one hundred and fifty-three genera of fish, all of which were caught by the apostles, and nothing remained uncaptured, as both noble and lowly, rich and poor, and every kind of human is drawn from the sea of this world for salvation. Moreover, what follows shows indirectly that on its shores and in its marshes, or in those areas that extend beyond the shores, the waters will not be healed. It indicates that those who are not in Noah's ark will perish during the reign of the flood, and those whom the river does not touch will not receive healing. Instead, they will be given to salt flats, according to what is written: When a pestilence strikes, the foolish is wiser (Prov. 19:25). For the examples of the wicked educate the good. Whether they are given in the saltworks, according to what is written in the Gospel: Salt is good; but if the salt has lost its savour, wherewith shall it be salted? It is thenceforth good for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be trodden under foot of men (Matt. V, 13): so that they may forever lack fruits and vigor. This is also demonstrated by a city that is sprinkled with salt after ruin. But above the torrent or river, on its banks on both sides, every fruitful tree, or as all have translated with one voice, βρώσιμον (Al. βρῶμα), which gives food and nourishment, and which can be eaten, is called in the Hebrew language Machal () and nothing according to the Seventy shall grow old in it, but its fruits will be renewed daily, whether its leaves do not wither, and its fruit is not lacking; according to what is written in the first psalm. And he shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season; his leaf also shall not wither (Psalm 1:3). He says that each month it will produce its first-fruits, or as it is written in the Septuagint: Its fruit will give its first-fruits in its renewal; so that all the fruits of the believers may be first-fruits, and each month may be assigned to each apostle. But this will happen because its waters will come from the sanctuary: Lest we think it is the banks, or trees, or months that provide the abundance of so much fruitfulness, it states the causes and brings them forth: Because its waters will come from the sanctuary." } Therefore, it is not of the one who wills or of the one who runs, but of God who shows mercy (Rom. IX, 16). The chief among all these trees is the tree of life, which is understood as wisdom, about which it is written: The tree of life is for all who believe in it (Prov. III). And that which is said: Its fruits shall be for food, and its leaves for medicine, indicates the mysteries of divine books: one of which pertains to the letter, the other to the spirit: so that we may understand the simple words in the leaves, and the hidden meaning in the fruits. For just as the knowledge of the Scriptures leads to the kingdom of heaven, and provides us with the bread that says, I am the bread that came down from heaven (John. 6:41): so its leaves contain moral doctrine, and give healing, so that they may heal the wounds of sinners. For the leaves which are called Ale in Hebrew, because of the similarity of sound and meaning, were translated into Greek as ascension, which itself can be understood in such a way that after the nourishment of the fruits, we ascend to heavenly things through the admonitions of words.


<h2 id='tocuniq351'>(Vers. 13, 14.)</h2>

(Verse 13, 14.) Thus says the Lord God: This is the boundary where you shall possess the land in twelve tribes of Israel, for Joseph has a double portion. But you shall possess it each equally like his brother, to whom I raised my hand to give to your fathers: and this land shall fall to you as possession. Because we have said that Joseph has a double portion, it was transferred by the LXX, an increase of the portion. For Joseph means 'increase,' signifying an understanding of the matter and confusing the reader's mind. For when the tribe of Levi was subtracted and given over to temple sacrifices, there remained eleven tribes, of which Joseph was divided into two, Ephraim and Manasseh. They said to Joshua, son of Nun, 'Why have you given me just one portion and one share, when I am of such a great multitude and the Lord has blessed me?' To which Joshua responded: If you are a numerous people, go up into the forest and cut out for yourself the spaces in the land of the Perizzites and Rephaim, because the possession of the mountain of Ephraim is narrow for you. And again: Joshua said to the house of Ephraim and Manasseh: You are a numerous people and of great strength; you shall not have one portion, but you shall go to the mountain, and cut out for yourself and clear the spaces to dwell, and you shall be able to proceed further, when you have driven out the Canaanite, whom you say has iron chariots and is the strongest. We say this for a reason, because now the Scripture mentions Joseph, that is, Ephraim and Manasseh, having a double portion. However, each tribe receives equal portions according to its size, dividing the land not by the will of the one dividing, but by a lot that is in the power of the Lord. Finally, even Joshua himself, who was the one dividing the land, did not reserve a separate portion for himself, lest he appear to have chosen the best part; but he received Thamnath-sareh in the hill country of Ephraim from the leaders of all the tribes.


<h2 id='tocuniq352'>(Vers. 15 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 15 onwards) This is the boundary of the land on the north side, from the great sea, the route that goes to Ethalon, Sadada, Emath, Berotha, Sabarim, which is in the middle of Damascus and the border of Emath: the courtyard of Thicon (or house of Atthicon), which is near the borders of Auran (or Auranitis). And the boundary will extend from the sea to the courtyard of Enon (or Seraranan), the boundary of Damascus, and from the north to the north boundary of Emath, the northern side. In the description of the land of the Holy Land of the twelve tribes, by Joshua the son of Nun, and which is now commanded by Ezekiel, the difference is that there the land is divided among the tribes by lot, whereas here it is delegated by the command of the Lord. In the book of Numbers (Num. XXXIV), in which the entire promised land is divided into four regions in a brief discourse, the description of the Northern region is as follows: Starting from the great sea, they will begin at the northern boundary and go up to the highest mountain, from which you will come to Emath, and as far as the borders of Sadada. They will go along the borders of Zephrona and the town of Enam, also known as Aser Enon. And the Hebrews say that the northern boundary begins from the Great Sea, which borders Palestine, Phoenicia, and Syria, which is called Coele, and extends to the shores of Cilicia, and stretches through Egypt to Libya. As for the statement, 'The borders reach up to the highest mountain' (Num. XXXIV, 7), the same Hebrews believe that it either refers to Mount Amanus or Mount Taurus, which seems more likely to us. From there, it is said, you will come to Emath, which is now called Epiphania, with its name changed by the most cruel tyrant Antiochus: for it had the nickname Epiphanes. He says that they will go as far as the borders of Sadada, a place that is now located in the reading of Ezekiel, and will reach the borders of Zephrona, which is a city known today as Zephyrium in Cilicia. As for what follows: 'And the village of Enam,' which is written in Hebrew as 'Aser Enon,' or 'Enan,' this present place contains it. And for now, it suffices to briefly summarize the history, and to connect the description of both Numbers and Ezekiel together: so that the wise reader can understand which places they mentioned, whether they are the same, nearby, or different. Now that we have interpreted the names individually, let us follow the anagoge, and with the help of the Lord, let us discuss what seems to us in each case. Ethalon is interpreted as the beginning of mourning; Sadada, his side, understand it as from the side, not from the width; Emath, anger, which is called χόλος in Greek; Berotha, wells; Sabarim, the circuit of mountains; Damascus, the blood of a bag and a kiss, or a cup. But Thicon, the house or atrium, is interpreted by Symmachus as the central atrium, which leads to the borders of Auran. Therefore, Thicon signifies the wrath of Auranitides, which in Greek is translated as Auran, seventy times. Aser, however, Enon, which is the border of Damascus, is called the atrium of the fountain in our language. Therefore, the northern region begins from the great sea through the way of Ethalon, which means the cradle of sorrow, and through penance it comes to Sadada, where there is a declination on the side. For we understand the impending Emath, which is the wrath of God: or Emath, with the truth being discovered, the wells of Berotha are opened to us, which were dug by the princes, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: and after a long circuit, we reach the mountains of Sabarim, which are situated between Damascus, which means the blood of the sackcloth, and the border of Emath, as we have previously mentioned, the truth. For just as we turn away from impending evils through sorrow and avoid them by sidestepping, so after the blood and the bloody tunic of life, before we reach the borders of Emath, we go around and come to the mountains, of which it is written: Mountains surround it, and the Lord surrounds his people (Psalm 124:2). This place is called the court of Thicon, which means the middle court, as Symmachus interpreted, near the borders of Auran, which means anger, and let us say with the prophet: I will endure the anger of the Lord, for I have sinned against Him (Micah 4:9). And from the sea to the boundaries of Damascus, where the apostle Paul (Acts IX) saw the light in darkness from the Jewish fury and the shedding of blood of the Church, and taking up the garment of old persecution, he preached the Gospel in order to arrive at the courtyard of the eternal fountain, and being placed in the North, he grasped the boundary of truth.

<h2 id='tocuniq353'>(Vers. 18.)</h2>

(v. 18) Moreover, the eastern boundary shall be from the middle of Auram, and from the middle of Damascum, and from the middle of Galaad, and from the middle of the land of Israel, following the Jordan River into the eastern sea. (Vulgate adds: and also) That is the eastern boundary. As it is written in the Book of Numbers: From there they shall measure the boundaries against the eastern boundary from the town of Enan, that is, Aser Enon, as far as Sephama; and from Sephama the boundaries shall descend to Rebla, opposite the spring; from there they shall continue eastward to the Sea of Chenereth and extend along the Jordan River until they finally reach the sea. He had said before: And the border will be from the sea to Enon Aser, the border of Damascus (Num. XXXIV, 10, 11). From the northern end, that is, the court of Enan, the borders extend next to the book of Numbers to Sephama, which the Hebrews call Apama: and from Apama the borders descend to Rebla, which is now called Antioch in Syria. And so that you know that Rebla signifies this city, which is now the most noble in Coele Syria, it follows: Opposite the fountain, which is clearly signified as Daphne: from which fountain the aforementioned city enjoys very abundant waters. However, this hearth was built by Gnaeus Pompeius, who was the first to conquer Judea under Roman rule, with military force; and according to the fable of the poets, it acquired the name 'Daphne' because of the laurels and cypresses, which are very abundant trees in that place. From there, it is said, the boundaries extend towards the Eastern region to the Sea of Chinnereth, as far as the Sea of Tiberias. The body of water is called a 'sea' because it has about 600 fresh waters, according to the language of the Scriptures, which refer to collections of water as seas. And the borders, he says, will stretch as far as the Jordan, and they will be closed off at the sea, either the Dead Sea, or as others think, the tongue of the Red Sea, on whose shore Ahila is located, where the Legion now resides, and the Roman garrison. This is stated in the book of Numbers. But according to Ezekiel, in the midst of Auran: which is the city of Damascus in the wilderness, and in the midst of Galaad, which is connected to the hills of Mount Lebanon, it fell into the territory of Reuben and Gad and half the tribe of Manasseh, and it is behind Phoenicia and Arabia: to this mountain Jacob arrived, coming from Haran, and was captured by Laban (Gen. XXXI), about which Jeremiah also speaks: Galaad, you are my beginning of Lebanon (Jeremiah XXII), which Galaad, son of Machir, son of Manasseh, took from the region of the Amorites; and the boundary of this region is the Jordan River, and the Eastern Sea, which in this place they understand to be the Dead Sea, not the tongue of the Red Sea. Let us speak according to the tropology: After the boundaries of the North, through Ethalon, and Sadada, and Berotha, and also Sabarim, Thicon, and Auran, and Damascus, and the courtyard of Enon, it reaches the eastern region as far as Emath: from the midst of the anger of Auran, and from the midst of the blood of Damascus, namely of penance, and from the midst of Gilead, which is interpreted as revelation, or hill of testimony, it shows the hope of salvation after anger and penance: and from the midst of the land of Israel, which contains the vision of peace, it reaches the sweetest streams of the Jordan: which, far from the separated sea, achieves the light of the East, so that it ends with the river Jordan, which is interpreted as the stream of judgment, and the boundary of the East. But what is set forth in the LXX as φοινικῶνος, that is, of palm grove, is not found in Hebrew: for which reason we have translated it as metiemini: And there is a clear error, because, deceived by the similarity of the letters, they read Thamorru instead of Thamoddu.

<h2 id='tocuniq354'>(Vers. 19.)</h2>

(Verse 19.) But the southern plague extends from Thamar to the waters of contradiction (or to the waters of Mariboth, for this word 'contradictio' or 'διαδικασμὸς' means disputes). Also, Cades and the torrent, up to the great sea (Vulgate: plague). This is the 601st southern plague. It is written in the Book of Numbers as follows: It shall begin from the wilderness of Sin, which is near Edom, and it shall have borders against the eastern sea (some versions add 'saltiest'), which shall go around the southern plague by the ascent of the Scorpion, so that they pass by Senna and reach as far as the south to Kadesbarne. From there, the boundaries will go to a city named Addar, and they shall extend to Asemona. And the boundary shall go in a circuit from Asemona to the torrent of Egypt, and it shall end at the shore of the great sea (Num. 34:3-5). This briefly signifies (so that we do not seem to have passed from the exposition of Numbers to the very broad occasion of Ezekiel) to go from the solitude of Sin, which is near Edom, and to go around the boundary of the Red Sea, and through the ascent of Scorpio, and through Senna and Kadesh-barnea, and the courtyard of Addar, and to arrive from Asemona to the river of Egypt, which flows into the sea near the city of Rhinocorura. But this boundary of the southern, that is, the southern, region begins at Thamar, which is a city in the wilderness, which Solomon also built with marvelous works, and is now called Palmyra. And it is called Thamar in Hebrew, which in our language means "palm", until the waters of contradiction at Kadesh, which is certainly in the desert, and the river enters the great sea, which extends along the shores of Egypt and Palestine, and this is the southern region towards the South. After the plague, therefore, of the North and the East, when the sun of justice has risen for us, we receive the Midday, when their light is poured upon us from above, and, like Abraham, we enter into a feast (Gen. 19), and we are intoxicated with the wine that gladdens the heart of man (Ps. 103), like Joseph and his brothers (Gen. 43). But this possession begins, and these are the boundaries, namely, Thamar and the palm of victory over vices, up to the waters of contradiction. For virtue is always contradicted. Hence, also, the Jews who opposed Paul in the preaching of the Gospel claim that it is contradicted throughout the whole world. And in the Gospel we read Simeon saying: 'This child is destined for the falling and rising of many in Israel, and to be a sign that will be spoken against.' Every contradiction, however, is a holiness, which is interpreted as 'the holy place,' as the Psalmist says: 'The Lord will shake the wilderness of Kadesh.' This means that it did not originally have the holiness of the Lord but was shaken and moved in order to receive God as a guest, who says: 'On whom does my Spirit rest, except on the humble and quiet one who trembles at my words?' The desert of Cades, all the way to the Great Sea in the south, is a torrid region, as we have said before; it does not have rain from the land, but rather has rain collected from the sky, with a variety of different virtues.

<h2 id='tocuniq355'>(Vers. 20.)</h2>

(Verse 20) And the plague of the sea, the great sea from the border in a straight line, until you come to Emath, this is the plague of the sea. About which the Book of Numbers writes more clearly and briefly.
