But the western plague will begin from the great sea, and it will conclude at the very end, that is, from sea to sea: namely, to the torrent of Rhinocorura, which flows into the sea, up to the place which is opposite the city of Emath in Syria, about which we have spoken above. But the setting sun, according to the laws of tropology, is always in the sea: always in the salt and waves, where daily shipwrecks occur, and the deaths of the wretched, and the loss of riches and goods, and yet when we have endured all these with patience, we come straight to Emath, that is, to the truth of the Lord, who, having conquered persecutions, has promised us eternal rewards.

<h2 id='tocuniq356'>(Vers. 21 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 21 onwards) And you shall divide this land among yourselves according to the tribes of Israel, and you shall allot it as an inheritance to yourselves and to the strangers who have joined you, who have begotten children among you. They shall be to you as native-born among the children of Israel; they shall share in the inheritance with you among the tribes of Israel. However, in whatever tribe the stranger resides, there you shall give him his inheritance,' says the Lord God. By this chapter we learn (and it escapes the eyebrow of the Jews) that there is no division between the people of Israel and the Gentiles. For if the foreigners and aliens come with those who are from the people of Israel, that is, the natives, the land is divided; there is no doubt that it is the same inheritance of the people of the Gentiles and the people of the Jews: if, however, they convert to the worship of the God of Israel, which has the proper name Christian, having the Jews with the letter of the Law, and for us the spirit: and having them holding onto the outer forms, and for us the one who is written on the pages. And with Moses, the land is divided by lot; but here, as we have said, it is delegated by the judgment of the Lord: and there is one possession for the stranger and for the Israelite, and in each tribe an inheritance is given, at the command of the Lord God.

<h2 id='tocuniq357'>(Cap. XLVIII.—Vers. 1 seqq.)</h2>

(Chapter 48, verses 1 and following) And these are the names of the tribes, starting from the northern borders along the road to Ethalon: 603 Emath, Atrium Enon, the boundary of Damascus to the north near Emath, and from the east side there will be the sea, Dan as one tribe. And from the boundary of Dan to the eastern side up to the seashore, Aser as one tribe. And above the boundary of Aser from the eastern side up to the seashore, Nephthali as one tribe. And above the boundary of Nephthali from the east side up to the seashore, Manasse as one tribe. And over the territory of Manasseh from the east side to the west side, Ephraim one. And over the territory of Ephraim from the east side to the west side, Reuben one. And over the territory of Reuben from the east side to the west side, Judah one. The possession of the holy land is described, both according to the present prophecy of Ezekiel and according to the book of Numbers: now the possession of each tribe from the east side to the west side, that is, the sea, is described: and they first receive their borders from the north near the way of Ethalon going to Emath, the courtyard or Aser-Enon to the north border of Damascus near Emath, about which we have already spoken. But first, the tribe of Dan begins; secondly, Aser; thirdly, Nephthali; fourthly, Manasseh; fifthly, Ephraim; sixthly, Reuben; seventhly, Judah, which is on the left side, and the number seven is completed. Then the first fruits of the priests, and the Levites, and the sanctuary of the Lord in the midst, and the holy of holies. Also, the city itself is described on each side as a square, having four thousand and five hundred rods. The suburban areas of the priests and Levites are also described in order, along with the possession of the prince. And again, on the right side, there follow five tribes from the same direction of the East, up to the direction of the West, of which the first is Benjamin: the second is Simeon, having its own special possession, and not mixed with Judah as before: the third is Issachar: the fourth is Zebulun: the fifth is Gad: and there are three gates of the city on each side: and the name of the city is written on the gold plate on the high priest's forehead. We will discuss all of these in their proper places. And it should be noted that the forty-eight cities, which are given in the Book of Numbers to the Levites for dwelling with their suburbs, the names of which are given here, and the cities of refuge, are omitted: of which three are beyond the Jordan, namely Bosor, and Ramoth, and Gaulon, which are given to the two and a half tribes: and three are within the Jordan, namely Kadesh, and Shechem, and Kiriath-arba. For there was no need in the mystical description and the habitation of the saints and the perfect conversation for the aids of the fugitives to be described, which Israel still needed while situated in the land, and hastening to come to this city through many labors and dangers, and saying in each holy place: I am a stranger and a sojourner like all my fathers (Ps. 38:13). And in another place: I dwelt with them that make peace. My soul hath been long a sojourner.

<h2 id='tocuniq358'>(Vers. 8, 9.)</h2>

(Verse 8, 9.) And over the border of Judah from the east side to the west side, there shall be firstfruits which you shall separate, twenty-five thousand in length and in width: as every one of the parts from the east side to the west side, and there shall be a sanctuary in its midst. The firstfruits which you shall separate to the Lord, twenty-five thousand in length, and ten thousand in width. It is superfluous to discuss at length and to labor again on those things on which we have already labored, as if they were not spoken. After describing the boundaries of the seven tribes from East to West, the first fruits are mentioned; the width of which is said to be twenty-five thousand stadia: but the length, like the individual tribes, extends from East to the sea, the exact measurement of which is uncertain. Because the measurement of each tribe is not described. However, if the width is twenty-five thousand stadia, it is presumed that the length is much greater, as it is always greater than the width. In the middle of the sanctuary, however, there is placed beside the first fruits, which are separated for the Lord, a length of twenty-five thousand cubits and a width of ten thousand cubits. Reading this, I can say nothing else but that of the Apostle: O the depth of the riches of the wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments and how inscrutable His ways! (Rom. 11:33) And in another place: That you may be able to comprehend with all the saints what is the breadth and length and height and depth, to know also the surpassing knowledge and charity of Christ, that you may be filled unto all the fullness of God. (Ephes. 3:18) But the number twenty-five refers to the senses, of which it is said: You shall possess divine sense, and ten thousand refers to perfect and complete virtue, which reaches from the Ten Commandments of the Old Testament to the sacrament of the Gospel, as we have explained briefly before and as we will now remind you in part. For if you add one number to four, you will reach ten, and thus it will happen that the old Testament is contained within the new, and the new is expanded within the old.

<h2 id='tocuniq359'>(Vers. 10 seqq.)</h2>

(Vers. 10 seqq.) But these shall be the sacred precincts of the priests: toward the north, twenty-five thousand cubits in length and ten thousand cubits in breadth; toward the west, ten thousand cubits in breadth; toward the east, ten thousand cubits in breadth; and toward the south, twenty-five thousand cubits in length. The sanctuary of the Lord shall be in the midst of it. It shall belong to the consecrated priests, the descendants of Zadok, who kept my charge and did not go astray when the people of Israel went astray, as the Levites did. And there shall be firstfruits of the firstfruits of the land, a most holy offering, according to the boundaries of the Levites. The four boundaries of the sanctuary are described by the four cardinal points, which do not pertain to the people, nor to the common crowd, nor to the Levites, who are of lower rank, but specifically pertain to the worship of the priests: namely the North, and the West, and the East, and the South. And the order of the progress is narrated in parts, that by leaving the cold of the North, we may come to the West: so that vices may set for us and perish, and thence we may pass to the East: and with the rising of the sun of justice for us, we may come to the South, in which the most shining and perfect light is: and both from the North to the sea, and from the East to the South, let there be twenty-five thousand in length and ten thousand in width: so that the same measure of length and width may be preserved everywhere. But the sanctuary, that is, the Temple of the Lord, will be in the midst of the first fruits of the Priests, and will be surrounded on all sides with equal parts. And what he had said: These, however, will be the first fruits of the sanctuary of the Priests, so that all the Priests would not claim the possession of this place and the ceremonies to be observed with a common name, he specifically adds: The sanctuary will be for the descendants of Zadok, who is interpreted as just; of whom it is said: The Lord is just, and He loves justice; His countenance beholds uprightness (Psalm 10:8). Regarding Sadoc, the Seventy write Sadduc. This Sadoc speaks in the Gospel: For the Father does not judge anyone, but has given all judgment to the Son (John 5:22). And about this, under the mystical name of Solomon, the Prophet sings: O God, give your judgment to the king, and your justice to the king's son (Psalm 71:1). But those priests of the Lord will possess the sanctuary and will guard his ceremonies. They did not stray when the sons of Israel and the Levites strayed, as discussed earlier. They do not offer victims, but, content with the privilege of their name and the humility of their error, they always speak from the heart: I acknowledge my iniquity, and my sin is always before me (Psalm 50:4). May this priestly rank hear, and, overcome by the heat of the Arian persecution, and later embracing the true faith, may it submit its neck to power so as not to lack resources, even if it is not expelled from the temple, if it holds onto a certain shadow and image of its former name, and does not, lying on its back, belch out delights, as if it were spotless and pure, vomit out the nausea of its own incompetence and babbling barbarism. There will be, he says, first fruits from the first fruits of the earth for them, that is, for the priests: and for those who did not stray, when the children of Israel and the Levites strayed. But the firstfruits of the firstfruits, like the tithes of the tithes, and the most holy things, were to be given to the Levites, according to the boundary of the Levites. For the Levites have the areas adjoining the priests, but they cannot possess the center of it, that is, the territory itself.

<h2 id='tocuniq360'>(Vers. 13 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 13 and following) But the Levites shall also have a portion along the border of the priests, twenty-five thousand cubits in length and ten thousand cubits in width. The entire length shall be twenty-five thousand cubits and the width ten thousand cubits. They shall not sell any of it, nor exchange it, nor transfer the firstfruits of the land, for they are sacred to the Lord. The remaining five thousand cubits in width, along the twenty-five thousand, shall be for common use: for the city and for dwellings, and the city shall be in the middle of it. What we translate as profane, Aquila translated as βέβηλον, Symmachus and Theodotio as λαἳκὸν; the LXX said προτείχισμα which we can call an antemurale. Profane, however, is both common and secular, that is, common to all people and widely permitted to dwell. But what the LXX said, 'It shall not be measured, it shall not be taken away,' is clear that it means what we said, 'It shall not be changed, it shall not be transferred,' has no meaning. The possession of the Levites is also described, which is indeed adjacent to the boundaries of the priests, and has the same length and width for the multitude of Levites, which it has in the belly of the priests, but nevertheless uses its own terms, and understands itself to be separated from the priestly rank: to shake off the pride of the ministers, who, ignorant of the humility of their own status, swell up beyond the priests, that is, the elders, and consider dignity not based on merit, but on wealth. Certainly, the one who is the first among the ministers, because he preaches to the people individually and does not depart from the side of the Pontiff, considers it an injustice if he is ordained a presbyter. And he does not remember that he is a minister of the tables and widows, entrusted not only to the service and ministry of the priests, but also of the widows and the poor. And, he says, they shall not sell it, nor shall they exchange it, so that the eternal possession of the Levitical distribution may remain, nor shall the worth of dignity be overcome by price, nor shall we transfer it from one to another: because those things which are sanctified to the Lord belong not to those to whom they have been given, but to Him in whose name they are possessed. But the remaining five thousand in latitude, by twenty-five thousand, is understood to be in length, will be profane to the city: so that it is permitted for all the Israelites to dwell, and for all the common people; not because they are unclean, or because anything in the habitation of the Holy Land is considered contaminated, rotten and dirty; but because besides the priests, it is allowed for everyone to dwell in them. By this we understand that all the things we mention regarding the senses, that is, regarding bodily pleasures, which we experience through sight, hearing, touch, smell and taste, are profane and do not possess the sanctity of the temple, nor the priesthood, but of common worthiness. But the city will be in the middle, of which it is written: The stream of water makes the city of God joyful (Ps. 46:4). And: A city set on a hill cannot be hidden (Matt. 5:14), about which we will speak in what follows. Προτείχισμα, meaning a front wall, and διάστημα, meaning a space, which the Septuagint translated as suburban, we do not know what meaning they have in this place.

<h2 id='tocuniq361'>(Vers. 16.)</h2>

(Verse 16) And the measurements of its wall are five hundred and four thousand on the north side, and on the south side the same, and on the east side the same, and on the west side the same. And it says: 'And these are its measurements,' to be understood, of the city. For at the end of the previous chapter it is written: 'And the city shall be in the middle of it,' that is, of the land. And it begins firstly from the North and places the Southern side directly opposite. And it restores equality: so that it places the Western side opposite the Eastern side, that is, the sea: and each side of the city has four thousand five hundred rods; which approximately make eleven thousand five hundred and eighty-five paces, so that, all together, the city, as is written at the end of this book, has a circumference of eighteen thousand rods, which make forty-four thousand three hundred and forty paces. And the forty-fourth Psalm, which is titled 'For those who shall be changed,' and belongs to the sons of Corah, that is, to the beloved of the Lord, or as Aquila interpreted, 'For lilies,' and Symmachus 'For flowers,' contains the sacraments of the Church, which is the city of the Lord, of which it is written in the same psalm: The queen stood on thy right hand in gilded clothing, surrounded with variety (Ps. 44:10). And again: All the glory of the king's daughter is within (Ibid.,14): so that she may not be like whitened sepulchers on the outside, but may wash all things within and without with the sprinkling of martyrdom (Matt. 23)." } And when we have departed from the North, with a very cold wind, we cross to the South, and after the rising of the light of knowledge within us, we fear the setting of courage, not at all considering the past but the future, not having a certain possession of virtue, but saying daily in prayer: Lead us not into temptation, which we cannot bear (Matthew 86:13).

<h2 id='tocuniq362'>(Vers. 17.)</h2>

(Verse 17.) The suburbs of the city on the north side will be two hundred and fifty, and on the south side two hundred and fifty, and on the east side two hundred and fifty, and on the sea side two hundred and fifty. As for the suburbs, which are called in Hebrew Magras, they have again a distance of seventy cubits, that is, a space. And what is said, two hundred and fifty on each side, implies reeds, which are six cubits and one palm long, and on each side they make six hundred and seventeen and a little less steps, and in total one thousand reeds, having two thousand four hundred and sixty-eight steps: these distances surround the walls of the city in a circuit, so as to separate the city from the rest. From this it is clear that none of these spaces have the right to be used for the activities of the city and the collection of fruits, but they are intended to be free from the use and work of humans, so that the areas surrounding the city walls, the spontaneously growing shrubs and herbs, and everything else that the land produces, may have beauty.

But the remaining length along the holy district shall be three miles on each side. Ten thousand shall be to the east, and ten thousand to the west. It shall be equal in length to the tribal portions, with the holy district and the sanctuary in the middle of it. The produce of the city shall be for food for those who serve the city. And the ones who serve the city, those who come from all the tribes of Israel, shall cultivate it. The entire tribute of twenty-five thousand by twenty-five thousand shall be set apart as a holy district along with the property of the city. He wants the description of the holy city and its suburbs, as well as the remaining portion of the sanctuary to be divided into 10,000 plots in the East and another 10,000 plots in the West. These plots are to be assigned to those who work for the city for various purposes, whatever the city may need. The purpose is to ensure that the workers, who either build the city walls or restore the interrupted and ruined structures, are provided with a space of 610 (units) where they can sow and eat the produce of the land. This way, the city will have its own cultivation and well-maintained buildings, which can be repaired when needed." } And this (i.e., this thing) is not only contained in Israel or in the possession of the holy land with a spiritual mystery of the Church, but we also approve that it is happening under the Roman rule, so that certain villages belong to the rights of the cities, either by royal generosity or through the inheritances and donations of many, so that buildings are not gradually collapsing and public buildings, which are an ornament to the city, are not worn out by long neglect. But the workers, he says, or those who serve in the works of the city, will be from all the tribes of Israel, so that no one may consider themselves exempt from the work of the city, but all may eagerly build up the Church. We read that the same was done in the tabernacle, so that, according to the variety of their strengths, some would offer gold and silver, scarlet, fine linen, and purple, and various and diverse coverings; others would offer skins and hair of goats. And although the gifts were diverse according to the quality of their substance, there was one reward for those who gave: indeed, a greater reward for those who offered little, but more according to their strengths, as an example of the widow who, being poor, sent two small gifts into the treasury; she was praised by the judgment of the Lord, who said: Truly, I say to you, this widow, in her poverty, has contributed more than all the others. For all these others have contributed out of their abundance to the gifts of God, but she has given out of what she lacked, all the sustenance she had. Therefore, as we have said about the works of the city, it is necessary to briefly summarize that all the firstfruits of the sanctuary and the possession of the city, when calculated together, amount to two thousand four hundred and sixty-three, and a third part. For if twenty-five thousand reeds, which are six cubits and one palm in length, make ours, that is, Roman sixty, and one thousand, and six hundred and sixty-seven paces; there is no doubt that when multiplied by four, this exceeds the previous number. From which we understand that all things are to be understood spiritually, the possession of the Church is much wider than it once was in Judah, who did not even receive a share of the holy land: but they received forty-eight cities from each tribe, not the full possession but dwelling and habitation: so too the laity, although they have not reached the level of priesthood and Levite, nevertheless if they work in the city of the Lord, they partake of the holy land, the land of the meek, and the land of believers, of whom one said: I believe to see the goodness of the Lord, in the land of the living (Ps. 27:13).


<h2 id='tocuniq363'>(Vers. 21, 22.)</h2>

(Verse 21, 22.) But the rest will belong to the prince from all sides, whether from here or from there (Vulgate is silent whether from here or from there) of the firstfruits of the sanctuary and the possession of the city from the east boundary (or opposite face) of twenty-five thousand firstfruits until the eastern boundary, but also from the sea (Vulgate to the sea) from the east boundary (or opposite face) of twenty-five thousand until the boundary of the sea, likewise, it will be in the portion of the prince, and the firstfruits of the sanctuary and the sanctuary of the temple will be in its midst. Also, concerning the possession of the Levites and the possession of the city in the middle of the prince's territory, it will be between the border of Judah and the border of Benjamin, and it will belong to the prince. It has been previously discussed in more detail about this prince and how he would receive as much as one tribe alone. But now we learn something else, that whatever is left from all the tribes, only he will receive it, so that no tribe will fail to offer gifts to the prince, not from anywhere else, but from the firstfruits that serve the temple, the sanctuary, and the assigned parts of the city. For this is what it says: On the opposite side, or facing the eastern boundary of the twenty-five thousand offering, or facing the boundary of the sea, there shall be an offering between the seven and five tribes, and within that offering shall be the city and its suburbs, and in the midst of the city shall be the sanctuary of the temple. And concerning the possession of the Levites and the remaining possession of the city, whatever is left shall be assigned to the prince; and the furthest part shall belong to the seven tribes adjacent to the offering, the city, and the temple in the tribe of Judah; and the furthest part of the five tribes, with the same rights as described above, shall belong to the prince in the tribe of Benjamin, that furthest part itself. Since the sacraments of Holy Scripture are wonderful and worthy of contemplation, they should be more pondered than spoken about (Dan. XXXII). In the former division of the land beyond the Jordan by Moses, the land was divided among the two tribes of Reuben and Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh (Joshua, XIII). But across the Jordan, by Joshua son of Nun and Eleazar son of Aaron, Judah possessed the land to the south (Joshua, XV); and Ephraim and the half-tribe of Manasseh possessed the land to the north (Joshua, XVIII). Then, after sending scouts through each tribe and receiving a report on the description of the land, Joshua and Eleazar gave Benjamin, next to Judah from the south, and next to Ephraim and the half-tribe of Manasseh, their inheritance. The second tribe, Simeon, received their inheritance within the tribe of Judah, in order to fulfill what was written about Levi and Simeon: 'I will divide them in Jacob and scatter them in Israel' (Genesis 49:7). The third tribe, Zebulun, received Galilee, where Mount Tabor is located. The fourth [lot falls to] Issachar, where Jezreel is, as far as the Jordan. The fifth [lot falls to] Asher, as far as Mount Carmel, which overlooks the great sea, and Tyre and Sidon. The sixth [lot falls to] Naphtali, in Galilee as far as the Jordan, where Tiberias, which was once called Chinnereth, is. The seventh [lot falls to] Dan, as far as Joppa, where the towers of Ailon, and Selebi, and Emmaus, which is now called Nicopolis, are. Although we will read later that they took for themselves the city of Laish, in the tribe of Dan, which is now called Paneas. Since this is the case, and there is such a difference between the previous description of the tribes and the one currently held, let us consider how both in the present description and in the past, the city and the Temple were placed between the tribe of Judah and Benjamin. In the previous description, Judah was in the south and Benjamin was in the north, but now it is the opposite, with Judah in the north and Benjamin in the south. After them comes Simeon, then Issachar, and then Zebulun, and fifth is Gad, as it is stated in what follows; for it is written:

<h2 id='tocuniq364'>(Vers. 23 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 23 and following) And to the rest of the tribes, from the Eastern border to the Western border, Benjamin received one portion. And next to the border of Benjamin, from the Eastern border to the Western border, Simeon received one portion. And along the border of Simeon, from the Eastern border to the Western border, Issachar received one portion. And along the border of Issachar, from the Eastern border to the Western border, Zebulun received one portion. And along the border of Zebulun, from the Eastern border to the sea, Gad received one portion. And the border shall extend from Gad to the south toward the Negeb. Then the boundary shall go from Thamar to the waters of Meribath-kadesh, and from there along the Great Sea. This shall be the land that you shall allot as an inheritance among the tribes of Israel, and these are their portions, declares the Lord God. What is set for the one portion and for the other is always the same, either a part, or a possession, or an inheritance; though the Eagle and Symmachus interpret it as a neutral gender τὸ ὅριον, which means boundary. And it should be noted briefly, in the last five tribes, the tribe of Gad, which was mentioned in the previous description beyond the Jordan, is placed in the same area that Judas previously held, namely the southern regions, and its boundary stretches from Thamar to the waters of Meribah-kadesh, as an inheritance opposite the Great Sea. Thamar itself, which we have already mentioned, is now called Palmyra, and was built by Solomon. For in Hebrew, a palm is called "Thamar," and some believe that it got this name because there are many palm trees there. And what follows: Even to the waters of contradiction at Cades, the inheritance against the great sea; for which seventy translated from Theman, and the water of Mariboth, (also called Marimoth) at Cades, the inheritance even to the great sea, it must be observed in Hebrew that the same word Nehela is ambiguous, and can mean both inheritance and torrent: and here it should be taken more as torrent than inheritance. For this is the torrent that enters the great sea of Rhinocorura, as we have already said. But the city which in the book of Joshua is called Kadesh-Barnea is in the desert, which extends to the city Petra. However, Mariboth, which is interpreted as 'contradiction', is not the name of a place, as many believe, but of waters, in which the people contradicted the Lord, and Moses offended God, as the Psalm says: They provoked him at the waters of contradiction, and Moses suffered for their sake (Ps. 105:32). And the entire inheritance of the holy land is bounded on the southern side by the borders of Egypt, Rhinocorura, and the river. And because Gad is interpreted as temptation, we pass from his possession of palm trees to the waters of contradiction until Kadesh, which is interpreted as holy, so that we may understand that even after the victory of the world we must be careful and always in fear, and remember that verse: Temptation is the life of men on earth (Job. VII, 1); and to attain holiness, despite the adversaries who oppose, and to obtain victory in such a way that we may contemplate the nearby stream full of rain.


<h2 id='tocuniq365'>(Vers. 30 seqq.)</h2>

(Verse 30 and following) And going out of the city from the Northern side, you will measure five thousand and four thousand. And the city gates from the tribes of Israel: three gates from the North. Gate of Reuben, one; gate of Judah, one; gate of Levi, one. And on the Eastern side, five thousand and four thousand, and three gates. Gate of Joseph, one; gate of Benjamin, one; gate of Dan, one. And on the Southern side, five thousand and four thousand you will measure, and three gates. Porta Simeonis, one: porta Issachar, one: porta Zabulon, one. And on the West side, five hundred and four thousand, and their gates three. Porta Cad, one: porta Aser, one: porta Nephthali, one: around eighteen thousand and the name of the city from that day, and the Lord is there. The measurement of the city, which has on each side four thousand and five hundred rods, was mentioned earlier: which makes eighteen thousand rods, as is also stated in the present chapter, that is, forty four thousand paces, and three hundred and forty paces. Now it is written that each side was eleven thousand and eighty-five paces, and that there were three gates, which Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotus call διεξόδους, and the Seventy call διεκβολὰς: we have interpreted them as exits and entrances of the city. And first, it should be briefly noted that the same tribes were encamped in a circle around the tabernacle, so that on the east side were Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun, the sons of Leah; and on the south side were Reuben, Simeon, and Gad, the two sons of Leah, and the third son of Leah's maidservant Zilpah. But towards the west are Ephraim, Manasseh, and Benjamin, indeed the two sons of Rachel; for Joseph, from the tribe of Levi, which is appointed for sacrifices, was divided into the two tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh. But towards the north are Dan, Asher, and Naphtali, of whom the first and third sons are the sons of Bilhah, Rachel's maidservant, and the second son is the son of Zilpah, Leah's maidservant, who are of lowly birth and positioned towards the north, for they were born from the stock of maidservants who were in contention with each other. According to the Book of Numbers and the description of the tabernacle, which was dictated by God to Moses (Num. XXXIV). But our city, which is the city of the great king, whose architect and builder is God, has another description of the tribes in the holy land, and the measurement of the city and the order of possession, and the boundaries of each tribe. For first, in opposition to the blows of the North Wind, three gates, or exits, of the city are set up, of which Ruben is the first-born, and Judah the founder of the royal line, and Levi, upon whose name, nothing is said in the description of the Tabernacle and the sacred things: so that possessing the first-born, we may despise the cold of the North as if it were a royal and priestly race. Secondly, towards the East, are Joseph, Benjamin, and Dan: both sons of Rachel, and one of Bilhah her maidservant. To the south, Simeon, Issachar, and Zebulun, who are the three sons of Leah. Then to the west, Gad, Asher, and Naphtali: the first two being the sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid, and the third being the son of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid. Who is wise and understands these things: a person who understands will recognize them? For the ways of the Lord are right, and the righteous will walk in them; but transgressors will stumble in them (Hosea 14:10). I believe that these twelve gates, or exits, have been assigned to each tribe according to the quality of their merits and virtues, under the names of the Apostles and the Patriarchs: about which it is more clearly written in the book of Revelation of John, and many mysteries of the divine Scriptures testify (Revelation 21). And it is necessary that such a city hold within its walls eighteen thousand calamities: under which number, and in the twenty-second psalm, the natural law is written, and the grace of the Gospel is described: by which the Church, that is, the city of the Savior, is built. The name of this city will not be Jerusalem, which means vision of peace, but Adonai Sama (( Al. Adonaisan et Adonaisamia)) (), which is translated into the Latin language as Lord is here, who shall never depart from it, as he departed from the former people saying to the disciples: Arise, let us go hence (John XIV, 31). And to the Jews: Your house shall be left to you desolate (Matthew 23:38), but may it have eternal possession, and let it be a possession to itself, promising the same to His disciples: Behold, I am with you always, even to the end of the world (Matthew 28:20).
